title: San Francisco's Chinese Resist School Busing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 The old Sun Sing Theater on Grant Avenue, the gaily lighted, touristchoked heart of Chinatown, was jammed. Its 800 seats had filled up early, mostly with seriousfaced Chinese women and squirming youngsters. Scores of latercomers stood patiently in the aisles and along the walls.

title: Ackley Calls for Compact On PayPrice Stabilization
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Gardner Ackley, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, called today for a social compact among labor, business and other groups to support a permanent system to stabilize wages and prices after the 90day freeze expires.

title: Superstar and On the Town Start OutWith a Past
description: Jesus Christ Superstar and On the Town, the two biggest musicals of the season, went into rehearsal this week. The two shows, poles apart in concept land design, have one main thing in common: a past. Superstar is based on a record. On the Town is a revival of the 1944 musical. In each case the show has a smash hit to live up to.

title: LEMUEL A. HULL
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Aug. 31 Lemuel A. Hull, retired vice president of Air Reduction Company and president of the National Carbide Corporation, one of its subsidiaries, died here on Monday. He was 83 years old and lived in nearby Belleair.

title: TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31The top political and business characters in Tokyo are playing down the AmericanJapanese financial crisis. Their nightmare seems to be that the dollaryen problem, with elections coming up in both Japan and the United States next year, will create political and psychological problems of the most serious nature.

title: U.S. Trade Moves Held Hurtful to Italy
description: Italy faces a severe crisis in industry and trade unless it can get some relief from the surcharge on imports imposed by the United States, it was predicted here yesterday by Giulio Andreotti, parliamentary leader of the Christian Democratic Party. Thousands of workers will lose their jobs, he said, and hundreds of small Manufacturers will be forced out of business.

title: British Give Version
description: LONDON, Aug. 31The Ministry of Defense maintained tonight that the two British army vehicles had been fired on by machine guns and rifles from within the Irish Republic.

title: Hall Gains in Mallory Racing
description: SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 31Graham Hall, a New York schoolteacher and yacht writer, moved closer to the lead in the regatta for the Clifford D. Mallory Cup off Padanaram Harbor and the New Bedford Yacht Club today.

title: SCHOOL BOARD GETS DRUGS PLAN TONIGHT
description: The Board of Education is expected to approve tonight a contract to receive $4,731,000 from the Addiction Services Agency of New York City for the purpose of developing a drugabuse prevention program vin 94 public high schools.

title: 30 Members of East Side Club Robbed by Band of Masked Men
description: A band of masked robbers last night walked into a private East Side club, the Town Club, and held about 100 members at gunpoint, robbing more than 30.

title: WOODALL OF JETS SUFFERS FRACTURE OF HIS LEFT MIST
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 31  The Jets now have two injured quarterbacks, but at least Al Woodall is expected to be available soon, surely for the National Football League season opener.

title: Bridge: An OverSuspicious Declarer Can Be Own Worst Enemy
description: Defenders occasionally depart from the normal rules of defensive play, through ignorance, from motives of low cunning or for the sheer hell of it. But the declarer who is constantly suspicious of his opponent's plays will be a loser in the long run.

title: Liberia Molds Farm Worker In Death of Peace Corpsman
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 31 (ReutersA farm worker, Robert Toe, has been arrested in the murder of an American Peace Corps volunteer, Marsha Lynn Ragno, 22 years, old, of Winthrop Harbor, Ill.

title: GoldDollar System Favored
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Japan would like to see the international monetary system restored to the dollargold basis on which it operated before President Nixon suspended the dollar's convertibility to gold. Multilateral parity adjustments would he made to accomplish this, Finance Ministry officials said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: By the end of the first quarter, even the most optimistic Jet fan had banished from his mind every fanciful idea he once had of planning a trip to New Orleans in January in order to watch his beloved heroes perform in the Super Bowl. He was already muttering despairingly, Is this trip necessary? while deciding that it wasn't, because the Jets obviously would not be involved in any postseason festivity.

title: PANTHER RAID CASE GETS A NEW JUDGE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 31The case of Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County's chief prosecutor, and 13 other law enforcement officers, was assigned today to another Cook County Circuit Judge and entered a new phase in its disputed movement toward a trial.

title: U.S. Aide Is Found Dead In Embassy in West Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Donald Leahy of Chicago, a State Department employe attached to the embassy in Santa Isabel, Equatorial Guinea, was found dead in the chancery yesterday, the State Department reported today.

title: New York Cricketers Win
description: A New York cricket side defeated the Sheffield Cricket Lovers Society of England by eight wickets, yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. New York scored 104 runs for two wickets to Sheffield's 103.

title: Budget Expert Named to Direct State's City Inquiry
description: Stuart N. Scott, the chairman of the new state commission that will investigate New York City operations, announced yesterday the appointment of Howard F. Miller, budget expert, as the director of the commission's staff.

title: Outbreak of Fires Brings Destruction In Italian Forests
description: ROME, Aug. 31A chain of forest fires is afflicting Italy, destroying millions of trees on the gentle hills of Tuscany, along the pine groves of the long coast and in the sundrenched orchards of Sicily.

title: CARDS WIN BY 21 ON SIMMONS'S HIT
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31Nolan Ryan struck out 12 batters in six innings tonight but his virtuoso performance had long since ended when the St. Louis Cardinals rallied in the ninth inning for a 21 victory over the New York Mets.

title: Israeli Envoy Criticizes the U.S. for Delaying Decision on Jets
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 31Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, said today that Washington was committing an error in postponing a decision on Israel's request for Phantom fighterbombers.

title: Census Bureau Finds Lost River's Not Lost
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Lost River, Idaho, is no longer lost, the Census Bureau acknowledged today.

title: Apprentice Has a Day to Forget
description: It wasn't Nathan Plotkin's day at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange posted their second consecutive decline yesterday in continued slow trading.

title: Shell Oil Ends Allowances
description: The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it has withdrawn all competitive price allowances granted to dealers and jobbers in depresssed areas of its Eastern and Central marketing regions.

title: Profit Is Increased By Seaboard Coast
Pontiac to Integrate, Despite Bus Bombings
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 31Pontiac school officials said today they would carry out courtordered integration school busing plan despite bomb explosions that destroyed 10 school buses last night.

title: Extra Shirt Pocket Is Allowed as Basis For Price Increase
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 31A manufacturer who adds a pocket to a shirt or who sews a monogram onto a garment will be permitted to raise prices, the Office of Emergency Preparedness told a meeting of producers and retailers here today.

title: John Leary Jr. Dies at 64; Columnist in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 31 John J. Leary Jr., newspaper columnist and retired city official, died of a heart ailment early yesterday in the hospital of St. Raphael. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: Merger New
description: The First Florida Bancorporation and United Bancshares of Florida, Inc., both important holding companies in that state, announced yesterday that they were negotiating a possible merger. The merger proposal, assuming the terms are finally agreed to by the companies, would be the first involving substantial bank holding concerns in Florida to, be presented to the regulatory authorities for approval.

title: More Money Discovered In Cache in Illinois Garage
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 31 (AP)  Twelve more boxes stuffed with uncashed checks and money orders made out to Paul Powell, the late Secretary of State, have been discovered in the garage of an apartment building in Springfield, a special Illinois Assistant Attorney General announced today.

title: Questions and Answers by Cost of Living Council on Issues in Freeze
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 31Following is the Ilth set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: How World War Two Began: III
description: MOSCOWBy Aug. 15, 1939, the tripartite negotiations had reached deadlock because of Prime Minister Chamberlain's and Premier Daladier's hostility to the Soviet Union.

title: Refusals on Insurance Narrowed by New Law
description: New Yorkers can no longer be refused insurance policy renewals without a specific reason in writing under a new law that goes into effect today.

title: 2.14% Average Rise Listed In Retail Prices for July
description: Prices advertised by representative department, specialty and general merchandise stores were on the average 2.14 per cent higher in July than in the yearearlier month, the Bureau of Advertising said yesterday, continuing a trend of the last few months.

title: New Bolivian Regime Is Recognized by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)The United States extended recognition today to the new military government of Bolivia, headed by Col. Hugo Banzer Suarez.

title: Britain's Penny Loses Status
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP)Britain's bronze penny, in circulation since the 18th century, will no longer be legal tender after midnight tonight, nor will the octagonal threepenny piece, introduced in 1937. Both are victims of Britain's switch to decimal currency.

title: YIELDS POST DROP IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The credit markets were called on by business and government yesterday to absorb a flood of new, fixedincome securities, and the response, by and large, was enthusiastic enough to push most interest rates down.

title: Stockholders on the Bench
description: Presidents are always urged to fill vacancies on the United States Supreme Court as quickly as possiblenot only because of the heavy workload on the justices but because possible tievotes are undesirable. Now we have the prospect of at least five major cases, all involving big business, having to be decided by less than a full complement of justices because members holding stock in the affected companies are withdrawing for reasons of possible conflict of interest.

title: Service for Lou McGarity
description: A memorial service for Lou McGarity, the jazz trombonist, who died do Alexandria, Va., last Saturday, will be held Sept. 12 at 7:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. The service will he conducted by the Rev. John G. Gensel, associate pastor.

title: London Stage: Fun of Sartre's Kean
description: LONDONThe theater is a place where ill humor all too often poses as wit, and farce is frequently the merest contemptuous excuse for a comedy's lack of life or credibility. It is as a consequence a special pleasure to encounter a comedy of style and breeding, and, most difficult of all, a period play at that.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyWhen things go wrong in Turkey, the army intervenes. Even a hundred and fifty years ago, if the fanatical Janizary Corps upset its regimental cauldrons, this betokened a change of administration.

title: Western RollerCoaster a Hit in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31In this land of dancing bears, expert gymnasts and champion weightlifters, ordinary Russians came by the thousands today for a final Westernstyle fling at the international carnival in Gorky Park before school starts tomorrow.

title: Steel Men Go to Capital To Study Japanese Plan
description: Senior executives of the American steel industry will be in Washington today to study a new proposal by Japanese steel companies that would limit their shipments to this country for three years, beginning Jan. 1, 1972.

title: Giants Asking Waivers On Baker, Two Others
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 31 (AP)  The New York Giants placed John Baker and Claude Brumfield, linemen, on waivers today.

title: The Mikheyev Case
description: Thousands of Soviet citizens from diplomats and scientists to ordinary seamen have defected in the last halfcentury. Normally the Soviet press ignores these flights, except when a person of unusual prominence such as Stalin's daughter is involved.

title: Cuba Is Halting Refugee Airlift to Miami
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The State Department announced today that Cuba has advised the United States of her desire to terminate the airlift that in the last six years has brought nearly a quartermillion Cuban refugees to this country.

title: GROUND FIGHTING IN VIETNAM DROPS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 (AP)Ground fighting diminished across South Vietnam today, but United States bombers pounded the country's northern front and inside the demilitarized zone.

title: Postal Unions Ask Court to Bar Freeze On Members' Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Postal unions asked a Federal District Court today to prohibit the United States Postal Service from holding back scheduled wage increases in accordance with the 90day wageprice freeze imposed by President Nixon.

title: Man in the News
description: A week ago last Friday, a tall, portly, baldish man sat in Governor Rockefeller's office on West 55th Street and listened as the Governor continued to outline a job proposal he had broached the previous day on the telephone. As the Governor's visitor recalls the conversetion: He went right to the heart of the matter, saying that there are eight million people and they are damned important and we have to determine what, if anything intelligent, we can do to better their lives and to provide better services for them and so forth.

title: Where They Encourage Squeezing the Tomatoes
description: WASHINGTONThe oldfashioned stall markets here, which seemed so lifeless just a few years ago, are bustling these days as shoppers wander from stall to stall to comparison shop and greet friends.

title: Cabinet Units Split On Plan to Merge 2 Major Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Nixon Administration was split today over the proposed merger of American Airlines and Western Airlines.

title: No Postponement
description: The headlines change, but the stubborn facts endure. The nation's most persistent domestic difficulties are poverty and the financial crisis of local governments. The racial issues are interwined with both these problems because a disproportionately large number of blacks, Indians, Puerto Ricans and Mexican Americans live in poverty, and their move from the countryside to the cities has contributed to the financial pressure on local governments.

title: Parasitic Foes of Gypsy Moth To Be Bred for U.S. in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31New Jersey has been given the task of supplying parasites to combat the gypsy moth in all areas of the country where the forest pest has become established

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place: Stock Trader Cites Conflicts
description: Talk to Frederick B. Taylor, a delightfully abrasive New Englander, about market research, and he'll give you an earful. Here's a man who has spent 45 of his 65 years in the investment game, and he hasn't been sitting around spinning mental cobwebs.

title: BINGHAM CHARGED IN PRISON DEATHS
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 31 Stephen M. Bingham, a 29yearold lawyer, was formally charged today with murder in the deaths of two convicts and three guards at San Quentin Prison.

title: F.D.I.C. Names Official
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that Edward J. Roddy had been promoted to director of its division of bank supervision, effective today. He succeeds John L. Flannery, who left the F.D.I.C. to join the StateDime Savings Bank in Hartford.

title: U.S. Astronauts Expected to Use Salyut
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31American and Soviet space planners are working under the premise that joint space ventures are possible in the near future and that the first would see American astronauts boarding a Russian Salyut space laboratory.

title: Yonkers Furrier Shot Dead By Woman Taking a Coat
description: YONKERS, Aug. 31  The 62yearold owner of a South Broadway fur shop was shot three times and killed this afternoon by a woman who then escaped with at least one fur coat which he had been showing her, the Yonkers police reported.

title: Payments Surplus In Japan Declines; 495Million in July
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Japan had a $495million surplus in her balance of international payments for July, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Cerf Rites Draw Friends of 2 Worlds
description: Many of the sober people of publisher's row allowed a smile and the funny people of show business cried a little in a subdued goodby to Bennett Cerf, the man who relished life in the two worlds.

title: Newcombe Opening US Tennis Today
description: The defections of top pro fessionals, the return of Gorgeous Gussie, a picket line and some promising new faces mark the start of the United States Open tennis championships today at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: GEORGES L. PEISSEL
description: ROME, Aug. 31 (AP)Georges Louis Peissel, director of external relations and general services of the United Nations world food program, died today in his office at the headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization. He was 61 years old.

title: U.S. Ending Gas Transfer
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP)The Government of the Ryukyu Islands said today that the United States Army planned to complete the transfer of poisonous gas to Johnston Island from Okinawa by Sept. 10, the Kyodo news service reported. It said American military authorities had told the Ryukyu Government that they still had to remove 700 to 800 tons of lethal nerve gas from Okinawa.

title: Interim Mayor of Jersey City Is Receptive to a Draft to Run
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 31 Mayor Charles K. Krieger, who said when he was appointed interim Mayor here 26 days ago that under no circumstances would he seek election in November, began talking like a possible candidate today.

title: ABRAM MATTES
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 31 Abram Mattes, who retired in 1966 as deputy commissioner of Purchase after 50 years with the New York City administration, died today in Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Leg of North Sea Oil Race Over
description: OSLO, NorwayThe first phase of the international race for North Sea offshore oil will end today when prospecting groups turn back 25 per cent of the acreage granted them by the Norwegian Government.

title: About Motor Sports
description: To Mark Donohue and other members of Roger Penske Racing, the impossible is only a minor inconvenience. While practicing last Thursday for the California 500 at Ontario Motor Speedway, Donohue lost conirol and rammed the retaining wall. He was uninjured, but his McLaren M 16Offenhauser was an untidy mess of bits and pieces. With no fuss and a mini mum of cursing their luck, the Penske crew got the car ready for Saturday's qualifying session.

title: Yen Floats Higher Against the Dollar
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31The yen floated slightly higher today and was quoted at 339 yen to the dollar, representing a 5.8 per cent upward revaluation of the yen.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Out of the distress that gripped Wall Street last year have come some strident calls for reform and it is only logical that the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Street's chief Government regulator, should become deeply involved in whatever reforms come about. Neverthe.less, some leaders of the securities industry are frankly surprised at the extent to which the Federal agency has promised to delve into affairs and issues that traditionally have been left to the purview of the New York Stock Exchange and other selfregulatory bodies.

title: Buffalo on the Turnpike?
description: After the late Percival Baxter donated to the State of Maine the magnificent Katandin park area which bears his name, he stubbornly resisted proposals to improve facilities at the park in ways he feared would spoil its wilderness character. Mr. Baxter was particularly adamant in opposing suggestions to pave and broaden the tworut rud that snaked through the park, barely leaving room for two cars to pass.

title: JERSEY AREA GETS ACCORD ON SEWAGE
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 2The city and nine Morris County communities are preparing ordinances aimed at creating a regional sewerage authority to rid the Rockaway River of pollution.

title: Police Deride and Fear Investigators
description: They are called shooflys by policemen, usually with derision, but sometimes with fear of what these undercover police officers with wideranging powers might discover.

title: Poll Shows Both Old and Young Are Cool to Contemporary Art
description: PARIS, Aug. 31Young people dislike contemporary art almost as much as do their elders, according to a new study.

title: KOREANS' PARLEY SET FOR SEPT. 20
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 31The South Korean Red Cross agreed today to hold preliminary talks with the North Korean Red Cross on Sept. 20 to arrange a conference on the problem of families separated in the two parts of Korea.

title: Paramount Cuts Off Filming in City
description: Paramount Pictures has canceled plans to film two major movies in the city and will shift the projects to other, undisclosed cities, attributing the action to a deadlock in contract negotiations with a local trade union. Pending contract agreement, the company will schedule no further local production.

title: Rogers Defends New Nixon Policy
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Secretary of State William P. Rogers defended President Nixon's new foreign policy today as necessary to meet the changing conditions of the world in the nineteenseventies.

title: Pentagon Broadens Religious Guideline For War Objectors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Pentagon revised its directive on conscientious objectors today to include deeply held moral or ethical beliefs as grounds for discharge as specified in a 1970 Supreme Court decision.

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yacovelli Said to Succeed Colombo in Mafia Family
description: Joseph Yacovelli is giving the orders in the Mafia family said to have been headed by Joseph A. Colombo Sr., according to underworld informants and Federal and state agents.

title: Denmark to Vote Sept. 21
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  Denmark will hold a general election Sept. 21, Premier Hilmar Baunsgaard announced in Parliament today.

title: STATE TO STUDY WELFARE IN CITY
description: State Welfare Inspector General George V. Berlinger yesterday advised, Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator, that he would shortly begin an investigation of the city's failure to prosecute welfare frauds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Codd, Discussing Kahane, Warns on Carrying Rifles
description: Chief Inspector Michael J. Codd warned yesterday that anyone carrying a loaded rifle or a shotgun either in a car or on foot would be arrested.

title: 5.5METER TITLE CAPTURED BY FAY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 Ernest Fay of Houston captured the national 5.5meter sailing championship with his Sundance today.

title: H. ALLEN WILLIS DIES; G.M.A.C. EXECUTIVE
description: H. Allen Willis, who retired last year as executive vice president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died of a heart attack Monday near his home in Austin, Tex. He was 65 years old and formerly lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Catholics Struggling to Prevent New Closings in School System
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31St. Martin de Porres High School has come to mean a great deal to black people on the West Side of Detroit, sending 90 per cent of its graduates to college last year. To keep it open, the people are selling bread and milk and candy and shares in an insurance plan.

title: Manufacturer Inventories Dropped Slightly in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Manufacturers' inventories declined slightly in July but shipments dropped even more, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Roundup: Yastrzemski Quiets Orioles, Hooters
description: There was a time Cart Yastrzemski was a hallowed name in Boston baseball. No one would have thought to boo the 32yearold threetime American League batting champion and youngsters were proud to wear Yaz Tshirts and purchase anything he endorsed.

title: PRESIDENT DENIES ARMSAID PLANS TO SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31President Nixon refused today to disclose to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the Administration's long  range plans for foreign military assistance.

title: OTB Opens Short Cut to Belmont With New Times Square Shop
description: Howie the Horse galloped into Times Square yesterday, giving a retired seaman named Fred Trench and hundreds of other Broadway horseplayers an immediate short cut to Belmont Park.

title: Football Injuries Are Linked to Synthetic Turf
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 31Just before the University of Washington football team begins practice these days, groundskeepers soak the artificial grass with hoses tc minimize the risk of knee and head injuries to play ers on the synthetic turf.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BOOK OP NIGHTMARES. By Galway Kinnell. 75 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $4.50.

title: Richardson Says He Agrees With Nixon on Busing
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 31Elliot L. Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, asserted today that he was in total agreement with President Nixon's policy of limited school busing. He denied that he had considered resigning his post after Mr. Nixon publicly repudiated A desegregation plan drawn up by Mr. Richardson's own agency.

title: Commissioner Is Calm in Hectic Days
description: Through it all, through those two days that convulsed the Police Department, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy moved with the hours of change caimly, with order, as of the whole program had been put into a computer and printed out.

title: GOVERNOR PICKS 6 FOR NEW AGENCY
description: Governor Rockefeller has selected six of the seven members who will form the controversial state agency that comes into being today to regulate development of the sixmillion acre Adirondack State Park.

title: Pennsylvania Tax Signed
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 31 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp signed into law toady a 2.3 per cent state income tax the second tax he has signed in six months.

title: Policewoman, Saved by Misfire, Promoted to Detective by Murphy
description: A 28yearold policewoman, attacked and threatened with death in a Bronx alley by three men, during an undercover narcotics investigation Monday night, was promoted yesterday to the rank of thirdgrade detective.

title: MONTE CARLO for 1972, Chevrolet's personal luxury ear
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31The Chevrolet division's 1972 models look a lot like last year's except for a new heavier bumper that will preserve cars in a 5mileanhour crash. Despite the few changes the company predicts that it will sell a record 3 million cars in the upcoming sales year.

title: Yanks and Mets Beaten By Single Runs in Ninth
Greek Premier ls Planning To Develop New Leaders
description: ATHENS, Aug. 31.  Premier George Papadopoulos, who last week cemented his personal control over Greece, appears to have embarked upon a slow process of producing his own elite.

title: Rondon Risks Title Oct. 16
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 31 (AP) Vicente Rondon of Venezuela, the World Boxing Association lightheavyweight champion, agreed today to defend his title on Oct. 16 against Gomeo Brennan at the Miami Beach Convention Hall.

title: Charles M. Sternhell, 55, Dies; An Executive of New York Life
description: Charles M. Sternhell, executive vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, died of cancer yesterday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 55 years old and lived at 187 Canterbury Gate, Lynbrook, L. I.

title: U.S. Banker Expected to Get U.N. Development Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31Rudolph A. Peterson, former president of the Bank of America, was reported today to be virtually certain to replace Paul G. Hoffman as director of the United Natins Development Plan when Mr. Hoffman retires at the end of the year.

title: OffTrack Littering
description: A week ago the Mayor's Council on the Environment asked for stern measures against business firms which, by illegal distribution of advertising throwaways, contribute to littering the city's streets. The Council's prescription: Maybe we should fine corporate executives who authorize the campaign. They are the environmental criminals.

title: BURGER CAUTIONS LOWER TRIBUNALS ON BUSING ORDERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that judges in lower courts were misreading the Supreme Court's opinions if they were ordering busing of pupils in the belief that the Court required racial balance in every school.

title: WORTV Altering Format and Time Of Its News Show
description: WORTV will move its halfhour, weeknight news broadcast on Channel 9 from 7:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M., switching to a new format in which Tom Dunn will replace Bill Ryan as anchorman.

title: Campbell Also Recalling Batch Of Vegetarian Vegetable Soup
description: The Campbell Soup Company, which is recalling chicken vegetable soup in 16 states because of contamination by deadly botulin toxin, announced yesterday that it was recalling a batch of another kind of soup  vegetarian vegetablebecause it too may be contaminated.

title: MRS. PAULINE G. PAUL
description: Mrs. Pauline Gleicher Paul, director of allday neighborhood schools in the city's school system, died in an automobile accident in Tours, France, on Aug. 21. She was 56 years old and lived at 261 East 66th Street.

title: Fund Will Aid Children Of Slain City Policemen
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association today announced the creation of a fund to be administered by city Councilmen to provide scholarships for the children of policemen killed in the line of duty.

title: Amex Names New Board Member
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of Burke Marshall to its 32man board of governors.

title: Executive House, Inc., Files Plan for Paying Creditors
description: Executive House, Inc., said yesterday that it has filed with the Federal District Court in Chicago a plan that has been approved by the committee of its unsecured creditors and the majority, in claim amounts, of all its unsecured creditors.

title: 50Story Building to Rise By St. Patrick's Cathedral
description: A $30million, 50story building with retail stores, office space and 240 cooperative apart ments will be built on Fifth Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets.

title: 57.7% Under 21 in City Have Registered to Vote
description: By the end of the eightmonth registration period this week, 57.7 per cent of New York City's newly enfranchised youths 18, 19 and 20 years old had taken advantage of their eligibilitya percentage that, almost exactly matches that of their elders in registering to vote.

title: Ingalls Shipbuilding Closed
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Aug. 31 (AP)The president of Ingalls Nuclear Shipbuilding ordered the large complex shut donw today after the spread of a walkout from another section of the shipyard. M. J. Marandino, the president, issued a bulletin to workers saying the pickets had reduced our work force to a point where the shipyard cannot operate safely.

title: KY, OUT OF RACE, BUSY IN POLITICS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 1Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky moved yesterday to get hack the $7,300 he had posted to run in the presidential election. Oct 3, emphasizing that he was out of the political scene.

title: Titian Among 14 Paintings Stolen From Italian Church
description: PIEVE DI CADORE, Italy, Aug. 31 (AP)Thieves stole a painting by the Renaissance master Titian and 13 other precious works from the church here overnight. The Titian was the only one in the town, where the 16thcentury artist was born. Experts valued the works together at above $1.6million.

title: 2 GERMAN MOVIES SHOWN AT VENICE:One Tells of Youths Living Supposedly Ideal Lives
description: VENICE, Italy, Aug. 31Germany, once the generous provider of artistic and intellectual cinema, today manufactures only a few more exportable films than Zanzibar, Albania or Staten Island. Since World War II there have been several Teutonic movies above the general international average, but they have been exceptions.What has happened? What has happened is such movies as "Liebe So Schoen Wie Liebe" and "Warnung Vor Einer Heiligen Nutte," both of which have been unveiled at the Venice Festival.The first concerns a band of self-admiring youths, who steal dogs, engage in petty fraud and otherwise endear themselves as they lead the theoretically ideal existence. One dislikes them all on sight; in the course of two hours one grows to loathe them.Second EntryThe second German entry, written and directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder, is better. It involves a disorganized movie company on location at a Mediterranean resort.The film itself is so disorganized that it is uncertain whether or not it is intended as burlesque. As satire, however, it lacks sharpness and bite, though the hardships that the director in the movie faces stirred the audience to impolite laughter.The message appears to be that an artistic filmmaker should have complete control over his work and be entrusted with dictatorial powers.A Mexican Western, "Arde," mingled sociological surrealism with the customary barroom brawls, escapes from rattlesnakes and gun battles on the desert. The story revolves about an itinerant undertaker and his adopted son, who discover a nest of black panthers on the frontier plains. Directed by Jos Bolanos and set at the time of the Civil War, it has been handsomely photographed, galvanizing its Zane Greyish plot with the unexpected and the unlikely.In addition, Ingmar Bergman's latest, "Beoringen" ("The Touch"), in color and in English, which has already been released in the United States, was shown tonight.

title: FM IS DISCUSSING COALGAS VENTURE
description: The FMC Corporation announced yesterday that it was discussing the organization of a consortium to, develop and engineer a plant for the production of synthetic natural gas and crude oil from coal.

title: 4 Students End a Test In DeepSea Chamber
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP)  Four divers ended 24 days in a simulated deepsea environmental chamber today; demonstrating that man can explore the ocean at depths of nearly a mile while breathing neon, helium and nitrogen.

title: Ingarfield Named Coach
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, Aug. 31 (AP)The Regina Pats of the Western Canada Hockey League signed Earl Ingarfield today as coach for the 197172 season. He succeeds Bob Turner, who resigned.

title: Closing of U.S. Base Signals Hardship for Philippine City
description: CAVITE, the Philippines, Aug. 31The United States flag was lowered for the last time today at Sangley Point Naval Station, ending a 73year chapter of American naval history and opening a time of trouble for this city of 76,000 down the bay from Manila.

title: Executive Changes
description: The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of Joseph C. Sibigtroth as senior vice president and chief actuary, and Edward H. Sweetser as senior vice president. Mr. Sibigtroth, formerly vice president and actuary, succeeds Lowell M. Dorn, who is retiring. Mr. Sibigtroth, 55 years old, joined the company in 1952 after 12 years at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. He will be in charge of all functions of the company relating to individual life insurance, health insurance and annuities. Mr. Sweetser, 51, was formerly vice president in charge of underwriting. He joined New York Life, the fourth largest life insurance company with assets of about $11billion, in 1937 and has spent his entire business career with the company. Mr. Sweetser will be in charge of departments handling the issuance of policies and payments of claims, the life underwriting department and the medical department.

title: NEW JERSEY METS TEAM OF FUTURE?
CIVILIAN TO RULE EAST PAKISTANIS
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Wednesday, Sept. 1The Pakistani Government this morning announced the appointment of civilian governor to take over administration of wartorn East Pakistan, which has been ruled for the last six months by Lieut. Gen. Tikka Khan.

title: Reston, Interviewed on TV, Gives Views on China Trip
description: Communist Chinais making a concerted effort to bring out what is best in man, according to James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times.

title: Lynch, in Statement on Border Incident, Accuses Britain on Incursions
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 31Prime Minister John Lynch said today that the British had failed to control movements of their troops along the border with Northern Ireland and that soldiers had made at least 30 Incursions into the Irish Republic in the last two years.

title: HOOT SPEED PICK IN HAMBLETONIAN
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 Glen Garnsey, the 37yearold reinsman who will be driving Hoot Speed, the favorite, in tomorrow's 46th annual Hambletonian, appeared to be completely at ease as he sat in the shaded area outside the Castleton Farm's barn at the Du Quoin State Fairgrounds today.

title: Chance to Help the City
description: Hope that the new state commission investigating New York City will apply itself constructively to solutions for the city's monumental problems, rather than to sterile attacks on the city administration, has risen substantially with announcement of key appointments to the commission's staff.

title: SEC. STUDIES USE OF BROKERS FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Staff econmists of the Securities and Exchange Commission have concluded that it may not be desirable or necessary for the protection of investors to bar completely the use by brokers of idle funds left in their hands by customers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. CHIEF DEFENDS PRESIDENT'S POLICY
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31No single segment of society benefits from President Nixon's new economic policy, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said today.

title: Teachers and Friends Recall Bingham: A Strong Social Conscience but Politically Naive
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31Stephen Mitchell Bingham was arrested in Clarksdale, Miss., in 1963 while helping blacks to register to vote.

title: STOCKS RETREAT FOR SECOND DAY
description: Stock prices staged their second retreat in a row yesterday in sharply reduced trading. Several glamour issues displayed sizable declines.

title: British Aircraft to Lay Off 1,500 Over Next 2 Months
description: BRISTOL, England, Aug. 31 (AP)The British Aircraft Corporation announced today that it planned to lay off 1,200 workers over the next two months, including members of the production staff of the supersonic Concorde.

title: JFK to Open Off Broadway
description: JFK, a staged biography of President Kennedy, assembled from speeches and press conferences, will be offered this fall off Broadway, with Jeremiah Collins in the title and only role. The show was presented earlier this year under the title, An Evening With John F. Kennedy at the National Press Club, Washington. Mark Williams, who created the show with Mr. Collins, will stage it with the assistance of Walt DeFaria.

title: Log of Mylai Attack Shows Early Reports of 84 Vietcong Slain, Trial Told
description: FORT. MEADE, Md., Aug. 31 Infantrymen assaulting the village of Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968, reported killing 84 Vietcong during the first hour and 10 minutes of the attack although they did not report receiving any hostile fire during the entire operation.

title: I.A.T.A. EXTENDS DATE FOR ACCORD ON FARES
description: MONTREAL, Wednesday, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press)The International Air Transport Association last night extended to Oct. 15 the deadline for Lufthansa to lift its veto of a new fares package for the North Atanitic route.

title: N.F.L. FRANCHISE SOUGHT FOR CITY
description: Assemblyman Andrew Stein has joined with three prominent Wall Street figures to explore the possibilities of attracting a professional football team to New York City to replace the Giants, moving to New Jersey in 1975.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Revises CommercialPaper Ratings
description: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., which earlier this month transferred its rating of commercial paper to its Moody's Investors Service subsidiary from its National Credit Office division, announced yesterday a new rating scale for such unsecured corporate notes.

title: MRS. MORRIS MILLER
description: Mrs. Bessie Miller, widow of Morris Miller, a real estate owner and fabric manufacturer, died yesterday at her home in Long Beach, L.I. She was 93 years old.

title: Boston Police Sue
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)The Boston Police Patrolmen's Association filed a civil suit in Federal District Court today asking to have the wageprice freeze declared unconstitutional.

title: Poor Medical Care Is Blamed in jail Deaths
description: Inadequate medical care in the city's overcrowded jails was described at a public hearing yesterday as a key factor do some of the 25 deaths of inmatesincluding eight suicides this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ugandans and Tanzanians Said to Continue Fighting
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 31 (UPI)  Uganda's armed forces were placed on full alert today, and unofficial reports said fighting continued on her troubled southern border with Tanzania.

title: The Perils of Face PeelingSome Have Been Scarred for Life
description: An experimental medical procedure, employed by surgeons to erase superficial wrinkles, is being used by nonmedical practitioners in this country and abroad who are promoting the technique as a miraculous discovery that produces baby fresh skin.

title: Hiatt's Nose Broken; Operation Necessary
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Jack Hiatt, Houston Astros catcher whose fight with Willie Crawford of the Los Angeles Dodgers started several other bouts between, members of the teams last night, suffered a broken nose and a blocked nasal passage and will undergo surgery Thursday.

title: Youths Returning From Europe Flooding Kennedy
description: The great transAtlantic youth migration of 1971 has swung into reverse, and the thousands of young Americans who flocked to Europe with a knapsack, a guitar and a $200 roundtrip ticket weeks ago were coming home.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Night Protection for Schools Asked After Ocean Hill Attack
description: In the wake of an earlymorning rampage through a public school by a mob in the Ocean HillBrownsville school district in Brooklyn, Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright, the president of the district school board, called for the hiring of nighttime guards.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Heavy selling near the close of the trading session pushed wheat futures prices down almost 3 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: 9 SINGERS TO MAKE CITY OPERA DEBUTS
description: Nine singers will make their debuts with the New York City Opera during the company's fall season at the New York State Theater, which begins tomorrow.

title: Crane Rate Up 11% For Nation in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Federal Bureau of Investigation released today statistics showing that both the crime rate and the annual volume of major crime rose substantially in 1970.

title: Proxmire to Enter Primaries In '72 in Quest for Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin is preparing to join the large field of Democrats seeking the party's 1972 Presidential nomination.

title: Johnson Testifies 3 Hours in Bid to Get His Angel Pay
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31 (UPI)Alex Johnson testified for 3 hours today before a threeman arbitration board in his bid to collect half his $52,500 salary from the California Angels.

title: 1,537 on State Welfare Placed in Jobs
description: More than half of the state welfare clients who reported themselves available for work were referred to jobs in the private sector during July, the first month under a new law requiring employables to pick up relief checks at state job centers.

title: JOHNSON'S DANCE, AMBIT, ENDS FETE
description: Anyone familiar with the innovative summer arts program that Trinity Church started in the Wall Street area two years ago would not be surprised that Ambit, a dance piece commissioned by the church from the young dancerchoreographer Raymond Johnson, was chosen to close this year's festival.

title: Mansfield Defends Moves
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Senator Mike Mansfield defended today President Nixon's measures to protect the dollar and said the United States economy could be further helped by cutting down the United States defense commitment in Europe.

title: Advertising: 4 at Y.&R. Go to Lois Holland
description: Four creative heavyweights at the $520  million  class Young & Rubicam will be moving out to become top executives at the $20million Lois Holland Callaway.

title: Tories Rout Alberta's Regime of 36 Years
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 31Conservative party candidates routed the 36yearold rightist Social Credit government in Alberta yesterday.

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Europe Is Shocked
description: BRUSSELSFew expressions have been used more widely to describe the effects of President Nixon's new economic policy than that America's partners are shocked and stunned.

title: Akron Disorder Quelled
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UPI) The police used tear gas today to break up a disturbance caused by several hundred persons who were throwing bricks and bottles on the city's west side. There were no arrests. The police were called to the area, scene of similar disturbances earlier this year, after the crowd starting throwing rocks and bottles at passing cars.

title: South African Banks to Give Equal Pay to Nonwhite Staff
description: JOHNNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 31The Standard Bank of South Africa and Barclays, South Africa, announced today they would give nonwhite employes the same rates of pay as whites. The move will affect nonwhite tellers and clerks employed mainly in nonwhite branches.

title: WIDE IMPACT SEEN IN SCHOOLS RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The United States Commissioner of Education said today that a California Supreme Court decision on public school financing may mean a very fundamental breakthrough in the concept of equity in state educational systems.

title: A Backwash of Bitterness Follows Police ShakeUp
description: There was disgust, bitterness and resignation. But mostly in the precincts that lost their captains yesterday, in Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's latest shakeup, there was anger.

title: CENTER SETS SERIES OF RUSSIAN SILENTS
description: A festival of Russian classics of the silent screen, many of them seldom shown here, will be presented from Sept. 9 to Oct. 31 at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle. Screenings will be held at 4 and 6 P.M., Wednesday through Sunday. Admission is included in the museum's general entrance fee of $1 (50 cents for students).

title: Judge Aaron J. Palmer Dies; Presided at Panther Hearing
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Aug. 31 (AP)Superior Court Judge Aaron J. Palmer died today at Middlesex Hospital, He was 67 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt Said to Get More RussianPiloted Squadrons
description: CAIRO, Aug. 31  The Soviet Union is increasing the number of Russianpiloted jet fighter squadrons in Egypt, according to wellplaced sources here.

title: Trading In Issue Suspected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had ordered suspension of overthecounter trading in the common stock of the National Tape Corporation of Maywood, N. J., through Sept. 9.

title: GLADYS DICKASON, EXUNION OFFICIAL
description: Gladys Dickason, a retired vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, A.F.L.C.I.O., died yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 305 West 13th Street.

title: Britain's Exchange Controls Come Into Effect and the Pound Tumbles
description: LONDON, Aug. 31  The dollar strengthened in relation to the floating pound sterling today as Britain's new exchange controls came into effect. This meant that the trading advantage from a devalued dollar being sought by the Nixon Administration was somewhat reduced.

title: MURPHY RELIEVES 6 POLICE CAPTAINS FOR LAXITY O JOB
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that he had relieved six captains of their commands because investigators had found repeated instances of policemen under their supervision sleeping on duty. Five of them headed precincts.

title: Madison Fund's President Named in Inquiry by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered a public proceeding today to investigate charges of securities law violations made by the Commis sion's staff against Edward A. Merkte, president and chief executive officer of Madison Fund, Inc.

title: Roundup: Jenkins Homers Twice and Pitches 6Hitter
description: Ferguson Jenkins of the Chicago Cubs, a major league pitcher par excellence, walloped a couple of homers yesterday.

title: 12 Seized as Counterfeiters
description: BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Twelve persons were arrested in five Greater Boston communities today in what the police described as a crackdown on one of the largest counterfeiting rings in the Northeast. The group, arrested in raids in Boston, Lynn, Revere, Malden and Reading, is believed responsible for the distribution of more than $2million in bogus bills in the last two years.

title: The Talk of Tonopah
description: TONOPAH, Nev.It's been nearly three years now and flilks up here in this dusty old milling town are beginning to lose their patience with Howard Hughes, the billionaire. They have been waiting and now they are tired, tired and frustrated, and slowly their disappointment is turning to anger and a feeling that Mr. Hughes has deceived them. A few are even beginning to believe that he just might have it in for the whole town.

title: Esther Driver Riegel Is Bride Of C. L. Flanders in Delaware
description: MONTCHANIN, Del., Sept. 1The marriage of Miss Esther Driver Riegel to Charlie Lane Flanders took place here this afternoon at Fiskekill, home of Mr. and Mrs. G. Burton Pearson Jr., stepfather and mother of the bride. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. Arthur R. McKinstry, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware.

title: Schmidt Signs Bruins' Pact
description: BOSTON, Sept, 1 (AP)Milt Schmidt, who has molded the Boston Bruins into a National Hockey League power, received a new twoyear contract today as general manager.

title: L'Oncle Ho
description: The crowd which assembled in Ba Dinh square in early dawn waited patiently. On the platform, a frail figure stepped forward. His beard blowing in the wind, he declared the independence of Vietnam.

title: Double Delta Takes Maskette Handicap at Belmont by HalfLength
description: She likes to goof off sometimes, but she had her mind on what she was supposed to today, said Kenny Knapp after Double Delta won the $33,050 Maskette Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Officials Say Price Freeze May Mean Cheaper Milk
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  President Nixon's 90day price freeze may save consumers from some mirror increases in retail milk prices this fall, Agriculture Department economists said today.

title: IMPORTS Al SEA. ON AUGA5 RULED FREE OF SURTAX Value of Products Affected by Ruling Is Estimated at More Than $1.5Billion.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The Treasury, in a move that will relieve major hardship for many importers, ruled today that imports already in shipment to the United States on Aug. 15 will not be subject to the new 10$ per cent import surcharge.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The distressing news from Northern Ireland necessitates some delicate action in order to prevent this open wound from festering any more.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am one of many IrishAmericans who read your newspaper's commentaries regarding the trouble that is going on in Northern Ireland. The press keeps stressing the religious angle, which has a bearing but which is not the reason for the strife. It is not a religious issue; it is an economic issue.

title: U. S. Starts the Pullout Of 42,000 More Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept 1 (AP)  The United States command announced today the start of a troop reduction of 42,000 that will cut American strength in South Vietnam to 177,000 men by Dec. 1.

title: Kennedy Hall Gets Acoustics Workout
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1An acoustic question in the Kennedy Center was partially answered this morning, when the Concert Hallone of the three auditoriums in the performing arts centerwas given a thorough workout.

title: Meeting at Panmunjon
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea Sept. 1 (AP)North Korea and the United Nations Command accused each other of creating tension and of hostile provocation on the armistice line. The evchange came at the 321st session of the Military Armistice Commission at this truce village.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS VOLUME RISES
description: The American Stock Exchange broke its twoday losing streak yesterday and advanced slightly in somewhat more active trading.

title: 49 Million Soviet Children Go Back to School With Bouquets and Books
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1Bearing bouquets for their teachers and carrying their books in briefcases strapped to their backs because Russian doctors think it good for their posture, millions of Soviet children embarked today on a new school year.

title: STOCKS RISE A BIT IN SLOW TRADING
description: Mobilehome issues starred yesterday, while many other glamour stocks fell by the wayside. For the market in general, prices inched ahead in slow trading.

title: Duryea Will Get a Chance To Try Governor's Chair
description: ALBANY, Sept. 1 (UPI)Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, frequently mentioned as a Republican candidate for Governor in 1974, will be given a chance to try out the job for the next few days.

title: EXAIDE GIVES UP IN ILLINOIS CASE
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 1 (AP)A former aide to the late Illinois Secretary of State Paul Powell surrendered and was booked today on a chargeof having tampered with public records Sangamon County sheriff's office.

title: Leader of I.R.A. Militants Detained on Arrival Here
description: Joe Cahill, leader of the militant provisional faction of the Irish Republican Army, was denied entrance to the United States by immigration authorities as he stepped off a plane from Ireland at Kennedy Airport last night. The authorities said that the visa of Mr. Cahill, who intended to embark on a fourweek national fundraising tour here, was canceled upon his arrival at the request of the State Department. A hearing was scheduled for 9 A.M. today before a special inquiry officer of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to determine whether the fiery, 51yearold Irish leader will be allowed to remain in the country or must return to Ireland. Sol Marks, district director of the Immigration Service, said that Mr. Cahill would spend the night at a detention center in his agency's offices, at 20 West Broadway.

title: CRIMMINS WITNESS SEIZED AS FUGITIVE
description: Joseph Rorech, a key prosecution witness in the Alice Crimmins murder case, was taken into custody in Waterbury, Conn., yesterday on a Federal charge of interstate flight to avoid prosecution on New York fraud charges.

title: 2 Issues Are Resolved in Museum Strike
description: Agreement on sabbaticals and training programs was reached yesterday in extended negotiations between representatives of the Museum of Modern Art and a 200member faction of its employes, on strike since Aug. 20.

title: A Second Bureau of Mines Official Ousted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Nixon Administration is removing another career official from the Bureau of Mines because, according to Interior Department officials, there has been little reduction in the high rate of death and injury in the nation's coal mines.

title: HALL HOLDS LEAD IN MALLORY SAIL
description: SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 1Graham Hall, Mallory Cup champion in 1969, and Runyon Colie Jr., each won one race today and are separated by a onefourth of a point entering tomorrow's final race for th Mallory Cup series out of New Bedford Yacht Club.

title: Ecology Fete Rejected
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 1 (UPI)Plans for a major ecological celebration called Expo 74 died here today when voters failed to approve a $5.7million dollar bond issue to support the project.

title: AIDE TO KY PREDICTS RESCHEDULED VOTING
description: An aide of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said yesterday that there was zero chance that his country's presidential election would take place on Oct. 3 because popular reaction to President Nguyen Van Thieu's running alone would force the Government to schedule a new one

title: DELINQUENCY RATE UP ON MORTGAGES
description: Delinquency on home mortgage loans increased to the highest level in more than a decade during the second quarter, Mortgage Bankers Association said yesterday. The report attributed the increase to a new surge of shortterm delinquency [payments overdue from 30 to 60 days] coupled with a growing volume of Federal Housing Administration 235 subsidized housing loans  that is, loans guaranteed under the terms of section 235 of the Federal housing legislation.

title: Man in the News
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 1He speaks softly with a gentle Cork lilt. He moves quickly and nervously, gripping a pipe, slightly stooped, eyes darting. He remains trim and physically vigorousa carryover to the days when he was one of Ireland's bestknown athletes. I have always applied the experience I gained on the playing field, says John Lynch, Ireland's Prime Minister. It is like thisin a match you fight to win, you give your all, it may even entail hard clashes with your immediate opponent. When the game is over, however, you shake your opponent's hand and there is no reason why you should not be on the friendliest terms with him.

title: Deere Plans New Tractor
description: MOLINE, Ill., Sept. 1, (Reuters  Deere & Co. said today it has developed a 175horsepower, twowheeldrive tractor to go into production next January.

title: Jets Weather a Hot and Cold McClain
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 1Clifford McClain says he had never heard the word lackadaisical until Coach Weeb Ewbank used it to describe McClain's style.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brookdale Names Aide
description: Dr. Benjamin Wainfeld has been appointed director of community health services and ambulatory care at the Brookdale Hospital Medical at Linden Boulevard and Btookdale Plaza in Brooklyn. He will be in charge of the current operation and the future development of the ambulatory care center, emergency clinic and other outpatient programs at the hospital.

title: QUESTION ON JAIL STUMPS OFFICIALS
description: The city's Health Services Administrator, the Commissioner of Correction and the Commissioner of Mental Health were stumped yesterday by the question of who was in charge of providing a resuscitator for the cellblocks of mentally disturbed inmates in the Tombs.

title: Mr. Nixon, World Traveler
description: The goodwill gesture President Nixon has made toward this country's two largest trading partners by announcing a visit to Canada next spring and a desire to visit Japan should help ease the strained relations brought on by his new economic policy. But it is unlikely to bring more than a brief respite.

title: KOTOUC DESCRIBES 2 MYLAI MESSAGES
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. An Army officer on duty at rear headquarters during the infantry push through the village of Mylai 4 said today that he had heard a radio message that a boy was being shot down on a highway near the hamlet.

title: U.S. AIDE DISPUTES TEACHER PAY VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The Under Secretary of the Treasury and the president of the National Education Association disagreed today over the status of teacher pay increases during the current wageprice freeze.

title: Muskie to Visit South
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, will make a brief trip through part of the South later this month. He will fly to Florida Sept, 18 and to Columbia, S. C., Sept. 20. He will also visit Tennessee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As one of the highranking police officers addressed by Police Commissioner Murphy on Aug. 23, I would like to emphasize, especially in view of the not so obvious but widely reported rumbling and grumbling, that many of us believe that a public office is indeed a public trust and that an accounting of our stewardship is altogether in order.

title: President Widens Freeze For Government Employes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1President Nixon extended today to about 600,000 Federal bluecollar workers the halfyear wage freeze that he had already announced for the regular Civil Service and the armed forces.

title: 8 MOVIES CHOSEN FOR N.Y. FESTIVAL
description: Two American films head the list of the first eight selections announced for the ninth annual New York Film Festival, which will be held at the Vivian Beaumont Theater from Oct. 1, through Oct. 16.

title: Sheikdom of Qatar Declares Independence From Britain
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 1 (UPI)The Persian Gulf sheikdom of Qatar declared its independence from Britain tonight, the Qatar Radio said.

title: Latin Americans to Weigh U.S. Trade Move's Effects
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 1LatinAmerican governments have scheduled an emergency regional meeting Friday to take a position on the adverse effects of President Nixon's recent economic measures on this area.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Good morning, good morning. The mailbags here in the studio are simply bursting. You good folks really responded to our exciting new contest. Did you ever love this one! Best ever. Remember the rules? As many words as you need to answer this question: Would you rather see the Yankees or the Mets leave New York, and why? Wow, that's a toughie! But what answers we got! I'm going to read a few selected at random. Remember, now, the contest is open until Mayor Lindsay comes up with a plan, These are just some, early returns.

title: Concerned for Grandson
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 1Friends and relatives of Mrs. Krasnoff said today that she had become involved in her transAtlantic journey in an attempt to shield her grandson.

title: Adm. Robert Lee, ExChairman Of MooreMcCormack, Is Dead
description: Rear Adm. Robert Corwin Lee, U.S.N. retired, former board chairman of MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., died yesterday after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived at the Beekman, 575 Park Avenue.

title: New Moon Landing Trips Being Weighed by NASA
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1 (AP)A space agency scientist said today that serious consideration was being given to extending lunar exploration beyond the two remaining planned Apollo moon landing missions.

title: Hanrahan Allowed to Query Jurors Who Indicted Him
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UPI)Judge Philip Romiti refused today to bar State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan from questioning grand jurors who indicted him and other law officers in the, Black Panther contraversy.

title: MURPHY DEMOTES TWO AND ACCEPTS TWO RETIREMENTS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday the retirement of two high police officials and the demotion of two others in his continuing drive to reshape the New York City Police Department.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Singer
description: Miss Margery Singer, a graduate of George Washington University, was married here yesterday evening to Steven M. Honig. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

title: Witco President Resigns
description: The resignation of Max A. Mannig as president of the Witco Chemical Corporation was announced yesterday by William Wishnick, chairman. Mr. Wishnick will assume Mr. Mannig's functions until the board of directors names a successor. Mr. Mannig, who is 53 years old, said that an offer of a senior executive position in another chemical company in the Middle West had led to his decision to leave Witco after 25 years.

title: Mrs. Onassis Says She'll Miss Opening Of Kennedy Center
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Mrs. Aristotle Onassis notified trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts today that she would not attend the formal opening next Wednesday of the $46million memorial to her late husband.

title: MITCHELL OPPOSES CAMPUS VOTE LAW
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 1  Attorney General John N. Mitchell said tonight that Congress would be discriminating against other voters, particularly servicemen, if it passed a law permitting students to vote in the communities where they attend college.

title: CHILE WILL MANAGE STRUCK TIRE PLANT
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 1 (UPI)  The Government took over the management of Insa, the country's largest tiremaker, today to end a strike by workers demanding nationalization. A United States company, General Tire, owns 37 per cent of the concern.

title: Wave of Political Arrests Is Reported in Portugal
description: LISBON, Sept. 1  A Portuguese prisoners' aid organization reported today that the number of political detainees more than doubled during the first seven months of this year. The National Commission for Aid to Political Prisoners charged that a brutal wave of arrests was taking place, involving indiscriminate jailing, torture and beating, and the systematic refusal of legal aid as well as other illegalities.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar the Use Of Alleged Subversive List
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)  The American Communist party and other groups sued the Government today to bar the use of the Attorney's Generals's list of allegedly subversive groups and to prevent the Subversive Activities Control Board from adding names to it.

title: Allende Wins Backing in Colombia Visit
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 1 President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile left Colombia today after five days that blended a formal state visit with informal political campaigning.

title: Hunts Point Youths Draw Gang Battle Lines
description: Puerto Rican and black street gangs, some well organized, others not, have surfaced in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx. Many people in the area, and particularly the police, are concerned that these teenaged groups may develop into successors of the warring gangs of the nineteenfifties and early sixties.

title: Yen Almost Unchanged
description: At the same time, the Japanese textile industry bluntly turned down a Government request for approval to reopen textile talks with the United States, deadlocked since March.

title: CASHFLOW POLICY CHANGED BY CITY
description: A new computerized system for handling the city government's daytoday cash flow, was announced by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brandywine Wins in Polo From Greenwich, 6 to 5
description: TOUGHKENAMON, Pa., Sept. 1 Brandywine, the defender, defeated the Greenwich (Conn.) Pitchforks, 65, today in a firstround game of the Gerald Balding memorial 8goal polo tournament.

title: Welfare Chief to Discuss Frauds With Prosecutors
description: Jule M. Sugarman, City Human Resources Administrator, arranged yesterday to meet this morning with the city's five District Attorneys or their representatives to discuss how to cope with welfare clients' wrongdoing  primarily check frauds.

title: Schweitzer Is Questioned For Sixth Day in Inquiry
description: State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer, who has been accused of accepting bribes and of meeting with defense counsel outside of court, submitted yesterday to a sixth day of questioning by investigators for the New York Court on the Judiciary.

title: LAIRD SAYS BONN WILL BUY 175 JETS FOR $750MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird announced today that the United States had agreed to sell 175 Phantom jet fighters to West Germany.

title: Convention Center To Open in 1976 Under City's Plans
description: Construction on the city's view $100million convention and exhibition center on the Hudson River waterfront will begin in 18 months and is expected to be completed in 1976 in time for this country's 200th bicentennial celebration, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

title: DR. TRACY PARKS JR.; LED NARCOTIC UNIT
description: Dr. Tracy G. Parks Jr., physician in charge of the Edgecomb Rehabilitation Center of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, died Saturday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 49 years old and lived and practiced at 10 West 135th Street. He also had a summer home in Wilyside, N. J.

title: T.W.A.'S JUDGMENT ON HUGHES UPHELD
description: An award of $145million for Trans World Airlines against Howard R. Hughes was affirmed here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: Old Cans Help to Roof Atom Smasher
description: A new kind of building material, panels made of empty beverage cans, is being used to construct a roof on an experimental area of the world's largest atom smasher.

title: Copter Saves Man in Harbor
description: A 21yearold exMarine, identified by the police as Thomas Brown, was saved yesterday afternoon by helicopter policemen after he jumped or fell from a Staten IslandtoManhattan ferryboat. The policemen, Charles Humphries and Sherwin Bogart, landed their helicopter in the water and pulled Mr. Brown aboard after a short struggle, the police said.

title: GENERAL COMBATS RACIAL IRRITANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The commanding general of the Air Training Command, spurred by a recent report of rising racial tensions at Air Force training bases, has begun a new, diverse and quiet effort to diinish racial irritations.

title: ECONOMIST URGES 12% DEPRECIATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1A leading international monetary economist reiterated to Congress today that it would take an average depreciation of the dollar relative to other leading currencies of at least 12 per cent to bring the United States international payments into ballance.

title: Bridge: Avoid Poor Contracts Limits in Bids Important
description: High school mathematicians learn about expressions that tend to a limit when they reach calculus. High school bridge players find that limits are equally important at the card table.

title: Judge Dismisses Attempt In Michigan to Bar Busing
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI)A Federal judge dismissed today a suit to halt the use of buses to achieve racial balance in the Pontiac school system. He also issued a warning to any who would resort to violence to stop the buses, threatening to use marshals, if necessary.

title: SEAVER WINS 16TH WITH 4HITTER, 71
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1Tom Seaver outpitched Bob Gibson tonight and won his fifth straight game as the New York Mets defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 71.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Soybean Futures Register Gain On Yugoslavian Import Report
description: Concern about the lack of rain and a report that Yugoslavia was again seeking heavy imports of soybean oil brought about heavy buying and short covering of soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, producing a gain of 6 cents a bushel. In 1970, Yugoslavia was the fourth largest importer of United States soybean oil.

title: Overpriced Tickets Bring Refund at Fair
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 1At 2 P.M. today state fair officials began refunding 50 cents to everyone who showed up with a $2 admission ticket stub purchased yesterday and this morning.

title: Estate of $400,000 Is Left In Margaret Case's Will
description: The will of the late Miss Margaret case of 550 Park Avenue, a contributing editor to Vogue magazine, was filed for probate was filed for probate in Surrogate Court in Manhattan yesterday, disposing of an estate worth an estimated total of $400,000.

title: CONTRACT AWARDED FOR SPACE ENGINES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. I (UPI) The space agency announced today the award of a shortterm contract to North American Rockwell's Rocketdyne division to get started on fundamental design work for engines for shuttle spacecraft.

title: Blackout in Westchester
description: A power failure his eastern Westchester County last night, blacking out 2,100 homes in Rye and Port Chester for more than an hour. A spokesman for Con Edison said last night that two 4,000volt feeder cables failed at 9:33 P.M. for a reason not yet determined. Power to some of the affected homes was restored at 10:37 and to the rest at 11:10.

title: Meschery Is Appointed New Coach of Cougars
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Sept. 1 (AP)Tom Meschery, a 10year player in the National Basketball Association, was named today coach of the Carolina Cougars, an American Basketball Association team.

title: WarCrimes Figure Loses Assignment As Army Recruiter
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 1 (AP)An officer who has accused the Army of harassing him has been transferred from a position where he was responsible for reenlistments to another job, the Third Army said today.

title: Film:
description: Lord love a duck, a Disney duck! No, not Donald. We mean a delightful new liveaction romp, with the Disney label, called $1,000,000 Duck. Her nameyes, her is Charley.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The classified ads:

title: Pressure Rises in Newark News Strike
description: NEWARK, Sept. 1  The strike of the Newspaper Guild at the The Evening News here will reach its 100th day tomorrow amid indications that pressures are mounting on both sides for a resolution of the dispute.

title: CITY'S HOSPITALS SUED ON BACK PAY
description: The Labor Department charged yesterday that New York City's public hospital system owed about $1.5million in back overtime pay to 6,000 employes.

title: N.B.C. NEWSWRITERS VOTE UNION SWITCH
description: Newswriters at the National Broadcasting Company in New York City have voted 5125 for union representation by the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians in place of the Writers Guild of America East. They have been represented by the guild.

title: Saigon Reports Foe Shelled a Column Near DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 2 (AP)North Vietnamese gunners reportedly directed a 500round rocketandmortar barrage at a South Vietnamese armored column near the demilitarized zone yesterday and also shelled five nearby bases.

title: But Some Find a Taste of Peace
description: BIRDINHAND, Pa.The swallows fly down from the barn and swoop out over the cornfields and the alfalfa, and 15yearold Manuel Vega, a leader of the Roman Kings gang in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx; stands there on the hill.

title: Hormel Seeks 2for1 Split
description: AUSTIN, Minn., Sept I (AP)  The board of directors of Geo. A. Hormel & Co., have called a stockholders' meeting here for Oct. 26 to consider a 2for1 stock split.

title: Equal Rights to Learn
description: A nationwide review of sources of local financial support for public schools may be set off by a 6to1 decision of the California Supreme Court invalidating that state's present system of financing public education. The court held that imbalances in the amounts contributed by rich communities as against poor ones violated the constitutional right of school children to equal protection under the law.

title: Utility Pledges Halt To Heat Pollution In Biscayne Bay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)  The Justice Department announced today the settlement of a suit to halt the discharging of heated water into Biscayne Bay by the Florida Power and Light Company.

title: Abbie Hoffman Accused Before Court of Peers
description: Did Abbie Hoffman steal some of the labors that went into the creation of Steal This Book, his antiEstablishment bestseller that, among other things, instructs its readers on ways to thrive without working.

title: LEONARD J. BRASS, PLANT AUTHORITY
description: Dr. Leonard J. Brass, recognized as the authority on the plants of New Guinea, died of cancer on Sunday at Cairns in his native Queensland, Australia, where he retired in 1966 from his position as curator of the Archbold Collections of the American Museum of Natural History. He was 71 years old.

title: Rozelle Says Area Could House 3 Clubs
description: Pete Rozelle, president of the National Football League, said yesterday he believed the metropolitan area could support three football teams.

title: CreditCard Protection Bill Gains Support
description: ALBANY, Sept. 1Governor Rockefeller's Consumer Protection Board, until recently headed by Betty Furness, threw its weight behind legislation here today that would permit a consumer who buys on a credit card to turn to the issuer for satisfaction whenever he is unable to get it from the merchant.

title: Notes on People
description: Paul G. Hoffman, an Under Secretary in the United Nations and administrator of the United Nations Development Program, will retire in January, Secretary General Thant has announced. Mr. Hoffman, who turned 80 on April 26, has been at the United Nations 12 years.

title: Michael Romanoff, the Prince And Restaurant Owner, Dead
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 1 (AP) Michael Romanoff, a selfstyled Russian prince who gained fame as a restaurateur, bon vivant and intimate of Hollywood stars, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital.

title: Watson Tells of Rampage At Home of Sharon Tate
