description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (UPI) Charles Watson said today that he had gone on a wild shooting and knifing rampage in Sharon Tate's home. He said he had done it because he could hear Charlie's voice saying kill everyone in the place.

title: Travel Curbs Annoy Many in East Bloc
description: WARSAW, Sept. 1  In Budapest one day recently a young man spoke with weary resignation of the vacation he was about to begin. It will be Sopot again this year, he said. I still can't get out.

title: Police Believe Masked Gunmen Had Inside Information on Club
description: Detectives said yesterday that the four masked men who held up members of the Town Club on the Upper East Side Tuesday night apparently had inside information.

title: Gas Shortage Is Pinching Con Edison
description: The major supplier of natural gas for the metropolitan area has told Consolidated Edison and other utilities that it cannot meet all its commitments at present and may have to fall short by 10 per cent on the supply due here this winter.

title: Anthony Colombo Bars Queries On Guns Found in Brother's Car
description: The eldest son of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. declined to answer 20 questions before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday and eventually was upheld in his refusal to respond to those related to the discovery last July 28 of three loaded guns in his brother's rented car.

title: Spread of Marijuana Creates New Specialist: The Drug Lawyer
description: DENVER. Sept. 1  The nation's growing use of marijuana has brought a flood of money into the practice of criminal law and with it a new generation of aggressive, young criminal lawyers.

title: Showdown on Atlantic Fares Put Off
description: The transAtlantic airlines yesterday postponed until Sept. 15 a showdown in their dispute over new fares, ruling out a price war at least temporarily.

title: U.S. Expreses Concern On Soviet Arms for Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The State Department said today that continued shipments of Soviet arms to Egypt were a matter of real concern and could have the most serious consequences.

title: Market Place:
description: Take it from Paul J. Hogan of Rochesterit's no fun to seek an appraisal of share value from the Delaware courts.

title: Lackawanna Ticket Agent Slain in Millburn Station
description: MILLBURN, N. J., Sept. 1 (UPI)A ticket agent at the ErieLackawanna Railroad station was shot and killed today in a robbery four minutes after the last morning rushhour train departed for New York, leaving the station deserted.

title: Chess:
description: Bobby Fischer's 19game victory streak, which includes 60 triumphs over Grandmaster Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union and Bent Larsen of Denmark in the world chess eliminations, started in a tournament in Palma, Majorca, in Spain. The last match the New Yorker lost was to Larsen, Lenmark's grand master.

title: KENNETH F. M'LELLAN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1Kenneth F. MacLellan, chairman of Unarco Industries, Inc., makers of grocery carts and other metal products, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Bolivia After Torres
description: Well aware of the instability of Bolivian politics, the United States waited more than a week after that country's latest coup before moving to recognize the new Government in La Paz headed by Col. Hugo Banzer. One factor in the delay, no doubt, was uncertainty over Whether former President Juan Torres would remain overthrown or whether a countercoup would be engineered by his followers. Another factor was Washington's unwillingness, through excessive haste in recognizing the new regime, to feed leftist charges that the antiTorres revolt was organized by the C.I.A. and that Colonel Banzer is an American puppet.

title: JAVA SEA OIL WELL BEGINS OPERATIONS
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 1 (AP)  President Suharto inaugurated a $60million offshore oil well venture today that is expected to be producing 75,000 barrels of oil a day by the end of next year.

title: Vietnam Action Ruled No War In an Insurance Case in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 1 CAP)The Virginia Supreme Court held today that the United States' involvement in Vietnam did not constitute a war in the legal sense.

title: Ellington to Tour Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Duke Ellington and his jazz band will tour the Soviet Union this fall under the Cultural Exchange Program, the State Department announced today. The orchestra is to leave Sept. 10 and perform 20 concerts during the fiveweek tour, Mr. Ellington's first in the Soviet Union. The tour will begin Sept. 13 in Leningrad. The band will play also in Minsk, Kiev and Rostov, ending with concerts in Moscow from Oct. 9 to 12.

title: 1972 Cadillacs Unveiled
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI)Stronger bumpers and minor styling refinements highlighted the 1972 model cars unveiled today by the Cadillac Division of the General Motors Corporation.

title: Pornography Shops Clean Up Windows to Comply With Law
description: Stores and theaters catering to the pornographic trade in Times Square were more decorous outside than indoors yesterday as the new state law barring public display of erotica went into effect.

title: Construction Spending Fell in July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  New construction spending fell $700million in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $104.1billion following an upward revised increase of $900million In June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: EDUCATION FUNDS IN STATE SCORED
description: Assemblyman Stanley Harwood of Levittown, L. I., the ranking Democrat on the assembly's Education Committee, said yesterday that he would file suit this month in Federal Court in an effort to compel the state to establish a new system of financing its public schools.

title: PLUTONIUM WASHED FROM HUMAN LUNG
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 1 (AP)  An Albuquerque hospital has performed what it believes is the first lung lavage operation specifically to remove radioactive particles from a human lung.

title: Leary Is Defended And Also Criticized On Corruption Issue
description: Former Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary was defended yesterday by his successor and attacked by his predecessor on the question of police corruption.

title: Third Movie May Be Shifted From Production Here
description: The likelihood of a third movie's being removed from New York followed Paramount Pictures' decision on Tuesday to shift production of Last of the Red Hot Lovers and Play It Again, Sam because of a contract dispute with a local union.

title: Shop Talk
description: The men's wear revolution has taken a new turn: It's back to classics in men's clothes as it is in women's clothes. The trend is away from tight, dandyish Edwardian styles to more relaxed tailoring. That, at any rate, is the message for fall from Bonwit Teller's men'sshop, which is redoing its boutiquelike ddcor to provide a more serious environment for more shop, which is redoing its boutiquelike ddcor to provide a more serious environment for more serious shoppers. The tailoring it is advocating is the British sort, with checks and plaids for casual clothes and pin stripes and flannels for business suits. Most even have vests. Leading the return to normalcy is the first venture into clothing of Turnbull and Asser, the London haberdashery that has been concentrating on ties and shirts since 1885.

title: Child Given to Adoption Agency Pending Appeal
description: A 3yearold girl of Chinese parentage who is the focus of a legal tugofwar involving her natural mother, her prospective adoptive parents and an adoption agency was surrendered to the agency Tuesday night pending resolution of the case.

title: A Hong Kong Native, She Taught French Cooking
description: May Chang Wong used to make one of the best souffles in Hong Kong where she was born. Four months ago she married Peter Trent, a municipal bonds specialist on Wall Street. And now she is turning her husband's East Side galley kitchen into one of the most interesting sources of Chinese food in New York.

title: FLORIDA BOARD SUES FOR U.S. BUSING AID
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP)The Duval County School Board, under a courtordered integration plan requiring busing of 75,000 pupils, asked a Federal District Court today to overrule President Nixon's order limiting the use of Federal funds for busing.

title: Desire of Baganda Tribe, Largest in Uganda, for Restoration of Monarchy Embarrasses President
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 30  Democracy has been moribund for a long time in the East African nation of Uganda, but a large part of the population hardly seems to care because to them the burning issue is restoration of a tribal monarchy.

title: RUBLE DEVALUED BY TOKEN AMOUNT
description: LONDON, Sept. 1The viet Union took note of monetary upheavals in the capitalist world today with a token devaluation of the ruble against the Western currencies that have floated up to higher rates.

title: Cooke and Mugavero Bid Priests Submit Nominations for Bishop
description: Cardinal Cooke of New York and Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn have written letters to the priests of their dioceses inviting them to submit names of candidates for the office of bishop.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  A hydroelectric plant costing $400million is to be built in North Sumatra to supply a planned new aluminum smelter there, a Public Works Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Baffled by That Maze Called Kennedy Airport? Not if the Golden Girls Can Help It.
description: What is a Golden Girl? In California, she is the media's term for almost any young womanespecially if she has long blond hair. At Purdue University, she is the featured baton twirler with the university's marching band. (She wears a skimpy golden sequined uniform.)

title: Ruckelshaus Scores Label Of Secrecy on ATest Note
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says that there is no substantive reason for classifying as top secret his recommendations to a Presidential committee on the underground nuclear test scheduled for early next month on Amchitka Island.

title: Executive Changes
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday the election of Edgar H. Griffiths as executive vice presidentservices. Prior to this appointment, Mr. Griffiths was president of the RCA Service Company subsidiary. In his new post he will be responsible for the RCA Service Company, the Hertz Corporation and RCA Parts and Accessories. He also was elected chairman of the executive committee, board of directors of the Hertz Corporation.

title: ROLLS SAYS CORNER ON RB211 IS TURNED
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 (UPI)RollsRpyce has turned the corner over the RB211 engine, Lord Cole, chairman of RollsRoyce, Ltd., 1971, said today.

title: News of Dogs
description: Trixie, a mixed breed purchased from an animal shelter as a pup three years ago for $5, was named America's dog of the year yesterday.

title: Advertising:
description: If you're wondering how piano sales are shaping up for the second half of this kazooeconomy year, the answer is good. Not grand, baby. Just good.

title: FILMS IN ENGLISH MARK VENICE FETE
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 1Today was an Englishspeaking day at the Venice Festival.

title: Bay State Names Geologist
description: BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Gov. Francis. W. Sargent announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph A. Sinnott of Worcester as the state's first geologist. The new post will pay $20,000 a year.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange omitted its usual weekly report.

title: 1,000 Maine Students Test 4Day School Week
description: THORNDIRE, Me., Sept. 1 (UPI)About 1,000 school children living in this conservative farming area of eastern Maine will participate much of this school year in a radical educational experimentthe fourday week.

title: Drive Began to Place Agnew on '72 Ticket
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)Declaring that, Vice President Spiro Agnew has won unprecedented praise from millions of Americans for his courageous, uncompromising positions, a group of conservatives has started a campaign to insure that he will be on the Republican ticket in 1972.

title: Assault Breaks Leg; Horse Is Destroyed
description: KINGSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 1 (AP)  Assault, who won racing's Triple Crown in 1946, was put to sleep today. Dr. J. K. Northway, King Ranch veterinarian, said the horse stumbled and fell earlier in the day, fracturing his left front leg near the shoulder. The 28yearold champion was buried on the lawn next to Northway's office.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Sato Interview on Changing Relations in the World
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1  Following are excerpts from the transcript of an interview of Premier Eisahu Sato by James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times. The interview was held yesterday and the transcript was approved by Mr. Sato today.

title: Favorite Bows in 4 Sets At Start of U.S. Tennis
description: Jan Kodes believes that tennis played on grass is a joke. To prove his point, the 25yearold Czech stunned John Newcombe, the topseeded Australian, in the opening round of the United States Open championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Woman Who Spent the Summer Flying Atlantic Dies in Europe
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 1 (AP)  The transAtlantic travels of a Cleveland widow and her grandson ended today when she died within earshot of the big jets she had used almost daily this summer.

title: PHOENICIAN STONE CLUE TO OLD CITY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1A Philadelphia archeologist digging at the suspected site of the Phoenician city of Sarepta has found what he regards as convincing proof that he is in the right place.

title: Newark Gains in Bid For Black Policemen
description: NEWARK, Sept. 1Newark, which has become a predominantly black city with a still largely white police force, today graduated its first Police Academy class with a majority of black members.

title: Columnist Fights F.T.C. Subpoena for His Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  A new contest over the rights of journalists under the First Amendment has developed as a result of a subpoena issued by a hearing examiner for the Federal Trade Commission.

title: WESTERN UNION REACHES ACCORD
description: A tentative settlement was reached yesterday in the 92clay strike against Western Union in the metropolitan area by members of the Communications Workers of America. If the agreement is ratified, the 3,100 strikers will return to work Sept. 13.

title: Fanny May Standby Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Association said today it would hold a standby auction of 12month commitments on Monday, Sept. 13, in addition to the auction of threemonth commitments next Tuesday. The auction will cover commitments for F.H.A. and V.A. mortgages not covered by the special assistance program for unsubsidized housing conducted by the Government National Mortgage Association.

title: 200 Schlitz Layoffs Include Dismissal Of 2 Vice Presidents
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company announced today that it was dismissing 200 salaried workers, including two of its 18 vice presidents.

title: Dollar Stronger On Exchange Here; Volume Is Limited
description: The dollar was a bit stronger in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday. In light trading, the Canadian dollar, the German mark and the Swiss franc were all slightly lower in relation to the dollar than on Tuesday. However, the British pound closed at $2.4565, up slightly from the Tuesday closing price of $2.4540.

title: Nurse Corps Head Named
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  Col, Lillian Dunlap was promoted to brigadier general today and became head of the Army Nurse Corps. The new general, who is 49 years old and a native of San Antonio, Tex., was an Army nurse in the South Pacific in World War II. She replaces Brig. Gen. Anna Mae Hays, who retired as head of the Nurse Corps this week.

title: NADER PRESSES U.S. ON DEFECTS IN AUTOS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, made public today a list of automobile problems, such as brake failures, window explosions, engine dislocations and fires, and accused the Federal Government of bungling and burying investigations of these.

title: I. C. C. Details Findings in Rail Merger Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) A report issued today by an Interstate Commerce Coinmission examiner showed that the Harriman family holdings in the Union Pacific Railroad total only slightly more than 3 per cent

title: Italian Exiles Protest Again
description: LINOSA, Italy, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Fourteen of 19 suspected Mafia bosses exiled to this tiny Mediterranean island 100 miles south of Sicily began a hunger strike today as their latest protest against confinement. Last week they refused to pay bills for rent and food.

title: WASHINGTON DATES FOR BALLET THEATER
description: American Ballet Theater will perform Sept. 11 and 15 at the Opera House of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington during the center's inaugural week.

title: Space Center Gets Rover 2
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 1 (UPI)The nation's second moon car was delivered today to the space center here for flight on the Apollo 16 expedition to the central lunar highlands next March. The $8million moon vehicle, Rover 2, is scheduled to be installed in the Apollo 16 lunar module landing craft in November after detailed tests and flight preparations.

title: Saving the Adirondacks
description: Governor Rockefeller's informal and incomplete list of appointees to the new Adirondack Park Agency offers hope that one of the state's greatest resources will be preserved for the enjoyment of future New Yorkers.

title: Officials Believe Bingham Fled California After Prison Deaths
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 (AP)Federal officials said today that they had reason to believe Stephen M. Bingham, charged with five counts of murder in the violence at San Quentin Prison Aug. 21, had fled from Californiapossibly to Canada or Cuba.

title: Rickkles Urges Action to Protect Tunnel Workers From Fumes
description: Bridge and tunnel attendants and toll collectors are subjected to incredibly high carbon monoxide levels. Robert N. Rickles, the Commissioner of Air Resources, said last night. He called for prompt action to protect workers from the poisonous fumes.

title: Mr. Eaton's Rhetoric
description: WASHINGTONThe recent remarks here by Cyrus Eaton are an example of extremism in rhetoric which has unfortunately become too commonplace in contemporary America.

title: Swiss to Recognize Hanoi, Hope to Play a Role in Peace
description: BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1 (AP)  Switzerland decided today to recognize North Vietnam and indicated she hoped to play a role in ending the war in Vietnam.

title: Saigon Officially Removes Ky's Name From Ballot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1  The South Vietnamese Government announced tonight that the presidential election would be held as scheduled Oct. 3 with only one candidate, President Nguyen Van Thieu. The name of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, it said, will be kept off the ballot.

title: Quarterly Profits At Heinz Set Mark
description: Sales and earnings of the H. J. Heinz Company in the first fiscal quarter, ended July 28, were the highest in its 102year history despite continuing inflationary pressures around the world, the company reported yesterday.

title: Gillette to Offer 2Faced Blade
description: The 1971 World Serles may well go down in history as the first to feature a doubleheader. And it will be brought to you by Gillette in its 33d year of Serles involvement.

title: U.S. Car Output In August Increased From Year Ago
description: Automobile production in the, United States in August to taled 501,910 cars, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit. In August of last year the industry turned out 285,450 units.

title: SEOUK CONSIDERS '71 WAR PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 South Korea was authoritatively reported today to be considering the withdrawal of all its forces from South Vietnam by the end of this year.

title: Fall Kills Bronx Boy, 2
description: A 2yearold boy was killed on the Bronx yesterday when he fell five stories from an apartment window. The police said the victim, Jose Castillio of 1692 Cauldwell Avenue, had climbed onto the livingroom couch and had fallen against closed window, He crashed through the glass and plunged down.

title: Donahue Cast as 'Sweet Saviour':Plays a Hippie Leader Who Orders Murders Disney Work, Horror Movie Also Open
description: Making fun of the screen career of Troy Donahue may by now have become a reputable cottage industry among cultural commentators, and in recent months, nobody has been better at it than Troy Donahue, who is currently establishing a new image. But that career happens to include Blake Edward's "The Perfect Furlough," Douglas Sirk's "Imitation of Life," Raoul Walsh's "A Distant Trumpet," plus four films by the immensely enjoyable and generally underrated Delmer Daves. And though I haven't seen all his work, it seems to me just possible that Donahue's first absolutely awful movie is "Sweet Saviour," produced and directed by Bob Roberts, which opened yesterday at the Forum and Trans-Lux East theaters.Donahue, his face half hidden now behind beard and long and slightly graying hair, plays Moon, an East Village hippie cult leader and drug dealer who identifies himself with the Second Coming and thinks he has a mission. One night, Moon and three of his disciples drive out to the suburbs, where, in some glamorous middle-class housing development, a pregnant movie actress (Renay Granville) and some of her jet-setting friends are preparing an orgy. Moon brings with him stuff to smoke, stuff to sniff, assorted pills and a certain sense of derring-do. The jet-setters provide a nice delicatessen platter, a cold roast turkey, and a plate full of Cheez Doodles for appetizers. After the orgy, when everybody is pretty tired, Moon has his disciples borrow knives and forks (from the kitchen, from the cold roast turkey), with which they murder the jet setters.Although the story is fiction, I cannot imagine that any accidental resemblance to persons both living and dead would be willingly rejected. In a work of this sort you must expect exploitation. But the exploitation in "Sweet Saviour" has almost nothing to do with the Sharon Tate murder case, the advance publicity notwithstanding, and has almost everything to do with the conventions of pornographic moviemaking."Sweet Saviour" is therefore an exploitation film of a fairly tame and boringly predictable sort. It has the obligatory group encounters, private encounters, lesbian encounters and transvestite encounters. Furthermore, it pretends to sex with drugs, without drugs and for drugs. It even offers a smoldering erotic dance, a set piece, that consists mostly of slow-motion head stands and is really pretty funny. Its murders are made up of timid screams and unhomogenized tomato juice, and at no point, either for love or death, does it achieve any hint of intensity. Although its ineptitude is such that you can't really hate it, there is simply nothing about it to like.It is quite without performances except for Troy Donahue, who is helplessly inauthentic. Its various exhibitions are graceless and phony, and I have no memory of anything real to "Sweet Saviour" beyond the sharp loud crunch of somebody's first bite into a Cheez Doodle.

title: LLEWELLYN MILLER
description: Llewellyn Miller, author and former drama critic and editor, died yesterday of cancer at her home, 23 West 73d Street. She was 72 years old.

title: Holmes Forms a Subsidiary
description: Holmes Protection, Inc., has formed a new subsidiary, the Holmes Marketing Corporation, to market security equipment. Alexander F. Jameson is general manager of the new venture.

title: Scribner Proposes Requirements For Acting School Supervisors
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has proposed new eligibility requirements for acting school supervisors as the result of a Federal judge's ruling earlier this summer that restrained the city school system from holding traditional examinations and issuing new eligibility lists for supervisory posts.

title: A 'Creatures' Bundle
description: They're at it again. Who? Our forefathers, supposedly. Once more we have one of those grunt-and-groan prehistoric bundles, with "undiscovered" talents hopping around in billowing hair and skimpy costumes, battling one another and an occasional animal.Most fortunately, yesterday's goody, "Creatures the World Forgot," came from England via Africa. Give it this much. At about midpoint, the color photographer, or directoror whoever was grunting-and-groaning behind the camerastarts doing some interesting things with the exotic African terrain. Also, a reedy score by Mario Nascimbene sustains a kind of witch-doctor punctuation.The principals, all sun-broiled and with carefully exposed limbs, include Julie Ege, Tony Bonner and Robert John. The homestretch is quite lively, and the whole thing is considerably better than the Raquel Welch "One Million B.C." Make that less bad.

title: City to Revive Madison Avenue Mall, With Changes
description: Three months after the city decided to shelve the Tuesdaynight closings of Madison Avenue for a pedestrian malla decision caused by objections from businessmen and residentsthe Economic Development Administration has decided to resume them.

title: GRAIN ELEVATORS CLOSED BY A STRIKE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1, (Reuters) Striking longshoremen forced the shutdown today of grain elevators belonging to six major companies estimated to handle from 60 to 75 per cent of the grain harvested in the Middle West that is shipped through Chicago ports.

title: News Analysis
description: It has been a bad year for many local school officials, confronted as they have been, on one hand, by widespread demands for better education and, on the other hand by rebellious homeoweners who refusel to put up any more property taxes for schools hardpressed for funds. It is not exactly surprising, then, that many local school officials would foresee salvation in the California Supreme Court's attack on the constitutionality of using the local property tax as the major source of funds for public education.

title: Ohio Lays Off 1,200
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 1 (UPI)  Ohio laid off 1,200 workers today as the first move in Gov. John J. Gilligan's austerity program to cut expenditures until the Legislature approves a budget. The state has been operating on an interim budget since the fiscal year began July 1.

title: Wdod, Field and Stream
description: HATTGRAS, N. C.Unsettied weather had been plaguing North Carolina's Outer Banks for several days when we arrived at Bob Smirnow's Hatteras Marine and Trading company tackle shop, burning with desire to do battle with a blue marlin.

title: Yankees Lose to Senators, 20
description: A 23yearold sinkerball pitcher named Bill Gogolewski continued the Washington Senators' strange dominance over the Yankees yesterday, allowing New York only four hits in a 20 triumph for the Senators at Yankee Stadium.

title: Answers Issued on Cost Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Following is the 12th set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The awarding of a $35.5million Navy contract to the Grumman Corporation for the continued production of EA6B aircraft was announced yesterday.

title: Greece Seizes 2 Americans as Plotters
description: ATHENS, Sept. 1The Government announced tonight the arrest of four persons, two of them Americans, on charges of having plotted to free the man who tried to assassinate Premier George Papadopoulos three years ago.

title: Merger News
description: The taxexempt note sector proved a sparkling exception to otherwise luckluster activity in the credit markets yesterday.

title: RICH TROT TAKEN BY SPEEDY CROWN IN STRAIGHT HEATS
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1 At times, Howard Beissinger, a Hamilton, Ohio, farmer turned harness horseman, found little, to like about Speedy Crown. There was the foal's original name, Headin' and Healin'. Then there was a nasty splint that nearly wrecked the yearling's future. And three weeks ago, there was a 1:57 45 time trial at Springfield, Ill. Beissinger thought the colt could have moved faster that day.

title: NELSON HAYES DIES; WROTE DILDO CAY
description: ROXBURY, Vt., Sept. 1Nelson Hayes, author of Dildo Cay, a novel that Paramount Pictures made into the motion picture Bahama Passage, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 67 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Brian McFadden's Aug. 21 letter once again promulgates the doctrine that evil can be resolved by maintaining an evil structure. The British plantation of the seventeenth century has been and can only be assisted by the British police force which continues to rape Ulster.

title: Baby Boy Is State's First Case Of Eastern Equine Encephalitis
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 1Fiveweekold Shad Slake of nearby Central Square has become the first person in the state known to have contracted the deadly eastern equine encephalitis disease, State Department of Health officials said today.

title: Residents of Union County Need Not Now Boil Water
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 1Residents of Union County were free to use water today without boiling it first while some in Middlesex County were advised to continue boiling water as a precaution against possible contamination caused by last weekend's flooding. Both counties are served by the Elizabeth Water Company.

title: N.F.L.'s Young Quarterbacks Having Their Ups and Downs
description: At the doubleheader in Cleveland on. Saturday night, the Giants will play against a young quarterback not doing well, Mike Phipps of the Browns, while the Jets will take on one doing very well, Terry Bradshaw of the Steelers.

title: Freezing Out Federal Employes
description: The Administration has given repeated signs in recent days of awareness that it must move with all practical speed to evolve a more flexible stabilization program control wages and prices after the present ninetyday freeze. A major aim of this Phase Two program will be to erase manifest inequities of the kind that are inevitable under a total freeze.

title: City Rent and Housing Reform Is Urged
description: Mayor Lindsay was asked yesterday to declare a moratorium on the demolition of sound housing until the critical housing shortage eases and to reform rentcontrol procedures.

title: Books of The Times
description: BETWEEN THE HILLS AND THE SEA. By K. B. Gilden. 549 pages. Doubleday. $7.95.

title: THOMAS J. SMITH, 63, AD EXECUTIVE, DIES
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept. 1Thomas Johnston Smith, a former advertising executive, died today in Norwalk Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived on Olmstead Hill Road.

title: Sato Says U.S. Remains Pivot of Japanese Policy
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan, in his first interview since the outbreak of the world monetary crisis, said yesterday that the political repercussions of Pres ident Nixon's new economic policy were serious but that the United States remained the pivot of Japan's foreign policy.

title: West Cards a 67 to Lead U.S. Amateur by 2 Shots
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 1 (AP)Marty West 3d, marking time until he is called by his draft board, shot a fourunderpar 67 today for a twostroke lead over a mathematics teacher, George Haines, in the first round of the 71st annual United States Amateur golf championship.

title: Paterson Dedicates Park in Celebrating Great Falls Festival
description: PATERSON, Sept. 1This industrial city is taking a backward look in its search for brighter future.

title: Heath and Lynch to Meet Soon on Crisis in Ulster
description: LONDON, Sept. 1The British Government announced today that Prime Minister Heath would meet next week with Prime Minister John Lynch of the Irish Republic to discuss the crisis in Ulster.

title: 3 Arab Nations Vote on a Union
description: CAIRO, Sept. 1  Millions Iined up at polling places today to mark a red circle on a ballot to signify their assent to a federation with Syria and Libya, or a black circle if they disapproved of the new venture toward Arab unity.

title: Merger News
description: The Northrop Corporation, a maker of aircraft and communications and electronics equipment, announced yesterday that it was holding discussions to acquire the George A. Fuller Company, a privately owned, buildingconstruction concern with annual sales of more than $150million. This would be Northrop's first venture into the building construction field. The Fuller concern, formed many years ago in New York, built the General Motors Building and the corporate headquarters of the Columbia Broadcasting System, both in New York.

title: State Tax Collections Lag, But How Much Is Disputed
description: ALBANY, Sept. 1 (AP)State tax collections are running behind last year's, but official reports on the situation differed today as to how much.

title: SATELLITE ON JOB AFTER 1,000 DAYS
description: The Orbiting Astronomical Observatory, a satellite marking its 1,000th working day in space today, has discovered what scientists suspect is one of the mysterious black holes in the sky, a remnant of a star that has shrunk to such density that no light can leave it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmental Protection Head Picks New York Regional Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, named today administrators for regional offices in New York, Denver and Atlanta

title: State Bank Board Blocks 3 Proposals for Mergers
description: The New York State Banking Board, in parallel decisions that tightened significantly the guidelines governing bank mergers in the state, denied yesterday three proposed acquisitions of small banks by major bank holding companies.

title: Company Brings Suit to Fight 5Acre Zoning in Jersey Area
description: The JohnsManville Corporation has brought suit against the New Jersey Township of Bedminster In what is believed to be the first challenge by a national building organization to largelot residential zoning in the New York suburban area.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1As the public schools open for the fall term, busing continues to be both a scare word and a straw man for those who are opposed to or dubious about desegregation. Busing also continues to be the only real hope for achieving substantial desegregation in the North and the larger cities of the South; and it Is therefore potentially one of the most important instruments for improving American education.

title: 3 Shot in Pittsburgh Fight
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (UPI) A quarrel between a police sergeant and a black man at a bus stop in the city's Hill district today led to a shooting in which the two men and a bystander were wounded. Sgt. Harold Friedman, 47 years old, was wounded in the stomach. John Mangam, 26, identified as his assailant, suffered a leg wound. The bystander, Walter Bailey, 77, was struck in the leg by a bullet.

title: Fashion Stressed In Israel's Apparel
description: Israel's devaluation of her currency will offer some assistance to apparel manufacturers exporting to the United States, but fashion and quality considerations will be the prime factors in expanding their market, Robert Keller, president of ATID, a nonprofit organization for promotion of Israeli goods, said here yesterday.

title: Poll Finds 75% of Voters Think Lindsay Wants to Be President
description: Most voters think. Mayor Lindsay wants to be President, but only about a third of them think he will ever win the Democratic nomination, according to a Gallup poll released yesterday.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily correspond to those in other financial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: Orthweins Win in Polo
description: TOUGHKENAMON, Pa., Sept. 2St. Louis scored three goals in the final chukker tonight and defeated the Fairfield County Hunt Club, 117, in a quarterfinal of the Gerald Balding memorial eight  goal polo tournament at the Brandywine Polo Club. Steve Orthwein scored six goals for St. Louis. His father, Dolph, chipped in with three and his brother, Dolph Jr., scored two. The Potomac Polo Club of Washington turned back the Myopia Hunt Club of Hamilton, Mass., 98 in overtime.

title: Powell Bars Race for Reelection As a District Leader in Harlem
description: Former Representative Adam Clayton Powell has declined to run for reelection Sept. 14 for a Harlem district leadership position he has held since 1958 in Part A of the 74th Assembly District.

title: CITY UNIT TO FOCUS ON TRANSIT BONDS
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue and the possible restructuring of New York City government will be the subject of public hearings conducted by the Mayor's Commission on StateCity Relations later this month.

title: COSMOS BOW, 1 TO 0, AFTER 121 MINUTES
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 2  Kaiser (BoyBoy) Motaung spoiled the New York Cosmos' entrance into the North American Soccer League playoffs tonight as he scored after 31 minutes 13 seconds of suddendeath overtime to give the Atlanta Chiefs a 10 victory in the twoofthreegame semifinal series.

title: Coal Production Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) The National Coal Association today estimated bituminous coal production in the United States last week at 13,265,000 tons. Production for the corresponding period in 1970 was 12,235,000 tons.

title: Clamor Continues for Seats at Kennedy Center Opening
description: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis's decision to skip the gala opening of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts next Wednesday apparently had nothing to do with the crowds that pursued and frightened her in Poland last week.

title: Bridge League to Aid United Cerebral Polsy
description: The American Contract Bridge League has announced that it will seek, to raise $250,000 next year to support research into the causes and prevention of cerebral palsy.

title: Advertising:
description: WRVR, now independent after a decade as the radio station of the Riverside Church, has taken the first two important steps toward going commercial.

title: Statehood Demagoguery
description: A group of latterday secessionists, led by Representative Bella S. Abzug of Manhattan, formally filed petitions yesterday to have the issue of statehood for New York City put on next November's ballot. The move is more likely to produce publicity for its promoters than it is progress toward solving this city's deep and desperate problems. If the petitions stand up under legal examination, the balloting on statehood and the hoopla it will generate can only divert public attention from more worthwhile and attainable goals.

title: BENJAMIN FEINFELD
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Sept. 2Benjamin B. Feinfeld of 181 Hartley Terrace, a Newark area lawyer for 42 years, died Tuesday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth, after a brief illness. His age was 64.

title: Sales Gain for Retailers
description: Although most retailers report that American consumers have not reacted significantly in the marketplace since the President announced his new economic program Aug. 15, eight of nine major retail chains announced yesterday moderate to substantial gains in business during August.

title: Two New Voters Avoid Their Fathers' Footsteps
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 2Westchester County's two United States Representatives are Republicans, but new voters in each of their families have enrolled in other parties.

title: Brian Woolf Marries Miss Harriet Dobin
description: Miss Harriet Dobin, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Rubin R. Dobin of Lawrence, L. I., was married last evening to Brian Woolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Doddy Woolf of Johannesburg, South Africa. The couple are students at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

title: OSKAR HANSEN, 79, LIBERTY SCULPTOR
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 2 (AP)  Oskar J. W. Hansen, colorful, outspoken Norwegianborn sculptor, died Tuesday at Charlottesville Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: ISRAELIS IN BATTLE 3 MILES IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2 (AP)Israeli and Lebanese forces clashed for five hours in south Lebanon today, and Lebanese Army spokesman said fighting was continuing.

title: Analysts Find Deployment Of Soviet Missiles Slowed
description: LONDON, Sept. 2In its annual survey of world military power, the International Institute for Strategic Studies said today that Soviet deployment of intercontinental ballistic missiles had slowed considerably since the beginning of 1970.

title: MISS FERRO, ON 79, WINS JUNIOR GOLF
description: CRESSKILL, N. J., Sept. 2Cindy Ferro of the Forest Hill Field Club successfully defended het Metropolitan junior girls' golf championship today with a 41, 3879 over the rolling hills of Tammy Brook Country Club's 5,165yard, par72 course. Only 10 players competed.

title: Federation Is Approved By Vote in Arab Nations
description: CAIRO, Sept. 2A loose union of Egypt, Syria and Libya, primarily intended as an Arab bulwark against Israel, received nearly unanimous endorsement in referendums yesterday in the three countries, according to official announcements today.

title: JUDGE DENIES BID TO END PAY FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) A Federal district judge denied today a request for a court order to bring the Nixon Administration's wageprice freeze to an immediate end.

title: 4 Women Challenge BallotListing Rule Of Gentlemen First
description: Four women candidates for Democratic district coleadership posts in Manhattan went to court yesterday to challenge the traditional practice of placing the man's name first on the primary ballot.

title: WESTCHESTER GETS A NEW SEWER LAW
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 2New health code provisions that for the first time make the installation of public sewers virtual requirement in new residential developments in Westchester County were made public here today.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AFishing, which was severely affected in the area by Tropical Storm Doria, has returned to normal. At The Ridge, chumming is bringing in the blues from 8 to 18 pounds and charter boats are taking marlin and tilefish at the Hudson Canyon, using squid or eel for the marlin and clams for the tile. Allison tuna, some 60pounders, also are at the canyon. Weakfish are in excellent supply along the beaches and in Barnegat Bay. Blues are being caught in the surf. Kingfish and flounder are in the bay.

title: ANOTHER BRUBECK SHOWS PIANO STYLE
description: The pianist at Trude Heller's, Ninth Street at the Avenue of the Americas, looks very much like a darkhaired Bill Evans. But he sounds more like Dave Brubeck, which is only natural because he is Mr. Brubeck's eldest son, Darius, whose quartet is making its New York debut, sharing the bill with Anita O'Day, the singer.

title: SCHWEITZER FRIENDS ORDERED TO TESTIFY
description: ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP)Two men identified as longstanding friends of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer were ordered today to answer questions in a special investigation of the justice's affairs.

title: State Hears Plea to Save Health Research Council
description: Dr. Hollis B. Ingraham, the State Health Commissioner, was reported yesterday to be receptive to a lastminute appeal by eight prominent figures in the city's medical establishment to save the Health Research Council, scheduled to be abolished at the end of this month.

title: Toyota Sales Up in August
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (Reuters) Araco Industries, Inc., said today that August wholesale sales of Toyota vehicles totaled 8,221 units, up 236 per cent from 2,446 a year before.

title: THOMAS L. PITTS, 56, COAST LABOR CHIEF
description: LAKEPORT, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP)Thomas L. Pitts, a California labor leader for more then 30 years and former president of the California Labor Federation, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 56.

title: Japan Seeks Textile Pact
description: TOKYO, Sept 2. (UPI)Japan is prepared to work out formal agreement with the United States on the textileexport issue to replace the present voluntary program, a top Government official said today.

title: $52BILLION PLAN DRAFTED BY NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The Navy has drafted an 11year, $52.3billion shipbuilding program that its planners think is necesary to modernize the fleet. The program would begin next July and run until June, 1983.

title: Ugandans Charge Tanzanian Planes Bombed a Village
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 2Gen. Idi Amin, President of Uganda, said today during a meeting in Kampala with the representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross that Tanzanian planes had bombed houses in the Uganda village of Kikagati, 230 miles southwest of Kampala. Other sources said the bombing took place yesterday.

title: ZIONIST ASKS NIXON FOR MIDEAST SHIFT
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2The head of the Zionist Organization of America called tonight on President Nixon to formulate a new diplomatic thrust in the Middle East aimed at moving the Arabs away from preconditions to peace talks that leave hardly anything open to negotiation.

title: Canadian Rider Triumphs At State Fair Horse Show
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 2Torchy Millar of the Canadian Equestrian Team rode Roman B. Good to victory in the first preliminary jumper class at the New York State Fair horse show tonight.

title: LBJ's Clashing Advisers
description: After being held on a tight civilian leash for three years, the Joint Chiefs of Staff saw the Tet crisis as the solution to the strategic reserves crisis. Not only was there a new event, the Tet offenshre, but the arrival of a new man in the Pentagon held some promise of a new strategic posture for the United States. The nemesis of the J.C.S., Robert McNamara, was being replaced by the superhawk, Clark Clifford. General Wheeler, chairman of the J.C.S., and General Westmoreland, the Vietnam commander, hoped that Clifford would be a tabula rasa on which to write their plan.

title: JUDGE BOUGHT JOB, GRAND JURY SAYS
description: A State Supreme Court justice on Long Island was accused yesterday of having bought his nomination for the post from a former Republican leader in Suffolk County for $50,000 and of having used a coded Swiss bank account to make the transaction.

title: Utility in Virginia Told To Set Up Negro Quota
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 2 (AP) A Federal judge ordered the giant Virginia Electric Power Company to hire one more black employe for every four whites.

title: Luna 18 to the Moon
description: Moscow's announcement that a new unmanned Soviet space vehicle has been launched toward the moon stirs immediate curiosity on a worldwide basis. One of Luna 18's predecessors brought back a few ounces of lunar soil, a remarkable feat since it was all done by automatic equipment. And another predecessor brought Lunokhod 1 to the moon, a mobile unmanned device which is stillafter more than half a yearexploring the moon and sending back data. Will Luna 18 unveil a new impressive capability going well beyond anything demonstrated earlier?

title: Market Place: 2 HandHolders At the Price of 1
description: If you're the nervous kind who likes to have his hand held by his broker, you might be interested in a service that by that measure at least is twice as good.

title: Altman's Picketed by 60 To Support Chair Strike
description: A demonstration was staged late yesterday afternoon outside the B. Altman department store at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street by about 60 members of the United Furniture Workers and supporters from the New York Central Labor Council.

title: Italy's Reserves Up in July
description: ROME, Sept. 2 (Reuters)Italy's net official reserves rose to 3,760,000 million lire in July from 3,745,900 million lire in June, the Bank of Italy said today.

title: Notes on People
description: The American Legion elected a new national commander at its convention in Houston. He is John H. Geiger, an architect and executive of United Air Lines who lives in Des Plaines, Ill. Mr. Geiger succeeds Alfred P. Chamie, a Los Angeles lawyer as commander of the Legion, which claims a membership of 2.7 million.

title: City Block: On 85th, An Uneasy Safety
description: When the people who live on 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue say that it is a good block, they mean that they feel more or less safe there. Nearly everyone knows of someone who has been robbed or mugged, of course, but nearly everyone also believes that he is considerably better off than someone who lives, say, a block away across Columbus Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Connors Defeats Olmedo in Five Sets
description: Youth had its fling yesterday in the United States Open tennis championships, from Jim Connors, a 19yearold protege of Pancho Gonzales to Chris Evert, the 16yearold Little Miss Sunshine.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AGENCY URGES NEW OIL DRILLING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The Department of the Interior has proposed the resumption of oil drilling in the Santa Barbara Channel area off the coast of California, scene of an oil well blowout in 1969 that polluted beaches and killed wildlife.

title: White House Comment
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 2Asked today for the White House's response to President Thieu's decision to proceed. with the Oct. 3 election in Vietnam, President Nixon's press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, commented:

title: Britaln's Bank Rate Cut To Ster a Dollar in low
description: PARIS, Sept. 2The British bank rate was cut from 6 per cent to 5 per cent today in a further British move to keep the pound from floating too high against the dollar.

title: Garment Gains Are Foreseen for Fall
description: Production of women's and children's coats and suits has taken a decided turn for the better in the last two months, Henoch Mendelsund, a vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said yesterday. He held that this is an indication of muchimproved fall season for the industry.

title: ChinaU.S. Phone Link, Cut in '68, Is Resumed
description: China has agreed to reestablish telephone service with the United States through a Japanese link, a snokesman for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company confirmed yesterday.

title: ART COLLECTOR INDICTED IN THEFT
description: A Greenwich, Conn. man was arrested here yesterday by the police of the Manhattan District Attorney's office on a 46count indictment charging him with stealing $840,000 by using false information and documents to get a loan for that amount.

title: Screen: Killer Pursues Mia Farrow in 'See No Evil':Fleischer Directs a Work by Clemens Relatives of a Blind Woman Murdered
description: After an afternoon of pleasant horseback riding, Sarah's young man deposits her at the front door of her uncle's magnificent country house, where, just up from London, she is staying. She rattles around the dear old place in the gathering dusk plays something on the phonograph, and finally sinks into bed. The next morning she is up and not even after she has made her own breakfast and begun to draw her bath does she realize that she is not alone. Her uncle, her aunt and her lovely cousin are all around herthey never even kept last night's engagements  but Sarah does not notice them because she is blind, and they are very quiet, being dead.So long as this sequence lasts, perhaps 30 minutes out of a total hour and a half, "See No Evil," has its share of thrills. Cheap thrills, to be sure, but thrills nonethelessand everything in the rest of Richard Fleischer's new movie, which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, encourages us to value small favors.Whoever shot her family has not yet finished, so long as Sarah lives. And the pursuit of the terrified Sarah (Mia Farrow), through the great house, over hill, over dale, and into a sodden clay pit, gives a shape to his taskin which the audience is always busier than the killer, mostly in following the false leads that the screenplay and the camera have set up for it. Of these, none is more insistent, nor ultimately more objectionable, than a kind of surly, decline-of-the-class-system sub-plot that is supposed to provide a motive and a murderer, but that actually provides little more than eyewash to confuse the customers.Attempting on the one hand to mean something and on the other hand trying to crank up the terror, Fleischer keeps suggesting confrontations between the rich and the poor, the old and the young, families with daughters to protect and men with warped desires. For all the potency of a camera movement, it can never have exactly the power of a conceptual image, and therefore "See No Evil" is better with its mindless terror than with its witless meaning. And although everything becomes far too much long before it is over, the movie is generally at it most ridiculous precisely where it hopes to make sense.Right at the start, during the main titles, Fleischer begins observing his killer's boots  so you can see the kind of guy he is, of course, and where he walks and what the world is like as he walks it by, but mostly so you can recognize him without knowing who he is. This begins a sustained concentration on boots and shoes, bare feet, bloody feet, muddy feetreally, above and beyond the call of plot and duty. Any cineaste will assume "Buel." But it is all as if Fleischer had taken on the mechanics of the great man's obsession without its passion, and "See No Evil" lacks even that small scandalous interest.What interest the film does have comes from the performance of Miss Farrow (I also liked Robin Bailey, Dorothy Alison and Diane Grayson as the uncle, aunt and cousin  before their untimely immobilization), who seems to the manor born and who plays her blind patrician with exactly the right small depth of pathos and vulnerable nobility. She has been a better actress in better movies ("Rosemary's Baby" and "Secret Ceremony") but she is more than good enough here, and I wish that she could lead a more normal life for once in somebody's film. Probably every man wishes it, with himself across the table, and that is why she is where she is, in perpetual peril and needing assistance.

title: IMPORTERS HAIL EASED SURCHARGE
description: The Treasury action one Wednesday granting some exemptions from the new 10 per cent import surcharge was hailed yesterday by importers as a welcome relief from the financial squeeze imposed on them by the sudden rise in duty charges.

title: Part of South Bronx Designated A Federal Redevelopment Area
description: A major part of the South Bronx, including some of the most deprived areas of the borough, has been designated a special redevelopment area by the Federal Government's Department of Commerce, it was disclosed here yesterday.

title: Unmanned Soviet Vehicle Launched on Moon Voyage
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2  The Soviet Union launched an unmanned spacecraft, Luna, 18, toward the moon tonight.

title: Theater
description: EDINBURGH, Sept. 2 None of us are getting any younger but it comes as surprise to realize that the Edinburgh International festival is now 25 years old. It has come a long way since it was first a glint in Rudolf Bing's eye, and the present festival is, typically enough, a feast, almost an orgy of culture.

title: PRICE COMPLAINTS CLLECKED BY PHONE
description: Although thevolume of complaints about violations of the Federal wageprice freeze has mushroomed here in the last few days, the Internal Revenue Service still is relying almost entirely on voluntary compliance to enforce the freeze.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyThe one crisis nobody wants to hear about is Cyprus and yet this familiar little volcano seems to be getting ready to explode again. The world already has its hands full with monetary troubles, Middle East troubles, SinoRussian troubles, North Irish troubles, winding down the Vietnam war and winding up the economy. It detests the thought of another headache in Cyprus.

title: Newton Cleared for Trial
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge Robert Kroninger cleared the way today for a third trial for Huey P. Newton when he denied a petition to stay proceedings. The Black Panther leader is charged with voluntary manslaughter in the death of a police officer, John Frey.

title: Watson Admits Killing 7 Under Manson's Influence
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 (AP) Charles (Tex) Watson admitted at his trial today that he had killed Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other persons in August, 1969.

title: Two Companies in Accord In Diesel Engine Research
description: Maschinenfabrik AugsburgNuernberg, A.G., of West Germany, and Sulzer Brothers, Ltd., of Switzerland, announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement to coordinate their efforts in diesel engine research, development and design.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: I.C.C. AIDE BACKS SALE OF C.&N.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) An Interstate Commerce Commission hearing examiner recommended today that employes of the Chicago & North Western railway be allowed to purchase the line from. Northwest Industries, Inc., the parent company.

title: Yanks Deal Senators 111 Lacing;
description: Stan Bahnsen of the Yankees had a most pleasing and unusual experience last night at Yankee Stadium. As he walked to the mound to start the third inning against the Washington Senators, he enjoyed an 110 lead.

title: SAIGON GENERALS SPLIT ON ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A United States intelligence report says that South Vietnam's military leaders are less than unanimous in supporting President Nguyen Van Thieu in his determination to run in the Oct. 3 elections even though he is unopposed.

title: HelpWanted Ad Index Rose Two Points in July
description: The helpwanted advertising index rose two points in July to stand at 85 per cent of the 1967 average, the Conference Board reported yesterday. It was the third consecutive month in which the index has risen but the July figure was still six points under the 91 average in July of 1970.

title: 2 Uruguay Policemen Killed
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 2 (AP)  Three armed terrorists were reported to have shot two policemen to death today in an attack on a hospital here. The police said they believed the three belonged to the Tupamaros, an urban guerrilla group.

title: Gentry's 6Hitter Beats Phils, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2The posters round town advertise, Baseball  like never before, and that's what worries Frank Lucchesi. His Philadelphia Phillies, who have hit bottom the National League East, may be playing baseball as never before.

title: Minor Misfortunes Plague the Giants
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 2 Minor misfortunes continued to pile up for the New York Giants of today, whatever Paradise awaits them eventually across the Hudson River.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE OFF FROM '70 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Aug. 28 was below the volume in the corresponding week last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: A New reed of Lobbyist: They Argue for the Public's Cause
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2They stood on street corners collecting petitions for Eugene McCarthy in 1968, and they rallied for Earth Day in 1970, and they have been asked a hundred times, O.K., so you don't like the state of society. What are you going to do about it?

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON BOND MARKET
description: The bond market, despite reports of purchases by the Federal Reserve and a cut in the British bank rate from 6 per cent to 5 per cent, responded unevenly yesterday and prices finished mixed.

title: Communist Chinese Film Previewed at Venice
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 2The Chinese film Red Detachment of Women, which will be presented officially at,, the Venice Festival tomorrow evening with Communist China's envoy to Italy, Shen Ping, attending, was shown to the press this morning.

title: SEARS CUP SERIES IS TAKEN BY SCOTT
description: OXFORD, Md., Sept. 2Charlie Scott became the first Chesapeake Bay sailor to win a North American Yacht Racing Union championship as, he carried the Annapolis Yacht Club colors to first place today in the Sears Cup regatta for juniors.

title: T.W.A. Laying Off 260 at Kansas City
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it would lay off about 260 mechanics and other technicians at its Kansas City jet maintenance base on Sept. 12 because of the nation's continuing slump in air travel.

title: Questions and Answers on the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Following is the 13th set of official questions and answers issued by President Nixon's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: MRS. JOHNSON FAINTS ON TOUR OF ROCKIES
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., Sept. 2Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson suffered a fainting spell, apparently because of the high altitude, and was unconscious for several minutes today at the 12,183foot Fall River Pass in the Rocky Mountain National Park near here. Doctors said tonight that she had suffered no ill effects.

title: Books of The Times
description: RODEO! The Suicide Circuit. Text and photographs by Fred Schnell. Rand McNally.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Policemen in Carty Case Dismissed by Atlanta Unit
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 2 (UPI)Three city policemen accused of beating the Atlanta Braves' baseball star, Rico Carty, and his brotherinlaw were dismissed from their jobs today.

title: Mrs. Farmer's 82 Wins Golf
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Sept. 2Mrs. Henry Farmer of Glen Ridge shot a 46, 3682 today to win a Women's New Jersey Golf Association oneday tournament at the Somerset Hills Country Club by four strokes. Mrs. Farmer led a field of 34. Mrs. R. D. Stitzer of Somerset was second, with 44, 4286.

title: President vs. Congress
description: News Analysis

title: Bridge: Play in the Knickerbocker To Get Under Way Today
description: The Knickerbocker Championships, one of the world's oldest established tournaments, begins at the New York Hilton Hotel today under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

title: SIGNING OF PACT ON BERLIN PUT OFF
description: BERLIN, Sept. 2  The Big Four ran afoul today of the complexities of the German language in their attempt to issue a translation of their accord on Berlin. This delayed the signing of the documents for at least 24 hours, and perhaps for several days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Trevino Hale, Hearty For Wethers field Golf
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 2  Lee Trevino returned to competitive golf today after an absence of four weeks from the pro circuit, most of which was spent recovering from an appendectomy.

title: Mr. Richardson's Surrender
description: Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Richard. son, in bowing to President Nixon's antibusing rhetoric and proclaiming it the department's avowed policy, appears to have chosen a familiar political trail. Still visible on that trail are the footsteps of Robert H. Finch, Mr. Richardson's predecessor. He, too, had walked away from his subordinates who felt it their duty to enforce the desegregation law, despite White House orders to put oftstated principles in cold storage.

title: GEORGE J. BRETT, 71, UTILITIES OFFICIAL
description: George J. Brett, former director and financial vice president of Niagara Mohawk Power Company and former chairman of the Canadian Niagara Power Coinpany, died yesterday in Lenox Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla., and at 530 Park Avenue.

title: DOLLAR SELLING IS BRISK IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2 (Reuters)Fears that the yen might be formally revalued sooner than previously expected caused a rush by Tokyo banks selling dollars on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today.

title: Seoul Denies It Is Weighing Full Vietnam Pullout in 1971
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 21 (AP)  South Korean officials today denied a report in The New York Times that their Government is considering the withdrawal of the 48,000man Korean force in Vietnam by the end of this year.

title: Oldsmobile Shows '72 Models, plans Small Car in '73
description: DETROIT, Sept. 2 (UPI)The Oldsmobile Division of the General Motors Corporation unveiled today its 1972 line, which has only faceliftMg styling changes but features a pew front bumper capable of withstanding parkinglot crashes of up to five miles an hour without damage.

title: President Will Deliver Labor Day Radio Talk
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 2The White House announced today that President Nixon would deliver nationwide radio speech at noon on Monday, Labor Day.

title: Guild in Plea to Lindsay
description: The Screen Actors Guild urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to use all possible means to resolve the stalemated contract negotiations between Paramount Pictures and Local 52 of the International Association of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators, which has led to the removal of three films that had been planned for New York production.

title: TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2In this part of the world, officials don't quite know what to make of President Nixon. They understand and even approve the logic of his moves in defense of the dollar and for better relations with China, but they don't understand his timing, his tactics or his style.

title: F.B.I. INVESTIGATES STATE DEPT. LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 State Department personnel are being questioned by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in an effort to determine how recent sensitive information leaked to the press, the department's press spokesman disclosed today.

title: Skelton in Greece 2 Years
description: John R. Skelton, one of four persons detained in Greece on plotting charges, had been in Greece for two years, studying Greek Orthodox theology at the University of Athens.

title: No Time for Bullying
description: If I thought that the spirit of the swaggering bullyboy displayed in Pierre Rinfret's OpEd article August 30 really reflected the mood of the Administration, I would be dismayed. I cannot, however, believe that to be the case.

title: Defending the Freeze
description: President Nixon can make a major contribution in his television speech on Labor Day to rebuilding unified national support for his ninetyday wageprice freeze, now the target of widespread and often illreasoned union attack.

title: Spokane Loses Ball Club
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 2 (UPI)The Los Angeles Dodgers announced today they would move their Pacific Coast League team from Spokane to Albuquerque, N. M., next year. The Dodgers' Dixie Association club drew 190,000 in Albuquerque this season, compared with 137,000 who saw games in Spokane.

title: City Maps Legal Moves To Halt Welfare Fraud
description: Measures to tighten administration of the welfare program and to step up the criminal prosecution of cheaters were drafted yesterday by Jule M. Sugarman, the Human Resources Administrator, and representatives of the five New York City District Attorneys' offices.

title: I.T.T. BANK FUNDS BLOCKED BY CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 2Bank accounts of the Americanowned Chilean Telephone Company were blocked by Government order today in apparent preparation for nationalization of the utility.

title: Thieu Terms Vote Test of Confidence
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that he would view next month's presidential voting as a test of public confidence in his administration even though only his name would be on the ballot.

title: N. A. ROCKWELL DEAL WITH COLLINS IS SET
description: The North American Rockwell Corporation announced yesterday it has consummated its stock purchase agreement under which It will make a $35million cash investment in Collins Radio Company.

title: For Weekend Chef: Eggplant and Steak
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Pound Circulation Increases 2.17Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England account for the week ended yesterday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: U.S. Appeals Court Denies Whelan a Reduction in Bail
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 (AP) A Federal appeals court refused today to reduce bail for former Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City and seven others convicted in the Hudson County extortionconspiracy case.

title: Lana J. Miele Has Nuptials
description: In the BethEl Chapel at Temple EmanuEl yesterday morning, Miss Lana Jane Miele, daughter of Mrs. Jene Gerald Miele of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Miele, was married to Lawrence Teller Simon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Simon of Elkins Park, Philadelphia, Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Commodity Index at 108.1 Unchanged, During Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials remained unchanged from 108.1 last week.

title: 2 Arrested by Police in Bronx As WouldBe Gambling Bribers
description: Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday after they allegedly tried to bribe a captain and a sergeant of the Police Department's inspections division to let an illegal gambling ring operate freely in the central part of the Bronx.

title: ADELE GARRETT
description: Adele Garrett, a freelance book editor who worked for a number of leading publishing houses in the Northeast, died last Monday in New York Hospital at the age of 76. She lived at 425 East 79th Street and was the widow of Edmund Garrett.

title: Parochial School Busing Is Invalidated in Idaho
description: BOISE, Idaho, Sept. (UPI)A divided Idaho Supreme Court has ruled unconstitutional a statute allowing the use of state funds for the busing of parochial school students.

title: Cahill Puts Storm Damage In State at $138.5Million
description: TRENTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) Gov. William T. Cahill told President Nixon today that New Jersey had suffered over $138.5million worth of damage from tropical storm Doria.

title: HOCKEY TRANSACTIONS
description: PHILADELPHIASigned Rick MacLeish and Bob Kelly, left wings, and Larry Brown, defenseman.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES HIGHER AT FINISH
description: The possibility that the soybean harvest will be seriously affected by drought brought about cautious short covering in the trading of soybeans futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: 19 U.S. Combat Deaths in Week Highest in Almost Two Months
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 (AP)  The United States command announced today that 19 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week. It was the highest weekly toll in seven weeks.

title: Prices on Amex Rise as Volume Grows
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished higher yesterday in slightly steppedup trading.

title: MARKET REMAINS IN THE DOLDRUMS
description: The stock market proved it self yesterday almost a carbon copy of Wednesday's session. It inched ahead in slow trading as the happiest investors were those already embarked on their long Labor Day weekend.

title: Executive Changes
description: Philip Morris, Inc., announced yesterday the election of John A. Murphy, 41 years old, as chairman and chief executive officer of Miller Brewing Company, a subsidiary. Miller Brewing, with sales of about $200million, has been without a chairman since the resignation of Charles W. Miller early in 1971. Mr. Miller returned to Marquette University as a professor in its graduate school of business administration. B. William Kostecke will continue as president and treasurer of the Milwaukee brewing company. He was elected president in January, 1970. Since 1967, Mr. Murphy has been executive vice president of Philip Morris International. He will continue as a vice president of Philip Morris, Inc., a position he has held since mid1967. Before joining Philip Morris in 1962, he was a member of the New York City law firm of Conboy, Hewitt, O'Brien, Boardman. Miller Brewing is the seventh largest brewer in the United States and sells its major brand, Miller High Life Beer, in all 50 states and 56 other countries.

title: NORFOLK ORDERED TO EXPAND BUSING
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 2 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit overturned a lower court decision today and told Norfolk that it must operate its schools in 197172 under a new desegregation plan requiring the busing of 18,000 pupils.

title: Canada's Reserves Rise
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press)Canada's foreign exchange reserves rose to a record $4.99billion at the end of August, with a sharp increase in official holdings of United States dollars, the Finance Department reported today.

title: Mexican Cuisine Goes From Delicate to Fiery
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: 9 SMUT RAIDS MADE ON TIMES SQ. STORES
description: The police raided seven Times Square bookstores yesterday and charged their operators with promoting obscenity. Two of the stores were raided a second time after they had reopened.

title: Juror Says Hanrahan Panel At First Refused to Indict
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP)A member of the grand jury that indicted State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan said today that, after the jurors first voted to return no indictments, the special prosecutor, Barnabas F. Sears, told them he was not pleased. Mr. Sears then talked to the jurors for 90 minutes to persuade them to return the indictments, the member said.

title: Pablo Vargas Badillo, ExEditor Of San Juan's El Mundo, Is Dead
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 2Pablo Vargas Badillo, one of the island's most prominent newspapermen and for 22 years the editor of El Mundo, Puerto Rico's largest newspaper, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 63 years old.

title: Convicts in Delaware Seize 3 Guards, Then Free Them
description: SMYRNA, ??, Sept. 3 (UPI) Inmates in the maximum security wing of the Delaware Correctional Institution took three guards hostage tonight and ransacked several prison offices. But they released their hostages after discussing grievances with reporters and prison officials.

title: Cities Question Allocation of Emergency Job Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The Nixon Administration has moved quickly to implement a $2.25  billion emergency employment bill made law on July 12, but public officials across the nation are questioning the manner in which funds, are being allocated.

title: Tour Finds Little Evidence of Philippine Rebels
description: ECHAGUE, the Philippines Sept. 2The main base of activity of the Communist insurgent force, according to President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile, is here in the northern Luzon province of Isabela. But a tour of the province disclosed little evidence of the mounting rebellion Mr. Marcos and Mr. Enrile describe.

title: LEVISS NOW BACKS PLAN FOR STADIUM
description: A switch in the Board of Estimate virtually assures, approval of Mayor Lindsay's plan to acquire and renovate Yankee Stadium and keep the Yankees in New York, board members and their deputies indicated yesterday.

title: In Behaviorist's Ideal State, Control Replaces Liberty
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.B. F. Skinner, who is widely viewed: among his peers as the most influential psychologist in the country, paused between bites of a ham and cheese sandwich the other day to talk about his latest book, an uninhibited assault on some of the Western world's most prized ideals.

title: NORTH VIETNAMESE BATTLE BIG FLOODS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam (AP) Sept. 2North Vietnam has mobilized thousands of troops and civilians to fight the country's worst floods since World War II, the Hanoi radio reported today.

title: Susan Ludel Is Bride of Professor
description: Miss Susan Ludel, East Coast picture editor of TV Guide magazine, was married here yesterday evening to Dr. Leonard Peikoff, an associate professor of philosophy at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, and son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Peikoff of Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 2 (UPI)Israeli troops and Arab guerrillas exchanged smallarms fire and mortar fire today at the foothills of Mount Hermon in Lebanon, the military command said. An announcement said six Arab guerrillas were hit in the battle north of Har Dov. No Israeli casualties were reported.

title: 6 BELFAST BLASTS HURT 39 AND RUIN OFFICES OF PARTY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 2Six bombs exploded in downtown Belfast today within minutes of one another, injuring 39 persons, and wrecking the headquarters of the governing Unionist party.

title: Next for Zeffirelli: Film on Jesus
description: ROME  Socialism has turned out to be a grim joke and democracy seems to be going to pieces. The nineteenseventies, will be a decade of spiritual reawakening.

title: U.S. Court Orders Catena Freed In Voiding Jersey Immunity Law
description: NEWARK, Sept. 2  Gerardo (Jerry) Catena, the reputed Mafia leader in New Jersey, was ordered released from state custody today by a Federal Court ruling that struck down New Jersey's witness immunity law.

title: THOMAS GREENLEY JR.
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., Sept. 2Thomas D. Greenley Jr., for the last 22 years professor of advertising art and design at the State University at Farmingdale, died yesterday at Brunswick General Hospital here after a, long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 37 Hamilton Avenue

title: U.S. Plans Court House Annex To Replace Detention Facility
description: Plans were announced yesterday for the construction of two eightstory buildings to re place the antequated Federal House of Detention on West Street and provide new offices) for the United States Attorney here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Friends in his native California tossed a party for Vernon (Lefty) Gomez in Palo Alto the night before last and there may never have been a sports bash to match this one for unusual motivation.
