It was unashamedly designed to give a hotfoot to the OldTimers Committee of the Baseball Hall of Fame, jolting it to the realization that behind the patina of classic Gomez flippancies is a pitching record that can withstand scrutiny.

title: 2 Greenwich Village Raids Yield $750,000 in Drugs
description: Thirteen persons were arrested and more than $750,900 in narcotics was confiscated in two drug raids in Greenwich Village Wednesday night.

title: 109710 Wins in Jersey
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., Sept 2 (AP)  This week's winning New Jersey lottery number is 109710. Holders of tickets with all six digits win $50,000; with the last five digits, $4,000; with the last four, $400; the last three, $40, and the last two, a free ticket in a millionaire lottery drawing.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Rise
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $175million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 99.035 and average yield of 3.91 per cent, compared with last week's 99.064 and 3.79 per cent. Today's $40million of 182day bills brought 98.013 and 4.97 per cent, against last week's 98.062 and 3.96 per cent.

title: 55,398 Petitioners Ask City for a Vote On Becoming State
description: Petitions for a referendum here in November on the question of statehood for New York City were filed yesterday by Representative Bella S. Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan.

title: Roundup: Astro Blooper Played Into a Grand Slam
description: Cesar Cedeno, who hit only seven home runs in his rookie season at Houston last year, smacked a 200foot, grandslam homer last night in the Astrodome in rallying the Astros to a 93 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Buddhist Monks Quietly Lead Campaign Against Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2In the growing wave of criticism directed against President Nguyen Van Thieu, who will be the only candidate in the presidential election next month, some of the sharpest and most scornful attacks come from the leaders of the An Quang Pagoda. The Buddhist monks keep their voices low, but their followers hear them clearly.

title: BELL BREAKS OFF CONTRACT TALKS
description: The New York Telephone Company broke off contract negotiations yesterday with its striking workers, charging that its equipment was being sabotagdthat cables had been cut in Queens and Suffolk County.

title: American and Chinese Discuss Film Exchange
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 2Marc Spiegel of the Motion Picture Producers of America, representing Jack Valenti, met today with Pi lisiensheng cultural attach of Communist. China's embassy here. They discussed a SinoAmerican filth exchange.

title: Advertising:
description: ACTION, the new citizens service corps conglomerate, has named Geer, duBois, the former Peace Corps agency, to handle its national advertising program, and Zebra Associates for the national minority group recruitment effort.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX OF AUGUST PRICES CLIMBED SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Wholesale prices, both food and industrial, rose strongly in August, the Labor Department reported today. The rise confirmed a general worsening of the price picture since the temporary improvement of last fall and winter.

title: Mrs. Day's Foursome Takes BestBall Golf by 3 Shots
description: SCARBOROUGH  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 2Mrs. Harry M. Day of Woodway, Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow, Mrs. Harold Kilpatrick of New Canaan and Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot scored 39, 3675 at Sleepy Hollow Country Club today to win the bestballoffoursomes tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association by three strokes.

title: Hospital and Tenants Agree On Pact to Save Apartments
description: Columbus Hospital and three plaintiffs who had filed a suit to halt the hospital's construction of a new building on East 19th Street announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached.

title: Effervescent Staff Chief
description: Woman in the News

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Bend Sales Top Cashins
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (Reuters)Sales of Series E and H savings bonds outweighed redemptions by $134million in August, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: Friends Fear for Diabetic Lady Fleming, Held as Athens Plotter
description: ATHENS, Sept. 2Friends of Lady Fleming, who was arrested here early Tuesday with three others on charges of plotting to free a man who tried to assassinate the Premier, expressed concern here today for her health.

title: Black Girl Jockey Victor
description: CHESTER, W. Va., Sept. (AP)Cheryl White, 17 years old, of Rome, Ohio, became the first black girl jockey in American thoroughbred history to win a race, scoring tonight at Waterford Park. She rode Jetolara, owned and trained by her father, Raymond A. White, to victory in the third race.

title: Dividends Up, but Concerns See No Violation of Spirit of Freeze
description: Some American corporations have found a way to increase their dividends to stockholders and at the same time maintain they are staying within the spirit of President Nixon's call for voluntary restraints.

title: CERF LEFT ESTATE OF OVER 1MILLION
description: Bennett Cerf, the publisher and television personality who died last Friday at the age of 73, left an estate valued at more than $1million, according to his will, which was offered for probate in Manhattan Surrogate Court yesterday.

title: Friends of Michael Romanoff Plan Coast Memorial Service
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 There will be no funeral services for Michael Romanoff, the selfstyled Russian prince who was one of the most beloved impostors Hollywood has ever harbored.

title: THE POST TO APPEAL ORDER ON HIRING BIAS
description: The publisher of The New York Post announced yesterday that her newspaper would appeal to the State Division of Human Rights an order of the agency directing the paper to reinstate a black reporter who was dismissed during his probationary period.

title: TYPICAL SMOKER: FACTORY MAN, 35
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The typical American cigarette smoker is a 35yearold male factory worker who earns $6,000 a year.

title: HARRY KUFFLER, 76, BROKERAGE PARTNER
description: Harry A. Kuffler, a general partner in David J. Greene & Co., stockbrokers of 30 Wall Street, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at the Dorset Hotel.

title: Albany Mayor Calls The State Capitol A Big Horseroom
description: ALBANY, Sept. 2  Mayor Erastus Corning 2d charged today that the biggest horseroom between New York and Chicago is the State Capitol.

title: Farasopoulos Making It With Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 2 He has a full head of curly hair, wears a peace ring that cost $4 and shares Room 1201 with John Rigging, the Jets' No. 1 draft choice, in the Hofstra dormitory.

title: FederalCity Force Fighting Narcotics Is Quadrupled Here
description: The quadrupling of the Federal  City Joint Narcotics Enforcement Task Force to 172 agents108 of them from the New York Police Departmentwas announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay, who said the plan might spread elsewhere as a model for similar Federalurban operations.

title: Widnall Holds Lead
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 2Bill Widnall of this port finished fourth in the sixth race of the International OneDesign Class world championship today. With one race remaining, only members of the Marblehead fleet have a chance to civertake him for the lead.

title: VITO F. LANZA, 75, OF SCHOOL BOARD
description: Vito F. Lanza, a former vice president of the Board of Education and a lawyer who pray ticed iri Brooklyn 54 years, died yesterday in St. John's Queens Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 3091 38th Street, Long Island City, Queens.

title: McLean and Pearce Share Amateur Lead With 139's
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. (AP)Jim McLean and Eddie Pearce gained a tie for the secondround lead in the 71st annual United States Amateur golf championship today with threeunderpar 139's.

title: General Signal Unit Given Washington Transit Order
description: The General Signal Corporation announced yesterday that its General Railway Signal Company unit has been awarded a $42,074,675 contract by the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority covering the automatic train control system.

title: MRS. JOSEPH GERARDI
description: Mrs. Frances Piazza Gerardi, who with her husband, Joseph, formerly operated the Dellwood Hotel in Purling, N. Y., died yesterday in Albert Einstein Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived in Hollywood, Fla.

title: Exacta Pays $1,868.40 at Belmont as Adams Rides Vivare to a $127 Triumph
description: Larry Adams received the news on showing up for work at Belmont Park yesterday that he had been fined $100 by the stewards for reporting late to the jockeys' room after repeated warnings. The seasoned jockey took the punishment as a matter of course, then went about his task of fulfilling his riding obligations.

title: Ashland Buys Stock
description: ASHLAND, Ky., Sept. 2 (Reuters)  Ashland Oil, Inc., said today it has purchased one million shares of the Oil Shale Corporation. The purchase price was $5million. As a result of the transaction Oil Shale Corporation now has about 17.8 million shares outstanding and about 2.4 million shares reserved for the exercise of options and warrants.

title: Soviet Publicizes Assurances By Rogers on Better Relations
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2The Soviet press gave prominence today to assurances by Secretary of State William P. Rogers that the United States does not want its contacts with Peking to jeopardize its continuing dialogue with Moscow.

title: CITY APPROVES PAY FOR CONSULTANTS
description: The payment of six outside consultant engineering contracts totaling $593,885 was approved unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate after some members called for the recruitment of unemployed, engineers into city government to cut down on the city's use of private consultants.

title: I.R.A. Chief Ordered Held Here Pending Visa Ruling
description: Joe Cahill, the 51yearold leader of the militant provisiorial wing the Irish Republican Army, Was held in a guarded dormitory yesterday after a hearing on the revocation of his United States visa had been adjourned until next Tuesday.

title: Two Desperate Hours: How George Jackson Died
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Sept. 2At 1:15 on Saturday afternoon, Aug. 21, George Jackson, 29 years old, the convict and author of Soledad Brother, put his prison denims back on after a thorough search and followed a guard to the prison visiting center to meet with a lawyer.

title: TWO REGISTRATIONS REVOKED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the registration of two New York brokerage houses.

title: P.B.A. Head Says Murphy Is Destroying Police Force
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that the changes instituted by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy were causing the systematic destruction of the finest police department in the world.

title: Priest Begins Boston Vigil
description: BOSTON, Sept. 2 (AP)  A Roman Catholic priest has begun a vigil of fasting and prayer in front of the residence of the Most Rev, Humberto S. Medeiros, Archbishop of Boston, to persuade him to sign a contract to build a parish school. He is the Rev. D. George Spagnolia, assistant pastor of St. Francis de Sales Church in Roxbury.

title: OTB's Chain Grows to 20
description: A model from Brooklyn helped introduce a new fashion to the Garment District yesterday: offtrack betting.

title: Simplified Justice
description: In an experiment in justice Abbie Hoffman is being sued before a counterculture tribunal. The essence this suit beyond the bourgeois looking glass is that the Yippie leader failed to pay Tom Forcade, an underground news man; for helping him turn out Steal This Book, a bestseller that tells antiEstablishment types how rip off food, clothes, subway rides and telephone calls but not, it seems, literary labors.

title: City Takes Over the Beaumont; Plans $5.2Million Remodeling
description: The $12million Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, home of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, was taken over by the city yesterday for $.1, with the Board of Estimate approving $5.2million to remodel it.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 2The Commerce Department today estimated last week's departinent store sales at $833million, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $756million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,556,000,000, up 6 per cent from $7,127,000,000.

title: Alabama House Passes Antibusing Bill
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 2 (UPI)  The Alabama House officially endorsed Gov. George C. Wallace's fight against busing today by passing a hill to allow a child to attend any school regardless of Federal court orders.

title: GOMEZ STOPS SAIJO IN 5TH TO TAKE TITLE
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2 (UPI) Antonio Gomez became the second Venezuelan to win a world boxing title in Japan in two months by knocking out the World Boxing Association featherweight champion, Shozo, Saijo, tonight in the fifth round of their scheduled 15round match.

title: Lane Bryant Profit Up;
description: A highly mixed pattern of sales and earnings results is shown by a group of companies in the retail, apparel and fabric manufacturing businesses, according to their reports issued yesterday for the second quarter and halfyear periods ending with July.

title: Slower Expansion Rate Shown in Money Supply
description: The Federal Reserve System, after four months of trying hard, may at last be achieving a measure of success in slowing the rate of expansion in the nation's money supply from the excessive pace characteristic since last spring.

title: 10 Killed in Indian Stampede
description: NEW DELHI, Sept 2 (AP) Ten persons were killed and four injured in Udaipur today when thousands of prospective motorscooter buyers smashed through police lines to register for the vehicles. The victims were said to have suffocated. A person wishing to buy a motorscooter in India must wait an average of nine years after registration for delivery.

title: Goldwater Exhorts G.O.P.
description: BOSTON, Sept. 2 (UPI)Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, urged fellow Republican conservatives today to choke back criticism of President Nixon's new economic policies and his diplomatic overtures toward Communist China. There are things that bother me in this Administration, Mr. Goldwater said in speech prepared for the Essex Club. But he said he would not challenge Mr. Nixon in 1972.

title: S.E.C. Reported Studying I.T.T. Insiders
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission was reported yesterday to be investigating insider trading by officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Deming to Head Banking Venture
description: Frederick L. Deming, UnderSecretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs in the Johnson Administration and former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, announced yesterday his resignation as a partner at Lazard Freres & Co. to head a new bank holding company  a concern that he expects to build quickly into an important force in banking in the Upper Midwest.

title: Ban on Smut in Their Mail Requested by 500,000
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Under the authority of a sevenmonthold law, about 500,000 people have asked the United States Postal Service to protect them from receiving smut in the mail.

title: Lincoln Isham Dead at 79; GreatGrandson of Lincoln
description: DORSET, Vt., Sept. 2 (AP)Lincoln Isham, of Dorset, greatgrandson of Abraham Lincoln, died yesterday in Bennington hospital after long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: TV: The Time Griffin Dropped a Heavy Question
description: Television has a habit of being so clumsy that it can get to be embarrassing. For today's amusingdepressing example take some capers. on The Merv Griffin Show, the Columbia Broadcasting System's contribution to the wonderland of lateevening talk shows.

title: Black Is Hospitalized; Ailment Not Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A spokesman at the Bethesda Naval Hospital said today that Associate Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court was in satisfactory condition after having been hospitalized with an undisclosed ailment.

title: Picasso Tribute to Mark Art Season
description: Viewed across a stack of museum and gallery announcements, the prospect of the 197172 art season in New York (and other American cities) shows that Pablo Picasso, king of the international art headlines for longer than most people can mmember, is still firmly seated on his throne. Ninety years old on Oct. 25, and closing in on the longevity record holder, Grandma Moses, who remained bright and spry beyond her 100th birthday, Picasso as he enters his 10th decade will be celebrated in New York by a double exhibition at the Saidenberg Gallery and the Marlborough Galleries, opening Oct. 6.

title: M.I.T. Sailers Triumph
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 2 The Prince of Wales Bowl sailing series, for the North American Interclub matchracing championship, was won on Lake Pontchartrain today by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Nautical Association team. Terry Cronberg was the winning skipper. The runnerup was the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Yacht Club team.

title: Lady Owen Wed To a Consultant
description: Lady Owen, widow of Sir David Owen, who was assistant secretary general of the United Nations and coadministrator of the United Nations Development Fund, was married here yesterday afternoon to Chester Burger, a New York management consultant.

title: NEIGHBORS SEIZE BURGLARY SUSPECT
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 2Andre Iannucci's neighbors came to his rescue early this morning, chasing from his apartment a burglar who had grabbed two kitchen knives and had threatened his wife and three children.

title: Pakistan Tries and Jails a Dutch Tourist as a Spy
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 2A 23yearold Dutch tourist, arrested last February for taking photographs outside a Pakistani air base, has been convicted of spying after a secret trial and sentenced to two years imprisonment, newspapers reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: After reading the OpEd article by Paul Hemphill, Aug. 26, I felt the urge to praise this type of man with so much empathy for his wife.

title: Helen Hayes Appointed To Arts Unit by Nixon
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 2 (UPI)President Nixon today appointed Helen Hayes to the National Council on the Arts, the group that advises on Federal financial assistance for art and culture.

title: Two Papers in Pittsburgh Set to Resume Publication
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Press Company announced today that it planned to resume publication next Thursday, ending a fourmonth newspaper blackout.

title: AMEX STOCKS RISE IN ACTIVE TRADING
ILL RIGHTS LEADER PAROLED BY COURT
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3Charles Koen, a civil rights leader, was paroled late today but remains in critical condtion in a St. Louis hospital as the result of a protest fast he began more than six weeks ago

title: Kodes Gains in Open Tennis
description: Who is Jan Kodes? the people write to Frank Svehla, the publisher of the daily Czech newspaper in the metropolitan area.

title: Lower Puerto Rico Fares Are Approved for Eastern
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today a schedule of reduced, weekend fares to Puerto Rico filed by Eastern Airlines.

title: Rogers Backs F.B.I. Role In Inquiry of News Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Secretary of State William P. Rogers insisted today that there was nothing unusual in the recent use of agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to try to discover the source of news leaks in the State Department.

title: U.S. Says Most Teachers Won't Get Pay Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Arnold R. Weber, executive, director of the Cost of Living Council, declared today that more than half the nation's two million teachers and other educational workers would not receive increased pay during the 90day wageprice freeze.

title: Federal Study Says TV Can Make Youths More Violent
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Violence in television programs can lead children who watch the programs to become more violent in their behavior, a team of psychologists sponsored by the office of the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service has found.

title: Argentina Freezes Her Prices, But Raises Pay and Allowances
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 The Argentine Government announced today a series of farreaching economic measures to deal with the soaring cost of living.

title: Marthe M. Smith Bride in Jersey
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 3The marriage of Miss Marthe Michelle Smith to E. Bruce Hallett 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hallett Jr. of Convent Station, took place here tonight. The Rev. George Chorba of the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar P. Smith, parents of the bride.

title: U. S. Judge Defied
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 3 (AP)A Superior Court judge has defied a Federal judge's order prohibiting interference with a desegregation plan for Muscogee County schools.

title: MOSCOW RENEWS ATTACK ON PEKING
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 4 The Soviet Union today said that China's new foreign policy tactics made it imperative for Communists to heighten their political vigilance and thwart Peking's efforts to extend its influence in the Communist movement and in thirdworld countries.

title: Levy Regarded as Poor PolicyScans Makes Appeal on Dividends
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 President Nixon has no intention of proposing or supporting an excessprofits tax on business as part of his immediate or postfreeze economic policy, authoritative White House officials, disclosed today.

title: Crowds Take Off On Last Holiday For the Summer
description: The Labor Day weekend crowds began flocking to the road and rail and air terminals last night amid indications that the sun would be playing hide and seek at least through Sunday of the traditional last big weekend of summer.

title: 40,000 in Chicago Hear President Say Program Will Benefit Farmers
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3President Nixon headed back to the capital tonight in much the same manner in which he left it three weeks agopleading for public support for his new economic strategy.

title: MRS. RUSSELL P. HEUER
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Crinian Heuer, wife of Dr. Russell P. Heuer, retired chairman of General Refractories Company, died yesterday in Bryn Mawr, Pa., where she lived. Her age Was 71.

title: KENNETH A. DURHAM
description: WINCHESTER, Va., Sept. 3 Kenneth A Durham, a former vice president of the Chemical Bank of New York, died here yesterday in Memorial Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 64 years old and lived at Richwood Hall, Charlestown, W. Va.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily correspond to those in other financial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: KILKENNY LIMITS YANKS TO SIX HITS AS TIGERS WIN, 31
description: A solid smash into the rightfield seats by Norman Cash, who is bidding to win the American League home run championship this season, spelled the difference last night at Yankee Stadium as the Detroit Tigers walked off with a 31 triumph over the Yanks in the opener of a threegame series.

title: WIDNALL WINS TITLE IN ONEDESIGN CLASS
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 3  Bill Widnall of Marblehead won the world championship of the International OneDesign Class today by three fourths of a point.

title: Notes on People
description: The Duke and Duchess of Windsor have decided again to sell their weekend home at GifsurYvette, outside Paris. The 23acre estate was put on the block a couple of years ago, but no one willing to pay the $1.2million asking price came forward. This time the decision to sell was said to be irrevocable, and the Duke and his Duchess will accept bids. The Old Mill, as the place is called, is the, depository of the duke's regimental flags, drums, bugles and other keepsakes of the days when he was King Edward VIII, including the desk at which he wrote his famous abdication speech. The keepsakes are not for sale. The Duchess, who supervised redecoration of the mill house, had slogans painted on beams. One of them reads: I'm not the miller's daughter, but I've been through.

title: Lane Bryant and Rockower Show August Sales Gains
description: Lane Bryant, Inc., and Rockower Brothers, Inc., retail chains, yesterday reported higher sales for August compared with the year earlier month.

title: FuelOil Divestiture Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The Justice Department today field a proposed consent Judgment under which the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation, member of the Royal Dutch Shell Group, will divest the New England fuel oil business it acquired from the C. H. Sprague & Son Company in 1969, If the judgment is approved by a Federal court, it will retire a civi antitrust suit the Government filed last December.

title: MRS. FRANK B. HALL SR.
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 3Mrs. Winifred Pillsbury Hall widow of Frank B. Hall Sr., a New York fire and marine insurance broker, died here Wednesday. She was 94 years old and lived in Water Mill.

title: BABY AND SENTRY SLAIN IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 3Sniper fire killed an 18monthold girl and a young sentry today following a wave of explosions in Belfast yesterday that left the city terrified.

title: Pacesetter Industries Is Leader During Quiet NewIssue Week
Maine Executive Confident
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 3 (AP) The president of Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company said today he was confident the huge nuclear power plant will be allowed to begin operations next year, despite new Federal regulations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL TODAY AT CLOISTERS
description: A medievalstyle festival and fair with jesters and jousting, the fabled unicorn and dragon and a marketplace displaying ancient crafts will take place today at the Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park.

title: Alma North Rated Pick In Belmont Race Today
description: Alma North, representing Gene Mori's East Acres Stable, is the overnight favorite to win the 76th running of the Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park today. The race, for 3yearold fillies at 1 miles, has attracted a field of eight, making for a gross purse of $56,200 and a winner's share of $33,720.

title: MOVIE LABOR TALKS SET TO RESUME HERE
description: Negotiations between five New York movie studios and Local 52 of the International Association of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Operators will resume Wednesday.

title: CONBOYS' PASSES TOP COLTS, 2714, AS 16,217 WATCH
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3The Dallas Cowboys beat the Baltimore, Colts, 2714, in a preseason game tonight between last January's Super Bowl rivals that attracted virtually no interest in Baltimore. The Colt fans once again stayed away in droves, the paid crowd coming to 16,217.

title: Site of Chess Match Set
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 3 (Reuters)Buenos Aires will be the site of the final challengers elimination chess match between Grandmaster Bobby Fischer of the United States and Grandmaster Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the World Chess. Federation announced here today. The winner of the match, which will begin Sept. 30, will meet the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, for the title, probably in April, 1972.

title: U.S. FighterBomber Attacks Gun Site North of Buffer Zone
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 4 (AP)  A United States fighterbomber escorting B52 bombers on raids against the Ho Chi Minh supply trail in Laos crossed into North Vietnam yesterday and attacked an enemy antiaircraft site, the United States command said today.

title: WALLACE TO TEST ORDER ON SCHOOLS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 3A group of state legislators told the Montgomery County Board of Education today that Gov. George C. Wallace was preparing for a showdown next week with a Federal court on the desegregation issue.

title: Argentina Returns Body of Eva Peron To Exiled Husband
description: MADRID, Sept. 3  The Argentine Government today returned the body of Eva Pern to her exiled husband, former President Juan D. Pern, ending a 16yearold mystery about its whereabouts.

title: Police Launch Is Named After Slain Detective
description: Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy will dedicate a new police launch on Tuesday and name it after John Pollins, a detective who was killed in the line of duty.

title: Philharmonic Lists Two Concert Innovations
description: Music by 11 contemporary composers will be conducted by Pierre Boulez, Michael Gielen and Bruno Maderna in the New York Philharmonic's fourconcert series this season at the Shakespeare Festival Public Theater in Greenwich Village.

title: $86,000 TAKEN HERE IN 2 BANK HOLDUPS
description: Bandits escaped with $86,000 in two bank robberies in Manhattan and Queens yesterday, the police reported.

title: Fanny May Sets Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that its next $250million convertible debenture issue will be for 25 years and will be offered on Sept. 15. Interest and conversion rates will be announced on the issue date.

title: BRIDGEPORT STUDY IS BEGUN BY F.B.I.
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3 The New Haven office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today confirmed reports that it was, investigating charges of brutality and civil rights violations brought against Bridgeport policemen by a group of blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: More Doctors Defecting From A.M.A.
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 3  Dr. George Abbott is 30 years old, five years out of Medical school and just starting private practice in La Jolla, an affluent and conservative suburb of San Diego. He refuses to join the American Medical Association because, to him, it is archaic and irrelevant.

title: Ward Is Planning Refunds On Some Catalogue Prices
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP)Montgomery Ward & Co. announced today that customers would receive refunds or credits on Christmas catalogue items whose preprinted prices are higher than those authorized under the Aug. 15 price freeze.

title: Arctic Gas Search Financed
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (Reuters)A Pacific Lighting Corporation subsidiary today agreed to provide up to $10million over the next five years for gas exploration work on permit lands in the Arctic Islands, held by a group of United States and Canadian companies. The land permits involved are held in the name of Prairie Oil Royalties, Ltd. Other companies in the group include the Callahan Mining Corporation.

title: U.S. SWIM LEADER OVER E. GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Sept. 3 (UPI)The United States swimming team took a 10361 lead over East Germany at Leipzig today, despite a world record by Roland Matthes in the men's 200meter backstroke, it was reported by the East German news agency, ADN.

title: Japanese Defer a Decision On the Issue of China Seat
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3The Japanese Cabinet today deferred a decision on the issue of China's representation at the United Nations as opposition to retaining a seat for Taiwan spread within the ruling LiberalDemocratic party.

title: DOROTHY F. GRINNELL
description: SHARON, Conn., Sept. 3Dorothy F. Grinnell, a retired writer and editor for the Dell Publishing Company, Inc., of New York, died Tuesday. Her age was 66.

title: Rogers Says U.S. Accepts Thieu Decision on Election
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Secretary of State William P. Rogers indicated today that the United States accepted President Nguyen Van Thieu's decision to run alone next month as a test of public confidence in his administration in the absence of a contested presidential election in South Vietnam.

title: TEXTILE IMPORTS UP ff 39% IN 7 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Textile imports rose 17 per cent in July to, 3.536 billion square yards for the first seven months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports of manmade fiber, cotton and wool textiles from January through July were 39 per cent ahead of the same period last year, the report said.

title: HOTEL TO IMPROVE SEWAGE DISPOSAL
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept, 3State Supreme Court Justice John L. Larkin announced today that the Flagler Hotel, a major Catskill resort that was accused by the State Health Department of dumping almost raw sewage into the Neversink River, had agreed to improve its sewage disposal system.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 6.1% IH AUGUST FROM 5.8% IN JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The nation's unemployment rate rose to 6.1 per cent of the labor force in August from 5.8 per cent in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Executive Changes
description: T. I. M. E.DC, Inc., transcontinental motor carrier serving market areas in the United States and Canada, announced yesterday the appointment of Roy M. Wilkins as its new president. Mr. Wilkins, previously vice president of planning and service, has been with thee ompany for 20 years. The carrier aldo promoted Rex R. Davis to the newly created position br executive vice president. He had been vice president, Eastern Division.

title: Chrysler in Simca Bid
description: PARIS, Sept. 3 (Reuters) The Chrysler Corporation is offering 90 francs per share for the 3.3 per cent of Simca stock that it does not already own, the French Stock Brokers Association said today.

title: The ThieuBunker Tragedy
description: The promise of South Vietnam's President Thieu to resign if his political police, military governors and bureaucratic minions fail to stuff the ballot boxes adequately Oct. 3 in the oneman plebiscite he has substituted for a presidential election would be laughable if it were less tragic.

title: Strange Animals and Exotic ArtA Family With a Penchant for Collecting
description: YONKERS, N. Y.It's fun to have people come here and stare, said Michelle Simon, 15, as she perched on a sofa in her family's living room

title: Enter Senator Proxmire
description: It is an offweek when some prominent Democrat does not let it be known, however unofficially, that he is a candidate for his party's Presidential nomination. Newest to slide into the contest, without precisely saying so, is Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin. His hint that he may enter a few primaries makes him eighth in the field, apparently, and sixth from the Senate.

title: U.S. Sues Missouri
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Government sued Missouri and three local school districts today in an attempt to desegregate an allblack school district established by state law in 1938 when Missouri required separate schools for white and black children.

title: 'THE ARP STATUE' SHOWN AT VENICE:Movie by a Novice Consists of an Hour of Still Shots
description: VENICE, Italy Sept. 3Today has brought a new stock of experiments to the Venice film festival.In "The Arp Statue" a novice director, Alan Sekers, presents an hour-long film composed entirely of "stills" with voices-over providing narration as well as recitation of dialogue. The device has been employed beforein Quinn's documentary on Picasso and in a French investigation of Castro's Cuba but is still a novelty. It has become a clich to end a film with a freezing of its final scene, a static image leaving a more lasting impression than an agitated one. Nevertheless, 60 minutes of "stills" is a strain.Even so, Mr. Sekers has accomplished two arresting bitsthe sequence in which the heroine is maimed by a tiger and the Belfast photographs, with their telling faces. The general story, however, suffers by the imposed restriction of movement.Marx and WellsBefore the showing of Alexander Kluge's film "Der Grosse Verhau" ("The Big Mess"), Mr. Kluge, the director, made a short address explaining that in it he was attempting a style alien to his other work.His lastest is actually in several styles. Technically it suggests Georges Melies, with the limited equipment of his day, remaking "2001." The scenario, also a mixture, hints that Kluge has mistaken himself sometimes for H. G. Wells and sometimes for Karl Marx and sometimes for the two of them simultaneously.The scene is in the next century when everyone is at war with everyone else and apparently anti-Americanism is at full tide. The flights through space are interrupted by subtitles conveying the left-wing slogans of 1970. The symbolism of "the last representative of U.S. civilization" being shot down is obvious, but otherwise the action of the motion picture is confused, and its ideas belong to the 19th, rather than the 21st, century.A Yugoslav SatireMore topical and vastly more entertaining is a movie by a Yugoslav, Bata Cengic, entitled. "The Role of My Family, in the World Revolution," a wickedly witty comedy describing the adjustment of a middle-class Serb family to the new order when and after the Russian tanks roll into their land.Its Marxism is that of Groucho, not of Karl, but despite its broad burlesque, its satirical thrusts flash with an angry fire. Sad reflection underlies the loud laughter as the hyprocrisy and futility of the totalitarian state are observed with increasing disgust by a boy growing up under stern domination. A tragic slap-stick farce, it benefits enormously from its ingenious direction and expert performances, just this side and occasionally over the border of caricature.

description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place:
description: The nation's accountants are in the midst of making further earthshaking changes in the way companies report their earnings, and Theodore J. Newton. Jr. an analyst at Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co. has mixed feelings about it.

title: FRANCES H. SMITH
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 3Frances H. Smith, for more than 25 years dean of Scarsdale Junior High for Girls and later a faculty member at Keuka College, Penn Yan, N. Y., died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 39 Manchester Road, Eastchester.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tom Wicker's apologia Death of a Brother. [Aug. 24], was without a doubt irresponsible jotirrialism at its very worst. Mr. Wicker's, column was a very patent attempt to cast doubt upon the official version of the San Quentin jailbreak by giving quasicredence to Jackson's mother's charge that her son was set up and murdered by prison officials.

title: Staff Ends Strike at Modern Museum
description: At 7 o'clock last night, a faction of professional and other employes of the Museum of Modern Art, who went on strike on Aug. 20 voted overwhelmingly to go back to work.

title: Court Refuses to Postpone Catena's Release in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3  The United States Third Circuit ourt of Appeals in Philadelphia today refused to stay its order releasing from jail Gerardo (Jerry) Catena, a reputed underworld figure.

title: 2 Congressmen Here Find Little Issues Big to Voters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 This is, a civics test: Is the following statement true or false?

title: Weather Report
description: Science intends to refute Mark Twain's old observation that everyone complains about the weather but no one does anything about it. What science plans to do, it seems, is to demonstrate that the weather, at least in New York, is fine as it is.

title: Record Auto Output
Report Played Down
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 3 (AP)Governor Wallace played down reports today that he had threatened to use state troopers to transfer seven white pupils.

title: Memento of Vacation On Its Way to Famliy
description: BIG HORN, Wyo., Sept. 3 (UPI)A Connecticut family that spent its vacation camping in Wyoming's Big Horn Mountains will soon receive by mail a reminder of the visit.

title: Japanese Win 2 Judo Titles.
description: LUDWIGSHAFEN, West Germany, Sept. 3 (Reuters)Hizashi Tsuzawa of Japan won the lightmiddleweight title and Shozo Fujii of Japan won the middleweight title in the world judo championships tonight. In the allJapanese finals, Tsuzawa scored a decision over Hiroshi Minatoya and Fujii outpointed Yoshinori Shigematsu.

title: MARKETS IN TOKYO DISPLAY STABILITY
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 A degree of stability, which is still far from normal, seems to have returned to the foreign exchange and stock markets here as they yen floated from 5 to 6 per cent beyond its old pegged value of 360 to the dollar.

title: COUNTRY FLAVOR IN BURRITO SONGS
description: The Flying Burrito Bros., the Los Angeles country rock band, has several new members and is appearing through tomorrow at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: FordToyo Kogyo Link Due
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (UPI)An agreement allowing the Ford Motor Company to invest in the Japanese auto manufacturing company, Toyo Kogyo, will be signed by the end of September, a Toyo Kogyo spokesman said today.

title: Ky Vows to Stage a Coup Unless Election Is Halted
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3Vice President Nguyen Caa Ky threatened today to stage military coup and destroy President Nguyen Van Thieu if Mr. Thieu went ahead with his plan to run as the only candidate in the Presidential elections Oct. 3.

title: More Japanese Aid for India
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (AP)  The Japanese Government will use United Nations channels to provide India with additional aid of $2.5million for relief of East Pakistani refugees in India, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Books of The Times
description: GRENDEL. A novel by John Gardner. Illustrated by Emil Antonucci. 174 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $5.95

title: Canada and Taiwan Agree
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)  Canada and Nationalist China have completed a new agreement effective next Jan. 1, on the import of Taiwan's manufactured cotton products and knitted articles, the Board of Foreign Trade announced today.

title: 2Month Teamster Strike In California Is Settled
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 3 (AP) The Federal Government's top mediator announced agreement today in a twomonth Teamsters' Union strike that had made idle some 65,000 construction workers in northern California.

title: DIAMONDTHUMBPRINT pattern is popular and unusual
description: There is talk that people are willing to pay $250 a piece for diamondthumbprint goblets when they can find them.

title: They Left a Beverly Hills Estate To Live in a 600Acre Winery
description: ST. HELENA, Calif.Back nearly six years, when Donn Chappellet and his wife Molly had five children (the number is up to six now), they decided it was time to turn their backs on mode of southern California living that is envied by many and achieved by few.

title: Miss Dasher Has Nuptials
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 3Miss Judith Ann Dasher and Ronald George Falk of Hong Kong, formerly of New York, were married here tonight in the Noroton Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Stephen Sibson. The Rev. Stephen Franckewicz, chaplain of the Roman Catholic Convent of St. Brigitte, Darien, assisted.

title: Harry J. Carpenter Dead; ExBank Vice President, 85
description: Harry J. Carpenter, a retired vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, now the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and former treasurer of the New York Board of Trade, died Thursday at his home in Avon Park, Fla. His age was 85.

title: POLICE SERGEANTS TOLD TO BE TOUGH
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, promoting 85 policeman and one policewoman to sergeant yesterday, urged them to go to their new commands and be tough bosses.

title: The President's Economic Betrayal
Northwest Orient And National Agree On Airline Merger
description: Northwest Airlines, Inc., and National Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge in an exchange of stock valued at more than $225million.

title: Fairchild and Northrop Duel for Jet Work
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 3Two of the nation's largest aircraft manufacturers are locked in a headtohead, billiondollar competition to decide who will get to build more than 600 of the Air Force's newest attack jetthe AX.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KRESGE DONATING DETROIT BUILDING
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3The S. S. Kresge Company is moving its headquarters, with 1,400 jobs, out of Detroit and is donating its office space to the Detroit Institute of Technology.

title: HOWARD HAWKES OF UNIROYAL DIES
description: Howard N. Hawkes, retired vice president and member of the executive committee and Loard of directors of Uniroyal, Inc., died here yesterday at his home, 166 East. 63d Street. He was 77 years old.

title: Car Sales Up 20% For August Period
description: President Nixon's new economic policy apparently has paid off its first dividends to the automobile industry as new car sales for the last 10 days of August rose by 20.1 per cent from the 1970 level.

title: G.N.P. Decline Forecast
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (AP)Toshio Kimura, director general of the Economic Planning Agency, said today that Japan's gross national product for the fiscal year ending March 31, 1972, would drop by more than 1 per cent because of President Nix, on's dollar measures.

title: President in Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 4 (AP)President Nixon returned to the White House at 12:25 A.M. today.

title: Openingat the City Opera
KAISERIS DROPPING PERUVIAN VENTURE
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it will relinquish its interest in Minera Bayovar, S.A., an 80 per cent owned subsidiary that holds phosphate and potash Mining claims and concessions in the Sechura Desert on the coast of Peru.

title: In Brownsville, Looting Is Condition of Life
description: Early in the day the people knew the school would be robbed that night. Each time the school is robbed, they see men standing on the roof all day waiting for the custodian to lock up and go home.

title: UNESCO Sees Illiteracy Surviving the Century
description: PARIS, Sept. 4 (UPI)More people can now read and write than ever before, but the problem of illiteracy may not be solved in this century, according to a report issued this week by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organizaiton.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, Sept. 3Shortly after 3 P.M. Wednesday, Joe Cahill boarded an Aer Lingus Boeing 747 In Dublin for a trip to New York and the start of a fiveweek fundraising campaign for the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: Colombia Will Nationalize The Bank of the Republic
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 3 (UPI)Colombia announced today that the Government had reached agreement with private national and foreign stockholders in the Bank of the Republic to buy out their interests and nationalize the institution.

title: Why Does the Volga Catch Fire?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The Soviet Union has nothing comparable to the Sierra Club or the Friends of the Earth.

title: Dr. Rosen, Pioneer In Surgery on Ear, Plans a China Visit
description: Dr. Samuel Rosen, originator of an operative technique in the ear, plans to leave next Wednesday or Thursday for China where he has been invited by the AllChina Medical Association to spend a month lecturing, demonstrating his methods and studying the Chinese experience in dealing with deafness.

title: BILL SEEKS TO CUT CAMPAIGN COSTS
description: A bill limiting campaign spending by candidates for the City Council was introduced yesterday by Councilman Mario Merola, a Bronx Democrat.

title: Cooping of a Sort
description: In this standup time for New York City's corruptiontroubled police force, Police Commissioner Murphy deserves and needs the total support of every honest Policeman: Instead, Edward J. Kiernan, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, has chosen to lie down. His posture is a particularly reprehensible form Of police coopingesleeping on the job and ignoring responsibility. Far from backing the commissioner his brave fight, Mrt. Kiernan urges that he quit.

title: Clash in Cambodia
description: BARAI, Cambodia, Sept. 3 (AP)  Cambodian soldiers, with the support of dive bombers and artillery, killed at least 100 Members of the North Vietnamese 205th Regiment yesterday at a road fork 65 miles northeast of Phnom Penh, an operations commander reported here today.

title: SEYMOUR SHAPIRO
description: EAST PATERSON, N. 3., Sept. 3  Seymour Shapiro, assistant principal at Haaren High School in Manhattan since 1948, died yesterday in Barnert Memorial Hospital after along a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived here at 143 River Drive.

title: Risk Conceded in Offshore Rigs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 The Department of the Interior conceded today that some unavoidable environmental damage could result from more Federal leasing of undersea oil and gas lands in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Radical Chic at the Cape
description: WELLFLEET, Mass.  In observance of Hiroshima Day, the invitation reads, we invite you to meet Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, Dr. Eqbal Ahmad at a Benefit for the Harrisburg Defense Committee at, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Lifton; Wellfleet, Massachusetts.

title: And Now, the Port of New York Giants
description: If the Ports of New York Authority had carried out the instruction it was given in the 1921 compact between New York and New Jersey, that brought it into existence, New York City would be cheering rather than bemoaning the Glints' Move to New Jersey.

title: Minh Aide Says Bunker Offered To Help Finance General's Race
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3A close associate of Gen. Duong Van Minh insisted today that among the inducements that the United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, offered the general to stay in the presidential race before he pulled out Aug. 20 was an unspecified amount of money.

title: Hijacking to Cuba Foiled
description: MIAMI, Sept. 3 (AP)A man armed with a sharpened screwdriver attempted to hijack an Eastern Air Lines plane to Cuba today but was subdued by the crew and passengers, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced. The plane en route from Chicago, landed safely at Miami International. Airport. K. W. Whittaker, special agent in charge of the F.B.I. in Miami, said agents had taken Juan Miguel Borges Guerra, 20 years old, identified as a Cuban refugee, into custody. Three persons were reported slashed in a struggle with the hijacker.

title: Japanese Discuss Strategy
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The Japanese cabinet today discussed Japan's strategy for meeting of the JapanUnited States Committee on Trade and Economic Affairs to be held in Washington next Thursday and Friday.

title: Brooklyn School Given FaceLifting
description: A major facelifting is under way at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn because its new principal, Marco Hernandez, refused to permit the 64yearold school to reopen for classes in the condition in which he found it when he reported to begin his duties.

title: JOHN M. HENKEL
description: John M. Henkel, recently retired manufacturer's representative for the Chandler Products Corporation of Cleveland, nuts and bolts, died yesterday of heart attack while on a fishing trip in liberty, N. Y, He was 66 years old and lived at 60 Ravensdale Road, HastingsonHudson, N. Y

title: Firestone Plans to Build A Plant for Truck Tires
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it will begin construction immediately of a plant for the production of truck tires, including allsteel radials. The cost bf the project was not disclosed, but industry estimate put the necessary, investment at over $10million.

title: A TANKER IN PACIFIC SINKS AFTER BLAST
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 3 (UPI)A 10,000ton tanker broke in half, exploded and sank last night in the North Pacific, the Coast Guard reported today.

title: State Aide Offers Guide to Teachers On Salary Raises
description: ALBANY, Sept. 3 (AP)The chief legal officer of the State Education Department, citing Federal guidelines, spelled out today the conditions under which he believes teachers in New York may be paid higher salaries when they return to work this month.

title: Net Monetary Reserves Up ln West Germany for Week
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept, 3West Germany's net monetary reserves rose by 40 million marks to 61.4 billion in the week ending Aug. 31, the Bundesbank said.

title: ROGERS APPLAUDS. ACCORD ON BERLIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Secretary of State William P. Rogers applauded the signing of the fourpower agreement on Berlin today and said that he hoped that other efforts toward reconciliation and cooperasion can be set in train in Europe.

title: JOHN F. CAREW
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 3John F. Carew, a civil engineer and a son of the late State Supreme Court Justice John F. Carw, died today in Central General Edspital, Plainview. He was 66 years old and lived at 56: Tarrance Street.

title: Defense League Assailed by Soviet Jew
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3  A Russian Jewish scholar who suffered harassment and imprisonment in his successful fight to emigrate to Israel condemned today the violent tactics of the militant Jewish Defense League, contending that they were sharply alienating Russian intellectuals who have been sympathetic to Soviet Jews.

title: Survey Finds Growing Response By Executives to Social Issues
description: Business executives have revised their attitudes on corporate responsibilities, it was pointed out in a survey by The Harvard Business Review published in the SeptemberOctober issue.

title: Bridge: A PostMortem' by Experts To Cover Interesting Hands
description: A novel postmortem event will conclude today's proceedings at the Greater New York Bridge Association's Knickerbocker Championships at the New York Hilton.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Department Asks for New Plan In Austin's Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today to set aside a courtordered desegregation plan for schools in Austin, Tex., and require the lower court to work up another.

title: Buckley Charges Mayor Made City a Wasteland
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 3Senator James L. Buckley accused Mayor Lindsay today of turning New York City into a veritable wasteland where crime, welfare and government spending have risen while productive business has fled.

title: Mr. Nixon and Berlin
description: The effort in the White House and by American Ambassador Kenneth Rush to portray the historic new Berlin agreement as a personal triumph for President Nixon brings a wry smile to the lips of Western diplomats. White House skepticism during the seventeenmonth Berlin negotiation was a continuous burden for West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, whose imaginative initiatives paved the way for the new accords.

title: Roundup: Killebrew Puts inch on A's With Slain
description: After Harmon Killebrew's name in The Baseball Register, there are a dozen notations concerning the Minnesota star's 18year majorleague career.

title: Amarex Completes Oil Well
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. (Reuters)Amarex, Inc., said today it had completed its No. 1 Peterman well with an open flow potential of 480 barrels of oil daily. The new well is in the North Humac Field

title: Theater: Two Contrasts
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 3Two of the drama companies visiting the Edinburgh festival this year provide a revealing contrast in a quality perhaps best described as authority.

title: Jets, Giants in Twin Bill Tonight
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 3  Four football teams fervently committed to the proposition that exhibition games don't mean much will take part in tomorrow night's 10th annual Cleveland charity doubleheader, and both New York teams will be included for the first time.

title: The Gyro, a Greek Sandwich, Selling Like Hot Dogs
description: A sandwich that is said to have originated 2,000 years ago is capturing the attention of Manhattan's quick eaters.

title: COWAN CARDS 210 FOR STROKE LEAD
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 3 (AP)Gary Cowan, despite a bee sting and hot words with his playing partner's caddie, shot a 2underpar 69 today for a 54hole total of 210 and a onestroke lead in the 71st annual United States Amateur golf championship.

title: The Talk of Rostock
description: ROSTOCK, East Germany, Aug. 31What use is it to us, the Berlin agreement? asked the young engineer. Everybody gets something out of it except us.

title: Grivas Has Disappeared, Makarios Says in Athens
description: ATHENS, Sept. 3Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, arrived here today for talks with top Greek officials on the divided island's future.

title: ECOLOGY ERRORS CITED BY MORTON
description: DENVER, Sept. 3Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said today that the biggest task his department faced was solving environmental problems that arose during the bobm days of the 1060's.

title: Proposition Will Begin New Edition Here Sept. 16
description: The Proposition, an Off Broadway improvisational musical revue, will begin its new edition here Sept. 16 with an openingnight curtain of 7:15 at the Mercer Shaw Arena, 240 Mercer Street. The show is nearing its 200th performance at the downtown theater.

title: Prices of Soybean And Wheat Futures Register Increases
description: Concern about a possible short soybean crop because of drought in the Midwest was still evident on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, as it was on Thursday. Traders continued to buy in the belief that the drought would affect the harvest.

title: Moscow vs. Peking
description: While Moscow took a long step toward friendlier relations with the West at the signing of the Berlin Treaty, Soviet propaganda organs yesterday released two furious attacks on the Chinese People's Republic. In New Times, the semiofficial organ of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, Peking was depicted as plotting war to gain world hegemony. Pravda gave much space to an only slightly less menacing onslaught.

title: Preliminary U.S. Talks With Its Trade Partners on Problems Are Inconclusive
description: PARIS, Sept. 3The United States and its major trade partners embarked today on a search for a resolution to the world trade and currency crisis provoked by President Nixon on Aug. 15. However, the initial discussions proved inconclusive.

title: Doug Index Up 12.12 As Turnover Jumps
description: The stock market suddenly took a new lease on life yesterday, amazing investors and analysts alike, as prices boomed to their best gains since the record  shattering Nixon rally on Monday, Aug. 16.

title: GRIFFIN ASKS C.B.S. TO CURB CONTRACT
description: Mery Griffin has asked the Columbia Broadcasting System television network to release him at the end of December as host of his latenight talk show.

title: G.M: Isuzu Capital TieUp Given Japanese Approval
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The Japanese Government today formally authorized a capital linkup agreement between the Isuzu Motors Company and General Motors of the United States.

title: Luna 18 on Moon Course
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (UPI)Luna 18 sped toward the moon today. Western space observers said the unmanned vehicle might land on the lunar surface and unload a new moon robot. Tass, the official Soviet press agecny, said Luna 18 was blasted aloft yesterday to carry out further scientific research of the moon and nearmoon surface.

title: Goldstrand Posts 63 to Lead by 2 Strokes in Greater Hartford Open Golf
Clingan Backs McGovern For Democratic Nomination
description: City Councilman Eldon R. Clingan, a Manhattan Liberal and the Council's minority leader, announced yesterday his Support for Senator George McGovern's candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: The Penn Central Offers to Sell Jersey Land Facing Manhattan
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday in Philadelphia that it was offering to sell 335 acres of, property running for nearly two miles along the west bank of the Hudson River opposite midManhattan.

title: DR. PAUL NIEHANS, SWISS SURGEON, 89
description: GENEVA, Sept. 3  Dr. Paul Niehans, well known for his cellular therapy and treatment designed to arrest the aging process, died Wednesday at Montreux. He was 89 years old.

title: A.E.C. WILL REVIEW REACTOR PERMITS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The Atomic Energy Commission bowed to environmental pressures today and ordered reviews of construction permits and operating licenses that had been given to nuclear power plants designed to produce more than 100 million kilowatts of electricity.

title: ExAide of AllState Credit Files Bankruptcy Petition
description: Ira Berman, a lawyer and a former officer of the AllState Credit Corporation, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the Federal District Court here, listing liabilities of $7,529,939.58 and assets of $17,000.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3A Washington heart specialist and an engineer have invented a diagnostic apparatus to determine whether a blockage exists in one of the neck arteries supplying the brain of a patient who has suffered a stroke. Dr. William L. Howell, a cardiologist at the Washington Clinic, and William B. Leaf were granted Patent 3,602,213 this week. It is assigned to Prototypes, Inc., an engineering development company that Mr. Leaf operates in Kensington, Md.

title: Thant Names Unit to Work Oh Safety for Journalists
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 (AP)Secretary General Thant announced the names of six newspapermen and a lawyer who will meet here next Thursday for a week's work on an international agreement to give safeconduct cards to journalists on dangerous missions.

title: Mrs. Cahill Asks Ulster For Welfare Payments
description: BELFAST, Sept. 3 (UPI)Mrs. Joe Cahill, wife of the Irish Republican Army leader held in New York City, has applied to the Ulster Government for welfare payments to support herself and their children, officials said here today.

title: China Expects Selassie Visit
description: PEKING, Sept. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)Emperior Haile Selassie of Ethiopia will make an official visit to Peking shortly, an authoritative source said here today. (In Addis Ababa, an informed source said on Tuesday that the emperor would leave on Sept. 29 for a visit to China.)

title: Screen: 2 Men in Unusual Situations:Teacher Infatuated in 'Lust for a Vampire' 'Man Who Haunted Himself' Also Opens
description: A somewhat esteemed colleague, a theater critic for this paper who knows me, has suggested that, considering the title, I might find much of what I generally want from a movie in "Lust for a Vampire," which is now playing at the Penthouse Theater and which he has not seen.Much, but not all. The story of a beautiful vampire and the man who loves her, "Lust for a Vampire" is set in and around a rustic Austrian village nestled snugly in the shadow of its vampire castle. It is the 19th century, a point that the visiting advanced skeptic, Richard (Michael Johnson) never lets anyone forget."Mircalla, this is the 19th, not the 18th century," he reminds his favorite student at the local girls' school where he has taken a job (because of the girls). But Mircalla (Yutte Stensgaard) continues to show a woeful ignorance of the last 100 years' literature, and the reason is not far to seek. However, she dresses with the timesEmpire, clinging, filmy, very low-cut, high-waisted, terrificand she is absolutely ravishing. Therefore it is not surprising that Richard falls at Mircalla's feet, where several have fallen before him, and wins the heart of an antique monster whose very life blood was just days before the sacrificial offering of an unwilling local virgin.It is love, not lust, that Richard makes to Mircalla outside the castle, and it is love that makes her hesitate long enough to take a burning stake in her bosom while she is being exorcised at the end. Richard then seeks rather too convenient refuge in the arms of the school's gym teacher (Suzanna Leigh, also a knockout) and what might have been the fatal passion of the century (19th, that is) settles down into another faculty romance.Despite many obvious lunacies, "Lust for a Vampire," which was directed by Jimmy Sangster and written by one Tudor Gates, is not unaware of its conventional sources of vitality, the nice tension between desire and decomposition, the bracelet of bright flesh around the bone.Such kinds of awareness seem totally lacking in its co-feature, "The Man Who Haunted Himself," a careful, potentially intelligent film by Basil Dearden and Michael Relph, that fails for lack of excitement in its own fiction. A split-identity story that falls somewhere between  and far below"Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "William Wilson," the film deals with a London businessman (Roger Moore) who gradually comes to realize that somebody, apparently his exact double, is beginning to fill his place in his office, his club and his wife's bed  and is making rather a better job of it in the bargain.The manner of his realization depends largely upon the hero's personality, and since he is a man of regular, dull habits, the realization follows a regular, dull processwhich is finally the shape of the movie. Any number of directors might have found in this a logical development of terror, but Dearden has merely found in it a poorly developed logic, and nothing even partly interesting happens to enliven its progress.Roger Moore plays himself twice over with virtually no distinguishing characteristics. Olga Georges-Picot is attractive as the alter ego's mistress, and Hildegard Neil is lovely and even a bit distinguished as everybody's wife.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In both of the first articles of your excellent series on New York City suburbs, the conclusion of the writers seems to be that zoning in the suburbs must be broken down to allow higherdensity, housing space for the middle class from New York Citiy. The underlying assumption is that homes willthen be cheaper.

title: School Lunch Cuts Feared
description: WASHINGTON; Sept. 3 (AP) Herman E. Talmadge, Georgia Democrat who is Chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said today that many needy children might go hungry because of new regulations proposed by the Agriculture Department for disbursing money for the school Iunch program. Mr. Talmadge wrote President Nixon that the proposed regulations would prevent some school districts from participating.

title: Robert D. Funkhouser, 65, Dies; Retired Dartmouth Controller
description: HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 3Robert D. Funkhouser, controller of Dartmouth College from 1950 to 1966 and since then consultant to, its treasurer and controller, died of a heart attack last night. His age was 65.

title: Capital Police Chief Says Force Was Not Ready for Protesters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 3 (UPI)  Police Chief Jerry V. Wilson acknowledged today that his department's handling of thousands of antiwar demonstrators last spring was not the ultimate in perfection but he defended his tactics and promised to be better prepared for similar incidents in the future.

title: Reserve Studies Interest But Calls Curb Unneeded
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board, while still contending that a ceiling on interest rates is not now necessary, has begun collecting information on rates charged by banks before and after President Nixons wageprice freeze order.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Yields on United States Treasury bills were mixed in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Big Four Sign Agreement On Status of West Berlin
description: BERLIN, Sept. 3The ambassadors of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France signed a treaty here today governing the status of West Berlin.

title: Shop Talk
description: Do you take the A train or the GG or the KK? Even experienced subway hands are confused these days, with the rerouting of trains and the alphabet soup of new designations. An amusing way for subway buffs to learn the best route to Mosholu Parkway or Woodhaven Boulevard would be to spend an evening or two working out a new jigsaw puzzle of the New York City subway map. After fitting the 500 pieces, the assembler has a 16by20 inch map in color, and possibly a better knowledge of the subway geography of Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Italy Asks New Standard For Currency Exchange
description: ROME, Sept 3 Italy proposed today gradual adoption of a new international curreneyexchange standard based on the system of Special Drawing Rightsthe pape golds of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Welfare Recipient Here Sues on New Work Law
description: A welfare recipient filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to challenge the constitutionality of a new state law that requires ablebodied relief recipients to accept publicworks assignments or lose their assistance.

title: WILLIAM M. CANBY 3d
description: William M. Canby 3d, an investment banker formerly associated with E. F. Hutton & Co., died of a heart ailment on Thursday. He was 68 years old and lived at 360 East 55th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: African Congress Begins Study Of Political Options for Blacks
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3  The study and development of techniques aimed at helping black Americans gain political power promises to be the major thrust of their Eastern Regional Conference of the Congress of African Peoples, meeting here this Labor Day weekend.

title: Merger News
description: The American Ship Building Company announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to purchase substantially all of the Great Lakes division of Litton Industries, Inc., for a total of about $20million. The purchase price includes assumption of the division's liabilities, cash and other obligations. The agreement is subject to resolution of certain issues now being negotiated, the approval of both company boards and favorable review by the Department of Justice and other governmental authorities.

title: Cutter Returns Here After 10 Months' Vietnam Duty
description: The Coast Guard cutter Morgenthau, returning from 10 months' duty patrolling the Vietnam coast, received a welcome yesterday morning at, Governors Island reminiscent of World War II and Korean war days.

title: Run on the Memory Bank Shuts Some OTB Doors
description: The tilt sign went on again at most of the city's offtrack betting shops yesterday after a central computer broke down trying too hard to carry out an Impossible order.

title: 105 Police Arrive for a Quiet Eviction
description: More than 100 policemen 1 with an array of equipment that included a mobile com munications center, five patrol wagons and gas masks converged on two squalid tenement buildings opposite the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights yesterday for a posIsible scuffle with 87 squatter families.

title: The Text of the FourPower Agreement Governing the Status of West Berlin
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Following is the official Englishlanguage text of the Berlin agreement and its annexes as made public today by the State Depdrtment:

title: GypsyCab Group Will Help Lazar Draft Regulations
description: A committee of leaders of the gypsytaxi industry, organized by Taxi Commissioner Michael J. Lazar, next week will begin drafting regulations designed to bring official recognition to the gypsytaxicab industry.

title: Polyester Breakthrough Reported by Stevens Co.
description: J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest manufacturers of textiles, says it has made a breakthrough in basic research on polyester fibers that should greatly expand their use in the apparel field.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MONTAUK, L.I.At noon the ocean was dead. The sun, pale yellow and formless, melted into a light blue sky like butter on a pan. There was not enough wind to fill the bow sail that would move the 42foot fishing boat in a drift. Her diesel engines shut down, the Cricket swayed soundlessly in the water. There was very little noise on deck; each of the nine aboard was lost in a corner of the warm, torpid, gentle moment.

title: Court Upholds Sale of 2 Seats On Exchanges as Plohn Assets
description: The United States Court of Appeals yesterday agreed with a Federal district court judge who directed the sale of two stock exchange seats by the receiver of the Charles Plohn & Co. brokerage house.

title: SHIRLEY SEIFERT, NOVELIST, WAS 83
description: KIRKWOOD, Mo., Sept. 3 (AP) Shirley Seifert, whose historical novels set in Missouri and Kentucky once gained her a Pulitzer Prize nomination, died Wednesday. She was 83 years old.

title: Arab Federation is Endorsed By Soviet in Lukewarm Terms
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3The Soviet Union gave qualified, luke warm enddrsement today to the new federation of Egypt, Syria and Libya, showing much less enthusiasm for the concept that it had last spring.

title: MRS. JAMES M. FARR 3D
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept. 3Mrs. Emily Anderson. Farr, widow of James M. Farr 3d, former investment counselor with Douglas T. Johnson & Co. and Estabrook & Co., died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital after a short illness.

title: 25 Debutantes in Bow At Westchester Dance
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 3 Twentyfive young women made their debuts tonight at the 33d Westchester Cotillion at the Shenorock Shore Club here. Mrs. Allan W. Ferrin was general chairman for the champagne dinner dance.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3Yields on United States Treasury bills were mixed in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Peoples Gas Unit Sets Deal
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI)The Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, a subsidiary of Peoples Gas Company, has contracted to purchase about 10 million barrels of ethane and propane from the Phillips Petroleum Company and Warren Petroleum Company for over $21million. The gases wil he received in liquid form and gasified for injection into Natural Gas's pipeline system.

title: Lettets to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Most Common Verb in Schools, Study Finds, Is ...Is
description: What is the verb most frequently encountered by youngsters in American schools?

title: E.E.C. MILLS LINK QUOTA AND SURTAX
description: BONN, Sept. 3 The West German steel industry expressed its firm view today that renewal of voluntary curbs on steel exports to the United States and nonexemption of steel from Washington's new 10 per cent surtax on imports were mutually exclusive.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The 18 members of the Accounting Principles Board are dedicated accountants who spend an inordinate amount of their time preparing and issuing opinions that attempt to improve the quality of corporate financial reporting. But it is our belief that much of their efforts have been, and will continue to be, heavily compromised by political considerationspressures from major corporations, governmental bodies and regulatory commissions.

title: Television
description: IF WE could only auction off his gallbladder, said a cynic, we could make a fortune.

title: AROUND THE
description: Time off.... Enjoy the long holiday weekend.

title: Few Heed L.I. Town's Ban on Mixing of Garbage
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Sept, 4A North Hempstead town ordinance forbidding the mixing of discarded newspapers with other garbage went into effect this week but town officials noticed no visible difference in the makeup of the garbage unloaded at the town's two incinerators.

title: Jean C. Jones Becomes. Bride Of T. J. Morris
description: NEW HARTFORD, N. Y., Sept. 4  Miss Jean Cole Jones and Thomas Joseph Morris were married here this afternoon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. The Right Rev. Ned Cole Jr., Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. George 0. Nagle, the rector.

title: Pakistan Names U.S. Envoy
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 4 (UPI)Maj. Gen. Nawabzada Agha Mohammad Raza, former Pakistani Ambassador to Peking, has been appointed Ambassador to Washington.

title: Schools
description: ATLANTA  Most Southern children went back to school last week, an event traditionally accompanied by public protest, frequent disruption and occasional violence. This time, however, there was, relatively speaking, a notable lack of resistance, even in districts where children rode buses out of their neighborhoods. Many, of those who have watched the annual tensions come and go shrugged, turned away and announced it was finally all over.

title: FIGURES ON HEROIN IN VIETNAM DIFFER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The picture of heroin use by American servicemen in Vietnam was further clouded today by new Pentagon figures showing that about onethird of those servicemen first identified as heroin users had not been taking the drug.

title: The Stadium Question
description: Should New York City raise $24million to acquire and renovate Yankee Stadium, and spend unspecified millions more to provide parking, lighting, landscaping and access roads around it?

title: Baldwin Sloop Reaches the Halfway ark First
description: Sorcery, James French Baldwin's Class A sloop, led the fleet around a Texas Tower, the halfway point, in the Stamford Yacht Club's 250mile Vineyard race yesterday. However, the 61nfooter was closey followed by a pesky group of Class E and F boats, to Whom she has to give up to 10 hours in handicaps.

title: Penn State Rated East's Top Eleven, With Syracuse and Boston College Next
description: Injuries, illness and resignations have taken their toll of important players on major Eastern independent college football teams during the past week, causing some revaluation of early season prospects. Penn State, one of the region's cofavorites 10 days ago, has avoided such losses so far and has thus moved in front as the choice to win the Lambert Trophy as the top major team in the East.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) President Nixon, accompanied by members of his immediate family, flew today to Camp David, the Presidential mountaintop retreat in nearby Maryland. Before departure, he net at the White House with George P. Shultz, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Kenneth Clark Asks New Drugs to Curb Hostility of Leaders
