description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The president of the American Psychological Association proposed today the creation of new drugs that could routinely be given to people, especially leaders holding great power, to subdue hostility and aggression and, thereby, allow more humane and intelligent behavior to emerge.

title: Puerto Ricans in Hoboken Rampage After 2 Arrests
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 4Bands of Puerto Rican youths roamed through the west end of the city last night and early this morning, breaking windows and dumping garbage into the streets.

title: Ingrid Stephani Wed
description: Miss Ingrid Stephani, advertising director for the Rosenthal China Company here, was married in Munich, West Germany, yesterday to Reynold Olsen, a partner in the Harold J. Siesel Company, Inc., a New York advertising agency. The parents of the couple are Gen. Gerhardt Stephani, chief of engineers of the West German Army, and Mrs. Stephani of Koblenz, West Germany, and Mrs. Arthur Olsen of Jamaica, Queens, and the late Mr. Olsen. The ceremony was performed at the Engineers School of the West German Army.

title: STATE REVAMPING WELFARE SYSTEM
description: The state government announced new efforts yesterday to reduce welfare dependency and to evaluate existing welfare programs on a strict costeffectiveness basis.

title: Paintings in Brooklyn Depict Black Life in America
description: Brightly colored paintings. illustrating black life in America are drawing passersby to a fence bordering construction site in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Mekong Claims 5 Thais
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 4 (AP)Four government relief workers were swept away and believed drowned in floods along the rising Mekong River where more than 90,000 Thais have fled their homes, reports. said today. A fifth man drowned in a boat collision in the same area, at the provincial capital of Nong Khai.

title: RICHARDS CAPTURES SHOOT AND CROWN
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 41 (AP)  Capt. Chuck Richards held onto his No. 1 position through today's final round of shooting to win the modern pentathlon national championship.

title: Miss Bartelink Wed To John D. Lane
description: CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 4In St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Frances Bartelink, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Everhard Hendrik Bernard Bartelink, was married to John David Latte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Rich Lane of Princeton, N. J. The Rev. Francis W. Voelcker performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Joe Morris Doss and the Rev. Richard A. Pugliese.

title: The Army on Trial
description: Lieut. Col. Anthony Herbert, a professional soldier with an outstanding upfromtheranks record of 24 years of service and a reputation as a top Combat commander Vietnam, has for all intents and purposes been cashiered by the Pentagon. Stripped of his command two years ago, he has since been denied an assignment to staff school and, after a demeaning tour as officer in charge of reenlistments for the Third Army, he was last week reduced to a supply job lie expects forced retirement next year at age 42.

title: Brother Thomas, 76, of Manhattan Dies
description: Brother Bonaventure Thomas McGinty, administrative consultant and former president of Manhattan College, died Friday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Not hashish, hops, datura, ephedra, sacrostemma or rhubarb
description: It was by drinking soma that the god Indra gained strength to slay the dragon of drought. So we are told by the most ancient literary monument of India, the Rigveda. Across the mountains to the west, in ancient Iran, we find records of the same substance, there known as haoma. Haoma was offered up by Yima, the first worshipper of Ahura Mazda.

title: One And a Ralf Cheers For Progress
description: I AM not a Luddite. Nor could ever be one.

title: The World
Polish Party Congress To Be Held Year Early
description: WARSAW, Sept. 4The Polish Communist party has decided to convene its Sixth Congress on Dec. 6, a year ahead of schedule.

title: ALL 109 ARE KILLED AS JETLINER HITS ALASKA MOUNTAIN
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 4A jetliner carrying 109 persons crashed into a mountain today while approching for a landing here. All aboard died, officials said, making it the worst singleaircraft disaster in United States history.

title: Suspect Is Charged With Slaying Seven In Arizona Family
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 4 (AP) A man was charged today with murdering seven members of the family of a former employe who reportedly disappeared with his wife seven months ago. Four of the victims were children.

title: A Hardship Is Not Having a 7Foot Center
description: Adolph Rupp, the Kentucky basketball coach, celebrated his 70th birthday last Thursday with five parties throughout the state, numerous wellwishers and an announcement that he had lost Torn Payne, his 7foot2inch center.

title: OLYMPIC OUTLOOK IS GRIM, SAYS IBA
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Sept. 4 (AP)Henry Iba, the retired college basketball coaching genius, says the United States' chances of contniuing to outclass the rest of the basketball world in the 1972 Olympic Games are in serious jeopardy.

title: NIXON GIVES JERSEY DISASTER AREA AID
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4  Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that President Nixon has declared New Jersey a disaster area because of flood damage from the tropical storm named Doria a week ago.

title: Princeton Post Filled
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 4Dr. Stephen M. Goldfeld, a Princeton University economist who specializes in financial institutions, has been named the first holder of the university's newly established Class of 1920 professorship in economics and banking. Dr. Goldfeld, 31 years old, joined the Princeton faculty in 1963 and has served as a consultant for the President's Council of Economic Advisers, the Federal Reserve Board and private industry.

title: Patrolman Among 16 Seized On L.I. on Narcotics Charges
description: MONTAUK, L. I., Sept. 4The East Hampton town police early today arrested 16 young people, among them a patrolman assigned to the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, on misdemeanor narcotics charges.

title: Movies
description: JENNIFER O'NEILL, the beauteous, mysterious, ethereal Dorothy of the hit movie, Summer of '42, is passed out cold. Zonked. Gone are her days as the grieving young war widow, and now she is playing Miranda Graham, an aspiring actress, currently unconscious on an examining table in Room H224 of Flower & Fifth Avenue Hospitals. Surrounding her are a doctor who is taking her pulse. (James Coco), a worriedlooking friend (Dyan Cannon), her bearded boyfriend (Ken Howard), and, in the background amidst a cluster of lights and a camera, a movie director with a bellowing voice and a gleaming paid pate (Otto Preminger). A blonde nurse shoves a yellow vial of nitroglycerin under Miranda's nose until the faintee, clad in, gray hot pants and ??own laceup Roman sandals, to.

title: Art
description: FRANCE has prodigiously celebrates Georges Rouault as one of its most important artists of the 20th century. When he died at the age of 87 in 1958, he had already been riding the crest of French critical and public opinion for almost 20 years. He was called nothing short of the great French genius of our age, glorified as the savior of contemporary art, and claimed an equal of Durer, Rembrandt and Goya, The Catholic philosopher Jacques Maritain, whose admiration for Rouault was in no way restrained, wrote that a philosopher could study in Rouault the virture of art in a pure state.

title: PanAmerican Games Open Door to Softball
description: The PanAmerican Sports Organization has admitted softball as an official sport for the 1975 PanAmerican Games to be held in Santiago, Chile.

title: Brewers Top Angels
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 (AP)The Milwaukee Brewers scored three runs in the fourth inning, two on a throwing error by Rudy May, and beat the Calif fornia Angels, 41, tonight.

title: MIAMI SURGEON SETS POWERBOAT RECORD
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (AP) A Miami Beach eye surgeon won the Catalina Challenge Trophy offshore powerboat race at Marina del Rey in record time today and also set a record for the most championship points in one racing season.

title: The Way the Ball Bounces Figures in Laguna's Training
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 3 Bouncing a rubber bail on the floor, Ismael Laguna weaved his head from side to side as the ball flashed past it. Every so often, he would duck his head and let the ball float over it.

title: A multiplicity of plaids
Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. Kills Its Own Cleanup Plan For the Passaic River in Jersey
description: The Nixon Administration has dropped a water pollution control program that might have cleaned up New Jersey's Passaic River and pointed the way toward clearing the pollution from other rivers in the country.

title: WOMAN IN BUSINESS
description: The office is in the Pentagon.

title: ORIOLES' PALMER REGISTERS 17TH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) Jim Palmer became the fourth Baltimore pitcher to win 17 games this season as he scattered nine hits in beating the Washington Senators tonight, 62.

title: Miss Helaine Lazar
description: Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, and Mrs. Lazar of Holliswood Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helaine Toby Lazar, to Steven Mark Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Harris of Port Chester, N. Y.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt's hard enough to discern the consensus of Congress when its 535 members are all in the capital. When they're scattered across the 50 states and 435 Congressional Districts, any attempt to assess the collective Congressional intent may be nothing short of foolhardy.

title: Wells Sentenced to Prison For Violation of Probation
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 4 (UPI)A Superior Court judge sentenced Warren Wells, the Oakland Raiders' wide receiver, to state prison yesterday for violation of his probation for a 1969 attempted rape conviction.

title: Utah Stars Cut Harlem Hero, Plan to Enroll Him in College
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 4 (UPI)Harlem's Earl Manigault, called by Lew Alcindor the best basketball player his size in the history of New. York City, was cut from the Utah Stars training camp yesterday. But his career, at age 25, may be just beginning.

title: MATTHEW M. LEVY, JUSTICE, 72, DEAD
description: State Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy died yesterday in BronxLebanon Hospital Center, of which he had been a vice president since 1962. He was 72 years old and lived at IT Fifth Avenue.

title: Miss Melnik of Soviet Snaps Her World. Record in Discus
description: MUNICH, Sept. 4 (UPI)Faina Melnik of the. Soviet Union broke her women's discusthrow world record today with a toss of 212 feet 10 inches at the Hans Braun preOlympic track and field meet.

title: Board of Education to Intensify Program to Curtail Drug Abuse
description: Steppedup drug prevention programs that will inchide specialists assigned to each of the Icity's public high schools have been announced by the Board of Education.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: NAY I comment on Joan Peyser's Boulez: Bringing 'Em Back To Life?

title: A COUNTRY CLUB IS FOR DOGS, TOO
description: At Arnell's Country Club the guests never play golf or tennis. Instead they mostly sleep, eat, walk and look out for passing cars.

title: Schools
description: Americans have long prided themselves on their nation's role as the Melting Pot of the world, the new land where the huddled masses of the globe were welcomed and accepted and integrated into the larger society. The job was done in large measure by the public schools.

title: Pirates Beat Expos in 11th, 76;
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4Vic Davalillo lashed a runscoring double down the leftfield line with one out in the bottom of the 11th inning today to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 76 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: MRS. HENRY J. WOLFF
description: Mrs. Frances Angela Thaddeus Wolff, a criminal lawyer with offices at 115 Broadway and a former Assistant United States Attorney for the East em District, died Saturday of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Pravda Hails Berlin Pact as Landmark
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4The Soviet Union called the Big Four agreement on Berlin an important landmark toward lasting peace in Europe and said all sides concerned would benefit from it.

title: Instant (almost) vacation house
description: Will housing of the future resemble this molded Fiberglas house from Finland? It's more than possible it will. Meanwhile, the house could be an urbanite's answer to instant vacationing. The structure, designed by architect Matti Suuronen for Polykem of Finland, will be on display at Gimbels during the store's Scandinavian fair starting September 10. The shell, excluding utilities, shipment to the site and erection, costs approximately $10,000. Not quite a bargain yetbut if the idea catches on and production reaches mass proportions, the price could be appreciably lowersome say as low as $6,000.

title: Jamming City Terminals, Many Make Holiday Exit
description: Travelers continued to jam Kennedy International Airport, bus terminals and train stations yesterday as the city began the first day of the last major summer holiday weekend.

title: Little Chrissie Captivates Tennis Fans
description: After she had won her first match in the United States Open tennis championships, Chris Evert shook hands with Edda Buding, her opponent, thanked the umpire and walked off the court to a rousing ovation.

title: CALCUTTA PLANS A SUBWAY BY '78
description: CALCUTTA, Sept. 4The Government has approved a plan to give this city a subway system by 1978.

title: Letters
description: Your designation of the Minorities Advancement Plan as The Galbraith Plan (The Galbraith Plan to Promote the Minorities, Aug. 22) is a bit hard on my two distinguished and diligent coauthors, Edwin Kuh and Lester C. Thurow, each of whom is as experienced on these problems as I am. And perhaps it is a bit hard on the plan itself for people, I think rightly, are somewhat assured by knowing that a proposed action reflects the collective judgment and discussion of more than one person.

title: Indians Top Red Sox, 119
description: BOSTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)Roy Foster, Chris Chambliss and Ray Fosse slammed home runs as the Cleveland Indians scored four runs in the sixth inning and seven in the seventh today to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 119. The Indians had been held to one hit over the first five innings by Jim Lonborg.

title: RESPONSE
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: CYPRIOTE ENDS TALKS WITH GREEK PREMIER
description: ATHENS, Sept. 4  Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus and Premier George Papadopoulos of Greece ended two days of talks here today with a bland communiqu that seemed to indicate that the two still have different views on how to resolve tensions between the island's Greek and. Turkish communities.

title: Truck Makers Happy
description: DETROIT  If there was any doubt that truck sales in the United States this year would hit the twomillion mark for the first time in the industry's history, it has been greatly diminished by President Nixon's economic plan for the nation.

title: COSMOS, CHIEFS TO PLAY TONIGHT
description: The New York Cosmos have healed their wounds from the physically brutal skirmish against the Atlanta Chiefs last Thursday night and are ready to battle the Chiefs in the second game of the North American Soccer League playoffs at Hofstra Stadium, at Hempstead, L. L tonight. The winner of two games will advance to the final.

title: CANADA SIX ALLOWED IN '72 WORLD GAMES
description: TORONTA, Sept, 4 (AP)While the Canadian Amateur Hockey Association has ruled it is staying out of Olympiclevel competition, it has given permission for a Canadian team to participate in next year's World Student Games.

title: Einstein The Life and Times. By Ronald W. Clark. 718 pp. New York and Cleveland: The World Publishing Company. $15.
description: Today, 16 years after his death at the age of 76, Albert Einstein is remarkably alive in contemporary science. I am not speaking about his practical influence, those parts of his theories that come to be incorporated into modern gadgets, from TV sets nuclearpower reactors. Rather, as a quick look current research journals or at the Science Citation Index can show, his work is still the acknowledged base of new research results in an astonishing variety of problems in physics, cosmology and to some extent also in chemistry.

title: CHINA STILL FINDS TROUBLE IN TIBET
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 4 Twenty years after the Chinese Army marched into Lhasa, the capital, Tibet remains one of China's most troubled regions. In establishing control over Tibet, Peking has had to cope with a sensitive border, a rebellious population and contending factions among the Chinese sent to settle there.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Indiscriminate addition, of a 10 per cent surtax on those items which are imported because they are not manufactured in this country, yet represent necessities, would contribute to inflation. In chemicals, we can cite the following examples: brucine alkaloid

title: Col. Schuder Is Named Army Athletic Director
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 4Col. William J. Schuder has become director of athletics at the United States Military Academy, succeeding Col. Gus Dielens. Dielens retired from the Army to become athletic director at the University of Tampa.

title: Carbine Hanover Captures $10,000 Pace at Freehold,
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 4Snow Shoe Farms' Carbine Hanover, with Bill Haughton driving won the $10,000 Asbury Park pace at Freehold Raceway today. The 4yearold son of Bullet Hanover posted a 2:00.1, mile, fastest time of the meeting.

title: St. Louis Defeats Potomac In Polo tournament, 11 to 9
description: TOUGHKENAMON, Pa., Sept. 4Steve Orthwein, a former Yale star, scored six goals to lead St. Louis to an 119 victory over Potomac of Washington today in a semifinal round game of the Jerald Balding memorial eightgoal polo tournament at the Brandywine Polo Club.

title: NETS PLAY BULLETS AT COMMACK OCT. 9
description: The New York Nets will take on the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association at Long Island Arena, Commack, on Saturday night, Oct. 9, for the benefit of the United Fund of Long Island.

title: They would walk into the mouth of a cannon without flinching
description: Talleyrand once said that treason is a matter of timing, and this is certainly true of the Black Panthers who, between 1967 and 1971, have ceased to be symbols of terror and have become contentious voices in the political wilderness. Of the three books about the rise and fall of the Panthers considered herePanthermania by Gail Sheehy, Look for Me in the Whirlwind by the New York 21 and Gilbert Moore's A Special RageMoore's book is by far the best. The other two, although they strive to be topical and to give new insights into the dramatic emergence and decline of a unique black revolutionary movement, deserve little more from the reader than a mildly affectionate disregard.

title: Schmidt Sets Record For Hammer Throw
description: LAHR, Germany, Sept. (AP)  Walter Schmidt of West Germany set a world record in the hammer throw today with a distance of 250 feet 7.93 inches.

title: Burger Asks Improvements In States' Judicial Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, meeting with the board of directors of the National Center for State Courts, today urged further improvements in the judicial systems of the states.

title: LETTERS
description: The article on market research (Aug. 29) may have conveyed the impression that Daniel Starch & Staff acquired a research firm from my father, Elmo Roper, whom you referred to as the late dean of public opinion researchers.

title: Mississippi Priest Enters Race for State Senate
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 4A white Josephite priest originally from Long Island, will become the first Roman Catholic priest to run for a seat in the Mississippi Legislature this fall.

title: Chilean Fishermen Ahead
description: IQUIQUE, Chile, Sept. 4 (AP) Chile took the lead in the ninth underwater fishing world championship today, its threemen team totaled 435,350 points. Peru was second with 403,250 points.

title: Photograpy
description: ANEW blackandwhite bromide printing paper just introduced produces high gloss enlargements without need for ferrotyping. The paper has a special plastic coating that gives the surface a permanent gloss, and that also makes it waterproof so that only a very short wash is necessary after processing. Distributed by Luminos Photo Corporation, 25 Wolffe Street, Yonkers, N. Y. 10705, and called Luminos BromideRC, this new enlarging paper can be dried in from five to seven minutes by placing on an electric drier, face side up, with a very low heat (it should not exceed 140 degrees). It can also be airdried without heat by merely placing it flat on a smooth surface, face side up, and allowing it to dry for for about one hour.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The Government and a host of distinguished grandstand quarterbacks were fully engaged last week in the process of devising a means of holding back wages and prices when the present freeze ends in midNovember.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The last three weeks haven't been particularly happy ones for one of the stock market's more dedicated minority groups, the investors (or speculators) in gold stocks.

title: Miss Dunham Has Nuptials
description: ST. HUBERT'S, N. Y., Sept. 4Miss Pamela Lewis Dunham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Dunham of New Canaan, Conn., was married here today to John Merrill Ely Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ely of Bronxville, N. Y., and Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: First Junior Tennis Bowl Is Awarded to Miss Evert
description: Chris Evert received the first Planters Peanuts junior tennis bowl yesterday as the outstanding junior player in 1971.

title: Narcotics Suspect Accused by Captain Of a Bribe Attempt
description: A suspect who allegedly tried to bribe a police captain in BedfordStuyvesant station was booked yesterday for attempted bribery in addition to the charges of possession of narcotics and dangerous weapons on which he had been brought in.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Fresh Yankee Sets Mark In Trot at Brandywine
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept 4 (AP)  Fresh Yankee, owned by Duncan McDonald of Nova Scotia, won the $25,000 Star's Pride Trot tonight at Brandywine Raceway, in worldrecord time.

title: Madeleine Lord Bride Of Dr. Benjamin White
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 4Miss Madeleine d'Ivry Lord, a granddaughter of the late Jacques de La Chapelle, who was a vice president of Abercrombie & Fitch and president of its Chicago store, was married here at noon today to Dr. Benjamin Winthrop White, a greatgrandson of Stanford White, the architect.

title: Professor Weds Mrs. Ellerkmann
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4Mrs. Hildegard Thun Scheffey Ellerkmann was married here this morning to Clyde de Loache Ryals, professor of English and graduate chairman of the department of English at the University of Pennsylvania. The Rev. John M. Scott performed the ceremony at a nuptial eucharist in St. Andrew's Collegiate Chapel at the Philadelphia Divinity School of the Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Donald F. Winslow and the Rev, Robert F. Evans.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:The adventures described in Our Night on the Grease Rack (Travel section, Aug. 1) in which Roy Bongartz told how he and his wife stayed overnight in Akron, Ohio, reminded us of our unplanned visit to Astoria, Ore. In our case it was bad weather, not car trouble, that afforded us our happy accident. We could not pitch our tent, because of persistent rain, and, bedraggled and soaked, we checked into an Astoria motel. In less than 24 hours in that delightful port we saw the Astoria Column, took a tour of the Bumble Bee canning factory, visited the maritime and historical museum and drove past the fine homes built by the wealthy in the 19th century. While we were extolling Astoria's virtues at lunch, just before leaving, the Mayor's wife overheard us and walked over to our table to introduce herself. What more could we ask! BARBARA GRUBMAN (Mrs.) Granada Hills, Calif.

title: Bengals Beat Packers, 2724
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 (AP)A rookie quarterback, Ken Anderson, engineered the Cincinnati Bengals to a 2724 victory over the Green Bay Packers tonight. The triumph was the fifth straight in preseason play for the Bengals.

title: Letters:
description: To The Editor:

title: Doria Forces a Shift In Site of Dog Show
description: Tropical storm Doria, which caused so much damage in Jersey, has forced the New Brunswick Kennel Club to shift the site of its eighth show tomorrow. Originally it had been scheduled for Johnson Park, River Road, Piscataway. However, the Raritan overflowed its banks and flooded the area. So the show will be held in Roosevelt Park, Route 1 and Parsonage Road, Metuchen.

title: Recordings
description: RECORD promoters learn to slice the publicity claim awfully thin, sometimes with such surgical skill that a blurb is as transparent as delicatessen ham. Still, fine distinctions have to be drawn these days; the classical literature has been so sedulously picked over in search of fresh repertory that the genuine first has become the trade's chimera. So, while RCA cannot claim that Peter Serkin's performance of Beethoven's Concerto in D [Op. 61a] is a recorded first, or even a stereo first, we can be advised on the jacket's front that this is the first major recording of Beethoven's own piano version of the famous Violin Concerto. Considering the confusion often generated by jacket blurbs, RCA's statement is clear.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kvancz to Coach at Brown
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 4 (AP)A former Boston College star, Jack Kvancz, was named today as an assistant basketball coach at Brown University.

title: JUMPER LAURELS TO SANS MARQUE
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 4Barney Ward's Sans Marque won his second open jumper class in two starts today at the New York State Fair horse show.

title: ROBERT A. GRIFFENBERG
description: Robert A. Griffenherg, who was serving as principal of Inwood Junior High School, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 3720 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. His age was 54.

title: Horse Show News
description: The North Shore horse show, the start of the annual major equine doubleheader on Long Island, gets under way for four days on Thursday at the Old Field Club in Stony Brook. The following week the Piping Rock show is scheduled for the same site. The two events are the sole remaining allClass A shows on the Island. In the past the Piping Rock show was held at the club's grounds in Locust Valley. The show was forced to move, however, and for a time there was some doubt that it would be held at all.

title: Jets to Ask Lindsay to Expand Shea Stadium to Seating Capacity of 82,000
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 4In another effort to explore the possibility of a new National Football League franchise to replace the New Jerseybound Giants, Mayor Lindsay will meet with Philip H. Iselin, president of the Jets, next Tuesday at noon at City Hall.

title: Lynch Urges U.N. Observers
description: DUBLIN., Sept. 4 (AP)Prime Minister Jack Lynch of the Irish Republic urged Britain tonight to join his country in asking for a United Nations observer corps to patrol the explosive frontier between the republic and Northern Ireland.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Under stricter Federal and local regulations, American industry's pollution  control efforts are growing.

title: The Nation
Miss Betsy Martha Whelden Engaged to Sandford D. Smith
description: PIEDMONT, Calif., Sept. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Clyde G. Whelden have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Martha Whelden, to Sandford Drexel Smith, son of Sanford C. Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Robert Creamer of Delray Beach, Fla.

title: The Nation
description: TORONTOFor several days after the announcement last month of President Nixon's measures to shore up the American trade balance, Canada fluttered with anxiety. Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, after striking a posture of imperturbability for three days, broke off an Adriatic vacation, flew home and counseled against hasty protectionism and a possible trade war.

title: Mayors Plan Overseas Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) The United States Conference of Mayors said today that five mayors would leave Sept. 30 to exchange ideas with their counterparts in Germany and Poland. Henry W. Maier, of Milwaukee, Wis.; Frank N. Zullo, Norwalk, Conn.; Roman S. Gribbs, Detroit; Willis D. Gradison Jr., Cincinnati, Ohio, and Thomas J. D'Alesandro 3d, Baltimore, will be in Munich Oct. 1 and 2 and in Warsaw and other Polish cities starting Oct. 3. The tour will end Oct. 16.

title: The County Sheriff Named du PontHere's a Man Who's Found a Hobby
description: ELKTON, Md., Sept. 4 (AP)When the man from the billiondollar family became a sheriff of Cecil County last November, he obviously wasn't after the $125aweek salary.

title: METS TAKE PAIR;
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4The lateblooming New York Mets swept a doubleheader from the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, extending the Mets' September winning streak to five games and the Phillies' losing streak to eight.

title: DIANA KENNEDY'S MEXICAN CORN SOUP
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitz Lowers Mark In 200 FreeStyle
description: LEIPZIG, East Germany, Sept. 4Mark Spitz swam to a world record in the 200. meter freestyle and pulled the United States into the lead in a recordbreaking relay race today as a touring American squad completed twoday rout of a strong East German team.

title: Extended Controls Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Arnold R. Weber, executive director of the Cost of Living Council, said today that some of the economic controls that might follow the end of the freeze would probably last as long as a year.

title: Egypt Asks Death Penalty For Sabry and 8 Others
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4  Egypt's Prosecutor General demanded today that a revolutionary tribunal impose death sentences on the former Vice President, Aly Sabry, and eight other former high officials who are among 91 persons accused of high treason for a challenge to President Anwar elSadat last May.

title: Dance
description: JUST in case you hadn't ejnoticed, the sixties dumped a cultural revolution in our laps. This included capital C Culture, and the faces of the arts have changed more in that decade than in the prevous half century. Music is probably the most unrecognizable, paintingcumsculpture running a close second. Film graduated to the status of an accepted art. Of them all, only opera seems unchangingly tied to the past; it will be interesting to see if it survives.

title: Jane A. Oonk Has Wedding
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4  The marriage of Miss Jane Ann Oonk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Oonk of Cos Cob, to Peter Lyman Goedecke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Goedecke of Canton Center, took place here today in Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert Hardman performed the ceremony.

title: Bourke Hickenlooper Is Dead; Former Iowa Senator Was 75
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 4  Former Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, died here early today at the home of friends. He was 75 years old. The police said a heart attack apparently caused his death but an autopsy will be held this weekend.

title: Gardens
description: HOUSE plants can do decorative wonders in a home. There is more economical way to raise them with greater variety abundance than from seeds.

title: Boeing Garbage Project Seeks Thriving Desert
description: BOARDMAN, Ore., Sept. 4 (AP)The Boeing Company says it is going to use 200,000 tons of solid waste, mostly household garbage, to see if it can make the Eastern Oregon desert bloom.

title: Alice R. Tepper Plans Nuptials Here on Sept. 25
description: ELBERON, N. J., Sept. 4Miss Alice R. Tepper, executive director and founder of the Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research group with offices in New York and Washington, plans to be married here Sept. 25 to Dr. John Anthony Marlin, an assistant professor of economics at the Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University of New York.

title: Beth Feldman to Wed
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Sept. 4Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Feldman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beth Ann Feldman, to Marc Howard Rudofsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rudofsky of Bayside, Queens. Mr. Feldman is administrator at the New York City Regional Office of the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene

title: Black Postmaster, The First on L.C., Started at $2,100
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I.  Major Simmons, a carer postal worker and resident here for 18 years, has been named Long Island's first, black postmaster.

title: Lad Neverntor Takes Raven Class In Sayville Regatta
description: SAYVILLE, L. Sept. 4Bill Ludlum sailed his Nevermor to victory in the Raven Class race as the Sayville yacht Club's annnel Labor pay weekpnd in vittition regatta got under Way today. Apriroxiniately 200 oiraft took starting guns with a southwester blowing up to 20 knots prevalling.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: No plan ever devised can be said to consist of all pros and no cons. I question whether the one envisioning a new West Side Highway [New West Side Highway Above River Proposed, Aug. 29] will prove the exception to the rule.

title: Half Stoned Triumphs
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Sept 4 (AP)Half Stoned, an 8yearof gelding ridden by Rudy Rincon, rallied from far back to win the $1,900 eighth race at Finger Lakes Race Track today.

title: FORD OPPOSES CUTS IN DEFENSE OUTLAY
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House minority leader, warned tonight that any curtailment of United States defense expenditures as the involvement in Vietnam nears an end would thwart the nation's effort to keep pace with Soviet military advances.

title: It Was a Good Week for Watching Tennis at Forest Hills Even if You Didn't Have a Seat
description: Hey, isn't that Jan Leschly on the court? whispered a fan at the United States Open tennis championships, I thought he'd retired years ago.

title: IN THE NATION
description: When Patrick V. Murphy was a young New York City policeman, he used to hear from cynics in the locker room the saying that the job is only good for time or money. Now that the gentlevoiced but exceedingly tough Mr. Murphy is Commissioner of the city's 31,000man police force, he has taken dead aim on that attitude and New York's Finest are not likely to be the same again.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In discussing the economic impact of the Administration's new economic program, Edwin L. Dale Jr. (Aug. 22) chided Paul Samuelson and Arthur Okun for not recognizing its stimulative potential.

title: LEMONGELLO SINGS AT RAINBOW GRILL
description: Give the Rainbow Grill credit for setting aside a month of its annual schedule to give a pair of young singers a showcase amidst its otherwise (supposedly) surefire headliners.

title: John Koch Marries Miss Virginia Sloss
description: HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 4Miss Virginia Sloss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Sloss, was married here this afternoon to John H. Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Koch of Allentown, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the garden of the Sloss home by the Rev. Dr. Carleton M. Fisher of the South Nassau Unitarian Church in Freeport.

title: The Nation
description: Sensation in New York is: A grand slam of heads rolling. . . A commissioner who says he's going to do something big, and then does it, no election in sight. ... Mayor Lindsay stepping back and smiling as one of his men gets the headlines, five days running.

title: 7 LUNCHEONS LISTED BY JETS' FAN CLUB
description: A series of seven luncheons to be held Mondays following home games of the New York Jets, has been set by the Jets' 1st and 10 Club at Thursday's 24 Restaurant, 57 West 58th Street.

title: TELEPHONE COMPANY BACKED ON FINANCES
description: A State Public Service Commission examiner has recommended closing the commission's investigation of financing practices of the New York Telephone Company, especially in relation to its parent, American Telephone and Telegraph Company, without taking state action.

title: DROWNING SHAKES A YOUTH PROGRAM
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 4The drowning of a Minneapolis youth in a Canadian lake this week while he was taking part in an Outward Bound program has raised questions about the future of such courses in wilderness survival.

title: September
description: Last night's full moon was the last full moon of summer by the calendar. The next full moon, the first week in October, will be this year's Harvest Moon, and by then there will be color in the woodland, ripeness in the grape and frost upon the pumpkin.

title: KEENE TO MAKE BOW AS MET CONDUCTOR
description: Christoper Keene, the, 24yearold American conductor, will make his Metropolitan Opera debut during the first week of the company's season, leading the performances of Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana and Leoncavall's Pagliacci in a double bill Sept. 24.

title: Infestations of Lice Increasing; Communal Living a Key Factor
description: Lice, for many years considered to be a plague primarily of vagrants, prostitutes and the overcrowded poor, have made a substantial comeback in recent years among the general populace, climbing steadily up the social ladder, according to reports from dermatologists around the country.

title: Headliners
description: The travels of 74yearold Mrs. Sarah Krasnoff ended last Wednesday, in Amsterdam within earshot of the big jets she had used to cross the Atlantic almost daily this summer along with her grandson, Howard Gelfand, 14. The boy's mother died in 1960 and since then he has spent much of his time with his widowed grandmother. Then this summer, friends and relatives said, Mrs. Krasnoff and the boy's father differed over whether or not the youngster was showing problems of adjustment. The grandmother took the boy out of school and the pair began travelling. There followed 130and perhaps 160crossings of the Atlantic at a cost of more than $1,000 a trip. In most cases they would arrive at Amsterdam in the morning and return to New York that evening without leaving the airport or even bothering to go through customs. Asked once why they were returning so soon, the youth answered: We forgot to turn off a leaking tap. But last Sunday, Mrs. Krasnoff arrived in Amsterdam alone and after complaining of feeling tired, was taken to a hotel. Howard arrived on Monday afternoon and called a doctor. But the exhaustion was too great. On Wednesday Mrs. Krasnoff died.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BEGADJAH, IndonesiaMan's life on earth ended today. Experts, roused from their sleep, declined to comment. But one local man, concluding an allnight celebration of the birth of his seventh child, said: Allah will provide.

title: CHINATOWN MIXED ON THE NIXON TRIP
description: To Shong Lim, surounded by real and plastic plants in his EverBlossom Flower and Gift Shoppe in Chinatown, President Nixon's planned trip to Peking is like going to visit a lion in its laironce you get in you never get out safe.

title: Daniel Derneure, Student, to Wed Miss Ellen James
description: LARCHMON T, N. Y., Sept. 4Winfield H. James, president of The New York Daily News, and Mrs. James have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen McNair James, to Daniel Jean Yvon Demeure, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Demeurd of Rennes, France. A December wedding is planned in Rennes.

title: Internal Strife Splits City's Taxi Union, 9 Months After the Strike
description: The New York City Taxi Drivers Union, nine months after a strike that brought many drivers a pay cut instead of a raise and made many New Yorkers wonder just how much they needed taxis, is torn by bitter strife and what the police say is a pattern of violence against dissident members.

title: Parachutes bested For Mars Landing
description: Tests of parachute systems designed to land scientific instruments on Mars in 1976 have been started in California by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Joseph H. Schubert To Wed Miss Wolff
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 4Miss Patricia Kingsley Wolff, plans to be married here Oct. 2 to Joseph Henry Schubert of New York, a certified public accountant.

title: Monica O'Gara Is Bride of Gardiner H. Shattuck Jr.
description: The marriage of Miss Monica O'Gara to Gardiner H. Shattuck Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Shatttuck of Wellesley, Mass., took place here yesterday in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the General Theological Seminary, where the bridegroom is a student. The bride is a daughter of James O'Gara, editor of Commonweal magazine, and Mrs. O'Gara of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: The Traveler's Guide To HashHouse Greek
description: BEFORE you go to Paris, you learn to say Bonjour, monsieur, je voudrais bien avoir un Chateaubriand avec des pommel de terra et un grand verre de Bordeaux. On the plane to Frankfurt, you memorize Guten abend, wir mchten zweimal Sauerbraten, Erbsen, etwas Schwarzbrot, and eine halte Flasche Zeller Schwarze Katz haben. So in your own countrywhere, if you expect to do any traveling, you run the risk of getting stuck in a diner at some time and place you owe it to yourself to learn Hash House Greek, the peculiar American lunchcounter cant.

title: Daughter to the Paleys
description: A daughter was born here to Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Paley of Harrison, N. Y., on Aug. 24 at the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Paley, a corporate lawyer in New York, is a former Republican State Senatorial candidate from the 25th District on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The child has been named Jennifer May.

title: NORTH INSINCERE, SOUTH KOREA SAYS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 4 Premier Kim Jong Pil charged today that North Korea had not shown sincere interest in peaceful reunification or in talks between the North and South.

title: Bang, Crash: It's a Sport in Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L.I.  The crowd is Middle America and it's joined by the same bond that used to unite spectators at a hanging. They shout, Three! Two! One ... Go! and in front of them Cadillacs and Imperials and Continentals begin to crash.

title: Will N. E. P. Work?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4From the standpoint of the startled Demotrats, the President's NeW Econbmic Program might just as well be entitled the Nixon Election Program.

title: Bridge Getting down to the nines
description: THE term solid is reasonably precise for the chemist or the physicist, but the unfortunate bridge player has to contend with degrees of solidity. For most purposes he can assume a potential trump suit solid if the partnership has the three top honors.

title: SHEFFIELD UNITED KEEPS ON WINNING
SHIEBLER RETIRING AS E.C.A.C.'S HEAD
description: After close to 45 years of affiliation with intercollegiate athletics; George L. Shiebler has announced his retirement as commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, the nation's largest.

title: 2 Miami Jockeys Charged In Bribery Conspiracy Case
description: MIAMI, Sept. 4 (AP)  The Florida Division of PariMutuel Racing reported today it had charged two jockeys, Terry Bove and Jos Suarez, with violations pertaining to bribery and conspiracy to commit fraud.

title: PROTESTANT MOVE FEARED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 4Amid growing fears of a Protestant backlash, British troops came under sporadic sniper fire, and attack today, leaving one soldier dead and two seriously wounded.

title: Rough Ride in Rapid Transit
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif.The Rohr Corporation, the first of what is becoming a throng of aerospace companies knocking at the doors of the nation's public transit operators, is finding out that rapid transit can provide a rough ride.

title: U.S. Blacks Visiting Africa Find That the Feeling of Kinship Is Not Always Shared
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 4A Cambridgeeducated Nigerian judge and a visiting American civil rights leader met at a diplomatic reception in Lagos not long ago, and their conversation turned to the race problem in the United States.

title: Linda McClellan Married in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4Miss Linda Lou McClellan was married here this afternoon to Peter O. C. AustinSmall of Greenwich.

title: New York
description: When Pvt. Virgil Jones drove a threequarterton truck in Germany, he dreamed of having his own business. Six months ago, the dream came true. He paid $700 for a 1965 Ford Galaxie, $100 for, a city livery permitand became a gypsy cab driver.

title: The work plots the course of the still uncompleted revolution
description: On the dust cover the embittered, suspicious face of August Strindberg peers from the top of a great, blank, black, elongated cone of a cloak that conceals everything else. If there were displayed, on either side of the head, a hand damaged by alchemical experiments, one would be tempted to scrawl, as a subtitle, Kilroy was here. And indeed since Strindberg has been here, there and everywhere that subsequent dramatists have been, the device would not be inappropriate; it could well be hung in every theater, round or square. And yet the essential part of the symbolism is the wall between him and us.

title: Crackdown in Soccer
description: LONDON, Sept. 4When British soccer players took the field in the opening matches of the season, they scarcely knew what hit them. The referees for long had been docile creatures who had stood by meekly and complaisantly while the players kicked, tripped and occasionally even punched one another. But now the referees had turned into roaring lions, authoritarians and monsters of pedantry.

title: POLL SHOWS NIXON TOPS 3 DEMOCRATS
description: President Nixon has pulled ahead of his three most potent Democratic rivals in public opinion samplings on the 1972 Presidential election, the Gallup Poll has reported.

title: Ch. Kenovo Constellation, English Cocker Spaniel, Is Best in Newton Show
description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Sept. 4When Pamela Hall's English cocker spaniel, Ch. Kenovo Constellation, was named best sporting dog at the 28th annual Newton Kennel Club Show at the Sussex County Farm and Horse Show Grounds today, Miss Hall received a silver pitcher.

title: Families at Tocks Island Site Protest Routing by Marshals
description: SHAWNEEONDELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 4A group of alleged squatters here protested today that the Federal Government had routed 30 of them from their homes, which were then razed, even though they say a Federal court has not determined whether they were trespassing illegally.

title: I.T.T. Under Fire
description: Harold S. Geneen, the 61yearold president, chairman and chief executive of the International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation, listened carefully as Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Antitrust subcommittee, spelled out in earthy terms his opinion of the giant, Geneenbuilt conglomerate.

title: SchoolHousing Complex Cleared for West Harlem
description: The New York City Educational Construction Fund announced plans yesterday for a $46million complex in. West Harlem that will provide 1,000 units of low  and moderateincome housing and an intermediate school for 1,800 pupils.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ALBANY, Sept. 4Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, in his capacity as Acting Governor in the absence of Governor Rockefeller and other state officials, today requested the Office of Emergency Preparedness to declare Orange, Rockland and Dutchess Counties in New York as disaster areas.

title: For Young Readers In search of hair and treasure
Valerie C. Roast, Niagara Junior, Plans to Marry
description: CONVENT, N. J., Sept, 4The engagement of Miss Valerie Celeste Roast, a junior at Niagara University, to Thomas Sean O'Connor, a 1971 graduate of the university, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Roast, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Justice Frank D. O'Connor of the New York Supreme Court and Mrs. O'Connor of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: YANKS BOW
description: The home run, one of the weapons that the Yankees employed gainfully during the long years of their glory days in baseball, came back to bedevil them yesterday at their currently controversial Stadium in the Bronx.

title: CHARGER DEFENSE HALTS RAMS 2014
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (UPI)  San Diego's defensive unit dropped Roman Gabriel in his tracks five times, intercepted four passes and blocked a punt last night as the Chargers whipped the Los Angeles Rams, 2014, before a crowd of 56,116.

title: Ramos to Fight Navarro
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (UPI) Mando Ramos, former lightweight champion, will meet Ruben Navarro, No. 4 contender, in a 10round bout Sept. 30 lat the Olympic Auditorium.

title: Army Is Shaken by Crisis In Morale and Discipline
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The bitter Vietnam experience has left the United States Army with a crisis in morale and discipline as serious as any its oldest and toughest soldiers can remember.

title: Congress Must Decide
description: Returning to work this week, Congress finds the political scene transformed. Republicans who have ritualistically deplored economic controls have to reconcile their rhetoric with President Nixon's wageprice freeze. Democrats who have advocated such controls have to decide what to wear politically now that the President has stolen their clothes.

title: Books:
description: THE INTELLIGENT MAN'S EASY GUIDE TO COMPUTERS. A. N. Feldzamen. David McKay Company, Inc. 263 pp. $7.95.

title: CAMBODIA TO SEEK A SAIGON PULLOUT
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 4 (AP)  Cambodia announced today that she would begin talks next week to get South Vietnam to withdraw its 10,000 troops from Cambodian soil. There are mounting complaints from Cambodian villagers and farmers of looting and brutality by South Vietnamese troops.

title: Five in Family Die
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Sept. 4 (AP)The estranged wife of a Fayetteville man walked into a family reunion uninvited today and fatally shot her husband and three other family members, then put the pistol's muzzle in her mouth and killed herself, the county sheriff said.

title: Deborah Wise Future Bride
description: Mrs. Hilda L. Wise of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Deborah Jane Wise of Washington, to Peter N. Sheridan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Sheridan of Scarsdale, N. Y. The wedding is planned for November.

title: Mrs. Doft Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Avrom I. Doft on Aug. 19 at Beth Israel Medical Center. The child has been named David Benjamin. Mr. Doft is vice president of Doft & Co., investment bankers.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: NOTRE DAME TOPS FOOTBALL RATINGS
description: In some unusual balloting, Notre Dame has been picked to dethrone Nebraska as college football's national champions in The Associated Press preseason poll.

title: '70 Motorcycle Deaths At 2,330, A Rise of 19%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) One of the nation's booming fads, motorcycle riding, claimed 2,330 lives in 1970, a rise of 18.9 per cent over the 1969 toll of 1,960 lives, Government safety experts said in a traffic warning for the Labor Day weekend.

title: Nudists From Rome Shed Their Tents, Take the Offensive
description: ROME, Sept. 4For ordinary vacationers this may be the offseason, but the Roman sun will remain hot for at least another month, and a growing number of nudists are coming out ofthe tent.

title: Portland's Entry in P.C.L. Unlikely to Return in 1972
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 4 (UPI)  Whether the Portland Beavers; the last survivors of the original Pacific Coast League, will be back in business next season appears problematical.

title: Burtis Wins in Star Class At the Sea Cliff Y. C. Races
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 4Alan Burtis's Guachero won Star Class honors today in the Hempstead Harbor Holiday sailing sponsored by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

title: Broncos Beat Vikings, 147
description: DENVER, Sept. 4 (AP)Pete Duranko scooped up a fumble by Minnesota's quarterback, Gary Cuozzo, in the closing minutes of the fourth period tonight, giving the Denver Broncos a 147 victory over the Vikings.

title: CHRIS EVERT UPSETS MISS EISEL IN U.S. OPEN TENNIS;
description: Chris Evert said she couldn't believe it, and neither did a stunned crowd of 10,233 at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

title: BourkeWhite Service Set
description: A memorial service for Margaret BourkeWhite will be held at 1 P.M. on Friday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. The internationally known photojournalist, who had suffered for 19 years from Parkinson's disease, died Aug. 27 at the age of 67. Her family has requested that in lieu of flowers contributions be made to the Robert Schwab Parkinson Fund at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: Miss Dawn C. Nagel Is Wed to Richard Berry Fiss
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 4Miss Dawn Carol Nagel and Richard Berry Piss were married this afternoon in the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Teacher Weds Miss Bronson
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Sept. 4  Miss Beverly Blancke Bronson, daughter of Mrs. Adolph Julius Merkt of New York, Guilford, Conn., and Nantucket and the late Walter Whittlesey Bronson 2d, was married here today to Henry Gerhard Theuer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Theuer of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: FILM 'LA VACANZA' STIRS VENICE ROW:Crowd Hoots Italian Entry -- Director Replies in Kind
description: VENICE, Italy, Sept, 4The 1971 Venice Festival had its stormiest session yesterday evening when a section of the audience loudly voiced its objection to a delirious Italian entry, "La Vacanza," which was itself deafeningly noisy."La Vacanza" stars Vanessa Redgrave and Franco Nero and has to do with a peasant girl who suffers more outrages at the hands of the Establishment than were visited on De Sade's Justine. One must have a heart of stone not to laugh at her humiliations, all of them grotesquely pictured.Sold by her parentsas a mareto a miller to whom they are indebted, she finds true love when she runs away and meets an understanding poacher in the woods. Her later aspirations to win the affections of Count Olaudio result in her being incarcerated in a lunatic asylum and later being sent to work in a factory full of vibrating sewing machines. Events here run to a high sexual pitch.At this point a cry of "Schifo""Disgusting"  was heard in the auditorium. That set off a chorus of "Basta""Enough"and the rest of the film became inaudible, though it equaled its spectators in noisemaking. It concluded with most of the players being machine-gunned by the police.Not to be outdone, the movie's director, Tinto Brass, greeted the dissatified house with an obscene gesture when the house lights rose."La Vacanza" is probably the squawkiest of all talkies. Its dialogue in Venetian and Milanese dialects is accompanied by snare drums, bugle calls, nightwatchmen's whistles, agonized shouting and gunfire.The evening's second offering was the official showing of the Chinese film "Red Detachment of Women," a ballet by the Peking Opera photographed in color. The dancers symbolized the militant spirit that prevailed among the women of the Red Army during the civil-war period (1927 to 1937). Maoist representatives, including Communist China's Ambassador to Italy, Shen Piuf, attended. The official showing passed without incident. It seemed anticlimactic after the clamor inspired by a native movie.

title: It Will Take Olympian Effort to Find a Bed in Munich
Stamps
description: POSTAL Service inspectorsthe Gmen of the mail service  are investigating a report by the American Philatelic Expertization Service that the Dwight D. Eisenhower 6c definitive stamp, issued Aug. 6, 1970, has been counterfeited. The original stamp, designed by Robert Geisman and based on a photograph by George Tames of The New York Times, was produced from line engravings. The counterfeit, reported by Col. James T. DeVoss, chairman of the Expertization Service, was produced photographically by lithography.

title: Medieval Day Is Marked By Children at Cloisters
description: Chivalry flowered yesterday in the green hills of fort Tryon Park for nearly everyone except motorists.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The L&M Continental 5,000 Championship, which already has had a goodly number of tight races, concludes its season tomorrow with a 100miler that may be the most competitive of the year. The finale of the eightrace series, which offers drivers from six countries handling big, sin Meseat, open wheel cars, will be run at Lime Rock, Conn., With a field of up to 30 cars. There will also be a preliminary race of 100 kilometers (62 miles) for Formula Super Vee cars, based on Volkswagen components.

title: YANKS TO HONOR LATIN AMERICANS
description: Seventeen acceptances have been received for the Latin American Night program scheduled at Yankee Stadium prior to the YankeeBoston Red Sox game on Tuesday. At least seven Latin states will be represented at the Stadium festival which precedes the 8 o'clock game.

title: Letters:
description: . . . May the request for lower rates for grandparents snowball and become a fact. We have children in California, but the fares are too exorbitant for us. Trains and buses used to have excursions  the empty planes would fill up if the airlines did the same. How about it, American, T.W.A., United?

title: Farm System Is Established by Nassau County Dance Company to Replace Departures From Ranks
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 4The Nassau County Dance Company, suffering the effects of success, is establishing a farm system to replenish its ranks.

title: Art
description: THE nine witty sculptures by William King installed on the terrace of 2 Hanunarskjold Plaza (a new office building) are yet another, proof that of all the qualities that may characterize a work of art, wit is the most elusive. It seems impossible of explanation by anyone who senses it to anyone who doesn't, It is there for you, or it isn't.

title: Miss Sarah Elizabeth DeLand Married to Alton G. Marshall
description: Miss Sarah Elizabeth DeLand and Alton G. Marshall, president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., were married here yesterday afternoon in Christ Church, Methodist. The Rev. James W. Crawford of the Central Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony. A reception followed at the Regency Hotel.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A.A.U. TO CONSIDER CHANGING ITS NAME
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (UPI) Proposals to change the name of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, to alter the definition of amateur and to involve more athletes will be considered at an annual convention Oct. 310 in Lake Placid, N. Y.

title: Art
description: MANFRED SCHWARTZ, who enjoyed substantial if not spectacular prominence as an expressionist painter in the forties and fifties, had no oneman show between 1963 and his death last November at the age of 60. Thus the vestpocket retrospective now at the Whitney Museum of nine paintings from the last decade of his life has about itgiven the skimpy halflife of New York art world reputations below the first rankthe air almost of a debut. What is curious is how well it comes across as such. Both the strengths and the weaknesses of the odd, glowing paintings that comprise it bespeak the hand of an accomplished, yet at the same time a peculiarly youngtalent.

title: Bassett Sells His Shares In Maple Leaf Gardens
description: TORONTO, Sept. 4 (UPI)The controlling triumverate of the Maple Leaf Gardens, home of the National Hockey League's Toronto. Maple Leafs, has been reduced by one member.

title: Philippine Constable Killed On Eve of a Peace Parley
description: MANILA, Sept. 4 (AP)A Philippine constable in Lanao del Norte was killed in ambush today on the eve of a peace conference called to seek an end to lawlessness and violence in the southern Philippines province.

title: Dolphins Victors, 2710
description: MIAMI, Sept. 4 (AP)George Mira threw two touchdown passes tonight as the Miami Dolphins registered a 2710 victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ATLANTA.

title: Most Suburban Schools Face Common Problem as They Open This Week  A Lack of Funds
description: The school systems in the suburbs surrounding New York City, far larger in aggregate than the city system itself, will welcome back two million pupils this week for a year that is starting with more than the usual number of budgetary questions.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: As I said goodby to my daughter at Kennedy Airport, I thought how ridiculous it is that the regular roundtrip fare to California is $326 while the youth fare to Europe is less than $200. Please help Americans who want togetherness with their families on the Coast. The telephone companies are cooperating; how about the airlines?

title: Woman Jumps 63
description: VIENNA, Sept. 4 (AP)Ilona Gusenbauer of Austria, the European champion, bettered. the 10yearold women's world highjump record of Rumania's Yolanda Balas today by a quarterinch, clearing 6 feet 3 inches at an international meet.

title: HIGHWAY PROJECT HALTED IN JERSEY
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Sept. 4 A Superior Court judge has halted a planned widening of the New Jersey Turnpike through this Middlesex County community until the ecological effects of the project can be determined.

title: Columbia's Defensive Unit Impressive in Scrimmage
description: LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 4The defense is always ahead of the offense in the early days of football practice, and that is certainly the case at Columbia's preseason camp. But seldom has the Lions' defense looked so good.

title: Percy D. Eldred ls Dead; Press Aide to Patton, Nimitz
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (AP)Percy D. Eldred, retired Associated Press writer and editor who served as Gen. George S. Patton Jr.'s press officer in World; War II, died yesterday, in Letterman Gen eral Hospital.

title: HEART TREATMENT AT HOME PRAISED
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 4  Some men who have suffered heart attacks recuperate just as well, and possibly better, when they are treated at home instead of in a hospital, a team of British doctors contends.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Why is it that so many writers of articles such as Toni Morrison's What the Black Woman Thinks About Women's Lib (Aug. 22) refuse to look squarely at the facts regarding black man white woman relationships? There are quite a number of white women (myself included) who are neither children, nor spoiled, nor rich, who are attracted to black men for some rather good reasons.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Four leases have been signed at the new 34story Capitol Industries Building at 1370 Avenue of the Americas at 56th Street which is now 90 per cent leased.

title: East Germans and Bonn Conservatives Voice Misgivings on Berlin Agreement
description: BERLIN, Sept. 4East German Communist and West German conservative politicians reacted alike today with subdued misgivings over the agreement on the status of Berlin signed here yesterday by the Big Four ambassadors.

title: Many Turn to Houseboats for the Life of a Comfortable Huck Finn
description: NORRIS LAKE, Tenn. Edgar C. Chaffin owns an oldfashioned boat and is proud of her. She is a 42foot Chris  Craft cabin cruiser with solid mahogany paneling, two baths and a double bed in the stateroom. He paid $60,000 for her 14 years ago.

title: 19 PEKING DIPLOMATS: SUMMONED BY CHOU
description: LONDON, Sept, 4 (AP)Premier Chou Enlai has summoned 19 key Chinese envoys home from abroad to help prepare for President Nixon's coming visit to Peking, senior diplomats disclosed today.

title: Hope Is Voiced for Suffolk Shore Growth
description: COMMACK, L. I., Sept. 4Over the last two decades, commerce and industry have gradually crept outward along the shoreline of Long Island, bringing oil depots, waterfront motels, marinas, apartments and shipping facilities as well as parks and recreational areas. The suburban sprawl, as planners term much of this phenomenon, is now well into Suffolk County on both shores, but planning experts were optimistic today that the time of unchecked and haphazard development of the shoreline was end.

title: R. L. Weiner Fiance Of Audrey Slifman
description: DEER PARK, L.I., Sept. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Slifman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audrey Dale Slifman, to Robert Louis Weiner, son of Mr. M. Edwin Weiner of Lyndhurst, Ohio, and the late Mr. Weiner.

title: The Good Word: It All Depends on Your Genre
description: In movies, they're called genre writers; in real life they're called hacks. If Alfred Hitchcock wrote novels, he would be herded into roundup, and thrown in the caboose at the back of the book section. If Agatha Christie made films, she would be the toast of France.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is strange to find oneself reading an article written last November and published now. Yet, this is what has occurred to me with my Point of View article of Aug. 15 [Architect Sees Need of Factory Housing.] It is also a bit embarrassing, for facts do change and they did in this instance.

title: New Criminal Process Law in Effect
description: The new Criminal Procedure Law, which will affect virtually every encounter in the state between a defendant and the police, courts, lawyers, judges and jails, went into effect last week.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: A recent extended automobile trip, which included large areas of the Northwest, prompts me to deplore the tragic destruction of timber resources wrought by lumber interests in Idaho, Washington and Oregon. In addition, commercialization in Oregon has turned much of the coastal area into an incredible eyesorewhere once there was a wealth of natural beauty and resources. An Easterner perhaps has no right to point a finger, but nothing that I have seen in the East can compare with the mayhem along the Oregon coast. There has been indiscriminate slash cutting, often right down to the water's edge, and it has left most of the coastal areas that I saw, from the Olympic Peninsula south to Newport, devoid of all but a few large Douglas fir and ponderosa pine. It was a strange sensation to drive along U.S. 101, a highway often lined with a solitary stand of large trees, and to see barren areas beginning a few yards from the highway and extending all the way back to the tops of coastal mountains. coastal area into an incredible eyesorewhere once there was a wealth of natural beauty and resources. An Easterner perhaps has no right to point a finger, but nothing that I have seen in the East can compare with the mayhem along the Oregon coast. There has been indiscriminate slash cutting, often right down to the water's edge, and it has left most of the coastal areas that I saw, from the Olympic Peninsula south to Newport, devoid of all but a few large Douglas fir and ponderosa pine. It was a strange sensation to drive along U.S. 101, a highway often lined with a solitary stand of large trees, and to see barren areas beginning a few yards from the highway and extending all the way back to the tops of coastal mountains.

title: Letteers to the Editor
description: The California State Supreme Court opinion against the system of publiceducation funding based on local property taxes (news story Aug. 31) is long overdue and much to be applauded.

title: The Becks Return After 65 Days in Brazil Jail
description: Protesting their innocence, Julian Beck and his wife, Judith Malina, founders of the Living Theater, arrived here yesterday from Brazil. They had been expelled from that country after spending 65 days in jail there on a narcotics charge.

title: Ogilvy Victor in Etchells22 Class at Y.R.A. Sail
Consummate Skeptic
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Bourke Blakemore Hickenlooper was often referred to by his Republican colleagues as the consummate skeptic. He questioned uncounted pieces of legislation, yet his name was attached to significant laws adopted during his 24 years in the Senate.

title: Blaze Attributed to Arson
description: REVERE, Mass., Sept. 4 (UPI) A general alarm blaze destroyed a fivestory condemned amusement ride and a fire truck, damaging several adjoining buildings and a roller Coaster early today. Fire officials said the blaze was definitely arson. The blaze, in the Virginia Reel, broke out about 11 P.M., just as thousand of patrons were streaming out of the amusement park in nearby Revere Beach, and from an adjacent dog track. There were no injuries.

title: Breaking Up the Beaumont: A Moral and Artistic Outrage?
description: THE Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center is being raped by the very family that was supposed to take care of itthe Lincoln Center board of trustees  while its husband, Jules Irving, looks the other way. The recently announced (and denounced) plan to raze the Forum is the least of it. The longstanding stepchild relationship that the theater company has had with Lincoln Center is about to be dissolved through a destructive plan to mutilate the Vivian Beaumont, divide its functions and then get it off Lincoln Center's back.

title: Despite Traditions a Growing Number of Rabbis Officiate at Mixed Marriages
description: Finding a rabbi to officiate at a mixed marriage these days isn't the chore it used to be, but it can still be a problem.

title: HANRAHAN TO FACE 2D CHICAGO JUDGE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3The case of State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan moved a slow step closer this week to a showdown on the immediate question of whether his indictment had been obtained by improper means.

title: The HeathLynch Talks
description: Prime Minister Edward Heath's decision to advance by six weeks the timetable of his scheduled talks with Prime Minister John Lynch of the Irish Republic tacitly acknowledges that he cannot stand pat on Britain's policy in Ulster. Up to now that policy has consisted of deploying British troops to maintain order while prodding the government of Northern Ireland to reform itself.

title: Burial in Spain Likely
description: MADRID, Sept. 4 (Reuters)The body of Mrs. Pern will probably be buried in Spain, at least temporarily, Peronist sources said today.

title: All Ranger Lands Expected to Be on Deck for Camp Opening Next Saturday
description: With no contract disputes worth mentioning, the Rangers open training camp next Saturday, barely four months after they played their last National Hockey League game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Parsons Wins Two Races For USAC Midget Crown
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 4 (AP) Johnny Parsons of Van Nuys, Calif., led every lap of both races today to win the twin50 national championship United States Auto Club midget races.

title: MILWAUKEE ENDS INTACT BUS PLAN
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4For years, pupils in certain classes at Milwaukee's Clarke Street School in the black area got on a bus each morning and were taken to a predominantly white school.

title: Amon Sets Mark at Monza; Snaps 155 M.P.M. Barrier
description: MONZA, Italy, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Chris Amon of New Zealand broke the 155mileanhour barrier for the first time in the history of the Monza race track today during official practice for tomorrow's Italian Grand Prix.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: ORDINARILY, the advent of Labor Day increases anxiety over the business and economic outlook for the final segment of the year. The current year, surely, is no exception, but the uncertainties have been heightened by the sweeping new economic policies suddenly instituted by Washington three weeks ago.

title: Announcements
Forward Gal, $7.20, Sets Gazelle Mark
description: Forward Gal, the 2yearold filly queen of 1970, showed her championship form in majestic fashion yesterday in the $56,200 Gazelle Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: British Computer Chief Calm in Crisis
description: LONDON  Arthur Humphreys is a John Bulllike figure well known to the more anonymous executives Who lead I.B.M.; Honeywell and RCA.

title: A General Amnesty To East Pakistanis Extended by Yahya
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sunday, Sept. 5In his strongest appeal to date to bring home refugees who have fled East Pakistan, Pakistan's President, Geri. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, today proclaimed a general amnesty.

title: Photograpy
description: EVERYONE in the business knew her as Maggie  everyone from Prime Ministers and revolutionary leaders to copyboys at Life magazine. As Margaret BourkeWhite, she was known to millions more throughout America and around the world, for she was one of the great stars of the great era of photojournalism. Maggie outlived that era, and her death last week, at the age of 67, can hardly be said to mark its end. Yet she epitomized it so perfectly, in its virtues as well as in its failings, that one must pause to look back at an age and a way of thinking that already seem as remote and almost as strange as the court of Louis XIV.

title: BOMBERS AND GUNS ATTACK FOE AT DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 (AP)American planes, artillery and warships hammered North Vietnamese positions in the southern half of the demilitarized zone and south of that area today.

title: Letters:
description: Your article about the sun said that the physicist Angstrm [Anders Jonas Angstrm, 18141874, for whom, the Angstrom unit, used in expressing length of light waves, was named] was. Swiss. Wrong: he was Swedish.

title: Ghana Gets U.S. Loan
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 4 (Reuters)An agreement was signed here today providing for a $20million United Stales loan to Ghana.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A $6,345,000 mortgage loan contract has been signed for the development of St. Philip's Church Housing in Harlem, clearing the way for construction of the first nonprofit project for the aging to be built in that community.

title: CAROLINA BISHOP ASSAILED BY NUNS
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 4An order, by the Bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese here for nuns to stop wearing secular clothing has provoked the resignation of at least eight teaching nuns at parochial schools and fanned controversy over the Bishop's policies.

title: Police in Greece Bar Transfer Of Lady Fleming to a Hospital
description: ATHENS, Sept. 4The Greek security police refused a request today to transfer Lady Fleming from her place of detention here to a hospital where her severe diabetes could be better treated. They also said that her lawyer could not see her until they had completed taking her deposition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I wonder how many of those people who are clapping their hands over the removal of the link between gold and the U.S. dollar have been wringing their hands over the rapid increase in the cost of living.

title: Run the Gantlet Wins $33,850 Turf Stakes at Atlantic City in Stretch Run
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 4 (AP)Paul Mellon's 3yearold Run the Gantlet stole the thunder from his more celebrated stablemate, Fort Marcy, by winning the $33,850 KellyOlympic Handicap today at Atlantic City.

title: Athletics Triumph Over Twin inters 18th Victory
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. (AP)Mike Epstein drove In two runs with his 16th homer and a single today while. Jim Hunter helped win his 18th game with a runscoring single as the Oakland A's beat the Minnesota Twins, 54.

title: Experimental Vehicle Derailed at 15 M.P.H.
description: PUEBLO, Colo., Sept. 4 (UPI)  Spokesmen for the Department of Transportation confirmed this week that a $2.5million experimental linear induction motor vehicle was derailed on a test track near here last week and suffered moderate damage.

title: Aides Deny Ky Threatened To Depose Thieu by Force
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky's office sought today to deny reports suggesting that Mr. Ky had threatened to use force to depose President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Dodgers Top Reds, 21
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (UPI) Willie Crawford's two  run double in the first inning and Al Downing's fourhit pitching gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 21 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: American Yachtsmen Win 3 Classes in Kiel Regatta
description: KIEL, Germany, Sept. 4 (UPI) American yachtsmen won three titles at a preOlympic sailing regatta that ended today in Kiel Bay.

title: It is those that can suffer most who will conquer
description: It is as if the hard men of the I.R.A. have always been with us. Before there was a Vietminh or a Vietcong, before Che Guevara and Fidel Castro, before E.O.K.A. moved in Cyprus or the F.L.N. in Algeria, before the Irgun or the Stern Gang unpacked their guns in Palestine, before there were Mau Mau, Huks, Weathermen or Black Panthers, there was an Irish Republican Army. It was always staffed by the men of no property, always on the run, prepared to die, as they say, for Ireland. Other revolutionary groups flared up, won famous victories or were smashed into defeat, and moved off the stage. Some petered out as their members discovered that revolutionary acts were more difficult to manage than revolutionary words. Others were bought off, or made respectable and sleek, or turned from the horrors of violence to tend private gardens. The I.R.A. endured.

title: FREEZE EXEMPTION SOUGHT FOR HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 4 (AP)Gov. John A. Burns is asking the Federal Government to take President Nixon's price freeze off Hawaii's food to help keep supermarket shelves full.

title: The Nation
PUERTO RICO BLOC PANS A PROTEST
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 4Puerto Rico's proindependence organizations are planning mass political demonstration to coincide with the opening here Sep. 12 of the 63d annual National Governors Conference.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: City's Refusal of Traffic Light Angers Williamsburg Residents
description: Despite a longstanding request from the Williamsburg community, the City Traffic Department has decided not to install a traffic light at a busy intersection where a 16yearold girl was struck down and killed last month.

title: Elizabeth D. Edwards Is Married
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Sept. 4  Miss Elizabeth Dunkel Edwards and Dr. John Lynn Leonard were married here today in St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church by the Rev. William Milholland.

title: The Franc: Split Level
