description: ROME, Aug. 31 (AP)  Georges Louis Peissel, director of external relations and gen eral services of the United Nations world food program, died today in his office at the headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization. He was 61 years old.

title: Closing of U.S. Base Signals Hardship for Philippine City
description: CAVITE, the Philippines, Aug. 31The United States flag was lowered for the last time today at Sapgley Point Naval Station, ending a 73year chapter of American naval history and opening a time of trouble for this city of 76,000 down the bay from Manila.

title: Questions and Answers by Cost of Living Council on Issues in Freeze
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 31 Following is the 11th set of official questions and an swers issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Coun cil on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Buffalo on the Turnpike?
description: After the late Percival Baxter donated to the State of Maine the magnificent Katandin park area which bears his name, he stubbornly resisted proposals to improve facilities at the park in ways he feared would spoil its wilderness character. Mr. Baxter was particularly ad amant in opposing suggestions to pave and broaden the tworut rud that snaked through the park, barely leav ing room for two cars to pass.

title: GOVERNOR PICKS 6 FOR NEW AGENCY
description: Governor Rockefeller has se lected six of the seven mem bers who will form the contro versial state agency that comes into being today to regulate development of the sixmillion acre Adirondack State Park.

title: Crime Rate Up 11% For Nation in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The Federal Bureau of Investi gation released today statistics showing that both the crime rate and the annual volume of major crime rose substantially in 1970.

title: Giants Asking Waivers On Baker, Two Others
description: BROOKVLLE, L. I., Aug. 31 (AP)  The New York Giants placed John Baker and Claude Brumfield, line men, on waivers today.

title: H. ALLEN WILLIS DIES; G.M.A.C. EXECUTIVE
description: H. Allen Willis, who retired last year as executive vice pres ident of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died of a heart attack Monday near his home in Austin, Tex. He was 65 years old and formerly lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: WORTV Altering Format and Time Of Its News Show
description: WORTV will move its half hour, weeknight news broad cast on Channel 9 from 7:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M., switching to a new format in which Tom Dunn will replace Bill Ryan as anchorman.

title: JFK to Open Off Broadway
description: JFK, a staged biography of President Kennedy, assembled from speeches and press con ferences, will be offered this fall off Broadway, with Jere miah Collins in the title and only role. The show was pre sented earlier this year under the title, An Evening With John F. Kennedy at the Na tional Press Club, Washington. Mark Williams, who created the show with Mr. Collins, will stage it with the assistance of Walt DeFaria.

title: 2 GERMAN MOVIES SHOWN AT VENICE
description: VENICE, Italy, Aug. 31 Germany, once the generous provider of artistic and intel lectual cinema, today manu factures only a few more exportable films than Zanzibar, Albania or Staten Island. Since World War II there have been several Teutonic movies above the general international ave rage, but they have been exceptions.

title: 4 Students End a Test In DeepSea Chamber
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP)  Four divers ended 24 days in a simulated deep sea environmental chamber today; demonstrating that man can explore the ocean at depths of nearly a mile while breathing neon, helium and nitrogen.

title: Youths Returning From Europe Flooding Kennedy
description: The great transAtlantic youth migration of 1971 has swung into reverse, and the thousands of young Amer icans who flocked to Europe with a knapsack, a guitar and a $200 roundtrip ticket weeks ago were coming home.

title: New York Cricketers Win
description: A New York cricket side de feated the Sheffield Cricket Lovers Society of England by eight wickets, yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. New York scored 104 runs for two wickets to Sheffield's 103.

title: Outbreak of Fires Brings Destruction In Italian Forests
description: ROME, Aug. 31A chain of forest fires is afflicting Italy, destroying millions of trees on the gentle hills of Tuscany, along the pine groves of the long coast and in the sun drenched orchards of Sicily.

title: Pennsylvania Tax Signed
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 31 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp signed into law toady a 2.3 per cent state income tax the second tax he has signed in six months.

title: Tories Rout Alberta's Regime of 36 Years
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 31Conserv ative party candidates routed the 36yearold rightist Social Credit government in Alberta yesterday.

title: About Motor Sports
description: To Mark Donohue and other members of Roger Penske Racing, the impos sible is only a minor incon venience. While practicing last Thursday for, the Cali fornia 500 at Ontario Motor Speedway, Donohue lost con trol and rammed the retain ing wall. He was uninjured, but his McLaren M 16Offenhauser was an untidy mess of bits and pieces. With no fuss and a mini mum of cursing their luck, the Penske crew got the car ready for Saturday's qualify ing session.

title: Advertising: 4 at Y.&R. Go to Lois Holland
description: Four creative heavyweights at the $520  million  class Young & Rubicam will be moving out to become top executives at the $20million Lois Holland Callaway.

title: Proxmire to Enter Primaries In '72 in Quest for Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin is preparing to join the large field of Democrats seeking the party's 1972 Presi dential nomination.

title: S.E.C. STUDIES USE OF BROKERS FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Staff econmists of the Securi ties and Exchange Commission have concluded that it may not be desirable or necessary for the protection of investors to bar completely the use by bro kers of idle funds left in their hands by customers.

title: Denmark to Vote Sept. 21
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  Denmark will hold a general election Sept. 21, Premier Hilmar Bauns gaard announced in Parliament today.

title: Commissioner Is Calm in Hectic Days
description: Through it all, through those two days that convulsed the Police Department, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy moved with the hours of change calmly, with order, as if the whole pro gram had been put into a computer and printed out.

title: HOOT SPEED PICK IN HAMBLEIONIAN
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31  Glen Garnsey, the 37yearold reinsrnan who will be driving Hoot Speed, the favorite, in tomorrow's 46th annual Ham bletonian, appeared to be com pletely at ease as he sat in the shaded area outside the Castle ton Farm's barn at the Du Quoin State Fairgrounds to day.

title: U.S. Trade Moves Held. Hurtful to Italy
description: Italy faces a severe crisis in industry and trade unless it can get some relief from the sur charge on imports imposed by the United States, it was pre dicted here yesterday by Giulio Andreotti, parliamentary leader of the Christian Democratic Party. Thousands of workers will lose their jobs, he said, and hundreds of small manu facturers will be forced out of business.

title: Market Place: de Stock Trader Cites Conflicts
description: Talk to Frederick B. Tay lor, a delightfully abrasive New Englander, about mar ket research, and he'll give you an earful. Here's a man who has spent 45 of his 65 years in the investment game, and he hasn't been sitting around spinning mental cob webs.

title: CARDS WIN BY 21 ON SIMMONS'S HIT
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31Nolan Ryan struck out 12 batters in six innings tonight but his vir tuoso performance had long since ended when the St. Louis Cardinals rallied in the ninth inning for a 21 victory over the New York Mets.

title: NEW JERSEY METS TEAM OF FUTURE?
description: M. Donald Grant, chairman of the board of the New York Mets, said yesterday he would recommend moving the base ball team to New Jersey if New York City succeeded in forcing the Mets to accept the New York Yankees as cotenants at Shea Stadium.

title: New Bolivian Regime Is Recognized by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)The United States ex tended recognition today to the new military government of Bolivia, headed by Col. Hugo Banzer Suarez.

title: Mandate From Congress
description: The commission is studying what new restrictions should be placed on the use of custom ers' cash balances and custom ers' securities under a direct mandate from Congress.

title: Ingalls Shipbuilding Closed
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Aug. 31 (AP)The president of In galls Nuclear Shipbuilding or dered the large complex shut donw today after the spread of a walkout from another section of the shipyard. M. J. Maran dino, the president, issued a bulletin to workers saying the pickets had reduced our work force to a point where the ship yard cannot operate safely.

title: Akron Disorder Quelled
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UPI) The police used tear gas to day to break up a disturbance caused by several hundred per sons who were throwing bricks and bottles on the city's west side. There were no arrests. The police were called to the area, scene of similar disturb ances earlier this year, after the crowd starting throwing rocks and bottles at passing cars.

title: Log of Mylai Attack Shows Early Reports of 84 Vietcong Slain, Trial Told
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 31 Infantrymen assaulting the village of Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968, reported killing 84 Vietcong cittring the first hour and 10 minutes of the attack al though they did not report re ceiving any hostile fire during the entire operation.

title: No Postponement
description: The headlines change, but the stubborn facts endure. The nation's most persistent domestic difficulties are poverty and the financial crisis of local governments. The racial issues are interwined with both these problems because a disproportionately large number of blacks, Indians, Puerto Ricans and Mexican Americans live in poverty, and their move from the countryside to the cities has contributed to the financial pressure on local governments.

title: F.D.I.C. Names Official
description: The Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation announced yesterday that Edward J. Roddy had been promoted to director of its division of bank super vision, effective today. He suc ceeds John L. Flannery, who left the F.D.I.C. to join the StateDime Savings Bank in Hartford.

title: '72 Chevrolets Little Changed But Record Sales Are Expected
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31The Chev rolet division's 1972 models look a lot like last year's ex cept for a new heavier bumper that will preserve cars in a 5 mileanhour crash. Despite the few changes the company pre dicts that it will sell a record 3 million cars in the upcoming sales year.

title: U.S. Astronauth Expected to Use Salyut
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 American and Soviet space planners are working under the premise that joint space ven tures are possible in the near future and that the first would see American astronauts board ing a Russian Salyut space laboratory.

title: Judge Aaron J. Palmer Dies; Presided at Panther Hearing
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Aug. 31 (AP)Superior Court Judge Aaron J. Palmer died today at Middlesex Hospital, He was 67 years old.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: Notes on People
description: Being the wife of the Presi dent means always being in a fishbowl, said Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, who confided to a television interviewer that the only place she could feel truly alone nowadays was on a secluded patio at the West ern White House in San Cle mente, Calif. At the present time it is the only place in the world where we can sit unguarded, said Mrs. Nixon. During the course of the in terview, which will be seen tomorrow night on the Amer ican Broadcasting Company network, Mrs. Nixon also said she got a good laugh over the fact I'm supposed to be shy. She classified that im pression of her as a myth.

title: Now, Attica Again
description: It is our firm conviction, said the New York State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction in a report earlier this year, that any penal system which falls short of affording to its prison inmates the fundamental dignities to which all human beings are entitled demeans our society and threatens its future safety.

title: Attica Rioters, Holding Out, Ask Foreign Asylum
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Saturday, Sept. 11Groups of angry pris oners holding 33 guards as hostages at the Attica State Correctional Facility continued negotiations into this morning with State Correction Commis sioner Russell G. Oswald.

title: Four Insurers Sue Accounting Firm On Company Audit
description: In a $10,27million lawsuit, four insurance companies ac cused a New York accounting firm yesterday of misleading and fraudulent financial state ments about a nowbankrupt cattle business.

title: SOUTHERN CAL UPSET BY ALABAMA, 17 to 10
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (UPI) Hardrunning Johnny Musso scored two touchdowns in the first half and a Stubborn Ala batna defense held the Univer sity of Southern California scoreless in the second half to night as the Crimson Tide reg istered a 1710 upset victory in a seasonopening football game.

title: Nan Lowlicht Married
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Sept. 10Miss Nan Leslie Lowlicht, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lowlicht, was married here this afternoon to Benja min Staples Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leicester Hall of Huntington. State Su preme Court Justice Joseph Liff performed the ceremony in the garden of the home of the bride's parents. The bride's father is a merchan dise manager with Mercantile Stores, Inc., New York. Mr. Hall's lather, a retired vice president of Grumman Aero space, is executive director of the Off Shore Office of the North American Yacht Rac ing Union.

title: Underwriters Trust Here Elects New Chief Executive
description: The Underwriters Trust Com pany, a small New York bank based in the Wall Street area, announced yesterday that Charles W. Smith had been elected president and chief ex ecutive. Mr. Smith was previ ously a vice president of the Bank of Commerce here.

title: BILLS DEFEATED BY PACKERS, 2014
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 10 (UPI) Dave Hampton scored his sec ond touchdown of the game on a 4yard run early in the last quarter and Dave Conway kicked a field goal later to give the Green Bay Packers a 2014 victory over the Buffalo Bills in a National Football League preseason game.

title: U.S. Vehicles Are Targets In Saigon FireBombings
description: SAIGON, South Veitnam, Sept. 10 (AP)  A series of fire bombings against United States and South Korean ve hicles broke out today in Sai gon.

title: FIREMENS' GROUP TO OFFER COURSE
description: The Uniformed Fire Officers Association said yesterday that it would sponsor classes for firesafety directors in high rise buildings, with any profit going to the families of dead firefighters.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The speech that President Nixon gave yesterday before a joint session of Congress was clearly more than an appeal for quick legislative approval of his new economic program. It also pro vided a glimpse of same of the themes he hopes to be able to set before the American voter next year. As such, it provides a glimpse of some of his current politi cal calculations. The shortterm tactical purpose of the address was, of course, to steal an early advantage in Congress by what amounted to a direct appeal to the voters  over Democrats who oppose his wish to reduce business taxes. They maintain that such a reduction represents a reversion to the old trickle down theory of social progress and would, in the end, reduce by several bil lion dollars the Government's ability to solve the problems of housing, health and education that Mr. Nixon said needed solving.

title: Gravel Accuses Administration Of Trying to Silence War Foes
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, accused the Nixon Administration today of trying to intimidate Congressional critics through the use of a Federal grand jury investiga tion here.

title: H.U.D. RULED GUILTY OF DISCRIMINATION
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) The United States Court of Ap peals for the Seventh Circuit ruled today that the Depart ment of Housing and Urban De velopment was guilty of racial discrimination in allocating money to the Chicago Housing Authority for construction of segregated public housing.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games
College Football On Tap Today
description: Morgan State and Grambling bring their annual charity game back to Yankee Sta dium tonight as they share the spotlight on this early opening Saturday of the 102d intercollegiate football season.

title: Spiritualist to Lecture Here
description: Rosemary Brown, a London housewife who claims that famous dead composers have communicated new works to her, will appear at Town Hall on Monday at 7:30 P.M. She will lecture on her psychic ex periences with the composers and play the music she has been given on the piano. The event is sponsored by the Spiritual Frontiers Fellowship.

title: Mary E. Wilson Married at U.N.
description: Miss Mary Elizabeth Wilson and Roger Roland Dowdes well were married yesterday morning in the Church Cen ter for the United Nations. The Rev. Carl Soule per formed the nondenomina tional ceremony, which was written by the couple.

title: Union Aide Backs Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 (UPI)Ed Turner, secretary of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union agrees with President Nixon's wageprice freeze. Un til we find differently from what we have seen at this writ ing, Mr. Turner said this week in his column Straight Speak ing, in the union's newspaper, we support him 100 per cent.

title: Farr Goes 94 Yards
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 (UPI) Miller Farr, aided by Jim Har grove's block that took out three Cleveland players, raced 94 yards for a fourthquarter touchdown on a pass intercep tion tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 2713 vic tory over the Browns in a pre season game.

title: WIDER PLOT LAID TO PONTIAC KLAN
description: DETROIT, Sept. 10Ku Klux Klan members charged with the dynamiting of 10 school buses in Pontiac were also accused of having planned to knock out a power station as a diversion for a mortar attack on the school bus depot to destroy buses.

title: 825 Students Escape Blast
description: AYDEN, N. C., Sept. 10 (UPI) The authorities arrested seven young blacks today for the dy namite bombing of an occupied school building and said more arrests would follow. The 825 students at the desegregated AydenGrifton High School were in class, but there were no injuries.

title: Urtain Held to Draw
description: BILBAO, Spain, Sept. 10 (AP)Jose Manuel (Urtain) Ibar retained his Spanish heavyweight boxing title to night although he was held to a 12round draw by Mariano Echevarria. Urtain weighed 198 pounds, Echevarria 213.

title: Rogers Terms Tokyo Aid Vital to Taiwan in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that if Japan did not join the United States in sponsoring resolutions aimed at preserving Chinese National ist membership in the United Nations, her action would have a detrimental effect on the American effort.

title: CITY SCHOOL BUSES FACE RATE FREEZE
description: Increased charges by bus companies that carry 116,000 city schoolchildren15,000 of them handicappedwere nulli fied yesterday by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council.

title: EGYPTIANS TO VOTE ON CHARTER TODAY
description: CAIRO, Sept. 10  Nearly two decades after reform minded young officers over threw King Farouk, the peo ple of Egypt are finally being offered a permanent constitu tion as President Anwar el. Sadat moves to consolidate political power.

title: ANTHONY BLOTTA, FASHION DESIGNER
description: Anthony Blotta, a leading fashion designer for 50 years, died Wednesday of a heart at tack here. He was 83 years old and lived at the New York Athletic Club.

title: MAXIMILIAN FRANKROSE FRANK.
description: Happy Golden Wedding Anniversary.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 10 (Reuters)The Brazilian cen tral bank tonight devalued the cruzeiro to 5.470/5.505 to the dollar from its previous parity of 5.370/5.405. It was the fourth devaluation this year by the Brazilian Government in line with its policy of small sliding adjustments. The previ ous change was on April 30.

title: Support Sought at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10The senior New York representative of Bangla Desh conceded today that his organ ization would have no means of being heard officially without the support of some mem ber of the United Nations.

title: Laird Says Nixon Will Accept Oct. 1 Pay Rise for the Military
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) Hoping to win Congressional extension of the draft, Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird agreed today to accept a pro posed Oct. 1 pay rise for the military even though it would run afoul of President Nixon's wageprice freeze.

title: Oil Pipeline Runs. Along Railroad Track
description: A 10inch pipeline that runs along a railroad rightofway will soon begin delivering fuel oil pumped from tankers berthed at Edgewater, N. J., to an electric generating plant five miles inland at Ridgefield.

title: F.C.C. Authorizes Cable Firm in City To Operate Pay TV
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  Time Life Broadcast and Sterling Manhattan Cable Tele vision were informed by the Federal Communications Com mission today that they are authorized to operate pay tele vision by cable.

title: ExCollege Queen Is Slain; Docker Charged in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Lynn Cecilia Eusan, 23 years old, the first black University of Houston homecoming queen, was found stabbed to death to day.

title: Prediction by Allende
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Judith Hart, a Member of the British Parliament, said today that President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile told her more than a week ago that Mr. Jack son would be released.

title: Store Sales Up 9% From 70
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended Sept. 4, were an stimated $844 million, up 9 pr cent from the $773million sales for the cor responding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $7.80billion, an increase of 9 per cent from the $7.97billion sales for the like period last year.

title: Is Freedom Obsolete?
description: Philosophers and psychologists have long debated whether man is a Noble Savage whose goodness must be protected against, corruption or an Ignoble Savage to be sternly subdued. B. F. Skinner, the Harvard psycholo gist who has long experimented with the conditioning of animal and human behavior, prefers to take as proto type a more neutral man, responsive mainly to the promise and habit of reward and punishment.

title: Cahill Adresses 10,000
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Mr. Cahill told a cheering crowd of 10,000 here tonight:

title: Penn Central Trustees Vote PensionFund Compromise
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Trustees of the Penn Central Railroad agreed yester day to a compromise that would return $2.6million to 121 exec utives who contributed to a pension plan.

title: Puerto Rican Panel Told Migrants Are Exploited
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 10A special legislative committee from the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, beginning a two week investigation of Puerto Ricans' working and living con ditions in the United States, heard here today that thousands of Puerto Rican migrant work ers in New Jersey were being abused and deprived of their rights on South Jersey farms.

title: McQueen Sued for Divorce
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (Reuters)Steve McQueen was sued for divorce today by his wife of 14 years, Neil Adams McQueen, a former actress. Mrs. McQueen cited irreconcil able differences, the only causes needed under new California di vorce laws, and said their mar riage had broken up in June. She asked support for herself and for their two children, Terri, 12, and Chadwick, 10.

title: 550 Will Start Monday In U.S.Aided City Jobs
description: The first 550 workers hired by eight city agencies under the new Federal Emergency Employment Act will be on the job Monday, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: NASA Launching Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) A snowstorm in Chile caused the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to post pone today a planned launching of a barium cloud rocket. NASA said that, be cause of snow conditions at a Chilean observation station, the planned launching from Wallops Island, Va., tomorrow night, had been postponed to Monday night.

title: Insurgent Teamsters Sue Hoffa; Charge Deal on Union Pension
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 James R. Hoffa, the former head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was sued today by an insurgent group within the labor union.

title: Bonn's Net Reserves Up
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 10 (Reuters)West Ger many's net monetary reserves rose 100 million marks to 61.5 billion marks in the week end ed Sept. 7, the Bundesbank said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: The last chapter of this book, published separately as The Burn Ward, is already justly famous. The rest of the book de serves to be. It will be, too. Its quiet elo quence, its factual precision, its emotional restraint braided into the horror and pain of the subject matter make it a book of great emotional impact. The writings in this series of sketches of the war in Viet nam are virtually flawless. There isn't a false note, a soft center in any of them. Dr. Glasser's fluency comes not from any literary manipulations but from his com mitment to what he is saying. A former major of the Medical Corps, he never preaches. But that does not mean that he has no point of view. It's in what he is telling us.

title: Ellen Cacace Bride Of T. Maxwell Jr.
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 10The marriage of Miss Ellen Cacace, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent A. Cacace, to Thomas Francis Maxwell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell of Stamford and New Milford, took place here this evening. The cere mony was performed in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Bernard Scanlon.

title: H. L. Mencken, Come Back
description: Dear Henry:

title: FRENCH BANK GROUPS REPORT AGREEMENTS
description: The two most powerful pri vate financial groups in France Cie. Financiere de Suez and Cie. Financiere de Paris et de PaysBasannounced yesterday that their directors had ap proved an agreement to sort out their differences over their common ownership in Credit Industriel et Commercial, France's largest commercial bank.

title: The Talk of Tricarico
description: TRICARICO, Italy, Aug. 30 There's a feeling of isola tion as one approaches this southern Italian town from the Appian Way, which winds along the crest of the Appenine Mountains.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Football Players Stabbed
description: JONESBORO, Ga., Sept. 10 (UPI)The police charged six black teenagers with assault today in the wake of an attack with knives and stones on white members of a victorious high school football team.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 437
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today launched Cosmos 437, the lat est in its series of unmanned satellites, the official news agency Tass reported.

title: JETS TURN BACK PATRIOTS BY 389 IN MEMPHIS GAME
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 10  It's easier to be a rookie running back behind a good offensive line than to be a rookie quar terback behind a bad offensive line.

title: Snipers Hit a Policeman in Texas Strife
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 10 (AP)Three Negro men were charged today with intent to murder after an early morning sniper shattered the main artery in a police patrolman's neck.

title: 24 Cambodians Killed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Cambodian troops suffered casualties of as many as 24 killed and 80 wounded in Communist attacks north and northwest of the capital today, a Cambodian military spokesman said to night.

title: Wharton Forecast Sees Nixon Freeze Cutting Joblessness
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP)President Nixon's new wagepricetax policies defi nitely will slow inflation and reduce unemployment in 1972 but will not spur exceptionally large changes, economists at the University of Pennsylvania said yesterday in the Wharton forecast.

title: Turco Trial Date Set
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP) A Criminal Court judge has set Nov. 29 for the retrial of Arthur F. Turco Jr., a lawyer from New York City, on charges of being an accessory in the murder of a Black Pan ther. Judge J. Harold Grady an nounced the trial date yester day, denying a move by de fense lawyers who asked that no definite date be set.

title: Article 6  No Title
JACKSON WARNS ON AID TO SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Senator Henry M. Jackson, a leading supporter of past United States, policies on the Vietnam war, threatened today to op pose further aid to the Saigon Government if the Nixon Ad ministration did not help ar range a genuine Presidential election in South Vietnam.

title: NATO Says Warsaw Pact Studies TroopCut Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 United States officials and At lantic alliance representatives asserted today that the War saw Pact powers had finally given evidence of preparing seriously for discussion of mili tary arms cuts in Europe.

title: U.S. BANKS PRAISE MOVES BY BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Sept. 10New op portunities for United States banks in London were opened today with the announcement by the Bank of England of sweeping changes in the Brit ish banking system.

title: Groups Back Freedom Fight
description: CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 10 The Awami League has joined forces with three leftwing po litical groups to direct the freedom struggle against the Pakistani Government of Presi dent Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan. The groups, the leftwing National Awami party, the pro Moscow splinter group of the National Awami party, and the Communist Party of Bangla Desh. All favor total independ ence for East Pakistan.

title: Giants Sign Fox for '72; Decision Made in Jane
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 10 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants announced today the rehiring of Manager Charlie Fox for 1972 for a substantial in crease in salary.

title: COMMON MARKET ADVISED TO URGE U.S. DEVALUATION
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 10The European Economic Commu nity's executive commission for mally proposed today that the United States devalue the dol lar as an integral part of major realignment of the cur rencies of the main industrial countries.

title: Miss BourkeWhite Receives Tributes At Memorial Here
description: At a memorial service yes terday for Margaret Bourke White, the qualities of mind and spirit that imbued the celebrat ed photographerjournalist took precedence over recollections of her tangible accomplish ments in a career marked by adventure and drama.

title: Lens Deal Is Set in Japan
description: Frigitronics, Inc., announced yesterday that it had signed a distribution agreement and a li cense to manufacture its Griffin soft contact lens in Japan with the Hoya Glass Works, Ltd. Hoya is the largest company in the field of ophthalmic sales in Japan.

title: Antiques
description: Oak furniture is getting to be as chic In New York as it is in London and Paris.

title: Auto Dealers Bitterly Complain Over Embezzling Consumers
description: A bitter group of metropoli tan area auto dealers turned a Better Business Bureau sem inar on consumer complaints yesterday into a tonguelashing against consumers themselves and the government agencies that protect them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: British Hondurans Flee Belize As Hurricane Edith Nears City
description: BELIZE, British Honduras, Sept. 10 (UPI)With Hurri cane Edith fast approaching this lowlying city of 40,000 people, evacuation of residents was begun tonight and British troops patrolled downtown streets to prevent looting.

title: AWARDS HALTED BY WILSON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  Competition for the prestigious Woodrow Wilson Fellowships has been suspended for at least a year because of a lack of funds.

title: Blacks in Boston and Baltimore In Mayoral Primaries Tuesday
description: WASHINTON, Sept. 10  Black candidates with sub stantial followings will be on the ballot next Tuesday in Democratic mayoral primaries in Boston and Baltimore but they are given very little chance of winning.

title: Article 4  No Title
B. F. Goodrich Names Chief Executive
description: The election of 0. Pendleton Thomas, 57 years old, as a vice chairman of the board, chief executive officer and direc tor of the B. F. Goodrich Com pany, effective Oct. 1, was an nounced yesterday.

title: The Impact of Crowding on Human Behavior
description: How doe's crowding affect humans? Although much has been written about this question and almost everyone seems to have views on it, until re cently there was little or no scientific evidence on which to base an answer. There was some research on rats hardly comparable to humansand a few survey studies or poorly controlled experiments. Social scientists have fi nally begun to study the problem and a few findings are beginning to emerge. They are still quite tentative, but for once we have some solid data.

title: SOVIET STRADDLES CAMBODIAN ISSUE
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10  Not since the winter of 196970 has the Soviet Foreign Ministry published its regular semi annual diplomatic list. Some foreign diplomats think the reason may be that Moscow is reluctant to show that it ex tends diplomatic recognition to the antiCommunist Govern ment of Cambodia rather than to the rebel government in exile of Prince Norodom Sihan ouk, whom the Russians pro fess to support politically.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Case Against Medina in Mylai Deaths
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 10The military judge in the trial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina denied today defense motions to dismiss the case. He said that the Government had produced some substan tial evidence in support of all the charges against the captain in the Mylai killings.

title: New Executive Director Appointed by Hadassah
description: The appointment of Miss Aline Kaplan, a lawyer here, as executive director of Ha dassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Max Schenck, president of the 325,000member organi zation.

title: Week's Car Output Declines by 35,000 Because of Holiday
description: DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP) Auto production in the United States dropped by 35,000 cars this week because of the Labor Day holiday.

title: Iacocca Urges Backing for Nixon Plans
description: Lee. A. Iacocca, president of the Ford Motor Company, gave strong support yesterday to President Nixon's new econom ic policy although he contend ed that the 90day wageprice freeze would cost the company $130million in pretax profits.

title: SHUVEE, RAM UP, IS BELDAME CHOICE
description: Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shu vec, the leading moneywinning horse of her sex, will seek to increase an already imposing bankroll today when she goes in the Beldame at Belmont Park. The 1 1/8mile test for fil lies and mares has attracted a field of seven who will battle for a gross purse of $82,850, with the winner getting $49;710.

title: Japanese Steel Prices Up
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 (AP)Jap anese steelmakers reportedly have decided to raise export prices by 5 per cent or more to compensate for the recent increase in the value of the yen, but the implementation of increases has been spotty so far.

title: Governor's Office Picketed
description: About 40 members of the Prisoner Solidarity Committee demonstrated for an hour yes terday outside Governor Rocke feller's Manhattan office on West 55th Street, demanding that Mr. Rockefeller visit the riottorn Attica State Correc tional Facility to negotiate inmate grievances. The pickets tried unsuccessfully to enter Mr. Rockefeller's office to de liver a list of demands, at tributed to the Attica prison ers. Mr. Rockefeller was in Washington, D. C., for the day.

title: Hawks Draft, Sign Payne
description: The Atlanta Hawks signed Tom Payne of Kentucky yes terday less than 3 hours aft er they had selected the 7 foot2inch center in the first National Basketball Association hardship draft. The signing pre cluded an expected money bat tle for Payne, who was also on the 11man hardship list an nounced yesterday by the ri val American Basketball Associ ation. The A.B.A. will conduct its draft Tuesday.

title: Last Gas Leaves Okinawa
description: NAHA, Okinawa, Sept. 10 (AP)The last shipment of 825 tons of toxic gas packed in can nisters left Tengan Pier in cen tral Okinawa today aboard the United States military trans port Francis X. McGraw for Johnston Island in the central Pacific. The gas removal began eight months ago.

title: First Unit in Educational Park System to Open Monday
description: There were still many things' that had to be done yesterday  furniture to be moved, partitions to be put up, electrical work and paint ing to be completed  and then there would be a busy weekend of tidyingup and lastminute preparations.

title: $30.4Billion Stability Budget Is Adopted for West Germany
description: BONN, Sept. 10The Gov ernment of West Germany adopted today a $30.4billion stability budget for 1972.

title: TRADING ACTIVE FOR NEW ISSUES
description: Four new issuesrepresent ing companies in the fields of frozen food transport, double knit fabrics, house construction and water treatment  began trading this week and three met an enthusiastic market recep tion.

title: Executive Changes
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company announded yes terday that John L. Sullivan, South Central regional vice president, has been elected a corporate vice president. Rolland C. Ladd was named to succeed Mr. Sullivan.

title: Joseph M. Proskauer, 94, Dies; A Judge and Political Adviser
description: Joseph M. Proskauer, a judge, political adviser and philan thropist who spent more than a halfcentury in public life, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 205 West 57th Street.

title: Tokyo Urged to Lift Curbs
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Japan's top economic body said today that it was urging the Government to ease rigid exchange controls that might seriously retard Japan's trad ing and industrial activities.

title: BUDGET DOUBLING SOUGHT BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  The head of the Food and Drug Administration said today that he wanted to expand greatly his agency's inspection respon sibilities.

title: Foe of Bigotry
description: Joseph M. Proskauer was an adornment of the New York bench and bar for more than a halfcentury. As chairman of the Stale Crime Commission nearly two decades ago, he did much to civilize the waterfront and bring it under the rule of law.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES REGISTER A DROP
description: Prices of soybean and grain futures declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: First of 2 Wedding Ceremonies Held for Susan H. Chambers
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 10Miss Susan Hathaway Chambers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Edmund Chambers of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married here this afternoon to Steven Paul Hirshberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvan C. Hirshberg of Haverhill, Mass. The cere mony was performed by Rabbi Samuel Silver at Tem ple Sinai.

title: Gaming Official in Nevada Gets Purported Letter From Hughes
description: FALLON, Nev., Sept. 10 Three representatives of How ard Hughes have delivered to the chairman of the Nevada Gaming Commission a hand written letter reportedly signed by the billionaire recluse.

title: Turner Extends 5.5Meter Sail Lead
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 10 Ted Turner of Atlanta in creased his lead over Ernest Fay of Houston to 8.4 points after winning the fourth race of the world 5.5Meter Class yachting championship today on Long Island Sound.

title: City Appoints OrganizedCrime Fighter
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yester day the setting up of a toplevel position within his department to combat organized crime in the city.

title: LABOR CHIEFS TELL NIXON THEY'D BACK A CONTROLS BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Labor leaders presented a united front today as they told President Nixon they would support the creation of a tri partite board, representing la bor, management and the gen eral public, to control wages and prices without govern mental interference after the current 90day freeze.

title: City Surprising to 4 Russian Architects
description: Four Soviet architects ar rived here this week with cameras to record New York's delights, and preconceptions to compare them with.

title: Bomb Found Under Bus
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 10 (UPI)A woman driver re moved an object from beneath her school bus today and drove her rounds delivering children. The object was later found to he a bomb that contained 14 sticks of dynamite in a paper sack.

title: Roundup: Orioles' Power Conquers Senators, 7 to 1
description: The Baltimore Orioles, on their way to a third succes sive Eastern Division cham pionship in the American League, can credit Washing ton for much of their success.

title: WORKERS' ROLES: DRAMA ADVISERS
description: BONN, Sept. 10At the City Theater in Oberhausen, work ingmen have been drafted into new, informal roles as directors and stage designers for a play about the working class.

title: Belmont Entries
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HENRY MATTSON, PAINTER, WAS 84
description: Henry Mattson, an artist who was known for his poetic, brooding seascapes and land scapes, died Wednesday in Woodstock, N. Y., where he lived. He was 84 years old.

title: Rulings on the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Following is policy statement No. 16 issued by President Nixon's Cost of Living Coun cil on the latest ruling rela tive to the 90day freeze on wages and prices. The rul ings are in addition to the previous 15 sets of questions and answers.

title: Men in the News
description: Once again yesterday, as he had done the day before, a short, heavyset man bus tled to and fro in the devas tation of the Attica State Correctional Facility, in specting, negotiating, con ciliating.

title: How an Artist's Eye Turned Carriage House Into a Home
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.It is, according, to the owner, a house that needs people. Its 15 areas (it's easier to call them areas because some rooms don't have partitions) sprawl over two floors, its ceilings are 12 feet high and, other than structurally, it bears no resemblance to the carriage house it once was.

title: Trend Seen in RobberyKillings Of Elderly on Lower East Side
description: A 73yearold widow was found dead yesterday with a stocking tied around her neck, apparently the latest victim of robbers who have been preying on elderly people in three Low er Manhattan housing projects.

title: Art: Whitney Shows Items From Hopper Bequest
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, which dis closed for the first time last spring that it had been be queathed a sizable number of worksvirtually the entire contents of the artist's studio from the estate of the late. Edward Hopper, has now mounted an exhibition con sisting of 157 items from this extraordinary bequest. Included are 49 oils, 44 watercolors, 49 drawings and 15 etchings, most of them never before recorded, ex hibited or reproduced. The work ranges in time from Hopper's student days at the turn of the century to the 1940's, and perhaps beyond many of the works are undated. Hopper died in 1967 at the of 85.

title: Shop Talk
description: O.K. Quit griping. There really are clothes to wear. Not just mad things to wrap yourself up in. But honest to goodness dresses. Even suits to wear to lunch eons. And coats that look like coats used to look before everyone took to ponchos and blankets. Oh, of course there are a few ponchos. And a couple of coats carved out of plastic and fake fur. This is 1971, remember? But the bulk of the styles Bergdorf Goodman has selected for its Givenchy boutique are the kinds of things women used to adore before the fashion world went wild around the nine teensixties.

title: Lawyer Is Accused Of Offering Bribe
description: A lawyer who has been a member of the bar for 40 years was arrested in the Criminal Court Building yesterday after allegedly trying to bribe a patrolman to change his testi mony.

title: Dollar Stages Recovery Against Francs in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 10 (Reuters) The United States dollar staged a recovery against both the financial and commercial francs this afternoon in interbank dealings, dealers reported to day.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: Article 1  No Title
Delay Denied Miss Davis
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)Judge Richard E. Aran son of the Superior Court re fused today to delay the Sept. 27 start of the murderkidnap trial of Angela Y. Davis. Judge Aranson ordered the black mili tant's defense to file all remain log motions in the case by Sept. 20.

title: RECORD HARVEST FORESEEN FOR '71
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) Based on Sept. 1 conditions, the Agriculture Department es timated today that American farmers will harvest the largest crops in history this year. It forecast record production of corn, wheat, grain sorghum and soybeans.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The sky was evenly overcast, no glints to dazzle the eye, and the breeze only wrinkled the flags above the sta dium. Two young girls in white came down the steps of the green awninged marquee, and high on the horseshoe's rim someone asked, Which one is her, is that her? Someone else said, No, no, she has long blond hair. The crowd stayed on its feet as the two girls, who were ball girls, took places alongside the grass court and turned toward the marquee, Waiting also.

title: News Analysis
description: NEWARK, Sept. 10As the recently completed fiveday meeting of the Congress of African Peoples here would in dicate, political organizing with in black districts around the country is beginning to take top priority with many social activists.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: British Envoy, Freed by Guerrillas, Leaves Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 10The British Ambassador, Geoffrey H. S. Jackson, who was released last night after spending eight months as a hostage of the Tupamaro guer rillas, left Uruguay at midday today on the first available flight to Europe.

title: Hitachi of Japan Arrives for Visit
description: Prince Hitachi of Japan, the second son of Emperor Hirohito and the fourth in line to the Imperial throne, arrived with his wife at Kennedy Inter national Airport last night for the first lap of a 10day visit to this country.

title: The Kennedy Opera House Acoustics
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 It may not be saying much to assert that the Opera House of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is, acoustically, the best in America. This country is not notable for operahouse con struction. It would be more to the point to say that the Kennedy Center Opera House is equal to any in the world as regards pure sound.

title: Clash on Westmoreland Visit
description: ROME, Sept. 10 (Agence FrancePress)Youths and po licemen clashed tonight at a demonstration against the cur rent visit here of the United States Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland. One demonstrator was arrested and eight were taken in for questioning.

title: Dance: Variety in Park
description: The New York Dance Fes tival got under way at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Thursday night, but only just. After a prologue of flashes and a drumroll of thunder, the performance was once brought to a total halt by a shower that was fortu nately only passing through. So, although the threat of rain never seemed more than an umbrellalength away, the performance did manage to complete itself.

title: Mrs. Kin Defeats Chris Evert, 63, 62
description: The endless summer came to a halt for Chris Evert yester day, before, the brilliance of Mrs. Billie Jean King.

title: Nabisco Plans Expansion
description: Nabisco, Inc., has purchased a 100acre tract of land in Henrico County, Va., and plans to erect on it a multimillion dollar cookie and cracker bakery.

title: Pier Angeli, Actress, 39, Dies; Film Star in U.S. for 2 Decades
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 10 (UPI)Pier Angeli, the Itai ianborn actress and forme. wife of Vic Damone, the singer was found dead in her apart. ment today. She was 39 years old.

title: U.S. JETS STRIKE AGAIN IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 (AP)  United States fighterbombers struck inside North Vietnam today for the third time this week.

title: Rutgers to Admit Women Students In the Fall of 1972
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 10Ending a 205year old tradition, Rutgers, the state university, will admit women to its undergraduate college as candidates for degrees in the fall of 1972.

title: Unhooking Addicts
description: An astronaut, back from the moon, displays symptoms of an unknown disease. The disease spreads, killing many and permanently disabling most of those who contract it. What comes next?

title: PRICES ARE DOWN IN STOCK TRADING
description: The stock market, which has enjoyed a Nixon rally inter mittently since midAugust, yes terday saw a bit more of the Nixon consolidation.

title: South Vietnamese Offer Private Funds To Flooded North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10Private relief efforts are under way here to send aid to the flood victims of North Vietnam, whose Govern ment has labeled President. Nguyen Van Thieu's offer to send food and money a deceit ful trick.

title: HardBitten Republican
description: Winston L. Prouty was a hardbitten Republican, like his fellow Senator from Vermont, George D. Aiken, but some times he seemed to chafe in the shadow of his colleague, the respected and politically popu lar dean of Senate Republicans.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Layoffs Had Ended
description: BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)About 4,400 laidoff workers had already been brought back to work by the LockheedCalifornia Company in anticipation of the $250 million loan guarantee formally approved yesterday by the Fed eral Government, a Lockheed spokesman said.

title: CHILDREN'S SERIES PLANS FEWER ADS
description: A series of special children's programs containing fewer commercial interruptions will be televised next season by the A.B.C. television network, James E. Duffy, network presi dent, has announced.

title: Airlines Still at Impasse On TransAtlantic Fares
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Sept. 10The major in ternational airlines failed again today to agree on a new fare structure for North Atlantic service.

title: Fern Loses Force
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 10 (UPI)Hurricane Fern, los ing its high winds through con tact with land, drifted along the Texas coast today, causing more problems with its drench ing rain than its winds.

title: McGovern Meets Vietcong As WarStudy Trip Begins
description: PARIS, Sept. 10 (UPI)Sen ator George McGovern said to day, after talks with Viet cong officals, that he under stood more clearly the difficul ties holding up progress at the Vietnam peace talks.

title: Dictaphone Shifts Groups
description: The Dictaphone Corporation announced yesterday a reorgan ization of its worldwide mar keting and manufacturing op erations. The company elimi nated the international operat ing group and transferred re sponsibilities previously han dled by the group to individual operating managers for com mon product lines.

title: Market Place: On Trying to Get The Last Points
description: The top dog of a major mutual fund organization re cently rejected an applicant for a money management job mainly because the applicant had sold a number of stocks while they were still on the upswing.

title: Brandt to Meet Brezhnev Next Week at Crimean Spa
description: BONN, Sept. 10Chancellor Willy Brandt will fly to the Crimea next Thursday to con fer with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: Bridge: Ruffing of Partner's Trick Is Not Necessarily a Crime
description: Ruffing a partner's trick is usually considered the mark of a beginner, but it may in dicate that a player is an alert expert. Such a play was needed on the diagramed deal, played recently in Aus tralia, and it is not surprising that the defender missed his chance to be a hero. The epi side was reported by Ron Klinger of Sydney, a brilliant young playerwriter.

title: Prescription for a Healthy Press
description: LONDONThe newspaper industry is ailing; but I do not think that news papers will altogether die.

title: Power Disruptions Affect Queens Areas and Hoboken
description: Seiarate power failures in Queens and Hoboken, N.J. affected thousands of residents yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl, 14, Is Killed in Bronx As Boy's Zip Gun Goes Off
description: A 14yearold girl was fatally shot in a Bronx park yesterday by, a 14yearold boy who was showing her a zip gun, a crude homemade weapon often used in gang fights in the nineteen fifties, the police said.

title: Barbados Leader Reelected; Party's Majority Increased
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Sept. 10 (Reuters)Prime Min ister Errol W. Barrow's Bar bados Democratic Labor party was returned to power with an increased House of Assembly majority in the general elec tions yesterday on this Carib bean island.

title: TEACHERS RESUME LEVITTOWN TALKS
description: LEVITTOWN, L. I., Sept 10 Negotiations to end the three day strike by the Levittown Teachers Association were re sumed this afternoon and con tinued until 11:30 tonight with a State Supreme Court Justice as a mediator.

title: PACER SCRATCHED: DRUGGING HINTED
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 10 The discovery this morning in a pack box at Roosevelt Race way of a syringe, bloodcov ered absorbent cotton and other evidence of possible drugging caused the scratching of Rusty Coast from tonight's eighth race.

title: Mets Defeat Phils, 4 to 3; Koosman Strikes Out 11
description: Jerry Koosman, who has had many lows this season, reached a high last night, but he needed help from Danny Frisella and Frisella needed help from Dave Marshall before the Mets se cured a 43 victory over Philadelphia.

title: Smuggled Raphael Is Sent Back to Italy From Boston
description: After months of negotiating with the Italian Government and the United States Treasury Department, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston is returning to Italy the Portrait of a Young Girl attributed to Raphael, which museum em ployes allegedly smuggled out of Italy in 1969.

title: Susan J. Steinbock Wed to Professor
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 10 Miss Susan Jill Steinbock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer L. Steinbock of White Plains, was married here this afternoon to Bruce Verma zen, son of James Ralph Ver mazen of Phoenix, Ariz., and the late Mrs. Vermazen. Judge Myron Martin of the Superior Court of Alameda County performed the cere mony in his chambers.

title: Silvestrone Team Wins
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Sept. 10 Art Silvestrone of Pike Brook and Mrs. Robert Shields of Al pine eliminated the defending champions, Bob Shields and Mrs. Philip Bads of Alpine, and 5, in the selecteddrive, al ternateshot New Jersey pro lady tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club today.

title: RAIL FREIGHT OFF; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week end ed Sept. 4 was below the cor responding week a year ago. Intercity truck tonnage in creased.

title: Spitz Leads U.S. Team To World Swim Marks
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R., Sept. 10 (AP)The American men es tablished a world record of 7 minutes 43.33 seconds in the 800meter freestyle relay today as the United States continued its dominance of a triangular swim meet with the Soviet Union and Britain by sweeping nine of 10 events.

title: Thant Says Farewell to the U.N. Staff
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10Secretary General Thant bade formal farewell to day to the 5,500 members of the United Nations headquar ters staff, again making it clear that he intends to retire when his present term expires in December.

title: BREWER POSTS 132, TIES FOR GOLF LEAD
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 10 (AP)Gay Brewer and John Miller shared the halfway lead in the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament today, turning in eightunderpar 132's.

title: CUBA AND SOVIET SIGN NEW ECONOMIC PACT
description: MIAMI, Sept. 10Cuba and the Soviet Union have signed a wide  ranging economic agreement, the Havana ?? announced today. The brief an nouncement gave few details, but both Havana and Moscow have indicated that under the agreement Soviet participation in the planning and execution of Cuba's economic and tech nical projects would be greatly increased.

title: MRS. BARD LINDEMAN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10A funer al service for Mrs. Adele Linde man, wife of Bard Lindeman, editor in chief of Today's Health magazine, will be held Sunday at Grace Lutheran Church in River Forest, Ill. Mrs. Lindeman, who was 40 years old and formerly resided in Westwood, N. J., (lied Wednes day after an operation.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Astronauts on the Apollo flights have been protected by emergency shock absorb ers that may serve also in automobile bumpers. William H. Keathley and. Clarence J. Wesselski, aero space technolo gists at the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston, were granted Patent 3,603,433 this week for the energy absorb ers, which are built into the struts of the command mod ule couches. The invention is a set of washers tightly fitted on a rod. Pressure against the end of the line of washers pushes one after an other along the rod as the force decelerates.

title: Jipcho of Kenya Wins Mile In 3:57.4 at London Meet
description: LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP)Ben Jipcho of Kenya, despite a knee injury, defeated Francesca Arese of Italy in the mile run at an international track and field meet at the Crystal Palace.

title: Latins Score Import Tax;
description: PANAMA CITY, Sept. 10 (AP)LatinAmerican econom ic leaders contended today that the United States 10 per cent import surtax is a coun terproductive measure that will harm United States trade with Latin America.

title: 6 Bombs Set Off as Ulster Awaits New I.R.A. Drive
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 10 (AP)Snipers fired at British troops in Londonderry and saboteurs set off six bombs in Belfast early today.

title: Mrs. McClory Wed To Azamat Guirey
description: Mrs. Fredericka (Bobo) McClory, daughter of Lady Omerod of Nassau, the Ba hamas, and the late Fred erick Sigrist, the British air craft multimillionaire, was married in Southampton, L. I., on Aug. 25 to Azamat Guirey, son of Princess Guirey of New York and the late Prince Kadir Guirey. The civil cere mony took place at Mr. and Mrs. Garrick Stephenson's home.

title: At 63, She Still Wants To Be a Doctor
description: GREEN VALE, L. I.,When Mrs. George Balluff was a child in Provo, Utah, she always wanted to be a physician. She still does, but now the 63yearold grandmother of 10 says she realizes she can forget about that because of her sex and age.

title: U.S. CONCERNS STIR CANADIANS' ANGER
description: TORONTO, Sept. 10  The move by two United States companies to extend the Nixon wage freeze to their subsid iaries in Canada provoked ex pressions of anger today from opposition members of Parlia ment and from trade union officials.

title: Murphy Urges Police Chiefs to Allow No Latitude on Graft
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy of New York City urged his fellow police chiefs today to stand together in es tablishing a zero level of tol erance for corruption.

title: Defeatism on Subway Fares
description: New Yorkers cannot accept the defeatism shown by Governor Rockefeller and his appointee as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Dr. William Ronan, on retention of the 3pcent subway and bus fare. Another jump in fares would be a municipal disaster, even if it did not run so counter to the whole thrust of the longterm antiinflation effort on which President Nixon has launched the country.

title: Moscow's Triple Policy
description: It becomes evident in retrospect that no world capital was more affected than Moscow by President Nixon's announcement that he would visit Peking. The two months since that development have brought what amounts to a revitalization of Soviet foreign policy and an inten sification of the pace at which it is being conducted. The consequences have been as varied as the new Soviet agreement to help India, the conclusion of a fourpower accord on Berlin and the ambitious schedule of for eign policy trips projected this fall for Soviet leaders, including Premier Kosygin's planned visit to Canada a trip that may bring him to this country as well.

title: UNION HEAD IS NAMED TO ADIRONDACK UNIT
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday the appoint ment of Joseph. P. Tonelli, presi dent and secretary of the In ternational Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Paper Mill Workers, as a member of the states new Adirondack Park Agency.

title: Saigon Tells How to Vote Against ThietzInvalidate the Ballot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10  South Vietnamese who want to vote against the Thieu Government in next month's presidential elections will be able to do so only by invalidating their ballotsmu tilating them or throwing them away.

title: BENGALIS TO SEND DELEGATION HERE
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 10 (Reut ers)The selfproclaimed sepa arist government of East Paki stan plans to send a delegation tion of seven or eight persons to New York to press its cause when the United Nations Gen eral Assembly convenes. The Assembly session will open there on Sept. 21.

title: ADAMANT JAMES BEST AT TUXEDO
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y. Sept. 10The topwinning dog in America, Ch., Chinoe's Adamant James, an English springer spaniel owned by Dr. Milton Prickett of Lexington, Ky., added to his impressive record at the Tuxedo Park Kennel Club's show on the grounds of the old Tuxedo Park Golf Course today When he was named best of 1,241 dogs.

title: Senator Prouty of Vermont Dies; Cast a Major Vote for the ABM
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Senator Winston L. Prouty, the junior Senator from Vermont, died today of gastric cancer in New England Deaconness Hos pital. He was 65 years old.

title: Soviet Delays on 5Year Plan; Rift Over Policy May Be Cause
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin's Govern ment has failed to carry, out a Communist party directive that it submit a final draft of the 197175 fiveyear economic plan to the country's Supreme Soviet by Sept. 1.

title: Purex Raises Profits for Year; Sales Set a Record for Period
description: The Purex Corporation, Ltd., in its report yesterday for the fiscal year ended June 30, showed net income of $10,670, 000, or 95 cents a share, up from $4,362,000, or 36 cents a share in the previous fiscal year.

title: Attica Has No Fear, but Anger Aplenty
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 10 When her husband works nights as a prison guard across the road in Attica prison, Mrs. Jean Stillinger does not bother to lock the doors of her pleas ant frame home.

title: Article 5  No Title
Carol M. King Has Nuptials
description: Miss Carol Marie King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. King of Geneva, Ill., was married yesterday to Sander Rubin of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Saul Rubin and the late Mr. Rubin. The cere mony at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture was per formed by Howard Box, lead er in Brooklyn.

title: Volkswagen Says That Its Director Has Not Resigned
description: BONN, Sept. 10Kurt Lotz, director of the Volkswagen Company since 1968, has come under fire because of his al leged failure to preserve the good fortunes of West Ger many's largest industrial enter prise.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Not Satisfied on Quota Concession
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The United States and Japan concluded a Cabinetlevel eco nomic conference here today still far apart on disputes over trade and monetary adjust ments.

title: COLONIAL PENN SET TO BUY AN INSURER
description: Colonial Penn Group, Inc., announced yesterday that it has agreed to buy the National Ben Franklin Insurance Com pany of Pittsburgh, one of the Continental Corporation's in surance companies.

title: New Faces for Tonight's Philharmonic
description: There will be at least a shade of difference in the look, and undoubtedly also in the sound, of the New York Philharmonic tonight. Fifty young musicians, blacks and members of other minorities, will sit in with the orchestra in an informal concert at Philharmonic Hall.

title: LOCKHEED AID SEEN A BAD PRECEDENT
description: The Congressional guarantee of bank loans to rescue the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy has set a dangerous precedent for Amer ican business, according to corporation executives polled by Dun's magazine.

title: LATE RALLY FAILS TO BOLSTER ALIEX
description: The American Stock Ex change closed slightly lower on balance yesterday as trading eased.

title: Ronan Suggests Possibility Of a 35Cent Transit Fare
description: The possibility of a 5cent increase in the city's transit fare was suggested privately yesterday by the chairman of the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority.

title: Big Board's Unfixed Rates Found Costly in Quarter
description: The free negotiation of sales charges on large stock trades cost the New York Stock Ex change membership $17million in the June quarter, according to Ralph D. DeNunzio, chair man of the exchange's govern ing board.

title: ExClerk Is Indicted in Post Office Theft
description: When a postal clerk opened the vault for registered mail in Jamaica, Queens last Nov. 23he saw a note taped inside. It read: I took the money. Love, Joel Winston Johnson Jr.

title: Freedom Denied to Russo
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (AP) A Federal judge refused to day to free Anthony J. Russo, jailed since last month for hav ing refused to answer grand jury questions about the Penta gon papers.

title: U.S. STEEL FURLOUGH OF 1,000 IS EXPECTED
description: DULUTH, Minn. (UPI)The United States Steel Corpora tion said today it expectd to lay off about 1,000 workers Oct. 1 when it shuts down many departments for an in definite period of time.

title: C.B.S. Names I.T.T. Executive To Succeed Stanton as President
description: A 50yearold lawyer and cur poration executive from outside the broadcasting industry was named yesterday to become president of the Columbia Broadcasting System Oct, 1, succeeding Dr. Frank Stanton.

title: Vatican Rule Change Due
description: ROME, Sept. 10The Vatican announced today that on Mon day it would publish a papal document containing new rules for confirmation, one of the seven sacraments of the Roman Catholic Church. The sacra ment, administered by bishops, according to church doctrine strengthens baptized persons for the profession of the Chris tian faith.

title: Once Gable as KingNow It's Bob Dylan
description: WHEN D. W. Griffith amassed enormous numbers of extras for the scenes of battle and pageantry that filled Intolerance and Birth of a Nation, when he almost literally invented the techniques of cutaways and lap dissolves, when he realized the dramatic effects possible in intercutting scenes from completely unconnected situations, he was opening the pages of a new art form, film. Griffith realized, with the almost intuitive perception that accompanies genuine artistic innovation, that he was dealing with a medium quite different from the theater, and that even though both were concerned with dramatic expression, motion pictures had a potentiala virtual environmentfor imaginative expansion that could never be realized on a theatrical stage.

title: DONDE TRIUMPHS IN RACE ON SOUND
description: SEA CLIFF, .L. I., Sept. 11 Short courses and big victory margins were the order of the day as 53 boats sailed with the Sea Cliff. Yacht Club in the MidSound, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition today.

title: U.N. Unit to Accuse Israel of Violating Occupation Accord
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 A United Nations special committee is preparing to report to the General Assembly that Israel, by her own admission, has violated a 1949 Geneva convention by preparing to rule permanently over Arab territories she has occupied.

title: Nun Leaving L.1. Diocese To Aid a State Program
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 17Sister Maria Goretti, coordinator of the Rockville Centre Diocese's Spanish Apostolate, has become an associate bilingual education for the state.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Alfred J. Green, president of Cotton City Industries, Inc., one of the largest independent dress manufacturers in the country, remembers when his company was engaged in chopping up cotton fabrics for women's house dresses that sold for 79 cents to $1.00 each.

title: Amnesty Demand Is Called Snag in Attica Prison Talks
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept 11 State correction authorities were described today as being willing to grant most of the demands made by the more than 1,000 inmates who have controlled the interior comPound of the Attica Correctional Facility and have held 33 guards hostage since Thursday morning.

title: Investor Clubs on L.I. Glue Eyes on Ticker
description: The stockmarket clubs of Long Island inhabit a world balanced between prudence and wild intuition where normally hardworking businessmen, professionals and housewives gather once a month in hopes of increasing their incomes.

title: Knick Rookie Camp in Jersey Is a Land of Giant Rookies
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 11  Walt Frazier was driving down the middle during a Knick workout when he found himself cornered by giant rookies, Steve Niles, a near 7footer, Dan Davis, 610, and Mike O'Brien, 68.

title: Giants in Last Exhibition Here;
description: The New York Giants come to the end of a most trying training season today when they play the Pittsburgh Steelers at Yankee Stadium at 1 P.M. in their final exhibition game.

title: New Hours for XRays
description: The Brooklyn Tuberculosis and Respiratory Disease Association will close its chest Xray center at 293 Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn an hour earlier than usual on Mondays and Thursdays after Sept. 1. The new hours will be from 1 to 7 P.M. on Mondays and Thursdays. The center will continue to he open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Tuesdays.

title: Columbia's Erickson Paces Victors in Team Scrimmage
description: LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 11 Glenn Erickson, a secondstring quarterback, was the top offensive performer in a defensedominated intrasquad scrimmage at Columbia University's preseason football camp today. The White team, made up of the firststring defense and secondline offense, downed the Blue squad, 90.

title: The Nation
Shelter Island Returned to the Hareleggers
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept, 11  Labor Day has gone, and with it most of the summer people. Now the population of Shelter island is rapidly shrinking to its permanent 1,700 or so, and the natives are beginning to resume their normal activities.

title: THE OPENING
description: LEAVES OF GRASSTonight, Theater Four, 7:30. A musical by Stan Harte Jr., based on Walt Whitman's works.

title: Education
description: When Sesame Street was created two years ago, the daily, hourlong television program for preschool children had a specifically American mission: to prepare youngsters for the world of learning, regardless of whether they lived in slums, suburbs or urban affluence.

title: Suffolk Park Rising on Garbage
description: HOLTSVILLE, L. I., Sept. 11 A 74acre park with facilities for tennis, football, baseball and other sports is being built here on a massive mound of garbage.

title: U.M.W. HEAD FACES SUIT ON ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  The President of the United Mine Workers of America will go to court here on Monday to defend himself against a Labor Department effort to void his 1969 election victory and force him to run again.

title: Cougars Mahaffey Retires
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Sept. 11 (AP)The Carolina Cougars said today that Randy Mahaffey, a former Clemson University star, was quitting basketball to remain in business in Georgia with his brother. Mahaffey has been in the American Basketball Association for four years.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opened here last week. And opened and opened and opened. A preview preview last Sunday night for an audience that included a select group of Catholic priests, a dress rehearsal Monday, a preview Tuesday, the gala opening Wednesday (which Mrs. Aristotle Onassis managed to dominate as much by her absence as she could have by her presence), etc. etc.

title: Arch of Asphalt Plant to Survive
description: To Robert Moses it was horrible modernistic design. To the Museum of Modern Art it was a prizewinning example of functional architecture. To millions of motorists who have confronted its unusual shape as they drove down the East River Drive just before passing Gracie Mansion, it has been eyearresting.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MUSQUARO Lake, Quebec In the black water on the edge of lily pads at the upper end of a small, unnamed lake in the Musquaro River watershed, large, deepbellied brook trout were taking our flies on nearly every cast.

title: Weinreichs Have Son
description: A son was born here on Aug. 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Theodore G. Weinrich of Riverside, Conn. The child has been named David.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: TO THE EDTIOR:

title: Gilligan's Island, German Shepherd, Is Best of 1,872 Dogs at Somerset Hills
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept. 11In one of the strongest finals at any show in the East this year, a German shepherd, Ch. Lakeside's Gilligan's Island, owned by Danny Dwier of Kresson, N. J., was named best of 1,872 dogs today at the 37th fixture of the Somerset Hills Kennel Club at the Far Hills Fairgrounds.

title: 9 ON SCHOOL BUS DIE IN COLORADO CRASH
description: GARFIELD, Colo., Sept. 11 (AP)Eight teenage boys and their junior varsity football coach were killed and 22 others hospitalized today when their school bus hurtled two miles down a mountain pass and overturned in a tilling station's lot.

title: Political Apathy Seen in Suffolk As Only 100 Attend Key Debate
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., Sept. 11 Only 100 people attended the first debate in the fourcornered Suffolk County Executive election campaign this week, prompting a Republican leader to express concern over the apparent apathy of the voters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 15 editorial opposing legislation prohibiting sex discrimination in college admissions concedes that is clearly unfashionable to admit that there are educational goals and programs peculiarly related to men's and women's needs and aspirations.

title: Hearing Set on Nixon Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Foreign Economic Policy will begin hearings Thursday on the International implications of President Nixon's new economic policies, it was announced today by the subcommittee chairman Representative John C. Culver, Democrat of Iowa.

title: WASHINGTON
description: FIERY RUN, Va., Sept. 11 The equinox has come to Virginia a little early this year, and Fiery Run, fed by gullywashing rains off Rattlesnake Mountain, is charging down these lovely valleys to the Rappahannock and the sea. It is startling to come home to an old preRevolutionary, cabin in these hills after a long journey into China, for it is a reminder of how old the American Revolution really is, and how young are the revolutions of China and the Soviet Union.

title: The Higher Realism Of Woodrow Wilson
description: Et Al.

title: Television
description: IT'S another new season, and it's breathless time once again in the land of television, The schedules are fixed (mere or less), the commercialnetwork executives are resigned (so to speak), the audiencerating machines are ready to impartially designate winners and losers, and the critics are struggling desperately to sort out the thousand and one impressions picked up in screening rooms over the past few weeks.

title: RAIDERS TRIUMPH OVER COLTS, 247
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla,, Sept. 11 (AP)Revenge and George Blanda, the oldest pro, spurred the Oakland Raiders to a 243 victory over the Baltimore Colts tonight in their final National Football League preseason game in the Gator Bowl.

title: U.S. Warns Vincennes, Ind.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, William D. Ruckelshaus, announced today a 180day notice requiring Vincennes, Ind., to abate its pollution of the Wabash River. Mr. Ruckeishaus can seek legal action against the city if it fails to take appropriate action within that deadline.

title: British College Buildings Depicted
description: BRITAIN'S 1971 architecture stamps, due Sept. 22, will portray university buildings at Aberystwyth, Southampton, Leicester and Colchester.

title: Britain to Vote at U.N. For Peking's Admission
description: LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP) Britain will vote for Communist China's admission to the United Nations even if it costs Nationalist China its seat, senior officials said today.

title: School of Arts' Location Belies Educational Status
description: On Second Avenue, squeezed between the old Fillmore East rock shrine and Ratner's celebrated dairy restaurant, is the door to the New York University School of the Arts.

title: A Gala Opening in Pittsburgh, Too
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 While many lovers of the performing arts had their minds on the opening of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington this week, the focus in Pittsburgh was on another hall, another era, another feeling.

title: Honolulu to Try Car Pool To Solve Traffic Problem
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 11Mayor Frank F. Fasi, who has advocated that a limit be placed on the number of automobiles on the island of Oahu, is taking steps to establish the nation's first citywide, computerized car pool.

title: Wyoming Beats So. Dakota Behind Fox, Brown, 4228
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Sept. 11 (UPI)Gary Fox threw two touchdown passes and kicked six extra points today to lead Wyoming to a 4228 victory over South Dakota.

title: Open Admissions Gives Brooklyn College New Life
