description: For Brooklyn College, new life begins.

title: Queens School Conflict Renewed
description: A Queens junior high school that a few years ago was a controversial symbol of the Board of Education's efforts to promote racial integration has again become the center of a bitter conflict with racial overtones.

title: Canada's Safety Council Reports on Snow Tires
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (AP) The Canada Safety Council maintains that snow tires, tire chains and sand on the street are nearly worthless when the temperature drops to zero on icy streets.

title: POINT OF VIEW
TEAM SAILING WON BY MANHASSET BAY
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11  Manhasset Bay Yacht Club Resolute Class skippers from Port Washington, L.I., narrowly defeated the Indian Harbor Y, C. Luders16 Class team of Greenwich, 17% to 18, today in their annual interfleet team match. They sailed in Luders16 sloops on an 8.5mile triangular course on Long Island Sound in a light southeast breeze.

title: Music: Heinz Hall, Pittsburgh's Acoustical Gem
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept 11 After decades of listening to the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra in the musically unsympathetic Syria Mosque, Pittsburghers at last have the opportunity to hear it as it ought to sound.

title: Morgan M'Ginley Weds Mary Dowd
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 11 Miss Mary Elizabeth Dowd, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald R. Dowd of West Hartford and East Lyme, was married here today to Morgan McGinley of Noank, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morgan McGinley of New London.

title: Specialists Hail Child Care Bill As a Step in Changing Program
description: The child development bill passed by the Senate last week is being praised by specialists as a first step in changing day care frorn limitedaccess custodial care to a universal, multiservice program for families of all economic strata.

title: Illinois State Gains a Yard
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept. 11 (AP)A sophomore, Larry Cates, scored three touchdowns today to pace Western Michigan to a 357 victory over Illinois State. Western Michigan's defense allowed one yard rushing.

title: A Farmer's Memories
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)Roswell Garst, the Iowa farmer who discussed hybrid corn with Nikita Khrushchev during a visit to Russia in 1955 and was visited in turn at home by Mr. Khrushchev in 1959, recalled the Soviet leader today as a man who did more to open up Russia for conversations and visitors than anyone before him. Mr. Garst, who lives in Coon Rapids, Iowa, spoke in a telephone interview.

title: Salavarria Beats Jimenez On Decision in Nontitle Bout
description: MANILA, Sept. 11 (AP)Erbito Salavarria, the World Boxing Council flyweight champion, defeated Natalio Jimenez of the Dominican Republic by a unanimous decision in a 12round nontitle fight tonight.

title: Janet Kendall, T. C. Gaillard, Innkeeper, Wed
description: HOLDEN, Mass., Sept. 11 Miss Janet Margreta Kendall and Tristram Coffin Gaillard were married here today at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. James Thomas Wilcox. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas V. Sullivan of St. Francis Episcopal Church.

title: Miss Ohio Is Chosen Miss America
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) Laurie Lee Schaefer, who entered the Miss Ohio pageant three times before winning it, was crowned Miss America 1972 here Saturday night.

title: Margaret Henry Is Attended by 7 At Her Wedding
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11  Miss Margaret Riker Henry and Thomas Donald Cunningham 3d were married here this afternoon in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Harold Bassage. He was assisted by the Rev. Arthur Hargate, rector of St. Mathew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Come in Number One, Your Time Is Up
description: Derek Jewell acknowledges the help of 13 advisers to backstop the accuracy of the technical, commercial, managerial and medical detail in his novel about a British conglomerate. That he has been well served is indicated by the book's intricate texture of corporate funny business. The director of an industrialcommercial octopus suffers a mild coronary and he has scarcely tottered back to his executive suite before his minions are battling for the succession.

title: Asters
description: There were wild asters in bloom by midAugust, but they are essentially autumn flowers with their heyday around midSeptember. Here they come, along every country road, in the old pastures and along the edges of the woodland. They mask the village dumps, they cover the scars of the road builders, they grow wherever they find root room for a season. They bring to September a veritable froth of blossom, and if they weren't so common they probably would be celebrated with a National Aster Day, or some such special occasion. Instead, they are taken for granted, like the ironweed and the Joe Pye weed and the bouncing Bet. But if the asters were blighted the whole landscape would be blighted after Labor Day.

title: Nixon Rally Fades As Wall St. Awaits Deeds, Not Rhetoric
description: EARLY last week the financial markets extended their buoyant Nixon rallythe exuberant response to the Administration's new economic program that was proclaimed so dramatically almost a month ago. But, toward the weekend, the markets turned gingerly downward in a display of wariness over the possible outlines of the program's Phase II starting in midNovember.

title: Khrushchev's Human Dimensions Brought Him to Power and to His Downfall.
description: LATE in the afternoon of Friday, Feb. 24, 1956, a short, rotund, roundheaded, gleamingly bald, baggysuited man stepped to the microphone at the concluding session of the 20th Congress of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, from which all foreign delegates and reporters had been excluded. Comrades, he began in his somewhat harshhoarse deliberate voice, in the report of the Central Committee of the party . . . in a number of speeches by delegates to [this] congress . . . quite a lot has been said about the cult of the individual and about its harmful consequences.

title: Toye of Cosmos Fined by League For Criticizing Playoff Referee
description: Clive Toye, vice president and general manager of the New York Cosmos, has been fined a substantial amount for remarks he made following the Cosmos elimination from the North American Soccer League playoffs, Commissioner Phil Woosnam has announced.

title: Music
description: WHAT'S happened to rock n roll? It's alive and well in the ghetto.

title: The District Attorneys Size Up Crime on L.I.
description: Many of the top members of organized crime in the metropolitan area make their homes on Long Island, hut, says Nassau District Attorney William Cahn, they know we know they're there, so we have it under control.

title: Bears Activate Holloway
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Chicago Bears today activated Glen Holloway, a guard, from the waived injured list. Holloway was injured in the Aug. 14 game with the Baltimore Colts. With Holloway returned, Randy Jackson could leave the offensive left guard and return to left tackle, a team spokesman said.

title: ARKANSAS ROUTS CALIFORNIA, 5120
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 11 (AP)Joe Ferguson led Arkansas to a 5120 victory over California tonight in his first start at quarterback.

title: Group Is Formed to Help Pass State's $2.5Billion Bond Issue
description: Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the formation of a nonpartisan committee that will try to persuade the state's voters to support his $2.5billion transportation bond issue.

title: Alicia M. Ferrer, Singer, Engaged
description: Mrs. Alicia Marin de Ferrer has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alicia Marin Ferrer, to Charles. William Jackson, an engineer in the nuclear division of Consolidated Edison Company. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Phillips Jackson of Wilmington, Del.

title: Minimum Wages Elude U. S. Farm Help
description: EARLE, Ark., Sept. 8 Five years after Federal minimum wage legislation was extended to agriculture, thousands of farm workers still labor for pay well below the legal minimum of $1.30 an hour.

title: Hoboken Quiet After a Pact Reached in 16Hour Meeting
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 11 (UPI)Hoboken remained quiet today after city officials and community leaders reached agreement on several issues at a 16hour meeting.

title: Sea Shells Charm Hitachi on City Tour
description: Prince Hitachi of Japan used his tour of the city yesterday to take a cram course that included marine biology, ornithology, American Indians, headshrinking and skyscraper architecture.

title: On Discovering the North Fork
description: ORIENT, L. I., Sept. 11 North Fork is scenic with natural things, Like the sudden whirring of an osprey's wings; Sights and sounds invite you to explore.

title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About hales
National Notes
description: Unfortunately, the embarrassment which most psychotherapists associate with this issue has left us with an even more embarrassing lack of facts, said Dr. Martin Shepard, a psychiatrist, last week. The issue: sexual relations between patients and therapists. Dr. Shepard wanted to know how much of it goes on, and he was urging the American Psychiatric Association and the American Psychological Association to conduct a study.

title: A Movie Puzzles You? Ask Questions
description: BACK in the thirties there came into being a Thirty  Nine Steps Club to which the late James Thurber belonged. According to Thurber, his group functioned as more than a mere fan club for the Alfred Hitchcock thriller. Members actually debated such provocative questions as the exact motivation of Mr. Memory in reciting publicly the secret of the ThirtyNine Steps. Did his response spring from the professional reflex of the trickmemory entertainer? Or was his subconscious so overloaded that he had to lighten the load with what amounted to a confession? No one was quite sure, but the character and his context were rich enough for the most extensive speculation.

title: 381 Cases Still Pending In Capital Mayday Protests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  The 9,382 charges against 8,733 persons arrested in the Mayday antiwar demonstrations here have been reduced to 381. In 757 of the cases, the dependents were either found guilty, pleaded guilty or pleaded no contest.

title: Growing Up in Birmingham
description: I.C.C* is acheckin on down the line, Well, I'm a little overweight

title: The World
description: SANTO DOMINGO  For the past five years, a grayhaired, softspoken bachelor with the look of a worried grandfather has defied all predictions for himself and his country by holding on to power and establishing a surprising degree of political stability.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONOn a balmy afternoon last Thursday, a college student from Providence walked up Pennsylvania Avenue to the Executive Office Building next to the White House and handed the armed guard at the door an open letter to Richard Nixon. The commonplace eventwas but one small step in a protest movement that has been building all year to stop the largest underground nuclear weapons test ever scheduled by the United States.

title: The H Persuasion
description: This is less a book than a collection of pietistic snippets by Believers. There is no reason to believe or disbelieve these exhomosexuals who claim that Eli Siegel put them on. the straight and narrow by showing that homosexuality was unaesthetic and therefore contemptuous of life. By the aesthetic realization that Beauty lies in. Opposites, they were cured. Nor is there reason to believe that anyone reading this volume would be moved, intrigued or piqued enough to try the cure.

title: Astros Subdue Reds, 52
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 11 (UPI) John Mayberry drove in three runs with his fourth and fifth homers of the season tonight as the Houston Astros beat the Cincinnati Reds, 52, and gave Jim Richard his second straight major league victory.

title: Royals Top White Sox, 42
description: KANSAS CITY Sept. 11 (UPI)Mike Hedlund triggered a threerun seventh inning with a tiebreaking single tonight, boosting the Kansas City Royals to a 42 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: National Notes
description: This is a tragic day for New York City . . . what we have here is a shocking example of indifference to the needs of this city. The injusticethe state decides and the city subway rider pays.

title: Troy Is Issue in Queens Democratic Race for Council Seat Tuesday
description: Queens Democrats go to the polls on Tuesday to choose a Councilman at Large in a primary contest that has been billed as the first major test of strength for the new Queens Democratic leader, City Councilman Matthew J. Troy.

title: For Young Readers: One of the most moving books ever written for children . . .
description: Several years ago John Donovan unsettled the children's book world by publishing a young adult novel in which a moment of sexual affection takes place between two adolescents. The adolescents happened to be boys, and although the episode was brief, and beautifully written, it caused a considerable uproar. One pondered at the time the courage it must have taken for Mr. Donovan to begin his novelist's career in such a manner. I'll Get There. It Better Be Worth the Trip was so plainly a book conceived out of idealism and love that it seemed not to take into account the conservatism of many parents and librarians. Mr. Donovan has now published a second noveland like its predecessor, it pays little respect to popularity. It is, however, one of the most moving books ever written for children, and I suspect that it will find a large audience.

title: 40 Soccer Fans Arrested At RangersCeltic Match
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 11 (UPI)About 40 soccer fans were arrested during today's Scottish First Division match between Glasgow rivals Rangers and Celtic, a police spokesman said.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Craig McGregor's viewpoint on Walkabout seems irrelevant and inattentive to the delicately beautiful, yet toughminded and quite unsentimental film I saw.

title: Brooklyn's Alpha School Is Devoted to Rehabilitation of Addicts
description: Why, Dee Dee, why did you do it? What's with you anyway, girl? Just what's inside you?

title: Kent State Field Goal Defeats North Carolina State, 23 to 21
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 11 (AP)Gordon Ober kicked a 20yard field goal with eight seconds left to give Kent State a 2321 seasonopening football victory over North Carolina State tonight.

title: Executives and the Freeze
description: Hundreds of the nation's most highly paid executives may be smiling all the way to the bank with their paychecks in coming months, notwithstanding President Nixon's wage freeze and whatever may follow it.

title: City Hospitals Chiefs Used Movie Fees to Finance Bear Mountain Retreat
description: Money paid by three motion picture companies for use of city hospital facilities was spent to finance an $1,800 weekend retreat at Bear Mountain for executives of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: A Doozy of A Dowser Convention In Danville
Postal Service: No Easy Road
Women's Liberation Unit Seeks Widening of Drive for Justice
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 A new political thrust indicating a second phase of the women's liberation movement was suggested in resolutions passed at the fifth national conference of the National Organization for Women held in Los Angeles

title: Peter Thomson Becomes Fiance Of Miss Hunter
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 11The enagagement of Miss Susan Hunter, a senior at Smith College, to M. Peter Thomson, a senior at Dartmouth College, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James Hewat Hunter of Willamstown and Sea Island, Ga., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Wilhelm Thomson of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Famed Prince, $24, Scores
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) Harvey Peltier's Famed Prince charged along the rail at the top of the stretch today and went on to win the $28,600 Midwest Handicap by six lengths at Hawthorne.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: It may seem plausible to Mrs. Roiphe that the turn against the idealization of family life is a form of population control. It is not plausible to anyone who believes rationally that this country and the world are in real danger if we do not and cannot stabilize population growth. No one, not anyone, advocates no more children! No one suggests doing away with WinniethePooh. But we do suggest additional reading, such as books by Dr. Paul Ehrlich (The Population Bomb, How to Be a Survivor, etc.). And we do suggest and urge limiting family size to one or two children. In this way we couldin 35 years if all childbearers took heed today  stabilize our numbers.

title: Movies
description: AT 46, Raoul Coutard is a very important cameraman; as everyone knows, he photographed nearly all of Godard's films, many of Truffaut's and Costa  Gavras's Z and The Confession. And he is very handsome, a cross, if you will, between JeanPaul Belmondo and Max von Sydow. But, stiffly posing in his room at the Drake, he is not a good subject for the photographer; neither is he a good interviewee. For his demeanor 73 distinctly stingylike that of a person testifying at his own trial who has been cautioned by counsel not to volunteer anything. And, as if to put even more distance between himself and his interrogator, Coutard decides on the spur of the moment (I feel lazy) to discourse in his native tongue, French, through an interpreter. Further, he declares that he will not answer questions about his private life. The situation is not without humor. For the reporter no longer holds the upper hand.

title: For the du Pouts, war was good growing weather
description: The modern Du Pont Company was built up with munitions profits from World War I, when the firm maintained a monopoly in the powder business. This book traces the role of Pierre S. du Pont in shaping the family enterprise into a large modern corporation, and then tells how he also became president of General. Motors and modernized that corporation as well. The story is laced with details of fiendishly complicated financial transactions, and it is a bit onesided, relying heavily on the company's version of what took place. Even so, the result is an unusually interesting book about business, down to earth and clear in setting forth complicated tale.

title: Open Admission Dropouts Double Usual City U. Rate
description: The percentage of day freshmen who dropped out of the City University's senior colleges after the fall term in 1970 was nearly twice as high12.4 per centamong openadmissions freshmen as it was for their classmates.

title: SERVER EATS PHILS, 92, FOR NO. 18;
description: Tom Seaver continued his onesided relationship with the Philadelphia Phillies last night as he pitched the New York Mets to a 92 victory in Shea Stadiumhis 18th of the season and seventh in a row.

title: Auto Union to Open Major Campaign in Congress for Tripartite Board to Review Wages and Profits
description: DETROIT, Sept, 11  The United Automobile Workers Union will begin a major push in Congress next week to establish a review board, representing labor, business and the public, to control wages and profits without governmental interference after the current 90  day freeze, it was announced today.

title: Brooklyn TeenAlters Turn Old Firehouse Into. Modern Center
description: A group of teenagers from the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn are converting former firehouse into their own recreation center.

title: British Soldiers on the Irish Border Fight an Impossible Battle Against an Unseen Foe
description: MIDDLETOWN, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5The armored car rumbling over a border road stops quickly. Maj. David Dinwiddie and two soldiers in flak jackets climb out and rush toward a youth walking into Northern Ireland.

title: A's Win in 10th, 53
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI)Reggie Jackson lined tworun homer with one out in the bottom of the 10th inning today to carry the Oakland A's to a 53 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: TROPICAL STORMS THREATEN 3 AREAS
description: Tropical storms threatened residents of the Texas coast, the sparsely settled Yucatan Peninsula and Bermuda yesterday. But none of the storms was considered especially dangerous.

title: Troubles
description: To stage a proper countryhouse novel, you need the right bit of property, a building spacious enough to house a menagerie of idiosyncratic specimens, and satiric intentions. To this basic recipe, J. G. Farrell (A Girl in the Head) has added his own moody, delicatelycalibrated style. The sum is a garden of original delights, in the best tradition of Crotchet Castle and Crome Yellow.

title: Stamps
description: FILIAL piety of the Chinese is traditional. The Taiwan postal administration is adding eight stamps to its 1971 Folk Tale series; in which this primary virtue of life is defined pictorially. The stamps, in low denominations, have been adapted from the 24 Folk Tales of Kuo Chliyeh (Yuan dynasty, 12791368). Filial piety in the view of Chinese sages demands respect for one's parents, obedience to their instructions, consideration of their welfare and no actions that would shame their good name. Parents, in turn, are to provide loving care.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: In the article, The Galbraith Plan to Promote the Minorities, it was implied that Jews have made it in the executive suites of American industry.

title: Sheffield Plays 22 Soccer Tie With Tottenham
description: LONDON, Sept. 11, Reuters Newly promoted Sheffield United maintained its unbeaten record today and remained at the top of the English League First Division soccer standing by gaining a 22 tie with Tottenham Hotspur.

title: Miss Jarrett Parker Wed on Yacht
Window Watchers Peel Eyes For Crime
description: Criminals in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn have a new enemy  the window watcher.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: In this complex world, it becomes harder and harder to determine what is real and what isn't. The Pentagon papers in The New York Times and other newspapers were real, for example, but the Pentagon papers in William Buckley's National Review weren't. And so it goes.

title: CenturyOld Role Of British Troops Ending in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 11 (AP) It's all rather sad, said a British colonel, stuffing batik sport shirts into a footlocker.

title: The World
description: LONDONFor 11 hours, Edward Heath and John Lynch discussed Northern Ireland, spending most of the time on the sundrenched lawn of Chequers, the British Prime Minister's official country residence. With the end of the meeting last Tuesdayand a hint of optimism in the. airMr. Lynch, the Irish Prime Minister, arrived in London for a tense, packed news conference.

title: Trenton Auto Racing Off
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)The 150mile AllStar Racing League championship scheduled for tomorrow at Trenton Speedway was canceled today because of flooding and the prediction of rain tomorrow.

title: Gardens
description: LIKE the world of people, the hardy bulbs have their characters, eccentrics, unusual and unforgettables, Make room for some of them in the garden to provide memorable beauty and to produce unusual effects.

title: A Sort Of Life
description: The first thing I remember is sitting in a pram at the top of a hill with a dead dog lying at my feet . . . The dog, as I know now, was a pug owned by my elder sister. It had been run overby a horse carriage? and killed and the nurse thought it convenient to bring the cadaver home this way.

title: Discovering wellknown radicals and undiscovering others
description: Some seeds of hope that Joseph Featherstone planted four years ago are sprouting throughout American education. In a series of articles in The New Republic in 1967, he portrayed British classrooms that had broken through to a new style of elementary schooling. This approach has won official endorsement in record time: It is the chief recommendation of Charles E. Silberman's Crisis in the Classroom (and Silberman handsomely acknowledges Featherstone's scoop). Whole states and major cities are turning toward it: New York, North Dakota, Vermont; Philadelphia, Akron, Washington, D. C. Most recently, a cover story in this newspaper's Sunday Magazine portrayed the system in action in a New York City school.

title: 4 Airlines Reject Proposal For Boston Airport Facility
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) After a sixweek study, four major airlines have rejected a proposal for a new passenger terminal at Logan International Airport.

title: INTEGRATION EFFORT:.
description: Letters:

title: Houston Triumphs Over Rice, 2321; Mullins Stands Out
description: HOUSTON, Sept. l.1 (UPI) Gary Mullins threw two touchdown passes and scored on 1yard lunge to lead the University of Houston to a 2321 victory over Rice tonight in the first meeting between the two crosstown schools.

title: Dance: Nonelitists Art in Central Park
description: If anyone has any illusions about dance's being an litist art, he should go to the New York Dance Festival in Central Park and not only watch the dancing but also the audience. It is alive, responsive and totally unjaded; more and More, I am beginning to think that the best thing you can do with the theater is to give it away.

title: EARLY RESERVATIONS
description: To THE EDITOR: It seems to me that J. R. Harris, marketing manager, U.S.A., for B.O.A.C., is slightly less than accurate when he says in a letter (Travel section, Aug. 8): B.O.A.C. has been campaigning for some time for lower fares, not just for one age group, but for all passengers willing to make their reservations at an early date. What he really means is: all passengers who are prepared to stay overseas within a minimum and maximum length of time. This underscores again what several other readers have pointed outbusinessmen and many others of us who prefer, fOr a variety of reasons, to determine our own length of stay continue to be penalized. I would be interested to know why the airlines feel it necessary to peg their fares

title: Theater Employe Slain
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP) The ticket taker at a theater was shot and killed last night by a teenager he had criticized for spitting on the lobby floor, the police said. Robert Yowell, 37 years old, was shot four times by the youth at the Walker Theater while a talent show was taking place.

title: AUSTRALIA DROPS PROTESTED TOUR
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 11 For the second time this year, sharp controversy erupted this week over AustralianSouth African sports.

title: Music
description: THE Kennedy Center is about to open as these lines are written, and I'll have more about it in this column next week. It will take a series of performances to assess the quality of the halls and the building itself. But even before its opening, the Kennedy Center has been subjected to criticism. While it was being built, there were cries that it was in the wrong location; that it should have been built in downtown Washington in order to upgrade the district. There are complaints that the opera house is too small. There are complaints about the ticket policy. There are complaints about the quality of Attractions booked into the center.

title: Hot Pants Test: Not an Inch Was Lost
description: A 16yearold girl and a 32yearold woman who recently tested the inflatable reducing Hot Pants for The New York Times both reported that they had lost no inches at all. The teenager is about 30 pounds overweight according to insurance industry statistics; the older woman, about 15 pounds overweight.

title: EGYPTIAN BOMBER REPORTED DOWNED
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 An Israeli machine gunner at the Suez Canal shot down an Egyptian Sukhoi fighterbomber shortly after noon today, the military command said. The plane was reported to have crashed in marshland in Egyptian territory, and the pilot was apparently killed.

title: Water Around L.I. Found Cleaner Than Last Year
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.The water around Long Island was considerably freer of pollution this summer than it was the same time last year, according to a team of scientists from the State University of New York at Stony Brook who recently completed a twoweek monitoring cruise of the region.

title: Art
description: STARTING about 30 feet above sidewalk level and rising another ten stories into the air, a giant painting in brilliant colors now covers what used to be a brick wall facing the spot where 19th Street comes to a messy death under the West Side Highway. It brightens the place up, said a truck driver who works out of an adjacent garage. Indeed it does, and indeed the end of West 19th Street is a decayed and ruptured bit of cityscape that can use a lot of brightening. But other considerations are involved. It isn't all that simple.

title: Kinetic Art Theater Presents Program Of Gordon Dances
description: The Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden was the setting Friday night for a dance concert by the Kinetic Art Theater, headed by Lonny Joseph Gordon. There is something about a coincidence of the right mood and place that can do wonders, and in this case it showed Mr. Gordon's work to great advantage.

title: Navajo Police Seek Raise And Right to Arrest Whites
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Sept. 11 (UPI)Navajo policemen, relying on public support instead of a strike, have ended a fourhour walkout but have pledged to press their demands for higher wages and more authority over the whites in three states.

title: Do Those Reducing Pants Work? Fat Chance, Many Customers Say
SISTER MARIE LYDON
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 11 Sister Marie Aidan Lydon of St. Anne's Villa, Convent Station, formerly a member of the faculty of St. Vincent's Academy in Newark, died yesterday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital here. She was 66 years old.

title: F.D.A, APPOINTEE TO FACE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Peter B. Hutt has offered Congress assurances that he will avoid conflicts of interest in his new job as chief counsel of the Food and Drug Administration despite recent ties to the food industry.

title: Seminar at Hofstra Calls for Unity in Drive on Drugs
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE ECONOMY: President Nixon promised not extend the wageprice freeze beyond the Nov. 13 deadline, but said he would take other, unspecified steps to halt inflation. . . . Japan rebuffed a United States plea to raise the value of the yen in order to solve American and world economic problems. The Japanese, who journeyed to Washington for Cabinetlevel talks, countered with a request that the Americans remove the 10 per cent import surcharge. Earlier Canada announced a plan to pay funds to companies hurt by the same surcharge, to offset worsening Canadian unemployment.

title: Volunteers Aiding Seaport Museum
description: Hard by Sloppy Louie's on South Street, to the cacophony of the East River gulls, there were final severe whackings with a limber rod, in the finest tradition of a Punch and Judy show, on the puppet stage at the South Street Seaport Museum the other day.

title: MINNESOTA SINKS INDIANA BY 280
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 11 (AP) Minnesota's defensive opportunists set up all four touchdowns as the Gophers drubbed Indiana, 280, today in a Big Ten football opener.

title: Mich. State Victor, 100
Coody's 68 Leads Golf Series by 3 Strokes
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 11  Charles Coody, the Masters champion but a newcomer to the World Series of Golf, scored a twounderpar 68 today and led Jack Nicklaus by three strokes.

title: REDSKINS, BENGALS BATTLE TO 1717 TIE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)Bill Kilmer, a substitute quarterback, connected with Jerry Smith, a tightend, on a 42yard touchdown pass in the fourth quarter tonight to earn Washington a 1717 tie with Cincinnati.

title: The Bitter Poetry Of BedSty Children
description: Stephanie Salley Age 10When Stephanie Salley wrote this poem, she was a pupil of a teacher named Irving Benig in a school in BedfordStuyvesant.

title: Consumption
description: James C. Abegglen's suggestion (New York Times, Aug. 29) that Japanese production will keep on coming to the United States (because there is nowhere else for it to go) should give pause to anyone who thinks world economic problems can be cured merely by realigning exchange rates and/or stopping inflation.

title: No. Carolina Beats Richmond, 28 to 0, As Oglesby Excels
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 11 (UPI) A North Carolina defeated Richmond, 280, tonight. Ike Oglesby, a junior tailback, scored on a 6yard run and was the mainstay of the Tar Heel ground game, carrying 29 times for 126 yards.

title: Rossetti Enlists Beame, Sutton, Rangel and Biaggi in Fight to Keep Leadership
description: Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader, who says he faces a tough fight in next Tuesday's primary, enlisted the help of topranking Democrats yesterday in his battle to retain his East Harlem district leadership.

title: Rockville Centre Gets Data Bank on Religion
description: Sister Helen Butler, a nun from the Amityville Dominican Community, was always fascinated by computers. Several years ago she had an idea that her religious order could use a dataprocessing system to help with administrative work.

title: Texas A. and M. Triumph
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Sept. 11 (UPI)Lex James accounted for two touchdowns and Doug Neil scored on two short plunges tonight to lead Texas A. and M. to a 417 victory over the Wichita State.

title: Khrushchev: Shift in Soviet Path
description: A young Russian migr  a leader of underground dissidentssaid a few days in New York: Russia owes more to Nikita Sergeyevich than to any other man of our time. But of course no one will say it until he's dead.

title: York Gets New Home In the Heart Of Jamaica
description: After four years of operation in temporary and borrowed facilities on the campus of Queensborough Community College in Bayside, York opens its new home tomorrow in the heart of Jamaica. Students will utilize six buildings near the site of the school's permanent campus, which is scheduled for completion in about a decade.

title: Thais Back Peking in U.N.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Thailand will vote for Peking's admission to the United Nations while opposing moves to oust Nationalist China, informed government sources said today.

title: Headliners
description: Center Court Cinderella

title: Miss Jane McCall Wed To Mauro Politi, a Judge
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 11 Miss Jane Ewart McCall, daughter of Howard Weaver McCall Jr., president of the Chemical Bank, and Mrs. McCall, was married here at noon today to Mauro Politi, son of Col. and Mrs. Adelio Politi of Florence.

title: OHIO STATE OPENS WITH 5221 ROMP
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11 (AP)  Don Lamka, an Ohio State quarterback who was a defensive reserve for the last two seasons, scored four touchdowns and gained 100 yards on 15 carries today in leading the Buckeyes to a 5221 victory over Iowa in a Big Ten Conference football opener.

title: Issues for Congress: Dixie, Football, Organ Music and Dixie
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Still beset with national and international problems, members of Congress returned last week from a summer recess.

title: Son to Mrs. G. M. Smith
description: A son was born to Lieut. Col. George Marlowe Smith, Army Medical Corps, and Mrs. Smith on Aug. 26 at the Womack Army Hospital, Fort Bragg, N. C. Mrs. Smith is the former Miss Marcia Ruderman of Hartsdale, N. Y. The child is named Matthew Marlowe.

title: The Brutal Takeover
description: Hitler was born in Linz and spent his formative years in Vienna; that Austria should be part of the Reich was one of his elementary articles of faith. Given Germany's military superiority and the general climate of appeasement in Europe, the fate of Austria was sealed from the day he came to power.

title: THE ELITE IS COLD TO GREEK REGIME Premier Has Few Friends in the Old Ruling Class
description: ATHENS, Sept. 6A few days after Premier George Papadopoulos reorganized his Cabinet on Aug. 26, two socially prominent Athenian women met on a busy downtown street.

title: Vikings Rout Dolphins, 240
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. Sept. 11 (AP)The Minnesota Vikings, led by the rushing of Clint Jones, stormed to a 170 edge and beat the Miami Dolphins, 240, tonight.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Trials Of 25 in Kent State Strife
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP) A Federal District Court judge has enjoined a local court from trying 25 persons indicted in the disorders at Kent State University in May, 1970.

title: Movie Mailbag:
description: To THE EDITOR: I very much enjoyed reading Now I'll Tell You How To Be a Movie Star, by Chris Chase.

title: THIEU PROMISES TO QUIT IF HE FAILS TO WIN MAJORITY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11  President Nguyen Van Thieu officially opened his unopposed Presidential campaign tonight by saying that he would resign from office if he received less than 50 per cent of the votes cast on Oct. 3.

title: SUFFOLK REDUCES WELFARE HOURS
description: BAY SHORE, LI., Sept. 1 The doors of the main offices of the Suffolk. Department of Social Services were locked at 1 P.M. yesterday, the fourth consecutive day this week that the offices were closed early as long lines of welfare recipients swarmed the understaffed headquarters here.

title: Foreign Notes
There's a Shadow on the Trail Of the HardtoCatch McLaren
description: BRAINERD, Minn., Sept. 11Jackie Oliver, the rambunctious English bantam, has yet to win a CanAm race, but he has never failed to be a factor in one. In 1969 and 1970, while driving the Peter Bryantdesigned Ti22, Oliver was the most consistent challenger to the mighty McLaren team, which has dominated the CanAm since 1967. This season Oliver is driving another of Bryant's innovative cars, the UOP Shadow. He does not let the McLaren success psych him.

title: Girl Figure Skater, 9, Youngest to Win Medal
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 11 (AP)Nineyearold Priscilla Hill of Lexington, Mass., became the youngest figure skater to win a gold medal, according to officials here, when she completed her figure skating and freeskating tests today.

title: YUGOSLAV PROTEST
description: Letters:

title: Offtrack and Offstride
description: Three months after its debut, the Offtrack Betting Corporation's prime computer system is still behaving like an erratic trotter who keeps going off stride.

title: 33Story Building to House Roosevelt Hospital Staff
description: A 33story middleincome apartment house will be built between 59th and 60th Streets near Amsterdam Avenue for the professional and technical staff of Roosevelt Hospital, it was announced Friday by State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt.

title: Piggott Rides Athens Wood to a Neck Victory in $121,723 St. Leger Stakes
description: DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 (AP) Lester Piggott rode Athens Wood to a neck victory today in the $126,723 St. Leger Stakes, giving the British jockey his sixth triumph in the race. The St. Leger was first run in 1776.

title: Plane, 5 Governors Aboard, Makes Emergency Landing
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 11 (UPI)An engine failed tonight on an Air National Guard C121 transport plane, carrying five Governors and their staffs to San Juan, P. R., for the National Governors Conference as the craft was 250 miles east of Miami. The plane made an emergency landing at Homestead Air Force Base.

title: In the Land of Cabots and Lowells, Debutante Parties Are on Decline
description: BOSTONFive years ago, the official list of debutantes in the Boston area had 300 names; this year there are only 92. And many of the girls who are on the list compiled by M. T. Bird & Company, the stationers, will simply be honored at small dances or tea parties at homeor plan to skip a debut altogether.

title: Photography
description: ONE of the photographer's trickiest exposure problems is trying to determine the correct aperture setting when exposing with flash or strobe  particularly when using multiple flash, or when there is also a substantial amount of other light present, natural or artificial. However, there is a compact, handy instrument now available which can eliminate all guesswork on exposures of this kind  the Calumet M100 Flash Exposure Meter, priced at under $70 and made by Calumet, Photographic, Inc., 1590 Touhy Avenue, Elk Grove Village, Ill. 60007.

title: Me Tarzan, You Jane Let's Make a Comeback!
description: WE'RE here for the interview, Tarzan said.

title: Cape of Storms
description: Anyone who wonders how much whaling technology has changed since Gregory Peck's pursuit of Moby Dick should pick up this sanguinary novel by a firstclass practitioner of the bloodandguts school. Blood flows in great torrents throughout the Antarctic cruise of a South African whaling expedition. Some of it belongs to the unfortunate beasts, who are transformed into a part of the gross national product by the hideous factory ship. And quite a bit belongs to the deckhands and crew, who have at each other with fists and knives over all sorts of things.

title: Vanguard Dealer of the AvantGarde
Tokyo Youth Leaps to Death
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11 (Reuters) Yoshinori Yazaki, 18 years old, has become the first suicide to leap from Japans tallest building, the 47story Keio Plaza Hotel, which opened here last June.

title: Nixon Goes to Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)  President Nixon flew this afternoon to Camp David, his retreat near Thurmont, Md., for an overnight stay. The President was accompanied by Mrs. Nixon and C. G. Rebozo of Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Six Escape in Plane Crash
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP)Six men escaped serious injury today when their twoengine plane apparently was hit by lightning and crashed at Philadelphia International Airport.

title: UConn Downs Brown, 140, In a Controlled Scrimmage
description: STORRS, Conn., Sept. 11 (AP)  Connecticut defeated Brown, 140, in a controlled football scrimmage today.

title: The World
Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Thank you so much for John Canaday's gracious article on the Brooklyn Museum. I remember as a child exploring the cavernous interior of that lovely monument, In those days, there was a huge stairway mounting like a Mayan temple from the, sidewalk to the second floor of the exterior, beneath the brooding statues of great men of antiquity. But the building itself was entered through an almost secret door beneath the great stairway, When the pretentious builders constructed those great stone steps, they must have left one Adirondack fewer.

title: Sweden Asked to Develop More Jobs
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 11The weeklong conference of the Swedish Trade Union Confederation, which ended today, reflected the mixed feelings of bluecollar workers in an affluent welfare state that is plagued by rising unemployment.

title: DON JUAN SCORES AT STONY BROOK
The Advance Man
description: Et Al.

title: Wild in The World
description: You could also call it Death Comes to the Little Oneswritten by the Executive Director of the Children's Book Council. Or, Another Page, Another Death and, as another American has remarked on these matters, so it goes.

title: PREDICTED LOG TEST CAPTURED BY HOYT
description: Swan Song, skippered by Dr. Anson G. Hoyt of t Red Bank, N. J., took the top honors in the Bayside yacht clubs predicted competition yesterday with an 0.3635 percentage of error.

title: Any Woman Can!
description: Et Al.

title: Reaction in Tokyo Slight
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11There appeared to be little reaction in Japanese financial circles to the conclusion of the United StatesJapanese economic talks in Washington. With the key points of contention still unresolved, business leaders preferred generally to repeat the Government's line that the talks were useful in promoting mutual understanding.

title: U.S. POLLUTION SUIT SETTLED IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, Sept. 11A Federal judge has approved a compromise agreement settling civil lawsuit brought by the United States Department of Justice against the Florida Power and Light Company over the discharge of heated water into Biscayne Bay.

title: HELLER ATTACKS ECONOMIC POLICY
Medals To Honor National Parks
description: A CONTRACT for medals to commemorate the centennial of our national parks, which will be celebrated next year, has been signed with Roche Jaune, Inc., of Kalispell, Mont., it was announced by George B. Hartzog Jr., Director of the National Park Service.

title: BOSTON'S RAPHAEL BACK HOME IN ITALY
description: ROME, Sept. 11The Boston Raphael, which the Boston Museum of Fine Arts bought two years ago for a reported $600,000, was returned to Italy today.

title: Bare Problems? Try Tuckin Plants
description: TUCKIN piants will solve bare problems. When voids occur in shrub borders or perennial plantings, then tuck in some small decorative plants to fill the open spot. These lowgrowersabout six to eight inches tallcover the soil and add interesting foliage pattern.

title: Bhutto Attacks Regime
description: KARACHI, Sept. 11 (AP) Mr. Bhutto criticized the military Government today for failure to hand over power to civilians, and warned there could be a civil war even in West Pakistan.

title: Decline and Fall
description: To the Editor: I agree with many of Garry Wills's comments in his review of my book, The Decline and Fall of Radical Catholicismbut, to my mind, they have little to do with the book itself.

title: the traveler's world
description: TO those of us who live in the socially insecure atmosphere of metropolitan New York, it comes as a rude, if pleasing, shock to discover that there is a place in the United States where you don't have to lock the doors and windows every time you leave home and where the local hotel does not have keys for its bedrooms because its guests have never had need to lock their doors.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: The paper industry has always been a productionoriented business. You put sopping wet woodpulp into one end of a machine, drain it and dry it and take off rolls of paper and paperboard at the other end, hundreds of tons at a time.

title: LYNCH AGREES TO GO TO TALKS ON ULSTER
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 11The Irish Prime Minister, John Lynch, said tonight that he would accept the British invitation to hold talks with Prime Minister Heath and Brian Faulkner, the Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, without preconditions.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Look, Let's Have justice Around Here
description: FROM every corner of the block on 110th Street in East Harlem they came to see the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater Company, and those who couldn't hung out of apartment windows and watched as technicians assembled the portable set.

title: NATHANIEL ROBIN, 71, NASSAU RADIOLOGIST
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 11  Dr. Nathaniel H. Robin, former chief radiologist at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, died of a heart attack last night at his home, 106 Hilton Avenue. He was 71 years old and had offices here and in Manhasset.

title: U.S. Horses Finish 1, 2
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, Sept. 11 (AP)Americanowned horses took the first two places in the Irish National Stakes for 2yearolds at the Curragh today and increased their prospects for next year's Epsom Derby.

title: Medical Schools Ask Aid for Research
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 11  The Association of American Medical Colleges has recommended that the Federal Government and private industry vigorously support more biomedical research because the goal of eradicating disease and advancing the state of Americans health is threatened with failure.

title: Pope Turns Down Plea To Lift Ban on Luther
description: WORMS, West Germany, Sept. 11, (AP) Pope Paul VI has turned down a request by a group of German Roman Catholic laymen that he lift the 450yearold papal ban against Martin Luther.

title: McGovern Sees Possibility Of Peace in Red Proposals
description: PARIS, Sept. 11 (UPI) Senator George McGovern Democrat of South Dakota, the only announced candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972, met North Vietnamese negotiators at the Vietnam peace talk today and said afterward that we believed peace was possible on the basis of Communist proposals.

title: How Mel Allen Started A Lifelong Love Affair
Miss Nancy Hazen Alesbury Is Bride
description: SUMMIT, N. S., Sept. 11Miss Nancy Hazen Alesbury, daughter of Mrs. Hazen Alesbury of Summit and Dr. Robert Johnson Alesbury of Manchester, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Robert Holmes Bradley 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bradley Jr. of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church by the Right Rev. David Keller Leighton, Episcopal Bishop Coadjutor of Maryland. He was assisted by the Rev. Allen Tinker.

title: Ward Four's Rowing Mark Stands for 100 Years
description: One hundred years ago yesterday a milestone in the sport of rowing was established. The date not only went down in history because a great international regatta was held, but because it represented the end of a glorious era.

title: To OUR READERS
description: Today The New York Times begins a separate section, 1A, on Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. It contains news and features of interest to readers in these areas and appears in copies distributed in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: The Death Of the Great Spirit
description: To the Editor: Anthony Wallace's comments on my book, The Death of the Great Spirit, contain numerous misrepresentations.

title: Haitians, Who Don't Play Game, Produce Millions of Baseballs
description: PORTAUPRINCE, HaitiFor eight hours a day, five days a week, Virginia Pierre sits in a huge room under a corrugated steel roof and makes baseballs.

title: Quarantine Ends in 3 States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11(AP) The lifting of a Federal quarantine for Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis in Arkansas, Oklahoma and New Mexico was announced today by the Department of Agriculture. Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi remain under quarantine. The disease is often fatal to horses.

title: Thank you, Marco Polo
description: Like ice cream, spaghetti originated in China, was brought to Italy by Marco Polo and eventually migrated West where it homesteaded in the American menu. Everyone eats spaghetti, but few people make it with a sauce as fresh and full of the sea as this spicy anchovy and clam triumph. The best way to test spaghetti's doneness is to dip a few strands in the sauce and taste. Chewy? Just right.

title: UNE DE MAI TAKES HOMECOMING RACE
Coins
description: AMERICAN collectors are showing considerable interest in India's proof coins for 1971 following an announcement by the Finance Ministry that the 10rupee specimen is to be changed after this year. The current issue will mark the last appearance of the 10rupee made of 80 per cent silver and this coin also will be reduced in size. It is now the largest of the nine coins in the set, measuring 34 mm in diameter.

title: Edwin Search Yarbrough. 3d Marries Leigh Hilton Johnson
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11Miss Leigh Hilton Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Betts Johnson Jr., was married here today to Edwin Search Yarbrough 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yarbrough Jr. of Durham, N. C.

title: Gauguin's Paradise Lost
description: Anything but a Hero

title: McCloskey Plans to Enter Oregon Presidential Primary
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 11 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey, Republican of California, announced today that he would run in Oregon's Republican Presidential primary next May 23.

title: The Lost Art of Politics
description: WASHINGTONAlong with, Adam Smith economics and the game plan, another casualty of President Nixon's wageprice freeze may have been the gentle but vital art of skillful politics.

title: U.S. REFUSES AID TO CON ED PROJECT
description: The Federal Government has refused to give aid for a Consolidated Edison Company pilot project to remove pollutants from power plant gases, despite President Nixon's proposal to Congress last June to double Federal support for such cleanup research.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: H. Ross Perot, the crewcut Texas multimillionaire, and his computer systems are in at Dominick & Dominick, Inc., and long hair, colored shirts and flared trousers are out.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  President Nguyen Van Thieu officially opened his oneman campaign for the Presidency yesterday with his opposition in disarray and effective dissent virtually, nonexistent.

title: 6 Die in Flooding in Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11 (AP)At least 26 persons have died and 26 have been reported injured in landslides and flooding caused by heavy rains in central western Japan, the police reported today. An additional 16 persons were missing.

title: Rumsfeld Heads Review Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) Donald R. Rumsfeld, counselor to the President, was designated today by President Nixon to he chairman of the Federal Property Review Board. The hoard attempts to identify Federal land that is not being used and can he turned over to state and local government, for recreational purposes.

title: 28 Seized at Rock Concert
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 11 (UPI)At least 28 persons were arrested and eight sheriff's deputies were injured last night when violence broke out in a small section of a crowd of more than 12,000 persons attending a rock concert.

title: Gillian Hatch Has Wedding
description: Miss Gillian Hatch, daughter of Robert L. Hatch, executive editor of The Nation, and Mrs. Hatch, was married in the Riverdale Presbyterian Church yesterday to Thomas Halliday Gretton of London, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. D. F. Gretton. The Rev. David D. Cockcroft performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Carol Grey E. B. Bretschger Wed in Suburb
description: HARTSDALL, N. Y., Sept. 11Miss Carol Lynne Grey was married here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church to Edward Bassett Bretschger. The Rev. Paul L. Lattimore performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Howard Bingley, a cousin of the bride's father.

title: WAR IN CAMBODIA IDLES PORT TOWN
description: KOMPONG SOM, Cambodia, Sept. 11 (UPI)War has left Kompong Som  once one of Cambodia's most prosperous cities  a seaport virtually without ships, a railhead without trains, a highway junction without traffic and a resort without tourists.

title: Brigham Young Wins, 4113, From North Texas State
CHIEF EDITOR NAMED BY ATHENEUM BOOKS
description: Simon Michael Bessie, president of Atheneum Publishers, has announced the appointment of. Herman Gollob as editor in chief of the trade book division, succeeding Richard Kluger who resigned on Wednesday.

title: Pinjara Edges Stablemate In Del Mar Handicap
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP)  Pinjara, Howard B. Heck's grass runner, edged stablemate, Makor, by half length today in the $85,700 Del Mar Handicap, a 1 3/8mile turf contest for 3yearolds and up.

title: Duke Beats Florida, 126
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 11 (AP) Duke's Steve Jones ran for 204 yards tonight to set up four field goals by Dave Wright as the Blue Devils defeated Florida, 126, in Tampa Stadium.

title: Medal of Honor Is Given By Agnew to Families of 5
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 11 (UPI)Vice President Agnew has awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously to five marines killed in Vietnam combat.

title: PAKISTANI AWAITS LEADERSHIP POST
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 11  While East Pakistan's most popular politician, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, is standing trial for treason, West Pakistan's most popular politician, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, is restively awaiting army permission to take his place in the Pakistani leadership.

title: McAnally, Expo Rookie, Tops Pirates on 6Hitter, 41, for His 9th Victory
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (UPI) Jim Fairey drove in two runs with a fifthinning double today and a rookie lefthander, Ernie McAnally, pitched a sixhitter as the Montreal Expos defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 41.

title: Reader's Report
description: After eight years of marriage to David, Emily is divorced by him sans alimony, sans children, sans everything except memories of conjugal love. The latter are strong enough to curdle promising relationships that commence in the New Hampshire town where the divorce goes back to teaching school.

title: New Autos Offer Some Unconventional Options
description: Despite the economic recession, the automobile industry is pushing ahead with a variety of unusual optional equipment that is available at extra cost and the public is buying it.indicative of popularity and predict that they will sell four times that many this year.

title: 4 Named to Jersey Panel To Plan Higher Education
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP) Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, and three others have been appointed to the New Jersey Higher Education Master Plan Commission by Gov. William T. Cahill.

title: Games People Play On Big E
description: Early in 1953, having taken unto myself a wife, I renounced the West Side IRT, the line of my youth, for the Queens branch of the IND. I have never regretted that move.

title: City Islands Fleet Starts 70Mile Race To Stratford Shoal
description: The City Island Yacht Club's 36th annual overnight race, a 70nauticalmile roundtrip to Stratford Shoal and return, began yesterday in a threefourknot southeast breeze off Big Torn Rock in Eastchester Bay. There were 41 entries competing in four sections.

title: The Nation
description: President Nixon's HertzAvis approach to the world economy keeping America No. 1undoubtedly appeals to many voters at home. But there is less enthusiasm abroad. Last weekend the country's chief allies were asked to help finance Mr. Nixon's ambition by absorbing a far greater increase in American exports than they had dreamed would be sought. Otherwise, they were told, the basic American balance of payments deficit would quadruple to an annual rate of $10billion to $12billion.

title: Council of Churches Backs Closer Tie With Catholics and Jews
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 11 The general board of the National Council of Churches, a federation of 33 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations, approved today proposals to widen radically the council's ecumenical character and to put more power in its pronouncements.

title: Market Reform
description: The Point of View expressed by Donald E. Farrar (Aug. 29) demands rebuttal in the public interest. Not once in his polemic did he express any concern for the place of the individual investor in today's institutiondominated markets. In fact, reading between the lines, he would not be concerned if institutions became even more dominant in the nation's capital markets.

title: CLOTHES ARE FUN
description: Letters:

title: Khrushchev Is Dead at 77
Interpretation Corrected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Before leaving for Canada today, the Japanese Cabinet delegation succeeded in clearing up the confusion that developed here last night over Japan's present attitude toward United States resolutions now being drafted with the aim of preventing the exclusion of Nationalist China from the United Nations.

title: AIDES AT ELMIRA DROP JOB ACTION
description: Correction officers at the Elimra, N. Y., Correctional Facility put off their plans for a work slowdown yesterday after Actong Deputy Commissioner Harold N. Butler authorized additional staff and overtime work with pay.

title: A PRECAUTION
description: To THE EDITOR: It should be reiterated that United States nationals are advised to register with our embassy when traveling in Eastern Europe. Where possible they should give the embassy a detailed itinerary. As a result of having registered with the U.S. Embassy in Warsaw during a recent visit to Poland, I was contacted about a death in my immediate family. I might add that the embassy officials expedited my return home in superb fashion. I hope that other travelers over there will keep our stations notified in case of an emergency.

title: Ancient Silk, $4.20, Takes Feature at Bay Meadows
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP)Ancient Silk, a 5yearold mare, won the $20,000 Hillsborough Handicap by a halflength today at Bay Meadows, holding off a late charge by Old Gypsy.

title: Photography
CAR KILLS WOMAN IN ALABAMA SITIN
description: BUTLER, Ala., Sept. 11 (AP) A young black woman was struck by a car and killed in this small west central Alabama town today as she took part in a sitin demonstration at an intersection, the Alabama Public Safety Director, W. L. Allen, said.

title: Metropolitan Women Golfers In Two Title Events This Week
description: Two important championships will be played this week, one in Westchester and the other in Long Island. The Women's TriCounty Golf Association sponsors the Elizabeth Wheeler memorial open championship, while a new event on the schedule will be conducted by two women's Long Island golf Associations.

title: About Pro Football
description: The first of pro football's two seasons ends tonight when the Detroit Lions play the Eagles at Philadelphia in a game to be televised nationally Channel 2 here starting at 9 o'clock. This is the last of 88 games in what has come to be called the preseason campaign. It began last July 30. Next Sunday the games will be for real as the 14week regular season begins. Although all the teams, except perhaps Baltimore, made money as record attendance totals were reached, the concept and structure of the preseason campaign is coming under criticism. Furthermore, the pro football establishment may have become so large and so unwieldy that it is incapable of change and the commissioner, Pete Rozelle, powerless to effect reform.

title: Two Aides Named at L.I.U.
description: George Barbezat and Ronald Smalls, former standout basketball players with Long Island University, have been named assistant varsity basketball coaches at their alma mater. Barbezat, 25 years old, will continue to coach the freshman team. Smalls, 25, has been an assistant freshman basketball coach.

title: FRANK W. APPLETON Sr.
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 11Frank W. Appleton Sr., who retired as a vice president of the New York Telephone Company in 1940, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 84 years old and lived at 30 Rockridge Road.

title: A Moveable Feast of Kings
description: Ah, hills and slopes of Brooklyn! I perceive you are more valuable than your owners supposed. . . . Walt Whitman

title: Basement Russian Roulette
description: For years, attempts have been made in various cities to copy Filene's famous bargain basement in Boston where goods are reduced In price every six days and the nonselling remainder is given to charity at the end of a month. However, those attempts invariably last only two weeks.

title: Medicine
TURNER RETAINS LEAD IN SAILING
Hospitals:
description: Last February a $20,000ayear Greenwich Village executive (we'll call him Wade Colsen) was told he needed a minor hernia repair job. But it was more than a month before his surgeon could find Mr. Colsen a bed in one of the city's prestigious teaching hospitals. It's high time, Mr. Colsen told his Village friends, that the Government did something about the shortage of hospital beds.

title: High Gothic in the Outback
description: In the kitchen of a small farm in an Auitralian approximation of Yoknapatawpha County, astigmatic, intense Barbara Glover prepares a syringe of antibiotic. Students of analogy will note the echo of barbarous in her first name and, perhaps, excavate from the family name as muffled lover. Thomas Keneally is constructing a complex fable, and the reader must keep his wits about him in case he muffs a level of meaning. And Barbara does throb with thwarted sexual energy. But; then, Mr. Keneally might have named her at perfect random; one of the characteristics of his sustained exercise in the baroque is a diabolical ingenuity, and it is sometimes difficult to ascertain, amongst the flux of startling words and events, what is significant and what is not.

title: Portugal's Population Drops 2 Per Cent in 1970 Census
description: LISBON, Sept. 11Drained by three colonial wars and emigration, Portugal has suffered a substantial decrease in population over the past decade.

title: What Hunch Bet Next Friday?
description: To the Editor: The Silver Blaze will be the feature race at Belmont Park Friday. Very few people knoW why the name is on the program. Here is why:

title: Mrs. MacKenzie And C. S. Clews, Architect, Wed
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 11 Mrs. Noele Doyle MacKenzie, widow of Robert MacKenzie, was married to Christopher Strawbridge Clews in a Quaker ceremony this afternoon in the Gosport Meeting House on Star Island, one of the Isles of Shoals off the New Hampshire coast.

title: Harriman Assesses Leader
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Sept. 11 (UPI)W. Averell Harriman, former United States Ambassador to Moseow, described Nikita S. Khrushchev today as man willing to compete with the United States in world dominatipn but ready to back down to avoid a nuclear war.

title: Lynne Buckley Engaged
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Sept. 11Mrs. Walter J. Buckley has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lynne Marie Buckley, to Dennis Michael Dowling, son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Dowling.

title: Odinga Rejoins Ruling Party In Kenya After Five Years
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 11 Kenya's ruling political party, the Kenya African National Union, has welcomed back to its ranks its most famous prodigal son, Oginga Odinga.

title: SWEDEN'S MUSHROOM
description: To THE EDITOR: My husband and I visited the mushroomshaped water tower at Orebro, Sweden, described in Roy Bongartz's article (Travel section, Aug. 22), this summer. Prospective tourists will be interested to know that the tower, which lies on Routes E3 and E18, is included in the itinerary of the twoclay Swedish Lakeland Tour between Stockholm and Oslo. The restaurant atop the tower is an informal cafeteria seating 275 persons. There is also a souvenir shop, an ice cream counter, and two telescopes to enhance the view from the circular balcony. The mushroom is open daily from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. June through August, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. in May and September, and 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays only in October.

title: Mrs. Mara Osis Wed Here to Donald Kurtz
description: Mrs. Mara Stoller Osis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Stoller of New York and Westhampton, L. I., was married here last night in her parents home on Sutton Place South to Donald J. Kurtz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Kurtz of Rock Hill, S. C. Rabbi James H. Perman officiated.

title: Flow of Refugees to Hong Kong From Mainland China Is Rising
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 11  More refugees are leaving China than at any time since 1962, when 60,000 streamed across the border into Hong Kong within a few weeks.

title: Revson Wins Pole Position for 210Mile CanAm Auto Race Today
description: BRAINERED, Minn., Sept. 11 With its usual form, the Englandbased McLaren racing team today swept the first two qualifying positions for tomorrow's running of the Minneapolis Tribune CanAm.

title: HARRELSON, ON 288, GAINS P.G.A. TRIALS
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Sept. 11Ken Harrelson survived the regional qualifying for the Professional Golfers Association's tour at Tanglewood Park today, posting a 72 for a 288 total, two strokes lower than he needed for the 30man cutoff.

title: His villains include the Kennedys
description: Perhaps no practicing book reviewer is so adept at inserting verbal barbs into famous and powerful men as Ronald Steel. His astringent and sparkling essays on their memoirs and literary efforts are never dull, for Mr. Steel is impatient with the cultivated illusions and pretensions of men of power. Imperialists and Other Heroes is a collection of his reviews and essays, as well as an account of his remarkably short political odyssey from the New Leader to the New York Review of Books.

title: VOLKSWAGEN FOUND UNSAFE BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) Ralph Nader urged today, that Volkwagen recall all of its three million cars to correct safety defects and said the VW Microbus is so unsafe it should be permanently barred from the road.

title: Infusion of U.S. Aid Improving Mass Transit Slightly
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10The first signs of a possible end to the decline in the quality of mass transportation in the United States are beginning to appear slowly in a few cities after decades of deterioration.

title: Ziegler's Sloop Gem Scores in Whitmore Yachting Series
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11 William Ziegler 3d's Gem, out of Noroton Yacht Club, was correctedtime winner by .0036 decimal hours, equivalent to 13 seconds, today in the third race of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual cruisingyacht series for the Whitmore Trophy. The final race of the seasonlong series on Long Island Sound will be sailed tomorrow.

title: Malays Hold Red Suspect
description: KUCHING, Malaysia, Sept. 11 (Reuters)The chief minister of the East Malaysian state of Sarawak, Haji Abdul Rahman Yakub, said today that security forces had arrested 111 suspected Communist terrorists and sympathizers.

title: Poll Finds Drop in Majority's Opposition to Busing
description: The overwhelming majority of Americans continue to oppose busing of pupils to integrate the schools, but opposition has declined since 1970, particularly among certain key groups in the population, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: R & D. Lag
description: Charles A. Anderson's acute observations (Aug. 22) on the threat to American technology through curbs being placed on research and development should be takers one step further.

title: Texas Concedes Illegality Of Voter Residency Law
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 11The Attorney General of Texas, Crawford Martin, has filed petition in Federal District Court conceding the unconstitutionality of a new residency restriction on the registration of voters under the age 21.

title: It's a cozy kind of look
description: When American designers talk about sportswear, they don't mean bathing suits or tennis dresses. They mean things like skirts and shirts, vest and sweaters. That's what they're showing for this

title: Jazz Buffs Are in Favor On Long Island Radio
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 11Jazz fans on Long Island who have had to depend on Ed Beach's radio program, Just Jazz, on WRVRFM in Manhattan, can now find more of their music on WCWP, the FM station at C. W. Post College.

title: Julie I. von Sternberg Is a Bride
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 11Miss Julie Iva von Sternberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jule Robert von Sternberg of Garden City and Palm Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Henry Lafayette Collins 3d of Berwyn, Pa., son of Mrs. Charles Edward Pacaud of Berwyn and Somerset Bridge, Bermuda, and the late Mr.Collins Jr.

title: Philae M. Carver Married to a Broker
description: WOODSIDE, Calif., Sept. 11  Miss Philae Margaret Carver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George William Douglas Carver, was married here today to Warren Arthur Knight Jr., son of Mrs. William Scott Wallace of Boston and Mr. Knight of Sarasota, Fla.

title: SmallBoat Men Object to Pollution Curbs
Europe Between the Wars
The New Man At the Met
description: THE scene is a rococo, whiteandgold reception room on the second floor of the Royal Opera House in Stockholm, Sweden. The time is March 25, 1971, and the cast includes Seved Apelqvist, whitehaired chairman of the Royal Opera Board; Goeran Gentele, general manager of the company, and Bertil Bokstedt, Gentele's planning chief and newly appointed successor. Surrounded by reporters and photographers, the three men smile into the harsh television lights as shutters click and cameras whir. Mr. Apelqvist announces the official transfer of authority as Gentele and Bokstedt gaze at him with the expressions of blank interest that public figures refor ceremonial occasions.

title: Vikings and Raiders Picked to Win Titles
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 11 (UPI)The Minnesota Vikings and Oakland Raiders, were established today by the Derby Sports Book of Las Vegas as the early 21 favorites to win the National Football League's Conference Championships. The early line:

title: WASHINGTON ROUTS SANTA BARBARA, 657
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 11 (AP)  Washington's Huskies, stung by an early touchdown, crushed the University of California at Santa Barbara today, 657.

title: Ronan Charges Some on Subway Panel With Political Avarice
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority charged yesterday that there had been distortions and outright lies for political purposes by some participants in talks to save the 30cent fare.

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR: The proposal by Professors Galbraith, Kuh and Thurow to legally require large corporations to promote individuals to upper level management positions on the basis of race and sex is an example of a new sort of racism, almost as pernicious as the older form, which is becoming increasingly prevalent. The assumption is that people should be given jobs, promotions, or whatever on the basis of the color of their skin, a characteristic which Galbraith et at. admit has no relation to job performance.

title: Ricki Schwartz Fiancee
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Sept. 11  Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Schwartz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ricki Schwartz, to Barrie Kellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Kellner of Miami Beach, Fla. Miss Schwartz, whose father is general manager of Herman's World of Sporting Goods in New York, was graduated from the University of Miami. Her fianc is an alumnus of C. W. Post College.

title: Miss Robinson Engaged To James jay Secor 3d
description: PERRYSBURG, Ohio, Sept, 11The engagement of Miss Christine Lawrence Robinson to James Jay Secor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Secor Jr., was announced here today by Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Davis Robinson 3d, parents of the future bride. The date of the formal announcement was chosen to coincide with the wedding anniversaries of the Robinsons and the Secors. Both couples were married in 1948,

title: Josephine A. Merck Engaged to Peter McAdoo Coy
description: FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. George Wall Merck of Far Hills and Tryon N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Josephine Amy Merck, to Peter McAdoo Coy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Meldrim Coy or Perrysburg, Ohio. The wedding is planned for Oct. 16.

title: Robert Raggio Weds Miss Alice McAdams
Letters to the Editor
description: The decline of singleroom occupancy housing on Manhattan's West Side does not signal a concomitant decline of singleroom occupants. It means only that the West Side has become again a more fashionable neighborhood, and so less desirable uses are being replaced. (The number of singleroom occupants in New York City is dependent on quite different factors.) Such persons are now to be found in other, declining areas of the city (for instance, the south Bronx).

title: Explorations
description: To the Editor: During World War II, Somerset Maugham, when asked Do you have any moral scruples? is said to have replied (with what I imagine as a smirk) Just now I have. Because of the war, you know. Save mankind, and all that sort of thing.

title: SIX PRIMARIES SET FOR CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 11Democratic mayoral primaries are scheduled on Sept. 22 in Connecticut's six large citiesHartford, New Haven, Bridgeport, Stamford, Waterbury and New Britain.

title: Grant Adams Service Set
description: A memorial service for Grant H. Adams, executive director of the United Hospital Fund from 1957 until his death on Au. 24, will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow at Alumni Hall in the New York University Medical Center, First Avenue near 30th Street.

title: MISS MEIER TAKES THE LEAD IN LOUISE
description: The New York City Opera's production of Louise, Charpentier's affectionate and sentimental hymn to Paris, is far from perfect, but at least it offers a chance to hear the work from time to time.

title: Elizabeth Lyon Fentress Is Bride
description: RADNOR, Pa., Sept. 11 Miss Elizabeth Lyon Fentress, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, James Fentress of Bryn Mawr and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Lieut. (t.) James Barton Goodwin, U.S.N.R., son of Mrs. Richard Wright Simmons of Lake Forest, III., and Andrew Jackson Goodwin Jr. of Anniston, Ala.

title: Drexel Eleven Hires DiMidio
description: Drexel University has signed Tony DiMidio, former professional football star to the position of defensive line coach. Before his appointment, DiMidio spent six years in professional football as a defensive tackle and taught school in the offseason.

title: UConns Trail in Victories But Lead League in Titles
description: STORRS, Conn., Sept. 11 (AP)The University of Massachusetts heads the Yankee Conference in football victories, but the University of Connecticut has held the crown more often than any other conference team.

title: WAGEPRICE UNIT TOLD TO PREPARE A 2DSTAGE PLAN
