description: TOKYO, Sept. 11If Japan decides not to cosponsor resolutions keeping Taiwan in the United Nations, the blame lies squarely with President Nixon, a Government source here commented today.

title: Thank You for The Giant Sea Turtle
description: For a couple of years now New York magazine has been setting its readers such tasks as concocting unusual greeting cards (vide the book title), famous first words, shortest book of the year (The Wit and Wisdom of Jacqueline Susann). Over 700 of these entries (some inspired: Anonymous Bosch, Germany's Unknown Soldier) have been collected by the contest's editor, Mary Ann Madden. Miss Madden contributes a funny introduction, which indicates that, if she chose, she could be her own most puissant competitor.

title: The Education of a Brooklyn Son
description: I tell myself, You are far away now and it was long ago and you were young then and you must avoid nostalgia. Also to be avoided is the classic American fatherson syndrome. The old man must not say, When I was your age, I walked through the snow each morning to get to school. Though to tell the truth, in those days of Brooklyn College, along the sprawling circuits of the transportation system of the borough, many of the students did endure the urban equivalent of those legendary wintry marches toward knowledge.

description: MONTEVIDEOIt began last Sunday evening when two groups of young, wellmannered and heavily armed men took over two little homes that stand back to back on a block next to Punta Carretas prison here.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The central question which underlies all the specific issues worrying the public is how to restore the legitimacy of the nation's institutions.

title: Deeds Replaces Hill as Head Of Pacific Coast League
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (UPI)Cameron S. Deeds, former athletic director at Los Angeles State, has been named interim commissioner of the Pacific Coast Athletic Association.

title: Canada Captures Tuna Cup As U.S. Finishes Second
description: YARMOUTH, Nova Scotia, Sept. 11, (Canadian Press)  Canada, host of the International Tuna Cup match for 22 years, won the event for the first time today. The Canadians landed three fish during the fiveday event with a total weight of 1,972 pounds. Scoring provides one point for each pound of fish caught. An additional 200 points for the largest number of fish caught gave the Canadians 2,172 points.

title: Avoiding a Fiasco
description: The Cabinetlevel conference between the United States and Japan engendered angry argument and wound up with both Governments still far apart on their trade and monetary disputes.

title: MRS. ROBERT HODGES
description: Mrs. Barbara Wyckoff Hodges, who was cited by the Library of Congress for her 30 years service in transcribing books into Braille, died Friday on a visit to Kalamazoo, Mich She was the wife of Robert W. Hodges, director of America House, a New York crafts shop, and lived at 23 Edgewood Road, Summit, N. J.

title: GRAMBLING TAKES BENEFIT CONTEST
description: An exuberant 65,055 fans, who showed no partiality as they cheered both teams, sat through more than three hours of wild college football as Grambling defeated Morgan State, 3113, in the Whitney M. Young Memorial Classic at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Nikita S. Khrushchev
description: Nikita Khrushchev died a second time yesterday. His first, a political death, took place in 1964 when he was unceremoniously ousted from power, plunging overnight from the status of one of the world's key leaders to an unperson in the land, he had ruled. His continued disgrace seven years later was emphasized by the fact that most Soviet citizens first learned of his passing from broadcasts to the Soviet Union by Radio Liberty and other foreign transmitters.

title: DEBATE OVER GUNS TO REOPEN TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The gunlaw reformers in Con gress begin a new campaign tomorrow to rid the country of the millions of cheap pistols that are being used to kill ever increasing numbers of Americans.

title: Hope Marks 33d Year As Performer on N.B.C.
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 12 (UPI)Bob Hope celebrates his 33d year with the Na tional Broadcasting Company network tomorrow night with a television special in which the comedian is surrounded by 18 beautiful girls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Whether President Nixon's new eco nomic program will put the brakes on inflation, only time will tell, but the degree of sacrifice being asked of various income groups can easily be determined.

title: Nixon to See Businessmen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  President Nixon is to meet tomorrow with 11 business leaders as he continues his con sultations on the course to take after the wageprice freeze ends. He also summoned his Cabinet, along with members wives, to an 8:30 A.M. meeting to talk about the economy. He will meet with the businessmen at 10:30 A.M.

title: Rome Daily American Is Changing Owners
description: ROME, Sept. 12The Daily American of Rome, Italy's only Englishlanguage news paper, announced today that its publisher, Robert H. Cun ningham, had sold out to an international group.

title: 3 Policemen Save Dog Caught in River's Tide
description: A black and tan German shepherd dog was carried a mile upstream in the East River by the strong tide be fore the three policemen aboard the launch Detective John Pollins managed to res cue him.

title: Stocking the Larder on Harvest Time Drive in the Country
description: ANCRAM, N. Y.The ap ple harvest is starting in Columbia County and else where in upstate New York and the farm stands are bursting with gloriously red early McIntosh and other apples, as well as pears, corn, squash, tomatoes, pep pers and cucumbers, all bloomingly fresh.

title: ATTICA PRISONERS WIN 28 DEMANDS, BUT STILL RESIST
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Monday, Sept. 13Rebellious Inmates who last Thursday seized the Attica Cor rectional Facility yesterday won 28 concessions they had de manded from the state, but they were stubbornly holding out for complete amnesty from criminal prosecution and the ouster of the prison superin tendent, Vincent R. Mancusi.

title: MLR MAY BALK AT MEDINA TRIAL
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 12First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. will be advised by his attorney not to testify unless he is threatened by sanctions when he takes the stand tomorrow at Fort McPherson in the My

title: 19 Children Die in Bus Crash
description: BRONKHORSTSPRUIT, South Africa, Sept. 12 (Reuters) Nineteen black African school children were killed yesterday in a collision between their bus and a truck.

title: Strain of the Vietnam War Weakens Army Elsewhere
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The tremendous strain placed on the United States Army by the Vietnam war has left many of its units stationed elsewhere not only demoralized but also unfit for heavy combat.

title: Stalin Descendant Baptized
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (AP)  Stalin's granddaughter was baptized today by Archbishop Iakevos, head of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America. Olga Peters, 4monthold daughter of Svet lana and Wesley Peters, was baptized at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church.

title: MONETARY FAULTS CONCEDED BY TIP.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12The International Monetary Fund conceded, in effect, today that the world monetary system was not in good shape prior to the recent dramatic actions of Pres ident Nixon that will probably fundamentally alter the system.

title: Marine Midland Appoints
description: Marine Midland BankNew York has appointed Alfred R. Heath as senior vice president, development and planning. Mr. Heath will continue as president of 250 Park Avenue Corpora tion, which operates the Marine Midland Bank Building.

title: Strike Ends at Maine Mill
description: MADAWASKA, Me., Sept. 12 (AP)Fraser, Ltd., and four union locals signed a threeyear contract today, ending a nine week strike that had halted production at the paper mill here and that at one point was marked by violence. The vio lence erupted Aug. 9 when an angry crowd of strikers and sympathizers pelted state troop ers with rocks, overturned a police cruiser and destroyed a locomotive that was en route to the Fraser yards to haul a trainload of paper.

title: 2 UNIONS ARE KEY IN PAPERS STRIKE
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12Al though the printers union, which went on strike against The Pittsburgh Press and The PostGazette on May 14, has ratified a new contract, new labor problems continued to plague the city's daily news papers last week.

title: NEWSPAPER REOPENS EGYPTIAN SPY CASE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 An Egyptian editor, now serv ing life imprisonment for spy ing for the United States, has stated that he was falsely ac cused by a former Egyptian in telligence chief and that he had kept in touch with the Ameri cans because the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser, asked him for information about activities of the United States Embassy in Cairo.

title: Peterson Takes Vienna Race And Increases Point Lead
description: VIENNA, Sept. 12 (AP) Ronnie Peterson of Sweden won the eighth European For mula Two Trophy car race to day at the TullnLangenlebarn Airport course. Peterson raised his point to total to 42., bolster ing his wide lead for the For mula Two driving title.

title: COODY CARDS 73, WINS GOLF SERIES BY SHOT WITH 141
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 12 Despite a 7 at one hole and a rally by Jack Nicklaus that carried him into a momentary lead, Charles Coody of Abilene, Tex., won the World Series of Golf today and its $50,000 first prize by one stroke.

title: Ben Heller Weds Mrs. Sedgewick
description: Ben Heller, art collector and private art dealer and a leader in the textile industry, married Mrs. Patricia Rosen wald Sedgewick yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Morrow in East Hampton, L. I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Lloyd Tennenbaum.

title: City's Schools Open Today Under Pinch of Budget Cut
description: The city's public schools will start the new academic year this morning with more pupils but fewer teachers than last fall and beset by many major problems and uncertainties.

title: 3 Steps Toward China Asked for Japan
description: TAKASAKI, Japan, Sept. 12 Yasuhiro Nakasone, the for mer Defense Minister, put for ward today three requirements for normalization of relations between Tokyo and Peking: Recognition of the People's Re public as the legitimate repre sentative of China, giving sub stance to this recognition by allocating China's seat in the United Nations Security Coun cil to Peking, and acknowledg ment hat Taiwan is part of China.

title: French Expect Output Of Champagne to Drop
description: PARIS, Sept. 12 (Reuters) Poor weather may halve the production of. French champagne this year after a harvest that is expected to fall below last year's record yield, officials said yesterday.

title: Jobs in City Show a Decrease For 16th Month in Succession
description: For the 16th month in a row, jobs in New York City have fallen below the levels of the preceding year, Herbert Bien stock, regional director of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statis tics, reported yesterday.

title: Israel Takes Action To End Labor Strife With Sterner Laws
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 12In a move to halt a wave of strikes by civil servants, Israel's labor dominated Government decided today to propose legislation giving the force of law to labor agreements in state and public services.

title: Tennis Rained Out; Will Resume Today
description: Rain postponed the pro gram in the United States Open tennis championships for a second consecutive day yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your Sept. 2 editorial Equal Rights to Learn, you commend the principle of equalizing financial sup port for public schools. In effect you support the new California Supreme Court ruling, as you rightly underscore the schooling gap between rich and poor localities, question the sacred cow of school finance from property tax and call for full statefinancing of public schools.

title: Allen L. Mayerson, Taught Insurance at U. of Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 12 Allen L. Mayerson, professor of insurance and actuarial mathematics at the University of Michigan since 1956, died last night of cancer. His age was 46.

title: 2 Held in Fire Fatal to 4
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UPI) Two brothers were in custody today after being charged with arson and murder in connection with an apartment house fire that killed four children a week ago. The suspects, Leroy Tisley, and his brother, William, 22 years old, were to be arraigned tomorrow.

title: Sudan Ends Steiner Trial
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Sept. 12 UPIThe trial of Rolf Steiner, a West German mer cenary accused of waging war against the Sudanese Govern ment, ended today after 41 days. The verdict of the mili tary tribunal will be announced after approval by the head of state, Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, but no date for the announce ment was set. Mr. Steiner faces a possible death sentence.

title: Egyptian Constitution Wins 99.9% of Vote
description: CAIRO, Sept. 12Egyptian voters have given the coun try's new constitution over whelming approval, Mam douh Salem, the Minister of the Interior, announced to day.

title: Officials Hope to Expand Role of the World's Museums

title: Joe Jordan, Composer, Dies; Ragtime Piano Player, 89
description: TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 12 (UPI)Joe Jordan, a ragtime piano artist and composer who played with many stars of his era, including Louis Armstrong, died here yesterday. His age was 89.

title: Man in the News
description: Vincent R. Mancusi, whose removal as superintendent of Attica Correctional Facility is one of the dernands of the re bellious inmates, has been in what is called correctional administration in New York State for many years, having worked his way up from guard.

title: August Money Growth Slowest for 7 Months
description: The rate of growth in the nation's money supply slowed sharply during August to an an nual rate of about 3 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

title: Personal Finance: Rates on Insurance
description: Thousands of people all over the country are getting bills from their insurance man asking for more money despite the fact that Presi dent Nixon has imposed a 90day freeze on price rises.

title: NIXON REAFFIRMS STAND ON RELIEF
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 12 President Nixon sought today to assure the nation's Gover nors, who have been strong supporters of his welfare re form proposal, that he had not given up on the program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon has found a clever way to scale down the war for Ameri cans: escalate the bombing. Although not very novel, it works quite well.

title: Virginians Softball Victors
description: CLEVELAND, Sept 12 (AP)  The Pile Drivers of Virginia Beach won the national slow pitch softball championship last night, beating the Detroit Little Caesars, the defending cham pions, by 94.

title: Miss Lacey T. Neuhaus Bride Of Jan McD. Warner, Composer
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 12Miss Lacey Thompson Neuhaus, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Charles Oakes and Philip Ross Neuhaus, both of Hous ton, was married here last night to Jan MacDonald War ner, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Miles Warner of Southport, Conn., and Barbados.

title: Vietnamese War Brides: Happiness Mixed With Pain
description: They move silently and anonymously through the streets of New York, some times saying they are Chinese if any body asks because they don't want yet another hassle about the war in Vietnam.

title: Bridge: U.S. World Championship Play Coming to New York Next Week
description: The semifinal playoff match that will help to determine the 1972 United States World Championship Team will be played here next week and will offer New York enthusi asts a rare opportunity for watching the experts in ac tion when the chips are down.

title: Soviet Announces Khrushchev Death in Cool Language
description: MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 13 Sovite authorities this morn ing broke their silence and an nounced with sorrow the death on Saturday of former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, who will be buried later today without full state honors.

title: TIMES IS CRITICIZED ON PENTAGON PAPERS
description: Leslie H. Gelb, coordinator of the Pentagon team that put together the secret study of the war in Vietnam, wrote in this week's Life magazine that he had two serious criticisms of The New York Times articles dealing with the study but that the articles were largely a fair representation.

title: Red Lands Cool to Khrushchev Death
description: Communist countries appeared yesterday to be slowly inform ing their people of the death on Saturday of Nikita S. Khrushchev, with short notices in newspapers and brief reports on television and radio.

title: Police Chiefs to Hear Agnew
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)Vice President Agnew will give the keynote speech Sept. 27 at the annual confer ence of the International Asso ciation of Chiefs of Police, the association said today. Other speakers scheduled for the threeday conference are Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Jerry V. Wilson, chief of police of Washington.

title: PUPIL AID PROJECT AUDITED BY STATE
description: A stateaided program for disadvantaged children, part of a teachers union contract, had a slow start because of in consistent directives and un certainty by the old city Board of Education in its first 19689 school year, State Controller Arthur Levitt reported yester day.

title: A DOZEN CONTESTS ENLIVEN PRIMARY
description: A dozen significant contests highlight a generally quiet pri mary election in the metropoli tan area tomorrow. Yesterday Mayor Lindsay endorsed Family Court Judge Millard L. Mido nick for the Democratic nomina tion for Manhattan Surrogate. His support of the reform candidate was his first such act since switching party alle giances last month.

title: Pollution Hearings Set Today
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  The House Public Works Committee opens a final round of hearings tomorrow on legis lation for the control of water pollution. Representative John A. Blatnik, Democrat of Minne sota, the chairman, said today he hoped to have an effective bill on the House floor early next month.

title: SAN DIEGO IS SPLIT ON CONVENTION AID
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 12A $400,000 guarantee by a sub sidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration has come under the scrutiny of a citizens group that is seeking to block the use of city tax funds for the Re publican National Convention in San Diego next year.

description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Anne Elise Berntsen Is Married
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 12In Christ's Episcopal Church here at noon today, Miss Anne Elise Berntsen, daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl A. Berntsen, was married to John B. Stanbury Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanbury of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Wendell Phillips performed the ceremony.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities: President and Mrs. Nixon were hosts at their 32d Sunday worship session at the White House.

title: Shop Talk
description: It had to happen. What with the cities of the world a sea of blue jeans and Levistrauss & Co. getting a Special Coty Award this year, somebody had to dream up a fragrance called Blue Jeans. The house of Shulton, feeling that there has been a generation gap in the perfume business, is giv ing the Now generation its very own scent. Middleaged copy writers are saying things like funky, groovy and pow to describe it and Shulton hopes to settle once and for all what a young scent is supposed to be.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Roundup:
description: Wilbur Wood, a relief pitcher turned starter, be came the first Chicago White Sox pitcher in seven years to win 20 games yesterday as he defeated the Royals, 30, at Kansas City on a five hitter.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HOCKENHEIM, Germany, Sept. 12 (AP)Frank Garner of England, driving a Lola T800, won the Formula 5000 today, beating a turbine Lotus of Emerson Fittipalidi of Brazil by only 5.2 seconds.

title: Revlon and Hulme Finish 1,2 for McLaren Team in CanAm at Donnybrooke
description: BRAINERD, Minn., Sept. 12  The McLaren team of Peter Revson and Denis Hulme turned in their familiar onetwo finish today in the Minneapolis TribuneCanAm of 210 miles over Donnybrooke Speedway. With the field's only two com petitive cars knocked out of contention early in the day, it was one of the team's easiest victory's of the year.

title: Television
description: A good many people, in the television industry and on its periphery, are insisting that the word for the new season starting this week is change. That bit of bluster is, in another word, non sense.

title: Arts Abroad
description: STOCKHOLMThe house at Drottninggatan 85 is up for sale and is likely to be the latest victim in the re building program that has been in progress in central Stockholm during the last 10 years. For Swedes and oth ers, Drottninggatan 85 has a special significance. Known as The Blue Tower, it was the last dwelling place of August Strindberg. It was in this tall, bour goisie house with its charac teristic tower  like construc tion that the dramatist spent his last years during the first decade of the century. And it was here that his last, symbolistic dramas ripened as he directed his fervent campaigns against national ism, the cult of Charles XII and of Sven Hedin through his biting newspaper articles.

title: 6.5% JOBLESS RATE FEARED BY PROXMIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)Senator William Prox mire, chairman of the Con gressional Joint Economic Com mittee, said today that Presi dent Nixon's economic strategy might lead to unemployment of 6.5 per cent through next year.

title: COCKER SPANIEL IS BEST IN SHOW
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 12The Westchester Ken nel Club has been staging shows for half a century, but few were held under more adverse conditions than the 54th today.

title: Daniel J. Plaine, Lawyer, Weds Lloyd R. Leva
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept 12  Miss Lloyd Rose Leva, research assistant to Repre sentative Sidney R. Yates of Illinois, and Daniel Jeffrey Plaine, a Washington lawyer, were married here at noon today on the front lawn of the home of the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Marx Leva. Rabbi Joshua Haber man of the Washington He brew Congregation officiated.

title: Man Listens for Life on Worlds Afar
description: BY URAKAN, U.S.S.R., Sept. 11  This week, for the first time since life originated on this planet, its most intelli gent species met at an inter national conference to con sider the possibility of com munication with intelligent life on other worlds.

title: Korvette Adding to Its Management
description: The $600million Korvette discount chain, which in slightly more than two de cades has thrust itself up between Macy's and Abra ham & Straus to become one of New York's three largest retailers, has named present and former key executives of both these concerns to its new management team.

title: CAPITAL MARKETS SCANNING FUTURE
description: The bond market, disappoint ed late last week by the lack of specific postfreeze proposals in President Nixon's address to Congress, enters this week in a more skeptical mood than it has shown in a month.

title: Commonwealth Meets Today Today
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  The 17th Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference opens here tomor row. The security of the Indian Ocean and Southheast Asia is the leading item on the agenda. A total of 144 delegates from 25 countries will attend the fiveday meeting, which is open to all members of the British Commonwealth with democratic legislatures.

title: NIXON'S POPULARITY PUT AT 49% IN POLL
description: President Nixon's popularity rating continues to hover near 50 per cent approval in two national polls taken since he announced his new economic program on Aug. 15, the Gallup Poll said yesterday.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater at Kennedy Hall
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 For the American Ballet The ater, it was home at last, so to speak.

title: Arnold Schlanger Marries Mrs. Berg
description: Mrs. Barbara Berg and Arnold Geoffrey Schlanger were married here yesterday afternoon in Temple Shaaray Tefila by Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum.

title: Trading Partners of U. S Hurt by Import Surcharge
description: Most of the United States main trading partners have been hurt in some degree by the international measures primarily the 10 per cent sur charge on importsincluded in President Nixon's economic program.

title: Open Letter To John B. Connally
description: Dear Secretary Connally: I understand that you have been given general responsibility for the implementation of the President's new program to halt the rise in prices and reduce unemployment. Since I had similar role in World War II, it oc curred to me that you might find the following comments useful.

title: Nagle of Australia Leads Boros in, World Senior Golf
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 12 (AP)Kel Nagle of Australia took a 5up lead over Julius Boros of the United States in the world professional senior golf championship today as driving rainstorm forced sus pension of play after 13 holes.

title: Colon Wins 3Mile Race
description: Tony Colon of New York, running won a threemile cross country race yesterday con ducted by Road Runners Club of New York at Van Cortlandt Park. Colon, in beating Don Rowe of the New York Athletic Club by 90 yards was timed in 15 minutes 46.2 seconds.

title: HIGH BRITISH AIDE ARRIVES IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Sept. 12The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, arrived in Cairo tonight on a threeday mission to scout opportunities for breaking the deadlock between Egypt and Israel.

title: Suspect Dies in Accident
description: BELFAST, Sept. 12 (UPI)A suspected member of the out lawed Irish Republican Army electrocuted himself today while attempting to pull down a power pylon damaged in an earlier I.R.A. attack, the police said.

title: Today's Doormen Are Guards, Mixing Charm and Alertness
description: He is polite, friendly, cheer ful. He knows his tenants names. He knows his tenants regular guests. He even knows his tenants dogs. But Wil liam Adrian, an East Side doorman, has another attri bute that, as he sees it, is at least as important to his job as any of the others: his size.

title: New Study Presents Hirohito as Militarist
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Emperor Hirohito, long consid ered by most Western histori ans as having been a passive figurehead in Japan's road to aggression and war in the nineteenthirties and forties, is described in a new book as a powerful autocratic protagon ist of the expansion program.

title: Austere School Opening
description: As the citys schools open for more than a million pupils today, the official mood is far from jubilant. The vast system and its decentralized community districts must operate under conditions of budget austerity; staff reductions, particularly in elementary school teaching positions, constitute a threat to the quality of instruc tion. Perhaps the most serious risk is that some of the gains in reading, laboriously achieved in the last two years, may be erased.

title: Advertising:
description: Another famous name in beer will be showing up of ficially on cans of malt liquor today, as Miller Malt Liquor goes to market in the sunny South.

title: Arab Spies Said to Join Mafia In Kidnapping Attempt in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 12  Italian au thorities are worrying about the activities of Arab secret agents in this country.

title: BOURBON IS VICTOR IN PRIX ROYAL OAK
description: PARIS, Sept. 12Bourbon, a colt who was a disappointment in the Epsom Derby, won the $155,240 Prix Royal Oak, a race often used as a prep for the Arc de Triomphe, at Longchamp today.

title: 12 Die in Ceylon Bus Plunge
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 12 (AP) A bus plunged down a 100foot precipice today at Agraptatana, killing 12 persons and injuring 50.

title: CITY RELIEF ROM NEARING PLATEAU
description: The growth in New York City's relief rolls appears to have reached a plateau, Jule M. Sugarman, Human Re sources Administrator, sug gested yesterday in releasing a report showing only 838 more persons were added during July.

title: Puerto Ricans Check Jersey Farm Camps
description: WOODSTOWN. N. J., Sept. 12A special legislative in vestigating committee from Puerto Rico this weekend saw several squalid migrant farmworker camps in which laborers complained bitterly of working and living condi tions and a lack of adequate medical care.

title: HOUSE UNIT TO ACT ON CONSUMER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Congress is bracing for re newed controversy over an is sue that has provoked sharp division between consumer ad vocates and business.

title: Setback for the E.P.A.
description: In the light of the sound job William D. Ruckelshaus has been doing as head of the new Environmental Protec tion Agency, his recent choice of regional coordinators is a jolting disappointment. Career men temporarily charge of the areas administered from Denver, Atlanta and Boston have been replaced with appointees whose chief qualification appears to be their political appeal on Capitol Hill.

title: Roundup:
description: The torrid Los Angeles Dodgers and the tottering San Francisco Giants scored victories yesterday before the opening of their crucial twogame series tonight in San Francisco that could settle the National League Western Division race.

title: Miss Levine Married
description: Miss Margaret Joan Levine and Robert Fagenson, gradu ates of Syracuse University, were married in the Ver sailles Suite at the St. Regis Sheraton yesterday by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Levine of Har rison, N. Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Fagenson of New York and Deal, N.J.

title: RED CHINA FORMS ECONOMICS BODY
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 12A new Ministry of Economic Af fairs has been added to the growing number of Govern ment organs in Communist China.

title: City Working on Improvements Near Yankee Stadium
description: The city has begun moving to renovate highways and streets and to create new park ing space for thousands of autos in the area around Yan kee Stadium, meeting some of the conditions set by the Yan kees owners before they agree to remain in the Bronx.

title: SovietRumanian Friction Fades
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 11The Soviet Union's summer propa ganda campaign against Ru mania has apparently run its course, according to Rumanian and foreign observers here.

title: No Austerity for School Buses
description: If the national freeze on wages and prices is to be effective in curbing inflation, it must be enforced both vigorously and broadly. By this standard, the President's Cost of Living Council seems fully justified in refusing to allow a whopping 40 per cent jump in the fees private bus companies seek to charge the, city for transporting about 100,000 schoolchildren. There may be special circumstances that do require exemptions to a policy that should apply broadly to everybody, but this dubious in the case of these bus companies.

title: Ecuador Team Turns Back Hapoel, 32, in Soccer Here
description: Emelec of Ecuador rallied in the second half to defeat Hapoel of Israel, 32, yester day at Randalls Island Stadium.

title: Muskie View Attacked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  The Republican National Committee accused Senator Ed mund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, today of shifting right ward on the civil rights issue by declaring that a Presidential ticket listing a Negro as Vice Presidential candidate would probably lose. In its newsletter Monday, the committee said that Mr. Muskie was not only relegating Negroes to second place in his party, but was also characterizing the White Amer ican electorate as bigoted.

title: Laurel Brandt Is Wed
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Sept. 12Miss Laurel Helen Brandt and Steven Klepper were married here today at the home of the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Brandt, by State Supreme Court Justice Arnold Frai man. Mr. Klepper is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent A. Klepper, of Roslyn Heights. The bride will be graduated from Cornell University with a B.A. degree in December. Her husband, who holds a B.A. from Cornell, class of 69, did graduate work of the University of Michigan. He is continuing his studies in economics at Cornell.

title: Steelers Win, 203, Handing Giants Their 6th Loss in Row
description: The final score was Pitts burgh Steelers 20, New York Giants 3, and the final tally for the exhibition schedule was six defeats in six games, but yes terday's game at Yankee Sta dium introduced some real ele ments of hope into the dismal Giant picture.

title: ROLAND DE VAUX, ARCHEOLOGIST, 68
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 12The Rev. Roland de Vaux, head of the French Ecole Biblique, Jerusalem's Biblical and archeo logical school, died Friday at the age of 68. He had lived here for the last 20 years.

title: Rioting in Londonderry
description: BELFAST, Sept. 12 (AP) Savage street, rioting broke out in Londonderry today and troops fired nausea gas to drive back a mob storming an army post after the funeral of a 3yearold boy run over by a British Army truck Thursday.

title: Chess:
description: A 23board exhibition at the Manhattan. Chess Club was given by Florin Gheor ghiu, the chess champion of Rumania. He posted a 203 score, with 17 victories and six draws.

title: Rangel Discovers His Campaign Against Drugs Is Bearing Results
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Representative Charles B. Rangel was surprised when President Nixon telephoned him a few weeks ago, but not nearly so excited as his secretary, who exclaimed to the rest of the Rangel office: I just had the President of the United States on hold!

title: EASTERN RITES HELD NO LONGER HERETIC
description: VIENNA, Sept. 12Roman Catholic and other theologians meeting here have agreed that the Eastern churches should no longer be considered heretical by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Marcia Riklis Married Here
description: Miss Marcia Riklis, (laugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Meshulam Riklis, was married in her parents townhouse here yes terday to Benjamin Kletter, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Kletter of Jerusalem, Israel. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Avraham Soltes.

title: WET TRACK CRASH IS FATAL TO REISCH
description: IMOLA, Italy, Sept. 12 Klaus Reisch, a 29year old Austrian driver, was injured fa tally today when his Alfa Ro meo skidded off a rainslick track and burst into flames dur ing an international auto race.

title: Illinois Crash Kills Eight
description: GLADSTONE, Ill., Sept. 12 (UPI)Eight persons, including six members of one family, were killed today in the head on collision of two cars on a curve on U.S. Route 34 a mile southwest of here.

title: AIRLINES SCORED IN NEW ENGLAND
description: DURHAM, N. H., Sept. 12 Air service in northern New England has come under bitter attack in a public hearing be fore the aviation subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Com mittee.

title: Isabel Minard Wed in Two Rites
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 12Miss Isabel Sara Minard, an account supervisor with SSC & B Advertising, Inc., in New York, and Norton Gar finkle, president of the Arcata Research Corporation in New York were married here to day in two religious cere monies.

title: SIDNEY KOMAR
description: LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Sept. 12  Sidney Komar, president of Charles Komar & Sons, South Amboy, manufacturers of women's underwear, died today at his home. He was 62 years old and lived at 28 Pine Drive.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Politicians measure other politicians, to a large degree, in terms of the discretionary powers they wield. By such standards, Howard J. Sam uels, president of the Off track Betting Corporation, is indeed a powerful figure. Mr. Samuels controls a pay roll of $1million a month, which is expect ed to double by next April with an increase in the number of employes to 2,500 from 1,300. He also controls $1.5million in leases the figure was never before made publicfor 48 horse parlors and the corporation's head quarters.

title: CAPT. GEORGE CAMPBELL
description: Capt. George W. Campbell, U.S.N., retired, who was assist ant director of Navy public relations during World War II, died of a heart attack yester day in his home at 40 East 10th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: Lazar Says All Cabs Will Be Licensed
description: Taxi Commissioner Michael J. Lazar said yesterday that the socalled gypsy cab industry would be licensed in New York City even though such a step could materially decrease the value of existing taxicab medal lions.

title: Gowon Gains Stature, But Nigeria's Troubles Mount
description: LAGOS, Nigeria. Sept. 12 In the 20 months since the end of Nigeria's bloody civil war, Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon has become more and more of an international figure, but his problems at home remain se vere.

title: Law Professor Is Named Board Chairman of Aspira
description: A son followed his father in Puerto Rican selfhelp leader ship here yesterday, with an nouncement of the election of Jose A. Cabranes, 30yearold international lawyer, as board chairman of Aspira of New York.

title: TINAJERO MAKES U.S. DEBUT TODAY
description: Is Tinajero another won der horse from Puerto Rico, or is he for real? The 3year old gray colt makes his Belmont Park debut today and is not expected to be heavily backed by the cynical New York racing fans.

title: HOPE FOR ACCORD ON DOLLAR IS DIM
description: LONDON, Sept. 12Finance ministers of the Western world's richest nations meet in London this week with only poor prospects for resolving the trade and currency crisis pre cipitated by the United States.

title: 3 Wounded in Coast Gunfight Identified as Black Panthers
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI) Three Negroes wounded in a gun battle with the police have been identified as Black Pan thers, the police said today.

title: ACCORD REPORTED TO PREVENT WAR BY ATOMIC ERROR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The United States and the Soviet Union were understood today to have agreed on a system to handle nuclear ac cidents together, supported by a new communications satellite hot line to insure instantane ous consultations.

title: Magazine Says Engineer Warned on Apollo 1 Fires
description: Life magazine reported yes terday that an engineer for the space agency, John Dietz, warned repeatedly of the danger from inflammable ma terial in the Apollo 1 space capsule for eight months be fore the fire that killed three astronauts in a 1967 ground test.

title: Miller's 13UnderPar 267 Captures Southern Open by 5 Strokes
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 12 (AP)John Miller went from promising newcomer status to that of tournament winner to day by winning the $100,000 Southern open golf title by five strokes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While in principle I agree com pletely with The Times editorial of Aug. 30 concerning public support of the private university sector, I would be remiss if I did not reply to its admonition to the School of Business here at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, as well as to private universities in general, of the need to raise our academic standards. I would, of course, not want readers of The Times, particularly our students and prospective students, to be less than completely informed about us.

title: 2 Elderly Women Mugged On Way to Mass in Queens
description: The 78yearold mother of Pa trolman Thomas O'Dea, widely known as Mr. Salute for his sharp salutes and arm signals in directing traffic, was in jured yesterday and her com panion knocked down when they were mugged in Jackson Heights, Queens, while on their way to morning mass.

title: E. F. Hutton Fills Post
description: Robert R. Pauley, former president of the ABC Radio Net work from 1960 to 1967, has joined E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., as a vice president for corporate finance.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The brochure begins, So, you say  who the hell Toledo anyway thinking it has an allAmerican football player, let alone two in one year! It is a modest little brochure among the 12page 4color popout multimedia kits arriving by mail these days, and its author, Max Gerber, is almost apologetic. I can't go in for color and can't send telegrams and make longdistance phone calls. Sometimes a gaudy campaign causes resentment, and a lot of writers and broadcasters don't like to be called home  well, maybe I'm just rationalizing.

title: Vietnamese Students Urge U.S. to Withdraw Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12 (AP)Fewer than a dozen motorcycleriding South Viet namese students staged a brief demonstration in front of the American Embassy today, de manding that the United States and its allies withdraw their troops from Vietnam before Christmas.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Joint meeting of Special Committees on Colonialism and Apartheid and Council for SouthWest Africa 10:30 A.M.

title: Lions Rout Eagles By 4910 as Landry Connects on Passes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 The Detroit and Philadelphia pro football teams came into stronger focus tonight as the Lions routed the Eagles, 4910.

title: Palisades Park Closes for 1971 And Hopes for Lease on Its Life
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Sept. 12 Palisades Amusement Park ended its summer season today on an uncertain note, with negotiations scheduled for to morrow to determine whether the playland, recently pur chased by a building company, will remain open another year.

title: Marcia King Bride Of Larry W. Benton
description: The marriage of Miss Mar cia Irene King to Larry Wayne Benton took place yesterday afternoon in the Concord Baptist Church of Christ in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Gardner Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: MISS BOYCE WINS HUNTER AWARDS
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 12 Joan Boyce of Crozier, Va., was not only the busiest but also the most successful hunter competition rider today in the final session of the fourday North Shore horse show.

title: Father of 7 Stabbed to Death
description: An East Bronx father of seven children, ranging in age from 8 to 20, was fatally stabbed yesterday when he tried to stop a fight between his 20yearold son and an un known man. Pancho Carrasquillo, 43, a plasterer, of 591 East 141st Street, died at 2:15 A.M. near his home after he was stabbed in the chest by an assailant who also wounded his son Eliue in the chest. The son was taken to Lincoln Hos pital where he was reported in fair condition.

title: 3 IN AMBULANCE DIE IN JERSEY COLLISION
description: VINELAND, N.J., Sept 12 Three persons were killed today when a tractortrailer struck the ambulance they were riding in. The police said the ambu lance was crossing an inter section on a red light at the time of the crash.

title: Legal Gambling Proposed By Murphy to Curb Graft
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and many of his sub ordinates have come to the con clusion that major forms of il legal gambling should be legal ized.

title: Doctors Median Income (40,550) Spurs Fee Debate
description: There is probably no more emotional, controversial or complex issue in the current debate over health care re form than the earning power of the physician.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The threatened increase in the sub way fare would do a double disservice. It would add to the already over inflated cost of living of the working people of the city. And it would tend, as these increases always have, to change the riding habit of significant numbers of New Yorkers from mass transportation to private cars.

title: Bush Sees Peking Seated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 George Bush, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has said that it is pos sibleeven probable that Pe king would replace Taiwan in the United Nations Security Council.

title: Cowboys End Preseason As Lone Unbeaten Club
description: After almost two months of activity that the losers insist isn't really revealing, the Na tional Football League's pre season schedule finally ended last night. Indicating the grip the sport still maintains on the public, the final game was a network telecast between the Detroit Lions and the Phila delphia Eagles.

title: Stage: An Evening of Gentle Virtues
description: LEAVES OF GRASS, a musical ale hralion, based on the writings of Walt Whitman. Adaptation and music by Stan Herle, Jr.; setting by David Chapman; score arranged by Bill birch n; musical director, Karen Gus stalson; musical staging by Bert Michaels; direction by Stan !lade Jr. and Bert Michaels; production stage manager, Jan Moored. Presented by Sew Era Productions, At Theater lour, 42d West 55th Street.

title: LUNN LONG, LED WORLD ALMANAC
description: Luman It Long, editor of The World Almanac and Book of Facts, an annual reference work, died yesterday in Over look Hospital, Summit, N.J., after having undergone thoracic surgery Friday. He was 64 years old and lived in Chatham, N. J.

title: Thinking More Unthinkable Thoughts:
description: PARISI have just spent a week in Tokyo, where everybody, including the children, is talking about Nixon shock. Many responsible people wear glazed expressions (though these have begun to Tack).

title: Anniversaries
description: LOBSENZCongratulations to our Morn & Dad, Henrietta & Benjamin Lobsenz on their 51st wedding anniversary Sept. 9 Love from their children Sylvia & Lonard.

title: 5 Die in Oregon Capsizings
description: COOS BAY, Ore., Sept. 12 (UPI)  Five persons drowned when two pleasure boats cap sized in rough surf today off this southern Oregon coastal city. Lieut. Doyle Porter of the Coast Guard station here said a lookout spotted one boat go ing over in the surf shortly before 10 A.M. A second craft attempted to assist it, but also overturned. A 25foot Coast Guard lifeboat was also cap sized when a large wave hit it. All the crewmen swam to safety. Two persons aboard the pleasure craft were rescued by a helicopter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As candidates for the Democratic leadership posts in Greenwich Village, Mrs. Elvine A. Noferi and I are pledged to use the influence of our party, the largest organized force in the district, to halt and reverse the deterioration that has gone on in the Village for ten years, ignored by our opposition.

title: Arrests Seen in Slaying On the Lower East Side
description: Chief of Detectives Albert A.1 Seedman said yesterday that he expected arrests to be made in the next few days in the case of a 72yearold widow who died Friday after she had been robbed and bound in her Lower East Side apartment.

title: ELLINGTON HAILED BY MOSCOW BUFFS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12Duke Ellington flew into Moscow yesterday for the start of fiveweek jazz tour of major Soviet cities and managed I Love You Madly in Russian to a group of jazz buffs who shouted their response in Eng lishWe love you back.

title: City Opera Stages A Boheme Graced With Joanna Bruno
description: Joanna Bruno, a soprano who made her New York City Opera debut last season in Menotti's The Most Important Man, assumed the role of Mimi in Puccini's La Bohme in the company's performance of the work at the New York State Theater on Saturday night and lost no time in show ing that she is particularly well suited for it.

title: Buchanan 21 to Defeat Laguna in Battle Tonight
description: With the precision of the carpenter he is, Ken Buchanan of Scotland will defend his world lightweight champion ship against Ismael Laguna, a Panamanian ordered to discard flash for leverage, in a sched uled 15round bout tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: QUILICO'S RENATO LIFTS BALLO RETURN
description: The City Opera production of Verdi's Ulf Ballo in Maschera returned to the State Theater Saturday afternoon, a little stodgy after its summer lay over, but still an impressive showcase for some of the finest singers in the company. Louis Quilico, in particular, was superb, his Renato managing a beautiful fusion of vocal over and dramatic compassion. Gilda CruzRomo more constrained in her acting, let Amelia sing with such warmth and purity of tone that nothing else seemed to matter. Michele Molese, as Gustavo, grew steadily more affecting through the afternoon, and Patricia Wise, an inordinately attractive Page, added a refreshing touch of ebullience.

title: Dilemma in Health Care: Rising Cost and Demand
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12A decade ago, one medical group in Manhattan charged $35 for a basic physical checkup; today it charges $65. In those same years the going rate for an ap pendectomy in New York rose from $485 to $1,175 and the cost of an average hospital stay, for the nation as a whole, rose from $265 to $785.

title: Florida Fears Drought in 1972 More Severe Than This Year's
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 12In spite of heavy rainfalls during the last week, Lake Okeechobee, the major reservoir of south Florida, is still two feet below its normal level for this time of year. As a result, a drought in 1972 more severe than the one suffered in Florida this year has been pre dicted.

title: New Yorker Dead in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 12 (Reuters) A 26yearold New York girl, who came to Ireland last month to visit her father's grave, was found dead near here today after disappearing from a small hotel a week ago. The police said the body of Miss Melissa Waugh of Staten Island was found in a clump of bushes in Clontare, a small town near Dublin.

title: Striking Teachers in Levittown Are Scheduled to Return Today
description: LEVITTOWN., L. L, Sept. 12 Striking teachers in the Levit town schools are scheduled to go back to work tomorrow after an earlymorning meeting to vote on a proposed contract with the district. Under the terms of the settlement, no de tails of the contract proposal were to be made public until after the teachers met.

title: Khrushchev's Legacy
description: Will Nikita Khrushchev's ghost haunt the Kremlin in the years ahead?

title: Guards at Another Prison Protest Over Attica Death
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP)Guards at Green Haven Correctional Facility here staged a sixhourlong work slowdown today to protest what they said was lack of swift action in freeing hostages held by re bellious inmates at Attica Cor rectional Facility.

title: Unser Wins 250Mile Race
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (AP) Al Unser, of Albuquerque. N. M., drove a 1971 Ford to victory in the 250mile Gover nor's Cup late model stock car race today at the Wisconsin State Fair Park track. Unser veraged 91,935 miles an hour around the onemile oval to finish more than a lap ahead of Roger McCluskey, of Tucson, Ariz., driving a 1970 Plymouth.

title: Director of Freeze Satisfied Thus Far
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Is the Cost of Living Council doomed to extinction after a few short summer months of soaring glory?

title: ROCKEFELLER BARS A VISIT TO ATTICA
description: Sipaling a harder line to ward rebellious inmates at the Attick, Correctional Facility, Govenor Rockefeller yesterday rejected a prisoner demand and a citizen committee's recom mendkton that he go to the prison.

title: M'GOVERN URGES U.S. ACCEPT HANOI OFFER
description: PARIS, Sept. 12Senator George MsGovern said today that President Nixon holds the key to the jail cells of Hanoi.

title: Forget Cannikin
description: A bright hope on a foreboding front is the news that President Nixon is considering cancellation of Cannikin, the underground nuclear test planned for this fall on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians.

title: Steel Orders Advance Slightly As Demand Remains Depressed
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 Steel producers reported a modest rise in demand last week. At one major mill, orders for September delivery were up 40 per cent from August ship ments. Orders for October were running 20 per cent ahead of the September pace.

title: CRANSTON DISPUTES PENTAGON ON DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, said today that 75 days without the draft had proved that military conscription might not be need ed at all.

title: NASCAR Race Off
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 12 (AP)  The Grand National Capital City City 500 National Association for stock car auto racing scheduled for today was rained out. It his been rescheduled for Oct 3.

title: John Riddell, Golf Champion, Petroleum Concern Head
description: John F. Riddell, president of the Riddell Petroleum Corpora tion of One Rockefeller Plaza, who was United States Senior golf champion in 1948, died yesterday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 580 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Miss Nicole Pilotaz Is Married To Bruce Lawrence Paisner
description: Miss Nicole Pilotaz, daugh ter of Rene Pilotaz of Cham bery, France, and the late Mrs. Pilotaz, was married here yesterday to Bruce Lawrence Paisner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Paisner of Providence, R. I.

title: YANKEES BEATEN BY HOME MS, 62
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 Fritz Peterson and three other Yankee pitchers feasted on Polynesian food last night, but Roy Foster and Graig Nettles feasted on Peterson today and powered Cleveland to a 52 victory.

title: Alabama Negroes Protest After Woman Is Killed by White's Car
description: BUTLER, Ala., Sept. 12 About 600 Negroes held a quiet protest march here today after a 19yearold woman was struck, run over and fatally injured yesterday by a car driven by a white man.

title: Advertising:
description: Coordinated Communica tions Inc., the leadership of which was getting up tight about the number of times it was coming in second in newbusiness races, is in the winner's circle this morning.

title: NADER BIDS VOLPE KEEP AIRBAG PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Ralph Nader, back in the auto mobile safety field where his consumer campaigns began, urged Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe today to hold firm for the installation of air bags in the 1974model cars.

title: Lew Schwartz, ExPresident Of AbelardSchuman, Is Dead
description: Lew Schwartz, a founder and former president of Abe lardSchuman, Ltd., general trade and juvenile book pub lisher, died yesterday in San Francisco, apparently of a heart attack, while on a busi ness trip. He was 64 years old and lived at 12 Park Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Ulster Quietly Planning New Reforms
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 12A month after im posing internment measures that brought a wave of terror ism, the Northern Ireland Gov ernment is quietly malting moves that it hopes will placate the Roman Catholic minority.

title: Merrick Breaks the Front on 7: 30 Curtain
description: The united front on the 7:30 Broadway theater cur tain will be broken tonight when the longrunning musi cal Promises, Promises raises its curtain at 8 o'clock. David Merrick, the producer, said he was making the move because he felt the earlier start prevented theater patrons from enjoying a more leisurely dinner.

title: Jobs Sought at San Quentin
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)State prison officials were pleased today by the turn out for the first written tests for San Quentin guards since an escape attempt that left six men dead. Lt. C. H. Wilson said 28 men took the exami nation yesterday, a larger than average number, and 25 of them passed. Three guards and three inmates, including George Jackson, one of the Soledad Brothers, wer killed Aug. 21 during an escape attempt.

title: GETTING HIS FEET WET: Mike Jorgensen of the New York Mets in center field chasing a double by Don Money Philadelphia in the fifth inning of the game yesterday at Shea Stadium. The New Yorkers won the contest, 3 to
description: With the score 22 and men on second and third, Mike Jor gensen came up in the ninth inning and poked a fast ball from Joe Hoerner into right center field to give the New York Mets a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Aug. 26 editorial concerning the establishment or performance standards for telephone companies by the Public Service Commission greatly overstates the impact of the proposed rules changes.

title: PARADE IN HARLEM IS A SHOW OF SOUL
description: The pulse of Harlem quick ened yesterday afternoon as a mammoth parade, sponsored by two community organizations, strode up Seventh Avenue for 40 blocks from 110th Street, drawing cheers from tens of thousands of men, women and children.

title: 2Inch Rain Brings Flooding Here and in Suburbs
description: Intermittent heavy rains that started on Saturday morning and continued through yester day drenched the city and the metropolitan area, flooding streets and basements of homes, snarling highways with stalled cars, and disrupting electrical systems.

title: Juilliard Opens a $36Million Fund Drive
description: With a $7million grant from the Ford Foundation as the initial gift, the Juilliard School today opens the first capital fund campaign in its history. The goal is $36mil lion.

title: Pier Angeli Service Set
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI)A memorial service will be held tomorrow for Pier Angeli, who died of an over dose of drugs. Members of her family, including her sister, the actress Marisa Pavan, arrived late last night to claim the body. The Italianborn actress, 39 years old, was found dead Friday morning in her Beverly Hills apartment. Coroner Thomas Noguchi said yesterday that the cause of death ap pears to be an overdose of drugs  one of which has been identified as barbituates. Miss Angeli will be buried near Paris, where her sister lives.

title: Last Chance in Vietnam
description: Two authoritative voices now have challenged the Ad ministration's handwringing act over the political crisis in Vietnam and its claims that it has done all it can influence President Thieu to turn his singleslate presi dential election into a real contest.

title: Miss Whipple Wed To J. B. Grinnell Jr.
description: COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 12 Miss Nancy Elze Whipple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Collins Whipple, was married here this afternoon to James Briggs Grinnell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Grinnell.

title: ZONING SUIT SLATED BY URBAN COALITION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The National Urban Coalition announced today that it would enter a legal challenge against county zoning practices that prevent the construction of sub sidized housing for lowincome families.

title: Swedish Rebuff to Solzhenitsyn Scored
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 12The Swedish Government has been sharply criticized for its re fusal to allow the 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature to be handed over to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in its Moscow Em bassy.

title: Books of The Times
description: A CAGE OF ICE. By Duncan Kyle. 254 pages. St. Martin's. $5.95.

title: NEW REPORT TELLS OF C.I.A.'S LAOS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) A transcript of secret Senate testimony described to day the Central. Intelligence Agency's role in secretly train ing and supporting 30,000 guer rilla troops in Laos since 1962.

title: Consumers in Queens Heard by Bess Myerson
description: Marking the third anniver sary of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, Commis siener Bess Myerson yesterday began a fiveday tour of the boroughs to learn firsthand what the people feel needs to be done to protect them from swindles.

title: WPIX Blames Mixup for Losing Interview With ExChaplain
description: A mixup in paperwork was blamed by a WPIXTV pro ducer yesterday for the erasure of a taped interview with the Rev. Laurence Gibney, the out spoken former Roman Catholic chaplain at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, also known as the Tombs.

title: Jimi Plays Berkeley' At Garrick
description: "Jimi Plays Berkeley," which opened at the Garrick Theater yesterday, is a 55-minute film record of portions of the late Jimi Hendrix's 1970 Memorial Day concert at Berkeley, Calif.According to these cameras, which may be lying in spite of themselves, the Berkeley performance never attained the freaky, controlled intoxication of those recorded in both "Monterey Pop" and "Woodstock." It's not that the star of "Jimi Plays Berkeley" is unnaturally subdued. He's all therealternately seducing his electric guitar, as if it were a thing to be persuaded, and then threatening forced entry, all the while belting out some of his best numbers, including his Day-Glo version of "The Star-Spangled Banner" and the almost autumnal "I Don't Live Today" (Will I live tomorrow?/Well I just can't say. . . .").It's not the star but the movie that looks somehow pale and small and mild, which is, I suspect, what happens when more or less conventional concert film techniques (quick zooms into and out of close-ups, lots of dim profile shots) are applied without particular thought to what is being done/said/sung by the subject being photographed. Also, the sound quality, at least at the Garrick yesterday, is not of the first order.Spliced into the concert material are snippets of interviews with not especially articulate Hendrix associates and fans ("He wants to communicate as a person, not as an idol"), as well as some Berkeley student-riot footage, which, I suppose, the filmmakers have used to establish the locale, as gondolas would, most likely, establish Venice.Also on the program is a terrible 25-minute short from the Netherlands, "Rainbow," a sort of Contemporary Dutch Expressionist interpretation of the Rolling Stones' "She's a Rainbow," which is heard on the soundtrack. The images and the cutting are ersatz Richard Lester, but the colors are not unpleasantly tulip-bright.

title: Boston Awaits Ruling
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP)The 200 children ignoring transfers to another school and still re porting to the Emily Elfield School in the Dorchester sec tion of Boston will be allowed to continue there, though un registered, until a court deci sion on their case, school offi cials said today.

title: Sweden and Solzhenitsyn
description: Sweden's world prestige gains no luster from revela tions of the submission by its Government to Soviet cultural policy with regard to Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's richly deserved Nobel Prize for Literature.

title: VW Chairman Resigns in Controversy
description: BONN, Sept. 13The Volks wagen Company, West Ger many's crisisthreatened auto mobile giant, announced today that its board chairman, Prof. Kurt Lotz, would leave the company.

title: U.N. Meeting Asked
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 Jordan today asked for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to discuss Jordanian charges that Israel has been seeking to change the Arab character of the city of Jerusalem.

title: Nixon Men Accused By Bayh of Failing To Cut Back Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  Senator Birch Bayh, Demo crat of Indiana, opened a new round of hearings today on gun control legislation and charged that the Nixon Ad ministration, despite fancy talk about law and order, had failed to act to reduce street crime.

title: Judge Orders New Haven To Let Yale Students Vote
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 13 (AP) Yale students who had been denied the right to register as voters in New Haven won their suit against that city's regis trars today.

title: Text of Monetary Accord in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 13 (Reu ters)The following is an un official translation of the full text of the agreement reached by the finance ministers of the European Economic Com munity, or Common Market:

title: Massacre at Attica
description: The fiveday rebellion by prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility has been crushed, but at a terrible price. This gloomy, graywalled prison near Buffalo will forever carry the stain of yesterday's gruesome mass, tragedy in which nine hostages and 28 convicts were killed.

title: College for the Arts Is Opened Amid Estates in Westchester
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 13 Sheltered from the rain by a yellowandwhite striped tent, the first entering class at the State University of New York's college at Pur chase was officially wel comed today to the newest branch of the state system.

title: Summary of the Recommendations of Commission on Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Following is the summary of the recommendations of the Commission on Interna tional Trade and Investment Policy submitted to President Nixon today. The summary is contained in the first chapter of the commission's report, entitled Strategy for the Seventies.

title: Landau Resigns From Posts At Brooklyn Philharmonia
description: Siegfried Landau, conductor arid musical director of the Brooklyn Philharmonia since its founding 17 years ago, has re signed both posts.

title: EDWARD W. STITT, 78; A LAWYER 55 YEARS
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 13Edward W. Stitt Jr., a law yer for 55 years, died Sunday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 35 Shady Glen Court.

title: Court Upsets City Rent Decontrol Curb
description: The State Supreme Court has upset a New York City law that would in effect have mod ified a state rentdecontrol law enacted last June.

title: Pontiac Workers Warned
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 13 (UPI)Two of the most power ful Organizations In this indus trial citythe General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workersdeplored today plans by school busing foes to try to close a G.M. plant to demonstrate their strength.

title: Service for Irving Karpas
description: A memorial service for Irv ing D. Karpas, philanthropist and secretary of the board of Beth Israel Medical Center, was held yesterday at the hos pital. More than 150 members of the medical staff attended. Charles H. Silver, president of the hospital and former presi dent of the Board of Education, delivered the eulogy. Mr. Kar pas died here Sept. 6 at the age of 81.

title: Agnew Tells Governors We're Open to. Ideas on Nixon's Policy
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 13 Vice President Agnew today defended President Nixon's new economic policy against its Democratic critics in a speech to the opening session of the 63d Governors Con ference

title: Hockey League Formed In Rivalry With N.H.L.
description: The prospect of a major rival to the National Hockey League, which has not been seriously threatened since it was formed in 1917, has arisen with the formation of the World Hockey Association.

title: Boys Wear Show Threaded With Optimism
description: There are smiles instead of sour faces this time.

title: Passing of a Coast Farm Stirs Ecological Furor
description: CARMEL, Calif., Sept. 13 Bruno and Emilio Odello are farmers, as was their father, Battista, before them.

title: SAM PEARCE, 62, THEATER CURATOR
description: Sam Pearce, curator of the Theater and Music Collection of the Museum of the City of New York, died of a heart at tack Sunday at his country home in Lobachsville, Berks County, Pa., on his 62d birth day. He lived also at 160 East 97th Street.

title: COLTS TO ACTIVATE UNITAS ON THURSDAY
description: The Baltimore Colts will ac tivate John Unitas on Thursday and their famous quarterback will be ready to play against the Jets in the opening game of the regular season on Sunday at Baltimore. This key intradivi sion contest has been the target for both sides since training camps opened.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Sept. 13, 1971 THE PRESIDENT Disaster. The Piesident de clared the southeastern part of New York. State a major disaster area. This action, which had been requested by Governor Rockefeller, enables Federal funds to be used to supplement state and local resources for relief and re covery measures after a tropical storm, Doria struck the area last month.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BOHIER LAKE, Quebec Rain rattled against the win dows of our Norsman float plane as we came in for a landing on a small, unnamed body of water that lies a quarter of a mile south of Bohier Lake. As we were taxiing toward shore, where the plane was tethered to two spruce trees, the squall passed overhead, however, and sunlight streamed down between the steep, green hills.

title: Mideast Battle of Words
description: Jordan's call for an urgent Security Council meeting on Jerusalem is only the opening shot in a new battle of words over the Middle East at the United Nations. Egypt is expected to press for full debate on the whole range of ArabIsraeli issues at the fall session of the General Assembly, opening here next Tuesday.

title: FundShort City Schools Open With Two Protests
description: A protest by parents pre vented a Bronx elementary school from opening yesterday morning as the city school sys tern began the new academic year under austerity conditions.

title: Market Place:
description: You are probably thinking that the Big Three auto makers are likely to do well in the months ahead if for no other reason than Presi dent Nixon's import sur charge.

title: Senators Hope to Rescue the Welfare Reform Bill by Bypassing Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 13  Backers of welfare reform legislation are planning a last ditch rescue operation to win Senate approval of a liber alized family assistance plan this year by bypassing the hostile Finance Committee.

title: AMEX ISSUES FALL AS TRADING DROPS
description: The American Stock Ex change finished lower yester day in quiet trading.

title: U.S.SOVIET PACT TO BE SIGNED SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Secretary of State William P. Rogers and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, are to sign later this month probably on Sept. 30agree ments on the handling of nu clear accidents. The accords were negotiated at the talks on the limitation of strategic arms in Helsinki, Finland.

title: PERCY HELTON, ACTOR IN 200 FILMS, IS DEAD
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 13  Percy Helton, stage and screen actor, died Saturday in Holly wood Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 77.

title: Son Lauds Khrushchev at Rites
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13Nikita S. Khrushchev was buried to day in a simple ceremony from which the Soviet leaders were absent but which was marked by a statement of homage from his son.

title: Mesa Co. to Call Shares
description: AMARILLO, Tex., Sept. 13 (UPI) The Mesa Petroleum Company announced today it will call all of its outstanding $2.20 cumulative convertible preferred junior Mesa preferred stock on Nov. 1 at a redemp tion price of $85 a share. Each holder has the right to convert the stock before Nov. 1 into common stock, at a conversion rate of 1.875 shares of common for each share of preferred.

title: Earnings of Rohr Decline in Quarter
description: A sharp decline in earnings was reported yesterday by the Rohr Corporation for the fiscal year and fourth quarter ended July 31. Sales for the year, however, rose to a record level.

title: Issues in Movie Dispute
description: The film companies have offered a number of proposals providing for increases in fringe benefits and in salary. According to the union, the companies last salary offer was for an 18 per cent increase, with additional 2 per cent increases Jan. 1, 1972, and July 1, 1972.

title: Births
description: MR. & MRS. J. TYLEE WILSON of Green with, Conn., announce the birth of their first child, a son, on Sept. 6, 1971; the child has been named Christopher Farrell.

title: Clean Urban Rivers Urged
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) The nation's top environ mental official, William D. Ruckelshaus, said today that America's rivers must be made clean enough again for swim ming. This achievement, com bined with an effort to open up and develop the recreational potential of all urban water ways, would completely trans form life in our decaying cities, said Mr. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environ mental Protection Agency. He addressed the American Public Works Association.

title: PhoneStrike Talks Here Are Halted by Accusations
description: Contract negotiations to end the twomonthold statewide telephone strike broke down after only a few minutes yester day when the New York Tele phone Company accused strik ers, for the third time in two weeks, of cablecutting, other vandalism and of threatening working personnel.

title: Radioman on Helicopter with Col. Henderson Says He Saw 30 Bodies at Mylai
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 13 The former radio operator for Col. Oran K. Henderson testi fied today that immediately af ter the infantry attack on Mylai he was told that 160 people had been killed, but some were women and children.

title: British Y Admits Women
description: MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 13 (AP)The Young Men's Christian Association in Britain reversed a policy of 127 years yesterday and decided to admit women.

title: UTILITY PICKS SITES FOR FLOATING UNITS
description: The advent of floating nuclear power plants moved a step nearer yesterday as the Public Service Electric and Gas Com pany identified two ideal sites off the Jersey coast.

title: Trudeau, Awaiting U.S. Step, Bars Aid To Exporters Now
description: TORONTO, Sept. 13The possibility of trade warfare with the United States was raised in Parliament during a question period today, another sign of the anxiety, dismay and frustra tion produced in Canada by Washington's new program to curb imports and bolster ex ports.

title: Floods in Texas
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 13 (AP)Texans in this area struggled to overcome flood water today while resi dents along the Rio Grande 150 miles to the south braced for possible new floods from tropi cal storm Edith, which took 23 lives in Nicaragua and Hon duras.

title: Arabs Reported Expecting A Soviet Tie With Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Authoritative Administration officials said today that Arab diplomats in Moscow believe that the Soviet Union expects to establish some form of rela tionship with Israel early next year.

title: ART WORKS STOLEN IN ITALY AND PARIS
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Sept. 13 (AP)Italy's wave of art thefts continued today with the dis appearance of three 17thcen tury paintings from a Bologna municipal building and five art works from a church near Vicenza.

title: Israel Backs Arab Theater
description: TEL AVIV (AP)The Israeli Government has budgeted $70, 000 for the country's only per manent Arab theater. The four yearold theatrical company, which travels to Arab villages in Israel, is directed by a Jewish actress.

title: Commonwealth Edison Deal
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (Reuters) The Commonwealth Edison Company said today it had ap plied to the Illinois Commerce Commission for permission to buy five miles of rightofway from the Penn Central Com pany for $1.15million. The utility plans to build a trans mission line on the property.

title: Kosygin Sees Wilson
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union and the Brit ish opposition leader, Harold Wilson, met in the Kremlin to day. The Soviet press agency, Tass, described their talks as friendly, but gave no further details.

title: Dr. Philip Stimson Dead at 82; Active in the Fight Against Polio
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 13Dr. Philip M. Stimson, New York pediatrician long ac tive in the fight against polio myelitis, died today in the Meadow Lakes retirement home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Bahnsen 3Hitter Vanquishes Red Sox,4  in FogShrouded Contestl.
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13With the fog thickening and Stan Bahn sen growing stronger as the game progressed, the Yankees whipped Boston, 4.0, tonight and moved two games behind the Red Sox in their battle for third place.

title: U.S. Vietnam Policy Makers Called Thugs by Ellsberg
description: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said here last night that over the years United States policy makers had acted like thugs, creeps and torturers in prolonging an immoral, lost war in Vietnam.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEES A PLOT Al PRISON
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that the uprising at Attica Prison was brought on by the revolutionary tactics of militants and that he had or dered a full investigation of all the factors leading to this uprising, including the role that outside forces would appear to have played.

title: Egyptians Say U.S. Has Failed To Keep Them Informed on Suez
description: CAIRO, Sept. 13Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad com plained today that the United States had not communicated with the Egyptian Government for two months on its endeav ors to promote an agreement between Egypt and Israel on reopening the Suez Canal.

title: Court in Italy Lilts the Threat That 10,000 Will Lose Degrees
description: ROME, Sept. 13Some 10,000 Italian university graduates  each one a dottore or dottoressa  breathed easier today when two Roman judges ruled that a recent general amnesty had wiped out criminal charges of fraud in the way they had ob tained their degrees.

title: Isaac Drives 69 Charger To Record 216 Miles an Hour
description: WENDOVER, Utah, Sept. 13 (AP)  Bobby Isaac, driving 1969 Dodge Charger, set a na tional stock car speed record of 216.35 miles an hour for the flying mile today at the Bonne ville Salt Flats.

title: TV: Opening Week of New Season
description: As far as the opening week of a new commercial televi sion season is concerned, it is less a question of covering it than of recording it while on the dazed run from screen ing room to TV set.

title: Polls in City to Be Open From 3 to 10 P.M. Today
description: The polls in New York City will be open from 3 P.M. to 10 P.M. today for the primary elections. In nearby suburbs, the polling hours will be from 3 P.M. to 9 P.M. However, the polls will be open only in those districts where there is a contest for party offices or public office nominations.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB PRESS PRIVILEGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to rule that journalists do not have a constitutional right to refuse to testify about the identity of confidential sources or other information learned in confi dence.

title: Dodgers Win 5.4, Cut Lead of Giants in Bean Ball Game
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 13 The streaking Los Angeles Dodgers beat the San Francisco Giants a record seventh straight time tonight. The 54 victory Cut the Giants once huge lead in the Western Division of the National League to two games. The Dodgers also posted their, seventh straight victory.

title: Miss Andrea Hegeman Is Wed To W. Barklie Henry in Chile
description: Miss Andrea Hegeman was married last Thursday to W. Barklie Henry, a trustee of the Whitney Museum of American Art, which was founded by his grandmother, the late Mrs. Gertrude Van derbilt Whitney. The cere mony took place in Santiago, Chile, where the bridegroom has been working on a novel.

title: Kaiser Official Named Federal Health Planner
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Nixon Administration to day named Scott Fleming, executive vice president of the Kaiser health groups, as the nation's first Federal health planner.

title: Mellon Bank Announces Top Management Changes
