description: The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, Pennsyl vania's largest bank, announced yesterday changes in senior management designed to spell out the line of succession when its present chairman, John A. Mayer, retires three years hence.

title: Bringing Up Babies, But Not by the Book
description: When today's young parents were in diapers, they were raised by the clock and the calendar. Most child experts of the late thirties and wartime forties were preaching feeding and sleeping schedules that would have made a Spar tan mother cringe.

title: JOHN M MANUS, 58, FILM EDITOR, DIES
description: John Armstrong McManus, film editor, who originated the television series Crusade in Europe, based on the book by President Eisenhower, died Sun day of a heart ailment at his home, 30 Park Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y. His age was 58.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is with some concern that I have followed the recent reports about ques tions being raised about the financ ing and continued existence of Radio Free Europe.

title: Ahostage Says Threats Left Him Scared Silly
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13I laid there on the floor and knew I was going to bleed to death right there.

title: GIANTS GET M'RAE, HYLAND OF BEARS IN MOVE FOR HELP
description: The New York Giants acquired two players they ex pect to use as starters by trading their No. 1 draft choice for 1972 to the Chicago Bears yesterday.

title: John R. Snedaker, 60, Is Dead; Retired Executive for Time Inc.
description: John R. Snedaker, an execu tive in the international divi sions of Time Inc. for 25 years, died of cancer Friday in Eas ton (Md.) Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old and had moved from here to Island Creek, Md., after his retire ment in 1970.

title: Universal Elevates Dickman
description: James J. Dickman has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Uni versal Terminal & Stevedoring Corporation. Mr. Dickman, who had been president of the con cern, one of the port's largest terminal operators, Is also president of the New York Shipping Assbciation. Mr. Dick man has been succeeded as president of Universal by Jo seph G. Barkan, a former presi dent of American Export Is brandtsen Lines.

title: MANY SHUN BUSES IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 A massive busing program to integrate 48,000 students in 97 elementary schools was conducted without violence here today, although scattered boycotts by parents caused an absentee rate estimated at 40 per cent.

title: A Radio Ham Tunes in London Police To Tape of $1.2Million Bank Robbery
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 Scot land Yard was embarrassed to day after a weekend bank rob bery whose cast of characters included Cockney robbers with walkietalkies, a radio ham from Wimpole Street and po licemen who heard a tape re cording of the robbers conver sation.

title: Panel's Failure Evident Day Before Police Acted
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 The resort to force in the Attica prison rebellion, with the re sultant death of 37 inmates and hostages; followed a fourday attempt by outside mediators to negotiate an endingan effort that clearly was collapsing as early as yesterday afternoon.

title: WHITNEY TO EXTEND NEW FILM SERIES
description: The Whitney Museum will continue its New American Filmmakers Series, started in December, 1970, to give ex posure to independently made American films, John I. H. Baur, museum director, has an nounced.

title: 148 Blacks Arrested in Alabama Town
description: BUTLER, Ala., Sept. 13 (AP) Officials in this racially tense southwest Alabama town ob tained a temporary injunction today to prevent further marching. They acted after 148 blacks were arrested during demonstration earlier in the day.

title: Sergeant, in $1Million Suit, Denies Role in Kent Killings
description: An Ohio National Guard ser geant yesterday sued a New York insurance man for $1,5 million, charging that the in surance man had libeled him in a private report dealing with the shooting of four students at Kent State University on May 4, 1970.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Here, for those who would like to read some genuine news for a change, are a few stories that won't be found in any other paper or on your TV screen.

title: CITY TALKS RESUME WITH PUBLIC UNIONS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ord ered the resumption of contract negotiations with policemen, firemen and sanitationmen.

title: BLACK LUNG TALKS HEAR MINER PLEA
description: A group of disgruntled Ap palachian coal miners, who said they are disabled victims of black lung disease being denied their rights, paid an unexpected visit to the Wal dorfAstoria Hotel yesterday to present their grievances to an international scientific confer ence on the occupational dis ease.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Sept. 3 editorial describing the Statehood for New York City move ment as demagoguery and its spon sors as publicity seekers is an affront to the Committee to Make New York City a State, which includes five mem bers of Congress, three Borough Presi dents, more than forty state legisla tors, city officials, political, commu nity, labor, education, religious and civic leaders and many others. It is also an affront to the more than 55,000 New Yorkers who signed our petition to place the statehood issue on the ballot.

title: Nader Assails the Industry
description: KERHONKSON, N. Y., Sept. 13Ralph Nader, the consum er advocate, today accused the insurance industry of institu tionalized cowardice and urged it to stop insuring un safe cars and facilities used by the public.

title: METS DOWN EXPOS IN 5 INNINGS, 42
description: After an hour and 35 minutes of play, then a wait of an hour and 22 minutes because of rain, the New York Mets emerged with a 42, fiveinning victory over the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Bomb Blast at Rally
description: MANILA, Sept. 13 (UPI) A small bomb exploded during the rally. No one was reported injured in the explosion but witnesses said one or two per sons appeared to be hurt when part of the crowd panicked and tried to run.

title: Concorde Official Says China Weighs Purchase
description: PARIS, Sept. 13China has expressed an interest in the FrenchBritish Concorde su personic transport and pre liminary negotiations are under way on the matter be tween Paris and Peking.

title: Picketing in Nashville
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 13 (AP) Policemen were sent to several Nashville schools today after, pickets blocked driveways in an effort to keep children out as the school system began its sec ond week of courtordered but ing to achieve racial balance. Some incidents of rock throw ing were reported.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PARIS, Sept. 13 (AP)Twen ty 14thcentury paintings, rep resenting the life and death of Christ, were stolen from a par ish church over the weekend,1 the authorities reported.

title: Buchanan Retains Title By Outpointing Laguna
description: As tough as a Scottish this tle, Ken Buchanan retained his world lightweight championship last night by earning a unani mous decision over Ismael La guna at Madison Square Gar den despite slit vision in his left eye for the last 13 of the 15, brawling rounds.

title: WORLD BANK'S AID AT RECORD LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The World Bank reported to day that it was well on its way to achieving its, goal of dou bling its lending to the lessde veloped countries from the levels of the late nineteen sixties.

title: Gordon Hirsch Dies at 88; Led 5th Assembly District
description: Gordon B. Hirsch, Democrat ic leader from 1949 to 1954 of the Fifth Assembly District South, covering the West Side of Manhattan between the low er end of Central Park and the Hudson River, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 253 West 72d Street.

title: Tinajero Takes Jerome by 2 Lengths
description: Tinajero proved to be all that his advance notices claimed for him in his mainland debut at Belmont Park yesterday. Rafael Escudero's 3yearold colt, who had registered nine victories in 10 starts in Puerto Rico this season, scampered to an easy score in the $57,000 Jerome Handicap, the onemile test that had its 102d running. The triumph was the seventh in a row for Tinajero.

title: At Least 5 Dead in Metropolitan Area As Violent 3Day Rainstorm Slackens
description: A severe threeday rainstorm that left at least five dead in the metropolitan area slackened yesterday as the slowmoving lowpressure area that had gen erated it gradually lost its force.

title: Suspect Held After Chase, Charged With. Cab Robbery
description: A city detective arrested a man yesterday after a two block chase on Central Park West after the man had alleged ly robbed and slightly wounded a gypsy cab driver.

title: NEW CHARGES MADE AGAINST BAIRD ON L.I.
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 13 Suffolk District Attorney George J. Aspland today with drew the original charges against William Baird Jr., the birthcontrol advocate, of en dangering the morals of a minor, but substituted three other charges.

title: BombCarrying Convict Killed by Sharpshooter
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 Just an hour after state police proclaimed the wrecked prison here secure, separate groups of legislators and reporters the latter chosen by lottoured the facility.

title: Oil Found Off L.I., Industry Says After Summer's Explorations
description: MONTAUK; L. I., Sept. 13 Oil and naturalgas deposits in commercial quantities exist on the continental shelf as close as 30 miles off the coast of Long Island, according to the findings of a summer's explora tions by a consortium of 34 oil companies.

title: Executive Changes
description: Chelsea Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that George A. Tunick, president, was elected chairman of the executive committee replacing David Casty, chairman of the board. Mr. Tunick will be in direct control of all operations of subsidiaries and divisions. Mr. Casty will remain on the committee and in the area of financial management.

title: Protests Erupt in Hue After G.I. Kills Youth
description: HUE, South Vietnam, Tues day, Sept. 14 (AP)  Anti American demonstrations erupted in Hue yesterday and the city was ruled off limits to United States vehicles after an American soldier shot and killed a Vietnamese youth and wounded a second.

title: Reform in Victimless Crime Laws Urged at Legislative Hearing
description: To alleviate the overcrowd ing of prisons and other weak ness of the criminal justice system, Investigation Commis sioner Robert K. Ruskin and other high officials urged re forms in laws concerning gam bling and other victimless crimed.

title: LIKE A WAR ZONE
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 The rebellion at the Attica Cor rectional Facility ended this morning in a bloody clash and mass deaths that four days of taut negotiations had sought to avert.

title: UNIVERSAL BOOSTS FILM OUTPUT PLANS
description: Universal Pictures has given the green light for the produc tion of five additional feature films in the United States within the next 12 months. The move was a direct result of the recent Internal Revenue Service ruling reducing the pre payment of taxes on estimated future television income result ing from the sale of the pic tures to the TV medium.

title: Shop Talk
description: Just before the first model stepped on the runway, a spokesman for Saks Fifth Avenue, told the fashion show audience that the clothes they were about to see were original without being eccentric. Frederique, the directrice of the Jean Patou salon in Paris, smiled in agreement. Mi chele Goma, the designer, was no where in sight at that point, but he had said earlier that his view of the collec tion was that it was totally balanced. The showing of the complete Patou readyto wear line held yesterday at Saks, didn't make liars of any of them. It was a blend of narrow, fitted, shaped and detailed clothes for conserva tive tastes and young, casual and sportif styles for the more adventurous.

title: Florida Keys Bill Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Representative Dante B. Fas cell, Democrat of Florida, says that he plans to introduce to morrow a measure establishing the Florida Keys Wilderness. It would be composed of feder allyowned lands in the Nation al Key Deer Refuge, the Great White Heron Refuge and the Key West National Wildlife Refuge.

title: BANKRUPTCY FEES CUT OFF FOR POOR
description: A Federal judge ruled yes terday that poor persons may file for bankruptcy without having to pay the usual $50 filing fee.

title: Gonzales Is Honored
description: Pancho Gonzales, 43yearold tennis star, was honored here yesterday for his work with young players and underprivi leged children. He received a check for $1,000 from the American Express Card Divi sion to help a young player of his choice further his education.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Yieds on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Govern ment's weeky competitive sae today of these shortterm securities.

title: WEIS, VOISIN & CO, SETS ACQUISITION
description: Weis, Voisin & Co., Inc., a mediumsized member of the New York Stock Exchange, an nounced plans yesterday to ac quire most of the assets of Scheinman, Hochstin & Trotta, Inc., another Big Board house.

title: Filmmaking Talks At an Impasse Here
description: Contract negotiations be tween representatives of five New York movie companies and Local 52 of the Interna tional Association of Theatri cal Stage Employes and Mov ing Picture Operators broke off yesterday, putting the future of New York movie making in doubt.

title: U. S. BARS AID CUT FORLATIN AMERICA
description: PANAMA CITY, Panama, Sept. 13  President Nixon promised today to exclude Lat in America from the 10 per cent reduction in foreign aid that is part of his new eco nomic policy now before Con gress.

title: History of Prisoner Riots
description: Prison riots have been a part of prison history in this country, but the loss of life at Attica. Prison yesterday was surpassed only once previously. On April 21, 1930, 317 inmates at Ohio State Penitentiary, locked in their cells, died in a fire set by other, rioting, prisoners.

title: A Funny Art Show That's Serious, Too
description: PARISThe Bibliothque Nationale has such a dignified and heavyweight reputation that it isn't exactly the place where a humorist would go for his source material. And yet it is currently the stage for a marvelously comic show of humor in drawings and en gravings. The celebrated li brary, known for its serious exhibitions, proves with this display that it does have funny bone and likes a good belly laugh every once in a while.

title: EscapeProof Attica Lost a Prisoner April 9
description: The Attica Correctional Facility, with a reputation for suppposedly escapeproof gates, saw that reputation challenged last April 9, when Joseph Sullivan made it past the walls, completing the first escape from Attica in 40 years.

title: SHIFTS PROPOSED FOR LETTER STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a new ver sion today of its proposed rule dealing with the sale of letter or restricted stock.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following stock primary prices for the week ended Sept. 7

title: STEEL PRODUCTION FELL 1.6% IN WEEK
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday declined by 1.6 per cent from the pre ceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday. The shorter work week because of Labor Day holiday contributed to the small drop.

title: JEWISH POOR SEEN AS UNDERSERVED
description: The Jewish poor have been underserved by antipoverty programs here, and so have the elderly poor of all religious and ethnic groups, the city's Human Resources Administration re ported yesterday.

title: Monti Rock Turns In Mike for a Comb
description: Monti Rock is rolling again  rolling up hair on plastic curlers.

title: Attica Took Its Name From Site of Athens
description: Attica, the small town where the riottorn prison is located, was named after the dry triangular plain in Greece where Athens was built.

title: China Fkeportson Khrushchevl
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Sept. 14 (Reuters)Hsinhua, the Chi nese press agency, reported to day without comment the death of the former Soviet Pre mier, Nikita S. Khrushchev.

title: Rube Melton, ExPitcher, Dies in Car Crash at 5
description: GREER, S. C., Sept. 13 (AP) Rube Melton, 54yearold for mer pitcher with the Philadel phia Phillies and Brooklyn Dodgers, was among three per sons killed in a twocar auto mobile accident Saturday night.

title: Books of The Times
description: VAN GOGH'S DIARY. The Artist's Life His Own Words and. Art. Edited by Jan Huisher. 188 pages. William Morrow. $12.50.

title: Doctors SitIns in Spain End After Madrid Yields
description: MADRID, Sept. 13Sitins by doctors throughout Spain in support of psychiatrists at a Madrid hospital have ended after the Madrid provincial au thorities agreed to most of the psychiatrists demands.

title: McGovern Begins a FactFinding Tour of Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13Senator George Mc Govern, the only announced candidate for next year's Democratic Presidential nomi nation, arrived here today for three days of gathering facts and impressions on the United States involve ment in the Vietnam war. The South Dakota Senator, a longstanding critic of the American role in the war, said at a brief news confer ence that the Vietnam issue was entering a crucial stage owing to the with drawal of American troons and the forthcoming onemart Presidential elections here,

title: 4 Days of Attica Talks End in Failure
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 At 9:43:28 this morning the power went off in the small littered steward's room on the second floor of the Attica Correctional Facility's admin istration building.

title: U.N. Parley Plans a Global Environment Conference
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, Sept. 13Representatives from a score of countries today opened a twoweek meeting to plan the first global conference on environmental problems, to be held in Stockholm next June.

title: Boycott In Alabama
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 13 (UPI) Students boycotted classes in large numbers in the western section of Jefferson County to day and officials closed a Perry County school when blacks as signed to another school re fused t leave. There were no reports of violence in either area.

title: Council Rulings on WagePrice Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 13 Following is. Policy Statement No. 17 issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Governors Select Tahoe
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 13 (AP)The executive committee of the National Governors Con ference has selected Lake Ta hoe, Nev., as the site for the 1973 conference. The 1972 con ference will be in Houston.

title: City Surtax for a Free Fare Is Urged
description: A proposal for the total eli mination of fares on the city's bus and subway lines was heart ily endorsed yesterday by leg islators, labor representatives, community leaders and mem bers of seniorcitizen groups at a City Hall hearing.

title: 72 Season Still Up in Air At Jersey Amusement Park
description: FORT LEE, W. J., Sept. 13 A buildingcompany executive and a concessionaire met to day to discuss the possibility of keeping the Palisades Amusement Park open for an other season next year, but they announced no firm deci sion.

title: Belgrade Expects Brezhnev For Visit, First Since 66
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13The Soviet Communist party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, will arrive Sept. 22 for his first visit to Yugoslavia since 1966, reliable sources said today.

title: U.N. to Get Jackson Appeal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP)Georgia Jackson, mother of George Jackson, announced today that she would petition the United Nations to dnvesti gate the death of her son in what was reported as an escape attempt at San Quentin Prison on Aug. 21. Mrs. Jackson said she also would ask the world organization to investigate and protect the rights of prisoners in what she called the bar barons penal institutions of the state of California.

title: Florida Phone Concern Nullifies Dividend Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)The Florida Tele phone Corporation today agreed to roll back a divi end increase that had been sharply criticized by the Nixon Administration.

title: Gottehrer Quits Post At City Hall
description: Barry H. Gottehrer resigned yesterday as Mayor Lindsay's $30,000ayear troubleshooter specializing in averting street disturbances, or what City Hall officials called keeping the city cool.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On Sept, 7 you published a letter from Sidney Orenstein suggesting a new approach to the problems of maintaining the city's libraries, mu seums and other cultural and recrea tional facilities which have been hit by the city's financial drain by cre ating a Civil Service Corps to provide muchneeded help.

title: Jordan and Guerrillas Warned on Jidda Parley
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 13 Saudi Arabia and Egypt have warned Jordan and the Pales tinian guerrillas that measures will be taken against them if they fail to attend the reconcili ation conference now scheduled for Wednesday.

title: South Vietnamese Find 32 of Foe Dead At a Bombed Cache
description: SAIGON, South, Vietnam, Sept. 13 (Reuters) South Vietnamese troops found three fully loaded Sovietbuilt trucks and the bodies of 32 North Vietnamese after they moved into a Laotian border area that had been bombed by United States B52's, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said today.

title: LOSS OF $9MILLION SEEN BY ROCK ISLAND
description: CHICAGO, Sept, 13 (AP) The head of the Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad said today that the line expected $9million deficit in 1971.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Liberals who wish to penalize South Africa for its separate development policy by taking away its U.S. sugar quota seemingly break down into three categories:

title: REP. CONYERS SCORES MUSKIE ON BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) A leader of the Congressional Black Caucus denounced today Senator Edmund S. Muskie's statement that he would reject a Negro as a Vice Presidential candidate and started a cam paign to get the Democratic Presidential nomination for Mayor Carl Stokes of Cleveland.

title: IN THE NATION
description: ATTICA, N. Y.Broken glass under foot, piled barricaded tables, a faint lingering whiff of tear gas; and in the echoing darkness the still figures of men with heads swathed in towels to resemble Arab headdress: Right on, brother! someone murmurs.

title: Chinese Team in Cuba
description: HAVANA, Sept 13 (Reuters) A 12member Chinese table tennis team arrived here Satur day for a series of matches against Cuban teams, it was reported today.

title: ExAddicts Start to Clean Arcade of City Building
description: A fiveman team  all former heroin addictsbegan a doubleedged experimental program yesterday that in volved cleaning the dirten crusted north arcade of the 59yearold Municipal Build ing. No one could remember when the arcade had last been cleaned.

title: Medina Witness Admits Shooting Boy
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 13A witness at the murder trial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina testified today that it was lie and not the captain who killed a small boy during the slaying of civilians in an attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai in March, 1968.

title: CORNELIUS J. ABBOTT
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 13 Cornelius J. Abbott, retired executive vice president of Ford, Bacon and Davis, Inc., New York City management consultants, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived here.

title: Menahin and Szeryng In an Airport Concert
description: ROME, Sept. 13, (AP) Yehudi Menuhin and Henryk Szeryng, the violinists, traded violins and improvised a serenade when they met at Rome's international airport today.

title: U.S. Communist Party Sends Its Condolences
description: The Communist party of the United States said yes terday that its leaders had sent a cablegram expressing condolences on the death last Saturday of Nikita S. Khrushchev to the Soviet Communist party and to Mrs. Khrushchev.

title: PileUp of 200 Cars on English Superhighway Kills
description: THELWALL, England, Sept. 13 (AP)Two hundred automobiles and trucks smashed together in a patch of fog on a major Brit ish highway near this Cheshire town today.

title: Charlotte Is Quiet
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 13 (UPI)Charlotte and Mecklen County schools opened very smoothly today for their first full day of operation under revised version of a busing plan that was approved in a land mark Supreme Court decision.

title: Bridge:
description: Innovations in the mechan ics of duplicate procedure are almost as rare as finding something new in the theory of cardplay. Such an innova tion was noted Saturday at the opening of the Bergen Bridge Center, 1386 Queen Anne Road, Teaneck, N. J., which becomes one of the short list of clubs in the metropolitan area providing duplicate bridge every after noon and evening.

title: Japan House Here Opens With a Call For More Contact
description: Japan House, a new center for United StatesJapanese un derstanding, was officially opened here yesterday, with Prince Hitachi, the younger son of Emperor Hirohito, calling for closer peopletopeople con tact between the two coun tries.

title: After Six Sets Purchase
description: After Six, Inc, has purchased four men's apparel stores in the Philadelphia area from Botany Industries, Inc. for an undis closed amount of cash. The names of the stores, which will be transferred to After Six on Jan. 1, will be changed from Wm. H. Wanamaker to Mor ville, the name used by the four other After Six units in that area. Botany has three other Wm. H. Wanamaker stores in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, about which the company made no announcement,

title: New Traffic Rule in Effect
description: The Department of Traffic put a 1.23mile stretch of Broadway between Canal and 14th Streets under a new traf fic regulation yesterday morn ing. The regulation prohibits standing by all vehicles, except trucks loading and unloading, between 7 A.M. and 7 P.M. Mondays through Fridays on both sides of the roadway.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: 15,000 Protestors in Manila Urge End to Police Measures
description: MANILA, Sept. 13 (Reuters) About 15,000 demonstrators, including nuns, farmers, priests, students and workers, marched through Manila today to de mand an end to sweeping se curity measures imposed by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: DUNNING METHODS SCORED AT INQUIRY
description: Despite the truthlnlending and other recent laws, con sumer credit is still a con game with the deck stacked in favor of the bill collector, a variety of government officials, law yers and consumers told a Fed eral Trade Commission hearing yesterday.

title: SCIENTISTS URGE MORE BIRTH STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Five former Presidential science advisers and 22 American Nobel Prize winners have joined forces to urge major increases in re search on population problems and birth control methods.

title: Kennedy Praises British
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 13 (AP)Senator Edward M Kennedy praised Britain's state operated medical services today and said patients were receiv ing quality health treatment. The Massachusetts Democrat told a news conference that talk of quality treatment of pa tients was too frequently un true in terms of the United States. I am more impressed by the qualities of the system than by any weaknesses, he said.

title: Deaths
description: ALBERT5. ALBERT. Devoted father of Adele Schanapper, Lillian Gersonl, dear brother of Captain Ben Levy and adored grandfather. Services Wednesday 12:30 at Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels Queens Blvd. and 76 Rd., Forest Hills.

title: BUSINESS FAVORS U.S. PANEL TO RULE PAYPRICE POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 13  Spokesmen from the business community told President Nixon today that the next phase of the new economic strategy should be managed by the Fed eral Government, with the pri vate sector playing essentially an advisory role.

title: Basic Payments Deficit Hits $9Billion Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Paul A. Volcker, Under Secre tary of the Treasury, disclosed publicly today that the United States basic balanceofpay ments deficit reached an an nual rate of $9billion in the first half of 1971.

title: SENATE COALITION FIGHTS THE DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 An unusual coalition of Demo crats and Republicans mounted a drive in the Senate today to send the controversial Se lective Service legislation back to a SenateHouse conference committee, thus further delay ing extension of the draft.

title: TEACHERS ACCEPT LEVITTOWN PACT
description: LEVITTOWN, L. I., Sept. 13 A threeday strike by mem bers of the Levittown Teachers Association ended today when teachers voted unanimously to accept a new contract.

title: VOTE FOR HELP CAST BY TARIFF CHAIRMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The new chairman of the Tariff Commission, Catherine May Bedell, voted today in her first major case to grant relief to an industry claiming injury from imports.

title: For Mother and Child
description: The child development bill, passed by the Senate 49 to 12, offers to all American mothers the kind of daily care for their children that used to be uvailable only to the very rich, and more recently some of the very poor. The measure would underwrite the establishment of pro fessionally staffed daycare centers for preschool chil dren, free of charge for the poor and on a payasyoucan basis for middleclass families.

title: French Surplus Narrows
description: PARIS, Sept. 13 (Reuters) France's foreign trade surplus narrowed to 331 million francs during August from 962 million francs in July, the Finance Mind istry said today. Imports de clined to 7.3 billion francs dur ing the month from 9.2 billion in July, while exports dipped to 7.6 billion from 10.2 billion.

title: Knowles Will Head Rockefeller Fund; Lost Out on U.S. Job
description: Dr. John H. Knowles, the 45 yearold Massachusetts hospital administrator who was a con troversial candidate for the na tion's top health post in 1969, was named president of the Rockefeller Foundation yester day.

title: NASSAU IS CLOSER TO ATTAINING OTB
description: Nassau County moved a step closer to offtrack betting yesterday when its Board of Supervisors passed an enabling law that could take effect in 45 days.

title: Dr. Robert Dinegar Dies; Medical Director of News
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 13 Dr. Robert H. F. Dinegar, who was medical director of The New York Daily News for 35 years, died today in Jersey Shore Medical Center  Fitkin Memorial Hospital, Neptune, N. J. He was 76 years old and lived at 126 Davis Avenue.

title: Brooklyn Motorists Warned Of Shore Parkway Detour
description: The Trafic Department said yesterday that a detour has been set up for westbound motorists who normally use the Fourth Avenue Fort Hamilton exit from the Shore Parkway in Brooklyn. A sewer construc tion project that will close this exit for six to eight weeks is scheduled to begin tomorrow.

title: GINNY MAY ACCEPTS TANDEM PLAN BIDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  The Government National Mortgage Association accepted $48,188,900 worth of bids in the first auction under its new tandem plan to help maintain the 7. per cent F.H.A. interest rate, it was announced today.

title: U.S.China Telegraph Link
description: The Shanghai Telecommuni cations Administration advised RCA Global Communications, Inc., yesterday that it was set to restore direct international telegraph service between Main land China and the United States tomorrow at 8 P. M. Eastern Daylight Time. There after, the direct San Francisco Shanghai service will be opera ted on a daily basis.

title: Prison Officers Here Ask Stiffer Penalties for Inmates Who Riot
description: Presidents of the city's wa dens and correction officers associations called yesterday for legislation to make the tak ing of a hostage in a prison riot a crime punishable by life imprisonment.

title: DEATHS DECRIED; CRITICS DISAGREE
description: Public officials and private citizens reacted to the violent ending of the struggle at the Attica Correctional Facility yes terday, all deploring the deaths but assigning the blame vari ouslyto the inmates or to the state's correctional system.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Far under the surface of the daily shallow turbulence of the sports world, strong currents are being formed by several deep streams flowing together. The separate chan nels are the move of the football Giants to New Jersey, the merger of the two basketball leagues, the growing power of offtrack betting and support for legalized betting on all sports, the disposition of the Curt Flood case by the Supreme Court and the fate of the baseball Yankees.

title: ThreeSided Ulster Talks Will Be Held Sept. 2627
description: LONDON, Sept. 13The threesided talks on the crisis in Northern Ireland will take place at Chequers, the offi cial country home of Prime Minister Heath, on Sept. 26 and 27, it was announced here today.

title: 6 Finance Ministers Ask America to Devalue
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 13The European Common Market, in an assertive mood, temporarily buried its internal quarrels to day to confront the United States with a uniform set of demands, including devaluation of the dollar, to resolve the monetary crisis.

title: Advertising:
description: To outbag a bagger you've got to make a better bag. That was the simple but ef fective philosophy that pre vailed at General Foods about a year ago as Reynolds Metals introduced its Brown InBag into the New York market.

title: New Queens High School Opens Despite Protests From Parents
description: Dr. Daniel Salmon was mid wife yesterday to the birth of a high school. And the short, stocky principal presided with the steady aplomb that is es sential to the task.

title: PIANIST STIRS IRE IN CONCERT SERIES
description: BRUEL, West Germany, Sept. 13Friedrich Gulda, the tem peramental Austrian pianist, last night completed what seemed to be his first and last concert appearance in the fa mous old Augustusburg Castle here.

title: LifeInsurance Rise Seen;
description: A sharp rise in life insurance over the next five years was predicted yesterday by Herbert F. Mischke, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters.

title: Dr. Leary Writes of Escape From Jail
description: Dr. Timothy Leary, the for mer Harvard psychologist turned guru of the LSD cult ists, has written a narrative describing his escape from a California prison a year ago and how he eluded the Federal Bureau of Investigation to find a sanctuary in Algeria.

title: Nuclear Desalting Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Commissioner James T. Ra mey of the Atomic Energy Commission called today for worldwide effort to develop nu clear desalting technology with in the next 20 years,

title: Rockefeller's Office Here Is Picketed Over Attica
description: A crowd of demonstrators, carrying red, flags and signs condemning Governor Rockefel ler as a murderer for yester days events in Attica, appeared last night outside the Gover nor's office at 22 West 55th Street.

title: U.S.I.A. COVERAGE ON AID DEFENDED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The director of the United States Information Agency said today that if the decision had been up to him, he would have broadcast editorials on a Con gressional move to suspend American military aid to Greece. The broadcast of editorials was prepared but not used early in August by the Voice of Amer ica.

title: U.S. Court to Study Bids for Beck Units At Friday Hearing
description: A hearing in Federal Court here is scheduled for Friday to consider three written offers and any others that may still be made for the assets of Beck Industries, Inc., the financially troubled conglomerate.

title: List of 9 Killed By the Prisoners
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 (UPI)Following is a list of five guards and four civilian employes killed by rebelling prisoners at Attica State Prison:

title: Death Penalty Possible In Slaying of Hostages
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13 (AP) Inmates responsible for the killing of hostages at the Attica Correctional Facility will be liable to, death penalty under New York State Law.

title: Sharp Rise in Bond Rates Slices Into Recent Decline
description: Interest rates on highgrade corporate and tax  exempt bonds shot dramatically higher yesterday, wiping out roughly half the decline in yields that took place between President Nixon's two recent addresses on the economy.

title: Statement by Commissioner Oswald
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 Following is the text of a statement issued by State Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald at 10:40 A.M. today:

title: MEANY CONDEMNS NIXON'S TAX PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 George Meany said today that President Nixon's tax relief pro gram was based on the same doctrine of inequality that, in Mr. Meany's view, the Presi dent's antiinflation program is based on.

title: GEORGETOWN U. BANS STUDENTS MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Georgetown University Law School banned today a planned meeting by students that would have required Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to compete for listeners with William M. Kunstler, the civil rights lawyer, when the Chief Justice dedi cates the Law School's new building next Friday.

title: Man in the News
description: At 9:46 A.M. yesterday, the voice of a tall, blueeyed, crewcut state police captain crackled over a short wave radio to the army of state troopers, sheriff's deputies and prison guards massed for the final assault on the rebels of the Attica Correc tional Facility. Move in, he shouted. Move in. All through the morning, the voice of Henry F. Williams coun seled the tactics of the bloody campaign to wrest control of the institu tion from its inmates.

title: NIXON PANEL ASKS FREE TRADE MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13A Presidential commission, calling for a new realism in the na tion's foreign economic and trade policy, said today that the time has come to begin immediately a major series of international negotiations With the Longterm aim of elim ination of all barriers to in ternational trade and capital movements within 25 years.

title: C. &N. W. ROAD BARS I.C.C.'S SALE TERNS
description: Larry S. Provo, president of both the Chicago & North Western Railway and the Northwestern Employes Trans portation Corporation, an em ploye cooperative formed to acquire the railway, said yester day that the railway's present owner, Northwest Industries, Inc., had found unacceptable conditions recommended by an Interstate Commerce Commis sion examiner for the sale.

title: SAIGON MAY ADD DIVISION TO ARMY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13The South Vietnam ese Army is considering a plan to form a new 13,000man di vision and to send it to the northern provinces to counter the serious Communist threat below the demilitarized zone, informed American sources said today.

title: STOCK PRICES SAG AS VOLUME FALLS
description: The stock market beat a modest retreat yesterday amid the uncertainty about phase two of the new economic program.

title: Britain's Trade Surplus Gained Sharply in August
description: LONDON, Sept. 13Britain reported today another strong trade performance, with an ex ceptionally high surplus in August equivalent to $163mil lion. The surplus is the differ ence between the value of goods exported and goods im ported.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. to consider application of Qatar for membership.

title: Texts of Tributes Paid to Khrushchev at His Funeral
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13Fol lowing are the texts of funeral orations for Nikita S. Khrushchev delivered by his son, Sergei; by Nadezhda Dimanshtein, an Old Bolshe vik, and by Vadim Vasilyev, son of a Communist official executed in the Stalin purges, as monitored and translated by The New York Times at Novodevichye Cemetery here:

title: $250,000 Bail in Drug Case
description: United States Magistrate Max Schiffman set bail at $250,000 yesterday for a Colombian bar maid charged with trying to smuggle five and a half pounds of cocaine into the United States. The woman, arrested at Kennedy International Airport, was identified in Brooklyn Fed eral Court as Nelli Restrepo, 28 years old, a barmaid at the Jai Alai Club in Barranquilla. She allegedly arrived on Avianca Flight 58.

title: Producers Cool to 8 P.M. Curtain
description: David Merrick's shift from Broadway's 7:30 P.M. curtain time to an 8 o'clock start for Promises, Prom ises, produced no followers yesterday.

title: More Unthinkable Thoughts: II
description: PARISIn my article yesterday suggested that the United States end the 10 per cent surcharge on imports and raise the price of gold to $38.50 an ounce in return for the Japanese, Germans, French, British and Canadi ans respectively setting their currencies at 300 yen to the dollar, three marks to the dollar, five francs to the dollar, four pounds to the dollar and .95 Ca nadian dollar to the dollar.

title: NUSKIE IS MISSED BY JERSEY TARTY
description: FLORHAM PARK, N. J., Sept. 13Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine didn't come here to day and that made New Jer sey's Democratic state chair man furious. No one here ever expected Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts to show up, even though he had been invited along with Mr.

title: Advertising:
description: The country's first cor rective advertising will break on television this week courtesy of ITT Continental Bakeries, the Federal Trade Commission and Ted Bates & Co.

title: No Comment by U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reu ters)The Treasury declined to comment today on the agree ment by Common Market fi nance ministers to press for a devaluation of the dollar. The Administration has frequently said in recent weeks that it is not prepared to raise the offi cial $35 price of gold.

title: SAIGON GROUP SAYS VOTES WERE RIGGED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13 (AP)A legislative committee studying charges of irregularities in the election last month announced today that it would recommend to the Senate that results in 10 prov inces be invalidated and new elections held.

title: Frank Robinson Hits 500th Career Homer
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (UPI) Frank Robinson of the Orioles, became the 11th man in baseball history to hit 500 career homers tonight when he hit nos. 499 and 500. The feat came as Baltimore beat Detroit 91, and then lost 105.

title: Facility at Attica Among the State's Newer Prisons
description: Less than a week before the riot started at Attica prison, Corrections Commissioner Rus sell G. Oswald chose the in stitution as the place to an nounce a vast program to im prove conditions In the state's 16 prisons.

title: Rainouts Cause Conflicts For Newconlbe, Others
description: Surrounded by a series of conflicts that thicken with each new raindrop, the Uited States Open tennis champions will try again today to complete the last two days of the tourna ment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Leading figures in government and business are persuaded that some form of wage and price controls will be necessary after the ninetyday freeze ends.

title: Connally Hints Price Controls After 90Day Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally indicated today that price controls in some form would be continued after the expiration of the current 90day wageprice freeze.

title: Primary Vote Today
description: The hope of machine politicians in any primary elec tion is for a light total vote, thus insuring nominations controlled by the welldisciplined turnout of organization stalwarts. The danger of such a distortion of the electoral process is particularly strong in an offyear primary, like the one New York City is holding from 3 P.M. to 10 P.M. today, in which only a few offices are at stake.

title: Despite Violence Within Prison Walls, Town of Attica Maintains an Air of Serenity
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 13 This was a day of blood in this village of 2,875 inhabitants, a day that will be remembered here for decades. Yet there was much that belied it, much that spoke of rural tranquillity, too.

title: Budget Cutback in the City's Schools Felt by Teachers, Pupils and Parents
description: Bonnie Sheppard, a young art teacher, had some bad news for 32 youngsters in her sixthgrade class at Public 130 yesterday morning.

title: StarStudded Program Pays Homage to Young
description: A celebritysprinkled audi ence and a glittering roster of onstage personalities made a festive occasion of Sunday eve ning's Tribute Concert to Whitney M. Young Jr. The Philharmonic Hall program, which also served as a benefit for the Urban League (of which Mr. Young was the executive director until his death earlier this year), went with the clock work efficiency of a television special.

title: Anniversaries
description: LOBSENZCongratulations to our Mom & Dad, Henrietta & Benlamin Lobsenz on their Slot wedding anniversary Love from their children Sylvia & Leonard.

title: Cunard to Offer CutRate Atlantic Cruises on QE2
description: LONDON, Sept. 13  The Cunard SteamShip Company, Ltd., will withdraw from the Atlantic passenger steamship conference and offer cutrate cruises on the luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2.

title: Merger News
description: Directors of the Easco Cor poration and the Arundel Cor poration announced yesterday that they had agreed in prin ciple for Easco to acquire Arundel through an exchange of stock valued at $40million.

title: Pope Revises the Rite of Confirmation
description: ROME, Sept. 13Pope Paul VI changed the ritual of con firmation, one of the seven sac raments of the Roman Catholic Church, in a decree published today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES OFF 6.5C A BUSHEL
description: Prices of soybean futures dropped 6.5 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Turner Gains World Title By Taking 5.5Meter Race
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 13  Ted Turner, sailing Tiger, clinched the world 5:5meter sailing championship today by winning the seventh and final race in driving rain on Long Island Sound.

title: Leningrad Goes Wild Over the Duke
description: LENINGRAD, Sept. 13The applause began before the cur tain went up on CJam Blues and kept on after 45 minutes of encores capped by Take the A Train at the opening tonight of Duke Ellington's fiveweek tour of the Soviet Union.

title: THOMAS F. WELCH
description: Thomas Francis Welch, a copy writer for Charles W. Reardon Associates, Inc., ad vertising, died Sunday of hep atitis in Jacobi Hospital, the Bronx. His age was 52.

title: COLUMNIST'S DATA SOUGHT BY HEARST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Hearst Corporation, deny ing that a journalist's consti tutional rights are involved, is pressing a hearing examiner for the Federal Trade Commission to enforce a contested subpoena.

title: On Behalf of Capital Punishment
description: MONTREALThe confident asser tion that the death penalty serves no useful purpose and that imprison ment offers a more satisfactory method of dealing with the problem of murder is contradicted by a number of selfevident facts.

title: Price Rules and Guideline
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Following are the texts of Policy Statement No. 18 is sued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices, and the text of the council's Dividend Guideline No. 2:

title: Pilot Tells Colonel's Trial of Mylai Dead
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 14 An Army helicopter pilot testified today that he had flown over the devastated South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 the day after civilians were killed in an infantry at tack in 1968 and had seen bodies still lying where they fell.

title: Taiwan's Foreign Minister Will Confer With Rogers
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Sept. 15 (AP)Foreign Minister Chow Shukai said today he would meet Thursday in Wash ington with Secretary of State William P. Rogers on his way to the United Nations. Their talks presumably will deal with Taiwan's coming fight to save its United Nation seat.

title: Ali to Meet Foster Nov. 29 In 15Round Bout in Tokyo
description: Muhammad All and Mac Fos ter are scheduled to meet in a 15round bout in the 14,000 seat indoor Budokan Stadium in Tokyo on Nov. 29. This was revealed yesterday at a news conference in the Benihana Palace restaurant, 15 West 44th Street, by Yoskio Kou, the promoter, and Rocky Aoki of the Prime Organization Inter national Company, Ltd., which is sponsor of the bout.

title: 10Day Car Sales Soared; Business Inventories Rise
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14New car sales soared far above the yearago level in the first third of September with at least some of the gains credited to growing consumer confidence resulting from Presi dent Nixon's New Economic Policy. The General Motors Corporation reported its deal ers had sold 94,285 United States type cars Sept. 1 to 10, up 37.6 per cent from 68,510 a year before.

title: JAPAN FEARS HARM FROM U. S. MOVES
description: Japan faces a 6 per cent de cline in real economic growth during its next fiscal year and a $1.7billion drop in exports to the United States as a result of this country's import sur charge and the subsequent floating of the yen, American and Japanese business leaders were told here yesterday.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILS U.S. ON GUN LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Mayor Lindsay, flanked by po lice officials, assailed the Fed eral Government today, for gross permissiveness and gross negligence in failing to adopt restrictive controls on the sale and possession of hand guns.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Lincoln Savings Bank announced, yester day that Fred Gretsch Jr., chairman, has been elect ed chief executive officer of the Brooklyn based savings bank, the nation's ninth largest with assets of over $1.25billion. Edward S. Backnick Jr., formerly executive vice president and mortgage officer, was elected pres ident. Mr. Gretsch, presi dent of the Fred Gretsch Company, Inc., maker of musical instruments, has been associated with the bank for many years. He was elected a trustee in 1942, vice president in 1953 and chairman in 1963. Mr. Backnick, prior to joining Lincoln Savings in 1960, served in the real estate department of the Chase Manhattan Bank. The positions of president and chief executive officer were previously held by the late Edmond G. Murphy.

title: Screen: 'Anonymous Venetian' Bows
description: Enrico (Tony Musante), an oboe player who aspires to be a conductor, and Valeria (Florinda Bolkan) have been married for 11 years and estranged for the last eight. After a long silence, Enrico summons Valeria from Ferrara, where she lives with their son and her rich, elderly lover, to Venice, where their love was born and died and where, in the course of one day, it's born again.But, alas, it's too late: Enrico is dying.As Enrico puts it more than once, he is like Venice, which is not strictly true. He isn't sinking into the mud. Hs has a rather conventional movie brain tumor."The Anonymous Venetian," an English-language Italian romantic drama, is death warmed overand talked outin Venice, along its canals, aboard its gondolas, in its piazzas and in front of its churches. It was directed and partially written by Enrico Maria Salerno and you're willing to think a bit, it's bad enough to be quite funny.I especially liked Enrico's recollection: "Do you remember how we used to read Proust together? His observations were always so witty and delicately phrased. . . ." There also is something appealing about the manner in which Salerno inevitably mangles a sublime clich, as when Enrico and Valeria return to the picturesque little restaurant where they used to dine as lovers."What do you have?" Valeria, as if in a dream, asks the waiter. Replies the waiter, with a straight face: "Spaghetti with meat sauce, spaghetti with clam sauce, spaghetti with. . . ." It's a Billy Gilbert scene without Billy Gilbert.Both Musante and Miss Bolkan have done creditable work in other films, but here one is pretty much limited to evaluating the cuts of their jaws, which are square and desperately determined. The movie opened yesterday at the Plaza, and by the end of it, I felt rather embarrassed, like the eye of Salerno's camera, which often can't bring itself to watch a scene directly but, periodically, just sort of collapses into a canal, where it studies the reflections.

title: NIXON NAMES PANEL ON PUBLIC HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) President Nixon announced today a new 15member Presi dential Committee on Health Education to recommend better ways to educate the public on how to keep well.

title: PAYMENTS SURPLUS FOR CANADA SHRINKS
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 14 (Cana dian Press)Canada's unusual balance  of  payments surplus, which ran to extraordinary heights last year, tapered off in April, May and June, fresh sta tistics on the economy's per formance show.

title: Nader Criticizes U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) Ralph Nader charged today that Federal officials were lull consumers into a false sense of security by not disclosing all the dangers of eating food contaminated by chemicals. He expressed concern about human consumption of chemicals acci dentally leaked into processed food and chemicals added to food as tenderizers or dyes.

title: Old Masters Are Replaced by Young MastersTemporarily
description: One ramp above Cezanne's The Clockmaker where a Dubuffet once hung, Eric Addison's painting of an eye done in brilliant colors stares unabashedly at strolling art connoisseurs in the Guggen heim Museum.

title: Merger News
description: Husky Oil, Ltd., announced yesterday that its directors had approved in principle a plan to acquire through a shareex change tender offer the re maining 45 per cent of the Empire State Oil Company that it did not already own. Husky Oil said it planned to exchange 1.125 shares of its common stock for each of the shares of Em pire State it did not own. Based on the closing price of Husky Oil on the American Stock Exchange yesterday of 18 the transac tion was valued at approxi mate more than $17million.

title: Bee Gees Do All Their Disk Hits at Philharmonic
description: You can't help but like the Bee Gees. Like themnot love them, that is. They look so haberdasheryneat and straightarrow, so intensely eager to please, that you ac cept them on that basis, de spite the limits of their musical gifts.

title: Nixon to Talk on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) President Nixon will explain his new plan for the economy Sept. 23 when he speaks to the Detroit Economic Club, the White House announced today. Gerald L. Warren, deputy press secretary, said that although details of the appearance were not completed, the President would probably answer ques tions.

title: New Rains Snarl Traffic as Mayor Asks Disaster Aid
description: A downpour that continued on and off through the day and evening spilled 3.76 inches of rain on the metropolitan area yesterday, snarling service on the East Side IRT subway and stalling eastbound auto traffic on the George Washington Bridge.

title: MARIENNE F. CHATIN, FESTIVAL TRUSTEE
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 14 Mrs. Marienne Francks Chat in, a trustee of the American Shakespeare Festival, Theater here, died yesterday while visit ing its president, Joseph Ver ner Reed. Sr. She, was 68 years old and had hemes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Williamstown, Mass.

title: Stennis Warns of a Crisis if Draft Bill Isn't Passed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Senator John. C. Stennis, chair man of the Armed Services Committee, said today that the military services faced a man power crisis because of expira tion of the draft. He urged the Senate to pass legislation that would allow conscription to be resumed.

title: Mrs. Marjorie M. Appleby Is Wed
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 14Mrs. Marjorie Mea cham Appleby, daughter of Mrs. Edgar A. Eyre of New York and Palm Beach and of the late Malcolm Meacham of Memphis, was married here at noon today to Sam uel W. Meek Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., vice president of the North eastern Industrial Park, Inc., in Albany.

title: Pullout Assurance Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 The United States commander in South Vietnam, Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, re portedly assured Senator Mc Govern today that under the Vietnamization plan no United States ground forces or air power would be left in Vietnam to support Saigon's army.

title: Time Ran Out for Oswald As He Planned Reforms
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 14  Russell G. Oswald, who pledged last spring to turn around New York's state prison sys tem, was an exhausted, agon ized man tonight as he ap peared with bleary eyes at an unusual news conference.

title: U.S. Apparel Industry Seeking Pay Rise for More Productivity
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Will the domestic apparel in dustry's 1.5 million employes  one of the largest labor groups in the nation  lose their motivation under the Nixon wageprice freeze?

title: PostFreeze Fog
description: Industry and labor have given President Nixon ideas that are nearly 180 degrees apart on what type of stabilization machinery ought to come after the present ninetyday freeze on wages, prices and rents. The same polarization exists on what tax changes Congress ought to authorize to revive the economy and restore full employment.

title: For National Symphony, an Optimistic Key
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The National Symphony Or chestra has turned the corner, and a measure of the credit belongs to the John F. Ken nedy Center for the Perform ing Arts and to President Nixon.

title: Monetary Repairmen to Meet Today
description: LONDON, Sept. 14With a name suggesting more the world of espionage than that of high finance, members of the G10, or Group of Ten, have been dashing about the world for a decade to shore up the international monetary system.

title: Social Security Rise Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, intro duced a bill today to increase Social Security payments by 5 per cent. Senator Gurney's pro posed legislation would also lower the age at which a man can receive benefits to 62 from 65, increase the amount aged persons can earn while receiv ing Social Security from $1,600 to $3,000 and expand the Medi care program.

title: Thousands Evacuated
description: CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 14 (UPI) The number of persons evac uated in the fourcounty Phila delphia area ran into the thou sands. Many persons were res cued from roofs and trees where they had climbed to escape the rising water that reached the second stories of many homes.

title: Reapportionment Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The House Judiciary Commit tee approved today a bill sug gesting that Feb. 1, 1972, be set or a deadline for states to reapportion Congressional dis tricts to reflect results of the 1970 Census. The measure, still subject to amendment before final committee vote Thursday, lays down guidlines for hasten Ing reapportionment and guard ing, against political gerry mandering of districts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On the Aug. 27 OpEd page Roger Wilkins wrote an eloquent eulogy of George Jackson, the black convict shot down in San Quentin's prison yard.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Herbert X. Blyden
description: From the crowd of desperate men at Attica, Herbert X. Bly den emerged as one of the most eloquent spokesmen for the prisoner revolt.

title: Bank Holding Venture Set
description: The Security Pacific Nation al Bank, Los Angeles, an nounced yesterday its intention to form a onebank holding company. Security, the nation's ninthlargest hank, is the last of the nation's 20 largest banks to propose or form a holding company to take over its ownership.

title: Smith, Kodes Gain Tennis Final
description: Stan Smith, the big Army private, will attempt to prevent Jan Hodes of Czechoslovakia from making a complete joke today of the men's singles in the United States Open tennis championships.

title: Dennison Asks Reorganization Of Suffolk Welfare Department
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept 14 Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison today proposed a Major reorganization of the county Welfare Department. He proposed splitting the depart ment into two separate agencies and slashing 138 jobs instead of approving the addition of 70 persons to the staff as request ed by the county's Social Serv ices Commissioner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We urge the defeat of Rockefeller's transportation bond issue to be voted upon in the next election. Our organi zation, Road Review League, repre sents several hundred concerned citi zens in northern Westchester County and feels that the bond issue as now drawn up will not be in the public in terest.

title: Give the Ching a Ring
description: The first tool I would like to point out here is the Bible. All of it. All the rest of your life. I won't list an address where to send for it. You can pick one up yourself, look in the top drawer of the next motel desk you come across if need be. It's nice to have your own, too. Get familiar with it and its drama. Take your time. Get a purple satin bookmark and keep your place and ease through a chapter or two before you go to sleep (it'll wipe the slate of your mind clean of Lever Brothers and you'll dream like Milton), or just cut in here and there now and then during the day, in a little quiet place with a bit of hash and some camomile tea with honey and lemon in it. A little at a time, steadfastly, and maybe a big hit once every week or so, for instance, on Saturday (for the Old Testament) and Sunday (far the New). Keep it up a while. You'll be amazed.

title: O'Horgan Teams With Kipness And Kasha to Stage Inner City
description: Joseph Kipness, Lawrence Kasha and Tom O'Horgan have joined forces to produce Inner City, a new musical based on Eve Merriam's The Inner City Mother Goose, a series of poems dealing with the perils and pleasure of city life.

title: A New Reform Era
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14To be a healthy nation, a strong nation, we need also restore the health of our government institutions, President Nixon told Congress the other day.

title: Discouraged About Peace, Sadat Says
description: CAIRO, Sept. 14President Anwar elSadat said today that he still favored a peaceful set tlement of the conflict with Is rael but indicated that he was discouraged about the chances for one.

title: Lefkowitz Hints He May Seek Indictments on Accounting Methods
description: State Attorney General Lou is J. Lefkowitz indicated yes terday that he would seek crim inal indictments as a result of an investigation into the ac counting practices used for Wall Street brokerage firms.

title: 44 SENATORS SEND APPEAL TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)  Fortyfour Senators 10 of them Republicans disclosed today that they had written to President Nixon to warn him that thousands of poor children would go hungry unless he changed new regulations for the school lunch program.

title: Communes in Canada Government Lends Hand With Grants
description: VANCOUVER, British ColumbiaUrban and rural communes have been thriving in this West Coast province for several years. But this is the first summer that some have been subsidized by the Ca nadian Government.

title: Charles Goingto Navy School
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland, Sept. 14 (UPI)Prince Charles, al ready a Royal Air Force pilot and a parachutist, ended summer vacation today and left Belmoral Castle near here to begin training as a Royal Navy officer. The heirapparent to the British throne enters Dartmouth Naval College to morrow.

title: Lockheed Gets First U.S.Backed Loan, for $50Million
description: A consortium of 24 banks yesterday lent the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation the first $50million against a possible $250million credit that the Federal Treasury has guaran teed it will make good should the big defense contractor be come bankrupt.

title: EXCITY AIDE GETS YEAR FOR BRIBERY
description: Eugene L. Sugarman, a for mer deputy city controller con Acted of 11 counts of receiving bribes and taking unlawful fees totaling $88,000, was sentenced yesterday in Manhattan Su preme Court to one to four years in prison.

title: DR, CHARLES B. KIELER
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 14Dr. Charles Benedict Kiel er, senior surgeon of the Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital and a diplomate of the American Board of Otolaryngology, died in the hospital today. He was 63 years old.

title: MIDONICK WINS SURROGATE POST
description: The Reform Democrats scored a major victory yesterday when their candidate, Family Court Judge Millard L. Midonick, de feated Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer, the organiza tion choice, for the party nomination for Manhattan Sur rogate in yesterday's primary.Complete returns from the county's 1,076 election districts gave the 57yearold Reformer 26,723 votes to 19,101 for Jus tice Backer, a margin of 7,622.The apathy that had marked the tepid campaign was re flected in the turnout with only about 12 per cent of the conuty's 415,000 enrolled Demo crats bothering to vote.

title: DETENTION CAMPS OPPOSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The House voted today to re peal a neverused law that gives the Federal Government authority to put suspected spies or saboteurs into detention camps during time of war or insurrection.

title: Feminists Halt Session on Prostitution, Demanding to Be Heard
description: Militant feminists pressed for reform of the prostitution laws yesterday by briefly interrupt ing a state legislative hearing and giving the first formal pres entation of their position on the issue to members of the Legis lature.

title: Pilot Dies in Copter Crash
description: MILLER'S TAVERN, Va., Sept. 14 (AP)A small helicopter en gaged in crop dusting crashed in a bean field two miles east of Miller's Tavern today, killing the pilot. Identification of the pilot was withheld pending notification of next to kin.

title: BLACK GIRL GETS MARTYR'S RITES
description: BUTLER, Ala,. Sept. 14  A black girl killed by a white man's car was given a mar tyr's funeral here today, and civil rights leaders laid plans for a massive campaign in this community.

title: Attica Reaction Widens; Prison Reform Proposed
description: Reaction from public officials and private citizens to the vio lent events at Attica took on a new dimension yesterday, broadening into general criti cisms of conditions in penal institutions throughout the country.

title: ST. LOUIS BROKER IS CITED BY S.E.C.
description: The brokerdealer registration of DempseyTegeler & Co. of St. Louis has been revoked by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: An Appraisal
description: The 115 works of art mostly paintings, with a group of graphics and a sprinkling of sculptures from the collection of the Chase Manhattan Bank now on exhibition at Finch Col lege represent about one out of every 15 works purchased by the bank since it became an art patron in 1959. They are a very sleek group indeed, and at this particular point in the de velopment of American art they afford a miniature sur veywithout being a census of a dominant trend of the nineteensixties.

title: Man in the News
description: When Dr. John Frederic Edland is feeling efferves cent, when he is in the mood for linguine with white clam sauce or a victory by his be loved football Giants, he wears his rimless eyeglasses.

title: Findings Shock Families of Hostages
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 14 Reactions from families of slain hostages to reports that they had died of bullet wounds and not by the knives of prisoners ranged today from angry disbelief to an accusation that authori ties had recklessly risked the hostages lives in ordering the assault at the state prison.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Consumers. The President appointed three new mem bers and reappointed three others to twoyear terms on the Consumer Advisory Coun cil. New members are Solo mon Harge of Cleveland, executive director of the Con sumer Protection Agency; Attorney General Gary K. Nelson of Arizona; and Mrs. Oscar C. Sowards of Pike ville, Ky., diairman of the Citizens Commission for Con sumer protection. Reappoint ed were Jacob Clayman of Bethesda, Md.; Wilma T. Don ahue of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Stewart Lee Richardson Jr., of Baton Rouge, La.

title: Victories in Primaries Go To Rossetti and Midonick
description: Frank G. Rossetti, the Manhattan Democratic leader, retained his East Harlem district leadership, the keystone of his political power, in yesterday's Democratic primary.

title: Carlson Backs Move
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Norman A. Carlson, the director of the United States Bureau of Prisons, endorsed today Gov ernor Rockefeller's stand again granting amnesty to prisoners who rioted at the Attica Cor rectional Facility.

title: Museum Gets a Sideline
description: LONDON (Canadian Press) The British Museum has gone into the jewelry business to raise revenue and provide good quality souvenirs. One of its best sellers is a $2.50 gilt brooch reproducing a Roman embossed head of Medusa, the mythological lady with snakes instead of hair.

title: Thant Expects ChinaIssue Solution at This Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.Sept. 14Secretary General Thant said today that he accepted as a firm statement of policy Communist China's declaration of Aug. 20 that it would refuse to take a seat in the United Nations as long as the Chinese Nationalist Government on Tai wan remained a member.

title: U.S. Dumping Inquiry Set On Japanese TV Tubes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 14 (AP) The Customs Bureau has be gun an investigation to deter mine whether color television tubes imported from Japan are being sold in the United States at less than market value.

title: U. S. Cardiologists in China
description: KANSAS CITY, 1VIo., Sept. 14 (AP) Two prominent Ameri can cardiologists and their wives arrived in China yester day, officials at the University of MissouriKansas City have been informed.

title: ARGENTINA BANS IMPORTS IN CRISIS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 14 The Argentine Government has banned all imports in a move to halt an outflow of hard cur rency and avert a balanceof payments crisis.

title: Advertising:
description: I think most people think we're nuts, said Irwin Barnett, whodespite the bleak ad vertising picturehas joined with Bernie Zlotnick to start a new ad agency.

title: PRICES OFF AGAIN IN BOND MARKET
description: Bond prices declined yester day, continuing the trend to ward higher interest rates that began last Thursday with Pres ident Nixon's address to Con gress.

title: Study of Adolescents Confirms Some Beliefs on Marijuana Use
description: A survey based on a na tional sampling of adolescents has confirmed several beliefs about marijuana use, among them that it is most common in the West and Northeast among middle and upperin come youths from metropolitan areas.

title: AUTOPSIES SHOW SHOTS KILLED 9 ATTICA HOSTAGES NOT KNIVES; STATE OFFICIAL ADMITS MISTAKE
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 14The nine hostages killed in the up rising in the Attica Correctional Facility died of bullet wounds, it was reported today after of ficial autopsies.

title: Business Inventories Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Total business inventories rose $420million in July, slightly more than the $320million in ventory accumulation in June, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Three Parties Open Ontario Campaign; Election Is Oct. 21
description: TORONTO, Sept. 14  A threeway election campaign be began today for control of On tario, Canada's most populous and wealthiest province.

title: Jets Clear 2 Players On Injured Waiver List
description: Weeb Ewbank, the New York Jets coach and general manager, announced yester day that the two players placed on the injured waivers list two days ago, W. K. Hicks, a safetyman, and Dave Foley, an offensive tackle, had both cleared.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS PANEL ON INMATES
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday that a dis tinguished panel of impartial visitors would be named to see that the constitutional rights of prisoners were pro tected during this transitional period at the Attica Correc tional Facility.?

title: METS 63 VICTORS OVER EXPOS HERE AFTER 121 LOSS
description: The smallest crowd of the year in Shea Stadium saw the New York Mets divide a double header with the Montreal Expos yesterday, and the chief gain for the Mets was that they finally saw the last of Rusty Staub until 1972.

title: Inmates in Baltimore Jail Stage a Brief Rebellion
description: Prisoners staged a brief re bellion yesterday in the Balti more City Jail, and prisoner activity was restricted in many penal institutions as an after math to the violence and dis orders at Attica Prison.

title: Purported Hughes Letter Says He Backs Reorganization Plan
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 14 A letter purportedly from Howard Hughes has assured Nevada state gaming authori ties that Mr. Hughes supports moves to reorganize the cor poration that operates his $300 million Nevada gambling em pire.

title: Economic Ministers Are Facing a Rough Monetary Confrontation in the Group of 10 Meeting in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 14  The Economic and Finance Minis ters and central bankers from 10 of the richest countries started arriving here today for what may well be one of the roughest monetary confronta tions since World War II.

title: NASA Names Official
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)Lee R. Scherer, director of scientific aspects of the Apollo lunar exploration pro gram, was appointed today as director of the National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion's Flight Research Center, Edwards, Calif.

title: SOOTHSAYER WINS BELMONT HURDLES
description: Of the six horses in yester day's $22,350 Broad Hollow Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park, Soothsayer looked like the least likely to succeed.

title: AMEX FALLS AGAIN AS TRADING. RISES Losers Outpace Winners by More Than 2to1 Ratio
description: The American Stock Ex change posted its fourth con secutive loss yesterday as the list declined in steppedup trad ing.

title: GIANTS DROP KOY, SHY AND 4 OTHERS
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 14 Ernie Koy, with six seasons under his belt playing in New York, was one of six players put on irrevocable waivers yes terday as the Giants trimmed down to their required 40 player limit.

title: US. EAR SURGEON ARRIVES IN CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 14Dr. Samuel Rosen, a 74yearold New York City ear specialist who two decades ago devised an operation that cures one kind of deafness, left here for China today to demonstrate his oper ation and study developments in the treatment of hearing de ficiencies in China.

title: Wheeler Golf Postponed
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 14Rain today caused post ponement of the Women's Tri County Golf Association's Eli zabeth Wheeler Trophy tourna ment for the open championship of Fairfield and Weschester Counties.

title: JOSEPH A. M'FADDEN OF CHEMICAL BANK
description: Joseph A. McFadden, retired executive vice president of the Chemical Bank, died Monday in House of Calvary Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 527 Highland Avenue, Ridge wood, N.J.

title: Israel Building Prototype For a Jet FighterBomber
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 14The Israeli's are designing and put ting together three prototypes of their own jetfighterbomber, according to well  placed sources here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Chicago Cubs appear in town tonight and Leo Durocher is still the manager, Ron Santo still the captain, Milt Pappas still the player representative and Philip K. Wrigley still the owner. But behind that fourthplace facade, they are a house divided and everybody inside and out is waiting to see what Wrigley decides: Who stays, who goes for 1972.

title: Hospital in Washington Again Reduces Its Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The District of Columbia's larg est voluntary hospital today est voluntary hospital reduced its charges for the second time in just over two months today in a move that is believed to be without comparable national precedent in recent years.

title: Lack of Data on Inmates Fates Scored by Prisoners Families
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 14The families of 16 Attica prisoners complained today that they had been unable to get state cor rection officials to tell them whether their husbands, fathers, brothers and sons were dead or alive, injured or well in the aftermath of the police assault on the prison yesterday.

title: George Huddleston, 51, Dies; Served Alabama in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) George Huddleston, a Wash ington lobbyist who had served 10 years in the House of Repre sentatives as a Democrat from Alabama died of a heart attack in his office today. He was 51 years old.

title: Lawrence Fleishman, 71, Dies; Chief of Customs Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) Lawrence Fleishman, a gang buster for the Treasury Depart ment during Prohibition, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: 2 SOLDIERS KILLED IN ULSTER CLASHES
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, Sept. 15 (AP) Two British soldiers were shot dead and five were wounded in gun battles that flared through scattered areas of Northern Ireland last night and early to day.

title: Delay at Indian Point
description: Unexpectedly cool weather has spared New York City major breakdowns in its electrical power, supply thus far this summer. But power cuts and failures remain a constant threat until adequate capacity can be assured through activation of new generators. Purchase of power from other sources becomes increasingly difficult now that the shortage has become a national problem. Local plants are obsolescent and overburdened. Big Allis is being nursed along, but at the cost of running the giant generator at less than full capacity.

title: Canada Not Seeking Devaluation of U.S. Dollar
description: TORONTO, Sept, 14Mitchell W. Sharp, Minister of External Affairs, said today that Canada, unlike the European Common Market, did not advocate formal devaluation of the United States dollar.

title: Medina Trial Told That Calley Said Killings Surprised Captain
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga:, Sept. 14  A witness testified today that four months after the killings at Mylai First Lieut. William L.
