Calley Jr., told a fellow officer that the slaying of civilians during an assault on the hamlet of Mylai 4, March 16, 1968, was committed with out the knowledge of Capt. Ernest L. Medina. Captain Medina was certainly sur prised when he learned of it, the witness quoted Lieutenat Calley as saying.

title: Tragedy Weighs Heavy on Townsmen
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 14 Residents of this stunned vil lage were trying today to come to some kind of terms with the tragic events at Attica prison and with the violent deaths of friends and family members, who worked there.

title: McGovern Rescued After Saigon Riot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14Senator George Mc Govern was trapped in a Roman Catholic Church school building this evening as a mob outside burned vehicles and threw stones and firebrands at the building.

title: Roosa Joins Opposition to a GoldBased Plan to Devalue Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Robert V. Roosa added his voice today to the rising chorus of leading Americans  includ ing President Nixonwho op pose devaluing the dollar through a small increase in the price of gold, as now demanded by countries of the European Common Market.

title: Antibusing Pickets Close 2 Car Plants
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 14 Antibusing pickets caused the closing of two major General Motors Corporation's plants here today.

title: Knowles Says Rockefeller Fund Will Stress Domestic Affairs
description: Dr. John H. Knowles, the newly named president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said yesterday that the foundation intended to devote a larger share of its resources to nation al, rather than international, affairs.

title: REDSKINS CLAIM KARRAS OF LIONS
description: Alex Karras, who could crush a quarterback or create a, quip with consummate skill, was dropped yesterday by the De troit Lions in their final roster cut of the season. The move was a surprise because Karras, a 36yearold defensive tackle, had been outstanding in pre season games.

title: Random Test Confuses Radio and TV Stations
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (UPI) An unscheduld test of the Government's emergency broadcast system today caus ed widespread confusion at radio and television stations across the country. One ma jor radio network was off the air for more than 30 minutes.

title: MILLION TENANTS IN CITY FACE RISE IN RENT ON JAN. 1
description: Ninetythree per cent of the tenants in the city's 1,3 million rentcontrolled apartments face rent increases Jan. 1, city and state housing officials said yes terday.

title: Cosmos 438 Put in Orbit
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (AP) The Soviet Union launched to day the 438th satellite in its Cosmos series, a secret program under which a wide range of space experiments and tests are conducted. The satellite's maxi mum distance from earth was given as about 200 miles and the minimum distance 130 miles.

title: About Motor Sports
description: It was a good idea, but it never got a fair chance to succeed. So the roadracing division of the United States Auto Club will be disbanded. The decision was made Mon day at a meeting of the USXC board of direCors in Indianapolis. Five road races had been scheduled for 1971, but four were canceled, princi pally because pro moters had no confidence in them. The one race that was run, at Kent, Wash., lost money.

title: SEEBURG'S PARENT SETS REFINANCING
description: The Commonwealth United Corporation, a onceglamorous conglomerate that has fallen on hard times, said yesterday that its major secured creditors have agreed in principle to a complex refinancing plan de signed to clear away $120 million in defaulted debt.

title: Bridge:Can Be Found in the Bidding Clue to Making Trump Lead
description: An opening trump lead, with the object of limiting dummy's ruffing power, is often the best if the dummy seems likely to have exactly three trumps.

title: First of Several Hundred Inmates Transferred From Attica to Ease Overcrowding
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 14  The transfer of the first group of what is expected to total several hundred inmates from Attica Prison began today in a predawn drizzle as heavily guarded buses quietly left the scene of death and destruction.

title: 4 U.S. HELICOPTERS DOWNED IN THE DELTA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 14 (AP)Four, United States helicopters were shot down and a fifth crashed in the Mekong Delta today. A helicopter was also shot down in northern South Vietnam.

title: It's the End of the Bus Ride That Matters
description: NOTRE DAME, Ind.After seven teen torturous years, the United States was about to desegregate many of its formerly segregated schools, North and mostly South. Following a deci sion of the Supreme Court, many of the school districts were using busing as a meansoften the only possible meansof doing so. After more than a decade and a half of legal struggles, the law seemed clear and finally, through the heroic efforts of many school boards, mainly in the South, the law was about to be followed. The result would be that finally, more than a century after slavery was ended in America, the greatgrandchildren of former slaves would finally have the opportunity to obtain a firstclass educationthe key to final liberation and upward social mobility.

title: COMMISSION LOSSES LISTED BY 56 FIRMS
description: A representative sampling of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange sustained losses on their securities com mission business in July, as a group, for the first time this year, the exchange reported yesterday.

title: 3 Who Had Drugs Given Life Terms Under New Law
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 (AP)  Two Bronx brothers and a Yonkers woman have been sentenced to life imprison ment under a new state law equating the penalty for pos sessing large quantities of drugs with the penalty for murder.

title: Pardon Urged for Calley
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) A Vietnam war veteran from Jackson, Miss., presented stack of petitions to the White House today asking President Nixon to pardon First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. The vet eran, Richard Barrett, said that Lieutenant Calley was convicted for the crime of serv ing his country and should be given an honorable discharge.

title: Judge Sets Up a Test Of His Dress Ruling
description: JAFFREY, N. H., Sept. 14 (AP)District Judge Bernard J. Hampsey Jr. sentenced two youths to 10 days in jail today to set up a test case on his requirement that the defendants wear a tie and suit jacket.

title: DODGERS WIN, 65, TRAIL BY A CAME
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 The surging Los Angeles Dodg ers rallied in the ninth inning tonight for a 65 victory over the San Francisco Giants and moved within a game of the lead in the National League's hectic Western Division title race.

title: 12 Die, Others Are Missing In Floods in Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 At least 12 persons drowned and others were missing today following a tourclay downpour in the Philadelphia area.

title: Following are sketches of two of the reported leaders of the Attica revolt:
description: A high school acquaintance of Richard Clark, said by ob servers of the riot at Attica to be one of the convict leaders of the takeover, described him yesterday as tough, street smart and unlucky.

title: Princess Expects Third Child
description: THE HAGUE, the Nether lands, Sept. 14 (UPI)Princess Margriet of the Netherlands is expecting her third child next spring, the Government infor mation service said today. The Princess, 28 years old, is the third daughter of Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard. Her hus band is an industrialist's son, Pieter van Vollenhoven. They have two sons, Prince Maurits, 3, and Prince Bernhard, 1.

title: Royal Japanese Couple Guests at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)President Nixon es corted Prince Hitachi and Princess Hanako of Japan through the White House Rose Garden today.

title: Flash Floods in Texas
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. Sept. 13 (AP)Heavy new rains and flash floods struck Corpus Christi and surrounding areas today while residents still tried to recuperate from the damag ing high water set off during the weekend by tropical storm Fern.

title: Organization Men Lead on L. I. In Test of CrossParty Backing
description: YAPHANK, L.I., Sept. 14 The Republican and Democra tic leaders ban on crossparty endorsements by Conservatives and Liberals appeared to be holding across the board in the Long Island primary elections where it was challenged today.

title: Lindsay Names City Sheriff
description: H. William Kehl, who had been acting sheriff since last July 1, was appointed city sher iff yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. He succeeds John J. McCloskey, who served as the city's only sheriff since taking office in 1942. The city sheriff is the chief executor of civil law. He carries out the mandates of city and state courts, seizes and sells property and serves legal documents.

title: Lindsay Names Health Aide
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ap pointed Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, a physician, who has been ac tive for various city agencies, as deputy commissioner of health with an annual salary of $34,710.

title: COST PLEA LOST BY SCHOOL BUSES
description: The President's Cost of Liv ing Council refused again last night to permit the bus com panies that carry 116,000 city school children to operate under increased charges called for in new contracts with the Board of Education.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M. to consider application by Qatar for membership.

title: Film Censors Overexposed?
description: SOUTHEND ON SEA, Eng land (AP)  The town coun cillors who censor films at this seaside resort may be in for trouble, one of them contends. The big danger is that the councillors get so blase about seeing sex scenes that they'll lose their sense of values, said Henry Devlin.

title: It's Fiesta Time As Mexicans Open Stay at the Garden
description: If you can imagine a trained Brahman bull jumping through a hoop of fire, followed by cowboy singing America the Beautiful atop a dancing horse to the accompaniment of a ma riachi band, you may have an idea of the range of entertain ment provided by the National Mexican Festival and Rodeo.

title: Market Place: Does Big Sales Campaign Pay?
description: If you're a shareholder in a company that does heavy promotions, sending its sales men on fancy trips if they make big quotas, you prob ably wonder if it is all worth it.

title: Seek More Relief for the Poor Without Adding to Revenue Loss
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14The two most influential members of the House Ways and Means. Committee agreed today that Congress should repeal part of a recently granted tax break for business. They would do this to provide new tax relief to poor persons without voting more overall tax reductions than President Nixon has asked.

title: Wills and Buckner Fined
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP) The Dodgers announced to day that the National League office had fined both Maury Wills and Bill Buckner as an aftermath to last nights ex plosive game in San Francisco.

title: BURCH OPTIMISTIC ON CHILDREN'S TV
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission yesterday expressed cautious optimism about children's television programing for this season but warned a packed meeting of broadcasters that the public is fed up to the teeth with past performance and not about to settle for mere cosmetics.

title: ARTHUR G. BRODEUR, PHILOLOGIST, IS DEAD
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 14 Arthur G. Brodeur, professor emeritus of English and Ger manic philology at the Univer sity of California, died last Thursday after a twomonth ill ness. He was 82 years old.

title: American Held in Israel On Wife's Support Plea
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 14 (UPI)A rabbinical court to day ordered an American jew to remain in Israel against his will until Decem ber, when it can hear his estranged wife's claim for support payments.

title: The Most Impossible Job
description: U Thant's final and categorical decision not to con tinue serving as Secretary General of the United Nations beyond the end of this year forces member nations to face up to what may well be the most difficult and important issue of this fall's sessionthe choice of his successor.

title: Martin Rich Has New Post
description: Martin Rich, an associate conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, has been appointed mu sic director of the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester for the 197172 season.

title: Move to Virginia By Press Institute Planned for 1974
description: The American Press institute announced yesterday that it planned to move to Reston, Va., a suburb of Washington, in 1974.

title: Jewish Leader Asks Laird For Action on War Crimes
description: The head of The American Jewish Congress urged Secre tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird yesterday to explain what mea sures the Defense Department has taken to prevent alleged shielding of soldiers guilty of war crimes and punishing those who report such acts.

title: Melville, Attica Radical, Dead; Recently Wrote of Jail Terror
description: Samuel J. Melville, the terror ist radical who pleaded guilty to the 1969 bombings of eight buildings in Manhattan, was one of the Attica prisoners killed Monday by state sharp shooters, Deputy Correction Commissioner Walter Dunbar said yesterday.

title: Lawyer for Gypsy Cabbies Here Reports 2 Threats on His Life
description: A Manhattan lawyer who is a consultant to the city's New Taxi Commission said yester day that his life had been threatened because of his activities in the socalled gypsy taxicab industry.

title: Senate Unit Backs Wallace
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 14 (AP)The Alabama Senate Finance Committee voted today to give Gov. George C. Wallace the power to withhold state funds allocated to the schools for bus transportation. Mr. Wallace had sought the power last month to reinforce his campaign against courtordered busing.

title: San Francisco Busing Gains
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 (UPI)Attendance in San Francisco's newly integrated elementary schools rose to about 65 per cent today, up from yesterday's 40 per cent. But thousands of parents in Chinatown aria elsewhere con tinued their antibusing boycott.

title: Meskill Orders an Inquiry Into Security at Norwich
description: NORWICH, Conn., Sept.  Gov. Thomas J. Meskillof Con necticut has ordered an inquiry into the escape Monday of four inmates from Norwich Hos pital.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP ON A BROAD FRONT
description: Stock prices took a decided downturn yesterday with some prominent glamour and blue chip issues among the losers. More than 1,000 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange de clined.

title: MAYOR RUNS FIRST IN BOSTON VOTING
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 Mayor Kevin H. White and United States Representative Louise Day Hicks won the two top spots in today's preliminary mayoral election and the right to oppose each other in a run off election on Nov. 2.

title: Roberts Contender For Supreme Court In Bronx District
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts emerged yester day as a strong contender for a State Supreme Court nomi nation.

title: Reed, Lucas Are Keys As Knicks Begin Drills
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 14The Knicks opened training camp today at Mon mouth College with some opti mistic talk by Dave DeBus schere about Willis Reed. The Knick captain underwent sur gery for tendonitis above his left knee last May and his complete recovery is a key factor in New York's bid to regain the National Basketball Association championship.

title: Newark News to Sell Sunday Paper
description: Beset by financial losses ag gravated by a 112day strike, The Newark Evening News has agreed to sell its Sunday edi tion and virtually its entire physical assets to its morning competitor, The StarLedger, for $20million.

title: YANKEES 5 IN 6TH BEAT RED SOX, 63
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14The Yan kees, who earned an extra $1,179.11 per man for finishing second last year, executed an other big move tonight toward receiving additional income this season.

title: Addicts in Military To. Be Hospitalized Even Against Will
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe, head of the Presidential drug addiction office, announced today that military personnel who were found during predischarge ex aminations to be addicted would be assigned to Veterans Ad ministration hospitals, even against their will.

title: PEKING BUYS WHEAT FROM CANADA AGAIN
description: WINNIPEG, Canada, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press)The Cana dian Wheat Board announced today the sale of nearly 20 mil lion bushels of wheat to Com munist China. This is in addi tion to a contract for 98 mil lion bushels negotiated in Pe king last October.

title: Papp Grant Tops U.S. Arts Awards
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The National Endowment for the Arts announced grants today of almost $1.6million to 36 theaters across the na tion, with the biggest award $125,000going to Joseph Papp's New York Shake speare Festival.

title: Production of Fuzz Moved From City
description: Fuzz, a United Artists comedydrama that was to have dealt with the New York police, definitely will be made in Los Angeles instead of New York City. Martin Ransohoff, the head of Film ways, the picture's copro ducer, had threatened to move production.

title: France Dismisses Five Leaders of Police Union
description: PARIS, Sept. 14The Gov ernment today dismissed five officers of a police union that had threatened to occupy Gov ernment ministries here.

title: Blue Bell Reports Increase In Dividend Will Not Be Paid
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Sept. 14 (UPI)  Directors of Blue Bell, Inc., saying they were complying with President Nix on's wageprice freeze, today announced that stockholders would not receive a dividend increase approved earlier after a 2for1 stock split.

title: Montana Elects Delegates
description: HELENA, Mont., Sept. 14 (UPI)  Montana voters today chose 233 candidates to run for election as delegates to the state's first constitutional con vention in 82 years. The 233, selected in Republican, Demo cratic and independent primary elctions from a fiel dof 518, will run in November for 100 seats at the convention to re vise the constitution next Jan uary.

title: Slater Will Resign I.O.S. Presidency; Harassment Cited
description: Robert E. Slater, the 54year old president of I.O.S., Ltd., the financially troubled mutual fund complex, will resign his post effective Oct. 1, it was dis closed yesterday.

title: Harris Invitation Set
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 14 (AP)Senator Fred Harris, Democrat, of Oklahoma, poten tial Presidential aspirant, will visit, New Hampshire next, month, the state with the na tion's earliest, Presidential pri mary, a Democratic party spokesman said today. The State Democratic Committee chairman, Harry Makris, said Senator Harris had confirmed an invitation to appear at political seminar Oct. 5.

title: German Deadlock. Over Berlin Persists
description: BONN, Sept. 14East Ger many and West Germany re mained deadlocked today in their dispute over varying in terpretations of the fourpower Berlin agreement.

title: Washington School Closed
description: PASCO, Wash., Sept. 14 (UPI)School was closed to day at Pasco High School in an effort to ease tension between black and white students after racial brawls.

title: ETHEREGE DRAMA STAGED IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Sept. 14Not per formed in London for more than 200 years, Etherege's The Man of Mode Is the latest Restoration comedy to benefit from the abolition of that cor don sanitaire formerly known as Restoration style.

title: 5 IN WEST VIRGINIA GUILTY IN VOTE DEAL
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Sept. 14 (AP)  Five highranking Logan County Democrats have been convicted of vote fraud conspiracy in connection with the 1970 primary election.

title: Arlan's Department Stores Reports 6Month Loss
description: Arlan's Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday a loss for the six month period ended July 31 indicating a loss also for the second fiscal quarter.

title: Florida 18YearOlds Lose
description: MIAMI, Sept. 14 (AP)The first 18yearolds to seek public office in Florida were solidly, defeated today in City Council elections in Tampa and Orange City, according to unofficial returns.

title: PANEL URGES BLACKS TO TAKE CATV ROLE
description: Cable television represents the last opportunity for black people to establish a firm place in mass communications and the economic mainstream, Theodore S. Ledbetter Jr., pres ident of the Urban Communi cations Group, Inc., of Wash ington, told a religious seminar yesterday.

title: Black Doctors Ask to See Attica Medical Facilities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The National Medical Associa tion, a group of black physi cians claiming 8,000 members, asked today to be allowed in side Attica Correctional Facility to inspect the medical facilities.

title: BonnPrague Talks to Resume
description: BONN, Sept. 14 (Reuters) West German and Czechoslovak officials will resume talks in Prague later this month on treaty to normalize relations, it was announced today.

title: Jackson Files Suit
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 14 The Jackson City School Board filed suit for an injunction in Federal District Court here late this afternoon in an effort to prevent a shutoff of all state funds.

title: Conferees Request Nixon's Approval For Alaska ATest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)SenateHouse conferees agreed today to a bill provi sion that would postpone a scheduled fivemegaton nuclear warhead underground explosion in Alaska unless President Nix on gave his direct approval.

title: David Rockefeller, No. 2 Art Buyer
description: David Rockefeller, whose brother Nelson has been mak ing art news for years, admit ted yesterday that he ranked No. 2 in the family as an art collector.

title: Soviet Getting U.S. Cattle In Deal Arranged by Eaton
description: RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 14 Three hundred and fifty cattle were being loaded here today for shipment to the Soviet Union. The sale was arranged by the industrialist, Cyrus S. Eaton.

title: Repeal of Relief Check Pickup And Job Referral Urged Here
description: Reporting on two months monitoring of the new state law requiring employable re lief recipients to pick up their checks at state employment centers and to be available for job referrals there, the Com munity Council of Greater New York called yesterday for the law's repeal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As former under secretary and vice chairwoman of the Overseas Commit ments and Development Committee of the Conference of Federated Trade Unions (C.F.T.U.), I must sharply dis agree with the interpretations given by Geoffrey Reade Duquesne in his Aug. 10 letter to the position of Labor rank and file both at the conference in 1967 and since concerning the question of British membership in the Common Market.

title: COURT ORDER CURBS A CREDIT REPORTER
description: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., was permanently barred by the State Supreme Court in Man hattan yesterday from printing in its credit reports a reference to a corporation president's 1947 burglary conviction and subsequent paradon.

title: Bank Rate in Netherlands Is Cut to 5% From 5%
description: AMSTERDAM, Sept. 14 (Reuters)  The Netherlands cut its bank rate today to per cent from 51/2 per cent, effective tomorrow. The central bank said the move was taken to halt the flow of foreign currency into the country.

title: Agnew Attends a Service For Prouty in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Vice President and Mrs. Ag new were among more than 200 mourners who paid tribute to Senator Winston L. Prouty at memorial services here to day. Senator Prouty, a Repub lican from Vermont, died in Boston hospital of cancer last week.

title: Dollar Drops to a Low
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The value of the United States dollar dropped to a low in West Germany and Japan to day and declined on several other international exchanges, apparently in reaction to the European Common Market's de cision to press for official de valuation of the American cur rency.

title: Jail Penalty for Manson
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (AP) Charles Manson, cult leader sentenced to death for the Tate LaBianca killings, has lost his visitor privilege for 10 days be ciuse he set fire to the bedding in his cell, according to the prison authorities. Manson set fire to blankets yesterday, they said.

title: NEWSPAPER STRIKE ENDS IN PITTSBURGH
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (UPI) Striking teamsters and jani tors at the Pittsburgh Press Company accepted new con tracts today, ending a series of labor disputes that caused a fourmonth newspaper black out.

title: DOCK UNION CHIEF RULES OUT STRIKE I.L.A. Would Work Without Contract to End of Freeze
description: Thomas W. Gleason, presi dent of the International Long shoremen's Association, said yesterday that the union had abandonedat least for the pe riod of the Presidential wage freeze  its traditional stance of no contract, no work.

title: LABOR CAUTIONED ON PHASE TWO PAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson warned today that collective bargaining agree ments scheduled to take effect after the 90day wage and price freeze might have to be changed because of the ad ministration's postfreeze poli cies.

title: Ordinary Russians Pay Tribiite to Khrushchev, and Some Deplore Way Officials Ignored His Death
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14Clus ters of ordinary citizens gath ered around the grave of Ni kita S. Khrushchev today to reminisce about the man who led their country for 11 years until he fell into disfavor with his official associates.

title: BURGER RULING SENT TO JUDGES BY MAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)Supreme Court officials confirmed today that copies of an opinion by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger on the thrust of school desegregation rulings by the full Court had been mailed to all Federal circuit and district court judges.

title: REV. PAUL A. CULLENS
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 14 The Rev. Paul A. Culiens, minister emeritus of the New town Congregational Church, died of a heart attack on Sun day in St. Joseph's Hospital, North Bay, Ontario. He was 72 years old and lived on Castle Hill Road.

title: Upsets in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 Two incumbent Republican leg islators were denied renomina tion in primary elections in Westchester County today.

title: SUPPORT SOUGHT ON RP DIG COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14U. Alexis Johnson, Under Secret ary of State for Political Af fairs, urged the House Foreign Affairs Committee today to authorize the creation of an American Council on Interna tional Communication Corpora tion.

title: Clifford Curzon Scheduled
description: Lincoln Center for the Per forming Arts has announced that Clifford Curzon, the Eng lish pianist, will replace Ar turo Benedetti Michelangeli in the Great Performers at Phil harmonic Hall concert to be given on March 5. Also, two artists have been added to the list of popular singers to be presented in the Great Per formers series. Mr. Taylor will appear on Dec. 5, relpacing Carole King, who had been scheduled for that date. Mr. Hathaway will appear on March 12.

title: Baseball Highlights
description: Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves drove in five runs with his 42d and 43d homers last night to become the Na tional League's leader in career runs batted in with 1,953. He is third in major league career homers with 635.

title: LTV Cuts Bank Debt
description: DALLAS, Sept. 14 (Reuters) LingTemcoVought, Inc., said today that it had cut further its outstanding bank debt by $10.2million, reducing the total bank debt to $18.3million. Funds for the repayment were made available by the receipt of payment of two shortterm notes of OmegaAlpha, Inc., originally issued as part of the purchase price for the sale by LTV of the Okonite Company.

title: Advertising:
description: When last the snow was deep upon the slopes Lorillard mounted a big sweepstakes promotion aimed at the coun try's ski nuts. Now, with autumnal hues creeping into summer greens, the cigarette makers are once again girding their loins to go forth among the smokers.

title: ECONOMIC POLICY SPLITS GOVERNORS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 14 Partisan squabbling over the Administration's new economic policy broke out In earliest to day at the 63d annual Gover nors Conference here.

title: FANNY MAY BARS AUCTION OFFERS Standby Commitment Bids Are Called Unrealistio
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)The Federal National Mortgage Association rejected all offers received in its auc tion yesterday of 12month standby commitments, it was announced today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLOSE WITH GAIN Buying Near the Close Wipes Out Midsession Losses
description: Hedge selling in corn and soybean futures was a major factor in midsession losses on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. However, specu lative commission house buy ing and short covering near the close brought soybean prices higher and led to fractional gains in corn.

title: Dollar Tumbles Here
description: The dollar dropped sharply in reiation to major European currencies in the New York for eign exchange yesterday in the wake of the decision of the Common Market to take a unified stand in favor of a for mal devaluation by the United States.

title: Executives Sell Shares
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) The president of the Ford Motor Company and the Chev olet divisional vice president of the Genral Motors Corpora tion have sharply cut their holdings of company stock, ac cording to the latest monthly report of the Securities and Ex change Commission on insider ransactions.

title: Postscript to a Massacre
description: In the aftermath of perhaps the most gruesome prison massacre in America's history, with the death toll at Attica already at 41 and expected to go higher, State Correction Commissioner Oswald has acknowledged that there was no truth to the version his aides originally gave about what happened to hostages when police officers stormed into the beleaguered jail with guns blazing. Only a swift and totally impartial investigation can clear up the confusion now beclouding this grim tragedy.

title: Fears on Unemployment
description: BELFAST, Sept. 14Brian Morton, chairman of the Lon donderry Development Com mission, said today that re newed rioting had wrecked hopes that jobs would be found for the city's 3,000 unemployed by the end of the year. He re ported that one company that had almost completed an ar rangement for expansion that would have meant 800 new jobs had now abandoned the idea because the time was not opportune.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: So The Times is a regrettable eco freak, according to selfstyled en vironmental journalist William Houseman. (Letter, Aug. 31.)

title: AUGUST SURPLUS SHOWN BY JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (Reuters) Japan had a surplus of $3.3 billion in her balance of pay ments for August, the Finance Ministry said in a preliminary report today.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally, the take charge guy of President Nixon's New Economic Policy, has his work cut out for him in facing angry foreign critics at the monetary and trade conference of the Group of Ten nations that starts in London today. The United States intends to keep the heat on the other rich cap italist countries  Britain, Japan, Can ada, West Germa ny, France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Swe den and Switzerland as an ob server  to take steps that will enable this country to swing from a huge balanceofpay ments deficit to a surplus posi tion.

title: Richey, Olmedo and Fillol Advance in Coast Tennis
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 14 (AP)Cliff Richey of Sara sota, Fla., ousted Richard Rus sell of Jamaica, 61, 57, 61, in the Central California National Open hardcourt tennis cham pionships today.

title: IAdministration Offers to Back QuickTrials Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  The Nixon Administration of fered today to support legisla tion guaranteeing defendants quick trials, if Congress would sweeten the pending bill by adding several measures favored by prosecutors.

title: Farmers Ask for Higher Supports and Curb on Raises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Representatives of five major farm organizations told Presi dent Nixon today that they would question wage and price increases for any sector of the economy unless provisions were made for a significant up ward adjustment in farm in comes first.

title: Kahane Arrives in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 14 (UPI) The head of the Jewish Defense League of New York, Rabbi Meir Kahane, arrived in Israel today and said he would set up a world headquarters in I'Jerusalem and would divide his time between Israel and the United States.

title: Rumania Reforms Her Schools
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 13Stu dents resuming classes this week at Bucharest's Petru Groza Lyda will be returning to what has become a new school in the old buildingthe Petru Groza High School of Physics and Electronics.

title: U.S. Judge to Study Move By Ellsberg on Subpoena
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (UPI) A Federal judge took under advisement today a motion to quash a subpoena for additional records stored by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, who has said that he gave the Pentagon papers to the press.

title: Unity! A Haunting Echo From Attica
description: Late Sunday afternoon, at the last meeting between in mates in rebellion at Attica Correctional Facility and a spe cial observers committee, black prisoner seized the micro phone.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BLOOD ORANGES. By John Hawkes. 271 pages. New Directions. $6.95.

title: Johannesburg Dean Calb Plot Charges Absolute Fantasy
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 14The Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, the very Rev. Gonville ffrenchBeytagh, dis missed as absolute fantasy to day charges that he had plot ted the violent overthrow of the South African Government.

title: Greenberg a Big Hitter In Celebrities Tennis
description: KIAMESHA, LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 14A new tennis king, who had passed up Forest Hills, was crowned today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The four power pact on Berlin provides for visits by West Germans to East Germany but, interestingly enough, makes no mention of visits by East Germans to West Germany.

title: POLICE ASSAILED OVER 2 INCIDENTS
description: A tense community in the Williasburg section of Brook lyn braced for new police ac tion against squatters today while its leaders were demand inent's Tactical Patrol Force never be sent into the area again.

title: Holds Money Should Not Be Used for Brokers Business Ventures
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Spokesmen for the Securities and Exchange Commission and for major securities industry organizations agreed today that brokerage firms should never again be permitted to use money or securities belonging to customers in the firm's own business ventures.

title: Attica Revolt Is Called A Tragedy by Lindsay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Mayor Lindsay today de scribed the rebellion and the shootings at the State Cor rectional Facility at Attica, N. Y., as a human tragedy of most profound propor tions, but repeatedly de clined to pass judgment on Governor Rockefeller's han dling of the situation.

title: JORDAN EXECUTES TWO GUERRILLAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14  Two Palestinian guerrillas, convicted of having murdered a Jordanian civil servant, were hanged today in Amman.

title: Mansfield Renews TroopCut Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Senator Mike Mansfield today seized upon international eco nomic difficulties as a reason for renewing his legislative ef fort to force a reduction in American forces in Western Europe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is indeed unfortunate that your Aug. 26 editorial Consumerism Rings the Bell ignored the very significant service that has been performed over the last fifteen years by the Bureau of Consumer Frauds and Protection of my office in serving thousands of consum ers throughout the State of New York and recovering for them many millions of dollars which otherwise would have been lost through fraudulent and de ceptive practices.

title: Governors Name Moore
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 14 (AP)  Republican Governors chose Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia today as the next chairman of the National Governors Conference. He de feated Gov. Daniel J. Evans of Washington on a secret ballot. The conference chairmanship rotates between the two par ties, Mr. Moore will be formally elected tomorrow to succeed Gov. Warren E. Hearnes of Mis souri.

title: TV: Attica in the News
description: Television is at its power ful best in the coverage of major public events, in the immediacy it can bring to a historic occasion or a major crisis. In capturing a partic ular gesture and certain tone of voice, the screen possesses an advantage virtually denied to the medium of print journ alism.

title: PAUL BLACKBURN, POET, DIES AT 44
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., Sept. 14 Paul Blackburn, poet and as sistant professor of English at the State University College here, died last night of cancer at his home, 60 Prospect Ter race. He was 44 years old.

title: Baltimore Council Head Wins. Mayor Nomination
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 14Wil liam Donald Schaefer, a 49 yearold white moderate who is President of the City Council, won the Democratic nomina tion for Mayor of Baltimore today, beating out two black candidates who mounted strong campaigns.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: D'AUTELTIL LAKE, Quebec On the third morning of our trout and landlocked salmonfishing expedition in eastern Quebec we discovered that only one member of our party, Mrs. Gordon Blair of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., had been sufficiently foresighted to lay in a good supply of Mickey Finn streamer flies.

title: MISTER DONUT SUIT REPORTED SETTLED
description: Settlement of a $10million class action suit filed 14 months ago by a group of dis satisfeid franchisees against Mister Donut of America, Inc., Boston, was announced yester day by that company and its parent, International Multi foods Corporation, Minneapolis. The latter formerly was known as the International Milling Company.

title: Seaborg Favors Change in Nuclear Safety Control
description: GENEVA, Sept. 15The re sponsibility for assuring safe ty in the use of nuclear energy should eventually be trans ferred from the Atomic Energy Commission to some other agency, Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, former chairman of the com mission, said today.

title: Mrs. Dempsey, Medalist, Loses in Long Island Golf
description: JERICHO, L.I., Sept 15 Mrs. Anson Beard, Piping Rock, upset the medalist, Mrs. Thorne Dempsey, Piping Rock, 2 up, today in the opening round of the Long Island match play championship at the Meadow Brook Club. Par for the 5,919 yard course is 36, 3672.

title: Padres Top Dodgers, 21;
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15 The Los Angeles Dodgers lost a chance to move into a tie for first place with San Francisco in the National League West to night as Dave Roberts, San Diego's superlative southpaw, stopped them, 21.

title: KENNETH P. FISHER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15 Keneth P. Fisher, president of the Scope Instruments division of Berkey Photo, Inc., died of a heart attack yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 17 Whitewood Road.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHIPPIE, & CARLSON PR Is Growing. Try Our New Phons. MU 40831. Or set ter Still, Drop In, At 205 Madison.Advt.

title: A Peacock Throne On Fifth Avenue?
description: Beginning Monday, B. Alt man & Co. will be singing a song of India.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your recent editorial The Irish Solution you refer to diehards on both sides as uncompromising bigots.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Shortly after 9 A.M. on Monday Sept. 13, 37 men lost their lives in a bloody massacre at the hands of Governor Rockefeller. We, the Broome County Committee of Prison Reform, protest this action.

title: Man in the News
description: Little more than six months after he left his job as a member of the United States Board of Parole to come to New York as executive dep uty commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services, Walter Dunbar found himself yesterday in the vortex of controversy.

title: TAX CHARGES CITE ALABAMA DONATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Justice Department to day announced indictment of three Alabama businessmen on income tax charges involving a $25,000 political contribution and an alleged $6,000 bribe to a former state official.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We were saddened by Anne Ber nays Sept. 4 OpEd article Radical Chic at the Cape.

title: Black Prisoners Embrace New View Of Themselves as Political Victims
description: As long as there have been prisons, prisons have been no place to be somebody.

title: HARLEMITE URGES LEGAL POLICY BETS
description: A numbers slip changed hands at the headquarters of the As sociation of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday, but not even the fustiest member turned a whisker.

title: MAINE CENTRAL HEAD ONAROOSTOOKBOARD
description: The longcherished plan of Frederick C. Dumaine for merging New England railroads moved another step closer with the announcement yesterday that E. Spencer Miller, presi dent of the Maine Central Rail road, has been elected to the board of the Bangor & Aroos took Railroad. Mr. Miller's elec tion is subject to approval by the Interstate Commerce Com mission.

title: Notes on People
description: Clifford N. Hardin, the Secretary of Agriculture, in troduced a portly goggleeyed character costumed in brown leaves, green pants and big yellow claws as Woodsy Owl, who will be the Forest Serv ice's official antipollution symbol.

title: Podell Urges Rockefeller To Call a Special Session
description: Representative Bertram L. Podell, Brooklyn Democrat, sent a telegram to Governor Rocke feller yesterday urging the ap pointment of a Moreland Act commissioner and calling for special session of the Legisla ture to make changes in the state's penal system, which he said for many years has oper ated in bankruptcy. The telegram read, in part:

title: Judy Dalton Eliminated In Tennis at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15 (UPI)Fifthseeded Judy Dal Iton of Australia became the second major upset victim in the Virginia Slims Louisville invitation tennis tournament to day as she lost to unseeded Becky Vest of Jackson, Miss., 75, 76. Leley Hunt of Australia lost yesterday to Mona Schal lau of Iowa City, Iowa, who bowed today to Margie Cooper of Winter Park, Fla., 3.6, 64, 61.

title: Giants to Start Hyland At Guard, Duhon at Back
description: With the approach of their season openers, the Giants and the Jets worked yesterday to organize their starting units.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Sept. 15  The world monetary crisis is basi cally about what economic, mil itary and political role the United States should play in the world and what part of this the other industrialized countries of the West should finance. On the first day of twoday London monetary conference the American Secreil Lary of the Treas ury, John M. Con nally, spoke of the need to define the magnitude of the problem be fore tackling other issues. What he meant was that there had to be some agreement on the American role well before the complex question of parity changes for the major nations is discussed.

title: Chile Says It Will Nationalize I.T.T. Unit in Days
description: The International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation said yesterday it had been advised by the Government of Chile that its Chile Telephone Com pany would be nationalized within a few days.

title: Brazilian Wins Star Sail
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 15 (AP) Joerg Bruder of Sao Paulo, Brazil, easily won the fourth race in the World Star Class sailing championship today, but was far behind the overall leader, Dennis Conner of San Diego, Conner placed sixth to day.

title: Tracts Planted in His Flat, Johannesburg Dean Says
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 15The Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, the Very Rev. Gonville ffrenchBeytagh, said in court today that illegal pamphlets of banned organiza tions had been planted in his apartment. The dean was testifying at his trial here on charges under the Terrorism Act.

title: BARELY EVEN WINS $35,200 ASTARITA
description: The undefeated Barely Even came in from Chicago yester day to win the $35,200 Astarita at Belmont Park. The seven furlong race for 2yearold fil lies had an impressive cast, with the Calumet Farm's Ron deau being sent off the favorite in the field of 11.

title: Watchmaker and Jeweler Are Shot to Death in Midtown Office
description: A watchmaker and a jeweler were found shot dead early yes terday in the watchmaker's fourthfloor office in Manhat tan's diamond district.

title: ABERNATHY JAILED IN ALABAMA TOWN
description: BUTLER, Ala., Sept. 15  The Rev. Ralph David Aber nathy and 193 other Negroes were arrested and jailed today in this racially tense commun ity where a black girl was killed by a white man's car Saturday.

title: Allende Orders Shutdown Of UPI's Offices in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  President Salvador Allende Gossens tonight ord ered the American news agen cy United Press International to close its offices in Chile.

title: MORE BUSINESSMEN FOR NIXON TAX PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)More businessmen lined up today behind President Nixon's taxreduction program in a strong show of support for the plan to stimulate, the economy.

title: Alcoa Plant Will Close
description: MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 15 (AP) The Aluminum Company of America will halt operations temporarily Oct. 1 of one of four digester units at its Mobile Works bauxite refining plants, a spokesman said to day. Ralph E. Whitson, plant manager, said about 65 of the plant']s 660 employes will be laid off.

title: Cairo Paper Says Israel Seeks a Base in Ethiopia
description: CAIRO, Sept. 15The Cairo newspaper Al Abram asserted today that the Israeli Chief of Staff, Gen. Haim BarLev, had endeavored during a recent visit to Ethiopia to reach an agreement to install radar and missile launchers at Bab el Mandeb, the entrance to the Red Sea.

title: ROBERT W. LEFFERTS
description: Robert W. Lefferts, vice presi dent and director of PennDixie Cement Company of New York, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark after a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived at 17 Somerset Place, Murray Hill, N. J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Is it possible that Mayor Lindsay and most of the population still do not recognize the truths of firearms legislation? New York City, with the strictest handgun control legislation in the country, is reported to have an increasing incidence of crime with pistols.

title: Tisch Is Named a Trustee Of Whitney Museum of Art
description: Laurence A. Tisch has been elected to the board of trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art, it was an nounced yesterday by David M. Solinger, board president.

title: Death Overshadows LandlordTenant Dispute
description: A yearlong landlordtenant dispute erupted yesterday into an altercation on the sidewalk in, front of a West Side apartment building dur ing which one of the tenants died.

title: A Natural Philosopher
description: A scientist whose awesome range of mind entitled him to be called a natural philosopher. John Desmond Bernal also ful filled Karl Marx's prescription for intellectuals to change the world as well as to understand it. A crystallographer who helped create the foundations of molecular biology, an expert on explosive devices and the waves of the sea and a notable historian of science, he was at the same time a stanch Com munist (but not a party mem ber) who won a Lenin Peace Prize in 1953 and who rarely let pass an opportunity to praise science in the Soviet Union and to criticize its social role under capitalism.

title: 4 DOMINICAN PRIESTS SENTENCED. IN BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 Four Roman Catholic priests were convicted of subyersion last night by a Brazilian mill tary court, and sentenced to prison terms ranging from six months to four years.

title: Morris Kaplan, Technical Chief Of Consumers Union, Dies at 60
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 15  Morris Kaplan, technical director of Consum ers Union for 25 years and a pioneer consumer advocate, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 60 years old and lived at 44 Old Country Road.

title: Personal Finance
description: Almost everyone has his own number, such as 054 36.2352, stashed away in a wallet or bureau drawer. It's his Social Security number not exactly a close friend because no one likes to be a statistic in Government records, but it does follow the individual almost from childhood to death.

title: Bay State G.O.P. Chief Quite
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP)The chairman of the Republican State Committee, Herbert R. Waite, announced his resigna tion today, effective Sept. 28. Mr. Waite, who was elected chairinan by the cormmittee Feb. 8, said the was resigning for personal reasons.

title: Additional Victims
description: The Department of Correc tion made public yesterday ad ditional names of inmates killed on Monday at the State Correction Facility at Attica. The list is still incomplete.

title: Trade Writer Gets Award
description: Emma M. Doran, former as sistant editor and foreign trade specialist of The Journal of Commerce, received the 1971 World Trade Writers Association Award last night at a reception in her honor at Luchow's. The award, pre sented by Michael W. Moyni han, the group's president, cited Miss Doran for sustained excellence in reporting inter national economic news. She joined the newspaper in 1929 and retired last October. A native of Iroquois, Ontario, Miss Doran received degrees from the University of Toronto and the Columbia School of Business.

title: Bridge: Double Knockout Tourney To State Here Next Month
description: Double knockout team events, in which a team must lose two headtohead match es before being eliminated, are excellent contests. They have regrettably been aban doned at the national level, because they are hard to schedule with a large num ber of teams, but they are en tirely satisfactory for local competitions.

title: In East Europe, Everyone Is Camping Now
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 11A Czechoslovak official became animated a few weeks ago when the subject turned from Tontics to tourism, particu larly camping. Everyone is camping now, he said. It is just like in the West!

title: U.S. Set To Review New Apparel Items
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Representatives of the nation's apparel industry were told at a White House meeting today that the Cost of Living Coun cil would review its definition of those new products that use higher priced materials and which differ from other pro ducts on the market.

title: Market Place Bad Advice Has Its Own Reward
description: Perhaps you never thought of it in just this way, but if you buy a stock on the advice of your broker and it goes down, he gets a double re ward for correcting his mis takea mistake you paid him well to avoid in the first place.

title: Screen:
description: Richard Benjamin is mak ing like Walter Mitty in an uneven, middling  good comedydrama titled The Steagle. That title, if it matters, refers to a football team merger back in the good old days. The best thing about the picture is Benjamin himself, a really deft, engag ing comedian when the oc occasion warrants.

title: CUBS SWEEP METS AS HOOTON, ROOK1E, SPINS3HITTER,32
description: The Chicago Cubs, who elim inated themselves from the Na tional League pennant race Tuesday, eliminated the New York Mets last night when they swept a doubleheader at Shea Stadium and made the Mets lost summer official.

title: Federal Food Program Is Called a National Disgrace
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A former hunger consultant to the Nixon Administration today sharply criticized the Federal program to feed the poor as national disgrace.

title: FRAZIER, REAMS; SERVED IN HOUSE
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 15 Frazier Reams Sr., a former Toledo lawyer and businessman who served two terms in the House of Representatives as the only independent in Con gress, died this morning at Oak land, Calif., where he had been hospitalized for the last five years. He was 74 years old and maintained homes in San Mateo, Calif., and in Toledo.

title: Thieu Says He'll Quit if U.S. Slashes Aid
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 16President Nguyen Van Thieu told more than 400 of his supporters from the provinces yesterday that he would step down if the United States Congress drasti daily cut economic and military aid to South Vietnam because of his unopposed candidacy in the presidential elections.

title: Mack Trucks Drops Plans To Build a Russian Plant
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 15 (AP)Mack Trucks, Inc., an nounced today it has canceled plans to build the world's larg est truck plant in the Soviet Union. Mack said it had not received United States appro val. Mack signed a preliminary agreement with Soviet offi cials last May 18, providing that the Allentown, Pa., com pany would design and supply a major part of the Soviet Union's $1.4billion Kama River truck plant. Mack Trucks is a subsidiary of the Signal Com panies, Inc.

title: U.S. Foreign Reserves Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Total assets of the overseas branches of member. Federal Reserve banks rose 28 per cent during 1970 to 52.6 billion from 41.1billion in 1969, the Federal Reserve re ported today.

title: For Those Fed Up With Haute Cuisine, a Simpler, Peasant Diet
description: The reaction to the gourmet revolu tion is setting in.

title: FAST TRAINS HELD VITAL IN THE 70'S
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The Department of Transporta tion said today that highspeed passenger trains offered the only hope of relieving conges tion, pollution and delay in the heavily traveled Northeast Cor ridor in the nineteenseventies.

title: $13BILLION GAIN SOUGHT TO SPUR PAYMENTS TO U.S.
description: LONDON, Sept. 15  Sec retary of the Treasury John B. Connally told the United States trade partners today they must help produce what he conceded would be a stun ning $13billion improvement in the American balance of in ternational payments.

title: Workers With Track Sweep Up the Debris
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 15 Workers with a green truck swept up the litter today on the grounds of the State Cor rectional Facility.

title: 6 Sundays Listed For Bicycle Riding On the Concourse
description: The center four lanes of the main street of the Bronxthe Grand Concourse  will be closed to motor vehicles and used exclusively for bicycles for six Sundays, starting this week.

title: Louisiana Braces for Storm
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Sept 15 (AP)  The tropical storm named Edith regain ed its hurri cane strength today and a hur ricane watch was posted along the Louisiana coast between Cameron and Morgan City.

title: eaumont Dispute Poses City Dilemn
description: When the finance commit tee of the City Council sits down today to consider the plight of the Vivian Beau mont theater building, one of the jewels of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, it will be weighing money and esthetics, pragmatism and idealism. No matter how it decides on the plan to allow the nonprofit City Center to operate the Beaumont, it will be criticized.

title: U.S. WILL SUPPORT SEAT FOR PEKING IN COUNCIL OP U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The United States has decided in principle to support actively, the assignment of China's per manent seat in the United Na tions Security Council to the Government in Peking.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: JOBS BILL DIVIDES G.O.P. LEADERSHIP
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 15 The chairman of the House Re publican Conference, in a sharp break with the Nixon Adminis tration, teamed up today with Democrats in their fight to give the Federal Government cease and desist power against job discrimination.

title: Saigon General Says Enemy Has Pulled Back 15,000 Men
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 16 (AP)A South Vietnamese general said here today that half the North Vietnamese forces threatening the northern provinces of South Vietnam had pulled back across the demilitarized zone and the Laotian border.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Sept. 4 editorial Weather Report contains a paraphrase from quote by Charles Dudley Warner, not Mark Twain. A nineteenth century editor of The Courant and friend of Twain, it was Warner who said: Everybody talks about the weather, but nobody does anything about it.

title: Mexico Eases Horse Ban
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 (UPI)A ban on transportation of horses was lifted today in nine Mexican states and terri tories where mass vaccination of horses, mules and donkeys against Venezuelan equine en cephalitis has been completed.

title: Stans Says PostFreeze Raises Will Be Based on Productivity
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans told business execu tives at the White House today that wage increases after the current freeze would be based on productivity gains, members of the business delegation re ported.

title: Murcer Helps Yanks Top Orioles, 4 2
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 15  Bobby Murcer was, getting ready to take practice before tonight's game when Mike Cuellar walked by.

title: Paksong Reported Retaken
description: PAKSONG, Laos, Sept. 15 (UPI)Government forces fight ing at close quarters against some 50 to 100 North Viet namese defenders reported that they had recaptured this key Boloven Plateau town overrun by the enemy May 16.

title: U.S. Plans Small Carrier
description: EAST GREENWICH, R. I., Sept. 15 (UPI) Navy Secre tary John H. Chafee said to night that the Navy ils devel oping an economysize aircraft carrier. The vessel would be far smaller than conventional carriers, and would cost only oneeighth as much, he told a Chamber of Commerce dinner. The vessel would carry helicop ters and vertical or shorttake off jet planes.

title: Space Plan Outlined
description: GENEVA, Sept. 15 (UPI) The United States announced today plans to send nuclear powered space probes to the outer planets in the next five years.

title: Cocktails and Customers: Designers Night Out
description: It was meeta designer time on Bloomingdale's third, or higher fashion, floor night before last. The store hadn't planned it that way. What it had planned was a cocktail party for clothes designers as many of them as it could round upand members and guests of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The benefit event marked the opening of the redesigned third floor. (There are more boutiques than ever.)

title: Saigon Nightclub Blast Kills 15 and Injures 57
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15A bomb explosion ripped through a downtown nightclub tonight, killing at least 15 persons and injuring 57.

title: Ulster's Leader Signs Orders For the Internment of 219 Men
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 15Prime Minister Brian Faulkner announced today that he had signed internment pa pers for 219 men suspected of being members of the Irish Re publican Army.

title: Protesters Staging Rallies As Prison Dispute Widens
description: The controversy over the deaths in the Attica Correc tional Facility continued una bated yesterday in statements from public officials, in the editorial pages of newspapers, in demands for investigations and in the streets.

title: Helicopter Chief Says He Told Henderson of Killings at Mylai
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 15 The commander of a heli copter unit during the assault on Mylai 4 testified today that he had told Col. Oran K. Hen derson of reports by his pilots that some 125 noncombatants had been killed by American soldiers.

title: DAMAGE SURVEYED AS FLOODS RECEDE
description: CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 15  Goodby, of house, said Er vin Gillis as he blew a fare well kiss in the direction of his home in the Eyre Park section of Chester, you and me are parting company.

title: BRANIFF DECLARES 3% STOCK DIVIDEND
description: Braniff Airways, Inc., which last February said it was sus pending cash dividends on its common stock to conserve cash and to provide for future air craft purchases, yesterday voted a 3 per cent stock divi dend for 1971 on common.

title: APPOINTS CHIEF OF INQUIRY
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 15 Governor Rockefeller designat ed Deputy Attorney General Robert E. Fischer today to con duct a broad investigation into events before, during and after the rebellion in the Attica Cor rectional Facility.

title: 98 Markets Accused of Violating Price Freeze
description: The city's largest union of public employes said yesterday that 98 of the 102 Manhattan supermarkets it surveyed this week were violating President Nixon's price freeze because they did not have available for public inspection a list of top prices charged for each item in the month before the freeze began.

title: Sales Begin in BonelessBeef Futures
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange began trading yes terday in imported frozen bonelessbeef futures.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On opening day Jan Kodes, an unseeded Czechoslovak, gazed upon the hallowed lawns of Forest Hills and said, I think that tennis on grass is a joke. This was not exactly a diplomatic remark, not when Californians, artificial turf manufacturers, egalitarians and players with slow, steady retrieval games, among others, had regarded grass courts as, variously, unjustifiably expensive, wasteful, too fast and bad for business, Kodes, a 25yearold who had made his reputation on slower, more reliable clay courts, felt that the bad bounces on grass made being lucky more im portant than being good.

title: U.S. UNSATISFIED BY 6% RISE IN YEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A top Presidential assistant was quoted today as saying the up ward revaluations of other countries currencies desired by the United States was a big number.

title: Militia Attacked Meeting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15The Saigon police chief said today that Govern ment militiamen had attacked an antiwar meeting attended by Senator McGovern here last night. He charged that the Senator had unwittingly been meeting with Vietcong agents before the militiamen broke up the gathering with gunfire and firebombs.

title: Vietnam Student Group Attacking G.I's and Trucks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15A scrawny 16year old Vietnamese high school stu dent, who loathes American sol diers, tried his best today to burn an American Army van and the G.I. driving it.

title: New Directions
description: ATTICA, N. Y.Since assuming the office eight months ago, we'have been working toward development of a re direction in overall programming for state correctional facilities. Many of you are aware of my philosophy in new directions and some of the steps already taken. Many of you have written favorably with reference to some of the changes already made. The main impact of the new direction for the department is the recognition of the individual as a human being and the need for basic fairness throughout our daytoday relation ships with each other.

title: The Economy, War and Fear
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  Most Americans fear that economic instability rather than foreign hostility will push the United States into another war, the pollster Samuel Lubell told Congress today.

title: Semblance of Outward Normality Returns to Attica as Some. Policemen Depart
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 15 A semblance of outward nor mality returned today to the State Correctional Facil ity here, as the tensions of the nearly weeklong crisis of in surrection and recapture sub sided.

title: New Commuter Cars Roll
description: The first of a group of 80 new airconditioned commuter cars began service on the Penn Central's Harlem line yesterday on two scheduled commuter runs between Westchester and Grand Central Terminal.

title: NO ALTERNATIVE
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day strongly defended the storming of the Attica Correc tional Facility on Monday to quell a prisoner revolt and said he was right in refusing to visit the prison personally at the request of a committee seeking a nonviolent solution to the uprising.

title: Chemical Ingredients In Detergent Dispute;
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Following are the major chemical formulations in volved in the detergent controversy:

title: Italian Company Hit by TakeOver Bid
description: ROME, Sept. 15A take over bid by an unidentified international group aimed at one of Italy's largest holding companies has caused sudden excitement on the chronically sluggish stock markets in this country.

title: The Animals at Attica
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 After massacre at Attica, Governor Rocke feller issued a statement that began with this sentence:

title: ABORTION AN ISSUE IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15 The Westchester Republican leadership believes that Roman Catholic priests in Northern Westchester, by raising the abortion issue two days before primary day, substantially con tributed to the narrow, un expected defeat of R. Bradlee Boal, a leading member of the county Legislature.

title: Executive Changes
description: Braniff Airways, Inc., announced in Dallas the election of Mrs. Albert Lasker of New York, noted philanthropist, as a director of the company. Harding L. Lawrence, chairman of Braniff, pointed out that Mrs. Lasker was the firit woman to serve on the board as well as one of the few to serve as di rector of any major cor poration. Mrs. Lasker's election to the board re flects her outstanding organizational acumen as well as Braniffs aware ness that women repre sent a vital air traffic market, both in themselves and for their influence on their families, said Mr. Lawrence. Mrs. Lasker, the widow of Albert D. Lasker, who is known as a pioneer of modern advertising, has been particularly active on behalf of medical research.

title: Chess:Alphonse and Gaston Style Usually Low in Excitement
description: When two players from the same country meet in an international tournament, the result is often a quick, even perfunctory, draw. This is especially true of players from some of the countries of Eastern EuropeRussians and Yugoslays, particularly. When two Yugoslays meet in the international arena, a de cisive result is most unlikely.

title: Merger News
description: The Interstate Brands Cor poration announced yesterday that Illinois Central Industries, Inc., had offered to buy the company.

title: Detergent Companies Hail U.S. Step on Phosphates
description: Detergent makers and phos phate suppliers welcomed the Government's statement yester day backing the use of phos phates in detergents, although some companies expressed dis appointment over the continued ban of nitrilotriacetic acid, or NTA, as a substitute ingredient to build the power of the de tergents.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Kenneth Clark, the psychologist, said the other day that it might save the world from a big explosion if its most powerful leaders had to take a sort of peace pill, which would be designed to keep the natural aggressive instincts of these hyperaggressive men subdued by chemical action.

title: What the Audience Was Wearing and What Scaasi Was Showing
description: Charity luncheons aren't exactly a dime a dozen these days. Neither are custom designers. So when Arnold Scaasi introduced his fall collection at the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel yesterday for the benefit of the American Cancer Society, everybody trooped in. It was, after all, a change. Besides Mrs. Stephen M. Sanford had asked them. She'd had a great success fundraising in Palm Beach for the charity last winter. She wanted to get things swinging in New York early this season.

title: Videotape of the Raid Was Made by Troopers
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 15 State troopers, using a video tape camera, filmed the assault Monday on the Attica prison's rebellious inmates, a spokes man for the state police said today.

title: Atlantic Air Fare Cut Due As Lufthansa Bars Accord
description: Lufthansa yesterday dis avowed the agreement that fixes the price of air travel be tween North America and Europe. The West German air line's decision will bring sharp reductions in transAtlantic air fares, and possibly a price war, on Feb. 1.

title: Rulings on WagePrice Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Following is the text of Pol icy Statement No. 19 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Stage: Swanson Is Back
description: Leonard Gershe's comedy Butterflies Are Free has been at the Booth Theater for nearly two years now and it still has a settled air to it. It is a warm and funny play, and it has a quality of heart to it that never degenerates into mush and sentimentality.

title: FREEZE NO SPUR TO BUYING PLANS
description: Consumer buying plans showed no appreciable increase in the weeks immediately fol lowing President Nixon's an nouncement of a wageprice freeze, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: Owners to Run City School Buses Through Tuesday
description: School bus operators here agreed yesterday to continue service through Tuesday while they make a further attempt to obtain Federal approval of their new contracts with the Board of Education.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on Jor dan's complaint.

title: Detective Dupes, Kills Man Who Held Woman as Hostage
description: A police detective, posing as a lawyer shot and fatally wounded a man who had held a cleaning woman hostage for more than an hour last might in the Federal Court House at Foley Square.

title: Harald Lander, Choreographer And Danish Ballet Master, Dies
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 15Harald Lander, Dan ish ballet master and choreog rapher, died here yesterday of leukemia. He was 66 years old.

title: BILL COLLECTORS MAY BE LICENSED
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz urged yesterday that all debtcollection agencies in the state be licensed to reduce fraud and diminish forms of debtor harassment.

title: Schick Appoints Chairman And Adds Board Members
description: Schick Electric, Inc, an nounced yesterday in Los An geles the election of Edward E. Ettinger as chairman succeed ing Patrick J. Frawley Jr., who retains the post of chairman of the executive committee.

title: A HASIDIC MUSICAL TO BE STAGED HERE
description: An English version of Only Fools Are Sad, an Israeli prize winning musical, will be pres ented at the Edison Theater, 240 West 47th Street, on Nov. 22 by Yaacov Agmon, who con ceived and produced it in Tel, Aviv in 1968 for a run of 600 performances.

title: Graduate Courses to Be Offered By Adelphi Aboard L.I.R. Cars
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., Sept 15 Starting Oct. 18, Adelphi Uni versity will teach graduate courses in business administra tion aboard commuting class rooms attached to a regularly scheduled Long Island Railroad train that leaves Port Jefferson, L.I., each day at 5:56 A.M.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Diplomatic. The White House announced that Guil ford Dudley Jr. has resigned as Ambassador to Denmark effective Nov. 1. Mr. Dudley will return to his former po sition as chairman of the board of the Life and Casu alty Insurance Company in Nashville. From Nov. 1 to Jan. 1, he will serve as an unpaid White House con sultant on matters relating to commercial business.

title: Rangers Showing Good Form In Practice at Camp in Ontario
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 15At 6 A.M., one hour be fore the Sun rose today over the flat horizon of this quiet city an southern Ontario, 26 New York Ranger hockey players rolled from bed and went out to play.

title: Prof J. D. Bernal, Physicist, Dies at 70
description: LONDON, Sept. 15Prof. J. D. Bernal, the eminent physicist, died here today after a long illness. His age was 70.

title: Retail Ticketing System Introduced by Dennison
description: The Dennison Manufacturing Company introduced yesterday a new retail merchandise tick eting and data system. The new system, called Meritag, has a ticket that carries up to 48 characters of information in easy to read printing on its face side. The identical infor mation is magnetically encoded on electronic bits on the re verse side.

title: 5.5Meter Sail Series Put Off
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 15 The Scandinavian Gild Cup 15.5Meter team race series, scheduled to start today on Long Island Sound, was post poned 24 hours because of lack of wind.

title: Industrial Output Fell Sharply in August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Industrial production declined substantially in August for the second consecutive month, largely because of a big falloff in steel output, the Federal Re serve Board reported today.

title: 3 SERVICE CHIEFS PRESS FOR DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Nixon Administration, in letters from the three service chiefs to each United States Senator and in a television ap pearance by Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, maintained public pressure today for im mediate Congressional approval of draft legislation.

title: Been Down So Long' on Film
description: Richard Faria's first and last novel, "Been Down So Long It Looks Like Up to Me," begins in the fall of 1958, the autumn of the Eisenhower years, a time of Vanguard rockets and Murray the K and Batista, of Dharma Bums who took to the road to learn about life and then celebrated what they found in literature that Truman Capote once classified as mere typewriting."Been Down So Long," however, was written in the 1960's (it was published in 1966, shortly before its author was killed in a motorcycle accident), and although set in the time of the Beats, it has the sound and feel of the decade that was yet to come. This explains, I think, something of the schizoid nature of the film adaptation that opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie.Gnossos Pappadopoulis (Barry Primus) has, it's true, been on the road when he returns to college to resume his academic career, but from the length of his hair and the rhythm of his speech, he's been mushing through the America that the men in "Easy Rider" could not find, not through Kerouac country. As a matter of fact, the unnamed school that Gnossos attends could well be the locale of a number of other movies about the late 1960's, including Jack Nicholson's "Drive, He Said."All of this would be nitpicking if "Been Down So Long" had any particular identity of its own. It doesn't. Robert Schlitt, who wrote the screen adaptation, and Jeff Young, who directed it, have excised practically all of the novel's lunatic, literary exuberance. What remains is a rite-of-university-passage of sophomoric angst, of dumb melodrama, and of such depressing familiarity that I feel as if I'd been burdened with someone else's memory, while having been denied the pleasure of the original experience.The young performers are attractive and, when occasionally given the opportunity (especially for comedy), they do very well indeed. Primus has a short but marvelous sequence in which he disrupts a fraternity rush (one of the few sequences that really fix the film in its time) by accusing a shorthaired "brother" of homosexual tendencies.I also liked David Downing, as a black student who turns, rather gently, toward militancy, and Linda DeCoff, as the virginal co-ed whose farewell gift to Gnossos requires treatment with penicillin. "Bringing this to Havana," says the Cuban doctor to Gnossos, "is like bringing bread to a bakery." He is, of course, talking about the Havana of Meyer Lansky and Lucky Pierre, not of Castro.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS ALASKA LAND CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The Senate Interior Com mittee approved today a bill to settle aboriginal land claims of Alaska natives by giving them $1billion and up to 40 million acres.

title: Stein, After Visit to L.I. Farms, Will Ask Laws to Aid Migrants
description: CUTCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 15 Assemblyman Andrew Stein said today he would sponsor legislation that would bring mi grant farmworkers in New York State under the provisions of workmen's compensation and unemployment insurance.

title: Bond Market Struggles To End Its Sinking Spell
description: The bond market yesterday seemed to be trying snap out of its recent sinking spell. Some sectors succeeded and others didn't. Treasury securities rose in price, some for the second day in a row, and taxexempt bond dealers talked about a better atmos phere in their market.

title: Books of The Times
description: MESSAGE FROM MALAGA. By Helen Mac Imes. 367 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovano vich. $6.95.

title: Iran Affirms Support
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 15 Iran today affirmed her support of Pakistan for the first time since the Pakistani Army moved in March to crush the independence movement in East Pakistan.

title: Cuts in Employes and SST Refund Lift August Profit of American Airlines
description: American Airlines, Inc., re ported yesterday a net income for August of $14,933,000, or 61 cents a sharp, compared with $6,984,000, or 34 cents, in August of last year.

title: Arthur Hill Is Star of New A.B.C. Series
description: The American Broadcasting Company is offering an in triguingly mixed bag of new faces this season: blind in surance investigators (James Franciscus in Longstreet), aggressively seductive news paperwomen (Shirley Mac Leine in Shirley's World), aging teeny  hopper idols (Bobby Sherman in Getting Together) and miniJames Bonds (Roger Moore and Tony Curtis in The Persuaders).

title: JORDANIAN KING WARNS FEDAYEEN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 Representatives of the Jor danian Government and the Palestinian guerrillas were in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, today for a conference to discuss the possibility of reconciliation.

title: A Brazilian Youth's Joys and Shocks:' Plantation Boy' Opens at 5th Ave. Cinema Benjamin Proves Deft Comic in 'The Steagle'
