description: Cinema Novo, the Brazilian moviemaking movement dedicated to a re-examination of, if not an outright break with, their film Establishment, is generally complimented by "The Plantation Boy," which began a two-day stand yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.As a remembrance of pleasant things past and auguries of a sadder future, it is a bittersweet blend of a somewhat disjointed memoir of a boy's joys and shocks and an oblique reflection on a benign, autocratic, landed society being pushed toward mechanization.Walter Lima Jr., who wrote the script and made his feature directorial debut with "Plantation Boy" in 1965, shot his film in Paraimba, in rural north Brazil, which, to all appearances, must look like the 1920 sugar plantation setting of the original.While he has not extracted towering performances from his principals, most of his cast, especially the titular hero, his grandfather and owner of the plantation, and the boy's aunt and uncle, are natural in their reactions to the serious and rare lighter episodes in the drama.Carlinho, the boy sent to the plantation after his mother has died, is exposed to a world he never knew including a variety of relatives, the mechanics of the plantation, a rural school, a young aunt he loves dearly whom he loses when she marries; a pet lamb he loses to the butcher; the death of a young cousin; a Negro farmhand literally put in stocks for refusing to marry a girl who says he violated her; his doting grandfather proud of his acres but aware that prompters for a refinery are closing in and the frolics at a sylvan pool with a visiting young girl.Savio Rollm, a dark-haired, introspective youngster who plays Carlinho with subdued sincerity, gives credibility to these varied vignettes, including a tearful farewell as he leaves the scenes of his childhood for school. Rodolfo Arena portrays his grandfather, an austere gentleman with cane and a straw sombrero, to the manner born. Anecy Rocha is properly affectionate as his aunt and Geraldo Del Rey, as his uncle, does well by a changing character as he is smitten by an unrequited love and the desire for industrialization.If "Plantation Boy" merely hints at outlaws who sometimes preyed on these tracts a half-century ago, "Memories of the Cangaco," the documentary on the bill, also made in 1965, focuses on these bands, their leaders and pursuers. Authentic old and new footage underlines that they were either brigands or peasant Robin Hoods in rebellion against the army and the police in a strange record that is hardly the touching matter that "Plantation Boy" is. With literal English subtitles for the Portuguese dialogue, the tandem does, however, give us a sharp view of hitherto largely vague people and places.

title: Yahya Visits Teheran for Talks; Peace Moves With India Hinted
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 15 President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan returned to Paki stan today after a oneday trip to Iran, where he was said to have held secret talks of great political importance. A communiqu said only that he had discussed matters of mu tual importance with the Iran ian Government.

title: Guards Put Down Disorder in Great Meadow Prison
description: Prisoners were disorderly yesterday at the Great Meadow Correctional Facility and a planned rebellion was reported to have been thwarted at Clin ton Prison, both in upstate New York, as tensions con tinued at jails in this state and elsewhere in the nation.

title: Ending the Monetary Crisis
description: The inability even to agree on an agenda symbolizes the difficulties that confront the ten leading industrial nations as their finance ministers and central bankers meet in London to seek answers to the world monetary and trade crisis. There is no agreed agenda because the United States and its nine major trading partners want to start negotiating on different issues.

title: Stop Demanded at 96th St. In 2d Ave. Subway Hearing
description: The priricipal demands of citizens groups at the first public hearing on the proposed Second Avenue subway last night were a station at 96th Street and four tracks instead of two.

title: U.S. Keeps Trevino Out Of Ryder Cup LineUp
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15  Lee Trevino, the United States, Brit ish and Canadian Open cham pion, was omitted from the United States lineup scheduled to oppose the visiting profes sional golfers from Britain and Ireland in the opening team matches tomorrow for the Ry der Cup.

title: OBSERVER
description: ATLANTASoutherners these days find themselves in an unaccustomed, indeed, unheard of positionlooking down upon instead of up to the rest of the nation.

title: Finland Seeks Comecon Link
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept, 15 (UPI)Premier Ahti Karjalainen said today that Finland was ex ploring the possibility of eco nomic cooperation with Come con, East Europe's economic bloc.

title: Primary Gives Mayor Role in Tammany Choice
description: The results of the Manhattan primary gave Mayor Lindsay a potentially decisive role for the first time in the selection of a major Democratic party of ficial, the Manhattan leader, district leaders said yesterday.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change yesterday overcame early weakness and finished mixed on moderate trading.

title: Mayor Tightens Operations Of Municipal Loan Program
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday additonal measures to tighten up the fiscal opera tions of the Municipal Loan Program, which has been under investigation.

title: News of Dogs
description: An adage attributed to the medieval monk, St. Bernard, is Love me, love my dog. However, with urban living conditions so crowded one cannot be quite so dogmatic.

title: Nixons to Fete Astronauts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reu ters)President and Mrs. Nixon will give a private dinner at the White House tomorrow night for the three Apollo 15 astronauts and their families. The astronauts  Col. David Scott, Col. James Irwin and Lieut. Col. Alfred Worden made their successful moon trip last month.

title: Return to Detergents With Phosphates Urged by Government in Shift of Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  In a major reversal of environ mental policy, Federal officials told American housewives to clay to return to the use of phosphate detergents.

title: Hong Kong to Restrict Textile Exports
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 15The Hong Kong Government an nounced today the introduction of voluntary controls on the export of manmade fiber and woolen textiles to the United States for 12 months starting Oct. 1.

title: Federal Inquiry Charges Bon Vivant Soup Factory Had Wide Sanitary Violations and Faulty Records
description: A Government investigative team that completed a detailed study of the Bon Vivant Soups, Inc., plant in Newark has found what it considers such inade quate sanitary procedures and such careless record keeping that it says none [of the firm's products] are consid ered  to be safe for con sumption by man or animal.

title: Panel of 5 Is Named To Protect Prisoners
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP) A panel of five impartial visitors, including a black and a Puerto Rican, were named by a judge today to protect the constitutional rights of Attica prison in mates.

title: COBAN JENKINS
description: Hugh Coban Jenkins Jr., newspaperman, died at Univer sity Hospital here Tuesday night after a short illness. He was 42 years old.

title: HICKEL LISTS CAUSES OF BREAK WITH NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Walter J. Hickel, former Sec retary of the Interior, says that the antiwar march on Washing ton, the military incursion into Cambodia, Vice President Ag new's criticism of the nation's news media and the fatal shooting of four students on the Kent State University cam pus led to his break with the Nixon Administration.

title: Judy Dalton Eliminated In Tennis at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 15 (UPI)Fifthseeded Judy Dal Iton of Australia became the second major upset victim in the Virginia Slims Louisville invitation tennis tournament to day as she lost to unseeded Becky Vest of Jackson, Miss., 75, 76. Leley Hunt of Australia lost yesterday to Mona Schal lau of Iowa City, Iowa, who bowed today to Margie Cooper of Winter Park, Fla., 3.6, 64, 61.

title: YUGOSLAV MISSION CLOSES VISIT TO U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A Yugoslav military mission, the first in 20 years, has just com pleted a nineday visit to the United States, officials con firmed today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The opinion that we are winning the war against pollution expressed by. Eugene Guccione on his Aug. 28 OpEd column is based upon conclu sions that are often inaccurate and certainly misleading.

title: 3 British Groups Offer Blues Styles Here
description: The blues rolled into Car negie Hall like a wave Tues day night. Three British groupsSavoy Brown, John Baldry and his friends, and Wishbone Ash  roared, rocked and rolled their way through blues styles that ranged from Muddy Waters to Miles Davis.

title: Lindsay Defines Foreign Role of U. S.
description: Mayor Lindsay, who has long advocated a change in national priorities to give greater empha sis to urban problems, warned yesterday that domestic needs should not be overemphasized at the expense of the nation's role in world affairs.

title: STOCKS REBOUND FOR SLIGHT GAIN
description: The stock market edged higher yesterday after four de clining sessions. In the absence of any meaningful news devel opments, Wall Street analysts described the improvement as mainly technical.

title: 8 Trotters Clear New York's First Prerace Drug Test
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 Prerace drug testing made its New York debut tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, giving bet tors a virtual guarantee that no horse was being helped or hindered by an illegal medica tion.

title: BALTIMORE VICTOR HAS QUIET APPEAL
description: BALTIMORE, Sept, 15Bal timore's next city administra tion will probably be marked by a lack of flamboyance and a jot of extra working hours, if the man most likely to be Mayor lives up to his 16year reputation as a City Council man.

title: MORE TIME SOUGHT BY PENN CENTRAL
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15Trustees of the Penn Central need an other six months to determine the earnings prospects of the bankrupt carrier and on Friday will ask the Federal Court in Philadelphia for a sixmonth extension of the deadline for coming up with a reorganiza tion plan, a trustee of the bankrupt line said today.

title: Alaska Under Siege
description: The oil companies, mining interests and land specu lators have Alaska under siege. The discovery three years ago of huge oil and gas deposits evoked an upsurge of economic lust that makes the Klondike gold rush look almost as genteel as a church cake sale.

title: Israelis Say Egyptians Build SAM Complex Near Canal
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Israeli military sources said today that Egypt has started setting up a surfacetoair mis sile complex in the central sector of the Suez Canal, about two miles from the waterway.

title: Botany Fills Key Post
description: Botany Industries, Inc., an nounced the formation of an executive committee headed by Samuel Holtzman, a director and head of its Baltimore Lug gage Division. The other direc tors who are members of the executive committee are Michael Daroff, chairman and president of Botany Industries, Joseph Daroff, president of H. Daroff & Sons, Inc., Clarenct, Hafford, president of Clonoit Mills, Inc., Henry C. Schwartz, president of the Botany Retail Division, and Robert Todd Lang of Weil, Gotehal & Manges, counsel to the company.

title: Smith Beats Kodes for U.S. Open Title
description: Stan Smith, a rejected ball boy, won the United States Open tennis championship yes terday.

title: NASDAQ'S VOLUME EXCEEDS AMEX'S
description: Volume of overthecounter securities traded through NAS DAQ, the National Association of Securities Dealers Auto mated Quotations system, is running ahead of that on the American Stock Exchange and roughly half that on the New York Stock Exchange, Gordon Macklin Jr., president of the N.A.S.D., reported yesterday.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The New York and the American Stock Ex changes yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in share ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers, of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Stars Suspend, Fine Peeples
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 15 (UPI)  George Peeples was placed on indefinite suspension today and fined $250 a day for not reporting to the Utah Stars preseason training camp.

title: Advertising:
description: National Airlines has gone girl crazy and the noses of its jets will soon be adorned with girls names much in the style of World., War II bombers. The advertising will go right along with the trend and both TV and print will spotlight pretty young things (frequently giggling) Who say something like I'm Cheryl, fly me, or Fly me to Lon don.

title: A's Top White Sox,32, And Clinch West Flag
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) The Oakland A's won the American League's West Di ision championship tonight, riding Sal Bando's tworun homer in the eighth inning to a 32 victory over the Chi cago White Sox. The triumph coupled with Kansas City's 62 loss to Califorhia, gave the A's their first title since 1931, when Connie Mack di rected the Philadelphia Ath letics to the American League pennant.

title: World Bank Says Refugee Cost May Stunt Indian Development
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 15A World Bank report has con cluded that India's economic development could be seriously stunted by the cost of support ing the millions of Bengali refu gees who have fled into India from East Pakistan.

title: Advertising:
description: Lots of advertising is need ed to sell the idea of adver tising, the head of the world's largest advertising agency told a group that lives on ad vertising yesterday. There was applause.

title: Egypt in the Mood For a Settlement, British Aide Says
description: CAIRO, Sept. 15The Brit ish Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, said today at a news conference that three days of consultations in Cairo had convinced him that Egypt was in a mood for permanent peace with Israel.

title: Historical District Named in Brooklyn
description: A particularly gracious neighborhood in the heart of the BedfordStuyvesant slum area in Brooklyn was estab lished yesterday as the city's 17th historic district.

title: Troopers Assert They Chose Their Targets Carefully During Storming of Prison
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 15 State troopers insisted today that they had closely followed orders issued before their as sault on the rebel prisoners of the Attica Correctional Facility that they had chosen their targets carefully.

title: Liquor Store Manager Kills 1 of 3 Holdup Men in Bronx
description: A Bronx liquor store mana ger, who was shot four times during a robbery last night, shot and killed one of three holdup men. The manager is in critical condition at Morrisania Hospi tal.

title: A Town Liberated by Cambodians Counts the Cost
description: KOMPONG THMAR, Cambo dia, Sept. 15Kompong Thmar used to be a town of 10,000 people. The Cambodian Army liberated it on Aug. 31 after more than a year of Com munist control. Today there are only blackened holes where the many wooden houses stood. The nearby trees are scorched from the, heat of the fire that obliterated the empty town after air strikes  by United States and Cambodian bombers.

title: OMAN SEEKS OFFERS FOR OIL CONCESSION
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 (AP)  The Oman Government plans to invite public tenders for a large offshore oil concession that had been held by the Wendell Phillips Oil Company of the United States, it was learned today.

title: BRANDT BACKS PLAN TO MEET BREZHNEV
description: BONN, Sept. 15 Respond ing to mounting press criticism and suggestions that some of West Germany's allies are an noyed, Chancellor Willy Brandt asserted today that his, private rneeting Friday with the Soviet party leader, Leonid I. Brezh nev, would be useful to all concerned.

title: U. S. Manufacturers Glum
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The American Textile Manu facturers Institute denounced Hong Kong's restraint program today as inadequate and in effective. John E. Reeves, president of the group, said the Hong Kong program was far cry from the restraints sought by the Nixon Admin istration and was no answer to this country's problem of textile imports.

title: TRADING WIDENED IN FEDERAL FUNS
description: A new development, which is being watched with concern by the Federal Reserve Sys tem, has cropped up in the Fed eral funds marketthe sprawl ing, nationwide market for loans between commercial banks.

title: The Midonick Meaning
description: The victory of Family Court Judge Millard L. Midonick in the rainy Democratic party primary for Manhattan Surrogate is a clear mandate for reform of this politics ridden court. At the same time it represents an impor tant psychological boost for the Reform Democrats their effort to take judicial designations out of machine politics.

title: Federal Environmental Aide Predicts Tax on Nonreturnable Bottles Within Two Years
description: The top Federal official con cerned with solid waste dispo sal said yesterday that within two years, Congress would be forced to pass laws either tax ing or prohibiting nonreturn able bottles and cans.

title: Talks with 20 Governors Bouy Muskie
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 15 Senator Edmund S. Muskie con ferred with 20 of the 29 Demo cratic Governors today and his political aides reported later that he had won an encour aging reception from all of them and commitments of backing from four.

title: Investigating Attica
description: The enormity of the tragedy at Attica and the many question marks that hang over the slaughter of hostages and prisoners there require the most searching inquiry, conducted under the most impartial circumstances. Such an inquiry is important to every official and citizen New York State, from Governor Rockefeller down; it important to the whole cause of justice and respect for the rule of law.

title: Prison Leaders in 8 States Support Assault at Attica
description: Prison chiefs in at least eight states generally uphold the storming of the Attica Cor rectional Facility, and some even believe that the assault should have come sooner.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: DELEGATION NAMED FOR KOREAN TALKS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 15The South Korean Red Cross appointed five delegates today for the preliminary talks with its North Korean counter part, scheduled to start Mon day at Panmunjom, on the problem of divided families.

title: Collins Shoots 69, Leads State Golf At Spa by. Stroke
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 15  Longhitting Bill Collins of Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N. Y., scored a 35, 3469, three under par, to lead by a stroke in the $30,000 MarlboroNew York State Professional Golfers Association championship on the 7,109yard Spa course to day.

title: MEDINA DEFENSE GAINS TWO POINTS
description: FORT MEPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 15The impeachment of a key Government witness and the admission as evidence of a reported statement by First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that tended to exonerate Capt. Ernest L. Medina of responsi bility for the killings at the Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai were achieved by the defense today at the Medina court martial.

title: Giants Beaten, 42, by Reds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 Jim McGlothlin, a shopworn rightbander who has had his share of problems this year, added to the San Francisco Giants troubles tonight while pitching the Cincinnati Reds to a 42 victory.

title: Opera:Ariodante at Kennedy Center
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Handel's operas can be counted on to lend a festive air to any occasion. They deal with royalty, and they give the designers a reason for dressing the stage with baroque magnificence. It was not unnatural for Julius Ru del, music director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, to choose Handel's Ariodante for its second production. It was given the first of two performances last night in the opera house, and it made a fine, sharp contrast to Leonard Bernstein's Mass, the center's inaugural pres entation.

title: Rulings on WagePrice Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Following is the text of Pol icy Statement No. 20 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: OTB NETS $375,000 ON AUGUST BETTING
description: Offtrack betting flourished in New York during August de spite repeated computer break downs, Howard Samuels said yesterday.

title: New C.B.S. Chief Discusses Plans
description: Charles T. Ireland Jr., who was recently named to succeed Dr. Frank Stanton as president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, comes to the post with a clean ideological slate. He says he knows almost nothing about the broadcasting indus try and almost never watches television.

title: KRETCHMER HITS PHOSPHATE MOVE
description: New York City's chief en vironmental official differed sharply yesterday with the changed Federal attitude to ward phosphates in detergents.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: You cannot have jawboning that is effective with out teeth.President Nixon. [1:8.]

title: OCEAN HILL STAYS 2 REASSIGNMENTS
description: The community school board of District 23 in Brooklyn, which includes the former Ocean HillBrownsville demon stration district, has ratified and then stayed the controversial reassignment of two acting principals to district headquar ters.

title: Weather Rocket Ejects Cloud
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Sept. 16 (AP)  A weather rocket ejected a lythiumbarium cloud today, leaving a reddish cloud visible over parts of the East Coast. The National Aeronau tics and Space Administration said the NikeApache sounding rocket was launched at 5:56 A.M. after several postpone ments. The trail, extending from 50 to 106 miles in alti tude, is used for testing the movement of the winds.

title: Guard's Burial Delayed
description: AUBURN, N. Y., Sept. 16 One hundred and fifty correc tion officers as well as county and city officials formed an honor guard today as funeral services were conducted for John J. D'Arcangelo, one of the nine hostages killed Monday at the State Correctional Facility at Attica.

title: GOV. JAMES HARRISON
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Sept. 16 (UPI)Gov. James Harrison of South Australia died of a heart attack today while aboard an aircraft bound for Hawaii, a Government spokes man announced. The spokes man said that the Governor, who was 59 years old, and his wife had left here Monday at the start of a world tour.

title: U.S. COURT ENJOINS 9 IN TEXAS DEALS Sharp Is Called Guilty of Civil Law Violations
description: DALLAS, Sept. 16  A Fed eral court issued a permanent injunction today against Frank W. Sharp and eight other Texas businessmen, ordering them not, to resume selling unregistered stock in companies that the judge said were involved in a stock manipulation scheme.

title: 39 Detergents Assessed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following is a list made public today by the Food and Drug Administration of 39 detergents it has analyzed and assessed for potential health hazards:

title: Blast at Nuclear Plant
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 16 An explosion of electrical equipment in a building at nuclear energy plant today in jured 11 persons, one seriously.

title: Lieb Leads Shields
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16 Warren H. Lieb of Columbia Yacht Club, Chicago, sailed into a 3point lead in the seventh annual Shields Class national championship today by placing fifth and second for 7 points in the first two races of the fiverace regatta on Long Island Sound off the Indian Harbor Y.C.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon met with the executive com mittee of the National Gov ernors Conference and rep resentatives of the National Association of Counties, the United; States Conference of Mayors, the National League of Cities and the National Legislative Conference. After holding an afternoon news conference, he was host at a private dinner for the Apollo 15 astronauts and their families.

title: DR. SALVATORE R. PORTO
description: Dr. Salvatore R. Porto, asso ciate surgeon of St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, and a prac ticing physician in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, for 39 years, died at his home on Monday of a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived at 463 83d Street, Brooklyn.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: PANEL ON RIGHTS WILL MEET TODAY
description: The fiveman panel set up to protect the rights of inmates of the Attica Correctional Facility will meet at 9 A.M. today in Attica to discuss procedures for carrying out its assignment.

title: Strengths of Vuillard Illuminated in Toronto Show
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16The French painter Edouard Vuil lard (18681940) is not one of those artists who are con stantly on our minds. Indeed, his work is so agreeableso shamelessly easy to like Shat we are sometimes in danger of forgetting exactly how strong and original it is. We cannot be too often re minded that Vuillard, in ad dition to being an artist of enormous charm, was also at trmes an artist of remarkable force and audacity.

title: Marcos. Hints His Wife May Run, Assails a Foe as Red
description: MANILA, Sept. 16President Ferdinand E. Marcos charged today that the secretary general of the opposition Liberal party, Senator Benigno S. Aquino Jr., was a Communist and said he would act to prevent him from becoming President even if Mrs. Imelda R. Marcos, the President's wife, had to run.

title: Nixon Repeats Support For Governor's Action
description: President Nixon reaffirmed yesterday his support of Gov ernor Rockefeller's handling of the uprising at the Attica Cor rectional Facility, and said of the rebellion that, like all tragic events, it has its affirma tive aspects.

title: SAMUEL A. JACOBS, DESIGNER OF BOOKS
description: Samuel A. Jacobs, a typog rapher, who designed books of E. E. Cummings, the poet, and other authors, died yesterday in Yonkers General Hospital. He was 80 years old and had lived at the Sans Souci Nursing Home in Yonkers.

title: Bond Market Stirred to Phase 2 Rally by Nixon's Talk
description: The bond market, which had been feeling rather ill in places this week, sprang back to life late yesterday afternoon after it received a new and pre sumably more effective dose of Nixon medicine.

title: The Screen:' The Bear and the Doll' Opens Run at Paris
description: It's a measure of the appeal of Michel Deville's "The Bear and the Doll," a witless romantic fable about two perfectly mismatched lovers, that for most of its running time Brigitte Bardot is the bear and Jean-Pierre Cassel is the doll.Miss Bardot plays what used to be calledat least in movies of the Great Depression  a tempestuous, headstrong heiress, but with such dumb intensity that the effect is less vivacious than voracious. Cassel, who has been an excellent comedian in the films of De Broca, is the mild-mannered cellist whose ancient Renault one day bump into her Rolls thereby prompting the kind of courtship that only the talent of the late Ernst Lubitsch might have elevated into fabulous farce.In effect, she chases him until he catches her, but the maneuverings are mostly the tactics of coy moviemaking here involving several awful child actors, windshield wipers that comment on the action, a huge but gentle dog, a Siamese cat named Prudhomme, and endless little rages between the lovers that define their real affection.Several years ago, Deville made "Benjamin," in which his appreciation for the classic comedy of manners was charmingly apparent, Charm is the ingredient that is in singularly short supply in "The Bear and the Doll," largely, I suspect, because Miss Bardot, once a sex kitten, now approaches middle age with all of the grace of a seasoned predator.The film, which is in French with English subtitles, opened yesterday at the Paris.

title: Bush Asks 35 U.N. Envoys for Support
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16  George Bush, the United States representative at the United Nations, met with the ambassadors of some 35 friendly countries today in an effort to convince them that their governments should be come cosponsors of the Ad ministration's twoChina resolu tions.

title: Pentagon Papers Figure On Hunger Strike in Prison
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  Anthony J. Russo, jailed for refusing to tell how Dr. Daniel Ellsberg obtained a secret Pentagon report on the Vietnam war, has gone on a hunger strike, authorities at Terminal Island Federal Prison revealed today.

title: ORIOLES 3 HOMERS BEAT YANKEES, 62
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 16Brooks Robinson supplied the flashy doubleknit orange uniforms the Orioles wore for the first time tonight and he also supplied the grandslam homer that powered Baltimore to a 6.2 victory over the Yankees.

title: Notes on People
description: It was a dj vu sort of thing for Senator Edward M. Kennedy yesterday when the Israeli Army helicopter in which he and his wife were riding made a forced landing on a Mediterranean beach south of Tel Aviv. This time, however, Mr. Kennedy was not hurt.

title: Mythology of a Bill
description: The effort to bring political campaign spending under reasonable control in this country has encountered so many difficulties that a bemused spectator could well fall back upon classical mythology to explain them.

title: ONEMAN TEAM: Juan Pizarro, Cubs pitcher, hit a home run in 10 victory.
description: Juan Pizarro, a 36yearold washedup lefthander, out pitched Tom Seaver for the second straight time yesterday and added insult to injury by hitting an eighthinning home run to defeat, the New York Mets, 10.

title: City Opera's Albert Herring in Bow
description: The New York City Opera, which has been more than hospitable to the works of Benjamin Britten, has added still another of the British composer's operas to its rep ertory. On Wednesday eve ning Albert Herring had its premiere at the New York State Theater.

title: Violent Us
description: LONDONIf criminals are to be punished even more severely (be it hanged or beaten or flogged or psy chologically assaulted, humiliated, de graded, or broken as human beings) who is supposed to do the punishing?

title: JAPAN'S ENVOY SEES GAP IN TIES WITH U.S.
description: Japan's Ambassador to the United States, Nobuhiko Ushiba, said last night that there was a serious communications gap between Japan and the United States, going far beyond cur rent uneasiness over money ex change rates.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M. to discuss Jordanian complaint.

title: CONNER CAPTURES WORLD STAR TITLE
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 16 (AP)  Dennis Conner of San Diego finished sixth, today in the final race of the world Star Class re gatta, but won the title on overall performance.

title: Personal Income Soared in August; Postal Rise Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Personal income increased in August by $8.8billion. The rise was an unusually large one, but the Commerce Department said that any effects from the new economic programs an nounced by President Nixon in the middle of the month were very minor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As one of many citizens of New York with varying degrees of commit ment to its improvement nay, sur vivalwho sometimes despair at the pace of progress toward those ends, it is impossible to fault Mrs. Rosen berg's reasons [letter Sept. 9] for being relieved of the burden of living, in New York City. They are personal and deepfelt (though I, for one, do not share them). I wish her and her family happiness.

title: TV : And the Premieres Roll On and On
description: Soaring majestically from the unbearable to the barely tolerable, television's pre miere week goes onand on.

title: 3 Leaders of Revolt Reported Still Alive
description: Three of the men described as leaders of the Attica re volt were reported yesterday to be alive and still in the prison.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT CITES HIS ORDEAL
description: Zhores A. Medvedev, a Soviet biologist and author, has defied official warnings and written a detailed journal of his arrest and detention in a mental hos pital last year. He was confined for 19 days and released after protests from top Soviet sci entists and writers.

title: Collins's 67 Raises His Lead to 3 Shots At 136 in Spa Golf
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 16Bill Collins, the pro at Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N. Y., increased his lead in the $30,000 Marlboro New York State Professional Golfers Association champion ship on the 7,109yard Spa course today with a record breaking 33, 3467, a 5 under par.

title: Poster prepared by Finance Administration to be displayed where cigarettes are sold
description: One trouble with New York City's new graduated ciga rette tax is that if it suc ceeds, it will fail.

title: Their Waiters May Be Ineptbut the Chef Certainly Isn't
description: Restaurants reviewed, on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their at mosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was surprised to read the editorial of Sept. 14 in The Times concerning the Nobel Prize of [Aleksandr] Sol zhenitsyn. The Times has evidently been misinformed about the facts. But it also touches upon a question of general interest, i.e., the functions of embassies in international coopera tion.

title: Bargaining Tool or Bludgeon?
description: The finance ministers of the ten richest nonCommunist nations have ended their London conference with a useful if deliberately vague  agreement that correcting the imbalances in world payments requires an appropriate realignment of currencies, but that other measures will also be needed on a wide front. One of the most crucial sectors of that front is the struggle over trade specifically, the degree to which nations are to have access to each others markets.

title: Veto of Plan Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16AI Government official said today that the Administration would consider favorably plans by Mack Trucks, Inc., to help build a large plant in the So viet Union. The official also said the Administration had not blocked the company's plans.

title: Attica Residents Inclined to Doubt Autopsy Findings
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 16 The shock suffered by resi dents here over the prison uprising and deaths seems steeped in incredulity as much as grief.

title: MORE FOR RELIEF IS APPROVED HERE
description: Because of unanticipated rises in welfare costs last year the City Council's Finance Com mittee yesterday approved an additional $52.5million in ex penses for the Department of Social Services.

title: Prices on Amex Finish Lower; PostFreeze Uncertainty Cited
description: Prices closed lower on the American Stock Exchange yes terday in slower trading.

title: Seaborg Post Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, to be United States Represent ative to the 15th session of the General Conference of the In ternational Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

title: ATTICA OFFERED AID BY MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 16  The School of Medicine at the State University at Buffalo offered today to take over much of the medical responsibility for prisoners at Attica Correctional Facility.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It is only eight years since Walter Kennedy became commissioner of the National Basketball Association and that shouldn't seem like such a terribly long time. After all, the rookies who will play in the league this season were already starting high school eight years ago, fully aware of the activities of the league they will now join. Some of the biggest stars now playingWilt Chamberlain, Oscar Robertson, Jerry West, Walt Bellamy, Dick Barnett and several otherswere already big stars then. Any fan past teenage can well re member those days and so can many teenagers. And yet, the basketball world of September, 1963, was so different from today's that it might as well have been light years removed. I couldn't help thinking about changes, Kennedy said the other day. The changes haven't been just in basketball, but they've been faster and more nu merous in our game, so we probably feel it more. But when you look back, it's fantastic. It's hard to be lieve so much can change so quickly. Because the basketball experience has been an intensified example of trends felt also in base ball, football and hockey, Kennedy's reminiscence is worth listening to. We all look at things from our personal vantage point, he said, so let me just point out some of the new things confronting a commissioner. I'm sure my opposite number in other sports have found similar situations.

title: House Rejects Broad Bill To Bar Job Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Organized labor and civil rights groups lost a major fight today as the House approved a sharp ly strippeddown version of bill designed to end, job dis crimination.

title: A JET AND A GIANT SHARE SAME WOES
description: W.K. Hicks of the New York Jets and Bennie McRae of the New York Giants were sep arated by about 25 miles yesterday, but bpth defensive backs were feeling the special pangs and pains known to the brotherhood of football players and both were worrying about their openingday games.

title: British Golfers Leading By Point For Ryder Cup
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16  The British team of golf profes sionals gained a slim lead in the first day of the biennial Ry der Cup matches today by scoring 4 points to 3 for the United States squad.

title: BROTHER HILARION
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Sept. 16 Brother Hilarion Flanagan, Maryknoll Missioner 37 years, died yesterday at the order's headquarters here. His age was 62.

title: Outlook for Fishing in Nearby Areas Over Weekend
description: AREA AThe pickings for bluefish on the Klondike slimmed out yesterday after expeditions there had paid big dividends early in the week. Capt. Dave Bogan said the Bogan's Basin's fleet's sights were being set for Barnegat Ridge for this morn ing, where blues in the Gto8 potind range were being taken in number. Chummers also have been taking alabacore there. Lots of small weakfish and flounder are be ing found in Barnegat Bay by anglers using squid or fluke rigs.

title: Rome Synod to Get Report on Charter
description: ROME, Sept 16The Vati can said today that the Synod of Bishops, due to convene here Sept. 30 for four weeks, would hear a report on a draft con stitution for the Roman Catho lic Church but hold no debate on that document.

title: Saigon Troops Put Enemy Dead at 49 In Clash in the Delta
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 (AP)South Viet namese infantrymen reported killing 49 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers today in the heaviest contact so far of an operation designed to upset an expected enemy offensive in the Mekong Delta's U Minh forest.

title: Hogan Looking Into Relocation Loans
description: Borrowers from the Munici pal Loan Fund received more lina a half million dollars for rciocation of tenants in build ings they were to rehabilitate, but were not required to prove new they spent it, according to a high law enforcement officer Wlio asked not to be identified the officer, who is close to orr of several current investi cations of the Municipal Loan Find, said the relocation money went to 32 owners of 36 build ings whose tenants have now scattered, making it difficult to aslt them Whether they had re:. ceivcd assistance in finding new quarters.

title: Police Here to Open Files and Men to Academic Researchers
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told a group of eight leading local educators yesterday that for the first time in its history the depart ment was ready to open its files, records and men to academic investigations.

title: U.S. Death Toll Is Down
description: SAIGON, Sept. 16 (UPI) American combat deaths totaled 14 last week, down two from the previous week, and the total of 49 wounded in the week was the lowest in nearly six years, the United States command reported today.

title: COAST CANDIDATES TOLD TO LIST GIFTS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 16Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. said today that he had warned 134 political candidates from 1970 either to file statements of campaign contributions from the primary and general elections or to face prosecution.

title: MEDINA DEFENDS ACTIONS AT MAI
description: FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 16  Capt. Ernest L. Medina testified at his murder trial today that he never saw the ditch at Mylai where group after group of South Viet namese civilians were herded and slain by his troops.

title: Wallace's Busing Bill Approved in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 16 (AP)The Alabama Sen ate, without a dissenting vote, passed Gov. George C. Wal lace's new antibusing law to night and sent it to Mr. Wal lace for his certain signature.

title: Prouty Successor Named In Response to Nixon Plea
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 16 (AP)Gov. Deane C. Davis re sponded to President Nixon's request for early help on draft bill vote by naming Rep resentative Robert T. Stafford to the Senate tonight.

title: GATT Group Urges U.S. To Drop Surcharge Soon
description: GENEVA, Sept. 16  The 55 member council of GATT adopt ed unanimously today a report holding the 10 per cent United States import surcharge not compatible with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It urged the United States to remove it within a short time.

title: Moratorium on Excellence
description: The suspension for at least one year of the annual competition for Woodrow Wilson Fellowships represents a dismaying new entry on higher education's finan cial fever chart. These grants have constituted one the most successful devices for the identification and training of highquality college teachers. That funds have dried up, even if perhaps only temporarily, signifies a deplorable lack of foresight by those foundations that have kept the fellowship competition alive since the Ford Foundation terminated most of its original support in 1967.

title: Dance: Delacorte's First of Two Rain Specials
description: Raindrops have fallen on the head of the New York Dance Festivaland fallen so hard that the festival has had four successive perform ances rained out or washed away.

title: WESTINGHOUSE GETS REACTOR CONTRACT
description: The Georgia Power Company announced yesterday the selec tion of the Westinghouse Elec tric Corporation to supply two 1.1millionkilowatt pressurized water reactor systems with as sociated equipment and nuclear fuel for a new nuclear power plant to be built near Augusta, Ga.

title: Advertising:
description: The people who create and place advertising were shocked, surprised and sad dened yesterday by the news of the death of Look, a ma jor national advertising me dium for 34 years.

title: Jordan Asks U.N. Action on Jerusalem
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 16  Jordan asked the Security Council today to stop Israeli annexation of Jerusalem and Arab lands around the city by invoking whatever sane tons it deems fit.

title: DR. MALCOLM PRESTON
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 Dr. Malcolm G. Preston, emeri tus professor of psychology at the University of Pennsylvania, died Monday at the age of 65.

title: Two on Negotiating Team Find Fault With Kunstler
description: Two members of the group that tried to negotiate a peace ful settlement of the revolt at Attica Correctional Facility charged yesterday that William M. Kunstler, the civil rights lawyer, had sought to under mine the negotiations.

title: Justice Transferred
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan was transferred to George Washington University Hospital today. His colleague, Justice Hugo L. Black, remained in Bethesda Naval Hospital. A Court spokesman gave no rea son for Justice Harlan's trans fer

title: Yugoslays Welcome Visit
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 16Yugo slavia today officially wel comed the forthcoming visit of Mr. Brezhnev with a reminder that SovietYugoslav relations were based on principles of noninterference in internal af fairs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Herman Kahn's suggestion [OpEd Sept. 13] that  the pound might be allowed to follow the dollar down part way and be valued at four pounds to the dollar was, of course, a Iapsus pennae rather than an unthinkable thought.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The movement to make New York City a sovereign state has gained mo mentum in the past few weeks. What seemed a short time ago a wild pro posal must now be taken seriously.

title: Investigator of Attica Uprising Is Largely Noncommittal at Briefing for Newsmen
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 16 Deputy Attorney General Rob ert E. Fischer, appointed by Governor Rockefeller to in vestigate the tragedy inside the Attica Correctional Facility, held what he called his first actual briefing today and de clined to answer most of the lingering questions.

title: JAPANESE TO AID A TOUR OF TODAY N.B.C. Says $150,000 Help Won't Affect Integrity
description: The National Broadcasting Company's Today show will receive at least $150,000 in services from the Japanese Government when the program visits Tokyo and other points of interest in Japan. The com pany will leave between Sun day and Sept. 25.

title: Assurance by Brandt
description: BONN, Sept. 16  Before boarding his plane, Chancellor Brandt made a brief statement assuring West Germany's allies of continuing friendship.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Like most Government offi cials nowadays, Richard Perle Nathan has little time to read poetry. But today he recalled a few lines from T. S. Eliot's The Hollow Men, which he found particularly fitting in view of his summons by President Nixon to begin setting up the vast machinery re quired to run the President's wel fare reform pro gram if and when it receives final Congressional approval. Between the idea and the reality, wrote Eliot, Between the motion and the act falls the shadow.

title: Prison Chaplain, at Guard's Funeral, Asks Separate Facility for Revolutionaries
description: BATAVIA, N. Y., Sept. 16 A widely known Roman Catho lic prison chaplain, the Rev. James P. Collins, stood near a freshly dug gravesite in St. Jo seph's Cemetery here today and warned that major prison upheavals would recur in New York State unless a separate institution was opened for in mates he described as hard core revolutionaries.

title: NIXON PROMISES EFFECTIVE CURBS ON BIG INDUSTRIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 President Nixon declared today that he would substitute a pro gram of strong, effective re straints on major industries after the 90day freeze on wages and prices expires at midnight Nov. 13.

title: PADRES3 HOMERS BEAT DODGERS, 41
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) Nate Colbert, Larry Stahl and John Jeter hit home runs and Fred Norman pitched a seven hitter as the San Diego Padres defeated Los Angeles, 4.1, to night and halted the Dodgers drive toward the top of the Na tional League's Western Di vision.

title: Nixon Regrets OneMan Race, Rejects Cutoff in Aid to Thieu
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 President Nixon conceded to day that the United States would have preferred to see contested presidential election in South Vietnam on Oct. 3, bat he rejected Congressional suggestions that American aid be cut off because of the one man race.

title: Spanish Church Assembly Asks End of Ties to State
description: MADRID, Sept. 16An as sembly of the Roman Catholic bishops and priests of Spain has called for an end to the traditional links between the Spanish church and Govern ment and for the establishment of human freedoms and social and economic justice.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: The Committee Game
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16The wel fare reform bill is the big proposal in President Nixon's domestic program. It has wide bipartisan support. Yet faces a rough journey in the Senate.

title: LONG SURCHARGE IMPLIED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 President Nixon implied today that the new, temporary 10 per cent import surcharge tax may remain in force for a long time to come.

title: MILITARY BUILDING TRANSFER MOTELS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The armed services are go ing into the motel business to ease the housing problems of transferred servicemen and their funnies, Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee told House subcommittee today.

title: With the Midi Out of the Way, Shoppers Are in a Generous Mood
description: It wasn't a final divorce, after all. Women and the fashion industry are ready to kiss and make up after two years of battling each other.

title: Books of The Times
description: A SORT OF LIFE. By Graham Greene. 220 pages. Simon & Schuster. $6.95.

title: The Military Manpower Crisis
description: The Administration is pressing the Senate for quick passage of a modifiedand weakenedSelective Service Act, arguing that the military services face a man power crisis unless conscription is speedily resumed. The fact is that a crisis already does exist within the armed services, but it is more qualitative than quantita tive. The problem cannot be resolved merely by restor ing the Administration's authority to draft men.

title: Karras Rejects Rams And Quits Pro Football
description: DETROIT, Sept 16 (AP) Saying I thought it over and feel I don't have to prove to anybody I wasn't over the hill, Alex Karras retired to day from football to enter show business and spend more time with my family.

title: PRESIDENT SCORES A MUNE REMARK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 President Nixon today accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie of a libel on the American people for having stated that they would not approve a Negro nominee for Vice President in the 1972 election.

title: Laotian Troops Battle to Take Key Town
description: PAKSONG, Laos, Sept. 16  Laotian and North Vietnamese troops were battling today in the streets and suburbs of this key town on the western rim of the Boloven Plateau in south ern Laos.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16Following is the official transcript of President Nixon's news conference here today: THE PRESIDENT: We will go right to your questions.

title: Market Place Little Fellow's Trading Burden
description: It's a debatable point, but there are Wall Street profes sionals who argueoff the record, of coursethat the brokerage surcharge is the worst thing that has hap pened to the trading market since the backoffice logjam.

title: Congress Told U.S. Policy on Cuba Is Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The State Department told Congress today that it had no plans to ease its longstanding, policy of coolness toward Cuba.

title: EUROPEANS FEAR A NEW RECESSION
description: LONDON, Sept. 16  The deadlocked London monetary conference has aroused fears among European officials that a new recession may engulf the world.

title: Fox Names Stulberg of C.B.S. as President
description: The longrumored appoint ment of Gordon Stulberg as president of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation was announced yesterday.

title: Wagner Panel Backs Free Tuition at City U. and More State Aid
description: A commission on the future of the City University headed by former Mayor Robert F. Wag ner has recommended preser vation of the university's free tuition policy and an increase in state support to 75 per cent of the university's oper ating costs.

title: Temple to Install Rabbi
description: Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum will be installed at a special service this evening at 8:15 as spiritual leader of Temple Shaa ray Tefila, 250 East 79th Street. Leaders of American Reform Ju daism, including Earl Morse, chairman of the board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations; Rabbi Robert Max, executive director of the New York Federation of Re form Synagogues, and Dr. Ber nard J. Bamberger, president of the World Union of Progressive Judaism and Rabbi Emeritus of the congregation, will partici pate.

title: HOUSE PANEL KEEPS ALASKA AID INTACT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)A move to reduce proposed 40millionacre land grant to Alaska's 55,000 natives was rejected today by the House Interior Committee.

title: Group of 10 Fails to Find Accord on Dollar Crisis
description: LONDON, Sept. 16Efforts by the world's most power ful finance ministers to resolve the dollar crisis ended deadlock today as the United States and its trade partners clung to hard opposing posi tions. The atmosphere at Lancaster House became testy after lunch as ministers con cluded the twoday meeting of the leading industrial na tions known as the Group of 10.

title: BRITON RECOUNTS LATIN KIDNAPPING
description: LONDON, Sept. 16Sir Geoffrey Jackson, the British Ambassador to Uruguay, said today he hoped that by now the Tupamaro urban guerrillas had found this business of ambassadorsnatching counter productive and selfdefeating.

title: WITNESSES DEBATE FARM WAGE FLOOR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The spokesmen for poverty otricken seasonal farm workers told a Senate hearing today that they would like coverage under minimum wage legisla tion equal to that in other in dustries. But the American Farm Bureau Federation testi fied that such a move would hurt the Nixon Administration's efforts to control inflation and reduce the balance of payments deficit.

title: William Underwood to Buy I.M.C.'s Ac'cent Division
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation an nounced yesterday it has agreed to sell its Ac'cent international division to the William Under wood Company of Watertown, Mass., the nation's oldest can ner, for more than $10million in cash and notes, effective Oct. 1. The Ac'cent international di vision had sales of $23.3million in the fiscal year ended June 30 compared with $22.8million in the previous fiscal year. The Ac'cent international division's business is primarily in mono sodium glutamate, used to en hance the natural flavor of foods.

title: LISTLESS STOCKS DRIFT DOWNWARD
description: The stock market drifted aimlessly yesterday in light trading and closed with small losses.

title: General Reported Killed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 16 (AP)Allied warplanes have killed a North Vietnamese or Vietcong general during heavy bombing on the northeastern front, unconfirmed reports reaching Pnompenh said today. A high command spokesman said the news had been brought by Cambodians who had aban doned the Communists.

title: CourtOrdered Busing Arrives in Nashville
description: NASHVILLEShe was a 6yearold with big brown eyes and a blue ribbon in her pigtails. On her first day of school, she cuddled next to her big sister, 8 years old, as the bus made its way through Nashville to the white neighborhood 12 miles away from her home.

title: Seven Are Named To. TaskForce Unit At Stock Exchange
description: Ralph DeNunzio, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday appointed a seven member task force to study re organization of the exchange.

title: WagePrice Freeze Enforcement Chief Reports a Few Complaint Cases Are Nearing Legal Action
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 George A. Lincoln, director of the Office of Emergency Pre paredness, which has been charged with enforcing the President's freeze on wages, prices and rents, reported to day that about 8,600 complaints of alleged violations had been made nationwide since the 90 day freeze began on Aug. 15. As yet no legal action has been taken in any case.

title: U.S. COURT REJECTS APPEAL BY ADDONIZIO
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Third Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld today the prison sentences and fines for former Mayor Hugh J. Ad donizio of Newark and three others convicted last year in $253,000 shakedown case.

title: Hurricane Edith Felt in Louisiana and Mississippi
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Sept. 16 Hurricane Edith, far less po tent than predicted, moved through Louisiana and into Mississippi today, spawning several tornadoes and causing some flooding.

title: House Unit Rejects 6Month Delay in U.S. Raises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The House Post Office and Civil Service Committee re jected today in a close, party line vote President Nixon's proposal for a sixmonth delay on pay increases for Federal whitecollar employes.

title: F.T.C. Pushes Fight on Borderline Ads
description: The consumer's tolerance for borderlinebetween truth and deceptionhas been stretched to the breaking point, an of ficial of the Federal Trade Com mission said yesterday.

title: About Pro Football
description: The JetsColts game at Baltimore is the key one Sun day as the National Football League's 52d season opens. It will be televised here, Channel 4 at 4 P.M., as will Houston at Cleveland, Channel 4 at I. P.M.; the Giants at Green Bay, Channel 2 at 2 P.M., and Minnesota at Detroit, Channel 7 at 9 P.M. Monday. Here is a preview of all the games with preseason wonlosttied records in pa renthesis.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 One month has passed since President Nixon froze wages and prices and lit a political fuse under the American politi cal system. He intends to use only one more month to design a more durable system of con trols so that the new machinery, which will be expected to function for a period of years, can be in opera tion when the freeze ends on Nov. 14. This is tantamount to notice that only four weeks remain in which to create a whole new political compact and arenaa system of decision, competition and ad judication that can win the support of major economic in terest groups and resolve breadandbutter issues affect ing almost every family.

title: Newcombe, Taylor Win Title, but Was It Legal?
description: A men's doubles final, which was completed in neardark ness under unusual scoring conditions, became a symbolic windup to the raindelayed United States Open tennis championships.

title: Theater: The Proposition Improvisational Troupe, Presents New Edition
description: The ladies in The Propo sition, which opened it new edition last night at the Mercer Shaw Arena, are young and attractive; the gamlinlike Judy Kahan, the energetic Karen Welles and Jane Curtin, who is as pretty as a prom queen. Each has a rich singing voice, a comedic talent and could have a great future in musical comedy.

title: Thieu Sees No Real Peace Till After Major 73 Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16President  Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that he saw no chance of meaningful peace talks in Paris until there had been an: allout military confrontation with North Viet namese forces, which he pre dicted would come in 1973.

title: The Root Causes of Attica
description: WASHINGTONWhen even a liberal with the doughty credentials of David Susskind is impelldd to react against what he called rancid liberal rhet oric, it is obvious, that the polemics of the doctrine of societal guilt have gone too far. Yet, that is exactly what has occurred in the aftermath of the riot and ensuing bloodshed at Attica state prison.

title: Energy Difficulties Foreseen By IndustryExecutive Panel
description: A panel of industry execu tives yesterday indicated that the road to adequate energy supplies for the United States in the coming years would cer tainly be complicated, possibly difficult and probably expen sive.

title: Health Peril Reported Corrected in TV Sets
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Department of Health, Education and Wel fare said today that there was no longer a significant health hazard through radi ation emissions from new television sets.

title: Menus for Weekend
description: In the menus below the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $749 million, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $693million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,062,000.000, up 17 per cent from $6,617,000,000.

title: Taxi Industry Files $10Million Claim Against the City
description: The taxi industry yesterday filed a $10million claim against the city, alleging it had failed to protect the in dustry's economy and safety.

title: KOREANS EXCHANGE ROSTERS FOR TALKS
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea; Sept. 16  Representatives of the North Korean and South Korean Red Cross societies met here today in their fifth contact to prepare preliminary talks on the problem of divided families.

title: List of Prisoner Dead
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 16 (AP) Following is a partial list of Attica Correctional Facility in mate dead supplied today by the Rochester office of the State Human Rights Commission and the State Department of Cor rection in Albany:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 16 (AP)  Topseeded Stan Smith dropped out of the Cen tral California openNational hardcourt tennis championships today. He said he suffered a minor shoulder injury in his final doubles at the United States Open.

title: REGINALD H. JOHNSON
description: NORWOOD, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)Reginald Hathaway John son, who was said to have attended every HarvardYale football game for the last 72 years, died yesterday in nursing home at the age of 97.

title: A.T.&T. REVENUES AND PROFITS RISE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and sub sidiaries yesterday reported gains in operating revenues and net income for the quarter and 12 months ended Aug. 31. Revenues in both periods set new highs for any threemonth or 12month period.

title: The Kirov Ballet's Swan Lake Is Now on Screen
description: SWAN LAKE, a Lenfilm/Sovexportfilm Production; choreography, Konstantin Sammy; directors, Apollinari Dudko and Konstantin Sergeyev; scenario, Isaak Glickman, Apollinarl Dudko and Ktistantin Sergeyev; camera, Anatoly Nazarov. With Elena Yevtereva, Jmmy Markovsky, Makhmud Esambayov, Valery Panov and members of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet Company, with the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra. Presented at Philharmonic Hall, Lincoln Center.

title: Train Reported Blown Up
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 16 (AP) The Government radio said today that Pakistani agents blew up an Indian passenger train in eastern Assam State late yesterday, killing one per son and injuring 17 others.

title: BRAZIL OUTLINES EXPANSION PLAN
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16 President Emilio G. Mdici has presented to Congress a development plan for Brazil that reads like a capitalist ver sion of China's Great Leap Forward.

title: Paper Mill Is Struck
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 16 (UPI)Two unions represent ing 500 workers went on strike today in a contract dispute with the Statler Tissue Cor poration. Local 84 of the United Papermakers and Paperworkers Union and Local 57 of the Brotherhood of Pulp, Sulphite and Paper Mill Workers have been working at a mill here without a contract since Sept. 1.

title: LAWYERS TO MEET ATTICA PRISONERS
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 16State Correction Department officials gave permission today for law yers, to interview prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility. They acted after a National Guard member testified in Federal Court here that he had seen prisoners being beaten and abused by prison guards and state troopers after the Attica rebellion.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Continental Can Company announced yester day the lection of Raymond G. Fisher and S. Bruce Smart Jr. as executives vice presidents. Previously group vice presidents of diversified products and paper operations respectively, with their new corpo rate positions they become general manager these groups. Mr. Fisher, 60 years old, joined the company in 1952, and Mr. Smart, 48, joined Conti nental in 1953.

title: PHILIP H. KITFIELD
description: LYNN, Mass. Sept. 16 (AP) Philip H. Kitfield, retired chief engineer of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority, died at Lynn Hospital yesterday after a heart attack at his home in Swampscott. He was 73 years old.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, Sept. 16  Can ada's unemployment rate climbed in August and consu mer prices rose sharply, the Government reported today.

title: Sale of the Beaumont Gains in Council
description: City Councilmen questioned yesterday why anyone would want to sell to the city for $1 property currently valued at $20million the Vivian Beau mont Theater in Lincoln Cen ter for the Performing Arts. But the proposal to buy the property was adopted anyway by the Council's Finance Com mittee.

title: 129TH PARIS SESSION: DEADLOCK UNBROKEN
description: PARIS, Sept. 16The 129th session of the Paris conference on Vietnam today produced only perfunctory restatements of previous positions.

title: Bridge:
description: The European Economic Community or Common Mar ket, although subject to some political and economic strains, is an effective entity in a bridge sense. The re cent Common Market cham pionships attracted substan tial entries from five coun tries in eight different events and, Italy won four of themdemonstrating that its pool of talent is not limited to the great Blue Team.

title: JOHNSTONS SONGS HAVE VITAL SPARK
description: Folk singer can be a valid, honest and honorable descrip tive term. But there are circum stances under which it seems needlessly limiting. The John stons, who are singing at Folk City, 120 West Third Street, until tomorrow night, are a case in point.

title: Parje $40.40, Scores at Belmont
description: Paraje, an Argentinebred 5 yearold running in the silks of Sigmund Sommer, ended a string of 11 races without suc cess yesterday by winning the 1mile feature at Belmont Park by a neck over Meadow hiil's Naskra, with the Hobeau Farm's Beaukins next in the field of eight. His straight re turn was $40.40.

title: KimberlyClark to Dispose Of a Paper Mill in Ohio
description: NEENAH, Wis., Sept. 16 (AP) The KimberlyCleric Corpora tion said today it will dispose of its Moraine Sulphite Busi ness Papers Mill in West Car, rollton, Ohio.

title: Americans in Vietnam Cautioned on Attacks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16The United States Embassy today advised all American personnel to take protective security meas ures in face of a growing number of attacks on United States vehicles here.

title: Job Funds Allocated
description: The Labor Department an nounced yesterday that San Juan, P. R., and St. Thomas, V. I., had received funding under the Emergency Employ ment Act of 1971 to provide jobs for 1,165 unemployed and underployed. According to The Associated Press, a total of $2,110,106 was said to have been allocated for the programs.

title: BUDDHISTS URGE ELECTION BOYCOTT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16The powerful antiGovern ment An Quang Buddhists to day called on South Vietnam's Buddhist majority and all other freedom and democracy loving people to boycott the oneman presidential election on Oct. 3.

title: Texas Railroad Unit Cuts Oil Production
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 16For the seventh consecutive month, the Texas Railroad Commission has cut oil production, as slack ening demand has been re ported to it by companies that buy the oil from Texas wells. Today's cut, to take effect on Oct. 1, is from 65.1 to 63.2 per cent of the wells ability to produce. It would reduce estimated production in October to 3,131,217 barrels a day, down 30,878 from September production.

title: Estimate Board Approves Plan For Queens Apartment Houses
description: Three 32story luxury apart ment houses can be built on the Glen Oaks Golf Course at the eastern edge of Queens, the Ward of Estimate decided yes terday.

title: City Names 4 as Violators of Health Code
description: The City Health Deprartment, announcing a campaign against unsanitary restaurants and food stores last june, promised to break tradition by publicizing the names of persistent viola tors.

title: Western U.S. Leads
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 16 Protests again marred the In ternational 14foot dinghy world team race today in Chesapeake Bay off Annapolis as the West ern United States team moved into a 2point lead.

title: BUSINESS OUTLOOK FOR 1972 OFFERED
description: A sharply improved econ omy. Lower unemployment. Less inflation. The likelihood that any upturn in interest rates will be checked by Gov ernment controls. The prospect that continued turmoil in inter national finance May disrupt the flow of trade and invest ment.

title: Stanford's Players Are Relaxed, Ready For Army Contest
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 16A Saturday night in, Kansas City followed by a Sun day night in New York and then five days of practice and relaxation at Bear Mountain Lodge have filled the week for 77 Stanford football players since their opening victory over Missouri last Saturday.

title: POLICEMAN KILLED IN JERSEY HOLDUP
description: EDISON, N.J., Sept. 16  An attempted bank holdup here to day resulted in the fatal shoot ing of one patrolman and the serious wounding of another. The lone armed robber was shot to death by a third police man, who happened to be pass ing by.

title: Antidraft Coalition In Senate Is Broken By Nixon Pressure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The tenuous coalition that had formed in the Senate against the military draft bill collapsed today under heavy pressure from the Nixon Administration.

title: Pakistan Chief Believed Seeking A Conference With Mrs. Gandhi
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 16 Persons close to the Paki stani Government said today that Pakistan was making a final effort to improve relations with India, Iran, it was said, would play an important role as intermediary. President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan re turned here yeterday after a oneday trip to Iran In which he held talks with the Iranian ruler, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi. Pakistan and neighbor ing Iran, both Moslem nations, are close diplomatic friends.

title: Senator Buckley Sends An Assistant to Attica
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Senator James L. Buckley has sent a staff member to Attica to make an onthe scene report to the Senator on the rebellion and the deaths at the state correc tional facility.

title: ROLE OF SUCCESSOR DISCUSSED BY THANT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16U Thant, who said on Tuesday that his decision to step down in December was final and irrevocable, delivered an address today on the role of the Secretary General that appeared to be in the nature of a valedictory.

title: Soybean Futures Show Price Drop; Grains Also Down
description: Except for some buying by commercial concerns there was a general lack of demand for soybeans on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Sadat Accuses U.S. of Deception in Creating Impression of Progress Toward a Mideast Settlement
description: CAIRO, Sept. 16  President Anwar elSadat accused the United States tonight of de ception and procrastination in its efforts to promote a peace ful settlement between Egypt and Israel.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP STEPS UP PROFIT
description: Net income of the Campbell Soup Company rose 7.2 per cent in the fiscal year ended Aug. 1 to $67,208,000, or $2 a share, the giant food con cern reported yesterday.

title: And Now, Maybe, Son of Kewpie Doll
description: Somehow, Mrs. Jean Cant well just doesn't fit the image of the nation's leading authority on Kewpie dolls. A cultured and gracious 45 yearold blond Missourian, she holds a master's degree In music, once filled in as an oboist for the Chicago Sym phony Orchestra, and is member of the Missouri State Council on the Arts.

title: City Dedicates Bronx SchoolHousing Complex
description: A construction project that is said to be the first in the country to combine housing and an elementary school was ded icated by city officials in the Bronx yesterday.

title: Advertising:
description: The thrifty lads and lassies at Kenyon & Eckhardt have just received a deposit of faith from the Savings Banks Association of New York State which spends about $1.25million a year on ad vertising.

title: The Unnecessary Deaths
description: NEWARK, N. J.  The bloodshed that occurred in Attica, N. Y., disturbs me more deeply than any event in recent memory.

title: Bank of America Predicts Over.all Improvement in 72
description: The Bank of America predict ed yesterday in its annual eco omic forecast that a paradoxi cal year of 1972in which economic progress would be measured in qualitative as well as quantitative terms would produce a much improved overall performance.

title: Bogs Knocks Out Chirino
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 16 (AP) Tom Bogs, Denmark's former European middleweight cham pion, defeated Jose Chirino of Argentina tonight on technical knockout as the referee stopped the scheduled 10round bout in the fifth with blood pouring from a cut over Chirino's left eye.

title: Memorial for Guards at Attica Also Remembers Dead Inmates
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 16A candlelight service that took place tonight in front of the Attica Correctional Facility for slain guards  became memorial service for dead in mates also as several clergy men offered prayers for all those killed during the uprising in the prison.

title: NIXON AIDES CITE THREAT ON DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 White House officials said to night they had learned on what they felt was good au thority that Democratic Senate leaders had threatened their colleagues that campaign con ributions in 1972 would be influenced by the way they voted on the draft extension bill.

title: A Kennedy and a Shriver Released From Probation
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass. Sept. 16 (AP)  Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and R. Sargent Shriver 3d were released from a 13month probationary period today by Judge Michael J. Donahue, sit ting in juvenile session of Barn stable District Court.

title: SELAS SAYS GROUP TRIED TAKEOVER
description: The Selas Corporation of America filed suit yesterday in the United States District Court in Philadelphia charging the Wilshire Oil Company of Texas, Siggi B. Wilzig, a director and its principal stockholder and several other companies and in dividuals with conspiracy to take control of Selas  by fraudulent acts and practices, that violate the securities and bankholding company laws.

title: Hesburgh for Open Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Rev., Theodore M. Hes burgh, chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said today that this country's housing problems would not be solved until any one with the money could buy any house he wanted anywhere. Father Hesburgh told the Hous ing Subcommittee of the House Banking and Currency Commit tee that a housing system was needed under which a person could buy a house without con sideration of his race.

title: SUGARMAN URGES CHECKLESS RELIEF
description: A system of welfare assist ance here that would do away almost entirely with welfare checks is under consideration by the Human Resources Ad ministration.

title: Nixon Appoints Executive
description: Maurice Rosenfeld, president of Equitable Bag Company, Inc., was appointed yesterday by President Nixon to the Na tional Advisory Council on the Education of Disadvantaged Children. Mr. Rosenfeld, 80 years old, has served as pres ident of the Youth Counsel Bureau of the City of New York and is an honorary trustee of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: REDS HAND GIANTS 4th DEFEAT IN ROW ON GRAND SLAM, 81
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 16 The fading San Francisco Giants lost again today, this time dropping an 81 decision to the Cincinnati Reds.

title: 39 G.I.'s in a Vietnam Unit Arrested in Drugs Roundup
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16Thirtynine American soldiers were arrested for drug use last week in one of the United States command's larg est single roundups of drug users.

title: JARRY CLOSING IN ON HIS NEXT GOAL
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 16  Pierre Jarry skated de liberately to within 10 feet of the goal, drew Ed Giacomin out of position with a feint to the left, then calmly stroked the puck into the right side of the net.

title: Policy Change to Allow Outright Buying and Selling of Issues
description: The Federal Reserve, in a significant change of policy, announced yesterday it would begin shortly to make outright open market purchases and sales in the securities of Fed eral agencies.

title: Brandt Flies to Crimean Resort For Conference With Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16Chan cellor Willy Brandt of West Germany flew to the Crimea to day for talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Commu nist party leader, on Soviet backed proposals for a Euro pean security conference and prospects for reducing military forces in Central Europe.

title: 3 Japanese Policemen Die, 150 Are Hurt As 5,000 Battle Students at Airport Site
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16Three riot policemen were stoned and beaten to death today and al most 150 were injured as rad ical students made a lastditch effort to prevent the Govern ment from preparing farmland for the construction of Tokyo's second international airport.

title: ROCKEFELLER LAYS HOSTAGES DEATHS TO TROOPERS FIRE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 16Gover nor Rockefeller said today that he believed the nine hostages slain in the Attica prison up rising had been killed in a cross fire of troopers bullets after the decision on Monday to wrench the facility from the control of prisoners.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The alarm raised among conserva tionists by New York State Commis sioner of Environmental Conservation Henry Diamond's novel concept of conditional certification has been swiftly justified.

title: For Look Staff, Wry but Sad Quips
description: There was laughter at Look magazine yesterday, but mostly it was nervous laugh ter, tinged sometimes with highpitched shrieks and other times with sighs; the jokes were very broad and, mostly, very bad.

title: Officer Testifies on False Report of Mylai
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 16 A leading prosecution witness in the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson admitted to day that he had signed a false statement in the aftermath of the Mylai 4 slayings that told of heavy fighting between American troops and enemy forces in the South Vietnamese hamlet on'March 16, 1968.

title: City Block: On West 85th St., Verdicts On the Deaths in Attica Are Already In
description: This is another in a series of reports, appearing from tune to time, on New York City as seen through the vari ety of life on one block West 85th Street between Central Park West and Co lumbus Avenue.

title: Coal Negotiators Optimistic
