description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Top coal industry and union negotiators said today that bar gaining talks covering 80,000 coal miners were proceeding at an accelerated pace and that they hoped to reach agreement by Sept. 30 when the old con tract expires. This assessment was made by W. A. Boyle, pres ident of the United Mine Work ers, and R. Heath Larry, chair man of the board of the Bitu minous Coal Operators Asso ciation.

title: Nixon Says Seating Peking In U.N. Reflects Realities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16President Nixon said today that the United States would vote to seat Peking in the Security Council as well as the General Assembly of the United Nations because this policy reflects the realities of the situation.

title: Cowles Closing Look Magazine After 34 Years
description: Look magazine, one of the country's last masscircula tion picture and text jour nals, will cease publication with its issue dated Oct. 19. The 34yearold biweekly was said to have succumbed to $5million loss in revenues in 1970, the slack economy and spiraling postal rates.

title: Mrs. King Wins 2 Matches In Louisville Tennis Event
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 16 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King breezed past two opponents to day in the Virginia Slims Louisville invitation tennis tournament.

title: TURNER'S BOAT WINS IN GOLD CUP SAILING
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 16 The defending champion, Ted Turner, of Atlanta, who last year returned the Scandinavian Gold Cup to the United States from Australia, won today's first race in the fivenation competition on Long Island Sound.

title: Textile Plan Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The White House said today the newly announced Hong Kong agreement to voluntarily control exports of noncotton textiles to the United States beginning Oct. 1 is not accep table to the United States.

title: BACIIE &CO. STOCK OFFERED TO PUBLIC
description: Bache & Co., Inc., the na tion's second largest brokerage house, made its first public of fering of its own stock yester day, selling 2.5 million shares of common stock at $16 share.

title: Advertising:
description: A little game of musical chairs just ended in Chicago with two winners. Does that sound right?

title: Caustic Soda Detergents May Be Banned by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Dr. Jesse L. Steinfeld, the Sur geon General of the United States, told Congress today that the Federal Government, because of a hazard to health, might eventually have to ban detergents made with caustic soda.

title: Leo J. Fitzpatrick Is Dead at 77; Served on Forerunner of F. C. C.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) Leo J. Fitzpatrick of suburban Grosse Pointe Shores, who started work as a newspaper man and became a national fig ure in radio broadcasting, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 77 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: WITHOUT MARX OR JESUS. The New Ameri can Revolution Has Begun. By JeanFran cois Revel. Afterward by Mary McCarthy. Translated by J. F. Bernard, 269 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: Requiem for Look
description: The demise of Look adds another tombstone to the journalistic cemetery, already overfull of magazines and metropolitan dailies killed by skyrocketing costs and fastchanging competitive pressures.

title: 642356 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The winning number in this week's, New Jersey lottery is 642356. Persons holding ticket with all six numbers in the cor rect order win $50,000; with the last five numbers, $4,000; the last four, $400; and the last three, $40, Holders of tickets with the last two numbers be come eligible for a millionaire's drawing to be held later this year. The drawing was held at the State Fair in Trenton.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Yen Controls Opposed
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Japan's top economic body decided today to ask the Jap anese Government to ease rig id exchange controls if the yen could not soon be revalued.

title: Excerpts From Justice Black Opihibhs and Views
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Following are excerpts from the judicial  decisions, lec tures, and other public state ments of Supreme Court Jus tice Hugo L. Black, whose retirement was announced today:

title: Archeologists, in Belgrade, Ask Nations to Curb Antiquities Thefts
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 17Stat ues stolen in India, graves robbed in Peru, masks smug gled out of Africa, pottery and sculpture taken from Iran and Turkeythe thriving interna tional trade in illegal antiqui ties became a major topic at a meeting of 800 prominent archeologists here.

title: JUSTICE BLACK, 85, QUITS HIGH COURT, CITING HIS HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Associate Justice Hugo L. Black retired today from the Supreme Court after 34 years of service spanning the administrations of six Presidents.

title: Beauty in an IBeam? Chromed, It Adds Beauty to Home
description: Shop in a boutique for I beams, gears, cutting wheels and ball bearings? Well, a number of people did earlier this week on opening day of a new industrial boutique called Entropy Design, Inc., at 235 East 51st Street. Of course the hardwares stocked are not just ordinary industrial mate rials. They are re cycled tools and equipment that end up serving handsomely in lamps, book ends, candle holders, mirrors, ashtrays, belt buckles and paper weights. The boutique was the idea of Judith Benjamin, whose husband is an indus trial engineer, and Stephanie Eisenberg, whose husband is a physician (the shop also stocks laboratory flasks and petri dishes). The two worn en friends decided that gears can be beautiful and set out to prove it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The President's recent invocation of executive privilege to protect the con fidentiality of future foreign aid pro posals is entirely justified. Senator Fulbright had requested a fiveyear plan for U.S. aid (which may or may not exist) on a classified basis to help his Foreign Relations Committee in its deliberations. Senator Fulbright is not very forthright, however, in implying that his Senate colleagues would respect to the letter the classi fication of such sensitive information.

title: Anniversaries
description: SUTTENBERGMichael and Martha. Happy Golden Wedding Anniversary. Best wishes and regards from your loving children and grandchildren.

title: TOKYO AIRPORT SITE CLEARED BY POLICE
description: NARITA, Japan, Sept. 17 (UPI)  Japanese riot police, meeting little resistance from farmers and students, seized control of land for a new air port here today.

title: GIANTS'HERRMANE RESTORED TO DUTY
description: Don Herrmann, the wide re ceiver who broke a collarbone early in the training season, was activated by the New Giants yesterday and is ex pected to start against the Packers in Green Bay tomorrow. They also added Steve Alexakos, an offensive lineman, to their list, giving them two reserves for the five offensive line positions.

title: TV VIEWERS PHONE STATION ON ATTICA
description: A hastily prepared Channel 13 special Thursday night on the Attica prison tragedy drew more than 1,000 telephone calls from viewers who wanted to discuss the issues with the program's guest panelists. The live program, which ran two hours, was taped and will be repeated tonight at 10 P.M.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 30 editorial on cutbacks in services in libraries and museums was excellent and timely. To think that the 42d Street Library should be closed even fifteen minutes less than its full week, much less evenings and weekends, is pure madness.

title: Western U. S. Team Wins
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 17The Western United States team, Capt. Dick Rose, Baird Bardarson, Dennis Clark and Tom Rosmond, became the first American team ever to win the International 14foot Dinghy Class world team racing cham pionship today.

title: Kodes Gains in Coast Tennis, Aided by Controversial Replay
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP)Jan Kodes of Czecho slovakia had to go three sets in both his matches today but captured a spot in the quarter finals of the Central California opennational hardcourt ten nis championships.

title: ALBANY BUILDING JOLTED BY BLAST
description: ALBANY, Sept. 17A bomb claimed to have been planted by the radical Weathermen ex ploded tonight in a washroom at the offices of the State De partment of Correction. Two lavatories and an unused shaft were damaged extensively, but no one was hurt.

title: Housing Starts Set a Record Again
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)New housing starts set a record in August for the second consecutive month, ris ing 13,000 units to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2, 228,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MEXICANS IN A SHOW OF DANCE AND SONG
description: The Grito is a traditional cry to celebrate Mexican inde pendence, and it was given along with a program of dance and song Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall. The audience included a large number of MexicanAmericans and sympa thetic onlookers, and the enter tainment was provided by the Javier de Le6n group of folk loric dancers, instrumentalists an0 singers flown in from Mex ico, for the occasion.

title: For 34 Years on Bench, A Key Influence on Law
description: Justice Hugo Lafayette Black, whose retirement from the Supreme Court was an nounced yesterday, rose to the highest bench in the Lincolnesque tradition: he was born the son of a Con federate soldier in a tiny cabin in Clay County, Ala.

title: Cougar II Rules Choice Today in U.N. Handicap
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 (AP)Mary F. Jones's Cou gar II, an import from Chile who has won five stakes in California this year, is the favorite in tomorrow's $100, 000 United Nations Handi cap over 1 3/16 miles on turf at Atlantic City Race Course.

title: Thieu and Diem...
description: The chances for total withdrawal of American combat forces from Vietnam in the foreseeable future and for negotiated settlement that would insure a speedy return of American prisoners of war have been set back by pronouncements in Saigon and Washington this week.

title: Mrs. King Triumphs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 17 (AP)The United States Open titleholder, Mrs. Billie Jean King, advanced into the semi finals with a 62, 63 victory over Lita Liem of Indonesia today in the Louisville invita tion tennis tournament.

title: No Concentration Camps
description: Fired by the antiCommunist hysteria that followed the outbreak of the Korean war, Congress in 1950 overrode a veto by President Truman and enacted a law authoriz ing the Federal Government to put suspected spies saboteurs into detention camps in time of war or insur rection. In 1952, the Government established six deten tion camps in Arizona, California, Florida, Oklahoma and Pennsylvania.

title: Unfounded Rumors Still Cause Fear and Uncertainty in Attica
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 17 Though the rebellion at Attica has been brought under control, horrifying rumors that preceded and accompanied the killings of prisoners and their hostages last Monday still fly around the town, engendering fear, uncer tainty and anger.

title: A.E.C. Backs Nevada Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commis sion said today that it had de cided that underground atomic testing in Nevada posed only small environmental risks and should he continued. The corn mission said the tests were necessary for weapons develop ment and for the development of peaceful uses of atomic ex plosions.

title: Rulings on the WagePrice Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Following is policy statement No. 21 issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: House Committee Confers With Rockefeller on Attica
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel yesterday called for special Federal grand jury to investigate the Attica prison uprising and to see whether the information Governor Rocke feller had relied on In sanc tioning an assault by troopers on the facility contained dis tortions of truth or outright lies.

title: Court Upsets Filing Fee
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (UPI)Federal District Judge Albert C. Wollenberg declared unconstitutional today the im position of a filing fee to run for public office in San Fran cisco. Judge Wollenberg made permanent his order prohibiting the registrar of voters from turning down applicants who could not afford to pay.

title: Canadian Bill Yield Up
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (Cana dian Press)The average yield on Canadian Government 91 day treasury bills auctioned yesterday was 3.89 per cent, up slightly from 3.83 per cent last week. The auction dis posed of $175million in bills this week, at an average price of 99.041, down from 99.055 the preceding week.

title: A Strike Gets Nixon Endorsement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)  President Nixon had an awkward moment in gutter today but he bounced back in fine style to roll strike on the White House bowling lanes.

title: Attica's Aftermath
description: The announcement by Governor Rockefeller and Republican and Democratic leaders of the State Legis lature that a citizens committee will be appointed under impartial auspices to investigate the events lead ing to, during and following the riot at Attica offers the prospect of removing much of the fog still sur rounding this enormous tragedy. The decision to have the investigating panel appointed by Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the Court of Appeals and the presiding jus tices of the four departments of the Appellate Division represents a long step toward guaranteeing its inde pbkidence and impartiality.

title: Guards Come From Afar
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 17 Today was a long and sorrowful day for the village of Attica.

title: U.S.Israeli Discussions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The United States is discussing sig nificant and farreaching ideas with Israel on a possible Middle Eastern peace settlement and is determined to continue its peacemaking role in the area, a senior Administration official said today.

title: EDMUND HAURIGAN
description: CLOSTER, N. J., Sept 17Edmund Haurigan, a former municipal magistrate, died to day after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Delay on Filing Plan Asked By Penn Central Trustees
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad yesterday petitioned the Federal District Court in Philadelphia for a sec ond sixmonth extension of its deadline for the filing of a re organization plan for the bank rupt carrier.

title: Weis, Voisin Completes Deal
description: Weis, Voisin & Co., Inc., member of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that it had completed its previous ly proposed acquisition of most of the assets of Scheinman, Hockstin & Trotta, Inc., includ INJ the latter's seven offices. The acquisition increases Weis, Voisin's total offices to 30.

title: Sales and Earnings Climb at Seagrams
2 in San Francisco Linked to Slaying Of Patrolmen Here
description: The slaying of two police men here last May 21 was reported yesterday by sources close to the investigation to have been brought closer to solution by the recovery of a revolver taken from one of the patrolmen.

title: FIRST BOSTON UNIT BARRED BY ONTARIO
description: TORONTO, Sept. 17 (Ca nadian Press)  The Ontario Securities Commission has re fused an application by First Boston Canada, Ltd., for regis tration as a securities dealer.

title: Riggs Is Victor
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 (AP)Bob Riggs of Plandome, N. Y., defeated Bob Galloway of La Jolla, Calif., 62, 6.3, to day in the quarterfinals of the National senior grasscourt tennis championship. Lennart Bergelin of Sweden downed Ellis Slack of Rochester, N. Y.. 63, 63.

title: Detective Charged in Attempt To Extort $400 on East Side
description: A police detective with 16 years on the force was arrest ed last night as he was alleged ly attempting to extort $400 from the operator of a prosti tution parlor in an upper East Side penthouse, the police said.

title: In Leningrad, Americans and Russians Agree on a Building for New Consulate
description: LENINGRAD, U.S.R.R., Sept. 16The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed on a site for the longplanned American Consulate General herea fashionable prerevo lutionary apartment house larg er than the American Embassy in the years before World War when Leningrad, then St. Peters burg, was the itnperial capital.

title: Soviet Reported Stipplying Cairo With Giant Copters
description: LONDON, Sept. 17The So viet Union has been supplying Eclypt with helicopters for pos sible hitancl.:run raids against Israeli forces on the east bank of the Suez Canal, according to wellinformed sources in Egypt.

title: BANK GROUP CLEARS, LINK WITH BROKERS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 17 (Reuters)The board of gover nors of the Investment Bankers Association approved today a I merger with the Association of Stock Exchange Firms in nearly unanimous vote.

title: Saigon Reports Heavy Losses For Its Units and Foe in Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 18  Heavy casualties were reported yes terday on both sides as enemy troops fought to oust South Vietnamese forces from the longtime guerrilla base area in the U Minh Forest southwest of Saigon.

title: Justice Black Steps Down
description: The judicial career of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black was eloquent testimony to the proposition that few things are less predictable than the consequences of Supreme Court appointment. Just a month after the Senate had approved President Roosevelt's nomination of that ardent New Dealer, the new Justice was being assailed as a onetime member of the Ku Klux Klan. But in one of his first major opinions he was to enunciate the eloquent defense of minority rights which would characterize his long and fruitful years on the bench: Under our constitutional system, he wrote, courts stand, against any winds that blow, as a refuge for those who might otherwise suffer because they are helpless, weak, outnumbered, or because they are non conforming victims of prejudice and public excitement.

title: NEW STORM FORMS IN CARIBBEAN AREA
description: MIAMI, Sept. 17 (AP)Tropical storm Irene was formed today in the same re gion of the Caribbean from which Hurricane Edith began her 2,500mile trip. The possi bility that Irene would be as dangerous was reported to to remote.

title: 3 States Get Disaster Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) President Nixon today de clared parts of Texas and Penn sylvania major disaster areas and extended disaster aid for New Jersey in the wake of recent storms and floods.

title: Soviet Union to Go Ahead With Building T ruck Plant
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17A high planning official said today that the Soviet Government would regret the withdrawal of Mack 1Trucks, Inc., from an agreement of intent to help build a $.1,4 billion truck plant, but he add ed that the Russians would go ahead with the project with their own resources.

title: CHARLES M. GEE, 68, COCACOLA OFFICIAL
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Sept. 16Charles McQueen Gee, retired CocaCola Bottling ex ecutive, died yesterday. He was 68 years old and had made his home here since his retirement in 1965.

title: Dead Jersey City Man Owes His Life to Court
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 17 (AP)A man who was de clared legally dead by the court seven years ago was legally restored to life here today by Judge Edward F. Hamil.

title: Vast Gain in Atom Power Plants Called Vital at 77Nation Talks
description: GENEVA, Sept. 17  Over the next 20 years the produc tion of electricity by nuclear power plants throughout the world must increase eightfold to tenfold, the closing session of the Fourth International Con ference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy was told here today.

title: Nixon Will Meet With Mickel During Sept. 26 Trip to Alaska to See Hirohito
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 President Nixon's proposed trip to see Emperor Hirohito of Japan in Alaska Sept. 26 has turned into a fourstate swing that will include at least one other Interesting confron tation: a meeting between Mr. Nixon and the man he dis missed last year as Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Hickel.

title: But in U. S., Hitch Arises On the Site
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17  A couple who want to keep a desirable apartment, have upset plans to open a Soviet consulate office in San Francisco.

title: Executive Changes
description: I. T. T. Levitt and Sons, Inc., along with its parent company, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday the election of Louis E. Fischer as president, ending search that began earlier this year when. William J. Levitt, chairman, resumed this post from Richard M. Wasserman.

title: Cambodia May Have to Import Rice to Avert Starvation
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 17Because of economic dis ruptions caused by 18 months of war,, Cambodia will have to import 100,000 to 200,000 tons of rice next year or see many of her people starve, according to American officials here.

title: Amex Prices and Turnover Register Slight Gains
Books of The Times
description: There must be any number of novels de voted to the creative fervor of the painter, that artistic vis a tergo that keeps the productive motor running until the mech anism breaks down or the artist diesevents that often enough occur simulta neously. Offhand, one can mention Somer set Maugham's The Moon and Sixpence, Joyce Cary's wonderfully alive The Horse's Mouth, Kipling's very early The Light That Failed and Russell Greenan's tour de force of a couple of years back, It Happened in Boston?

title: Meskill Names Broker to Head State's Environmental Agency
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 17Dan W. Lufkin, a millionaire invest ment banker, was appointed Connecticut's first Commission er of its new Department of Environmental Protection to day.

title: Pilot Cites Threat to Halt Mylai Flights
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 17 A flier who helped evacuate frightened peasants from the path of advancing infantry at the hamlet of Mylai 4 in South Vietnam said today he was among several pilots who re fused to support the troops dur ing the remainder of the oper ation unless the unnecessary killing was halted.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ASPEN, Colo.I see a place on the fringe of, the town with trees and hill nearby. There's a building attuned to the scape, large with a rearing roof. At one end is a glassedin wall back ing a hooded veranda, from which ramp slopes down gradually to place where children work.

title: COLLINS CAPTURES STATE P.G.A. TITLE
Article 2  No Title
description: This is the story of the maiming of a school. A very good school. And a very good maiming. I should say almost the perfect crime, since all the suspects not only have a proper alibi but have behaved in such a manner as to make it appear that they are not suspects at all. And they are probably not. Which makes the mystery of the school even more intriguing.

title: MAX M. BLUMENTHAL
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 17  Max M. Blumenthal, who retired as executive mer chandise manager of the Cherry & Webb Department Store in Providence, R. I., in 1957, died today in St. Peter's Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 1050 George Street.

title: The Unfair Tests
description: This year 600,000 children in the New York City public schools were subjected to the Metropolitan Achieve ment Tests in Reading. And there was much indignation when it became known, shortly thereafter, that some teachersmany of them in ghetto schoolshad prepared their pupils by coaching them in advance with the actual test material. At the request of the Board of Education, Chancellor Harvey Scribner immediately promised an investigation of the conduct of the teachers involved.

title: Antiques: Signs of the Times (1800's)
description: Collectors are beginning to realize that trade signs and posters do not have to date before 1830 to be worth owning.

title: Fuld Group to Meet Here Today to Name Citizens'
description: Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the Court of Appeals said Yesterday that he would meet today in New York City with the four justices appointed with him to establish a citizens com mittee to investigate the events at the Attica Correctional Facility.

title: Group of 10 Agreement on Need for Realigning Currencies Is Cited
description: LONDON, Sept. 17Despite general gloom elsewhere, United States officials argued today that progress was being made toward resolving the dol lar crisis on the broad basis set out by the Nixon Adminis tration last month.

title: U.S. Golfers Lead British, 106
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17With Arnold Palmer and Jack Nick laus contributing a spectacular victory, the United States Ry der Cup team held a 106 mar gin today over the profes sional golfers from Britain and. Ireland.

title: A. MEDINA CHARGE REDUCED BY JUDGE
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 17A charge that Capt. Ernest L. Medina murdered small boy at Mylai was thrown out at his courtmartial today, and another murder charge that he was responsible for at least 100 civilian deaths  was reduced to involuntary man slaughter.

title: Laymen Will Train for Priestly Roles
description: Charles A. Postler will present himself at St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers Monday evening to begin studying theology and learning such priestly skills as how to bap tize and officiate at mar riages.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The two poignant letters published under the title Before 2 A.M. My Son Was Dead [OpEd Sept. 6] were mov ing documents that made telling points. However, it is doubtful whether The Times served well the longrange cause of furthering communication between youthful drug experimenters and their parents.

title: Sumitomo Chief Favors Yen Revaluation of 10%
description: The head of Japan's largest chemical company said here yesterday that a 10 per cent re valuation of the yen would he both fair and desirable.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The announcement in early August that President Nixon will call for legis lation and a sizable appropriation in order to declassify all World War II documents strikes me as a needless waste of money and time.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given at the end of the WQXR 6 P.M. news broadcast, and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times or \VQXR for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

title: Lindsay Criticizes Governor on Attica
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 17In. his first appearance at a major Democratic meeting, Mayor Lindsay today indirectly criti cized Governor Rockefeller's handling of the prison rebel lion at Attica.

title: ROBERTS TO RUN FOR REELECTION
description: At the urging of Mayor Lind say, Burton B. Roberts has de cided to run for reelection as Bronx District Attorney, rather than seek a State Supreme Court judgeship.

title: Mrs. Drewes Married
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 17Mrs. Marjorie E. Puppo Drewes, widow of Alfred H. Drewes, president of the Na tional Lead Company, was married here this evening to Alfred J. Morgan Jr. of Scars dale, N. Y., a partner in the New York law firm of Big ham, Englar, Jones & Hous ton. The Rev. John. Van Zan ten performed the ceremony in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church. The bridegroom's first wife, the former Blair Johnson, died. After a wedding trip to Eu rope, the couple will live in Englewood.

title: Greece to Try Lady Fleming
description: ATHENS, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  Lady Fleming, Greekborn widow of Sir Alexander Flem ing, the Briton who discovered penicillin, will stand trial be fore a military court Sept. 27. She was one of four persons arrested Aug, 31 and accused of plotting the escape from prison of Alexandros Panaghoulis, who tried to kill Premier George Papadopoulos in 1968.

title: Timing Device Utilized to Indicate Fertility Periods
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17Lawrence M. Sherman has several good reasons for faith in the Family Fertility Indicator, of which he is coinventor. He and his wife used the little computer to space their four children 21 months apart. The youngsters are now 2, 4, 6 and 8 years old. Mr. Sherman and James E. Richard son, a bachelor, were granted Patent 3,604,623 this week. The Cambridge Research and Development Group, West port, Conn., to which they assigned the patent, expects to get the timing device onto drugstore counters at a price below $25.

title: FUR MEN OPPOSE SEALKILLING BAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 17The fur industry opposed to day a bill that would prohibit the killing, of, ocean mammals, particularly the Alaskan fur seal.

title: Soviet Naval Force Sails Among Hawaiian Islands
Mortgage Ceiling Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The National Association of Home Builders urged today pas sage of emergency legislation that would lift for one year the Government National Mortgage Association $22,000 ceiling for mortgage purchases.

title: EGYPTIANS DOWN ISRAEL TRANSPORT
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 17The Israeli military command said today that an air force cargo plane was shot down this after noon by Egyptian groundtoair missiles. The plane was flying 14 miles behind Israel's front line positions on the Suez Canal, the command said.

title: FRANCIS NI'CURN, FORMER JUSTICE
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP)Francis D. McCurn, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division, Fourth, De partment, of the State Supreme Court in Rochester, died yes terday at CommunityGeneral Hospital after a long illness. He would have been 82 years old today.

title: Abbott Sets Price Cut
description: Abbott Laboratories, Inc., an nounced yesterday it had re duced its prices on erythrocin stearate tablets, one of several dosage forms of the antibiotic erythromycin that the company produces. Under the new sched ule, the price of 250 milligram tablets will be reduced to $14.99 per 100 tablets, from $21.99, a decrease of about 32 per cent.

title: Celanese Has New Film
description: The Celanese Plastics Com pany, a division of the Celanese Corporation, announced yester day that it had developed new polypropylene film, water proof and bacteriaresistant, that could literally breathe. The company said that the ma terial, called Celgard, would open membrane technology to vast areas of the medical and industrial fields.

title: COMPUTER MAKING IS HALTED BY RCA; NO BUYER IS FOUND
Latin America Is Denied Exemption From Surtax
description: PANAMA CITY, Sept. 17The United States gave its final no here today to Latin Amer ican pleas that their region be exempt from President Nixon's 10 per cent surcharge on for eign imports not covered by specific agreements.

title: Laotian Town Retaken
description: PAKSONG, Laos, Sept. 17Laotian troops were in com plete control of this Boloven Plateau town by midday today after rooting out the last enemy snipers.

title: The Game of Please the Teacher
description: So many kids these days are bored and disillusioned with education. They go through the motions of getting good education, which leads to bet ter job opportunities and more money, but they never really learn anything.

title: U.S. DOES NOT AGREE WITH A GATT REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 President Nixon's chief trade negotiator said today that the United States did not concur in the judgment of a report yes terday by the council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade criticizing the new United States 10 per cent im port surcharge.

title: Refund Ordered at Rice U.
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)The regional Office of Emer gency Preparedness, noting that football game tickets at Rice University cost $7up $1 from last yearordered the school to refund the difference to the 62,000 persons who bought tickets to last Satur day's game with Houston. The O.E.P. said Rice had violated President Nixon's price freeze.

title: Mrs. Morrow Is Wed
description: Mrs. Clare Poller Morrow of Scranton, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Alvin Rosenthal of Brooklyn, a real estate assessor with the New York City Assessment De partment. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph R. Cor so performed the ceremony in his chambers in Brooklyn.

title: Steve Miller Show At Beacon Is Stolen By 2 Opening Acts
description: Cannonball Adderley and John McLaughlin opened the show at the Beacon Theater Wednesday night, and promptly stole all the marbles from the nominal headlinerthe rock Istar Steve Miller and his band.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is disappointing to learn that even a scholar as discerning as Dr. Kenneth Clark, president, of the American Psychological Association, can suc cumb to the lure of the technological fix. [News story Sept. 5.] Perhaps the truth that is most difficult for the modern intellectual to swallow is that there are no simple technical solutions to complex environmental or social problems.

title: SCHARY IS SEEKING TO SAYE BEAUMONT
description: Dore Schary, the playwright and the city's former Commis1 sioner of Cultural Affairs, agreed yesterday to head a committee of theater people to fight plans to alter the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center for the purpose of pro viding facilities for the Henri Langlois film collection and three small theaters.

title: Hugo P. Keller Jr. Dies; An Importer of Sapphires
description: Hugo P. Keller Jr., founder and president of Hugo P. Kel ler, Inc., importers of indus trial sapphires, and of L. J. Kel ler Company, Inc., importers of precision metal parts, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hos pital. He was 69 years old and lived at 700 Park Avenue.

title: CONTRACTOR BARRED FROM FEDERAL JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The Government barred a Philadelphia area building con tractor today from further Fed eral contracts in the first en forcement test of the Nixon Administration's campaign to increase minority hiring in the construction trades.

title: BUSINESSMEN GET BRIBERY WARNING
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy warned New York businessmen yesterday that he had instructed the city's 32,000 policemen to arrest anyone who offered them a bribe.

title: MGOVERN IN TOKYO, DISCUSSES SURTAX
description: TOKYO, Sept. 17 (AP)Sen. George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, suggested to day that the United States should devalue the dollar and remove the import tax, and Ja pan should revalue the yen and drop barriers to United States products.

title: They Found a Home Where the Aged Don't Feel as if They've Been Put Away
description: Donal McLaughlin is old: 95. He has a bright smile, moves quickly and has strong opinions about life and about growing old. When his wife died five years ago, he thought he could fend for himself. But his two sons were worried about him, and, he now admits, they were right.

title: Soldier and Policeman Killed in Ulster Attacks
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 17 (AP)A British sol dier and a policeman were killed today and another po liceman was wounded in steppedup action by the Irish Republican Army against British rule in Northern Ire land.

title: COMMUNISM ROLE DEBATED BY P.E.N.
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 17Contrast ing opinions of the effects of Communism on literature were given here today by Soviet and Taiwanese delegates at the clos ing session of the 38th Interna tional Congress of Poets, Essay ists and Novelists.

title: Role Here for Joan Blondell
description: Joan Blondell will return to the New York stage on Sept. 28 when she takes over the leading female role in The Effect of Gamma Ray on Man intheMoon Marigolds, which is in its second year at the New Theater.

title: German Position Taken
description: BONN, Sept. 17 (Reuters)Economics Minister Karl Schil ler said today that Germany would reject any bid in the Common Market to impose fur ther foreignexchange and cap italmarket controls should the I.M.F. reach no agreement on the monetary crisis at the end of this month, an Economics Ministry spokesman said.

title: DODGERS BOW, 32, TO BRAVES IN 11th AND FALL 2 BACK
STOLEN TITIAN FOUND BY POLICE IN PADUA
description: PADUA, Italy, Sept. 17 (AP) The Italian police recovered a priceless painting by Titian and arrested 10 persons today. But burglars got away with three other precious paintings and a gemencrusted chalice from a local church, the sec ond art theft here in two days.

title: Autry Has Eye Surgery
description: BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP)Gene Autry, former cowboy singing star, is making a good recovery from surgery for a de tached retina, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary said today. Mr. Autry, a wealthy business man, underwent the operation Wednesday.

title: British Psychiatriits Protest
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  Forty four members of the depart ment of psychiatry at Shietfield University have called upon psychiatrists throughout the world to express their opposi tion to the Soviet Government's practice of sending dissenters to mental hospitals.

title: PROTESTS MOUNT, PRAYERS OFFERED
description: Inmates at Trenton and Rah way State Prisons in New Jer sey were given time out from their work yesterday to show their respect for the dead Attica. A group of 15 persons held an interfaith prayer serv ice outside Governor Rocke feller's office on West 55th Street. One thousand persons gathered for a threehour me morial service in Buffalo.

title: AntiGovernment Protests Erupt At Saigon Assembly and College
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Sept. 18 (AP)Anti Government demonstrations erupted in four sections of Saigon today, triggering fire bombings and rock throwing. The police retaliated with tear gas attacks. Two students were reported seriously injured.

title: Forbes's Yacht Wins in 5Nation Series
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 17 David T. Forbes's Carabella from Sydney, Australia, won the second race today in the fivenation Scandinavian Gold Cup 5.5meter series on Long Island Sound.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The game plan of the steel execu tives has failed. Since the end of World War II they have refused to involve either their employes or the United Steelworkers of America (U.S.W.) in productivity bargaining. Instead they have been trying to off set employment cost increases with price increases and capital expendi tures.

title: Congress May Move Soon. To Extend Control Power
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Congressional leaders said after meeting with President Nixon today that they might move quickly to extend the Presi dent's legislative authority to impose wage and price con trols.

title: BETHLEHEM TO WORK LACKAWANNA AGAIN
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 17 (AP)The Bethlehem Steel Corpora tion said today that it will re sume making steel next month at its huge Lackawanna mill, where operations have been slowed since the steel industry labor settlement.

title: 24 Firemen Are Treated After Blaze on West Side
description: Twentyfour firemen were treated at hospitals yesterday, primarily for smoke inhalation* after fighting a threealarm fire in a sevenstory apartment building at Columbus Avenue, and 73d Street.

title: Democratic Candidates Told Doorbells Can Lead to Election
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 17  More than 100 Democratic candidates for local political offices throughout the state were advised by experts here today on how to win from ring ing doorbells to stressing the right issue.

title: 'A Young Couple,' French Film, Opens at the Trans-Lux East
description: While it hardly arrives at startling or incisive answers, "A Young Couple" makes it abundantly clear that even in France love's young dream can eventually become a good deal less than idyllic.But it must be stressed that the "couple" are not caricatures and that they and their exploded dream have been exposed with compassion and tenderness even if Ren Gainville, the director, his screenwriter and his principals have not developed an especially trenchant drama in the French film that opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East.Gainsville has pointedly focused on nuances that are generally effective in clothing the bare bones of a basically simple plot. The ecstasy of the couple's Athenian honeymoon begins, almost imperceptibly, to diminish as they visit the young husband's folks in the Loire region. It fades further as Veronique, the pregnant bride, has to settle for an apartment a good deal simpler than the posh places she and her chic, gadabout friend, Ariane, would like.Their young daughter's upbringing adds to the miseries of Veronique and her adoring mate, Gilles, whose love of his family is not matched by his restless wife, who envies the rich, swinging life of Ariane and her husband, and pines for something more than wifely duties. Veronique, it evolves, is not out of love so much as she is terrified of not tasting life's joys as soon as possible."We have only one life and it passes too quickly," she notes anxiously and adds, flatly, "these days we can't live only for our children."Gilles is no simpleton, but merely helpless as he continues to love his wife, now headed for an imminent divorce and a liaison with a rich playboy despite her obvious, deep affection for the man she is leaving.As Gilles, Alan Libolt, a dark-haired, willowy type facially reminiscent of Jean-Louis Barrault, is impressive in a subdued characterization that projects his confusion and anguish. Anna Gael, the curvaceous blonde beauty, who has literally been exposed in a variety of flesh epics, such as "Thrse and Isabelle" and "Nana," is revealed here as a fairly sensitive type in the rose of Veronique. She is neither flighty nor lascivious but all too human and young in a predicament she simply cannot handle. And Anny Duperey and Jean-Franoise Calve, as her properly chic and one-dimensional rich friends, head an efficient supporting cast.Perhaps this "Young Couple" should never have married in the first place. But director Ren Gainville, a newcomer here if memory serves, makes them, their coterie and their simple, sad saga credible and occasionally touching.

title: Youths Kill Bronx Father of 5 Who Took Back His Son's Bike
description: A 39yearold Bronx father of five was killed late Thursday night by a group of youths minutes after he had retrieved a motorbike that had been stolen from his son earlier in the day.

title: Arraignment of 27 In Draft Raid Case Delayed in Camden
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 17The scheduled arraignments of all but one of 28 persons charged with plotting to destroy Selec tive Service records here were postponed for two weeks today at the request of the defend ants.

title: First Snow Falls in Denver
description: DENVER, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Denver residents woke up today to the first snowstorm of the season. By 9 A.M., the city had four inches of snow in six hours. Some areas had 10 inches, with heavy damese reported to trees and shrub. bery.

title: K. G. B. Questions 2 Western Newsmen on Dissident
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18The So viet secret police have inter rogated two Western newsmen, one American and one British, in connection with the inves tigation of a Soviet dissident reportedly charged with anti Soviet activities.

title: Ulster's Economy Hurt by Terrorism
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 17The nightly bombs and bullets are eating away at the economy of Belfast as they are at the nerves of its citizens.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Sept. 17The events at Attica prison raise terrible questions for Americans: about the racial divide in our society, about the prison sys tem, about official truthfulness and political courage. Tom Wicker, who was there, has written of all these with moving restraint. At a distance, the episode evokes some general thoughts on violence.

title: SENATE REJECTS A DELAY ON DRAFT BY 471036 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Senate took a major step today toward allowing the mili tary draft to be resumed by rejecting, 47 to 36, a motion to send the Selective Service bill back to conference with the House.

title: Dance:A Park Marathon
description: The rains, which have been none too kind to the New York Dance Festival this fall, showed mercy at the Dela corte Theater on Thursday night, when the New York Shakespeare Festival present ed the second and last of its rain date performances.

title: SILVER FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
EDGAR WIND DIES; ART HISTORIAN, 71
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  Edgar Wind, art historian and pro fessor emeritus of the history of art at Oxford, died in a hos pital here early Sunday at age of 71.

title: TRAVEL AGENCIES NAMED IN U.S, SUIT
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board filed suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday against five New York travel agencies and their owners, seeking an injunc tion to halt the operation of what the Government called illegal charter flights to Europe.

title: Trial of Soledad Brothers Delayed by California Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP)The trial of the two sur viving Soledad Brothers, set for next Monday, has been delayed indefinitely by the California Supreme Court.

title: New CairoSoviet Cooperation Apparently Begun
description: CAIRO, Sept, 17  A new phase of closer EgyptianSoviet cooperation appeared to be emerging in the wake of Presi dent Anwar elSadat's virtual repudiation last night of United States mediation in the Arab Israeli conflict.

title: MOST NEW ISSUES ROSE IN THE WEEK
Judge Bars Pennsy Sale Of Unlisted Garden Stock
description: Federal District Judge John P. Fullam yesterday denied the proposed sale by the trustees of the Penn Central Rail road of its holdings of 1,045,593 shares of the Madison Square Garden Corporation at $3.50 a share to Bear Stearns & Co. The Penn Central's invest ment is in unregistered stock of Madison Square Garden. Judge Fullam, who is in charge of the Penn Central's bankruptcy pro ceedings, rejected the Bear Stearns deal on several bases, including his finding that a 6centashare commission in the deal for Bear Stearns was excessive. The sale had been opposed by David Berger, a lawyer representing a group of Penn Central Com pany stockholders.

title: Burger Speaks and Kunstier Counters
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 17 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger and William M. Kunstler both spoke here today and agreed on a need for prison reform, but on little else.

title: Engelbert Humperdinck Sings to Vocal Audience
description: Some sort of ceremony ought to be held in the Royal Box of the Americana Hotel on Monday, Sept. 27. On that day Engelbert Humperdinck, the singer, will have corn pleated an engagement there for which he will have been paidaccording to a sincere eyed spokesman for the Royal Box$50,000 a week.

title: Maravich Injury Minor
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 17 (UPI)Pete Maravich of the Atlanta Hawks was sidelined with a leg injury today but an Xray determined it was noth ing more than a muscle bruise.

title: Inmates'
description: A year ago Mr. and Mrs. Preston McNeil, as a last re sort to keep their son out of trouble, persuaded him to give up his parole and return to prison for the last 18 months of his sentence.

title: Mills Says He Still Favors a Tripartite Board
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 17 Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said on a tour of the Lehigh Valley area that he still favored a tripartite board after expiration of the Nixon wageprice freeze Nov. 14.

title: Assurances Given by F.D.A. Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 ,Peter Barton Hutt, the new general counsel of the Food and Drug Administration, vol iintenred today to ask former clients for permission to dis close their names.

title: Frederick J. Rabe Is Dead; Active in Exchange Firms
description: ROSLYN, L. Sept. 17 Frederick J. Rabe, a registered representative with Reynolds & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, and former head of the company of his own name, bank stock brokers, died last night in St. Francis Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 160 Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, and in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Europe Is Pressured to Retaliate Against Nixon TaxCredit Proposal
description: PARIS, Sept. 17European governments are coming under mounting pressure from busi ness interests to retaliate against President Nixon's 10 per cent job development tax credit if it is approved by Congress.

title: Prague Liberal Says in Interview Barely 10% Back New Regime
description: ROME, Sept. 17  Josef Smrkovsky, one of the leaders of the shortlived Prague, spring of liberalization in 1968, said in an interview pub1 lished by an Italian Communist magazine yesterday that barely, 10 per cent of the Czechoslovak people supported the present proSoviet regime.

title: Thant, at U.N. Gathering, Eulogizes Hammarskjold
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17Secretary General Thant today eulogized his predecesor, Dag Hammar skjold, as the world's first public servant at a cere mony here marking the 10th anniversary of the death of Mr. Hammarskjold.

title: Cairo Says Plane Is Transport
description: CAIRO, Saturday, Sept. 18 (AP)Egypt shot down an Israeli transport plane over the Israeliheld Sinai Desert yes terday.

title: DOW INDEX UP 5.11 AS VOLUME RISES
Title Soccer Game Put Off
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (UPI)The showdown game between the Atlanta Chiefs and the Dal las Tornado for the North American Soccer League cham pionship was postponed today luntil 7 P.M. Sunday.

title: Bridge: A Review of Declarer's Bid Provides a Clue to Trumps
description: Inexperienced players usu ally consider that the de clarer's hand is wrapped in foggy mystery, in spite of the light that has been shed by the auction. As a point of de parture, the defender should ask himself how many trumps the declarer is likely to have. Most of the time there will be a clue, and often the trump length will be a virtual certainty.

title: Hudson Trust Co. Rescinds Plan to Increase Dividend
description: The Hudson Trust Company, of Union City, N. J., yesterday rescinded a plan to pay divi dends at the rate of 80 cents share a year, up about 20 per cent from previous years.

title: The OncePowerful Poverty Agency Has Lost Strength
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Nixon Administration, in seeking recently to promote minority leaders, offered to As sistant Secretary of Labor Ar thur A. Fletcher the post of Director of the Office of Eco nomic Opportunity, the Gov ernment's antipoverty agency.

title: A Turn Backward
description: Just as the Federal Government embarks on effort to increase jobs and revive the economy, the Douse has taken a giant step backward by depriving the Equal Em ployment Opportunity Commission of authority it needs to insure that hiring will be done without bias against those who most need workblacks and other minorities.

title: Moon Genesis Rock 4 Billion Years Old
description: Scientific analysis has con firmed what the Apollo 15 as tronauts suspected at first sight: That the socalled gene sis rock is the most ancient large fragment ever found on the moon, an estimated 4.15 billion years old.

title: ...the Mansfield Amendment
description: The new indications of prolonged American involve ment in Vietnam make especially disappointing the Senate's decisive rejection of a chance to restore the Mansfield amendment to its version of the Selective Service Act. The amendment calling for withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina within nine months is not dead, however. It received strong affirmative sup port when the Senate first voted on the draft act last July. It should receive even stronger backing when Mr. Mansfield reintroduces it as an amendment to the mili tary procurement bill, as he has indicated he will do.

title: Jakobson Confident on U.N. Candidacy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17  Max Jakobson, Fin land's permanent representa tive here, expressed confidence today about his chances of suc ceeding U Thant as Secretary General.

title: AUTOGRAPH AUCTION BRINGS $46,910 HERE
description: George Washington and Abra ham Lincoln are still the peers of the autograph field. An auc tion Thursday night that in cluded the autograph signatures of all the Presidents proved that in a sale that grossed $46,910.

title: The Sandboy, a London Play, Has an Unworkable Structure
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 One's heart starts sinking from the first moment of Michael Frayn's The Sandboy at the Green wich Theater when Eleanor Bron drops an armload of cush ions to stare at us aghast and go into an embarrassed hostess routine. We are supposed to be part of a vast television crew that has gatecrashed the house to film a day in the life of her celebrity husband.

title: Market Place: Fee Spending Ala Neuwirth
description: When Henry Neuwirth raised the management fee for his two mutual funds to 1 per centdouole his former basic feelots of people fig ured this was to pay for a helicopter and other niceties of the executive suite at a time when assets under man agement had dropped in half.

title: Nigerian Stake in Phillips
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept, 17 (Reuters)The Nigerian Gov ernment announced today that an agreement had been signed giving the Government a 33  per cent equity share interest and an equivalent working in terest in concessions, held by the Italian oil company, AGIP.

title: Fire Destroys a Castle. Overlooking the Hudson
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 17A 20room turreted cas tle, built in the eighteennine ties on a 27acre site over looking the Hudson River here, was devastated today by a fire casting more than five hours.

title: Council Ready to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The President's Cost of Liv ing Council is ready to send from 20 to 25 cases alleging violation of the wageprice rent freeze to the Justice De partment for possible legal action, the council's executive director said today.

title: Notes on People
description: Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, former Attorney General and Undersecretary of State in the Johnson Administration, joined the faculty of the Columbia Law School. Mr. Katzenbach will serve as an adjunct professor of law and teach a seminar in Presi dential Congressional rela tions. He will continue to be a vice president and general counsel for International Business Machines.

title: Detergents: Series of Health Controversies
description: Almost from the day they came on the market described as washday miracles, house hold detergents have been em broiled in one environmental health controversy after an other.

title: Attorneys for Attica Prisoners Begin Interviewing Inmates About Their Rebellion
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 17 Lawyers from legal organiza tions claiming to represent al most 1,000 prisoners were per mitted to enter the Attica Cor rectional Facility today to be gin interviewing inmates about their rebellion and the police attack that took the lives of 40 inmates and prison employes.

title: Double Dare Leads
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 17 Joseph F. O'Hora and Dr. George K. Brazill Jr. of Larch mont (N. Y.) Yacht Club, co skippers of Double Dare, held a 4%point lead for the Shields Class national championship to day after the third and fourth races in the threeday regatta were sailed on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Y. C. One race tomorrow will com plete the event.

title: A Bilingual Center For Day Care Opens In the East Bronx
description: A daycare center designed to meet the unique needs of the Puerto Rican child was offi cially opened in the East Bronx yesterday.

title: Jacques Kaplan Going Abroad To Try Out the Hermit's Life
description: Jacques Kaplan says he's had it with the New York fashion scene. After pav ing Mrs. William S. Paley's bathroom with Indian lamb, running up blue fox sleeping bags for $2,000 and stenciling a white rabbit coat with the word FUR in big red letters on the back, the multimillionaire pelletier is moving to Europe, perhaps for good.

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH OVER PADRES,75, TO INCREASE LEAD
Shanker Lays Some of Blame For School Crime to Chancellor
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teach ers here, said yesterday that 1,000 teachers and students were assaulted last year and he'blamed, in part, top admin istFators, including the Chan cellor of the school system.

title: Dollar Trading
Peking Orders Sweeping New Measures in Its Fight Against Industrial Pollution
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 17 Sweeping new measures to combat major sources of indus trial pollution have been or dered into effect in China.

title: Toward a Nixon Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The resignation of Hugo La fayette Black from the Supreme Court may be cited by future historians as the event that ushered in, the era of the Nixon Court. That this can be speculated, in advance of the selection of his successor, is not indicative so much of the proven propensity of President Nixon to appoint conserv ative, lawand order Justices as it is of the impact of Justice Black's presence on the Court.

title: Bella Darvi, Protege of.Zanuck Who Became Actress, a Suicide
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Sept. 17 (AP)Bella Darvi, the actress, was found dead today in an apartment here. The po lice said she committed suicide a week ago. Her age was 44.

title: DR. BALDWIN, 56, TAUGHT MEDICINE
description: Dr. John Macky Baldwin Jr., who was for many years asso ciated with the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center, died at the Presbyterian Hospital yesterday morning. He was 56 years old and lived at 267 Maple Street in Englewood, N. J.

title: MUSIC HALL MAY GET MASS BY BERNSTEIN
description: Leonard Bernstein said yes terday that negotiations were in progress with a view to pre senting his new Mass at Radio City Music Hall. But, he added, it's not settled yet.

title: Melvin Gains Triton Lead
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 17 Ridgely Melvin of the Annap olis (Md.) Yacht Club, the de fending champion, took the lead for the national Triton sailing title today by placing second, then first, in the open ing two races of the fiverace regatta on Long Island Sound off Stamford Y. C.

title: Five in Morocco Doomed For Plot Against Hassan
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  Five persons were sentenced to death and six imprisoned for life today for plotting the overthrow of King Hassan II.

title: 40 at a Junior High In Jersey Collapse In Football Workout
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., Sept. 17 Forty junior high school foot ball players were hospitalized here today after they collapsed during a workout, apparently because of a combination of high humidity and high pollen count.

title: Concorde in French Guiana; Returns to France Today
description: CAYENNE, French Guiana, Sept. 17 (UPI)  The English French supersonic jet Con cords flew here from Rio de Janeiro today after having completed a series of demon stration flights in Brazil and Argentina.

title: Article 79707324 -- No Title
description: HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., Sept 17Mrs. Theron U. Ly man of Trenton and Mrs. Cyril Crabb of Spring Brook will meet next Friday at the Hack ensack Golf Club in a play off for the 20th Women's New Jersey Golf Association Nielsen Memorial Trophy.

title: 4 SENT TO PRISON FOR STOCK FRAUD
description: An Illinois banker and three other men were sentenced here to prison yesterday for fraud and conspiracy to manipulate the price of a stock listed on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Mexico Plans Boycott
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 17 (UPI) The Mexican Government said today that it would pro mote a boycott of American made products by Mexicans residing along the United States border in retaliation for Wash ington's 10 per cent surcharge on imports.

title: Ryan to Rejoin N.B.C.
description: Bill Ryan will rejoin the National Broadcasting Com pany as a Washington corres pondent for the WNBCTV (Channel 4) 6 P.M. newscast, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Ryan, who was an N.B.C. cor respondent for many years be fore joining WORTV as the anchorman of its 7:30 news cast, is leaving Channel 9 as a result of the station's deci sion to change the format of its newscast and to bring in Torn Dunn as the anchorman when it moves back to 10:30 P.M. Oct. 4.

title: New Vermont Senator Robert Theodore Stafford
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17I've always followed my own road, says Robert Theo dore Stafford. This morning that road led to the United States Senate chamber where the Vermont Republican was sworn in as the interim re placement for the late Win ston L. Prouty.

title: Passionate Story of a Bandit:'Augusto Matraga' Is at 5th Avenue Cinema Movie From Brazil by Santos Arrives
description: Roberto Santos's "The Hour and Turn of Augusto Matraga" (Hora E Vez De Augusto Matraga), which opened yesterday as part of the Fifth Avenue Cinema's retrospective devoted to Brazil's Cinema Novo, seems, on its surface, to be one of the least revolutionary films to come out of that revolutionary film movement.Only by its uncompromised passion and by its almost romantic appreciation for the landscapes and characters and attitudes that are unique to the bleak, rural regions of northern Brazil can it be identified as one of those socially concerned Brazilian films, made in the nineteen-sixties, in a wave of protest against the commercialized Brazilian cinema."The Hour and Turn of Augusto Matraga," based on a popular Brazilian novel I haven't read, reflects a universe in which the rewards and punishments are doled out in a decidedly pre-Marxian manner. Augusto Matraga is a very bad man, a farmer who likes to terrorize the countryside just for the hell of it, who treats his wife like a servant, and who rapes a virgin and then murders three members of her family when they object.He is, in fact, so spectacularly evil that his sudden repentanceafter he has been beaten up and branded and left for dead by an outraged citizenry  can only be accepted as a poetic truth. Nursed back to health by an old black couple whose barren lives are devoted to Christ, Augusto vows to live in peace and poverty until, as he has been promised by a priest, his hour will come. The hour that comes (the priest has told him, with an absolutely straight face, that every dog has his day) permits Augusto to certify his conversion in a duel to the death with a bandit chief, who is, perhaps, the only man he has ever loved.Like some of the later later Cinema Novo films (I'm thinking of Glauber Rocha's "Antonio Das Mortes"), "The Hour and Turn of Augusto Matraga," which was made five years ago, has the narrative symmetry of a folk ballad, but it is told without the flamboyant fantasy, the self-conscious surrealism and what one critic has called the "Third World humor" of the more recent, so called "tropicalist" Cinema Novo films. (Third World humor, I've found, is more often firmly committed than funny.)Maybe because I saw it at the end of a week that has been notable for the unrelieved insipidity of the new films, I found myself responding to and being moved by "The Hour and Turn of Augusto Matraga," by its humanistic concerns, by its order and by its conviction that the most squalid spirit  mean movie critics as well as mean farmers, I assumecan stand in hope of redemption.In view of all the passion expended, Santos has obtained some remarkably restrained and effective performances from his cast, particularly from Leonardo Vilar, as Augusto, and Jofre Soares, who looks enough like Nick Ray to be his brother, as the quite genial bandit chief. Aside from a fondness for skies photographed through filters that turn clouds into cotton balls, Santos never imposes on the production the sort of picturesque sensibility that, in some other Cinema Nova films, looks like condescension."The Hour and Turn of Augusto Matraga" belongs, in its style and spirit, anyway, to the early days of the Cinema Novo, which now, I'm told, has been effectively destroyed by the various Brazilian Government and film-industry elements. This film is decent evidence of the talent and the enthusiasm that, for a short time, made Brazil a very exciting place to make movies in.

title: State CrossExamines Dean At His Trial in South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 17  The state began crossexamination, today in the trial of the Dean of Johannes burg, the Very Rev. Gonville ffrenchBeytagh, who is charged with supporting terrorist plans for the violent overthrow of the South African Government.

title: McCracken Rules Out Controls On Interest Rates After Freeze
description: The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers ruled out yesterday direct controls over interest rates from the as yet undefined Phase Two of the Administra tion's new economic policy, once the present 90day wage price freeze expires in mid November.

title: JUDGE TO STUDY BIDS FOR BECK INDUSTRIES
description: Judge John M. Cannella, of the United States Southern Dis trict Court in New York, ad journed a hearing yesterday until Oct. 1, to consider offers to purchase assets of Beck In dustries, Inc.

title: JAMES TRITTIPO, TV ART DIRECTOR
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17James Trittipo, awardwinning television art director and theatrical designer, died on Wednesday. He was 43 years old.

title: Argentina Sets '73 Election
description: BUENOS AIRES (AP)Presi dent Alejandro Agustin La nusse announced tonight that general elections would be held in Argentina on March 25,1973, and that the new government would take office two months later on May 25.

title: DR. JOHN A. ROSS JR.
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP)Dr. John A. Ross Jr., president of Clarkson College of Technology front 1940 to 1947, died at Potsdam Hospital following a lengthy illness. He was 92 years old.

title: Prague Sets Elections
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 17 (Reuters) Elections will be held in November for the federal as sembly and national and local councils, it was announced to day.

title: OUTPUT OF AUTOS ROSE DURING WEEK
G.N.P. in Germany Shows A 4 Per Cent Real Rise
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Sept. 17. (Reuters)West Ger many's gross national product rose 11 per cent at current prices to 359million marks in the first half of 1971, compared with the G.N.P. of the 1970 pe riod, the Federal Statistics Of fice said today. However, the real growth  measured in fixed, 196 priceswas 4 per cent, the office added.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On Monday, Harlem numbers operators were publicly assured that off track betting wasn't hurting their business. On Tuesday, free speech was dropped from the Detroit lions roster, on Wednesday, a United States Army private won $20,000 and a car at Forest Hills. On Thursday, the Milwaukee Bucks replaced Lew Alcindor with Kareem Ab dul Jabbar. And yesterday, Friday, George Blanda was 44 years old. As you can see, this week had its moments.

title: Newman Is Upheld On Ousting Jessel From Today Show
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that Edwin Newman, N.B.C. news man, was within his rights when he ejected George Jessel from the Today Show for referring to The New York Times and The Washington Post as Pravda.

title: Harriman and Mrs. Leland Hayward Will Marry
description: W. Averell Harriman, for mer Ambassador at Large and Governor of New York from 1955 to '59, and Mrs, Pamela Digby Hayward, the widow of Leland Hayward, the theatrical producer, and once the daughterinlaw of Sir Winston Churchill, plan to marry during the first week in October.

title: Rep. Caller Lauds Black
description: Representative Emanuel Cel ler, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that he expected President Nixon to name an archcooservative to the Su preme Court to succeed Justice Hugo L. Black, whom he de scribed as a fearless judicial warrior and a cherished liberal.

title: A Philippine Island With Little of Anything
description: TAMPAGAN, the Philip pines, Sept. 11A man died of cholera this morning in this village on Simunul Is land, in the Sulu Archipelago, where the southern Philip pines and northern Borneo almost touch.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On DraftTabling Plan
CHANNEL 5 PLANS PRIMETIME FILMS
description: WNEWTV will begin a series of Wednesday night primetime movies Oct. 6 with the presen tation of Castle Keep, a 1969 production starring Burt Lan caster and Peter Falk.

title: Syracuse Holding Trump Cards
N.B.A. Players Spurn Offer by Owners as Senate Hearings on Merger Near
description: The Players Association has turned down a late offer from the National Basketball Association owners designed to end its opposition to the proposed merger with the American Basketball Association.

title: Growth of City of God Stirs Brooklyn Heights
description: Shortly before noon every weekday the lazy treelined streets on the western tip of Brooklyn Heights come alive with pedestrians.

title: Botulism Epidemic Ending; Coast Lake Near Normal
description: OAKLAND, Calif. Sept. 18 (UPI)The fourweek botulism epidemic that killed 150 ducks at Lake Merritt has run its course, according to park rangers here.

title: Tsip Wins by 2 Lengths In Delaware Park Feature
description: STANTON, Del., Sept. 18 (AP) Mrs. Lafayette Thomas's Tsip took charge on the final turn and won the Obeah Purse for fillies and mares at Delaware Park today by 2 lengths over Helen Jennings.

title: The Nation
description: My heart is in Lookit's my baby, Gardner Cowles, chairman of Cowles Communications, Inc., said last year when asked if he intended to close the magazine down. I founded it 33 years ago. I'd sell everything to keep it going.

title: In Electronics, Imports Dominant
description: Robert A. Schieber looked to the development of new technologies as an abvious way for American consumer electronics manufacturers to compete internationally.

title: Board of Education Audit of Community School Boards'
description: A Board of Education review has found what it terms irregularities in expenditures made last year by many of the city's 31 decentralized community school boards.

title: Logothetis Wins PredictedLog Test
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 18The 19th annual Commodore's predictedlog contest, run by the Port Washington Yacht Club under sponsorship of the Eastern Cruiser Association, was won today by Sophocles Logothetis in his 35foot cruiser CaRiAnn II. His percentage error of 0.88 was the lowest in the fleet of 13 that competed in the 3Smile contest.

title: Egypt Accuses Israel
description: CAIRO, Sept. 18A risk of intensified warfare hung over the Suez Canal today following the third outbreak of shooting in the last seven days.

title: Bridge Too good to be true
description: IN bridge as in life great wealth is sometimes accompanied by gullibility, and when the sun is shining brightly, at may be difficult to foresee an impending storm.

title: Washington Edges Purdue, 3835, on Sixkiller's Late Scoring Pass to Scott
Television
description: LAST year the password in television programing was, at least for a while, relevance. The schedule was crowded with lawyers, doctors and schoolteachers ready to lay their idealistic best on the naive heads of society's unfortunates. Most of the dogood activities, of course, were performed in offduty hours. A bit of conscience is all right in its place, but a secure position in the Establishment is nothing to be sniffed at either.

title: AUBURN ROMPS, 607, OVER CHATTANOOGA
description: AUBURN, Ala., Sept. 18 (UPI) Pat Sullivan, hitting on the first eight passes he threw, led Auburn to four quick touchdowns as the 10th ranked Tigers opened their season today with a 60to7 mauling of Chattanooga.

title: Moira Kennedy Bride Of Cormac O'Malley
description: STURBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18The Federated Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Moira Kennedy, daughter of John P. Kennedy and the late Mrs. Kennedy, to Cormac Kevin Hooker O'Malley, son of Mrs. Richard Roelofs Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Ernie O'Malley of Dublin, onetime CommandantGeneral of the Irish Republican Army.

title: U.S. Reported Set To End Combat Role In Vietnam June 30
description: SAIGON, Sept. 18 (UPI)United States military sources said today that the American fighting role in Vietnam would end formally next June 30 when, according to plans, the United States military forces will turn to advisory and support activities.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: A few weeks ago, while reading An Anthology of Irish Literature (Modern Library), I came across the suggestive historical note in the Introduction that the Earl of Tyrone, Hugh O'Neill, a leader in the 1601 Rebellion, had fled to the continent after his defeat by the English.

title: OFFICIALS SILENT ON AILING HARLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The possibility of a second Supreme Court retirement emerged today as officials continued to decline comment on the condition of Justice John M. Harlan, who has been hospitalized for more than a month with what is believed to be a back ailment.

title: LINDSAY VISITS NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: FRANCONIA, Sept. 18 Mayor Lindsay led the top echelon of his City Hall staff to this rustic retreat this drizzly weekend to attend an aide's wedding and, although everyone denied it, to assess his Presidential primary prospects in talks with local political leaders.

title: Stamps
description: A FTER Rosh Hashana (New Year) and Yom Kippur (Day of Atonement), both of which will be observed later ,this month, Jews throughout the world will, early in October, celebrate Sukkot, the Feast of Tabernaclesthe Harvest Festival.

title: Et A1.
description: The weekend repairman who is all thumbsseveral of them hammersplayedmay get few laughs from this determined spoof. Mr. Williamson offers a practical hint here and there but mainly satirizes the American dream of a doityourself home. Toilet repairs: There are people who pretend to know how to fix toilets, but you'll notice that their technique consists of jiggling the lever. That's not knowhow; that's faithhealing. Rome repair, is useful, according to Mr. Williamson, mostly for getting out of visiting relatives.

title: Observers Lay Killings to Official Intransigence
description: Eighteen members of the observers committee that tried to negotiate a peaceful settlement of the rebellion at the Attica prison charged yesterday that official intransigence had caused the killings during the suppression of the revolt.

title: Turner's 5.5Meter Wins Second Race in Gold Cup
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 18 Ted Turner's Tiger won her second race for the United States today as three nations were eliminated today from the Scandinavian Gold Cup 5.5Meter series on Long Island Sound.

title: GEORGE BORGER SR.
description: NAPLES, Fla., Sept. 18.George A. Borger Sr. a retired vice president of the Irving Trust Company of New York, died Thursday at the age of 70. He had also lived in Montclair, N. J.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Dress manufacturing is still an important industry in Chicago, according to Hy Smoler, whose company Boris Smoler & Sons, Inc., is situated in that city.

title: An Angela Davis Lawyer Is Accused of Embezzling
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP)An attorney for Angela Davis has been charged with embezzling $10,800 from the San Mateo County Legal Aid Society, District Attorney Keith Sorensen disclosed today,

title: MarylandEastern Wins
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18 (AP)S tan Perry, a sophomore defensive end, recovered a fumble to pave the way for one touchdown and then blocked a punt and scored another as Maryland Eastern Shore defeated Howard, 307, in a MidEastern Atlantic Conference football game today.

title: 145 Standardbreds Sold At Liberty Bell for $1Million
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18Mighty Butler, a bay son of Adios Butler out of Dream Lady, brought the highest bid of $26,000 on the opening of the Harness Breeders Sales twoday venue of standardbred yearlings today at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Lindley Greenough Is Bride in Jersey
description: EDISON, N. J., Sept. 18Miss Jane Lindley Greenough was married here this noon to Paul Bridgewater Thomasset. The Rev. Robert Seamen performed the ceremony at the Oak Tree Presbyterian Church.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:Here at the American Consulate in Medellin Colombia, we find your Book Review a useful addition to our small library. As you will understand Colombian readers are particularly interested in articles touching on this country. We had quite a number of comments on Maurice Zeitlin's review of Revolutionary Priest: The Complete Writings and Messages of Camilo Torres. Edited and with an Introduction by John Gerassi.

title: Holt of U.S. Golf Victor
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Sept. 18 (AP)Capt. Pliny Holt, retired United States naval officer from Potomac, Wash., became today the first American to win the Jubilee Vase of the Royal and Ancient Golf. Club. In the 18hole final over the old course at St. Andrews, he defeated Arthur M. Young of Britain, 3 and 1.

title: WARFOES FIGHTING CARRIER'S RETURN
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 18Four antiwar organizations maimed 100 polling places throughout this Navy port this weekend, seeking a popular vote of protest against the return to Vietnam of the aircraft carrier Constellation and the 5,000 members of her crew.

title: Child to the Falkenbergs
description: A daughter was born here on Aug. 23 to Mr. and Mrs. Edward Falkenberg of Scarsdale, N. Y., at the Woman's Hospital.

title: 6 Attica Hostages Buried; Families Are Not Present
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 18The bodies of six hostages from the Attica prison disturbance whose funerals were held yesterday were buried today. Clergymen conducted final ceremonies, but families were not present.

title: Turtles Struggle Ashore to Lay Their Eggs, the Burden of Filipino Islands Economies on Their Backs
description: TAGANAK, Philippines, Sept. 13  The ponderous creatures that have given their name to the Turtle Islands emerge, singly, from the Sulu Sea after dark and heave themselves across the stretch of yellow sand toward the beach grass under the tall coconut palms.

title: Kenneth Walton Hubbard Marries Ellen C. Fuller
description: Miss Ellen Cooper Fuller and Kenneth Walton Hubbard were married here yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Hines and the Rev. Almus Thorpe. A reception followed at the Colony Club.

title: BEN SMITH IS AHEAD IN ETCHELLS SAILING
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 13Ben Smith of Marblehead, Mass., took the lead in the Etchells22 Class national sailing championship today.

title: Art
description: THE best way to begin is just to say that the exhibition gallery in Japan House, the new quarters of the Japan Society at 333 East 47th Street between First and Second Avenues, is a beautiful space, and that Rimpa, the inaugural exhibition, which opened to the public yesterday, is perfectly mated with it. For anyone with the slightest interest in Japanese art, the only other essential information is that the gallery is open from 10 to 5 Monday through Friday, 11 to 5 Saturdays, and 1 to 5 Sundays and holidays.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
