description: WASHINGTON  Once there were two Japanese manufacturers of cameras who sold their goods all over the world, and particularly in the United States. The only difference between them was that one kept up with all the international monetary negotiations, developments in gold and such things, and the other did not.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: IN THE absence of any definitive indications so far as to the scope and nature of the post freeze domestic economic program and the ultimate outcome of international monetary negotiations, the financial markets continued to display a considerable amount anxiety last week.

title: The World
description: MANILA  Communists will not stop trying to take over the Philippines and to harm me and my family. They must be crying for my head today. But it so happens I am President, and I have a duty to do.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: If James Taylor And Peter Fonda Flop...
description: IT was my first day back from vacation and I had yet to reestablish a connection with reality when Stanley, my film industry friend, appeared in the door of my office.

title: But the Ubu is missing
description: Dear Frederick Barthelme: stop reading. I wish I'd taken your warning on p. 11: The bulk role of this second book in my We, as it is in yours, is to occupy the time... all I have to do is sit here and blow it out and then they'll buy it and then I'll do another one and so on until I die. I thought your best line was on p. 12: Many things have happened here which, to the untrained eye, might appear interesting. This, Frederick Barthelme is going to be a bad review.

title: The Nation
description: When last we left Bon Vivant Soups, the worst seemed over. But last week there was a new chapter: the Federal Food and Drug Administration released a report detailing the numerous violations it had found last July in the currently bankrupt company's Newark plant. To wit:

title: National Notes
description: Windows broken, doors sagging, obscene graffiti on the wallsthe abandoned building has long stood as a symbol of New York's chronic housing shortage. According to the Rand Corporation, 38,000 dwelling units are abandoned annually in the city, providing the single biggest reason for a total 800,000unit shortage. Many explanations are suggested for the abandonments: A crimeinduced flight to the suburbs; unscrupulous landlords who, having gouged the last possible cent from aging and overcrowded structures, desert rather than repair them; developers who use blockbusting to oust middleclass homeowners and build more profitable highrise apartments.

title: AMERICAN PANEL ASKS BROADER U.N.
Irene Groffsky Engaged to Uri Wernik
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 18Mrs. Herman Groffsky has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Irene Groffsky, to Uri Wernik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuven Wernik of Jerusalem.

title: A Georgian Love Story
description: The author of this book was born in 1888. Octogenarian novels always pose a problem for a younger critic. How can he combine the deference youth owes to age with the blunt and sometimes cruel things that need to be said about their inevitable shortcomings? Plainly, Mr. Raymond was something of a rebel in his time. Sensibly placing the story of his latest novel before World War I he describes the love affair between a sexually retarded young Londoner of the middle class and a workingclass girl. If we had been around then, no doubt we would have found Stewart O'Murry as likeable intelligent and forwardlooking as he does. Having been born 51 years after Mr. Raymond, I find his hero a patronizing prigThis (at least for me) is bound to affect the novel's viability.

title: Woody Strode? He Wasn't the Star But He Stole the Movie
description: WOODY Strode? Silence. You remember. That marvel?? looking black man  the one in Sergeant Rutledge. Wasn't the star, but stole the movie.

title: Stamford Tops Darien, 21 to 7; Darling Hits Lee for 61 Yards
description: Stamford, the Connecticut state scholastic football champion, opened its season yesterday by beating Darien, 217, on the loser's field.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricane Irene Hits Nicaraguan Lowlands
description: MIAMI, Sept. 18 (AP) Hurricane Irene began to hammer the desolate Nicaraguan lowlands today as she followed an old pirate route to the Pacific.

title: Cici Simon Is the Bride of William Francis Holbrook
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 18Miss Celia Carroll (Cici) Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Simon, was married here this noon to William Francis Holbrook of Keene, N. H., son of the late Mr. and Mrs, Sidney Wallace Holbrook.

title: David Levine's Coney: Goya and the Greeks Amid Ancient Waves
description: Being America's preeminent caricaturist would be enough to please most designing mortals, but it is not enough for David Levine.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Although still stalled in their negotiations on a limitation of strategic arms, the SovietAmerican talks in Helsinki (SALT) produced progress on a related problem last week. It was disclosed that the two sides had agreed to. establish a new communications system be, tween Washington and Moscow in order to warn each other of an accidental or unauthorized missile launch.

title: Sarah P. Finch Becomes Bride Of P. J. Minella
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 18Miss Sarah Pauline Finch, whose father, Edward Cornell Kip Finch, is board chairman of Save the Children Federation, was married here this afternoon to Phillip Joseph Minella.

title: TENNESSEE CRUSHES SANTA BARBARA, 486
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 18 (AP)Tennessee combined an alert defense with a scrambling offense today in outclassing the University of California at Santa Barbara, 486.

title: Holdup Man Spurns $25
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. (Reuters)Inflation has hit. the underworld. A holdup man walked emptyhanded out of the Manhattan Hotel this week after turning down $25 in drawer. His comment was, It's not worth the effort.

title: Headliners
description: A Doctor in the House Dr. John H. Knowles, general director of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston since 1962, is an outspoken liberal on social and medical issues. His views frequently conflict with those of the American Medical Association, and it reportedly was this conflictand opposition from conservative Republicans that lay behind his failure to become the nation's top health officer in 1969. Dr. Knowles had been nominated by Robert H. Finch, then Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, but the nomination was dropped after a fivemonth controversy. Now the 45yearold doctor is moving to another prestigious post: He was named last week as president of the Rockefeller Foundation, the second wealthiest foundation (after Ford) in the country. The philanthropic organization has an image of conservatism, which prompted one foundation executive to say Dr. Knowles's selection: He'll probably give it a pretty considerable shaking over a period of time.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Sept. 18 (UPI)Oregon State overcame six lost fumbles and four pass interceptions to grind down opportunistic but inoffensive Iowa, 3319, today.

title: SHEIK MUJIB TRIAL REPORTED ENDED
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 18 (AP)The secret military trial of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the East Pakistani leader charged with waging war on Pakistan, has ended, the Governmentowned Morning News reported today.

title: The sixth and most accessible novel by, feasibly, our best writer
description: Briefly, before black humor, there was among one kind of writer in America a preoccupation with blackness and darkness in general, the various hearts of darkness in Conrad, Melville, Faulkner, Dostoevsky, against which perfectly good writers like Lawrence and Forster looked a little fruity. The scrub writers of that moment could scarcely offer a fiction to the reader without a full complement of dwarfs and religious maniacs. The seats of Pullman cars itched cancerously; heroines had extraordinary moonlike faces; Arabs ran off with one's wife; and jockeys with small, vulpine heads and ancient racing silks scuttled through a landscape that was not quite of this world. It was an age of the grotesque when readers of Alfred Chester salivated for pus; when Norman Mailer was prominently between publishers; and when one read aloud from Djuna Barnes with a sense of historical mission. But there was a varsity too; and of that crew, John Hawkes wrote a fiction that was less doctrinaire dark than it was truly hallucinatory; and absolutely no one comes to mind who could so well arrest that perpetually terrified portion of the inner mind with unnerving images of things going to pieces.

title: Time Running Out on the Candy Stores
Bigger Airports? Not in My Backyard
description: Long Island, which was the launching platform for Charles A. Lindbergh's transAtlantic solo flight and which once boasted of its role as a cradle of aviation, has become in 1971 one of the nation's most bitter battlegrounds in a classic conflict over aviation and human values. It is a battle that pits economic progress against the good life in suburbia.

title: Attica Inmates Tell of Running Gantlet
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 18The committee set up by Governor Rockefeller to safeguard the rights of Attica prisoners reported today that a score of inmates had told its members they had been forced to run a gantlet of blows from nightsticks after the prison revolt was crushed on Monday.

title: Sanda C. Leach, F. F. Cooper Jr. To Be Married
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Sept. 18Miss Sanda Cannon Leach, great granddaughter of J. W. Cannon, founder of Cannon Hills in Kannapolis, plans to be married Oct. 23 to Fowler Paine Cooper Jr., second vice president of the Federal Compress and Warehouse Company in Memphis.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I was an employe of F. I. duPont at the time of theE.D.S. takeover. I left as soon as I was able.

title: Cambodian Troops Regaining Ground
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 17Cambodian army troops, taking advantage of the current rainy season that has flooded most of the Mekong Delta basin, have moved out from the capital along highland roads and have reestablished Government control in about half the national territory, according to Western sources here.

title: Padres'
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18Clay Kirby, a tall righthander, missed a bid for a perfect game on a leadoff eightinning homer by Willie McCovey today as he pitched the San Diego Padres to a 21 victory over the San Francisco Giants. The Giants thus missed an opportunity to increase their twogame lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers who lost again to the Atlanta Braves. Both teams have 10 games left to play in the National League Western Division.

title: Police Department Is Drafting a Reorganization Plan Involving New Roles for Detectives and Patrolmen
Et A1.
description: Rouech continues to do his thing, narratives of medical detection, such as the story of the title character, a man who ate too many carrots. The writing is smooth and clear, informed and interesting. Originally in The New Yorker.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The calculations in J. Karl Justin's Point of View article ["Benefit of Building Systems Overrated, Sept. 5] are completely fallacious and the resulting conclusions quite invalid.

title: Editorial Cartoon 5  No Title
East Pakistan's Governor Swears In Interim Cabinet
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 18 Nine members of a 10man Civilian Council of Ministers for East Pakistan were sworn in yesterday at Dacca, the provincial capital.

title: Janet Rosen Fiancee of Daniel Kleinman
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 18Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Rosen of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Ellen Rosen, to Daniel Kleinman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kleinman of Yonkers. The wedding is planned for Nov. 24 at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: Nixon Plan Ricochet
description: SYDNEY, Australia  In the current uncertainties and upheavals following the Nixon economic package, some Australian financiers feel like the proverbial innocent bystander who gets hurt in other people's quarrels.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  President Nixon flew today to Camp David, Md. He was accompanied to his retreat in the Catoctin Mountains by Mrs. Nixon and H. R. Haldeman, one lof his top White House aides. He is expected to return to Washington tomorrow afternoon.

title: BRANDT SUPPORTS A EUROPE PARLEY
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany today gave new momentum to the Soviet drive for a European security conference by joining Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, in pledging to accelerate efforts to arrange the conference.

title: Fordham Harriers Defeat Seton Hall in Opener, 1640
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 18  Fordham University defeated Seton Hall University, 16.40, in the opening crosscountry meet for both schools today. The Rams took the first fonr places with Torn David finishing ahead of his teammate, Frank McCann.

title: Bowling Green Turns Back Ohio University by 2019
description: ATHENS, Ohio, Sept 18 (UPI)  Bowling Green, behind the passing of Reid Lamport and the running of Paul Miles, both sophomores, topped Ohio University, 2019, today in a MidAmerican Conference opener for both squads.

title: German Classrooms Hold Some Surprises for U.S. Teachers
description: HAMBURG, West Germany Sept, 16Richard Bukowski, a 28yearold mathematics teacher from Chicago, recalled that Everyone told me, You're going to find out what discipline is really like, but Mr. Bukowski says, The atmosphere is really free, maybe just a little bit too much so.

title: The Innocent Investor and the Shaky Ground Floor
description: Advice for the small investor. As Mr. Margolius rushes to point out in his first chapter the financial cards are stacked against the modest spender these days compared to the privileged treatment accorded the big boys. The book tells the small investor how to slip through the interstices of the system; also how to go about getting treasury notes; how to buy life insurance; and facts about savings accounts. There are also chapters exposing the various shady operations designed to mulct the little man.

title: Sanctions on Cuba Opposed
description: PANAMA. CITY, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Galo Plaza, secretary general of the Organization of American States, called today for an end to economic and diplomatic sanctions the O.A.S. imposed against Cuba seven years ago. My opinion is that the politics of isolation have been neither constructive nor effective, Mr. Plaza said at a news conference at the annual meeting of the InterAmerican Economic and Social Council.

title: CRAFT TO STUDY, CORONA OF SUN
description: A spacecraft designed to study and photograph the sun's corona the faint outermost layer of solar atmosphere that is normally seen only during total solar eclipsesis scheduled to be launched Thursday at Cape Kennedy, Fla.

title: Congress Moves to Control Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18For the first time in the 30year history of large scale strip or surface mining in this country, Congress is beginning to move toward Federal regulation of that industry. More than 2 million acres have been gouged by stripping and it is feared that this figure will double in 10 years if the current rate is not slowed.

title: RATES TOP METS FOR TITLE TIE, 40
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18The Pittsburgh Pirates have not been able to read about themselves in the hometown newspapers this summer because the papers have been closed by strike for four months.

title: Toll Booths And Other Sorrows
description: The football Giants plan to leave New York City for the suburbs, because they're not too happy with the old neighborhood. They signed a 30year lease. Some time ago I left New York City for the suburbs, Long Island, because I wasn't too happy with the old neighborhood. signed a 30year mortgage.

title: Between The Hills And the Sea
description: Caught between the devil and the deep blue sea is Mish Lunin, a union leader of the 1950's. The devil is United Vacuum, an industrial colossus for whom Mish is a firstrate machinist. The sea is his union local, of which he is a sometime president. To bath of these masters, Mish brings a high sense of integrity that is part of his undoing. Success, in the labormanagement field belongs to the schemers and the connivers; and Mish is a relic of the thirties, as one of management's lackeys informs him, burdened with obsolete ideals of militancy. When he makes his final run for re election against a company stooge he is the victim of almost total betrayal.

title: National Notes
description: It's a part of the American dream: Some day they'll find oil next door, and we'll all live like kings. But there were no paroxysms of public joy on Long Island last week over the news that there might be oil deposits off the Atlantic coast. Scientists, legislators and environmentalists called the prospect of oil prospecting next door not a dream but a nightmare.

title: White collar girls
description: It's covered, it's black and it has a white collar and cuffs. The Kitty Foyle dress is back. The innocent charm of this spickandspan look is right uptodate, although 1971 versions are as likely to be in playgirl velvet and satin as in workinggirl jersey or knit.

title: John Jones, a Top Officer Of Federated Stores, Dies
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 18John Paul Jones, a senior vice president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., died today of a heart ailment, His age was 53.

title: VOTER DRIVE SET BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Vernon E. Jordan Jr.'s first major project as the new executive director of the National Urban League will be an intensive voter registration drive in Northern ghettos, he said during a television interview here.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Nearly one third more apartments will have been started in the United States in 1971 than in any previous year according to projections made from construction put in place so far this year.

title: U.S. JUDGE LIMITS BUSING IN FLORIDA
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. IS (AP)A Federal judge, declaring massive busing of elementary school pupils not feasible, has ordered that only 5,000 of 90,000 students be bused in Orange County, where the school board members vowed to resist more sweeping busing at the risk of being jailed.

title: Alden, Care and Profits
description: DETROIT  The nursing home industry in the United States has consolidated during the last decade from a wide assortment of marginal mom and pop operations, as one industry source puts it, to some 70 public corporations doing around $3billion a year in business.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: LAST night a kind of phenomenon took place: A true star dropped in on us.

title: Souvenir Chairman Named
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (UPI)Harold Peterson, curator of the National Park Service, has been named chairman of a new Philadelphiabased advisory committee on 1976 bicentennial souvenirs. Mr. Peterson said he would encourage the production of quality souvenirs and discourage junk memorabilia posing as authentic military reproductions.

title: The Old Man called the tune
description: Give me a condor's quill Give me Vesuvius's crater for an inkstand! writes Melville in Moby Dick. Instead of Vesuvius, Shirley Ann Grau has once again dipped her quill into the crater of the South delineating the traditions legends and characters of her native Louisiana.

title: Music
description: WHAT with the Walker Art Center, the Minnesota Orchestra, the Tyrone Guthrie Theater, the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, the Center Opera of Minnesota and the St. Paul Opera, the Twin Cities have become one of the liveliest cultural centers in the Midwest.

title: National Notes
description: Congressman Jim Wright, a Texas Democrat, called it a reminder of a time when hysteria ran like a fever in the American bloodstream. He was referring to the law, passed over President Harry Truman's veto in 1950, that authorized detention camps to hold each person as to whom there is reasonable ground to believe... probably will engage in... or conspire to engage in.. acts of espionage or sabotage in time of war, invasion or insurrection in aid of a foreign enemy Acting under the law, the Government set up six such camps in 1952; they were never used.

title: GREEN BAY FIRST ON A TOUGH CARD
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 18 What you think of the 1971 New York Giants, who opens their 47th National Football League season here tomorrow, depends almost entirely on what you thought of the 1970 Giants.

title: Skyhitching Isn't All It's Cracked Up to Be

The other 98 per cent falls in the category of general aviation, a catchall phrase for the winged parade of businessmen cargo operators, crop dusters farmers ranchers clergymen doctors and pleasure fliers.

title: Recordings
description: WHEN a performance is billed as Verdi's Don Carlos or Don Carlo, the immediate question must he: What, exactly, is being offered? The Verdi opera first performed at the Paris Opera in March, 1867, was Don Carlos, a five act grand opera to a libretto in French which Francois Joseph Mery and Camille du Locle had based upon Schiller's pseudohistorical drama Don Carlos. But the opera staged at Covent. Garden, London, not quite five months later was Don Carlo: the French text had been translated into Italian by Achille de Lauzieres, and Verdi himself had made the consequently essential revisions in the mu

title: Regulars Sweep Primaries On L.I.
description: YAPHANK, LI., Sept. 18It was a week of viotories for the political machines of Long Island.

title: New York Horsemen Awaiting Court Decision on Racing Dates in Florida
description: MIAMI, Sept. 18Horsemen in New York and throughout Eastern and Midwest racing centers eagerly await a court decision, due this week, that will materially alter the Florida horseracing picture.

title: Photography
description: To inaugurate its large new exhibition space on lower Fifth Avenue, the Underground Gallery has mounted a nicely contrasted shoW by Norman Snyder and Fred Picker,

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Yorkville area of Manhattan furnishes numerous examples every day of the helplessness of public housing to meet this city's overwhelming need ["Public Housing Helpless to Aid Most Who Apply, Sept. 5]. Because of its excellent location the area can renew itself by private enterprise. But this merely aggravates the condition of the poor and elderly who inhabit the dilapidated rentcontrolled tenements that exist sidebyside with the everincreasing number of new or renovated highrent apartment houses.

title: Thant Voices Concern
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 18 (Reuters) Secretary General Thant expressed concern today over what he termed the renewal of hostile acts in the Suez Canal sector.

title: COLUMBIA IS VICTOR IN SCRIMMAGE, 176
description: Don Jackson passed for one touchdown and ran for another yesterday as Columbia defeated Williams, 176, in a preseason scrimmage at Baker Field.

title: Los Angeles Still Trails by Two Games After 4th Loss in Row
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept 18The slugging Atlanta Braves dealt the Los Angeles Dodgers a 9.6 defeat today, the fourth straight loss for the Dodgers. The Braves, charging on the outside in the National League West race, moved to 5 games behind firstplace San Francisco and 3 back of secondplace Los Angeles.

title: LAITY TO GET VOICE IN PARISH SCHOOLS
description: Community hoards of education designed to bring more lay participation into the operation of Catholic elementary schools will be established as pilot projects in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn and the FlushingWhitestone section of Queens.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Karras: Block & Tackle After he was let go by the Detroit Lions last Tuesday,, Alex Karras turned down an :offer to continue his distinguished 13year career as a defensive tackle with the Washington Redskins. No thanks, said the bluff Rarras. I've played long enough without a quarterback.

title: STEELE, POWEL WIN SENIOR NET TITLES
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 18 (AP)The topseeded players, Chauncey Steele in the 55yearsandover division and Nick Bowel in the 60andover bracket, won the single chapionships today in the national grasscourt senior tennis tournament.

title: Plaid: One Jump Ahead
description: 1 Not partaking in the horseplay, a compoundboxplaided sport jacket knitted of wool and polyester. St. Laurie's centervented coat is $150 at Altman's. Oleg Cassini for Boonshaft shirt.

title: Reader's Report
description: Actors who write novels write usually about actors. But Alexander Knox, whose histrionic career stretches back into the Wilson Administration (movie version) has chosen to write about three Eskimos, mushing north in the high Arctic. Surprise number two is that the novelat least to this nonEskimoseems utterly authentic. Mr. Knox is as familiar with the sanitary facilities of an igloo as he is with the nuances of family life.

title: LAW VOLUNTEERS TO HELP AT TOMBS
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 18A battery of experienced lawyers, assisted by thirdyear law students from New York University and probably from Columbia University, will work as volunteers in the Manhattan House of Detention, also known as the Tombs, to assist prisoners with legal and civil rights problems.

title: Austrian Slide Kills 2
description: VIENNA, Sept. 18 (AP)An avalanche hit an Alpine rescue squad today killing two mountain guides and injuring two., The party was seeking the bodies of two climbers near the 12,460foot Grossglockner peak.,

title: Movies
description: THE movies have always tried to think big big, after all, is the vulgarian's great, But hard times are upon us, and doubly so on Hollywood, and big can no longer be afforded. Impecunious and desperate the movies needed an easy and inexpensive substitute for big. They have now come up with one: pretentious. You make your movie small, with any old script and any new talent (or lack of talent), and you douse it liberally with pretentiousness; out comes a movie that implies all those magnitudes, portends all those dimensions that can no longer be paid for in sets, extras, farflung locations and extended shooting schedules. It may be only one square foot of land, but if you keep digging into it, you may reach China!

title: Siani's Heisman Vote Goes to Siani: Im the Best
description: Mike Siani, Villanova split end, already knows who won't win the 1971 Heisman Trophy. He won't.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Much has been made of the 28 concessions that Corrections Commissioner Russell G. Oswald agreed to during the course of negotiations to end the Attica prison uprising. Some of those concessions would represent real improvements in prison life, but is it true that in refusing to surrender on that basis the prisoners were being intransigent and unreasonable?

title: VERMONT TOPPLES CONNECTICUT, 207
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 18 Spearheaded by a rugged defense, Vermont snapped a 13game losing streak by defeating Connecticut, the defending Yankee Conference champion, by 207 today before a crowd of 7,200. The losing streak was a New England record.

title: LEHIGH RALLY TOPS C.W. POST BY 2414
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 18Lehigh rallied in the second half today to defeat C. W. Post, 2414, before a crowd of 8,000. Last week the Engineers turned back Hofstra, another Long Island rival, 280.

title: Maryland Triumphs, 357
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 18 (UPI)Al Neville, a quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for another today as Maryland trounced North Carolina State, 357, for its first victory over the Wolf.. pack since 1962

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: My recent flight across the Atlantic was wretched be cause I was sitting near two pipe smokers who puffed away continuously except for the time they found it necessary to eat. However, I write not to complain about the innocent thoughtless but to suggest a modest proposal to the airlines. Since it appears impracticable to arrange isolated smoking areas in planes, why not schedule some proportion of flights for nonsmokers only? On New York to Chicago flights, for example, make onefifth or onequarter of them nonsmoking. I suspect that these flights would be mobbed. Where two airlines compete, the first to offer a respite from the equivalent of rotten eggs and sulphuric acid mist I believe, enjoy a profitenhancing boost in the percentage of occupied seats. In any event, why don't planes catch up with bases in the eighth decade of the 20th century? Hasn't the time come for a rigid ban on pipes and cigars on all aircraft?

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE ECONOMY: President Nixon pledged strong, effective restraints on industry after the 90day wageprice freeze expires.... Commerce Secretary Stans said wage increases would be tied to productivity gains... Common Market demanded U.S. devalue the dollar as key to resolving the monetary crisis.... GATT urged U.S. remove quickly its import surcharge, but President Nixon implied it would be longlasting.... Group of Ten meeting in London was unable to reach an accord on the dollar crisis.... U.S. balanceofpayments deficit reached $9billion annual rate in first half of 1971.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Last year a $500million advertising agency cut its marketing department from 60 people down to three.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 18 Robert Jackson, a substitute quarterback, won a starting role for Montclair Academy today when he fired four scoring passes to Glen Veit to pace a 440 victory over Kings School.

title: Attica Demands Presented To Correction Chief in July
description: A list of 27 demands, signed by five men calling themselves the negotiating committee of the Attica Liberation Faction, was drawn up and sent to Commissioner of Correction Russel G. Oswald early in July.

title: Why Muskie?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Senator Edmund S. Muskie's long lead in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination is not an accident.

title: Easy Velvet
description: 1 Velvet: a fabric to relax and have fun in. Center seated, a brassbuttoned jacket of plush black cotton velvet. Wide curving notched lapels, flapped pockets, side vents. $150. The pleated wool tartan slacks with selffabric belt, $50. Both, for Jaeger by Carlo Palazzi, are at Mannie Walker.

title: Woman Slain in Village
description: A woman was found murdered in her Greenwich Village apartment yesterday. The police of the Sixth Precinct said the woman, tentatively identified as Miss Katherine Rubin, 26 years old, of.56 Jane Street, was found dead in bed with her hands tied behind her back and a gag in her mouth. Detectives from the homicide souad said that they were awaiting word: from the Medical Examiner on the cause of death and whether the woman had been sexually assaulted.

title: Seferis, Nobel Laureate, Is Seriously Ill in Athens
description: ATHENS, Sept. 18George Seferiadis, the 71yearold Greek diplomat who won the 1963 Nobel Prize for literature for his poetry written under the name George Seferis, was in serious condition today at the Evanghelismos Hospital here.

description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  The Suffolk County police have begun a threeyear surveillance of people convicted of driving while intoxicated who have had their drivers licenses revoked.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Total victory against some important and allbutconquered diseases is slipping away in the United States as more and more Americans ignore the vaccines available.

Christian have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Jean Christian, to Lauren Douglas Templeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Templeton of Manhasset, L. I. description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept, 18 Before an overflow crowd of 42,148 fans, largest in the history of Michie Stadium, Army put on a good first quarter show today before succumbing to a much superior Stanford team, 383.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 18The Defense Ministry announced today that 5 South Korean Marines and 3 civilians were killed yesterday in clashes with 4 armed North Korean infiltrators at a village 25 miles northwest of Seoul.

title: KISS NEBLETT SINGS ROLE OF VIOLETTA
description: Carol Neblett had her first chance to sing Violetta in La Traviata with the New York City Opera Friday night. The young soprano's performance was praiseworthy as an initial attempt at a difficult role, but it wasn't until the last act that it turned from something potential to achievement. Here Miss Neblett sang with the temperament she has shown in other parts, giving variety to tone and phrasing. Earlier her singing had often been without nuance or dramatic expansive

title: The Nation
description: ATTICA, N. Y.The troopers moved in. Ladders went over walls. A rescue squad of 27 men led by correctional guards broke into D cellblock where 38 hostages were being held. Marksmen with highpowered.270caliber rifles equipped with sniper scopes shot down into that yard. Tear gas canisters fell from National Guard helicopters. The main assault was over in about an hour. Then troopers and inmates fought each other handtohand in cells and corridors.

description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 18The Democratic State Committee endorsed today most of the demands for prison reform made by the rebelling inmates of Attica Correctional Facility after they took over the institution.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18After sitting for 181 years be hind a simple straight bench, the Supreme Court will change the shape of its bench this year into a shallow U.

description: THE two commissioned works that were the musical features of the opening ceremonies at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts could not have been further apart. Leonard Bernstein's Mass, commissioned by Jacqueline Onassis, was slick, chic, sentimental, altogether showbiz. Two evenings later came an opera, Beatrix Cenci, by the Argentine composer Alberto Ginastera. This work, commissioned by the Opera Society of Washington, made few concessions to popular taste. It was a dissonant postSchoenberg work with a gruesome libretto (incestuous rape, murder, torture, the

title: Dale Ann Bourjaily Is Married
description: Miss Dale Anne Bourjaily, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monte F. Bourjaily of Spiting Lake, N. J., was married in Overveen, the Netherlands, yesterday to Adrianus J, van der Pol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes F. van der Polvan Dam of Overveen. The ceremony was performed in Our Sweet Lady of the Immaculate Conception by the Rev. P. Veltmann, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

description: WASHINGTONNow that the celebrities and critics have had their opening nights, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here in the nation's capital is open to the people as a national cultural center, Large numbers have begun to visit Washington's newest tourist attraction and to fill the two theaters already open. third, the Eisenhower Theater, opens Oct. 18 with Ibsen's A Doll's House.

title: British Newspapers Halted
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  Newspaper proprietors stopped publication tonight of all Sunday newspapers in London and Manchester and said no weekday newspapers would be published until printing workers ended their harassment tactics of holding union meetings at crucial production times. This action by the Newspaper Publishers Association, representing newspapers sold nationally, means that only provincial papers will appear Monday.

title: Office of Education to Press New Demands on Title I Funds Despite Challenge From Three States
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Office of Education is standing by its plan to demand reimbursement from seven more states of allegedly misspent education funds, despite an unexpected challenge by three other states over a similar demand.

title: USAC's Racing Title at Stake In 500 at Pocono Oval Today
description: Today and next Sunday, the United States Auto Club comes to this area with two big races, each with a divisional championship at stake, The club's stockcar title will be riding on the Pennsylvania 500 this afternoon at Pocono International Raceway at Long Pond, Pa. Roger McCluskey, driving a Plymouth Su. perbird, is out to win his third straight championship, a string no one else has ever achieved. He leads the standings with 2,685 points against Butch Hartman's 2,225.5 and Jack Bowsher's 2,049.75.

title: Israeli Scholar Preparing New Edition of Talmud
description: In Jerusalem, the land of the Bible, charisma comes in many vesselsa little man with wisps of floating white hair, a toughminded grandmother, a oneeyed general given to original thinking.

title: How America and Russia lost China, a country neither ever had
description: Stalin lost China three timesfirst in 1927, again in the mid1930's and finally on Oct. 1, 1949, the day Mao Tsetung proclaimed his new regime in Peking. That was the same day we lost China. Nikita Khrushchev lost it again for Russia between 1958 and 1960and this loss seems final, at least for the foreseeable future.

description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP)Colgate's football team, dominated by sophomores, survived a Boston Unversity rally to record a 2721 triumph in its football season opener at Andy Kerr Stadium today.

description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 18 John C. Higgins, board chaii, man and former president of the Franklin Bank of Paterson, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital after a short He was 61 years old and lived at 29 Eagle Rock Way.

description: MILAN, Italy, Sept. 18Our 16yearold son is always surprised when someone refers to our 11yearold daughter as Korean, John E. Adams of Creswell, Ore., told the first World Conference on Adoption and Foster Placement here.

title: Northeastern, Led by Raby, Beats Rhode Island, 3622
description: BROOKLINE Mass., Sept. 18Phil Raby completed two touchdown passes to Bill Murray and ran for one himself to lead Northeastern University to a 3622 victory over Rhode Island today in the season opener for! both teams at Parsons Field.

description: The chairman of a community planning board has called upon the City Planning Commission to reopen a public hearing on a proposed zoning change concerning air rights that he described as inimical to the interest of Manhattan's residential tenants.

title: Et A1.
description: An anthology on time. The contrast between Hebrew and Greek time (linear vs. cyclical), psychological and physiological time; pharmacological tests of the way normal, schizoid, drugged, hypnotized people experience time. Quentin Fiore, the McLuhan collaborator, on The Future of the Book. The volume would provide the basis for an acceptable but hardly galvanizing college course.

title: Reports of Talks Denied
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 18Official sources refuted today reports from Karachi that secret contact had been arranged betwen India and Pakistan in Teheran during the visit of President Yahya Khan three days ago. The sources denied that there had been any contact, secret or open, and discounted speculation on a possible meeting between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and the Pakistani President to lessen the tension over the East Pakistani crisis.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Notes
description: When the Federal Government last July began testing servicemen for narcotics addiction, it had been fondly expected that hooked soldiers would agree without much argument to take advantage of new programs in the Veterans Hospitals to get them off drugs before returning to civilian society. Last week, Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe, head of the Presidential drug addiction office, revealed that this voluntary treatment program was not working as we hoped.

title: Pope Receives Amin
description: ROME, Sept. 18 (AP)Pope Paul VI today received Gen. Idi Amin, the President of Uganda, who is a Moslem, and one of General Amin's wives in a 30minute private audience. The Pope visited Uganda in July, 1969.

title: FRANK L. MANDATO
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Sept. 18Frank L. Mandato Sr., president of the Glen Concrete and Foundation Company of Sea Cliff and the Bronx, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Mill River Club in Upper Brookville. He was 61 years old and lived at 152 Dubois Avenue.

title: Central Conn. Triumphs
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Sept. 18 (AP)Central Connecticut's Bob Hayes threw three touchdown passes as he directed the Blue Devils to 496 romp over Towson State of Maryland today.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The description of Anthony Mancini's experiences in his father's hometown in Italy (Travel section, Aug. 1) reminded me of my visit a few years ago with relatives in Mannheim, West Germany. My mother came to the United States 90 years ago, and no one in the family here had ever returned. I could not speak German and my relatives English was limited, but I was treated like royalty. I did learn that when my cousin Heinrich said 'we promenade he meant a twohour hike and not a threeblock walk. After five days of promenades, gesturing, using the dictionary and just puzzling, I was exhaustedbut so happy! The faces of Heinrich and his wife, as we waved goodby, are still vivid in my mind. My life was enriched because of their hospitality, and I humbly hope they think well of all their American cousins as a result of the visit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In 1968 I was consultant to the National Commission on Urban Problems (Douglas Commission) and studied the subject of benefits of buildings systems in depth. I found that the most reliable sources for labor man hours statistics in building were those of the United States Department of Labor and the Federal Housing Administration. These sources indicated approximately 43 per cent of onsite cost as labor cost, an almost similar amount as material cost the rest being other costs.

title: Dodgers Offer Tickets For League Playoffs
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Los Angeles Dodgers announced today that tickets for the National League championship series are available by mail order in case the club wins the Western Division title.

title: How Jets and Giants Got That Way
Sophisticated eel
description: The ancients prized eel above almost any other food. And Aristophanes suggests, in his play The Acharnians, that one of the major hardships suffered by Athenians during the Peloponnesian War was an import embargo on eels. Today. in many countries of the world. their tender, white, notatallfishy flesh is considered a delicacy of the first order. On Long Island, some people smoke them, which produces mild taste of real subtlety. In France. especially in the district of the FrancheComtin the east. it is common to stew eel wine. In this recipe, an adaptation of a sophisticated version of the dish. the sauce is studded with raisins and mushrooms.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: In his zeal to dramatize the events surrounding the filming of The Godfather, Nicholas Pileggi makes several statements in his article, The Making of The Godfather  Sort of a Home Movie (Aug. 15), regarding film production in New York City that are simply not true.

title: Mrs. Boyer Has a Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Alger Boyer of Hewlett Neck, L. I., on Sept. 8 at the New York Hospital. The child has been named Gay Alexandra. Mrs. Boyer is the former Miss Gay Martha Hedlund and Mr. Boyer is an independent management consultant in New York.

title: Clark U. Provost Named
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 18 Dr. Alan E. Guskin, 34 years old, a specialist in educational and social psychology at the University of Michigan, has been named to the newly created post of provost at Clark University here. As provost, Dr. Guskin will be Clark's chief academic officer. The appointment will be effective in December.

title: New Bowling Frame Is StrikingPaula Sperber's
description: Her blue eyes framed by a Veronica Lake head of hair, Paula Sperber smiled sweetly and said, Sure I'm a pool hustler. In fact, I hustle pool better than I do bowling.

title: Late Missouri Bid Fails In 76 Loss to Air Force
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Sept. 18 (AP)Missouri's Greg Hill missed a 37yard fieldgoal attempt with five seconds to play today as Air Force held on to gain a 76 football victory over the Tigers.

title: Public Eligible in Draw Of 3,500 Rose Bowl Tickets
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 18 (AP)A block of 3,500 tickets for the Rose Bowl football game next Jan. 1 has been made available to the general public, with a drawing to determine the purchasers.

title: IRAQIS BROADCAST CONFESSION OF SPY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 Baghdad radio and television yesterday broadcast a recording of what was described as a confession of an agent of the British intelligence network. The Iraqis said that other agents had been involved in espionage and conspiracy and that their confessions would later.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Korean Family Ethics Yielding to Modern Pressures
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 18One of the most popular television programs in South Korea these days, a serial melodrama about an aged widower whose married children do not like to live with him, dramatizes a shift taking place in the family system of this ancient nation as part of social changes resulting from modernization.

title: Protecting Ocean Mammals
description: Ocean mammals are among the most intelligent and fascinating of nature's creatures. The great whales, the polar bears, the dolphins and porpoises, the sea cows, the walruses and the seals evoke the interest and admiration of both scientists and ordinary citizens.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I want to protest very strongly against the disastrous first page of the Aug. 15 Arts and Leisure Section.

title: Jo Anne Dee Married
description: The marriage of Miss Jo Anne Winifred Dee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Dee of New Milford, N. J., to Paul Stephen Field of New York, son of Mrs. Reginald Field of Arlington, Va., and the late Mr. Field, took place here yesterday in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. James J. Healy and the Rev. Richard J. O'Donnell performed the ceremony.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTONIn a small town in northeastern Connecticut last month, a housewife was confronted by a common problemthe ran out of laundry detergent. She solved the problem in a common way, by borrowing a cupful from a neighbor.

title: How to Make the U. N. Work
description: New York is about to be immersed again in its annual word, bath. Foreign ministers and diplomats of 127 nations are flocking in for the 26th General Assembly, which opens Tuesday. Before they depart in December, if the past is a guide, they will hold 800 plenary and other meetings, listen to ten million words of speeches, wade through 27,000 pages of printed documents, debate about 108 agenda items and pass some 130 resolutionsfew of which the world will even note, much less remember.

title: Nuptials for Kathrin Schwarzschild
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 18Miss Kathrin Schwarzschild, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harry Schwarzschild, was married this afternoon to Dr. George Clifford Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Hardin Brown of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ousted Teacher Gets Pay
description: FOREST PARK, Ga., Sept. 18 (AP)  The Clayton County school hoard has given full back pay and $5,000 in damages to Forest Park high school English teacher, Luke T. Calloway Jr., who lost his job over the teaching materials he used. Mr. Calloway was dismissed last year because his classes used Playboy magazine and a surrealistic movie by Salvador Dali. The pay and damages were awarded by a court.

title: BEST SERVICEMEN LINKED TO DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Behind the scenes of the Pentagon's fight to get the draft reinstated, highranking ficers are quietly, explaining to legislators that their concern is even more with the quality than with the quantity of military manpower.

title: RADIATION OF FOOD GAINS ACCEPTANCE
description: GENEVA, Sept. 18  After years of experimentation and public rebuff regarding the use of radiation to keep foods fresh the process seems to be coming into its own.

title: Federal Reversal on Detergents Creates Confusion Across U. S.
Tax Reform Panel Set Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  Formation of a National Committee for Small Business Tax Reform was announced today. The group will press for enactment of a dozen relief measures that are frequently introduced but are never pushed to a vote in Congress.

title: Movie Mailbag; WHICH 20 SECONDS?
description: TO THE EDITOR: Groans are heard from many lamenters these days for the 'good old clean flicks.

title: Wheels
description: Arthur Hailey has written three blockbuster novels in a row. The first was about a hotel (Hotel) and the second was about an airport (Airport). The third, here under review, is about the automobile industry (Wheels). A book to gladden the hearts of Doubleday's sales force  who can advertise it, with certain truth, as soon to be made into a major motion picture.

title: In his heyday, the Boswell of Hard Times Square
description: While Bob Thomas, who authored King Cohn (as in Harry), Thalberg, Selznick, was researching the Walter Winchell biog, his New York and Hollywood sources were prone to observe, Who cares? Thomas's Winchell will make many care.

title: 4Day Week Planned
description: SAN ANTONIOThe United Services Automobile Association, 14th largest automobile insurer in the nation, will place 3,000 workers on a fourday, 38hour work week beginning Oct. 4, for a 90day trial period.

title: Et A1.
description: Another gathering of Art Buchwald's Washington columns. Why it's better to turn off the audio when Nixon is on TV, relying on his body language to decide what he's not saying; how Martha Mitchell was forced to move her phone from the bathroom. Further confirmation that this international gadfly found the City of Light a more nourishing feedingground than Foggy Bottom.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Judging from the report (Sept. 12) on the new Electronic Data Systems Corporation dress code, Ross Perot must think that his name is Watson. The next thing will be an E.D.S. Songbook.

title: Lew Anderson Has a Field Day With His Groups at Town Hall
description: Lew Anderson, a saxophonist, singer, arranger and conductor, whose normal habitat is the world of commercial jingles, had a field day  or, more correctly, field nightat Town Hall Friday night.

title: How tiresome to be forever resisting everything' yes, and yet...
description: This collection of essays and reviews draws upon Midge Decter's unusual range of experience as a wife and mother, a writer and editor, Jew born and bred in the Middle West but now a significant figure in literary New York. She has made it in what was once called a man's world without neglecting the older conventions of womanhood, and despite its title The Liberated Woman and Other Americans will not please the doctrinaire feminism now in vogue.

title: JUDICIAL PARLEYS NAME CANDIDATES
description: Democratic and Republican leaders in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens held their biennial judicial conventions yesterday to fill 10 vacancies in the State Supreme Court.

title: N. CAROLINA TOPS ILLINOIS BY 270
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept 18 (AP)A flashing tailback, Ike Ogleby, piled up 175 yards rushing and scored on a 58yard pass play and a threeyard plunge to lead North Carolina to a 270 upset football victory over Illinois today.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:As governor in charge at the Information Center of the Pan American Society of New England, I was shocked that you should so far depart from your usual high standards in recent Et Al column.

title: Red China to Compete In World Title Hockey
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 18 (AP) Communist China is scheduled to participate for the first time next spring in the world ice hockey championships, an official of the International Ice Hockey, Federation said today.

title: SOLING SERIES LED BY NOROTON SAILOR
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18  Robert Crane of Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club held a 2point lead for the United States Atlantic Coast Soling Class championship today. The third and fourth races of the threeday regatta were sailed by a fleet of 37 on Long Island Sound off Riverside Yacht Club.

title: N.F.L. Season Gets Under Way Today
description: The National Football League, enjoying unparalleled prosperity but still beset with a host of nagging problems, will start its 52d year of action today.

title: MARK BERKE,56,DIES; HOSPITAL EXECUTIVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18Mark Berke, executive vice president of Mount Zion Hospital and Medical Center here, immediate past president of the American Hospital Association and recipient of its 1972 distinguished service award, died today of cancer. He was 56 years old.

title: So I Did Beats Jane Heir By a Neck at Narragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept 18 (AP)So I Did won its sixth race in seven starts today by finishing ahead of Jane Heir by a neck in the feature at Narragansett.

title: ARIZONA SETS BACK WASH. STATE, 3928
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 18 (UPI)Bill Demory threw three touchdown passes and scored one today as he brought the Arizona Wildcats from behind to a 3928 victory over Washington State.

title: Miss Katherine McBride Hall Is Married to Dr. Leon Mann
description: BELLEVUE, Wash., Sept. 18Miss Katherine McBride Hall, a greatgranddaughter of President William Howard Taft, was married here at noon today to Dr. Leon I. Mann, an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the Cornell University Medical College in New York. He is the son of Mrs. Leo Mann of Albany and the late Mr. Mann.

title: IRISH INTERCEPT 7 IN 507 CRUSHING OF NORTHWESTERN
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 18  Outlined against a gray September sky, Notre Dame's manypistoned football machine began another quest for the national title by rolling over Northwestern, 507.

title: Rochester 3521 Victor
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 18 (AP) Four touchdowns passes by Greg Conrad paced Rochester to a 3521 victory over Washington of St. Louis today.

title: DEFENSE NETWORK IS TESTED BY NATO
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is holding the final tests or what its officers describe as the most extensive and complex international air defense system in the world.

title: Letter From the Bay Area
description: In Bay Area soil everything can grow. In the next earthquake everything can fall into the Pacific Ocean. This is a metaphoric place in which life and death are yoked together. It is like the original book where men used to read of the goodness of beginning, the mystery of ending and the chaos of being between. After five years in this book I find it hard to distinguish the strictly literary from what isn't. Everything I see wants to speak of another thing.

title: Wives
description: Subtitled An Investigation, this is actually just another taperecorded safari into the psyche of the genus housewife. Reams of nattering about sex, presumably to the end of satisfying other housewives voyeurism. It all sounds like the leftovers from John Cassavettes cutting room. By the author of the bestselling novel The Detectives and a teacher at Swarthmore of children with learning problems.

title: DUKE WINS, 2812, FROM S. CAROLINA
Pays $8.40 in U.N.
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18The Rokeby Stables sent the right one into the $100,000 United Nations Handicap today. Run the Gantlet, representing Paul Mellon's thoroughbred operation, won the 13/16mile turf event, just as his stablemate, Fort Marcy, did last year.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: To the Editor: Our 1972 football schedule was published in The Times last Sunday. It was sent to you by mistake. Here is Deerfield Academy's 1971 schedule:

title: Et A1.
description: A shallow, if lively, portrait of the new Australia. Mr. Aitken, a London journalist, emphasizes the boomtown aspects of the country and manages to convince one that Australia may very well be the gogo land of the seventies. Mineral discoveries abound, and money flows like Texas oil; but the effect of the book is more dizzying than enlightening.

title: Nixon Visit Sparks Dispute in Dayton
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 18In the aftermath or President Nixon's visit here Sept, 3 to dedicate the new Air Force Museum, Representative Charles W. Whalen, Republican of Ohio, has urged the commander of WrightPatterson Air Force Base to explain why part of the crowd was barred from the ceremonies.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: Marshall's New Team Loses Comeback Game
description: MOREHEAD, Ky., Sept. 18 (UPI)Marshall University, rebuilding with sophomores and freshmen, stayed close to Morehead State for three quarters tonight before losing 296, in its first football game since a plane crash last November killed 75 persons, including most of the Marshall team.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Women said Aristonaxius of Nessus (or perhaps it was Lepocarthus of Messina), are emotional creatures. And when they write detective fiction, many women are apt to be emotional about it. The genre has developed a few masters. There was Dorothy Sayers of course A venerable lady named Agatha Christie still has a certain followingbut too many females of detective fiction are so cutesy that the reader can whoopsie. There is the love interest and the arch dialogue and the alarmed heroine and the brave, handsome hero who at first is altogether a suspicious character. Lady can be a trial.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:I must protest a statement made by Mark Mancall in his essayreview of my book China and Russia: the Great Game.

title: Television
description: IT happens every year, as regularly as Groundhog Day, August White Sales and GoVernor Rockefeller's nasal pronouncement that the state is headed for fiscal disaster unless he raises taxes. So it comes no surprise that, once again, The Doris Day Show has been completely redesigned. New format. New supporting cast. New production staff.

title: Peking Seat Would Upset Power Patterns in the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18It has never been easy to say who runs the United Nations. With the almost certain arrival this year or next of the mainland Chinese, it will be even more difficult.

title: Report on Men's Wear
description: On the cover: a pair of knit suits. At left, honeycombpatterned polyester, twobuttoned, patchpocketed, backbelted, sidevented. Flared trousers. By Hardy Amies. $135 at Whitehouse & Hardy. Lew Wald shirt; Eros tie. At right, chevronstriped doubleknit polyester. Two buttons, flapped pockets, center vent slightly flared trousers. $115 at Wallachs. Hathaway shirt; Walter Handley tie. Stetson hats. Her dress; Bonwit's. Having shown that they are shockproof to bizarre fashions, men can now relax: clothing for fall has eliminated the aggressive styling and unnecessary excesses of recent seasons while sensibly retaining the freshness and sense of fun won during the socalled fashion revolution. Even old favorites returning on the coattails of the nostalgia boom reappear looking newly liberated.

title: National Notes
Multinationals of Two Minds
description: As far as multinational companies are concerned, the Administration's international economic measures the 10 per cent import surcharge and accompanying monetary strategyseem to be on the order of what is one man's meat may be another's poison.

title: FLORIDA STATE WINS ON A BAREFOOT GOAL
description: MIAMI, Sept. 18 (UPI)Frank Fontes, a barefooted placekicker, kicked a 25yard field goai in the final five minutes today to give Florida State a 2017 victory over the Miami Hurricanes.

title: JEWS WILL MARK NEW YEAR TONIGHT
description: Rosh haShanah, the start of the Jewish New Year, will be observed by Jews at sundown. today with services in temples and synagogues.

title: The Buck Fever Papers
description: Sherwood Anderson's Buck Fever columns for two southwest Virginia papers in the late twenties and early thirties. Buck Fever comments on manners and mores of a fictitious town, in the witty and satirical manner faMiliar to newsPaper readers of the day. A genial minor bit of Americana by 71 major American writer. Previously uncollected.

title: Photoengravers in Pittsburgh Approve Contract
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (UPI) Photoengravers voted today to accept a new twoyear wage contract with the Pittsburgh Press Company, paving the way for the resumption Monday of daily newspaper publication in this city for the first time in 128 days.

title: Mitchum, a Character In Search of a Jail
description: THE sky hung low and dripping over the Sheraton Motor Inn, and Robert Mitchum hunched his shoulders against it and scooted around to the other side of the Mercury, slamming the door against the rain.

title: Blacks Here Plan To Bury Any Bodies Unclaimed at Attica
description: Black community groups in the New York City area are planning to bury any of the inmates killed last week at Attica prison whose bodies are not claimed by relatives.

title: A place to play
description: If you had a superb site on the rugged shore of Long Island Sound and if you had built a modern house on it and if you had nine grandchildren, what next? Well, if you were Mr. and Mrs. Buttenwieser, you would turn part of the site into a playground for the kids. Ann Buttenwieser, an adviser on parks and playgrounds, and her husband commissioned Paul Friedberg, the playground expert, to design a miniplayground based on the newest playfacility concepts. He placed it on a sandy stretch in view of the house but far enough away so that all the neighborhood youngsters could play there without worrying about the decibel count. The sculptural arrangement of timbers looks as natural as piers and jetties. But it offers more options for play. There are mountains to climb, bridges to cross, poles to conquer, slides and swings. Yes, there might be an occasional splinter. ButChildren must learn to deal with wood, Friedberg says, just as urban children have to deal with the hard edges of the city.

title: Knits: Set To Go Places
description: 1 A spirited whalebonedesigned double knit wool suit: shaped, twobuttoned, deeply centervented. The slightly flared trousers have an extension waist. $225 at Saks Fifth Avenue. Eagle shirt. J. S. Blank tie. Stetson hat.

title: Kings Point Triumphs
description: KINGS POINT, L I., Sept. 18 It was homecoming day for the alumni of the Merchant Marine Academy today, and the Kings Pointers, celebrated by winning the football game with Norwich University. 137, on Captain Tomb Field.

title: Texas Moves on Ground To Beat U. C. L. A., 2810
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UPI)Eddie Phillips ran over one touchdown and threw for another on his only completion today as Texas scored a 2810 victory over the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: CORWIN LEADING IN 420 CLASS SAIL
description: NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 18 G. R. (Garry) Corwin Jr., of the Tappan Zee Sailing Association at Piermont, held a  point lead over Richard Fraser of Larchmont Yacht Club today after the first four races in the Atlantic Coast championship of the 420 Class were sailed on the Hudson River off Nyack Boat Club.

title: Westminster Scores, 260
description: NEW WILMINGTON, Pa., Sept. 18. (AP) Gene McNamara threw two touchdown passes to Roger Price and scored another himself as the Westminster Titans drubbed Marietta, 260, today. The Titants have now won 16 straight games.

title: Xavy, the neurotic, makes progress
description: This is a very rare thing: a novel about people searching for their identity which is not searching for its own. It is probably the best book yet to come out of my generation, and a surprise: assured, unassuming, clearsurfaced, and therefore able to touch rare depths of affection and belief. It has none of the verbal gesticulation and manic inclusiveness that are so often used to express the style and panic of this generation instead of communicating its experience; nor does it try to deal directly with politics, drugs and the war (subjects which may require a War and Peace of their own), though these things are felt as potent, shadowy absences, the novel's barely spoken premise. Rather, it is about ordinary life lived in their shadow and lived much as usual, though somewhat at a loss, in the peculiar limbo of the late sixties. And in Jonathan Strong's hands, ordinary life becomes almost a palpable medium, with a lovely, casual precision that makes most other prose read like a melodrama of the perceptions.

title: Royals Beat Twins, 42
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 8 (UPI)Al Fitzmorris scatered five hits today as the ??ansas City Royals registered 4.2 victory over the Minneota Twins.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: When China Gets Into the U.N.
description: WHEN the United Nations General Assembly meets on Tuesday there will be the usual dozens of items on its agenda, but one of them will overshadow all othersthe question of China.

title: Lindsay Unfreezes Construction Funds Tied to Union Bias
description: The freeze on city building that had halted $280million worth of construction of schools, libraries, police stations and other projects was lifted yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: MELVIN INCREASES TRITON SAILING LEAD
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 18 Ridgely Melvin of the Annapolis (Md.) Yacht Club, who took the series lead in the first two races yesterday, increased his margin to 5 points today in the National Triton championship regatta on Long IsIsland Sound off the Stamford Yacht Club. One race ends the regatta tomorrow.

title: Being Black in Belorussia Is Like Being From Mars
description: THE Third World students in Moscow say that the season they like best is the green winterthe summer. This was the season chose to drive through European Russia in my silvergray 1958 Daimler 104.

title: ConvictAid Leader Praises Oswald
description: The head of an organization that aids former convicts had muted praise last week for Russell G. Oswald, the state's Commissioner of Correctional, Services.

title: University Names President
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 (AP) Lewis A. Toepfer, acting president of Case Western Reserve University here since last October, has been elected president of the school. Ralph Besse, chairman of the university trustees, said this week that Mt. Toepfer had been chosen unanimously by the trustees in a special meeting.

title: Miss McCarthy Is Wed in Troy
description: TROY, N. Y. Sept. 18Miss Rosanne McCarthy, who is in her second year at the University of Colorado School of Law, was married hero this noon to Henry Van Sinderen Hall, who expects to graduate from the same law school in June. Msgr. William Slavin performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: Tokyo Aide Again Rules Out Unilateral Revaluing of Yen
description: TOKYO, Sept. 18 (AP)Finance Minister Mikio Mizuta reiterated today that Japan would not revalue the yen unilaterally, declaring that such an action would only jeopardize national interests.

title: KINGCASALS FINAL SET FOR LOUISVILLE
description: LOUISVILLE, Sept. 18 (UPI) Touseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King and thirdseeded Rosemary Casals scored straightset victories today in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims Louisville invitation tennis tournament to set up a rematch of their United States Open final.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Today's New York Times includes a separate section, 1A, on Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. contains news and features of interest to readers these areas and appears in copies distributed in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Clues in Albany Blast
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18Federal and slate investigators were sifting through the debris today for evidence to determine the cause of a blast that ripped through two lavatories and an elevator shaft in the Department of Correction offices here last night.

title: Cramphin Aids Middlebury In 337 Victory Over Bates
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Sept. 18  Former Simsbury, Conn., high school teammates, Phil Pope and Doug Cramphin, helped Middlebury College to a 33.7 victory over Bates today.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED ON MINER DISEASE
description: Miners have long known about the lethal quality of the air they breathed while digging coal from the earth; they recorded their knowledge in song:

title: What Next for the Younger Generation?
description: IS it possible that we're getting practically everything wrong? This generation business, for instance, and the matter of changing tastes. I admit to total confusion after one recent experience in the theater.

title: Forwarding Air Freight
description: A decision earlier this year by the Interstate Commerce Commission is expected to play an important role in helping the airfreightforwarding industry, which has been flying high for the last decade, maintain its lofty sales altitude in the seventies.

title: VA. TECH ROUTED BY WAKE FOREST
NEW ELECTION DATE IS SET IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18 President Alejandro A. Lanusse has announced that Argentina will be returned to civilian con stitutional government on May 25, 1973, following elections on March 25.

title: 2 Soviet Envoys in Eastern Blot Shifted to France and Austria
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18The Soviet Union today announced the appointments of new Ambassadors to France and Austrig in what appeared to be the beginning or a shuffle of top dipiomatic personnel Europe.

title: Reader's Report
description: For one who has thought of the Isle of Lewis with Harris chiefly as a label on tweed Morris L. West's adventure novel is a consciousnessexpander. Poaching smuggling, murder and deep primal passions roil through the deceptively idyllic landscape where crofters still handweave the material for sports jackets.

title: Miss Chapman Wed
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 18The marriage of Miss Michele Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Chapman, to Howard C. Riemann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Riemann of Chicago, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Lutheran Church. The Rev. Bernhard Johnson performed the ceremony.

title: Copper Badge of Shame
description: CONWAY, Ark., Sept. 18 (AP)Four youths have been sentenced to wear copper wire around their wrists for 12 months. That was one of the conditions that Circuit Court Judge Russell C. Roberts imposed in giving oneyear suspended sentences to four youths, age 17 to 20, who pleaded guilty last Tuesday to participating in the theft of about 81.000 worth of copper wire in four counties.

title: Tigers Win, 21, as Lolich Takes 25th
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18 (UPI)Mickey Lolich pitched and batted Detroit to a 21 victory over Baltimore today to chalk up his 25th victory against 11 defeats and moved the Tigers to within five games of the divisionleading Orioles.

title: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title
A.B.A. Pros Cut 2 Rookies
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 18 (AP)The Memphis Pros of the American Basketball Association today trimmed two rookies, Rod Behrens of Samford, a forward and 15thround draft choice, and a center, Larry Duckworth of Arkansas A.M. and N. a free agent, from the roster.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: This book reads like a mystery story. The mystery is why the New York Stock Exchange either failed to understand or deliberately countenanced the weak financial position of so many of its member firms.

title: Reunion in a Gallery: Three Generations of Wyeths
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa.  A sunbleached farm wagon, phased out but not forgotten, stolidly at rest in a field. A solitary figure beside the road wearing bib overalls, not because they are fashionably funky but because his kind have always wornthem. A plain white house against the summer horizon. You are in Wyeth Country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mr. Justin overlooked some of the major savings anticipated from industrialized building while focusing on only one areaonsite labor costs.

title: ISRAEL J. SCHWARTZ
description: Israel J. Schwartz, the author of eight books of Yiddish verse and recipient of several prizes for poetry, died yesterday in Mon tefiore Hospital; the Bronx. He was 86 years old and had lived at the Kittay House, the Bronx.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: As an onagain, offagain, working actor, I convulse with horror at the prospect of picking up a future edition of your newspaper and reading the terrifying and not too improbable bannerhead: Vivian Beaumont DemolishedIrving Exiled to San FranciscoLanglois Constructs Cinema City to be catered by Chock Full O'Nuts.

title: Speed Reading Has Become a Permanent Feature of Education in America
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 9Speed reading, which became something of a national fad after President Kennedy prescribed it for the White House staff a decade ago, is no longer a fad but a solid fixture of American education.

title: AIRBUS PLANNED OVER EAST RIVER
description: Cable cars 200 feet above Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive are planned by the Welare Island Development Corlomtion to provide a fourminute ride between Manhattan and the new town to be built on the island.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Roger Greenspun's review of the entertaining and fastpaced Shaft is patronizing for reasons not made clear in the body of the review. Greenspun's attitude toward Gordon Parks, the film's director, is similarly condescending.

title: Architecture
description: THE John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opened here last week after more than a decade of planning, fundraising, design and construction, and it is a cultural bonanza and monumental disaster.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH an outside basement entrance that is, a direct access entryway from the basement to the yard was once almost standard on older houses, most newer homes (those built in the past 15 or 20 years) for some reason do not include them. Yet, in many ways today's homeowner, needs an outside basement entrance even more than his parents did.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Planning Presidential Bid on Jan. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)  Representative Shirley Chisholm, the only black woman in Congress, says she will announce formally her candidacy for the Presidency on New Year's Day, provided she has enough campaign money.

title: DACCA STILL A CITY OF VANISHING MEN
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Sept. 18 (AP)Despite President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan's announced amnesty for East Pakistani prisoners, Dacca remains a city of missing men.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Add to your list of hashhouse Greek:

title: Education
description: When the City University of New York proclaimed its openadmissions policy a year ago, the program brought mixed reaction. Some students and faculty members saw the program as the beginning of a nightmare leading to reduced academic quality. Others hailed it as a dream of equality come true.

title: Soviet Trawler Seized
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 18 (Reuters)The United States Coast Guard seized a Soviet fishing trawler today 30 miles northeast of the Aleutian Islands. The trawler was reported to have been fishing inside United States territorial waters.

title: SAIGON OPPOSITION STAGES 4 PROTESTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday: Sept. 19AntiGovernment students and opposition politicians protested South Vietnam's forthcoming oneman presidential elections yesterday with the demonstrators hurling stones and gasoline bombs and the police responding with tear gas.

title: Aleksandr A. Prokofiev Dead; Wrote Soviet Patriotic Poems
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (Reuters) The Soviet poet Aleksandr Andreyevich Prokofiev, whose patriotic po:,try and other works won him high official acclaim, died today in Leningrad after a long illness, the official press agency Tass reported. He was 70 years old.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Why not open the subject of hashhouse Greek, described by Dan Carlinsky (Travel section, Sept. 5), to readers who have items to contribute to the list? To start it off, burn the British toasted English muffin. MORTON YARMON New York

title: Elizabeth C. Thacker Married To Van Zandt Hawn, a Lawyer
description: Miss Elizabeth Coverdalo Thacher was married at noon yesterday in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher, in Riverdale, the Bronx, to Van Zandt Hawn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clinton Van Zandt Hawn of Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON Eighty days after draft authority expired, legislation extending the Selective Service System remained stalled in the Senate last week, caught up in a political storm that no one quite anticipated last spring, when the legislation started sailing through Congress.

title: Showers Interrupt Parade To Mark Steuben Day
description: Interrupted briefly by showers, traditionally dressed German Americans in 70 units, marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the 14th annual Steuben Day Parade.

title: Bishop Takes Race In Borrowed Sloop In Larchmont Sail
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 18James Bishop, sailing William E. John Jr.'s International sloop, Donde, and Martin F. Zavell, at the helm of the Rhodes19, Bizarre, were winners on Long Island Sound today in the first regatta of Larchmont Yacht Club's annual fall series for Yacht Racing Association clases, which runs until Columbus Day.

title: Four Sad U.S. Horsemen to See PreOlympic ThreeDay Trials
description: The preOlympic threeday trials in Munich, West Germany, Sept. 23:25, will be a frustrating experience for four spectators.

title: An Expert Gives Pointers On the Art Of Floral Design
description: ANYONE who talks with Dorothy Vietor about flower arranging soon catches her enthusiasm. She is brimful of ideas and bubbles over with artistic verve.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IN his article, Breaking Up the Beaumont: A Moral and Artistic Outrage? Martin Gottfried is, as usual, flogging a dead horse. The Vivian Beaumont Was dead at the moment when the impossible design for the socalled flexible theater was approved for construction. No, it was dead even earlier, at the point when somebody decided that a cultural center ought to invent a repertory theater.

title: Dance
description: So what is new in New York City dance as the old summer ends and the new season starts? Not much. It has been the busiest dance summer in years probably the busiest ever. And now for the first time in about 12 months the pace has slackened off. The City Center Joffrey Ballet doesn't open until Oct. 6, on Oct 17 an AfroAsian Dance Festival is beginning at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and on Nov. 16 we have the return of New York City Ballet.
