Other events in the next few months include the return for a week of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens with their rockballet, Tommy, which opens at the City Center on Tuesday and, also at the City Center, in November, a return engagement of Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century from Belgium.

title: Stamps
description: THERE has never been a stamp exhibition such as that to be staged at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel Nov. 26Dec. 1, when the Aristocrats of Philately are placed on display in a show commemorating the 75th anniversary of the Collectors Club, New York.

title: Carter Nicholas, a Law Student, Marries Miss Eleanor M. Moore
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Mess Eleanor Montgomery Moore, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Alanson Moore of New York, was married to Carter Nicholas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond Nicholas of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. Victor Baer performed the ceremony.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Let me add my four other favorite books on Greece to Henry Miller's The Colossus of Maroussi cited by William H. Honan in his article about Greece (Travel section, Aug. 29):

title: Butler Chases Thief From Look Publisher's Home
description: A burglar was chased from the home of Gardner Cowles, the publisher, in Newcastle, N. Y., Friday night by a butler wielding a hickory cane. The butler had found the intruder rummaginng through the master bedroom while the family was downstairs, the police reported.

title: Joanne Connors Becomes Bride Of Jay Kriegel
description: SUGAR HILL, N.H., Sept. 18 Mayor Lindsay of New York and Mrs. Lindsay were among the guests here this afternoon at the wedding of Miss Joanne Connors to Jay Lawrence Kriegel, special counsel to the Mayor. Miss Connors is a former administrative assistant in the Lindsay administration's Budget Bureau.

title: Brooklyn Cricket Club Wins
description: The Brooklyn Cricket Club beat Staten Island C,C.by six wickets in a league match today at Walker Park, Staten Island, scored 116, Brooklyn 117 for 4.

title: Coast Guard's Late Surge Overcomes R.P.L, 2827
description: TROY, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP) Paul Howard's four scoring passes in the last quarter carried the Coast Guard Academy to a 2827 uphill victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Insti tute today.

title: Memoirs of ah exert Fox, My Kingdom for a Coke
description: THE one thing I have in common with the late Nazi Field Marshal, Erwin Rommel is a passion for deserts. Of course, he thought deserts were an absolutely swinging place in which to maneuver tanks and infantry whereas my feeling for them is inspired by the fact that I believe that deserts possess a magic unsurpassed by any other natural environment. So you can see that, actually, if we two Desert Foxes had ever met, after the first exchange a few words, we would have had very little to say to each other.

title: For Very Young Readers: Six Picture Books
description: In certain picture books for the very young, not only the print but the purpose is writ large. Like neon lights on old Broadway, a worthwhile message flashes intermittently over and above the ostensible story line. Yet, while responsible parents may give points for noble lessons neatly encased in palatable if not perfect tales, children are unlikely to be influenced in the least by what is patently good for them.

title: Mastropieri Proves Right Weapon in Troy's Battle to Forge Leadership
description: When Matthew J. Troy Jr. fashioned the coalition of working politicians who chose him as Democratic leader of Queens, he knew he had to prove promptly that he was a leader. The main weapon in his effort was an unassuming but personable 34yearold lawyer who turned out, on testing, to be a diligent and effective street campaigner. This weekend the lawyer, Eugene F. Mastropieri, winner of the boroughwide Democratic primary for a Councilman at Large vacancy, stayed home processing dozens of constituent requests for help. And Mr. Troy had his first big victory.

title: I'm Doing All Right, I'm Never Good Enough, But I'm Not Standing Still'
description: PLANIST Andre Watts's new suit pearlgray gabardine that includes a vestis beautifully cut to fit a slightly larger man. His tie is narrow and subdued; his eyes, behind blackrimmed spectacles, alert and anxious. He stands in the fusty, mockFlorentine foyer of his coop on West 57th Street; while waiting for his mother to descend, he extracts a cigarNicaraguangrown from Havana seedfrom a case bearing gold initials, applies it to a gold cutter but doesn't light it.

title: Beowulf from the monster's viewpoint
description: The Beowulf legend retold from Grendel's point of view. That one sentence treatment of Grendel suggests some unsustainable satire, valid for perhaps three pages of a collegehumor magazine. But John Gardner's Grendel is myth itself: permeated with revelation, with dark instincts, with swimming, riotous universals. The special profundity of Gardner's vision or visions is so thoughtfertile that it shunts even his fine poet's prose to a second importance. As is often the case with profundity, Gardner's brand is consistently unpleasantexcept in its sturdy, structured, inevitable working out. But unpleasantness is a characteristic of myth. Grendel is another fierce blow struck against the realistic novel, the dead novel. Good, I say: let's hold no more mirrors up to nature. Make nature approach the artist; make nature grovel. Gardner The damn it.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:In his review of Bruce Cook's The Beat Generation, Thomas Parkinson states that he (Parkinson) was compiling the first anthology of the Beats in 1960. Mr. Parkinson is in error.

title: Delbanco, 29, on Delbanco, 48
description: Few American novelists under 30 have written novels worth reading twice. Nicholas Delbanco, however, with In the Middle Distance, his fifth novel in six years, has produced a bold and moving book whose pleasures and complexities will draw serious readers time and time again to its dense pages. Anyone in this category who reads it will be convinced that his is a name to conjure with in modern fiction.

title: The World
description: MEXICO CITYIt is 150 years since the five tiny republics of Central America  Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Costa Ricabecame independent of Spain, and they celebrated the occasion last week in a mood of political uncertainty and economic confusion. The countries have geography, history and language in common, but political divisions among them prevented a planned gathering of the five Presidents for toasts and backslapping.

title: 5 Rogues in Yank Clubhouse Picture
description: They wear twodigit numbers on their uniforms and work at Yankee Stadium, but to hear them talk about each other, one would hardly assume that they were teammates.

title: Peace Post Loses Charter
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 18 (UPI)The national charter of the controversial Veterans of Foreign Wars peace post has been lifted. The post, which was placed on probation in June for failing to go along with the national V.F..'s victory in Vietnam resolut:on, Was ordered to give up its charter.

title: 8OAR SHELL UPSET IN REROW OF RACE
description: The United States Coast Guard Academy made rowing history of a sort yesterday in the Elite eightoared crew race during the Metropolitan championships on the Orchard Beach Lagoon. The cadets boat overturned in the third attempt to complete the race.

title: KENNEDY REGAINS GALLUP POLL LEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18Senator Edward M. Kennedy regained the lead today in the Gallup poll's survey on the preference of Democratic voters for their party's 1972 Presidential nominee.

title: SEAGULL IS CALLED A POLLUTION GAUGE
description: STANDISH, Me., Sept. 18 (AP)A Maine naturalist says that the common seagull is good barometer of pollution.

title: Job Testing Comes Under Fire
description: An applicant to the apprenticeship program of a local steamfitters union un dergoes a battery of four tests to qualify. On one of them, he is called on to answer questions, such as the relationship between Shakespeare and Othello, Dante and the Inferno and Walt Whitman and poetry.

title: Jan Stenerud Is No Football Player But He Wins Foot all Games
description: REGARDLESS of where they met, practiced or sweated at their training camp the other afternoon, the Kansas City Chiefs had a persistent visitor: Jan Stenerud, a tall, blondhaired man who resembles Danny Kaye with the meter rolled back 30 years. Trying to act like an integral part of the team, he dutifully carried his playbook into the strategy meeting. But, having never played football, he goodnaturedly conceded that it was difficult for him to understand even a few of the Chiefs 150 plays. When it came time for the team to maneuver through the obstacle course, he ran as spiritedly as anyone. Yet his efforts only moved one of the team's ugliest players, feigning prayer, to jest: God help us if he has to carry the ball. Undaunted, he mingled enthusiastically with the pass receivers. But the number of balls that bounced off Stenerud's body demonstrated that nobody will ever throw to him in a real game.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WATSHISHOU LAKE, QuebecAt dusk the cry of a loon rose above the sound of rushing water, and a hardwood cooking fire flickered brightly before the main cabin.

title: BACKLOG IS HUGE IN PHONE STRIKE
description: Six thousand uninstalled telephones a day, adding up to a backlog of 200,000 unfilled orders, represent the main result of the twomonth statewide strike against the New York Telephone Company by installers, linemen, repairmen and maintenance employes,

title: Miss. State Wins, 1310
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 18 (AP)  Glen Ellis kicked a 35yard field goal in the fourth quarter tonight to give Mississippi State a 1310 Southeastern Conference victory over Florida.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: Brandt Stresses Allied Ties
description: BONN, Sept. 18In a homecoming statement at Bonn Airport today Chancellor Brandt stressed that the Crimean talks had been conducted with complete loyalty to the respective alliance partners on both sides.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article, Postal Service: No Easy Road (Sept. 12) conveys the unwelcome probability of even higher postal rates that are almost certain to be sought next year. Is it not paradoxical that nothing was mentioned concerning the measure of progress, if any, by the new entity toward faster delivery schedules?

title: Hillcrest High School Stressing Innovation
description: On a map of Queens, the controversial new Hillcrest High School on Parsons Boulevard, a block north of Hillside Avenue, occupies a position near the center of the borough.

title: Aussies CoWinners at Net
description: BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 18 (AP)Bob Carmichael and Ray Ruffels of Australia were designated cowinners of the Mount Washington Hotel invitation tennis tournament today after rain forced cancellation of the championship match. Carmichael and Ruffels were to have competed for the title. Each received $1,500, dividing the $3,000 in prize money.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Walter Kerr wrote junk about theater in, the streets. The truth of that Festival of Street Theater which has just packed its psychedelic scenery away from the fountain plaza at Lincoln Center is in the poster one of the players held up for an avid camera: Legalize pot.

title: V.M.I. 273 Victor
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Sept. 18 (UPI)Mac Bowman scored two touchdowns and Mike Cole booted a pair of field goals today as Virginia Military Institute broke a 10game losing streak with a 27.3 victory over Davidson.

title: Soviet Dissidents Appeal in Film Smuggled to West
description: LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP)The defiant face of an old woman looks at the audience from a blurred and amateurish protest film smuggled out of the Soviet Union.

title: India Curbs Border Visits By Foreign Correspondents
description: CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 19 The Indian Government is restricting the movements of foreign correspondents attempting to visit camps for East Pakistani refugees and the border areas in West Bengal and eastern India.

title: Art
description: THE exhibition called Art in Revolution, which is now installed at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, is still another attempt to document the achievements of the Soviet avantgarde in the early years of the Russian Revolution. This particular chapter in the history of modern art, no doubt because it represents a heroic effort to enlist the most radical esthetic innovations of the modern movement in the service of a new Revolutionary regime, is currently the subject of intense interest both in the West, where research is openly pursued and exhibitions organized at an accelerating pace, and in the Soviet Union, where research is necessarily more covert and exhibitions absolutely forbidden. Wherever the relation of modernist visual esthetics to radical political ideology is being seriously, pondered today, the Soviet experiment (as it was once hopefully called) has acquired a special significance, and its accomplishments are now being revived and reevaluated on a scale unknown since the twenties.

title: The Corporate Conscience
description: The Xerox Corporation, by inaugurating a program that will grant employes extended leaves at full pay to allow them to engage in social action programs, has opened a new chapter for the corporate role in modern society. Though anathema to conservative economists, who see efficient production with a view to maximum profits as a corporation's only legitimate function, the Xerox viewpoint is entirely in tune with the emerging legal interpretation of the corporate conscience.

title: Stafford Is Favored in Vermont To Win 5Year Term in Senate
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept 18On Thursday, Gov. Deane C. Davis, a Republican, named Representative Robert I. Stafford to the Senate seat that had been held by Senator Winston L. Prouty, who died on Sept. 10.

title: Cortland Tops Springfield In Final 13 Seconds, 1412
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 18Cortland State scored with 13 seconds remaining today to top Springfield College, 1412.

title: Cars Called Youths Biggest Peril
description: For young motorists, the automobile, either when they are driving it or riding in it with other young drivers, has become the greatest hazard to survival which American youths must pass successfully to reach adulthood, a new Federal study concludes,

title: CHURCH IN SPAIN FACES NEW CRISIS
description: MADRID, Sept. 18An incident in which the police forced their way into a Madrid church this week is threatening a new crisis in churchstate relations, already strained by the continuing sessions of a national assembly of bishops and priests.

title: VIETCONG AMBUSH GOVERNMENT UNIT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Sept. 19 (AP)Govarnment troops fell into a Vietcong ambush north of Saigon and lost more than half of their 75man force, military spokesmen said yesterday. Three American advisers also were reported killed and one wounded.

title: Canadian WaterSki Victor
description: BANALOS, Spain, Sept. 18 (Canadian Press)  George Athans, of Kelowna, British Columbia, won the overall world water ski championship today, becoming the first Canadian to take the event. Athans placed fifth in slalom, second in tricks and while his position in jumping was not known, 153foot jump put him well ahead of other contenders for the overall crown.

title: ALABAMA TROUNCES SO. MISS. BY 426
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Sept. 18 (AP)Johnny Musso and Terry Davis led Alabama to a 426 football victory today over outmanned Southern Mississippi to give the Crimson Tide's coach, Paul (Bear) Bryant, his 201st triumph.

title: Business in Rumania
description: BUCHARESTA Rumanian law encouraging foreign companies to join national enterprise in setting up joint ventures has encouraged more than a dozen American, British and German companies to begin negotiations.

title: Marine Band Instruments Stolen, Then Recovered
description: A rented truck containing United States Marine band instruments and uniforms valued at $100,000 was stolen at A.M. yesterday from a motel parking lot at the intersection of Routes 1 and 9 outside Woodbridge, N. J.

title: A Museum Built on 5,000 Cans Of Beer
description: HICKSVILLE, LI., Sept. 11  Joseph Veselsky has one solution to the problem of what to do with old beer cans. He saves them.

title: Moore's Resolute Sails To Victory at Cow Bay
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 18James B. Moore's Allure led eight Resolute Class sloops to the finish today as 51 boats sailed with the Knickerbocker Yact Club in the Cow Bay area Yacht Racing Association of Long Island competition:

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Where did the Nixon Rally go?

title: Foreign Notes
description: Irish Drama The Government's internment policy has been one of the most sensitive issues behind the violence in Northern Ireland. Under the policy. the Government rounded up 337 men in predawn raids five weeks ago and held them without trial.

title: Kansas Defense Excels In Defeat of Baylor, 220
description: LAWRENCE, Kan. Sept. 18 (AP)A brilliant Kansas defense paved the way for all of the, scoring today as the Jayhawks thrashed Baylor, 220, in an intersectional football game played in a cold drizzle.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18Bobby Riggs of Plandome, N.Y., defeated Lenhart Bergelin of Stockholm, 16, 76, 63 today and gained the final round in the 45yearsandover division of the national senior grasscourt tennis championship.

title: The Nation
Alfred Downs Brockport As Tierney Scores 2, 277
description: BROCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 18  Alfred University defeated Brockport State, 277, today for the 140th victory of the 31year coaching career of Alex Yunevich. Steve Tierney scored two Alfred touchdowns on runs of 17 and 1 yard.

title: Toledo Edges Villanova, 107, on Keim's Fields Goal With 12 Seconds Left
For A Black Vice President In 1972
description: IT is next summer and the Democratic party has just nominated on the third ballot Edmund Sixtus Muskie as its candidate for the Presidency of the United States. In one of the Godawful hotels along Collins Avenuein Miami Beach, Muskie and his advisers are agonizing over the question of the VicePresidency. If it looks as if there is a possibility of a fourth party, made up of dissident leftwing Democrats, Muskie will have to secure his left flank and the VicePresidential candidate must be someone who will appeal to the liberals, the young, and the blacksSenator Tunney or Senator Stevenson, or, just possibly, Mayor Lindsay. If, on the other hand, the left flank seems reasonably safe, the obvious thing for candidate Muskie to do is to follow the 1960 strategy of John Kennedy and seek out a presentably liberal Southerner, such as Georgia's Jimmy Carter. Thus, a year before the event, it appears that the VicePresidential nominee will be either young Northerner or a liberal South

title: TOUGH DEFENSE WINS FOR IOWA STATE, 247
description: AMES, Iowa, Sept. 18 (AP)A revamped Iowa State defense held Idaho to 129 yards total offense today and fired the Cyclones to a 247 opening football victory.

title: INSPECTIONS CLOSE CAPITAL FOOD SITES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18District of Columbia health and licensing officials have closed a dozen food establishments this month as continuing scrutiny is placed on restaurant sanitary inspection procedures here.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: Beaty Quits A.B.A Post
description: DENVER, Sept. 18 (UPI)Zelmo Beaty of the Utah Stars, who has headed the American Basketball Association Players Association, announced his resignation from that position today. Beaty, elected to the presidency in Houston, said he did not believe he could devote the necessary time to the office.

title: Flying Shuttle Ferries Commuters in Florida
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)A flying Shuttle service designed to aid Florida's commuters has begun lifting passengers between Tampa and St. Petersburg on a 10minute flight that costs $5.

title: Prisons Feel a Mood of Protest
description: A movement paralleling those that have arisen in recent years among blacks, students and women has now begun to emerge in the nation's prisons.

title: Montclair State Rallies To Defeat Kutztown, 2520
description: KUTZTOWN, Pa., Sept. 18 Trailing by 143 at halftime, Montclair State fought back with three touchdowns to down Kutztown State today, 2520.

title: Flag Pants Bring Probation
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 18 (UPI) Mrs. Sandra Sizemore of Cleveland has been placed on probation for one year for displaying the flag contemptuously, to wit, on the seat of her pants. She pleaded guilty to the charge last Wednesday, was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $1,000. But Judge George Pillersdorf of Municipal Court suspended both sentences.

title: End of Summer
description: This is the week of the autumn equinox. By midday this coming Thursday summer will be at an end, according to the almanac. Already the hours of daylight and darkness are nearly equal and the sun rises almost due east. But the precise moment, even the day itself, is unimportant, only a matter of mathematics relating to the orbit and inclination of the earth. Summer merges with autumn so subtly that no one can say, Now! Now the leaf will turn, the frost will come.

title: TRANSFER OF EXPERT ON INDIANS DELAYED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. I8The transfer out of Washington of William H. Veeder, an authority on Indian land and water rights, has been suspended by the Department of the Interior pending a review of his case.

title: The Nation
description: Long hours of listening to the contradictory ideas of labor, industry and farmers on how to hold wages and prices in check after the freeze led President Nixon last week to the reluctant conclusion that a strong element of Federal compulsion would be needed to keep the inflationary spiral from zooming off into the stratosphere again after Nov. 13.

title: Chicano College Head Foresees An Activist Role in New Mexico
description: LAS VEGAS, N. M., Sept. 18 Frank Angel Jr., president of New Mexico Highlands University, was sitting on his desk with his feet dangling above, the floor.

title: Wool Faces Fuzzy Future
description: Wool as a textile fiber faces a fuzzy future. Its prospects have been complicated by the surcharge on imports, which has come on top of a price freeze and drastically lowered consumption in the United States.

title: Survey Finds Some Fail To Collect Small Claim's
description: As many as 33 per cent of consumers who win cases in Small Claims Court here cannot collect the money they win, a survey prepared for the eity's Department of Consumer Affairs has indicated.

title: UTAH STATE ROUTS NEW MEXICO STATE
description: LOGAN, Utah, Sept. 18 (AP) Utah State used an opportunistic defense and shrewd quarterbacking by Tony Adams and Mickey Doyle to whip New Mexico State, 340, in battle of western independent teams today.

title: Ski People
description: 1 Chinesered nylon ski jacket fronts four patch pockets, a twoway zipper. Belted and Mylarlined, it's by Head Ski and Sportswear. $91 at Bloomingdale's... Waistlength jacket of cir nylon has contraststriped quilted side panels. Snapclosure and concealed zipper; flapped seethrough chest pocket, two lower zippered pockets. By Aspen Skiwear. $40. Macy's. Hat: C & B Sportswear... Red stitching zestfully trims the chest and lower angled zippered pockets of Van HeusenWindbreaker's navy nylon parka, lined with quilted Fortrel. The zipfronted coat has elasticized sleeve cuffs. $25 at Abraham & Straus. Warmup pants, zippered and striped at the sides, snapped and elasticized at waist, $22... Quilted patches reach from chest to shoulder on a snapcovered, zipfronted nylon cir jacket which has a standup collar, doublesnapped lower pockets. Polyester filled, it's $32. The crazyquiltpatterned warmup pants, lined with urethane foam bonded to nylon tricot, are $25. Jacket and pants, by White Stag, at Herman's.

title: A Breed That Came Up the Hard Way
description: The Staffordshire bull terrier is a somewhat squat, muscular, smoothcoated dog. He should resemble a square solid block of concrete. His ancestors are believed to be the bulldog and English terrier and he was known as the Pit Dog or Pit Bull Terrier. Our breed was made famous in literature by the infamous Bill Sikes in Oliver Twist, said William R. Daniels, president of the Staffordshire Bull Terrier Club of the United States of America. Sikes's dog was said to have been a Stafford.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Early in the century, a young man who worked in a shoe store had a dream. His dream was in prosaic black and white because those were the colors of Dun & Bradstreet. The young man wanted a credit rating that would show the world he was good for $25,000.

title: Most of 1976 Bicentennial Fair to Be Held in New Jersey
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 17Virtually all of the 1976 bicentennial World's Fair will be held in New Jersey rather than Philadelphia, the original site designated by President Nixon.

title: Medicine
description: DETROITHaskell Shanks is the only man in the world with two hearts beating inside his chestone, his natural heart, battered by several heart attacks, a scarred wreck barely able to keep blood coursing through his body; the other, an auxiliary heart, a white plastic airdriven pump that does almost as much work as the heart he has had since birth.

title: Canadian Newspapers Oppose a Ban on Cigarette Ads, Ask Regulation Instead
description: TORONTO, Sept. 18  The Canadian Daily Newspaper Publishers Association has proposed that the Government regulate cigarette advertising instead of prohibiting it.

title: National Notes
description: By the beginning of last week, the weather had been so bad for so long that one New York City official thought it was time to dry off an old joke: It was, he said, a typically rainy Monday.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: It is a favorite maxim of many executivesand all entrepreneursthat, The greater the risk, the greater the reward. Yet, one rarely hears anyone reciting the reverse: The less the risk, the less the reward. We don't like to think negative thoughts, but, nevertheless, this maxim is as real as the first.

title: L.S.U. Triumphs, 37 to 0
description: BATON ROUGE, Sept. 18 (AP)Louisiana State, relying on its defense, subdued Texas A. and M. 370, tonight.

title: Butler, Ala., Gains A Biracial Accord; Abernathy Freed
description: BUTLER, Ala., Sept. 18 (AP)Black and white leaders reached a compromise agreement today in an effort to solve racial differences in this rural Alabama county.

title: OKLAHOMA VICTOR OVER S.M.U., 300
Oberlin, Ohio, Imposes Penalty, For Nonreturnable Containers
description: OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 18As of Jan. 1, 1972, Oberlin will impose a ban on the sale or possession of nonreturnable soft drink and beer containers and provide penalties for, violators.

title: Late Drive, Paced by Woodruff, Earns 2020 Deadlock
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 18  Bob Woodruff punctured the theory that Coach Ben Schwartzwalder doesn't develop sound quarterbacks at Syracuse Universty when he put the finishing touches on a fine individual performance with a 12yard touchdown pass that tied Wisconsin, 2020, in the closing seconds of play today.

title: The Safari Suedes
description: 1 Suede safari suit whose belt runs through the deep loops joining the upper and lower pockets. Woodenbuttoned coat has epaulettes; jeanstyled slacks are flared. By Robert Lewis. $180 at Gimbels N.Y.

title: JOSEPH L. PICKLES
description: Joseph L. Rickles, president of the SanfordHall Corporation, carpet and rug suppliers to the decorating industry died yesterday at his home at 22 West 77th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: the traveler's world
description: IN the AliceinWonderland world of Washington, especially in those solemn quarters dealing with travel and transportation, history instead of repeating itself whips around continuously in smaller and smaller circles like a tailswallowing snake. A new gyration has just been added to the whirl in which the Civil Aeronautics Board, the Department of Transportation and the Department of Justice spin their respective mental wheels, the new crisis being the proposed merger of National Airlines and Northwest Orient Airlines.

title: The Last Word: The Late George Jackson
description: On Saturday, Aug. 21, George Jackson was shot and killed by a San Quentin prison guard as he allegedly attempted to escape. His death, the deaths of two other prisoners and three guards, and the bizarre circumstances that characterized the violence have given rise to numerous questions. Some will be answered at official hearings and at the trial of John Clutchette and Fleeta Drumgo, the two remaining Soledad brothers. But others, those concerning Jackson himself, are perhaps best answered by turning back to his bestselling book, Soledad Brother.

title: The Nation
description: The meeting in London ended In a stalemate. A communique on Thursday said only that the participantsthe finance ministers and central bankers. of the Group of 10, the most affluent non Communist nations  had agreed that ending the monthold international financial crisis that has embittered relations between the United States and its trading partners would require a substantial adjustment. It said this would mean an appropriate realignment of currencies.

title: Coins
description: A SILVER coin of 10lirot denomination will be issued early next month by the Bank of Israel, It was announced last week by Rafael Aldor, Director of the Israel Government Coins and Medals Department here.

title: Wall Street's Super Bear
description: Wall Street always has its pessimists predicting doom for the stock market, but few have ever been as bearish as Thomas J. Holt, publisher of, The Holt Investment Advisory.

title: Pro Football Luncheons Resume Here Thursday
description: The weekly pro football luncheons, featuring scouting reports and gameoftheweek films in color, will resume Thursday at Kenny's Steak Pub, Lexington Avenue at 50th Street.

title: COUNCIL TO STUDY 2 CITY AGENCIES
description: A major investigation of the :city's housing and investigations departmentsprompted primarily by disclosures of scandals In the multimilliondollar municipal loan program Was announced yesterday by leaders of the City Council.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I was pleased to see the article on the Lardners in the Magazine. But I feel you have ignored and done injustice to other members of the family: Rex Lardner Sr. (a brother of Ring Sr.), who was the editor of Liberty magazine; his son Rex Jr., who wrote for The New Yorker and has written sports stories and books; George E. Lardner Sr. (my husband and a nephew of Ring Sr.), who was the editor for BellMcClure Syndicate and the author of a book on golf, and my son, George E. Lardner Jr., who is a reporter for The Washington Post.

title: National Notes
description: The Red Baron strikes again. Lufthansa, the West German airline, last week apparently scuttled an agreement, only recently arrived at by the 25 scheduled airlines that fly the North Atlantic, aimed at combatting aggressive nonscheduled charter lines on the same routes.

title: Reader's Report
description: You could look a long time before finding a more total nebbish than Ernie Buddusky the hero of Darryl Ponicsan's second novel. (His previous book was The Last Detail.) Ernie is a high school English teacher with a terminal case of angst. Everything about him spells loser. His students are barbaric, his wife is unresponsive. Even his dog is stupid. Following the path of least resistance into an affair with a frigid math instructor (their tryst is in a bowling alley), Ernie also contracts syphilis.

title: GEORGIA BEATS TIRANE BY 177
Arcaro Is Race Victor As Owner Not Rider
description: Eddie Arcaro's debut as a horse owner produced a victory yesterday at Belmont Park. In a stirring fourhorse, photo finish, Braulio Baeza brought Scotch Thorn home by a nose a $9,40 payoff in the eighth race.

title: Reader's Report
description: Imagine if you will a cattle drive in the year 1877  over legendary cowboysandIndians country, from the Montana to the Dakota Territory. Chief Joseph and his Nez Perces are on the rampage and the plains are thick with bad guys. Now imagine that the cowboys are really boys, a dozen kids from 13 to 15 signed on by a crusty ramrod at the DoubleO when his own cowhands up and quit to go prospecting. Can you see the old chuck wagon... songs around the campfire... boys reaching sudden manhood.. hot lead and cold steel... fancy women and plain grub... rustlers... John Wayne... Warner Brothers?

title: SUSPECT IN HOLDUP SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: A grocery store owner in Brooklyn snatched a revolver from one of two holdup men and shot him fatally before the second holdup man grabbed the gun back and shot the store owner, the police reported last night.

title: The Rangers at Kitchener: Where the Young Players Put Their Dreams on ice
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 19Young hockey players work and sweat and hit with the same ferocity as young football players trying to win their place on a pro team.

title: Letters:
description: In the Aug. 8 Travel sec, Non a letter from Mrs. Claire Friedman suggested the formation of a travel organization that would enable parents and grandparents with families on the West Coast to fly out there at special rates. Many readers have written to Mrs. Friedman and to the Travel Editor expressing. support for her proposal. Mrs. Friedman is mailing reply to each of her correspondents.

title: The World
description: TEL AVIVBathers on Tel Aviv's Mediterranean beaches one recent Sunday could see a lone jet aircraft circling overhead. It looked like a Mirage3, a Frenchbuilt fighterbomber, and, since Israel has nearly 50 Mirages, the plane did not stir much curiosity.

title: Realism on China
description: President Nixon's decision to favor the immediate seating of Peking in the United Nations Security Council, as well as in the General Assembly, stems paradoxically from the effort to win majority support for retaining Taipei's seat in the Assembly. The Security Council move, which was urged by most supporters of the American dual representation formula, gives Taipei at best a 5050 chance of remaining in the United Nations. Without it, all evidence indicated that the uphill struggle on Taipei's behalf would fail.

title: Et A1.
description: The story of Eli Cohen, the Israeli spy who was captured and hanged in Syria in 1965. The authors trace Cohen's career from Egypt, where he grew up and became a Zionist, through his undercover activities for Israel and last assignment in Syria. Cohen managed to work his way into the top echelons of the Arab Baath Socialist Party and was slated to be made defense minister when he was apprehended. This is a fine job of reconstructing a remarkable career in the silent service.

title: Delaware Wins, 397
description: NEWARK, Del., Sept.18 (AP) A sophomore halfback, Glen Covin, lead Delaware's offense today, rushing for 104 yards in 13 carries,, as the Blue liens trounced Gettysburg, 397.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: An estimated $3.3billion in new or increased state taxes has been approved in 27 states so far this year, according to a survey by the Tax Foundation, Inc.

title: O'Hora and Brazill Take Shields Title With 28 Points
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18 Joseph F. O'Hora and Dr. George K. Brazill Jr. of Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club, the coskippers of Double Dare, won the seventh annual Shields Class national championship today by placing second in the fifth and final race of the threeday regatta sailed on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Y. C.

title: Claridge, $12.60 Winner
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 18Claridge, owned by D. H. Wallach of Philadelphia, scored a mild upset in the $10,000 Ridgewood Pace at Freehold Raceway today. Driven by Clarles Greedn and timed in 12:01.3, Claridge held off Ark Time by a nose with Harold Kelly at the reins. Claridge Paid $12.60, $5.60, $3.60; Ark Time, $4.60, $2.80 and Bewitched, finishing third, $3.

title: Laird, in Budget Appeal, Cites Big Military BuildUp by Soviet
description: WARRENTON, Va., Sept. 18 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warned today that the momentum of the Soviet defense buildup had exceeded our anticipations. He appealed for draft legislation and full acceptance of an $80billion defense budget.

title: ROCKINGHAM SPRINT TO GREAT MYSTERY
description: SALEM, N. H., Sept. 18 (AP) The favored Great Mystery outraced Lion Sleeps in an early speed duel today and then coasted to an easy victory in the $10,000 Rockingham Park Handicap.

title: GOV, NUNN SCORES MINE SAFETY ACT
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18Pressure is increasing for changes in the 1969 Coal Mine Health and Safety Act, with operators of small mines working hard for change and Government officials indicating that they may be listening.

title: The Nation
description: Over the centuries the strange structures and their strange or commonplace names arise, disappear on the human landscape: Maison de Force, Bastille, Devils Island, Sing Sing, Attica. But on the Yard the topic is interminably the same: Where have you done time? How much time? No other subject so deeply engages men in confinement, not even the trauma of physical confinement itself. Prisoners have survived or transcended every other pain of imprisonment. No man can overcome his time.

title: Dartmouth About to Lose Dominance in Ivy League
description: Unpredictability has been the long suit of Ivy League football, and this season as the Ivies begin the 15th year of roundrobin play, the key word seems to be confusion.

title: Photography
description: A COURSE in child photography will be conducted by Josef Schneider at his studio at 119 West 57th Street. An organizational meeting preparatory to setting up the course will be held at the studio on Tuesday evening at 7 P.M. for those that are interested. The fee will be $95, and the phone number for more details is (212) CO 51223.

title: Space
description: BYURAKAN, U.S.S.R.For centuries men have speculated about the possibility of life on other worlds. Now the possibility of discovering and indeed communicating with such worlds has become sufficiently real for a group of this planet's leading thinkers, some of them Nobel laureates, to have assembled this month on a remote hilltop here in Soviet Armenia to discuss the matter.

title: Elected Officials Win Role
description: KARACHI, Sept. 18President Yahya Khan announced tonight that he planned to allow popularly elected officials some role in framing a new constitution. But he said that he would retain absolute veto power on proposals for the charter and that, in effect, elected officials would have only an advisory role in preparing it.

title: Drake Triumphs, 3417
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 18 (UPI)  Drake scored for 31 points in the second half to defeat Abilene Christian, 3417, today.

title: Windjammer Runs 6th
PHILADELPHIA AGE RETIRES 32 IN ROW
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP)Rick Wise set down 32 consecutive batters and singled, in Philadelphia's winning run in the 12th inning as the Phillies edged the Chicago Cubs, 43, today.

title: Five in Morocco Doomed For Plot Against Hassan
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Sept. 18 (Reuters)  Five persons were sentenced to death, three of them in absentia, and six imprisoned for life yesterday for plotting the overthrow of King Hassan II.

title: ZAMBIANS AGREE TO GAME REFUGE
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 18 President Kenneth Kaunda and a conservation organization headed by a former Portland, Ore., lumberman, A. H. Stange, have signed an agreement to establish a 2,400 squaremile wildlife refuge in this centralAfrican republic.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: In Europefirstclass, reserved accommodations notwithstandingtravel on railroad and ship has been made unbearable by the hippie invasion. They are like locusts, strewing litter and bad manners everywhere, cluttering up aisles of trains, lying over the decks of ships. What are the executives of the airlines thinking about? If one intends to improve the economy of Europe through tourism, give the reduced air rates to the over30's who spend the money in hotels and restaurants. The hippies sleep in the aisles, on the decks, in the forests, and buy sandwiches at the grocery.

title: Art
description: PUBLIC and private funding for the arts, as no one should need to be reminded, boomed in the sixties. Spurred by such factors as the prestigehunger of affluencebred new collectors and philanthropists and the sort of instant Augustanism of the Kennedys, checkbooks were opened for art projects and institutions, and often even for artists, as never before. No more striking legacy of this era, now rapidly on the wane, remains to us than Westbeth, the huge former New York Telephone building in the West Village converted into relatively inexpensive artists housing and opened

title: Reds Win in 11th, 32
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)George Culver's wild pitch enabled the winning run to cross home with two outs in the 11th inning today as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Houston Astros, 32. Woody Woodward, who had opened the 11th with a single, scored the winning run when Culver's pitch bounced in the dirt, and off catcher Larry Howard's glove, back to the screen. Woodward had advanced to second on a passed ball and to third on a sacrifice by a pitchhitter, Jim Merritt.

title: U. S. Urges Restraint
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The United States urged Egypt and Israel today to refrain from resuming hostilities.

title: Chess
Letter
description: To the Editor:Commenting on Richard Grunberger's book The 12year Reich, Terence Prittie fails to mention some interesting statistics offered by the author.

title: ALLEGED MAFIOSO FOUND MURDERED
Miss Cornwall Bride of Thomas Miner
description: POUGHQUAG, N. Y., Sept. 18  The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Stuart Cornwall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clift Cornwall of Short Hills, N. J., to Thomas Hopkinson Miner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Miner of Riverside, Conn., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Andrew Fiddler performed the Episcopal ceremony at the bride's home.

title: GILLIGAN'S ISLAND NAMED BEST DOG
description: EMMAUS, Pa., Sept. 18Rain or shine, Cr. Lakeside's Gilligan's Island, a German shepherd owned by Danny Dwier of Kresson, N.J., keeps right on the winning trail.

title: Nixon Tries for Two
description: The big issue to be considered in the United Nations session opening Tuesday is the China question. And the outcome is likely to turn on United States action.

title: Police Chiefs'
description: BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Sept. 18 (AP)G. Robert Triano of Southington, Conn., has been elected president of the New England Association of Police Chiefs. Mr. Triano was chosen at the group's 46th annual convention Tuesday. He succeeds Robert Wagner Jr. of Bath, Me.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Would the latest Disney production, $1,000,000 Duck be tiresome, silly stuff"? That question confronted Howard Thompson, about to view the latest from Disneyville. HIS answer, no. It was a movie that spins along so easily and breezily, according to Thompson.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I have read Aaron Latham's article, The Lardners: A Writing Dynasty (Aug. 22).

title: Article 5  No Title
description: EDISON, N.J., Sept. 18Two long scoring runs by a halfback, John Kimmel, paced Newark Academy to a 306 victory over Wardlaw School today.

title: Perils of Force
description: The backgrounds to the tragedies at Attica prison and Kent State University could not have been more dissimilar. Nevertheless, in those vastly different episodes there is one common factor: the inappropriate and blindly destructive use of force that turns law enforcement into murder, no matter how inadvertent and even abhorrent to those who commit it.

title: A.B.A. to Study Restrictions Put on Hiring of ExInmates
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP)The American Bar Association has been awarded an $185,440 contract from the Manpower Administration of the United States Department of Labor to establish a national clearinghouse on the problem of jobs for rehabilitated prisoners.

title: AROUND THE
description: NOT FROZEN If the prices went up, on nursery stock at the local garden center, don't call the sheriff. Price hikes are legal on garden plants and cut flowers in spite of the recent wageprice freeze. The American Association of Nurserymen reports from its Washington headquarters that it has obtained formal information from the Cost of Living Council that all garden plants are exempt from the price freeze as raw agricultural products. The ruling also includes seeds and bulbs.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferry Becomes Community Center for TeenAgers
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Sept. 18 (AP)  For $1  plus $200,000 in Federal funds this city has turned a ferryboat into a community center for teenagers.

title: Autos Back From the Brink
description: DETROIT  Someone up there must like automobiles.Just a few weeks ago the industry seemed to be lumbering toward disaster. Sales of Americanmade cars weren't particularly impressive.

title: Jeffrey Rogers Weds Kristine Olson
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Sept. 18Secretary of State William P. Rogers was best man this afternoon at the wedding of his son, Jeffrey Langston Rogers, to Miss Kristine Arline Olson, a fellow student at the Yale Law School.

title: U.S.C. Tops Rice, 240
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18 (AP)Steve Fate and Alonzo Thomas intercepted two passes each and Pete Adams recovered two key fumbles tonight to spark Southern California to a 240 victory over Rice.

title: BRITAIN DEFEATED
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 Jesse Carlyle Snead, a husky newcomer to international golf, scored the point that assured a Ryder Cup victory by the United States over Britain today.

title: Saigon Hotel Bombed
description: SAIGON, Sunday, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  A bomb exploded on the second floor of a hotel in Saigon's ChoIon district dur, ing the night, injuring five persons, the South Vietnamese command announced today. The plastic charge damaged three rooms of the Thu Do Hotel.

title: Mexicanizing Process Ends
Article 4  No Title
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 18 (UPI)  Joe Hartshorne booted a 33yard field goal with three seconds remaining today to give New Mexico University a 1310 upset victory over Texas Tech.

title: Michigans Downs Virginia
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich. Sept. 18 (AP)Michigan scored the first time it had the ball and almost at will thereafter to crush Virginia, 560, today in one of the Wolverines most lopsided football triumphs in the last quartercentury.

title: National Notes
description: The Blue Room will be bluer, the Red Room truer, but the Green Room will not change too much. That's the word on the White House's three famous state parlors, now a little tatty after a decade of wear and tear from millions of tourists and hundreds of thousands of Presidential guests and about to be refurbished by Mrs. Richard Nixon and the Committee for the Preservation of the White House. It is the first such change since Mrs. John Kennedy's celebrated restoration of the mansion's interior in 1962.

title: Australian Critics Fear That Secret U.S. Bases May Invite a Nuclear Attack
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 18 Secret American scientific installations for military purposes in the harsh Outback, as tie arid Australian hinterland is called, are being criticized here as a potential, invitation to attack in the event of a nuclear war involving the United States.

title: Nassau Seeks to Lure Bus Riders
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18Large redandwhite buttons with the words Try it! will be distributed throughout Nassau County soon in Madison Avenue approach to the problems that beset the bus lines.

title: U.S. IS PREPARING AID TO YUGOSLAVIA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The United States is preparing to postpone $56million in Yugoslav debt payments over the next 10 years as part of an American assistance program totaling nearly $300million, ficials disclosed here today.

title: 15,000 Watch Ali in Brazil
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 18 (Reuters)Muhammad Ali, the former world heavyweight champion, fought Alberto Lowell of Argentina in a nodecision, fiveround match here, last night before a crowd of 15,000. The no contest fight followed a fiveround sparring session yesterday between All and his partner, Alonzo Johnson.

title: The President and Peking
description: LONDONA major cause of difficulty in handling Far Eastern affairs in recent years ha been lack of contact between the United States and mainland China. Admittedly, such contact would not of itself have prevented grave differences over such a contentious issue as Indochina, but it could conceivably have provided an opportunity to stop their escalation into war.

title: CORONA RESIDENTS CALL MAYOR BIASED
description: Mayor Lindsay has been accused of discriminating against ItalianAmericans by a group of residents of the Corona section of Queens who have been fighting the efforts of the city to relocate or raze their homes for a high skehool.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: J. Anthony Lukas, in his article, As American as a McDonald's Hamburger on the Fourth of July (July 4), implied that McDonald's Hamburgers was founded by Ray A. Kroc in 1955. The facts are that McDonald's Hamburgers was founded by M. J. and R. J. McDonald in 1948. The. first McDonald unit was opened in San Bernardino, Calif., and by the time Mr. Kroc entered the picture there also were McDonald units in Phoenix, Ariz., Los Angeles, Calif., Sacramento, Calif., Alhambra, Calif., Azusa, Calif., Downey, Calif., plus other locations being processed.

title: Dug In and Ready, Israelis Say
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  The former commander of the Israeli Air Force, retired Maj. Gen. Ezer Weizman, who is secretary general of the leading Opposition party, declares that if Egypt resumes even limited hostilities along the Suez. Canal he would strongly urge Israeli leaders not to settle, as they did in 1969 and 1970, for another war of attrition.

title: Judah P. Benjamin
description: To the Editor: Reviewing the letters of Justice Brandeis, Eric Goldman states correctly that Brandeis was the first Jew nominated to the Supreme Court It may be pointed out that, in 1853 President Fillmore offered the same position to Judah P. Benjamin. which he declined because he had just been elected Senator from Louisiana.

title: HAROLD E. VERRILL
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., Sept. 18Harold E. Verrill, a retired partner in the investment securities firm of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill Noyes, who managed the Portland office, died in his home here yesterday. He was 77 years old.

title: W. Michigan Wins, 90
description: MUNCIE, Ind., Sept. 18 (UPI)  Ted Grignon led Western Michigan in passing and rushing today as the Broncos won their second straight football game, 90, over Ball State. Grignon completed seven of 12 passes for 111 yards and carried 23 times for 72 of Western's 207 yards on the ground.

title: Medgar Evers College Opens
description: Some 700 highschool graduates, most of them drawn from the hardcore poverty areas of midBrooklyn, gathered at the imposing Brooklyn Masonic Temple last week and took dead aim on success.

title: HitRun Driver Kills L.I. Girl
description: GREENLAWN, L. I., Sept. 18 Dianne Heilig, 16 year old, was killed here at 11 o'clock last night by a hitandrun driver while walking south on Broadway near her home at Bowden Drive. The police are looking for the driver, who abandoned his auto at the scene and fled on foot.

title: Lebanon Plans Surcharge On LuxuryItem Imports
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18Lebanon is to mpose a surcharge varying between 4 and 50 per cent on imported luxury items.

title: Massachusetts Victor
description: ORONO, Me., Sept. 18 (AP)Massachusetts, scoring in the first and fourth periods, defeated Maine, 130, in a Yankee Conference football game today.

title: Trail Biking in Nation's Wilderness Area Stirs Dispute
description: In Colorado's Rocky Mountains, outdoorsmen hiking in the thin air at 14,000 feet sometimes run into buzzing motorbikes on their trails above the timber line.

title: Pop
description: ADAPTATIONthat's the trick. Survival of the fittest is all well and good, but the only way the fittest survive is by adapting to the changes in an environment. And that's just as true in pop music as it is on Darwin's Galapagos Islands.

title: Penkowers Have a Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Monty N. Penkower on Aug. 31 at the NOrthern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N. Y. The child, whose father is assistant professor of history at Bard College, AnnandaleonHudson, N. Y., has been named Avram Yair.

title: ATTICA'S CAUSES LIKENED TO WAR
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 18Representative Claude Pepper, the head of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Crime, said today after visiting Attica prison that the violence reminded him of occasions when nations have stumbled Into war.

title: Miss Wofford Wed in South
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Sept. 18  Miss Florence Jennings Wofford, daughter of Mrs. James J. Range and the late Allen Harris Wofford, was married here this afternoon to Donald Roger Brooke Liddell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Liddell Jr. of New York and Englewood, N. J.

title: The Nation
description: The retirement of Justice Hugo L. Black last Friday, after 34 years on the Supreme Court, signals the end of an era. His appointment to the Court in 1937 created a new majority which was no longer disposed to exercise sweeping judicial vetoes over economic legislation but which became increasingly solicitous of the individual rights of citizens in their relationship with government. Justice Black was one of the principal proponents of his libertarian trend which achieved Its greatest following in the Warren Court, and his retirement making way for another appointment by President Nixon, further dilutes the old libertarian majority.

title: Hershberger Is Hospitalized
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP)Mike Hershberger, outfielder with the Chicago White Sox, was admitted to Mercy Hospital today with a possible kidney stone ailment. The 31yearold Hershberger was listed in fair condition.

title: E. F. von Briesen Weds Alice Marvin
description: LOCUST, N.J., Sept. 18Miss Alice Ruth Marvin and Edward Fuller von Briesen were married here this noon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Forer. The Rev. James B. Simpson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: SCARSDALE BOWS TO EASTCHESTER
description: Eastchester and Yorktown, playing at home, highlighted the opening of the Westchester scholastic football season yesterday with upset victories.

title: Et A1.; What Became Of Jane Austen? By Kingsley Amis. 223 pp. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $6.50.
description: The author of Lucky Jim and seven other novels, most recently The Green Man, on Lawrence, Colin Wilson, Portnoy's Complaint, James Bond, Dylan Thomas, Lolita (not pornographic enough), Fiedler, Jesus even. Crisp, commonsensical, witty, pungent, insightful. These 31 pieces were originally done for magazines but are worth seeing and keeping in book form.

title: Fateful Triangle
description: WE Americans love surprises and daring adventure. We have always been fascinated by China  by far the largest, oldest and perhaps most mysterious country in the world. And after a quarter century of agonizing over the loss, containment and bitter hostility of China, who would not welcome a step that promises to lead toward a relaxation of tensions between us and this great nation? The announcement that President Nixon would visit Peking before next May thus produced a wave of happy excitement.

title: Music; Can Electronic Music Be Romantic?; composer and electronic music practitioner
description: A JUNIOR high school music teacher asking her principal to include a synthesizer in the budget for classes next year... more and more studios and centers for electronic music degrees in electronic music and related fields... portable synthesizers widely available and within reach of individual composers and performers... perceptive audiences and critics for electronic music demanding content and meaning, no longer impressed simply by the novelty of the sounds... commercial exploitation of electronic music in rock, jazz, folk, and symphonic music... distinguished concert artists commissioning works combining live and electronic music...

title: Christophe's 2 Scores Help Grambling Top Alcorn, 216
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP)Herman Christophe, a junior running back, scored twice in the second quarter last night and Matthew Reed, a quarterback, added a third touchdown as Grambling College defeated Alcorn A. and M., 216, in Soldier Field before a crowd of 33,000.

title: The Good Word
description: To the Editor:In a recent Good Word column Wilfrid Sheed reports on his Diogenesvisit to Dublin in search of Bad Writers.

title: POPULATION RISE SEEN CONTINUING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The world's population will continue to increase for at least the next 60 years, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Mitchell Scores Five Touchdowns in Rout by Penn State
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18?? Mitchell, a senior halfback, scored five touchdowns today as Penn State opened its football season with a 563 rout of Navy.

title: The World
description: SAIGONI am not sitting near the door or next to any windows, a calm American civilian said last week, choosing his table in a restaurant in downtown Saigon with unusual care. He meant hp didn't want to be the target for an explosive or grenade.

title: New American Review
description: To the Editor:In Richard Locke's Last Word editorial a critique of New American Review, there is not one mention of the word poetry, or of NAR's poetry editors, Stanley Moss (for the first 10 issues) and Richard Howard. The latter is referred to only as the author of piece.

title: Who wants to be the last American killed in Vietnam?
SECURITY MEASURES EASED IN PHILIPPINES
description: MANILA  President Ferdinand E. Marcos today restored the right of habeas corpus in certain parts of the country where, he said, the condition of Communist insurgency and subversion has now substantially eased.

title: A Treasure Behind the Seaside Dunes
description: THE wild beach plum is almost unknown outside its natural range along the Atlantic coast. At home on the unspoiled roiling lands that lie just behind the high dunes facing the sea, it stands up to violent winter storms and intense summer heat. Its roots are deep in dry sand which contains few of the nutrients generally available to other fruiting shrubs and trees.

title: $4Million Bonds For Public Lands Used Up in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 18 (AP)A $4million bond issue primarily for the purchase of valuable coastal and lake property has been virtually used up by Maine's Park and Recreation Commission.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The news this week was not all depressing. For several days it seemed that it would be, but then, on Thursday morning, on the Editorial Page of The New York Times, a small shining nugget of good news lay glistening at the bottom of the Letters to the Editor columns, under the heading, Mark Twain Didn't Say It.

title: Plimpton Getting Downstate Center Involved
Memorial Services Here
description: Two memorial services for prisoners killed in the Attica rebellion will be held today at the Washington Square Methodist Church, at 133 West Fourth Street. At 11 A.M. David Rothenberg, executive secretary of the Fortune Society, will address the congregation. At 5 P.M. a service will be held for Samuel J. Melville, the radical who pleaded guilty to bombings in 1969.

title: Motor Vehicles Total Shows Sharp Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)The Federal Highway Administration estimates that motor vehicle registrations total 112,010,000. Every state has more cars and truck than ever.

title: FACULTY UNIONISM SPLITS EDUCATORS
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 18 More than 250 college officials and professors from 30 states who met here this week to analyze the recent trend toward faculty unionization generally agreed that some form of collective bargaining in higher education was inevitable.

title: Suffolk Museum Offering Display of Contemporary
description: The Suffolk Museum in Stony Brook is not the first place that comes to mind when you think about exploratory art exhibitions. All those wonderful carriages in the Carriage House branch, yes. And all those William Sidney Mounts in the art museum properyes again. But until Oct. 7 the Mounts have been put in storage to make room for a show that is worth the temporary sacrifice. Its ambitious subject is The Contemporary Figure: A New Realism.

title: 2 SCHOOLS PAIRED BY MINNEAPOLIS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 18 With the proportion of its black elementary pupils rising each year, Minneapolis has taken a cautious first step this week in compulsory integration by pairing two of its elementary schools.

title: HARRY FARKAS
description: Harry Farkas, a pressman employed at The New York Times since 1956, died Friday morning at Ewing Memorial Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived at 25 Eagle Lane, Farmingdale, L. I.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT FIRE ALONG CANAL AFTER 13 MONTHS
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 18Egypt and Israel exchanged rocket fire across the Suez Canal today for the first time in more than 13 months, according to communiques. The future of the Middle Eastern ceasefire was left in doubt.

title: BroadwayLove It or Leave It
description: BY now readers of these pages are only too familiar with articles by actors and directors who, fed up with New York's nectic theatrical scene, have quit Broadway to work in regional groups and similar outofstate enterprises. So persuasive are these diatribes that they may influence peripheral stagefolk to flee New York, too. In that case we may soon be reading valedictories like these, by:

title: Fieldston Defeats Branswick, 20 to 0, As Liebster Stars
description: Joe Liebster, a halfback, scored three touchdowns yesterday in pacing Fieldston School to a 200 football victory over Brunswick Prep at Fieldston. Liebster ran five yards for his first score and caught passes from Joe Feliciano, the quarterback, for his other two scores.

title: Medicine
description: The sign in the window of the Pasteur Pharmacy in Manhattan says Kidneys Wanted in nineinchhigh black block letters. The display calls attention to a serious national problem how to get help to the more than 7,500 Americans who each year are diagnosed as having terminal kidney distanse and  theoretically could be saved.

title: MANHATTAN ELEVEN BEATS CANISIUS,176
description: Manhattan College opened its football season yesterday by beating Canisius, 176.

title: British Auto Driver Killed in Race Crash
description: OULTON PARK, England, Sept. 18 (UPI)Peter Hawtin, a British auto racer, was killed today when he crashed his Cooper in a Formula 5,000 event.

title: Autumn Checks In A Few Days Early: It's Football Time
description: The summer heat, humidity and baseball linger, and autumn doesn't start officially until Thursday. But no matter what the thermometer and the calen dar say, the autumn madness known as football is here.

title: SAVOIR TRIUMPHS IN COLONIAL TROT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18Savoir upset Speedy Crown, his straightheat conqueror in the recent Hambletonian, tonight in the $103,120 Colonial Trot before 15,748 fans at Liberty Bell Park.

title: ERIC H. IRVING
description: Eric H. Irving of TempeIsman & Co., dealers in diamonds and precious metals, died Friday at his home 30 Park Avenue, apparently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Entries Close Thursday For Windjammers Rate
description: Entries close Thursday for the Douglaston Yacht Squadron's seventh annual windjammers race, to be sailed next Sunday from a start off the Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I. The race is open to traditional Americantype yachts such as schooners (excluding racing and staysail schooners), Friendship sloops, bugeyes, sharpies and catboats.

title: Attica
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLS UNIT OPENS OFFICE IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Representative Wilbur D. Mills's interest in the Democratic Presidential nomination will be fanned to an open declaration of candidacy if a 32yearold Arkansas businessman and political propagandist has his way.

title: Et Al.
description: The first Miss America beauty contest was held 50 (yes, 50) years ago, in Atlantic City What happened between then and now is here superdetailed: how the idea of Talent was added to the simple allAmerican notion of Beauty; how the girls are selected; how they cash in afterwards; what they like and dislike; what musical instruments they play (only one winner so far has mastered the bassoon); trends in their names; more measurements than Earl Wilson ever dreamed about. Illustrations, natch.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Most everybody considers American Telephone and Telegraph to be a sound and safe investment for widows and orphans and, on the face of things, they are correct. A share of A.T.&T. stock, purchased on Jan. 1, 1930, cost $221 and had an annual dividend of $9. Fortyone years later, on Dec. 31, 1970, the price per share was $49.25, which must be multiplied by six for stock splits, therefore the value of the original share went up to $295.50 and the dividend of $2.60 times six is $15.60.

title: Emily Dickinson as a maternally deprived plagiarist
description: 'Half cracked to Higginson/.. Equivocal to the end/ Who are you? That is the question as Adrienne Rich asks it. What sort of person wrote the poems? I take it that we need to know about Emily Dickinson because her poems remain fresh and stunning in their impact upon us. I want to go toward the life, with and into it, if possible. For I want to come into a greater feeling, a larger knowledge about Emily Dickinson so that I am able to turn toward the poems and apprehend their motion, their thrust of meaning, with a finer keenness and a surer clarity than before I read about her life.

title: Article 3  No Title

In the name of peace, the questions posed in the current debate on foreign policy are: How fast and how much should the United States pull back from responsibility in the world? How many troops can we pull out of Asia or Europe? How far can we cut the military budget, or the foreign aid budget?

title: ' You've Got to Walk It . . .,' Genial Put-Down of Establishment
description: As a genial put-down of the Establishment, "You've Got to Walk It Like You Talk It or You'll Lose That Beat," which landed at the Cinema Malibu and the Cinema Village yesterday, is the latest example of youthful, charming iconoclasm that appears to be losing some of its charm. As the first feature of writer-director-producer Peter Locke, who shot it all here in fine color about two years ago at the age of 27, its heart is in the right place, but it does very little more than make charming jokes about the serious problems it zanily illustrates.Of course, Mr. Locke isn't trying to be a polemicist. It's obvious he's kidding, and it's equally clear that he and his associates were up to their ears in ideas that were tossed, seemingly willy-nilly, before the camera in gross lots. The results are sporadically comic and only rarely trenchant or meaningful.Meaningful is precisely the word Mr. Locke is stressing in spinning the wacky saga of Carter Fields, his young, confused middle-class hero, who's anxious to achieve a "meaningful" career but is judged a freaked-out flop by his girl and a succession of far-out characters he encounters in his quest.In tilting against the windmills of the Establishment he is exposed to a variety of traumas, among them, his doting mother, a fat, black girl, a crazy old lady, the Puerto Rican minority municipal madness in the form of a new job ferreting out "revolutionaries" supposedly out to bomb our highways; group therapy; Madison Avenue advertising; Women's Lib; abortion, and even unrewarding marriage and fatherhood.A lot, as noted, does happeneven if it is disjointedwith the aid of explicit and "in" dialogue, off-screen narration and subtitles. And, Mr. Locke is partial to more than a few gross sequences, some of which are funny, such as the one involving Richard Pryor, the TV and nightclub comic, who plays a gibbering lush in a men's room.Zalman King, who has been featured on TV's "The Young Lawyers," makes a credible nebbish as the naive Carter Fields. Allen Garfield is crazily apoplectic as a group therapy fiend. Robert Downey, a director and writer who neatly dissected advertising tastemakers in "Putney Swope," does a nutty bit as a doubletalking ad executive. Suzette Green, as the pretty heroine, and Paula Frankle, are among the lasses who add to his confusion and sex education. They all seem to be trying to be meaningful.But as a free-swinging lampoon, "You've Got to Walk It Like You Talk It or You'll Lose That Beat" projects lots of walking and talking but precious little heartfelt beat, despite its willing cast and a plethora of sight gags and surface philosophies.

title: 2 Innocents After The Bomb:Jim McBride's 'Glen and Randa' Arrives X Rating Belies Film's Philosophical Intent
description: The world, as we know it, came to an end about 25 years ago, but Glen and Randa, two innocents born after The Bomb came down, have apparently not spent all of their lives quite as naked as they are when the camera first discovers them picking berries in a woody gladeor doing whatever it is that innocents do in woody glades.At least, Glen hasn't. From his two tones of tan, it looks very much as if he's recently been wearing jeans. This is not the major failure of "Glen and Randa," or even a failure at all, only an indication of how one mind wandered during this week's end-of-the-world movie, which is as solemn and sincere and, I'm afraid, as unprovocative as most newspaper editorials calling for an end to the arms race."Glen and Randa," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvous, is not actually about the arms race or even about the annihilation of civilization, which have provided lively material for everyone from George Pal and Stanley Kubrick to dozens of Japanese moviemakers.Jim McBride, the director and co-author of the screenplay, is, instead, concerned with the nature of man, his curiosity, his impulse towards knowledge and his compulsion to impose his own order on the universe, which, as far as I can make out from the film (as well as from some remarks made by McBride in an interview), otherwise exists in some sort of moral harmony.McBride, unfortunately, is a good deal more interesting as a moviemaker than as a philosopher, with the result that his movies have a tendency to look as if they mean a lot more than they really do. His first and, to my way of thinking, his best film, "David Holzman's Diary," was a tough and amusing put-on of cinma vrit, about a man whose manic search for truth-on-film prompts him to photograph his own life, which ultimately leads to his complete alienation from it.In "Glen and Randa," Glen's search for the mysterious city, which he has seen pictured in an old Wonder Woman comic book, is not unlike David Holzman's search for truth. It is, I suppose, both tragic and ironic, but it is dramatized in such simplistic terms that I, for one, noticed things like suntans and the fact that Glen can read well enough to pronounce "Shazaam!" correctly though he has seemingly never heard of gasoline.Glen also has a habit of philosophizing in a manner that might be called 20th-Century Cute. When he and Randa find themselves sitting in an ancient car high in a tree (which I assume was a mere sapling when The Bomb went off), he is likely to say: "Maybe cars become trees the way leaves become butterflies." And everything, I should add, eventually becomes dust.I rather like the way the film eschews dramatic climaxes, as if reflecting the barrenness of the emotional lives of Glen and Randa, but this leads to an awful monotony that neither the meaning of the film nor the performances can relieve.Shelley Plimpton ("Alice's Restaurant," "Putney Swope") is dear and sweet and pale as Randa, who would prefer to settle into a nice, floor-through cave, instead of lurching off to find Metropolis. Steven Curry's Glen looks like a former cast member of "Hair" (which Curry is). In his interpretation, however, innocence is pretty much equated with the mannerisms of an inexperienced actor.The cast also includes Woodrow Chamblis, as a gentle, fuzzy-headed old man, whom Glen and Randa find living with his wife's skeleton in a trailer near Boise, which now has a coastline like that formerly at Big Sur, and Garry Goodrow, as an aging medicine man who remembers enough of the old world still to be able to quote Keats and to swindle other survivors out of any gold, silver and jewels they might possess."Glen and Randa" is neither a successful nor an entertaining movie, but it is sober, and what mind it has is high. Thus I'm completely mystified by the X rating that has been attached to it, apparently because of its nudity and love-making. They might be thought obscene only by stretching a censor's imagination.

The U.N. has persisted in treating the problem as solely a humanitarian one, providing relief assistance to the victims. Such relief assistance is, of course, an immediate necessity, but as long as the human rights of the people of East Pakistan are ignored, a solution of the problem will be impossible.

With the body were found a Russiandesigned AK17 automatic rifle and forged credentials, the authorities said. The fourth man is being hunted.

title: Film: Brazilian 'The Deceased' Opens
description: Beneath the umbrella of Cinema Novo, Brazilian filmmakers of various stylistic persuasions are huddled. In "The Deceased" ("A Falecida"), which began a two-day run yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, the director, Leon Hirszman, is, on the surface, something of a neorealist.The landscapean impoverished suburb of Rio de Janeirois bleak, and the people are depressed, economically and psychologically. The director accentuates the somberness by placing scenes in dimly lit, dismally furnished kitchens and bedrooms, in funeral parlors and pool rooms. Almost everything in the film seems dark gray, sometimes so dark that faces are obscured.In keeping with the tonealthough this may be the fault of a poor printthe editing seems choppy, the sound occasionally muffled. The actors look like peopleunglamorous, seemingly plucked right off the street, in some cases filmed right on the street. The acting, with the exception of Fernanda Montenegro in the lead, is artless and in some instances awkward. Miss Montenegro is clearly an actress, though in a few places she overacts. In one scene she stands in the rain tearfully and joyfully embracing the raindrops as the director overdirects, spinning his camera around her like a top.But in side glimpses one gets a feeling of the threadbare life, the hopelessness of the day-to-day existence. The theme of the movie is death  one woman's obsession with death and how she self-wills herself toward it.The principals are an unemployed football fan (Ivan Candido) and his wife (Miss Montenegro) who is going crazyor who already may be crazy. She consults a fortune teller, who warns her to beware of a blond woman, whom she decides is her cousin, a neighbor. She becomes compulsively preoccupied with the cousin, whom we see only fleetingly.The wife behaves frigidly toward her husband, but at a revival meeting in a public park she "receives" Christ with a passion that is positively sensual and later she allows a fast-talking coffin salesman to flirt with her (she is convinced she is going to die and is making plans for her own very expensive funeral). At one point she demands that her husband have an affair with the cousin. Later she gleefully tells him the cousin has cancer. It is obvious, except to the other characters in the movie, that there is something seriously and sexually wrong with this lady.The root of her problem is an affair she had with a big bus and taxi tycoon. In a flashback we see their first meeting. While having ice cream with her husband in a tearoom, she goes to the ladies room, and upon exiting she meets the tycoon. Love suddenly blooms and in five minutes somewhere in the neighborhood of the ladies room, in partial view of the camera (the movie is very discreet), the passion is consummated, while the husband finishes his ice cream.This is all as ridiculous as it sounds. One might tend to shift some of the blame from the director to the screenwriter except that Hirszman is one of the three screenwriters. "The Deceased" was made in 1965 when Hirszman was 27. One hopes that since then his cinema has become more novo.

title: Military Gains Ground in U.S. Embassy in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH. Cambodia, Sept. 17United States Embassy officials who wanted to keep the American military presence! here down to a bare handful'. have lost some ground that they considered important.

title: Casey Facing Accusation His Policies Are Harmful

Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will apparently have to defend himself, on Tuesday, from charges that he has personally put policies into effect that are reducing, by millions of dollars, the value of individuals holding in pension funds, mutual funds and life insurance policies.

title: MRS. PAT HARRINGTON
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UPI)Ann Hunt Harrington, widow of Pat Harrington Sr., the New York musical comedy star, died yesterday of cancer. She was 68 years old.

title: Mideast Crisis Imperils Soviet Stance
description: LONDON, Sept. 19The extensive Soviet military preSence in Egypt, already raising some parallels with the American experience in Vietnam, poses two fundamental questions worrying governments from Washington to Tel Aviv and beyond.

title: Memorial Service Is Held At Capitol for Attica Dead
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19 The Albany, Troy and Schenectady branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People held memorial service on the steps of the Capitol today for the 30 prisoners and 10 hostages killed at Attica.

title: Adriana van der Borg Married To Robert O. Phillips, Lawyer
description: Miss Adriana Elizabeth van der Borg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes F. E. M. van der Borg of Nijmegen, the Netherlands, was married there yesterday to Robert Osborn Phillips of New York, on of Mrs. Alfred H. Phillips of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. Phillips.
