title: Siberia Denounces Dig and Run Mining Ventures
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19A Siberian Communist party official called today for permanent settlement of the Soviet Union's mineralrich Arctic regions and denounced a muchdebated dig and run approach to development there.

title: Cambodian Sect in Vietnam Urges a Boycott of Election
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19 (AP)The hierarchy of the Cambodian Buddhist church in Vietnam urged its two million followers today to boycott the oneman Presidential election on Oct. 3.

title: Court Rules MakeUp of City's Board of Elections Discriminates Against Queens, Bronx, Staten Island
description: A Federal judge has declared that the traditional composition of the city's Board of Elections is unconstitutional, portending major changes in controversial board that wields administrative power over election procedures here.

title: Rise in Dirt Particles Found in City's Air
description: Despite strict new controls on air pollution, more particles of dirt are in New York City's air now than last year, the latest statistics indicate.

title: Jackson an Enigma In Life and in Death
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19It has been nearly a month since George L. Jackson was shot and killed inside the walls of San Quentin Prison.

title: U.S. Command May End Rest Leaves in Sydney
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19  American military officials here say that the restandrecreation leave program for G.I.'s in Sydney, Australia, will be terminated in December, and they announced today that the last restandrecreation flight to Hong Kong would take off on Sept. 30.

title: British Newspapers Halted For 2d Day in Union Dispute
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The owners of Britain's national newspapers, locked in dispute with printing workers, decided today to shut down production for the second day in a row.

description: A canvas by the 19thcentury realist painter William M. Harnett that disappeared decades ago has fallen like ripe plum into the hands of the Kennedy Galleries.

title: SAMUEL D. STEIN
description: Samuel D. Stein a retired admiralty lawyer, who had served on the attorneys committee for claimants in the Morro Castle ship disaster, died yesterday at his home, 344 West 72d Street. His age was Si.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At 11:30 I kissed them all goodbye. She said, But what about lunch? I hoisted my old duffle bag and let her hear the sixpacks clank. One of the smallies asked, We gonna see you any more? I rocked his shouider pads and whacked him on the can. When the going gets tough, the tough get going. You're the man of the house now, kid. I headed downstairs, trying not to hear them sniveling behind me. That's always the toughest part of the new season, I lock myself in tight.

title: Paris: Neutral Age, Neutral Museum
description: PARISMarking one's tenure or power by a prestigious monument has long been tradition with France's rulers, It used to he churches and chateaus. Significantly, President, de Gaulle did not build new palaces but refurbished old ones, in particular the Grand Trianon at Versailles, a choice aptly reflecting a policy bent more on restoring the country's past glories than on inventing new ones. No less significantly, President Georges Pompidou has decided to illustrate his own term by the construction of a museum, to he knownat least for the time beingas the Beaubourg Center (after the name of the empty area near Les Halles, now serving as a parking lot, where it is to be erected).

title: HEART CASE LOAD CALLED TOO LIGHT
description: Most hospitals performing cardiac surgery are not performing enough operations to maintain high professional standards or justify the tremendous cost of the staff and equipment, a report by a team of heart specialists has charged.

title: MEXICO BLAMES REBELS FOR RAIDS
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19An urban guerrilla group known as the Movement for Revolutionary Action has been blamed by Mexican police for a recent wave of assaults and bank robberies in this and other Mexican cities.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 19 (AP)British troops wounded three gunmen early today during rioting in Belfast in which there was sniper fire and blasts of nail bombs.

title: NEW ELECTIONS SET FOR EAST PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 19 Byelections for 78 National Assembly seats and 105 Provincial Assembly seats will be held in East Pakistan between Nov. 25 and Dec. 9, the ,Election Commission announced in Islamabad today.

description: Every investor likes to measure his performance over a period of time. and the yardstick is growth.

title: Deaths
Pope Says Art Thefts Dishonor Civilization
description: VATICAN CITY, Sept. 19 (Reuters)Pope Paul VI, in an apparent reference to Italy's recent plague of art thefts from churches, said today tat such crimes dishonor civilization. It was the Pontiff's first allusion to thefts of paintings, mainly from churches, in the last few weeks.

title: Stewart Captures Canadian Grand Prix Curtailed by Fog
description: BOWMANVILLE, Ont., Sept. 19Jackie Stewart won the Grand Prix of Canada today in a rainsoaked race that could have qualified as an amphibious event. The race was stopped after 64 of the scheduled 80 laps because of fog and imminent darkness.

title: Nebraska, Irish Uncover Power
description: The turning point, said Minnesota's coach, Murray Warmath, came when they blew the whistle for the kickoff.

title: Worst East German Harvest
description: BERLIN, Sept, 19 (UPI) East Germany suffered its worst harvest since World War II this year and Erich Honecker, head of the Communist party, blamed the bad weather, the newspaper Neues Deutschland said today.

title: Dollar Drain Continues
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)The flow of dollars to American controlled corporations overseas eased slightly in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today, but the total of direct investment abroad still showed an unfavorable balance of about $1.1billion.

title: U.S. and Australia Reach Agreement On Jumbo Flights
description: SYDNEY, Australia Sept. 19 (Reuters)Civil Aviation Minister Robert Cotton announced agreement today between Australia and the United States on South Pacific airline routes.

title: Books of The Times
description: In his new novel, The Tenants, Bernard Malamud has rushed in where angelic liberals fear to tread. In exploring the relation between blacks and Jewsand carrying it to its implicit conclusionhe has seized contemporary history by the horns. And because he is one of our best writers, his book is infinitely more radical than those who call themselves radicals. Like Saul Bellow in Mr. Sammler's Planet, like Ralph Ellison in Invisible Man, Malamud goes beyond the rhetoric of the revolutionaries to the very root of the matter, to man's inhumanity not only to man, but also to himself. Like them, he has taken a subject that could and all too often does  degenerate into propaganda and shaped it into art. In the depth of penetration, the inescapable specificity, the unwinking nakedness of his work, he has reminded us once again that politics and social science are child's play compared to art.

title: Lessard Wins in Cycling
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press)Jean Lessard of Montreal edged the defending champion, Sigi Koch of Chicago, to win the North American Cycling championship yesterday.

title: New Cabinet Organized in Cairo As Part of a Reform Program
description: CAIRO, Sept. 19  A new Egyptian Cabinet was formed tonight, with Dr. Mahmoud Fawzi retaining the Premiership, as part of a program of administrative reforms undertaken by President Anwar elSadat.

title: GREGGHAYWOODDUO WINS AT W. VIRGINIA
description: SUMMIT POINT, W. Va., Sept. 19Peter Gregg of Jacksonville, Fla., and Hurley Haywood of Chicago, Ill., driving a Porsche 914.6 GT, won the International Motor Sports Association 250mile GT series race today, averaging 72.34 miles an hour around Summit's tight twomile road circuit as they finished almost a lap ahead of the No. 3 Porsche.

description: Cross out all the stereotyped notions about poor, dedicated and ethereal poets starving in garrets when you meet Sandra Hochman.

description: LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 19John L. Cable, a lawyer who was

description: The First National Bank of Chicago believes that the Nixon Administration's new economic, program has serious implications for the bond and money markets for the longer run.

title: Dr. William F. Albright Dead; Biblical Archeologist Was 80
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 19Dr. William Foxwell Albright, leading Biblical archeologist, died here today after having recently suffered a stroke. His age was 80.

title: Tornado Wins Soccer Title
description: ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 19 (AP) The Dallas Tornado won its first North American Soccer, League championship today, defeating the Atlanta Chiefs, 20.

title: ECONOMY THE KEY TO DANISH VOTING
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 19 Danish citizens, worried about rising prices and taxes, will vote Tuesday in an election whose central issue is the nation's economy.

title: Rockefeller Revisited
description: In the aftermath of Attica, the bloodiest prison uprising in all American history, Governor Rockefeller may well emerge with a new political image in much of the country. It was his decision to send police forces storming into the prison facility to rescue guards being held as hostages and to restore order. While in the past he has been considered liberal, so liberal that conservative elements in the G.O.P. once booed him from their Presidential nominating convention hall, today he may be considered conservative. These same elements are sending him congratulatory telegrams.

title: PROXMIRE WEIGHING A WAGEPRICE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said tonight that he was considering introducing legislation to establish a wageprice stabilization board.

title: DEMOCRATIC AIDES SCORE SURCHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19Apparently by coincidence rather than design, there has emerged a rising chorus of criticism by former high officials of the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations of one major element in President Nixon's new economic policythe 10 per cent import surcharge.

title: Home Back From Mideast
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP)Foreign Secretary Sir Alec DouglasHome, who returned from a Middle Eastern visit tonight, said he had found openings that could lead to an interim settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict and the reopening of the canal.

title: Aide Job Deadline Is Today
description: Today is the final day for Model Citiesarea residents to apply for federally funded posts as fire and police aides in their neighborhoods, Joseph B. Williams, administrator of the Model Cities program in New York, said yesterday. Applications may be filed at the Model Cities offices in the south Bronx, Harlem, east Harlem and central Brooklyn, where the aides will work, or at the city's Civil Service Commission office, 49 Thomas Street.

title: DUNNE SUPPORTS ATTACK ON ATTICA
description: State Senator John R. Dunne, who was welcomed by the rebelling Attica prisoners as one of the principals on the observers committee to negotiate an end to the uprising there, said yesterday that he saw no alternative to the storming of the prison by the police last Monday that left 30 prisoners and 10 guard hostages dead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: have had the occasion to go to Ireland three times since April, and recently spent three weeks there, both in the North (including Belfast) and in the Republic. I would like to make a few observations and suggestions.

title: Lana Cantrell Sings at the Maisonette
description: The Maisonette of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel, once noted for the specialized chic of such singular singers as Hildegarde and Patachou but, more recently, wandering in limbo so far as its entertainment policy is concerned, is moving into a new phase this fall with a varied lineup of performers in store.

title: PoliticoMilitary Poison
description: For 23 years, a senior Army intelligence officer used his official status and private resources to compile massive file of what he considered subversive persons and organizations. The lists drawn up by Maj. Gen. Ralph H. Van Deman scrambled together all those whose motives he mistrusted and misunderstood  liberal politicians, scientists, entertainers, writers and artists, along with some who genuinely opposed the American system of government. The resulting stew was rancid with antilabor, antiSemitic and anticivilrights bias.

title: Colts Rout jets, 220
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 19The New York Jets put it all together todayno offense, no defense, weak coverage on punt returns and numerous other mistakes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Stephens's Fasching Wins in Dressage Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 19Mrs. Lois Stephens rode Pasoiling to victory in the Grand Prix event with a score of 298 today at the first alldressage horse show at Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP)The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy left for a 10day preaching mission to the Soviet Union today after he posted a $200 bond and was released from a Butler, Ala., jail. He was arrested Wednesday after he attempted to lead 160 blacks on a march to a county courthouse in defiance of a law barring demonstrations.

title: Bing Regrets Lack Of Experimentation In Met's Schedule
description: I started with Verdi, and ended with Verdi. Verdi closes the cycle, said Sir Rudolf Bing on the eve of his final session as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. He appeared with Mayor Lindsay on WNEWTV last night.

title: Rosh haShanah
description: Public schools in the city and some suburban areas will be closed today and tomorrow during the observance of Rosh haShanah, Banks and department stores generally will be open, as will parochial schools. Alternate side of the street parking regulations will be suspended, The Jewish High Holy Days continue until the end of Yom Kippur, at sundown Sept, 29.

title: Cowboys Defeat Bills, 4937, as Hill Scores 4 Touchdowns, 2 in Last Period
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 19Persistence, rather than performance, paid off for the Dallas Cowboys today as they came from behind three times to defeat the pesky Buffalo Bills, 4937.

title: Captures Fail to Curb Illegal Mexican Immigrants
description: EL PASO, Tex., Sept. 18Stale air and the odor of unwashed bodies filled the eightfoot by eightfoot deportation hearing room five floors up in the county jail here yesterday.

title: Rabbis Plead for Adherence to Values
description: As Jews began the observance of Rosh haShanah, the start of the 10day period of the High Holy Days, yesterday at sundown, rabbis pleaded for a greater adherence to the values of Judaism and called attention to the problems that confront modern society.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Some sobering thoughts are in order with respect to our detente with China. Essentially this new friendship has grown out of a joint awareness that the U.S.S.R., number one power in military might and expansionist dynamism, is the contemporary equivalent of Germany in the first half of the twentieth century.

title: Two Marine Recruits Die
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Sept. 19 (UPI)  Two Marine recruits died within 12 hours of each other after apparently unrelated training exercises at the depot, Marine officials announced today. They were Pvt. Frankie C. Vickers, 19, years old, Greenville, Fla., and Pvt. Warren H. John, 23, of Baltimore.

title: Antoinette Barbey Bride of Baron
description: GENEVA, Sept. 19  Miss Antoinette Barbey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Barbey of Geneva, was married yesterday to Baron Ernest Antoine Seilliere of Paris.

title: Carrithers Beats Padres
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 (AP)Hal Lanier's highhopping single drove in two runs in the second inning today as the San Francisco Giants beat the San Diego Padres, 41. But the Giants lead in the National League West was cut to 11/2 games. The Los Angeles Dodgers gained a halfgame by sweeping a doubleheader from the Atlanta Braves, 120 and 40.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Sept. 19In 1946 the Supreme Court heard a claim that unequal population in a state's Congressional districts violated the Constitution. It was a novel claim: The institution of the gerrymander was as old as the country and had never been held unconstitutional. A majority of the Court, finding the issue inappropriate for judges, refused even to consider it on the merits.

title: 15Kilometer Walk to Laird
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 19 Ron Laird of the New York Athletic Club won his 57th title in 16 years of competition when he captured the National Amateur Athletic Union 15kilometer walk today at Post College in 2 hours 1 minute 48 seconds. The New York Athletic Club won the team title with 7 points.

title: Chess: Small, Strong Tournament Was an Exciting AlsoRan
description: In addition to the great tournament of grandmasters held recently at Amsterdam and won by Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, there took place at the same time a small but very strong masters tournament. This was won by a young Czech, Smejkal on tiebreaking points over an East German, Boris Malich, after each had scored 83.

title: Cocoa Nations Complain
description: LAGOS, Nigeria (Agence FrancePresse)  The Cocoa Producers Alliance, representing Cameroun, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Nigeria and Togo, expressed deep concern this weekend about the American economic program that began Aug. 15. The group said President Nixon's action had adversely affected exports to the United States of cocoa produced by members.

title: Handelman Cancels Offer
description: The Handelman Company of Detroit announced over the weekend that it was withdrawing its stock registration statement, filed July 16 with the Securities and Exchange Commission, on the ground that the company and offering stockholders were dissatisfied with the current market price of the common shares. The stock closed Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at 37%. Its 1971 high was 47.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Murray N. Rothbard alleges that fascism came to the United States on August 15, 1971 [OpEd Sept. 4]. Why? According to his definition, fascism is the destruction of the free price system by the Federal Government and therefore of the entire system of free enterprise and free markets that have been the heart of the American economy. Before examining the soundness of his definition, one should immediately point out that big government could not destroy something that had gone out of style by the first decade of the twentieth century.

title: Pocono Race Halted
description: LONG POND, Pa., Sept. 19 (AP)Rain and a dense fog halted the Pennsylvania 500 stock car race today after 100 miles, with Butch Hartman riding in first place. The race will be restarted at 1 P.M. next Saturday at Pocono International Speedway.

title: Black Leader in China; Abernathy Off to Soviet
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 19 (UPI)  A black American civil rights leader carrying a letter for Chairman Mao Tsetung entered China today.

title: The Prisoners
description: Nathaniel Hawthorne characterized it: The black flower of civilized society, a prison?

title: 2 DOCTORS VERIFY THAT GUNS KILLED 9 ATTICA HOSTAGES
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 19Two pathologists who reexamined the bodies of the nine hostages killed during the assault on the Attica Correctional Facility last Monday today verified an earlier finding that all had died of gunshot wounds.

title: Smallpox Declining Worldwide; End Is Viewed as Likely by 1973
description: GENEVA, Sept 19Smallpox vaccinations are about to become a thing of the past for most Americans and Britons.

title: Blomberg Gives Yanks 32 Victory in Ninth and a Happy New Year
description: Ron Blomberg made sure he'd be home by the start of the Jewish New Year yesterday when his ninthinning hit scored Jake Gibbs for a 32 Yankee victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Murphy's Drive on Graft Is Deeply Affecting Police
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's drive against corruption and inefficiency has deeply affected the attitudes of policemen and the daily work of the Police Department.

title: Henry Holthusen, Lawyer, Dies; Foreign Service Inspector, 77
description: Henry F. Holthusen. a corpolration, admiralty and international lawyer, who spent many years in Governmnt service, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 128 Central Park South. His age was 77.

description: As the plane started to dcscend toward St. Louis, the pilot announced: Four miles visibility with haze and smoke.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Analysis
description: The passing of the RCA Corporation from the computer industry was much like the announcement of the death of a relative who had been seriously ill for a long while. Everyone is shocked at the event, but the course of those companies still surviving in the electronic data processing business will be little changed. The chief beneficiary, according to analysts, will be the International Business Machines Corporation, the industry's giant. This would appear fitting since it was RCA's inability to compete with I.B.M. that was the chief cause of its demise as a factor in the computer business.

title: 58 LAYERS FOUND IN LUNAR SAMPLE
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20  Analysis of the ninefoot core extracted from the lunar surface by the Apollo 15 astronauts has disclosed 58 distinct layers representing 58 chapters in the history of the sun, the leader of that mission reported here today.

title: Siberia Pipeline Crews Advance
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20Pipeline work crews carving a path through the virgin forest of Northwest Siberia have advanced to within 25 miles of a vast natural gas deposit that is supposed to supply industrial consumers in Western Europe by the late nineteenseventies.

title: Toward a Stable Peace: II
description: AUSTIN, Tex.A great question evidently still exists in Moscow which we should understand and discuss candidly:

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Looking back over the bloodiest events of the last few years, certain parallels are visible.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A scant four years into the future and we shall be hip deep in a nightmare of American Government: 1976the twohundredth anniversary of the Americanoh boy!

title: General Motors of Canada Is Planning Layoffs of 7%
description: OSHAWA, Ontario, Sept: 20 (AP)General Motors of Canada, Ltd., announced today it would reduce its combined work force at five Ontario plants by up to about 7 per cent during the winter. Japanese competition was given as one of the main reasons.

title: EURATOM IMPASSE WITH PARIS ENDED
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20  The European Atomic Energy Community ended a twoyear deadlock today and decided to start discussing arrangements for the inspection by an outside agency of nonmilitary nuclear installations in five member countries West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

title: RALPH DAVIES, 74, SHIP LINES HEAD
description: WOODSIDE, Calif., Sept. 20 (AP)Ralph K. Davies, who became head of American President Lines after two careers in the oil industry and another inl government, died here yester day at his estate on the SanFrancisco Peninsula. He was 74 years old.

title: Witness in Medina's Trial Is Charged With Contempt
description: ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 20 Federal contempt charges were filed today against a witness who refused to testify under a grant of immunity in the courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina.

title: Banking Group Enlarged
description: The Orion Banking Group, established in London last December to provide financial and banking services for major international institutions, has been enlarged to include Credito Italian, one of Italy's largest commercial banks. It joins the Chase Manhattan Bank, the National Westminster Bank, the Royal Bank of Canada and the Westdeutche Landesbank Girozentrale as a shareholder in Orion.

title: ShakeUp in Top Management Is Announced by Detroit Edison
description: The Detroit Edison Company announced yesterday a shakeup in its top management. William G. Meese, president, was named chief executive officer, effective Nov. 1. He will succeed Walker L. Cisler, who will retain his post as chairman.

title: Witnesses in Police Slayings To Try to Identify New Suspects
description: Three alleged witnesses to the slaying of Patrolmen Waverly M. Jones and Joseph A. Piagentini here May 21 were expected in San Francisco today, accompanied by representatives of the Manhattan District Attorney, to try to identify two suspects in a police lineup, police officials said yesterday.

title: 300 at Nuclear Test Site In Alaska Put on Furlough
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Atomic Energy Commis sion announced today that it had furloughed 300 of its workers who have been in Amchitka Island in the Aleutians for the nation's largest underground nuclear explosion.

title: DEPOSIT SYSTEM IS BEING WEIGHED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Senator William V. Roth, Republican of Delaware, today proposed creation of a National Securities Corporation to operate a nationwide depository system for stock certificates.

title: Namath Sorely Missed; Absence of Jet Quarterback Builds Confidence Among Club's Opponents
description: There's good news and bad news for New York Giant fans in the wake of Sunday's surrealistic 4340 victory at Green Bay.

title: Exchange's Board to Vote On Black Firm as Member
description: The pending application of the First Harlem Securities Corporation, a blackowned brokerage house, for membership on the New York Stock Exchange will be voted on by the exchange's board of governors on Sept. 30, according to the Big Board's Weekly Bulletin.

title: Mortgage Futures Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (Reuters)  The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is studying the possibility of trading home mortgages on the commodityfutures market, although an official said the plan Is still only in the idea stage.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: This summer researchers at a state laboratory in Rome, N. Y., discovered mercury in the neckbone of a 15,000yearold mastodon. The concentration was twice the limit considered acceptable for food by the Federal Government.

title: JAPANESE SEE NIXON DUE IN CHINA MONDAY
description: TOKYO, Sept. 20 (UPI)Asahi Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper, said yesterday that President Nixon would fly directly to Peking after he meets with the Japanese Emperor in Anchorage, Alaska, on Sunday.

title: Rosmond Wins First Race In National Dinghy Series
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 20  Tom Rosmond of Seattle jumped to an early lead in the International 14foot dinghy national championships on Chesapeake. Bay just off the mouth of the Severn River.

title: Lufkin's Salary Is Minimum
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 20 (AP)Dan W. Lufkin of Newtown, the multimillionaire who is serving as Connecticut's first environmental protection commissioner, will receive a salary of $31,281 from the state. The pay, announced today by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, is the lowest salary authorized for his job. Mr. Lufkin, 40 years old, made an estimated $15million as a stockbroker and financier in New York City.

title: The Talk of No. 5 Forsyth Street
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20When Gunnar Myrdal returned to the South this year after an absence of nearly three decades, one of his appointments was at No. 5 Forsyth Street, an aging office building deep in the downtown core of this city. So, this is where it begins, the celeebrated Swedish sociologist muttered to himself as he strode into the little lobby. Where what begins? an acquaintance inquired. Dr. Myrdal, author of An American Dilemma, a widely read volume on race relations in this  country, harumphed professorially.

title: Brooklyn Driver Booked On Police Bribery Charge
description: A Brooklyn motorist was held on bribery charges last night after he allegedly tossed a $10 bill into a police car when stopped for a traffic violation.

title: Garment District Repaving
description: Vincent J. Gibney, the city's Commissioner of Highways, announced yesterday that he was taking advantage of the lull over the Jewish holidays to repave some street in the Garment District. Starting yesterday, he said, 12 gangs of more than 100 men from his department will pour 2,500 tons of hot, sheet asphalt on West 35th, 36th, 37th, 38th and 39th Streets, in areas between Seventh and Ninth Avenues.
