description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Two leading economists presented today to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress proposals for taxes on excess profits after the current 90day wage and price freeze expires midnight of Nov. 13.

title: Martha Mitchell's DressBuying Spree
description: Hello, everybody. Dimpling, grinning and shaking hands all around, the ebullient Mrs. John N. Mitchell burst into the Seventh Avenue showroom of Jo Ellen Couture yesterday morning, spreading cheer and buying clothes.

title: SENATE APPROVES DRAFT BILL, 5530; PRESIDENT TO SIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Senate gave final Congressional approval to the draft bill today, permitting a return to military conscription until June, 1973.

title: HOOTON OF CUBS BEATS METS, 30, ON A TWOHITTER
Boy Dies Rescuing Pets
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 21 (AP)A 3yearold boy, Jeffrey Fullmer, ran back into his burning home today, apparently to rescue his dog and cat, and died in the fire.

title: Bravo Guerreiro' Bows
description: There is no doubt about where some of the directors of Brazil's revolutionary Cinema Novo stand. Gustavo Dahl's passionate manifesto, "O Bravo Guerreiro," which opened at the Fifth Avenue Cinema yesterday, shouts out bravely, if stridently, against the callousness of entrenched politicos, social and political inequities and the despair felt by the working class.While there are no viable arguments against his pleas for justice, Dahl, who is in his early thirties and made "O Bravo Guerreiro" as his first feature about two years ago, is more concerned with the imagery of words and speeches then in full character analysis or action. His courageous, tragic young hero, as well as his friends and enemies, turn out, unfortunately, to be figures of speech literally rather than of men under terrible stress.In essence, Dahl's "Brave Warrior," played intensely, if glumly, by the dark-haired, lanky, mustachioed Paulo Cesar Pareio, is a radical lawyer-union official-Congressman torn between his ideals and the compromises of practical politics. A switch from his radical party to the all-powerful national party, following the advice of Mario Lago, an old, experienced legislator, does not, however, result in victory.His fellow-unionists relay word that his congressional colleagues have warped his enlightened bills against him and the unionists and his chances of helping the oppressed go glimmering. There is also a break with his wife who has discovered a moment of infidelity and, in a climactic, fiery union meeting, he both quiets and impresses the assemblage with his forthright credos and the fact that he has failed them.Dahl ends it all on a note of impending doom as his lost crusader holds a gun to his mouth. But Dahl's largely static scenes, including the last one, merely emphasize, despite the complex machinations, his social and political stands through torrents of words. His integrity and potential cannot be faulted. The ills he relates in Portuguese are stark and disturbing but they are rarely moving or tragic as illustrated by "O Brave Guerreiro" despite its English subtitles.

title: Winthrop. Rockefeller to Talk
description: Winthrop Rockefeller, former Governor of Arkansas, will be guest speaker at the annual Idinner meeting of the 77th Infantry Division Reserve Officers Association at the New York State Armory on 14th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenue on Friday evening. Mr. Rockefeller was an officer with the division in the southwest Pacific in World War II.

title: Japan Agrees to CoSponsor U.S. China Resolutions in U.N.
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 22 Premier Eisaku Sato announced today that Japan would join with the United States in sponsoring two resolutions intended to preserve the seat of Nationalist China in the United Nations while admitting Communist China.

title: PARADE IN PEKING A NATIONAL EVENT
description: PEKING, Sept. 21For nearly a generation, the two hours before noon on Oct. 1 have seen the eyes of all China fixed on Tienanmen Square, in the heart of the capital.

title: Pnompenh Blaze Put Out
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 21 (AP)Fires in two gasoline storage dumps on the northern outskirts of Pnompenh were finally extinguished today more than 36 hours after tanks had been set ablaze in an enemy attack.

title: Casey Says S.E.C. Plans a StockFee Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21William J. Casey, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the commission was about ready to approve a new schedule of sales commissions on stock transactions, one that would remove the surcharge of up to $15 on orders of 1,000 shares or less.

title: Upstate Man Sets Himself Afire Over Closing of Mental School
description: WILLARD, N. Y., Sept. 4 (UPI)A man who wanted tol dramatize protests against the closing of the Sampson State School for the Mentally Retarded set himself afire today and later declined to be admitted to a nearby hospital.

title: Thieves in Florence Steal Jewels From Saint's Coffin
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Sept. 21 (UPI)Thieves broke into St. Mark's Church yesterday and stole jewels that had been with, the embalmed body of a saint the police said. A gold ring, a gold cross and a bishop's staff were taken.

title: SCIENCE PANEL ASKS STRICT CURB ON DDT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) A panel ofscientists says the pesticide DDT poses no immediate threat of widespread human sicknescs or death but is likely to cause a gradual deterioration of the environment.

description: It's been long overdue, but the happy fact is that at last it has come through. Peter Revson has been invited, for the first time, to race in the United States Grand Prix on Sunday, Oct. 3, at Watkins Glen, N.Y. He thus joins another distinguished American freshly entered in Grand Prix competition  Mark Donohue, who made a brilliant debut by running third last Sunday in the Canadian Grand Prix.

title: XEROX STEPS OUT OF A TV CONTRACT
description: The Xerox Corporation has canceled sponsorship of the National Broadcasting Company's new series entitled The Quarterly Report.

title: Joseph Jablonower Rites Will Be Held Tomorrow

description: TOKYO, Sept. 21Yoshikatsu Takeiri chairman of the Komeito, or Clean Government party, was stabbed and seriously wounded here this afternoon.

title: CANADIANS TO END ADS FOR TOBACCO
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 21 (AP)Canadian tobacco companies announced today that they would voluntarily end cigarette advertising on radio and television Jan. 1.

title: West Germany Puts a 10% Limit on Upward Float of the Mark to Aid in Bargaining

A total of 13,000 tons of the munitions were moved from Okinawa in the twoandahalfmonth operation.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The Small Business Administration reported today it made a record 78,902 loans during the last fiscal year, totaling $1.4billion.

description: Miss Claudia Goncalves was married in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, Monday night to JeanClaude Pujol, manager of Les Pyrenees, one of two New York restaurants founded and operated by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jean Pujol. The other is du Midi.

description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 21Four young men are standing on the sidewalk, going nowhere, doing nothing. A polic emanbecause of professional instinct or personal preference  wishes they would move on.

title: Mayor Names 71 to Govern Comprehersive Health Planning  Unit
Notes on People
description: A sevendayaweek radio program is just too confining, said Arthur Godfrey, in announcing that after 43 years he was ending his radio career.

title: The Negro College Crisis
description: The nation's colleges have made substantial progress toward opening their campuses to black students. It one of the major accomplishments of the civil rights movement that most leading universities, after years tokenism, now make it their business to recruit and subsidize large numbers of minority students.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)The Senate confirmed without objection today the nomination of Robert A. Morse as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. Also, New Jersey Judges James Hunter 3d and James Rosen were confirmed to the Third Circuit Court without opposition, after a brief hearing earlier in the day by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

description: Mrs. SuSan Phipps Cochran of Oyster Bay, L. I., daughter of Michael G. Phipps of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Phipps, was married on Aug. 27 to Michael R. Santangelo of New York. The ceremony was performed atop the Hoover Dam on the Nevada side by the Rev. John Peters, a Unitarian minister.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21President Nixon asked the Senate today to approve the treaty returning Okinawa to Japan. He said that the arrangement would place. United StatesJapanese relationships on a more sound and enduring basis without sacrificing United States security needs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The accounts in The Times and other papers of the appearance by New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson on Sept. 8 before the New York State Assembly committee concerning nofault auto insurance reform indicate shocking conduct on the part of some committee members.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Frank Robinson joined the exclusive Five Hundred Club a week ago as he became the 11th man to hit 500 career home runs. The staging of his triumphant entrance was handled wretchedly, however, because Robbie's historic shot landed on public consciousness with no more impact than a wet towel dropping on a showerroom floor.

title: J. JAMES NEALE
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 21J. James Neale, senior vice president and director of radio and television at DancerFitzgeraldSample, Inc., a New York advertising agency, died last evening at Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, after surgery. He was 61 years old and lived on State Road.

title: BEIRUT TALKS BEGUN BY 11 OIL COUNTRIES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21Representatives of 11 countries controlling about 80 per cent of the world's oil production began meetings here today to decide on issues that have a major impact on international petroleum companies.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is just no gainsaying the profound importance of B. F. Skinner's new book, Beyond Freedom and Dignity. If you plan to read only one book this year, this is probably the one you should choose. But Dr. Skinner's message is hard to take. First off, one tries to dismiss it for its superficial resemblance to the old totalitarian line that the struggle for freedom and dignity is a waste of time when, with a little controlled planning, the world can be turned into marzipan. Not a very palatable message even if the doctor's aims are beneficient.

title: ROCKEFELLER VOWS SUBWAY FARE AID

title: Jersey Lottery Bites Into Numbers Racket, Forcing It to Cut Odds
description: The success of the New Jersey lottery is dealing a sharp blow to the numbers racketeers, police officials have concluded.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The House overrode its Judiciary Committee today and agreed to vote on a proposed constitutional amendment to permit prayers in schools.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 21Frank Sullivan, the humorist who created Mr. Arbuthnot as the ultimate cliche expert on every subjet under the sun, enters his 80th year tomorrow in this city of his birth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: You provide various yardsticks to compare the American doctor's average income of $40,000 with that of attorneys, dentists, bankers and other professions. [News story Sept. 13.] Has any economist ever gauged a physician's income on a perhour basis? The banker, dentist and attorney who (granted periodic exceptions) have regular office hours, also enjoy a work advantage few M.D.'s have.

Kingston, Assembly majority leader, said today he would sponsor legislation next year establishing state scholarships that would include the children of the guards slain last week at the State Correctional Facility at Attica, N. Y. The bill would provide scholarships for the children of all peace officers and firemen killed in the line of duty.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21Following are the major provisions of the Selective Service legislation that was given final Congressional approval today:

description: WASHINGTON, Sept., 21Stiff opposition from Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. greeted the National and American Basketball Associations today as they sought permission from Congress to merge.

Advertising:

Last year the city's Board of Ethics had said there was no conflict of interest in the fact that Mr. Kerr was head of a city planning council that awarded his firm a $212,000 contract.
