description: Have you ever seen a dream skating? If the answer is no, take time out between now and Oct. 3 to visit Madison Square Garden where Peggy Fleming is gracing the 27th edition of Holiday on Ice.

title: MEDINA MAY GET A LESSER CHARGE
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 21The military judge in thel, courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina told Government and defense counsel today that he would instruct the jury that it could consider convicting the captain of the misdemeanor of negligent homicide.

title: Bomb Damages the Home of Labor Leader in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21 (AP) A terrorist bomb exploded tonight at the home of a labor leader once mentioned as a running mate of President Nguyen Van Thieu in what seemed to be an assassination attempt.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
Giants Lose to Astros but Keep 1Game Lead as Dodgers Bow
Senate Witness Bids U.S.Fund 25 Big Urban School Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The superintendent of the Philadelphia school system recommended today that the Federal Government nationalize the operation and funding of the nation's 25 largest urban public school systems.

title: 2 Held in Attempt To Sell Stolen Guns To 3 Detectives
description: Three detectives last night asked a Greenwich Village pizza parlor owner Where's the World's Trade Fair Center?

title: GREGORY MAJZLIN, TEACHER OF NURSES
description: Dr. Gregory Majzlin, who supervised the NurseMidwife Training Program in Family Planning at the State University's Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, died in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Sept. 10, on a State Department visit. In 1969 he had been a consultant to the Afghan Government and the Afghan Family Guidance Association. He was 60 years old and lived at 92 Whitman Drive in Brooklyn.

title: Next Monetary System
description: A few days after President Nixon suspended convertibility between the dollar and gold on Aug. 15, an obituary notice was circulated at offices of the International Monetary Fund in Washington.

title: Catholic Church in North Vietnam Is Reported Deeply Split Over Cooperation With Hanoi Regime
description: ROME, Sept. 21A report from Hanoi in L'Unita, the Italian Communist party newspaper, said today that the Roman Catholic Church in North Vietnam was deeply split over the issue of cooperation with the Communist Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is hard not to comment on the problem of transit fares in view of the number of hours I have spent on the problems of New York City transportation of all kinds.

title: Rebuffed Nader Raiders Picket Auto Club Meeting
description: Ralph Nader's dispute with the American Automobile Association gathered steam inside and outside the Americana yesterday as a handful of Nader Raiders picketed ,the association's annual meeting at the hotel.

title: Bridge: An Italian Renaissance Could Be Due Next June
description: The eclipse of Italy on the international bridge scene may prove to be merely temporary. The great Blue Team, which retired in 1969 after 13 years of almost uninterrupted success, may decide to defend its world team Olympiad title in Miami Beach next June. And Italy will be favored to win the European title in Athens in November with a team that includes only two of its greatest stars, Benito Garozzo and Giorgio Belladonna.

title: Issues at the U.N. Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21Following are the issues that are expected to figure prominently in the General Assembly session that opened today:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his speech before Congress on Sept. 9 the President stated: I urge the Congress to remove the 7 per cent excise tax on automobiles, so that the more than eight million people in this country who will buy new American built cars in the next year will save an average of $200 each. This is a sales tax paid by the consumer. Its removal will stimulate sales, and every 100,000 additional automobiles sold will mean 25,000 additional jobs for Americas workers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Sept. 14 letter by Deputy Mayor Timothy Costello asks for volunteers to fill positions in the city's libraries, museums and other cultural and recreational facilities. It would seem ridiculous to fill such positions with volunteers on an hourly basis when many welfare recipients would be happy to give a similar number of hours to these tasks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Look magazine's death is a grim reminder of Washington's heavyhanded discrimination between competing media. Look died because lost too much advertising to television. It paid $4 million a year for the right to use the mails, and the price would have risen to $10 million a year, more than Look could pay for access to this public facility. Its television competitors pay nothing to use another publicly owned means of communication, the channels assigned to them by the Federal Government.

title: President of 26th Assembly Adam Malik
description: The new President of the United Nations General Assembly, Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia, is noted for an ability to depict positions of bitter enemies in such ways that they sometimes end up thinking that they have been agreeing with one another all along.

title: MRS. MANNIE HALBERT
description: SOUTH FALLSBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 21Mrs. Nettie Halbert, a coowner with her husband, Mannie Halbert, of the Raleigh Hotel here, died yesterday at her home after a long illness. She was 54 years old.

title: Oct. 9 Leif Ericson Day
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)President Nixon designated today Oct. 9 as Leif Ericson Day in honor of the Norse explorer.

title: Short Interest Rose In Month to Sept. 15 Following 5 Drops
GEN. K. B. WOLFE, B 29'S DEVELOPER
description: SOLANO BEACH, Calif., Sept. 21  Lieut. Gen. Kenneth B. Wolfe, Air Force, retired, who directed the development and production of the B29 bomber in World War II, died yesterday at his home here after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

title: NASSAU JUDGE SUES TO NULLIFY ELECTION
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 A Republican Nassau County District Court judge who was defeated by a Republican writein candidate in last week's primary elections after he had accepted Conservative party endorsement filed suit in State Supreme Court here today to set aside the election.

title: AIRLINES DEBATE 1972 FARE ACTION
description: One week after Lufthansa German Airlines disavowed transAtlantic air fares agreement, most other airlines appear to be in a quandary over how to cope with the situation. The result is uncertainty over how much it will cost to fly to Europe after Feb. 1.

title: Blount Says Postal Service Increased Productivity 3.5% in the Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Declaring that the United States Postal Service was in the vanguard of change, Postmaster General Winton M. Blount told more than 3,000 delegates to the fifth annual Postal Forum today that postal productivity increased 3.5 per cent in the last fiscal year, under present management techniques.

title: Troop Withdrawal Urged
description: DURHAM, N. H., Sept. 22 Representative William R. Anderson, Democrat of Tennessee, today urged complete withdrawal of United States forces from Indochina by next March 30 and said that all land forces overseas should be brought home by 1976. Mr. Anderson spoke to students at the University of New Hampshire. The appearance was part of a fiveday swing through the state to test his Presidential popularity.

title: 15,000 Reach Semifinals In Merit Scholarship Tests
description: About 15,000 high school seniors have qualified as semifinalists in the 197172 National Merit Scholarship competition, which involved 655,000 students in 16,600 schools throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.

title: Soviet Remains Elated by Results of BrandtBrezhnev Conference
description: MOSCOW. Sept. 22The Soviet leadership embarked today on its most concentrated burst of travel in 16 years but foreign diplomats believe that the most important contact has already taken place, and at home.

title: German Sees Trade Threat
description: The head of one of Europe's largest banks warned yesterday of the threat of a growing disintegration of world trade if the United States and the Common Market did not settle their differences over international monetary reform.

title: WASHINGTON VOTERS BACK 18YEAROLDS
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 22 (AP)Two 18yearolds, one advocating increased use of the rod at school, the other increased power to the people, called for changes in local offices today after upset primary election victories in Washington.

title: U.S. Planes and Ships Attack Southern Half of Buffer Zone
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 23 (AP)TWo United States fighterbombers destroyed an antiaircraft gun site 77 miles inside North Vietnam after receiving fire from the gun position, the United States command announced today.

title: Prison Guard Union Threatens LockIn to Enforce Demands
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22  Jerry Wurf, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, said today that prison guards would stage a lockin on Oct. 7 if the state did not meet six union demands to fulfill the legitimate needs of correction officers and inmates by then.

title: West German Bank Buys More Dollars To Hold Mark Rate
description: PARIS, Sept. 22The West German Central Bank continued to purchase dollars today to try to keep the exchange rate of the mark from rising excessively,

title: Shooting Defended
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22William E. Kirwan, superintendent of the state police, said today that the recapture of Attica Prison was not a turkey shoot. There was, he maintained, no indiscriminate firing by law enforcement agencies.

title: SATO UNDER FIRE FOR CHINA STAND
description: TOKYO, Sept. 22Premier Eisaku Sato's decision to join the United States in sponsoring two resolutions on Chinese representation in the United Nations drew immediate hostility from his political enemies and frosty silence from his allies today.

title: OPPOSING MERGER, BASKETBALL STARS DISCLOSE INCOMES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Oscar Robertson, Zelmo Beaty and Dave DeBusschere gave vivid examples of how their income increased when it was possible to exercise a choice of employers as they testified today before the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee. They spoke in opposition to a bill that would ,give the National and American Basketball Associations the right to merge and participate in a common draft.

title: ITALIANS IMPOSE PRICE CONTROLS
description: ROME, Sept. 22The Government today adopted price controls to curb a sudden increase in the cost of living that has caused grumbling among Italians.

title: CITY DISTURBED BY GAS SHORTAGE
BRITAIN WILL SEEK ROLE BY CATHOLICS IN ULSTER REGIME
description: LONDON, Sept. 22The British Government, in a change of policy, indicated today that it was ready for major political concessions to the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.

title: CORRUPTION LAID TO EXINSPECTOR
description: A prosecutor disclosed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday that a former chief inspector of the Police Department had been involved in the alleged corruption efforts of Hugh Mulligan, a reputed bookmaker and loanshark.

title: Britain and Malta Reach Agreement On the Use of Base
description: LONDON, Sept. 22  Agreement on the continued use of the naval base in Malta by Britain and her allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was announced here tonight.

title: PROVIDENT NATIONAL SEEKS MAGUIRE &
description: The Provident National Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire John P. Maguire & Co., a factoring subsidiary of Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., for $20million in cash and notes.

title: EUNICE ANN MUNSEL
description: MALIBU BEACH, Calif., Sept. 22Mrs. Eunice Ann Munsel, the mother of Patrice Munsel, the former opera singer, died of cancer at the Berkeley Convalescent Hospital in Santa Monica Tuesday. Mrs. Munsel was a residetn of Malibu Beach.

title: OneTon Racing Makes Debut in U.S.
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22OneTon yacht racing arrived in the. United States for the first time today, when the Ida Lewis Yacht Club committee fired its starting gun at 12:30 P.M. for seven boats.

title: Yugoslays Speculate on What Soviet Wants
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 20 You cannot have detente in Europe and war in the Balkans.

title: JOSEPH STEVENS, 83, OF SPORTS CATERERS
description: Joseph Benson Stevens, retired chairman of Harry M. Stevens, Inc., the sportsevent caterers, died last night in the Merwick unit of Princeton (N. J). Hospital. He was 83 yaers old. Mr. Stevens was the youngest of four sons of Harry Stevens, who founded the business at the turn of the century. The company, with offices at 521 Fifth Avenue, supplies food and operates concessions at race tracks and stadiums across the country.

title: ALLEGED MAFIOSO BURIED IN QUEENS
description: James Plumeri, a reputed Mafia figure known as Jimmy Doyle, was buried in St. John's Cemetery in Queens yesterday after a private, Roman Catholic funeral service. Doyle was found murdered on a Queens street Friday.

title: Chicago Seven Prosecutor Runs for Illinois Governor
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (UPI) Thomas A. Foran, a former United States Attorney in Chicago, who was the prosecutor in the Chicago Seven trial, announced today he would seek the Democratic party's nomination for Governor.

title: Narcotics Pusher Given 20 Years to Life in Prison
description: A convicted narcotics pusher was sentenced yesterday to 20 years to life imprisonment for possession of more than two pounds of heroin.

title: Rockefellers to Be Honored
description: The 1971 Humanitarian Award of United Cerebral Palsy of New York will be presented to Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller at a dinner to be held in their honor on Oct. 14 in the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton.

title: Thousands Protest Regime At Athens Rites for Seferis
description: ATHENS, Sept. 22 The funeral of George Seferis, Greece's only Nobel Laureate, turned today into a mass display of opposition to the country's militarybacked regime, as thousands of people marched behind the bier to the cemetery singing songs banned under the present martial law.

title: State Agency Acts to Put Welfare Mothers to Work
description: The State Department of Social Services has requested Federal approval for a demonstration project that would require welfare mothers with children over the age of 6 to go to work or to care in their homes for children of other welfare mothers who are working.

title: Manes Is Sworn as Queens Head
description: Donald R. Manes, sworn in yesterday as the 16th Borough President of Queens, immediately called for the return of control of vital city services to the office of the Borough Presidents.

title: Arms Cache in Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 22 (AP)The Government said today that security forces had discovered the biggest arms cache in Amman since Palestinian guerrillas left the capital in May.

title: U.N. GETS APPEAL ON EAST PAKISTAN
description: ROME, Sept. 22The international relief organization of the Roman Catholic Church appealed to the United Nations today to save the people of East Pakistan from what threatens to be one of the most deadly famines of our times.

title: August Rise Here Only 0.1
description: Consumer prices in the metropolitan area rose 0.1 per cent during August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: The Music Box Theater Takes a Bow at 50
description: On Broadway it is usually the plays and the performances, not the theaters, that stir up memories. But yesterday it was the Music Box, celebrating its 50th anniversary, that took the bows. The Music Box, Moss Hart wrote in Act One, is everybody's dream of a theater.

title: Notes on People
description: In 1958, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, as wife of the Vice President, swung and missed twice with a bottle of champagne that was supposed to christen a Caribbean cruise ship. Yesterday, in the same shipyard at Newport News, Va., preparing to christen the U.S.S. California, Mrs. Nixon almost bobbled the bubbly again.

title: Orders of Durable Goods Declined 2.3% in August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters)New orders for durable goods fell by 2.3 per cent, or $714million, in August compared with a revised increase of 3.4 per cent in July, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Customs Post Blown Up
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 22 (Reuters)A customs post in County Armagh was blown up and an army patrol in the same area was fired on last night.

title: Revised Investment Spur
description: The House Ways and Means Committee has rewritten President Nixon's proposed job development credit"his tax credit for business purchases of new equipment. Instead of the President's firstyear rate of 10 per cent, with a drop to 5 per cent next August, the committee would set the rate permanently at 7 per cent. Its aim is to avoid so heavy a bunching of business orders for equipment in the first year as to cause a sharp drop thereafter.

title: Texaco Units Trim Prices
description: Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday that its White Fuel Corporation subsidiary and its Paragon Oil Company division had reduced their posted prices by 25 cents a barrel for No. 4, No. 5 and No. 6 fuel oils with sulphur content in excess of 1 per cent. The reduction is effective along the Eastern seaboard.

title: C. W. BISHOP 81; SERVED IN HOUSE
description: MARION, Ill., Sept. 22 (UPI) C. W. Bishop, former Representative for 14 years from the old Illinois 25th Congressional District, died last night in Marion Memorial Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in nearby Carterville. He had been a patient at the hospital for 11 days.

title: WHITELAW ELECTED TO DIRECT E.C.A.C.
description: Robert M. (Scotty) Whitelaw, associate commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, was elected commissioner at the conference's fall membership meeting yesterday. He will assume his new position on Feb. 24 when George L. Shiebler, the current commissioner, retires.

title: ECONOMY IS HELD KEY U.S. CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Economic problems have replaced the Vietnam war as the chief concern of the American people, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: State Grants $7.9Million For Methadone Aid Here
description: Approval by the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission of more than $7.9million in 197172 grants to four methadone maintenance pro. grams in the metropolitan area was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

title: TV: Xerox Move and Reporter Changes Spotlight a New Direction for News
description: Item: The Xerox Corporation canceled sponsorship of a new National Broadcasting Company series called Xerox Presents The Quarterly Report.

title: MONETARY TALKS SET FOR WEEKEND
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Monetary negotiations here next weekend will center on procedure, not substance, and the United States will be as insistent as before that the price of gold and the United States import surcharge not be among the first items to be considered in future negotiations.

title: Cubs Subdue Mets, 41;
Court Urges DDT Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals here ordered the Environmental Protection Agency today to consider placing an early ban on all uses of the pesticide DDT.

title: Only Calley Convicted
description: The only American military man convicted for the murdering of civilians at Mylai is First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. He was found guilty last March of the murder of 22 civilians at the South Vietnamese hamlet.

title: DRUG AD INQUIRY HEARS 3 ON F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22  Two members of the Federal Communications Commission told a Senate subcommittee today that their agency had no expertise and little power to regulate the multimilliondollar advertising of drugs on television and radio.

title: Marichal 31 Victor
Murphy for Trying Drug Maintenance In Controlled Study
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said last night that a very carefully controlled heroin maintenance program might be worth experimentation.

title: Hugo Black Suffers Stroke; Condition Listed as Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Former Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black is in serious condition in Bethesda Naval Hospital after having suffered a stroke on Monday.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS LOOMIS NOMINATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters)The Senate Banking Committee today approved President Nixon's nomination of Philip A. Loomis Jr. to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 24 INDIANS SEIZED IN CAPITAL CLASH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22A band of militant young Indians sought to make a citizens arrest of a Federal official today and wound up in a noisy clash with Government guards at the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: Colonels Win by 11185 As Bullets Use Rookies
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 22 (AP)The. Kentucky Colonels scored the American Basketball Association's first victory over a regular National Basketball Association team tonight, pummeling the Baltimore Bullets, 11185.

title: DR. THOMAS D. GRIFFITH
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 22Dr. Thomas D. Griffith, psychiatrist and director of the Northeast Mental Health Clinic in Glen Cove since 1964, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home. He was 45 years old and lived on Duck Pond Road.

title: Sports of The Times
description: President Nixon has let it be known that he now considers the California Angels his home team: He may even throw out the first ball when the Angels open their season in Anaheim next year. His decision may turn out to he the most farreaching response to the recently announced move of the Senators baseball_ club from Washington to DallasFort Worth. Despite the current fustian and blahblah, the move is probably as important as the relocation of your favorite Carvel ice cream stand.

title: Zing! Due in January
description: Zing!, a new musical with book and lyrics by George Haimsohm and music by John Aman, will be produced on Broadway in January by Albert Zuckerman. Barbara Brownell, David Christmas and Winston De Witt Hainsley head the cast. Larry Ziegler is the director. The show will have its world premiere at the Bucks County (Pa.) Playhouse next Thursday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a parent I consider the loss of subsidy on, carfare for schoolchildren reckless and a deplorable wrong. The incentive to go to school is low enough without having to walk in rain and cold weather. It remains to be seen what these children, from kindergarten to eighth grade, will encounter in the streets on their way to schoolwhen. they do go.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Antipoverty Bill Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) House leaders postponed today consideration of a $4.9billion antipoverty bill. The measure had been scheduled for debate today, with a vote on passage tomorrow. Speaker Carl Albert, Democrat of Oklahoma, said no date had been set for consideration of the bill, but that it would be taken up later.

title: Deceptive Quotes in Ads Face Ban
description: The city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Bess Myerson, introduced yesterday a regulation barring the use of deceptive quotations in theater, movie and book advertisements.

title: Dollar Trading
Chess: Swiss Player Makes Debut A Winning One in Athens
PRIMARIES HEED IN CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 22  The Mayors of four major Connecticut cities won renomination in Democratic party primaries today.

title: HOUSE PANEL CUTS TAXES $3BILLION BELOW NIXON PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The House Ways and Means Committee completed work on the tax bill today, adding more than $3billion over the next three years to the tax relief for individuals proposed by President Nixon.

title: John Muhlke Jr., 54, Dies; Ad Manager for Magazine
description: John H. Muhlke Jr., advertising manager of Nation's Business magazine, died Tuesday in Veterans Administration Honpital, Northport, L. I. He was 54 years old and lived at 305 East 24th Street.

title: PHYSICIST TELLS OF VISIT TO CHINA
description: Communist China is believed to be seriously weighing plans to build its own giant particle accelerator, an atomsmashing machine for research in highenergy physics.

title: A Reply to Mr. Maisky
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The Times has carried on this page three articles by the former Soviet Ambassador in London, Ivan Maisky, purporting to describe the diplomatic preliminaries and causes of World War II

title: Saigon's Senate Bids Thieu Delay Voting for President
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22  The South Vietnamese Senate today called on President Nguyen Van Thieu to postpone the Oct. 3 elections because his oneman presidential candidacy would lead to disaster.

title: MURRAY SIEGEL, HEAD OF VORNADO
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Sept. 22Murray J. Siegel, president and chief executive officer of Vornado, Inc., a merchandising and retailing conglomerate, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at Englewood Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 12 Illingworth Avenue.

title: Panel Organized to Study DDTLike Compound for Environmental Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Officials of seven Federal agencies are expressing increasing concern over the possible health hazards of a colorless, odorless liquid named PCB that some scientists hold to be even more dangerous than DDT, to which it has a close chemical resemblance.

title: Orioles Clinch Title Tie
AMEX SLATES PLANS FOR INCORPORATION
description: The American Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday to incorporate as a nonprofit organization and said its membership had approved constitutional amendments to do so. The exchange has traditionally operated as an unincorporated association.

title: Renata Scotto Shows Artistry in Met's Rigoletto
description: Since Verdi's Rigoletto was performed by the Metropolitan Opera last season, the return of the work on Tuesday night was not a momentous occasion, but the performance was not without interest.

title: Abrams and Sutton Warn Of Fight on Transit Bonds
description: The Borough Presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx said yesterday that they would fight Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue unless they were guaranteed that the 30cent subway fare would be maintained.

title: REVISIONS MADE IN POLICE DIVISION
description: The Police Department an nounced yesterday a series of changes in its plainclothes division, with new rules, an influx of young patrolmen and a system of grading policemen and slottting them for future assignments.

title: Insurers Shifting Urban Aid From Housing to fobs
description: In the heart of the black community of south central Los Angeles, construction is under way on what will eventually become a vast housing and commercial development known as Ujima Village.

title: Nolan Triumphs, 41
Wood, Field and Stream: Duck Plans
description: Along the Massachusetts coast and the off Shore is lands winter often comes slowly; there may be high, winds and rain but bitter cold is uricemmon,'even into December.

title: YIELDS MOVE UP ON UTILITY BONDS
Advertising:
description: How does the fourth quarter look from the vantage point of Madison Avenue's executive suites? Well, put it this way: Nobody is throwing a party, but then they're not jumping out of windows, either.

title: Chamber Ensemble in Concert After Talks With the Audience
description: Not everyone, it may be, yearns to be talked at by musicians. In a world of mounting babble, a few listeners may still look at the purely musical concert as a refuge of wordless peace.

title: DANISH GOVERNMENT TO AWAIT A RECOUNT
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 22 (Reuters)  Premier Hilmar Baunsgaard announced today that his centerright coalition Government would await a recount of the votes in yesterday's parliamentary elections before deciding whether to resign.

title: Pilot Dies in Crash
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 22 (UPI)  A small private plane crashed into a house early today, killing the pilot and injuring an occupant of the building. The pilot, the only person aboard the plane, a Piper Cherokee, was identified as Donald E. Gray, 24 years old, of North Augusta, S. C. The plane crashed into the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Collier. The family managed to escape unhurt except for 16yearold Margaret Ann Collier who suffered a broken collar bone.

title: Congress Bans ATest Unless Nixon Orders It
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Congress completed action today on an appropriations bill containing a ban on the planned underground nuclear test on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians unless the President gives his direct approval for the test.

title: Books of The Times
description: The trouble with reading books like these is that they really mess up your mind. Here I thought football players were little iridescent figures no bigger than beer cans, who dance around the TV screen on weekends, and hero come Neil Amdur, Chip Oliver and Bernie Parrish to propose that football is part of the real world and that the players are human. It really messes me up. Why, it almost makes me feel guilty for cheering the tiny white figures who beat the Green Bay Packers last Sunday, after I'd sworn I'd never give another thought to the NewYorktoNewJersey Giants. I mean it's almost as if there were a connection...

title: New Haven Line Hit By Wildcat Walkout
description: A wildcat strike of locomotive engineers that began midnight will disrupt service this morning on the New Haven division of the Penn Central, the railroad said early today.

title: PARIS TALK SESSION CANCELED BY HANOI
description: PARIS, Sept. 22The North Vietnamese delegation today called off tomorrow's session of the Paris pease conference in protest against the American bombings of North Vietnam.

title: 120 Teamsters in Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) About 120 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters demonstrated in front of their headquarters here today, demanding the immediate release from prison of James R. Hoffa, former president of the union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I recently had an experience about illegal parking at hydrants which proves that citizens can participate in helping the Police Department.

title: Ruling by H.U.D. May End Subsidized Slum Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22In a decision that could have an important national impact on where subsidized housing is to be built, the Department of Housing and Urban Development ruled today that a project previously approved for the central city of Philadelphia should have been rejected.

title: Wallace's Brother Linked to Bond Theft
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22A Montgomery newspaper reported today that, a ranking Alabama legislative official and a brother of Gov. George C. Wallace split a $60,000 payoff from a prominent Birmingham lawyer who handled the legal work on state bond issues in 1965 and 1967.

title: 10 Die in Philippines Clashl
description: MANILA, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Five Moslems and five Christians were killed and 14 people were wounded in two incidents yesterday in the southern Philippines, the police reported today. More than 70 people have been killed this month in clashes between Christians and Moslems.

title: Cowboys'
description: DALLAS, Sept. 22 (UPI)The Dallas Cowboys said today that rain and prospects of more of it would delay the surfacing of the parking area at the new Texas Stadium, so the club's Oct. 3 home opener against Washington, and possibly the Oct. 11 game against the New Yorks Giants, would be played in the Cotton Bowl.

title: White House Has Trouble Convincing Reporters That President Won't Slip Off to China
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Because the White House refuses to say even in the most general terms when President Nixon hopes to make his trip to China, it has had some trouble convincing reporters that he will not slip off secretly one morning, as his aide Henry A. Kissinger did last July. The few officials who know something about the preparations and who are willing to wink and gruntthough not speakon the subject suggest that Mr. Nixon and the Peking Government have settled on sometime early next year, without fixing a date.

title: $9Billion Backlog For Total Orders Reported by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company's total order backlog has reached a high of more than $9billion, or about the same as our annual'. sales, Fred J. Borch, chairman and chief executive officer, told some 350 security analysts at a special meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Pierre. Mr. Borch indicated that at the end of June more than half$5.6billionrepresented orders for power generating and delivery equipment.

title: SCOTT SAYS BROOKE WOULD HELP TICKET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, said today that Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts, the only Negro Senator, would be an asset to the G.O.P. national ticket.

title: Brynner Rides Again in 'Adios Sabata'
description: Yul Brynner, who apears to be as indestructible as many bad movie plots, is back again in "Adios Sabata," the latest of the Italian Westerns with dubbed English dialogue and filmed in color on Spain's rugged sierras, which clattered into the Victoria and 86th Street East Theaters yesterday.The laconic Brynner, astride a prancing sable stallion and wearing the grim expression and black gunslinger's outfit he affected 'way back in "The Magnificient Seven" simply gets lots of exercise this time. There is little that's magnificent in "Adios Sabata" other than the scenery, which obviously isn't man made."There's too much violence in the world," a local priest remarks sadly at the opening of the explosive festivities in "Adios Sabata." So, immediately thereafter, it's mostly shooting and gore, as Brynner, the soldier of fortune on the side of the revolutionaries striving to free Mexico from the yoke of Emperor Maximilian in 1867, goes after Colonel Skimmel, the Austrian bad guy, and his assorted connivers.There's nothing really historic or notable here except for the fact that Colonel Skimmel, a vicious blond dastard with muttonchop whiskers favored by Maximilian, is ready to take off with a hogshead full of gold dust that our good hombres led by Brynner want for obvious reasons.On second thought, the reasons turn out to be somewhat less than obvious since Brynner and the revolutionaries are afflicted by avarice, which makes the going just that much dustier.In any event, Brynner, a cool operator, is unusual in that he works with a gold-plated, sawed-off, repeating rifle that contains several shells and a cigar that our hero calmly puffs after each murderous fusillade.His unusual sidekicks include Dean Reed, a young, handsome American artist who appears to be working both sides of the struggle; Sal Borgese, a mute who can dispatch an adversary by flipping balls at them with his feet, and Joseph Persuad, a gypsy who goes into a flamenco stomp before each kill. It should be mentioned that Brynner and Reed do a four-handed piano rendition of a Schubert piece too. Incidentally, no one gets the gold and despite these strange talents it's a pleasure to say "Adios Sabata."

title: Executive Changes
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday the advancement of Colin MacLennan, former vice president and controller, and Herman A. Streller, former senior vice president, operations, as executive vice presidents. Tilford C. Gains, former vice president and economist, was elected senior vice president and economist. Named senior vice presidents are Dwight G. Allen, international; Albert E. Christie, legal; Arthur C. Langsdorf, real estate and mortgage; and Leslie Oland, operations. All formerly were vice presidents. In addition, Robert C. Isban; formerly deputy controller, was elected controller.

title: Japan and Soviet Union Sign Trade Agreement
description: TOKYO, Sept. 22 (AP)Japan and the Soviet Union today signed a new fiveyear trade and payments agreement, calling for an exchange of goods valued at $5.2billion during 197175, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: Boston Board Halts Move to Integrate Schools
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22The Boston School Committee has abandoned a threeweek integration effort and allowed some parents today to send their children to neighborhood schools largely along racial lines.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the Sept. 5 article Rehabilitation Plan for Venice Is Stalled by Local Bickering, which I find distressingly accurate except for one paragraph. If left unchallenged, it may damage efforts of the International Fund for Monuments and its Venice committee to raise funds for our oilgoing program of restorations in Venice, which will cost more than $1 million.

title: Rep Celler Backs Poff for High Court Inwire to President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Representatives Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, and William M. McCulloch, Republican of Ohio, urged President Nixon today to name Representative Richard H. Poff to the Supreme Court.

title: Cholera in Portugal
description: LISBON, Sept. 22, (Reuters) Portuguese health authorities said tonight that four confirmed cases of cholera had been detected at Almada, near Lisbon. The four people were said to be doing well in a Lisbon hospital.

title: Coup for Philadelphia Museum: Castiglione Show
description: PHILADELPHIAThe Philadelphia Museum of Art has scored a small coupno, take out the small and make it plain couphas scored a coup with an exhibition that has slipped onto the scene quietly, the first anywhere devoted to Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione, with a handsome catalogue that must stand for some time as the definitive work on this 17thcentury Genoese artist.

title: Redistricting Bill Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UN) The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bill suggesting that state legislatures complete the reapportionment of Congressional districts by Feb. 1, 1972. Federal law requires that after each 10year census the states redraw districts to reflect shifts in population. A committee source said that only 16 of an estimated 40 to 44 states that must reapportion before November, 1972, had completed the job.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Gromyko. The White House announced that President Nixon would meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, next Wednesday. The White House declined to say what they might discuss. Mr. Gromyko is in the United States to attend the United Nations General Assembly session and will confer with Secretary of State William P. Rogers in New York Friday.

title: Ma and Pa Telephone Concerns Dying Out
description: COPAKE, N. Y., Sept. 22The oldtime friendly telephone operator is disappearing in this rural area, but anyone with a problem can, pick up the phone, and talk directly with John Benedict (Ben) Ackley, president of the local telephone company.

title: Insiders'
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The lists include the following:

title: Students Urge Lindsay to Shun Race
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Two hundred student leaders from campuses all over the country urged Mayor Lindsay today to stay out of the Democratic Presidential race and endorse Senator George McGovern instead.

title: GOLDSMITH KEEPS SOLING SAIL LEAD
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 22 Bruce Goldsmith's Schroeder, from Chicago, maintained a 1point lead for Soling Class honors after finishing seventh in today's second race of Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's centennial series on Long Island Sound.

title: STOCKS TUMBLE AS VOLUME RISES
Facility for Militants Urged
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., Sept. 22A deputy commissioner who is regarded as chief troubleshooter for Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald said today that he would recommend to Mr. OSwald the establishment of a maximum Security facility to which the more militant people, the aggressive people within the state's prison population would be concentrated so they won't spread their poison to other inmates.

title: Jersey Delays Bill for Ban On NoReturn Containers
description: TRENTON, Sept. 22A bill that would ban nonreturnable beverage containers to reduce litter appeared to be immobilized today in a legislative committee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Is President Nixon's new economic policy fatally flawed because its fundamental requirement for success, an overwhelming sense of national unity and purpose, is clearly belied by society becoming increasingly polarized and divided?

title: Raynauld Will Take Over Canadian Economic Post
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 22 (UPI)Dr. Andre Raynauld, a 43yearold economics professor from the University of Montreal, will take over as chairman of the Economic Council of Canada, effective Jan. 1.

title: 2 Hostages Are Killed in France as 2 Fail in Jailbreak Attempt
description: PARIS, Sept. 22A prison nurse and a guard were found dead today after police blasted their way into a prison infirmary where they had been held hostage by two convicts. The police said that their throats had been slashed.

title: Autumn Debuts Today In Full, Living Color
description: Autumn, the season of the turning of the leaves, of crowded collegiate football stadiums, of the proliferation of chestnut venders, and of the compilation of Christmas lists arrives at 12:45 P. M. today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: New York City faces, it appears, even more drastic cuts in library service, far beyond those which have AL ready made the neighborhood branches unavailable to most working people. The New York Public Library claims it needs $240,000 in order to keep the Library of the Performing Arts functioning properly, and large additional sums to maintain the other special branches which are so important to the cultural life of the city.

title: VandalPlagued Children's Zoo in Jersey Closes
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 22When the tiny city farm known as the Children's Barnyard was closed yesterday, only a pigeon with a broken wing was left behindand this morning the crippled bird was found smashed to death, just as so many other animals at the yard had been tortured, maimed and killed recently.

title: RICHEY LEAVES DAVIS CUP SQUAD
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP)  Cliff Richey has quit the Davis Cup tennis team that is to meet Rumania in the Challenge round in Charlotte, N.C., Oct. 8 to 10.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent Democratic primary demonstrates that the leadership, both Reform and Regular, of the New York County Democratic party is fighting over issues which are a matter of almost complete disinterest to the members of the party. In one of the lowest turnouts in years, less than 6  per cent of the eligibles voted for Judge Midonick and less than 5 per cent for Judge Backer. The total turnout was slightly under 11 per cent.

title: Nixon Is Distressed by Senators Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  President Nixon, dist ressed over the franchise shift of the Washington Senators to Texas, said today he was shifting his allegiance as the nation's No. 1 baseball fan to the California Angels.

title: GEORGE H. HULL DIES; BUSINESS WRITER, 91
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Sept. 22 George Huntington Hull, a retired real estate manager and writer, died Monday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, after he was injured in an automobile accident in Millburn. He was 91 years old and lived at 108 Forest Drive.

title: GEORGE FRIED
description: George Fried, assistant director for financial affairs of Newark Beth Israel Medical Center, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack while driving in Newark. He was 58 years old and lived at 390 First Avenue here. The car Mr. Fried was driving was in a collision. No injuries were reported.

title: MAYOR OF SAN DIEGO LOSES 3DTERM BID
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 22 (AP)Mayor Frank Curran has been defeated in a bid for a third fouryear term as head of California's secondlargest city.

title: Prayers and Politics
description: The action by a bare majority of the House of Representatives to lift the ban on prayers in public schools a move to undermine rather than to amend the Constitution. The principles at issuereaffirmed in 1963 by the Supreme Court in an 8to1 rulingare both protection of the individual's freedom from religious coercion and prohibition of the establishment of any religion by the state or its publicly supported institutions.

title: Medina Found Not Guilty Of All Charges on Mylai
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 22Capt. Ernest L. Medina was acquitted today of all charges of involvement in the killing of civilians at Mylai.

title: 4 Rescued as Tug Sinks
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 22 (AP)The tug Columbia sank in Chesapeake Bay two miles south of Fisherman's Island today, 90 minutes after she reported to the Coast Guard that she was taking water. Her fourman crew was rescued by two Coast Guard utility vessels and a Coast Guard helicopter.

title: STUDY SAYS MAN ALTERS CLIMATE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22A panel of 30 ecological specialists from 14 countries has found that man is unintentionally altering elements in the world's climate and may change the climate of Western Europe.

title: Carty Cleared of Charges, Ruled Justified in Fighting
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 22 (UPI)Municipal Judge Robert M. Sharp ruled today that Rico Carty was justified in fighting with three police officers last month and dismissed charges against the Atlanta Braves outfielder of assault and creating a turmoil.

title: Police Picketed in Protest Of West Side Drug Traffic
description: A group of youths and adults began a fast yesterday practically on the doorsteps of the 24th precinct station at 121 West 100th Street.

title: Communications Workers To Resume Talks Today
description: Negotiations will resume today between the Communications Workers of America and the New York Telephone Company in an effort to end the 10weekold strike by 38,500 craftsmen.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Sept. 22Many of the seven hundred or so persons who braved a downpour to gather in the chapel at Wake Forest University were puzzled at the news just in from Washington. The Senate had passed the draft bill, after gutting the Mansfield Amendment to withdraw all American troops from Vietnam in nine months.

title: Notes on People
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)The Mayor of Nashville said today lie was optimistic that the Nixon Administration would join the city in seeking to overturn a courtordered school busing plan.

title: Furniture: A Revival for Those Dark, Ornate Styles?
description: If Barbara D'Arcy is right about what women want in decorating this season, we're in for a bigger traditional revival than the one that dominated the sixties.

title: NEW AUTOPSY IS SET IN KILLING OF JUDGE
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Sept. 22 (UPI)Over the objections of his widow, the body of Judge Harold J. Haley, killed Aug. 7, 1970, in a gun battle at the Marin County Civic Center, was ordered exhumed today so that Ruchell Magee could try to prove he was not the judge's killer.

title: Petrosian in Buenos Aires For Match With Fischer
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 (UPI)  The grandmaster and former world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, arrived here today for the elimination matches with Bobby Fischer of the United States in the world chess tournament.

title: East Pakistani Guerrillas Reported Active in the West
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 22 The police in Karachi said today that Bengali guerrillas were apparently operating in West Pakistan as well as in East Pakistan.

title: City Planners Approve ModerateIncome Housing Plan for East Side Area
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday approved a revised plan for the Ruppert Brewery urban renewal area that eliminates the disputed luxury housing, proposed in 1968 but that includes 680 units of moderateincome housing, renting for about $90 a room.

title: Mother Sentenced to 5 Years
description: A 24yearold Bronx mother was sentenced yesterday to five years on probation for the starvation death of her 8monthold son. Bronx Supreme Court Justice Edward McCaffrey said Mrs. Edna Mae Young's treatment of her son, Mark, was more an act of ignorance than criminal neglect. Three of the woman's five other children are in foster homes while the remaining two are being cared for by a grandmother.

title: Kulikov, 60YearOld General, Is Named Chief of Soviet Staff
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22A 50yearold army general today replaced Marshal Matvei V. Zakharov, 73, as the chief of the General Staff.

title: Youth Convicted of Kidnapping Quebec's Slain Labor Minister
description: MONTREAL, Thursday, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Bernard Lortie was found guilty last night of kidnapping Pierre Laporte, Quebec Minister of Labor and Immigration, after the 12man jury hearing his case had deliberated for three and a half hours.

title: NIXON MAY DELAY MILITARY RAISES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The White House said today that it was seeking some way to defer a scheduled $2.4billion military pay increase until the present wageprice freeze ends Nov. 13.

title: Varnish Kills 20 in India
description: MADRAS, India, Sept. 22 (Reuters)Twenty people died) here today after drinking varnish, the police reported.

title: AUSTIN C. CHESHIRE
description: Austin C. Cheshire, a former officer and trustee of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Garden City, L. I.

title: Chinese Opening Lima Office
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 22 (AP)A delegation of Chinese officials has arrived in Lima to open a commercial office under terms of a trade agreement signed five months ago. The agreement calls for exchange of commercial offices and granting most favored nation status in sale and purchase of certain products.

title: To Files, Upset of Packers Was Anything but Esthetic
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 22 A lot of things went into the New York Giants seasonopening victory over the Packers in Green Bay on Sunday, but the finishing touch in that minor miracle.belonged to Jim Files, the secondyear middle linebacker.

title: MORRIS M. SATIN
description: Morris M. Satin, a former president of the Jewish Educadon Committee of New York, died Monday at his home, 80 Central Park West, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Planner of Global Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 22Nine months hence what many consider a small miracle in international relations will occur: Representatives of most of the world's nations will meet at Stockholm to take collective action on global environmental problems.

title: Experts in Hong Kong Skeptical Of Reason for Dropping Parade
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 22Specialists in Chinese affairs here were skeptical today of the explanation given in Peking that a big National Day parade and rally on Tienanmen Square Oct. 1 would not be held because the Government had decided to scale down the observances.

title: Inmate Just Released From Attica Says Revolt Was Originally Scheduled for July 4
description: BATAVIA, N. Y., Sept. 22A prisoner who was released from the Attica Correctional Facility today said last week's revolt had been planned for July 4, but was postponed after stool pigeons had warned the authorities. He said the revolt stemmed from prison conditions not from radical ideology.

title: Giants Not Moving
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP)Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants, said today he had absolutely no interest in considering possible offers to move the San Francisco franchise to Washington.

title: British Press Shutdown Is Ended by Settlement
description: LONDON, Sept. 22The dispute between printers and publishers that halted production of national newspapers for four days was settled tonight.

title: JAMES WESTERFIELD, CHARACTER ACTOR
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 22 (AP) James Westerfield, a burly character actor who often played a tough policeman, died of a heart attack on Monday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills. He was 58 years old.

title: Whites Volunteer a Busing Program
description: TULSA, Okla.I hate to sound like I'm waving a banner, but I guess we did put our liberal money where our liberal mouths were, said Mrs. R. W. Caldwell.

title: Deposit Refunds on SST Pact Aid Pan Am, T.W. A. Profits
Delegates of 3 Small New Members Enter the Mainstream at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Sept. 22Diplomats from the United Nations three new member countriesBhutan, Bahrain and Qatarcompleted the rites of admission to the world organization today.

title: Petrified Wood Collection Used to Build Ranch House
description: MIAMI (AP)Frank Luther, 76 years old, decided a year ago to turn his collection of petrified wood into a model ranch house.

title: Soviet Is Relaxing Its Official Attitude On Private Autos
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22The Soviet Union announced today the start of production on the second main assembly line of its Italianbuilt Fiat plant and unveiled the most complete set of statistics on car output and ownership yet published in its official press.

title: ANNE LINDBERGH TO PUBLISH DIARY
description: Anne Morrow Lindbergh will publish selections from her letters and diaries, starting with her school years and continuing through World War II, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich announced yesterday.

title: Rotten Boroughs, Rotten Board
description: When Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel rules that the mandated composition of New York City's. Board of Elections discriminates unfairly against the voters in three of the city's five boroughs because all its members come from the other two boroughs, he is manifestly correct. To continue the board as if Manhattan and Brooklyn are all there is to the city is to perpetuate a form of discredited rottenborough government.

title: SCHOOL BUS RUNS CONTINUED IN CITY
description: School bus operators agreed yesterday to continue to transport 116,000 city pupils until at least Nov. 13, when the current wageprice freeze ends, despite the latest Federal refusal to exempt their new contracts from emergency controls.

title: Senate Rejects a Move by McGovern for $339Million Cut in Funds to Develop a Supersonic Bomber
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22A Senate weary from a protracted fight over the draft settled down today with little apparent enthusiasm or interest to its annual debate on the defense budget and routinely supported development of a new supersonic bomber for the Air Force.

title: Clifton C. Carter Is Dead at 53; Was Johnson's Campaign Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Clifton C. Carter, a close aide in most of President Johnson's political campaigns, died in Arlington (Va.) Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. He was 53 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: DRUG MAY COMBAT RARE NEW DISEASE
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 22  A South African doctor, as the result of experiments he made on pigs, has suggested that an inexpensive drug might counteract the terrifying symptoms of a new disease that occurs, on rare occasions, when some patients undergo surgery.

title: $250,000 Indemnity
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 22 (UPI) Bobby Bragan, the president of the Texas League, said today he expected the league would receive about $250,000 in indemnity for the Washington Senators move into the DallasFort Worth area, but that his chief problem now was finding a new home for the Spurs' franchise.

title: BHUTTO DEMANDS ELECTIONS IN 1971
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 22Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, leader of West Pakistan's majority party, implied today that his party might begin armed resistance to the military Government if it did not cede power by the end of the year.

title: BOSTON RECEIVES LINDSAY WARMLY
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22Mayor Lindsay of New York was introduced to a group of business and civic leaders here tonight as our charismatic leader by Mayor Kevin White of Boston.

title: Isaac Newton Revival Seeks Clues to Tortured Scientist's Genius
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  If ever there was a mad scientist., it was Isaac Newton.

title: Dr. White Denies Role
description: PEKING, Thursday, Sept. 23 Dr. Paul Dudley White, an eminent United States cardiologist who is visiting Peking at the invitation of the Chinese Medical Assoication, said last night that Chinese doctors have assured him that Chairman Mao is in excellent condition.

title: Don't Bother Me to Bow
description: Vinnette Carrol's Urban Arts Corps revue, Don't Bother Me, I Can't Cope, will be presented off Broadway in November by Arch Lustberg and Ed Padula at a theater to be announced. The show has choreography by Talley Beatty. The company will include Alex Bradford and his gospel singers and Micki Grant, singer.

title: Bengali Refugees Say Soldiers Continue to Kill, Loot and Burn
description: KUTIBARI, India, Sept. 21The latest refugees from East Pakistan report that the Pakistani Army and its civilian collaborators are continuing to kill, loot and burn despite the central Government's public avowals that it is bent on restoring normalcy and winning the confidence of the Bengali people.

title: Brazilian Forces on Alert After Terrorist's Death
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 22 Brazil's security forces were placed on the alert today following the death of a terrorist leader, Carlos Lamarca, a former army captain.

title: New Plan Is Backed for World Court
description: RACINE, Wis., Sept. 22A group of lawyers, jurists and law scholars, after meeting here for four days, proposed last week a new plan for establishing an international criminal court and additional offenses specified as international crimes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The great social value of an independent, impartial medical examiner system has been dramatically demonstrated again with the reports on the deaths at Attica State Prison. The confusion and distortion have been cut through and a clear report has been made by Dr. John F. Edland, a trained forensic pathologist, the medical examiner in Rochester.

title: Brezhnev, Visiting Belgrade, Denies Doctrine of Limited Sovereignty
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 22Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, arrived in Yugoslavia today and said he had come to discuss a whole line of important questions. Tonight, alter having begun talks wish President Tito, the Soviet leader delivered a toast at a dinner in his honor that appeared to be a conditional affirmation of noninterference in Yugoslavia's affairs. He denied that there was any doctrine of limited sovereignty for Communist states. Mr. Brezhney, who arrived here at the start of a Soviet diplomatic offensive launched in many parts of the world in apparent response to growing Chinese Communist influence, said at the airport that he wanted to talk about further development of SovietYugoslav relations and of party connections. He also mentioned current events in international life and the world situation in general. President Tito, who greeted him, stressed that cooperation between our two countries is based on equality and mutual respect and restated Yugoslavia's policy of nonalignment. He did so again later in blunter terms, at tonight's dinner. In his toast, Mr. Tito said that peace in Europe required a system of relationships that insured full independence, inviolability of frontiers and protection from aggression, use of force and pressure or threats of force.

title: With Chefs Scarce, Haute Cuisine is Forced to Edit Escoffier
description: To the layman, haute cuisine means expensive French food served in expensive restaurants To a chef however it is a science and a style, a classic way of approaching food that was codified by Escoffier in his Guide Culinaire. It does not depend on chic but on long years of apprenticeship for the chef.

title: Ballets Canadiens Performs Tommy As Warren Bows
description: After a long tour, Les Grands Ballets Canadiens has returned to City Center with its successful acid rock opera ballet Tommy. More a cycle of songs than an opera and more a sequence of tableaus vivants than ballet, Tommy creates its own theatrical form swinging around the pounding music and ironic lyrics created by The Who.

title: TROOP MOVEMENTS REPORTED INCHINA
description: Diplomatic reports from Peking said yesterday that the Chinese armed forces had been placed on alert and that unusual troop movements were occurring in various parts of China.

title: 3 Flee to West Berlin
description: BERLIN. Sept. 22 (Reuters) Three East Germans slipped unnoticed across the heavily guarded and fortified East German border into West Berlin last night, the police reported today.

title: TOKYO CRITICIZED ON ECONOMIC AIM
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22Speaking against the background of President Nixon's new economic policies, the leading executives of the United States textile industry charged here today that Japan is practicing the ultimate in economic nationalism as far as international trade is concerned.

title: Bisa Diatur
description: The election of Adam Malik as President of the United Nations General Assembly is a personal triumph for Indonesia's dynamic Foreign Minister and a favorable portent for this crucial U.N. session.

title: AMEX'S RESULTS WORST IN 7 WEEKS
Dr. Claudia MoholyNagy, Environmental Planning Aide
description: Dr. Claudia MoholyNagy, director of the Victor Gruen Foundation for Environmental Planning, died Tuesday night in New York Hospital. She was 35 years old and lived in Los Angeles

title: Boulez, in a Bow, Takes Podium at Philharmonic
$193Million in Auction Bids Are Accepted by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  The Federal National Mortgage Association said yesterday it accepted $193million of the $437.5million in bids submitted in Monday's free market system auction for mortgage commitments.

title: U.S., JAPAN RENEW FIGHT ON TEXTILES
description: TOKYO, Sept , 22After a simmering summer truce, the textile war between the United States and Japan has ,erupted again. And, the Japanese say, the Americans shot first.

title: U.S. LOSES ROUND IN U.N. CAMPAIGN FOR 2 CHINA PLAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22The United States today lost the first skirmish in its campaign to prevent the expulsion of the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan from the United Nations.

title: Lindsay Praises Printers At Opening of Exhibit Here
description: Mayor Lindsay heralded the printing industry yesterday as one of the major industries of New York City at a ceremony opening a campaign by city printers to increase their share of the market.

title: Revised Penal Code on Coast To Be Proposed to Legislature
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 22California's criminal laws governing sexual conduct, gambling and abortions would be revised under proposals to be submitted to the Legislature next year as a result of an eightyear study of the state's penal code by a legislative committee.

title: SEZNA POSTS UPSET IN U.S. SENIOR GOLF
description: PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Sept. 22Wally Sezna of Greenville, Del., upset David Goldman of Dallas, a twotime runnerup, 3 and 2, in the first round of the United States senior amateur golf championship today at Sunnybrook Golf Club.

title: Phone Off the Hook
description: Nearly a quartermillion unfilled orders for new telephones have piled up in the ten weeks since installers, linemen and maintenance employes of the New York Telephone Company went on strike. Only the high degree of phone automation, plus the roundtheclock efforts of managerial personnel and Bell System troubleshooters brought in from other areas, has prevented a major breakdown of servicenone too good even before the strike.

title: Threatened Couple To Remove Negro In White Cemetery
description: DADE CITY, Fla., Sept. 22 (UPI)Threats and resentment over the burial of a black man in an allwhite cemetery have resulted in a decision to transfer the body to an isolated Negro cemetery.

title: C.B.S. Presses Complaint Against Teleprompter Corp.
description: A trial began in Federal Court here yesterday on a complaint by the Columbia Broadcasting System that the Teleprompter Corporation was relaying programs from outside its franchise areas.

title: Personal Finance: Prepaid Legal Help
description: Helen Brown, a member of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers union in Chicago, is planning to buy a homer sometime next year and will need a lawyer.

title: PROTANTO, $6.80, CAPTURES STYMIE
description: In a threehourse blanket finish that had the crowd of 20,792 at Belmont Park waiting and wondering after the completion of the 1mile event, Cragwood Stable's Protanto won the 16th running of the Stymie Handicap yesterday.

title: Jewish Woman Sentenced Over Letter to Kosygin
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22A Jewish woman who sent an anonymous letter to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has been sentenced to three years confinement on charges of slandering the Soviet state, a Central Asian newspaper has reported.

title: Long Gray Lines Break Ranks For a Fun Match at the Point
description: For years plebes at West Point have recited: A cadet may not have a horse, wife, dog or mustache. So it will be a bit of an oddity on Sunday, when a match dog show will be held on the Military Academy grounds. As far as we can ascertain, this will be the first at the academy in its 169 years, said Lieut. Col. Samuel J. Newsom Jr., president of the new West Point Dog Club. It will not be a match sanctioned formally by the American Kennel Club; it will be strictly a fun affair. A dog won't have to be A.K.C. registered. Anyone paying the entry fee of $2 may walk into the ring with his dog for judging. There is no admission fee and parking spaces are plentiful.

title: New Group Formed
description: Critics of the state's handling of the Attica uprising demanded prison reform yesterday and disclosed plans to demonstrate sympathy for the dead prisoners and give aid to their families.

title: Go Back Where You Came From
description: On the lips of almost every person in America is that strange wordAttica. Few, however, are willing to admit that had the American public voiced its concern when they were asked to by those inmates (weeks before), we would not have the blood of 40, human beings on our hands. We forget that some of those same people asked for these same basic demands a year earlier at the Tombs and in Queens. They were duped at that time by empty promises.

title: Thomas Gangemi Jr. to Run for Mayor of Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 22Thomas Gangemi Jr., whose father was forced to resign as Mayor, in 1963 because he lacked United States citizenship, announced today that he would seek the post in the special municipal elections here Nov. 2.

title: Advertising:
description: A European marketing company whose parent concern is in Australia has just introduced into the United States (the world's No. I marketing power) a cleansing cream for black women that was developed in Africa by a white chemist.

title: LOAN AIDE OUSTED FROM HIS CITY JOB

He was accused of having approved payment of $268,000 for slum renovation work that had not been performed, according to Commissioner of investigation, Robert K. Ruskin.

title: The Mystery of the Lake

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Toughness. Yes, toughness. That is what we admire here. Here in Washington. The nation's capital, baby, and don't you forget it.

description: The first issue of (More): A Journalism Review a monthly 20page tabloid magazine intended to be the gadfly of the print and broadcast press reached the stands yesterday and its owners celebrated with a news conference at its offices at 11 East 35th Street.

title: C. WYMAN POOR
description: ONANCOCK, Va., Sept. 22Cornelius Wyman Poor, a retired executive of the Chatham Manufacturing Company, a blanket manufacturer, died on Friday. He was 78 years old.

title: SMITH BEATS PARUN ON COAST, 64, 64
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI) Stan Smith, the United States Open champion, easily defeated New Zealand's Onny Parun, 64, 64, to advance to the third Tound of the $73,000 Pacific Southwest open, tennis tournament today.

description: The Association of American Publishers held its fall meeting yesterday amid warnings that Government censorship and radical pressure groups are increasingly threatening the nation's First Amendment freedoms.

description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 22Governor Rockefeller was applauded here today at a $100aplate Republican breakfast after he had been praised for his actions in the Attica prison uprising, which led to the deaths of 10 hostages and 30 inmates.

title: Hurricane Irene Now Olivia
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)  Hurricane Irene now has been renamed Olivia. The Weather Bureau changed the designation Monday when it passed across the CentralAmerican peninsula from the Atlantic to the Pacific. A different set of names is used for the two oceans.

title: Prices in Nation Up 0.3%;
Harris May Announce Candidacy Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma will announce his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination on Friday, informed sources said today.

title: Rochester Wins Series
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 22 (UPI)Rich Coggins collected four hits and scored five runs tonight as Rochester of the International League defeated Denver of the American Association, 96, and won the Junior World Series, four games to three.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES HAVE STEADY DAY
description: Trading of soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday was very steady, largely in response to early speculative short covering. Soybeans closed 1 cents to cents a bushel higher.

title: Market Place: Drop Is Forecast In Interest Rates
description: John Wright, the benevolent despot who presides over Wright Investors Service in Bridgeport, Conn., has always concentrated on those quality stocks we sometimes call investmentgrade issues. And, in his issue of Investment Advice and Analysis just out, he extols their virtues as usual.

title: Court Bars Job Action at Nassau Community College
description: MINEOLA, L. I. Sept. 22Nassau County obtained an injunction in State Supreme Court here today barring continued job action at Nassau Community College in a dispute over an increase in teaching hours.

title: Soviet Union Hoping to Improve the Initiative of Workers by Offering Them Instruction in Economics
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22  The Soviet leadership has ordered a wideranging program of economic instruction to spur the initiative of workers and stimulate interest in the results of their labor.

title: City Within City Plan Supported on S.I.
description: A Staten Island city within a citya project that in the next two decades would include a dozen communities with a population of more than 420,000 in a 10,600acre southern area of the borough  won support yesterday from most speakers at a public hearing on the proposal.

description: The New York Jets elected their team captains yesterday while preparing to oppose a quarterback recommended to the St. Louis Cardinals by their coach.

title: Drat! Signs Young Actor
description: Walter Bobbie has been signed for the leading juvenile role in Drat! the new musical opening Oct. 18 at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater. He will be playing opposite Jane Connell and Bonnie Franklin in the Richard Barr and Charles Woodward production.

title: Bridge:
description: The keenest spectator in the International Team semifinal playoff match beginning at the New York Hilton tomorrow evening will be Lee Hazen of New York.

title: Film: Desperate Couple:MacLaine and Mars Star in Gilroy Work
description: If there were such things as urban renewal projects for people, then Sophie and Otto Bentwood (Shirley MacLaine and Kenneth Mars), a couple approaching lovelessness and middle age on the outskirts of Brooklyn Heights, would be likely prospects for immediate aid.Otto is a well-to-do lawyer and Sophie is an occasional translator of books, but their emotional lives are run down and scarred as their renovated brownstone is handsome and spruce. They are childless, middle-class city dwellers, coming apart in a world whose problems have grown beyond the liberal's capacity to comprehend, much less solve.The time of "Desperate Characters" is now, and it could be taking place just a year or two before Jules Feiffer's "Little Murders." In the vision of Frank D. Gilroy, who produced and directed the film, as well as adapted Paula Fox's novel, New York is still functioning, but all of the omens are bad.When Sophie feeds a stray cat, it bites her and for several days she's threatened with a series of rabies shots. Otto, contemptuous of his law partner, who specializes in needy cases, is, nevertheless, a guiltily easy mark for a fast-talking, black chizzler, who insinuates himself into the house to use the telephone and then walks out with a nonrepayable $10 loan.The subways they ride are inhabited by two kinds of people, those who talk to themselves and those who pretend not to notice. The streets are boobytrapped with garbage and dog excrement and drunks who might be stiffs. There's an obscene phone call, a rock tossed through a window and a depressing visit with Leon, an English professor who won't eat in the cafeteria because he's afraid someone will slip a little acid into his soup.I describe all of this at some length because it reflects the quality of the film itself, which is full of the details of urban desperation, painfully and accurately observed at eyelevel, without exploitation or condescension. Yet I must confess that "Desperate Characters" left me, if not unmoved, then unenriched. It's as if its cheerlessness had been bottled straight, without the additive that transforms recognizable experience into art.I've not read Miss Fox's novel, but I've been told that Gilroy's adaptation is a model of fidelity, even to careful inconclusiveness with which it treats the future of the Bentwood mariage. In every respect, the screenplay is a vast improvement over Gilroy's Pulitzer Prize-winning "The Subject Was Roses." Its literary style, however, is similar, and it's a style to which I, for one reason or another, find it difficult to respond.His characters talk in great chunks of theatrical exchanges, and monologues, which not only deny the splendid accuracy of the situations and the settings, but also somehow make me suspicious of the integrity of the characters. This is especially true of the supporting characters, who are always telling us too much, remembering too many details out of the past, nudging us for sympathy and never letting us discover them at our own speed.In drama, as in real life, people have to earn the right to bestow confidences, as well as to receive them. There is a dramatic license for just about everything, including Gilroy's style of theater, a style that I associate with the more serious television writing of the 1950's. It is not, however, for me.Perhaps because they have more time on screen, and are less pressed to make their points quickly, the stars of the film come off best, which is not always the case in movies with lots of little character-specialty numbers. I have nothing but admiration for both Miss MacLaine, who seems to be as sweet and appealing as a woman at the end of her rope can be, and Mars, whose denseness and cruelty are obviously the eroded remains of decency."Desperate Characters," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, marks Gilroy's debut as a film director, and I have a feeling that the director has perfectly served the writer. That is to say that Gilroy has realized the movie he intended to make. I wish I liked it more.

title: House Passes Airways Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)The House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation to make sure that airway user taxes were spent for the purposes intended by Congress  airways modernization and airport development. The Commerce Committee said that the Administration had been withholding part of the special tax money and spending some on related but not authorized work.

title: Curran Opposes Bill to Let 4 American Lines Sell Ships to Foreign Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Joseph E. Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, said today that he was completely opposed to proposed legislation, as it now stands, that would enable the owners of four leading American ship lines to sell vessels, including the liner United States, to foreign buyers.

title: CITY SEEKS TO FILL 635 AGENCY JOBS
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the opening of recruitment drive to fill 635 jobs made available under the Federal Emergency Employment Act to residents of the city who are unemployed or underemployed.

title: Bronx Welfare Recipient Arrested on Fraud Charge
description: Commissioner of Investigation Robert K. Ruskin announced yesterday the arrest of a Bronx welfare recipient who allegedly defrauded the city of more than $11,000 while she was employed as a nurse's aide in a Queens hospital.

title: NIXON AND GROMYKO TO MEET WEDNESDAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (Reuters)President Nixon will confer at the White House next Wednesday with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, the White House announced today.

title: Pirates Defeat Cardinals, 51; Repeat as Division Champions
Germans Again Fail to Agree on Berlin
description: BERLIN, Sept. 22Talks between the two German states aimed at completing the Big Four agreement on Berlin remained deadlocked today after a fourth fruitless meeting.

title: Paper Institute Elects Head
description: The American Paper Institute, at its annual meeting in Colorado Springs, Colo., meeting elected David L. Luke 3d as its new chairman. Mr. Luke is president and chief executive officer of Westweb Corporation.

title: Knicks'
description: Tickets for the Knicks' two preseason doubleheaders will go on sale today at the Madison Square Garden box office at 10 A. M.

title: DEVICE IS TESTED THAT SCANS SEAS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 22Scientists of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have developed a method for aerially monitoring one of the most vital activities on earth the biological productivity of lakes and seas.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22Following are the texts of the two American draft resolutions on China that were formally introduced in the General Assembly today:
