description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Donald T. Regan, chairman of the board of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., said that a new agency might be needed to regulate the se curities markets of the future.

title: COPPER STRIKE ENDS AS UNIONS VOTE PACT
description: BUTTE, Mont., Sept. 25 (UPI) Approval of a new threeyear copper contract by striking An aconda Company craft unions has ended a strike that cost Montana workers $14million in wages and at its height made 39,000 workers idle in five western states.

title: About Pro Football
description: The Redskins are favored over the Giants in New York's home operer Sunday. That brings a partial black out with two games on tele vision, Dallas at Philadelphia, Channel 2 at 1 P.M., and Oakland at San Diego, Chan nel, 4, 4 P.M. The Jets play at St. Louis on Monday night, Channel 7 at 9 P.M., with the Cardinals fa vored, too. Here is a preview of all games with wonlost records in paren theses:

title: REGENTS PROPOSE A COLLEGE REGION
description: The State Board of Regents will establish a council of major college and university leaders today to devise a master plan for the joint development of public and private higher edu cation in New York City.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Vice President Agnew assailed four of the leading Democratic Presidential prospects today, characterizing their support for cuts in defense spending as reckless and appalling.

title: Suspect in Murder And Bank Robbery Is Seized by F.B.I.

description: To the Editor:

title: House on 102d Street Is Called A Center. of Narcotics Trade
description: Irate neighborhood leaders said today that a house on West 102d Street, which the police called a public nuisance, was a center of the narcotics trade. But people in the house said they felt differently, insist ing that it had seen a heap of living and was just a home.

title: BridgeOlympiad Event Here to Aid Multiple Sclerosis Society
description: Teams captained by Joel Stuart of New York and Lew Mathe of Los Angeles clash tonight at the New York Hil ton in the semifinal stage of the international team play offs.

title: M'GOVERN ACCUSES THIEU ON ATTACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern asserted today that the rioters who hurled firebombs and stones at him in Saigon last week included South Vietnam ese civildefense workers hired by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) The Federal court trial in which the United Mine Work ers Union is accused of rigging its 1969 presidential election was recessed today so at torneys for the Government and the union could shorten the list of witnesses giving testi mony.

title: Stage: O'Neill and Shaw Are TimeTested in the Middle West
description: MINNEAPOLISIt is in structive to see how some playwrights seem to grow in stature with the passage of time, while others fade. At Michael Langham's Guthrie Theater here in Minneapolis the company has just started previewing two major 20th century plays, Eugene O'Neill's A Touch of the Poet and Bernard Shaw's Misalliance, a contrasted pair from an American Irish man and English Irishman.

title: WALSH PROPOSES LOAN FUND CURBS
description: New regulations for the Municipal Loan Fund, designed to prevent abuses of the kind that have been exposed during current investigations, were proposed yesterday by Albert A. Walsh, head of the Housing and Development Administra tion.

title: Senate Is Prodded By Administration To Act on Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  The Nixon Administration stepped up pressure today for speedy Senate action on wel fare reform as the national cost of welfare payments was re ported to have soared by a rec ord amount during the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: Chlorine Gas Leak Drives 1,500 From Yonkers Homes and Fells 5
description: About 1,500 persons were evacuated from their homes in a 20block area of southeast Yonkers early today after poisonous chlorine gas fumes began leaking from storage fa cilities at a nearby reservoir, the police reported.

title: TV REPAIR SHOPS SCORED IN HEARING
description: Do you feel you have been gypped by a television repair man?

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  President Nixon indicated to night that some form of export subsidy may be necessary for those sectors of American in dustry and agriculture that were faced with unfair bar riers in foreign countries.

title: STATE DEPT. SEEKS MORE BENGALI AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 23 The State Department was re ported today to be planning to ask Congress for an additional $250million for relief of Pakis tani refugees in India and for rehabilitation programs in East Pakistan.

title: U.S. Gives Seoul a Textile Ultimatum
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 23  South Korea received a formal notice today that un less she concludes an agree ment with the United States to restrict exports of noncotton textile goods Washington would have to impose mandatory im port quotas starting Oct. 15.

title: Sir Edgar Whitehead, 66, Dies; A Former Leader of Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Sept. 23Sir Edgar Whitehead, the last Prime Minister of Rhodesia who favored an accommodation be tween the races, died during the night in a nursing home at Newbury, Berkshire. He was 66 years old.

title: The Medina Acquittal
description: After President Nixon abruptly intervened last April in the case of Lieut. William C. Calley Jr., convicted of murdering Vietnamese civilians in Mylai, the Army prose cutor wrote an anguished letter to the President. In it the prosecutor, Capt. Aubrey M. Daniels, said: You have subjected a judicial system of this country to the criti cism that it is subject to political influence.  What will be the impact of your decision upon the future trials, particularly those of the military?

title: Suspect Held in Armory Blast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today it had arrested Charles Noell Hess, 29 years old, of Salinas in con nection with the burglary and bombing of the National Guard armory at De Laveaga Park in Santa Cruz July 24. Robert Gebhardt, special agent in charge, said the suspect ar rested late yesterday in a re mote area of Santa Cruz County near Corralitos. He said that a large cache of weapons taken in the burglary had been recovered.

title: The Money Men
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23As pres ently organized, the House of Repre sentatives is insufficiently responsive to the urban and social needs of the nation. Its seniority system and com mittee structure are forces for the status quo and a constant drag on progressive reform. They work more in behalf of the interests and conserva tive attitudes of rural and smalltown Americans than of the interests and opinions of the cities and their suburbs where the majority of Americans live.

title: GOLDSMITH VICTOR, LEADS SOLING CLASS
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 23 Bruce Goldsmith's Schroeder won another race in the Sea wanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's special centennial series for Soling and Shields Class yachts today on Long Island Sound and now leads Carl Gus taf Piehl of Stockholm by 5 points in the race for Soling honors.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS WINS PRICE RISES
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23  The American Motors Corporation said today that it had raised prices on its 1972 cars with the approval of the Federal Government's price control office.

title: Alioto Jury Panel Instructed
description: VANCOUVER, Wash., Sept. 23 (UPI)Prospective jurors in the $2.3million civil lawsuit against Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco were instruct ed today that the Mafia was not involved in the case. Judge Donald L. Gaines made the statement after one prospective juror indicated she was dis turbed by reference to the Mafia in the questioning of another juror. The questioning involved Mr. Alioto's libel suit against Look magazine for an article that linked him to the Mafia.

title: Report on I.M.F. Plan Lifts Currencies
description: PARIS, Sept. 23Major for eign currencies rose today on combustible foreignexchange markets as officials of 118 na tions began departing for Washington for a week of meet ings on the monetary crisis.

title: POVMAN ELECTED TO CITY COUNCIL
description: The City Council yesterday elected Morton Povman, a Queens district leader, as Coun cilman from the 15th Council District, replacing Donald R. Manes, who was elected Queens Borough President Wednesday.

title: Foss Gets Brooklyn Post
description: Lukas Foss has been named conductor and music adviser of the Brooklyn Philharmonia for the 197172 season. He succeeds Siegfried Landau who recently resigned. Mr. Foss's most re cent permanent post was that of music director of the Buffalo Philharmonic. The Brooklyn Philharmonia will open its sea son of four concerts at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Dec. 11.

description: To the Editor:

title: Still a Big Generation Gap When It Comes to Question of Sex
description: For some parents, even in a time of changing attitudes about sex, the ques tion of how to deal with their teenage children is answered simply. I'd chain my daughter up if I had to, says one father.

title: Another Inmate Dies
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 23 Another inmate, wounded by gunfire during the police as sault on State Correctional Fa cility here 10 days ago, died early this morning.

description: The Lockheed Electronics Company, a unit of the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation, said yesterday that it had received a $50million Navy contract for the production of shipboard gunfire control systems. The contract follows an initial $27 million award made last year for the development of the system.

title: U.S. AIDES CAUTION SAIGON GENERALS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23  United States of ficials have passed the word to South Vietnamese generals that any coup ?? against President Nguyen Van Thieu in the present elections crisis would lead to the ending of American support.

title: 572746 Wins in Jersey;
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 23 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 572746.

description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 23The New York Rangers, one of the National Hockey League's bestrounded squads, pared their training roster to 22 players today, three above the limit for regularseason play.

description: TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP) Finance Minister Mikio Mizuta said today Japan will propose creation of a new world mon etary system with the Interna tional Monetary Fund's special drawing rights on gold playing a pivotal role.

title: Hanoi Boycotts Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Sept. 23 (Reuters) The 130th session of the Viet nam peace talks was canceled today because of a Communist boycott in protest against United States air raids Tuesday over North Vietnam. Hanoi's chief negotiator, Xuan Thuy, in formed the United States and Saigon delegations of his deci sion to call off the talks and requested that the next session be held Sept. 30.

title: PACKERS' DEVINE CONSOLES HYLAND
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 23 A telegram arrived for Bob Hyland a few days ago and now the 6foot5inch, 250 pound guard, acquired last week from Chicago, doesn't feel quite so bad about his first game in a New York Giant uniform.

title: Freeze Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Following is policy state ment number 23 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23A vast program of day care and health services for children of all income levels was approved today by the House Education and Labor Committee.

description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an as terisk are followed by a recipe.

title: DOCTORS ASSAIL YOUTHCARE LAW
description: The full spectrum of the city's medical establishment told a state legislative commit tee yesterday that physicians should be allowed to treat teen agers without parents' consent.

title: Philadelphians Hail Return Of Ormandy and Premiere
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) A new piece by a distin guished American composer and the return of a conductor whose retirement had been feared highlighted the opening last night of the Philadelphia Or chestra's 73d concert season.

title: Joblessness in Britain and Ulster Is at Highest Level Since 1940
description: LONDON, Sept. 23Unem ployment in Britain and North ern Ireland rose in September to the highest level since 1940, the Government announced to day. Measures taken in July to stimulate the economy and pro vide more jobs have had no effect as yet, and the Govern ment is under increasing po litical attack.

title: Governor Links Bond Issue to City Fares
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept 23 Governor Rockefeller said to night that the Borough Presi dents of Manhattan and the Bronx and other politicians who were threatening to op pose his $2.5billion transporta tion bond issue unless the 30 cent New York City transit fare was retained were biting off their noses to spite their faces.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS TRADING DIPS
description: The stock market slipped lower in moderate trading after failing to rally from Wednes day's broad decline.

title: City Block: Small Landlords Cope With Large Problems
description: Nearly all the landlords on 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue know one another, or at least know something about one another. And to gether they make up a kind of gentry, joined in the mys teries of plumbing, painting and the collection of rents, and sometimes in the sour suspicion that their tenants are ready to rise up and do them in.

title: Thieu's Foes Trying to Unite to Defeat Him
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23  South Vietnam's many opposition groups, oft en considered weak cells of protest, are trying to band together to stop Nguyen Van Thieu in his unopposed bid for reelection next month.

title: Bond Market Slide Ends;
description: The bond market, buoyed by the thought that President Nixon again might say some thing that would push interest rates downward, ended its weeklong slide yesterday after noon.

title: Submarine to Do Research
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Sept. 23 (UPI)The deepdiving sub marine Alvin, aboard the re search ship Lulu, is expected to arrive off southern Florida Sept. 30 for two and a half months of oceanographic re search

title: and the Need for Distinction
description: After the Senate last year rejected President Nixon's appointment of G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court, as it had earlier rejected Clement F. Haynsworth Jr., Mr. Nixon asserted that it was not possible to get confirmation for a strict constructionist if he happened to come from the South. To the Southerners he sent the pledge that the day will come when men like Carswell and Haynsworth can and will sit on the High Court.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL ACCUSES CITIES OF JOBS RUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23A number of cities are making paper layoffs of employes to rehire them with funds in tended to provide jobs for the unemployed under the Emer gency Employment Act, the na tion's top manpower official disclosed today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Prices of soybean futures de clined 2 cents to 4 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade.

title: G.I,'S RESTRICTED FOR VIETNAM VOTE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday,  The 215,000 Amer ican servicemen in South Viet nam will be confined to their barracks and places of work until three days after the pres idential referendum Oct. 3.

description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 23 Mayor Julius Wilensky was nominated for a second term today by Republican voters, turning back a challenger sup ported by the party organiza tion.

title: HAVANA TO PERMIT ONEWEEK AIRLIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The Cuban Government has in formed the United States that it will permit a temporary resumption of the refugee air lift between Cuba and Miami for a week starting Monday.

title: Colombian Urges A Curb on Power Of Some in I.M.F.
description: BOGOTA, Sept. 23Colom bia's Finance Minister, Dr. Rod rigo Lllorente, today told Latin American economic policymak ers that the international mone tary system would be well served should trade ties be teen freeenterprise nations and the socialist countries of Europe and Asia so expend as to di lute the excessive power of some of the present members of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Memorial Planned Sunday For Mrs. Susan Oppenheim
description: A memorial service for Mrs. Susan R. P. Grace Oppenheim, reporter and publicist, who died here Sept. 14, will be in the First Unitarian Church Chapel, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn, Sunday, at 1:30 P.M. She was 68 years old and lived at 76 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

title: Students in Town of Attica Are Recovering From Shock
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 23In the JuniorSenior Attica Central School, the studentsmany of them children of guards at At tica prisonare just beginning to shake off the shock of the uprising and the bloody as sault in which fathers of some of their classmates were killed or faced death.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales for the week ended Sept. 18 totaled an estimated $7,512,000,000, an increase of 7 per cent from the $7,011,000, 000 sales for the corresponding week of last year. Department store sales for the latest week were an estimated $819million, an increase of 10 per cent above the $743million sales for the corresponding period last year.

title: 10Day Car Sales Surge; Comparison Is Difficult
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23  The automobile manufacturers to day reported 194,104 sales of United Statestype cars in the Sept. 1120 period, up 22 per cent from 159,201 a year be fore.

title: Spot Market Price Index Of Commodities Declines
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 107.2 from 107.6 last week.

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKS BILL ON CYCLAMATES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) The Nixon Administra tion has endorsed legislation to reimburse industry for losses caused by the Government's ban on cyclamate food sweet eners.

title: Senate Confirms Loomis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nomination of Philip A. Loomis, a veteran Securities and Exchange Com mission official, as a member of the S.E.C. for a term that runs until June 5, 1972.

title: 800 in Albany Protest the Attica Assault
description: ALBANY, Sept. 23  About 800 demonstrators marched for three miles through this city, today to the steps of the Capi tol in a protest rally against the storming last week of At tica prison.

title: B52's Bomb DMZ
description: SAIGON, Friday, Sept. 24 (AP)The United States com mand today reported a renewal of B52 bomber strikes against North Vietnamese positions in the southern half of the de militarized zone.

title: Canadian Breweries in Pact
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP)The completion of a co operation agreement between Canadian Breweries, Ltd., of Toronto and United Breweries CarlsbergTuborg of Copenhag en was announced today by the Carling Brewing Company of Waltham. Carling Black Label is Canadian's main brand.

title: JERSEY WOMEN WIN TEAM GOLF TROPHY
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 23 New Jersey won the Myra D. Paterson Trophy today for the first time since 1955 in the 42d annual intersectional team match of the Women's Metro politan Golf Association.

title: Newton Files Juror Suit
description: OAKLAND, Calif. Sept. 23 (UPI)Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, filed suit today seeking inclusion of 18 yearolds in the Alameda Coun ty panel of prospective jurors. Through his attorney, Charles Garry, he said that his involun tary manslaughter trial, sched uled for Oct. 12, should be post poned until 18yearolds were included.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 4,000 Pickets March at Hall To Protest a Variety of Things
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23Four thousand persons picketed Cobo Hall in downtown De troit this evening as they awaited the arrival of Presi dent Nixon.

title: Jail Deaths in France Lead Pompidou to Question Reform Moves
description: PARIS, Sept. 23  President Pompidou, responding to a wave of revulsion at the slay ing of two hostages by con victs yesterday, took issue to day with proposals for penal reform and the abolition of the guillotine.

title: France Bars Concession To U.S. Economic Policy
description: PARIS, Sept. 23President Georges Pompidou barred today any submission by France to the requirements of American policy and warned her partners against exorbitant conces sions at the conference of the International Monetary Fund starting next Monday.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING 600 REALTY DEALS
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is investigating a se ries of realestate deals, and its action is expected to result in the filing of criminal charges this year against more than a dozen brokers and other indi viduals.

title: STOCK DEPOSITORY IS SET ?? ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP)The Pacific Coast Stock Exchange announced today the opening of a new securities depository designed to reduce wasteful movement of stock certificates.

title: Lobbyist Ordered to Trial
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP)Patrick H. McLaughlin, Philadelphia's former Washing ton lobbyist, has been ordered held for trial on charges of de frauding the city with false ex pense accounts. Three wit nesses at a preliminary hearing in Magistrate's Court today, in cluding Representive William J. Green, Democrat of Pennsyl vania, denied Mr. McLaughlin had provided them with all the luncheons and dinners specified in the vouchers.

title: Urban Coalition Study Sees Cities Bankrupt by 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23A special commission established by the National Urban Coali tion to take a new look at the central cities concluded today that, if present trends continue, most cities by 1980 will be preponderantly black and brown, and totally bankrupt.

title: Leviss Named to Aid New Queens President
description: As one of his first acts, the new Queens Borough Presi dent, Donald R. Manes, yes terday appointed his prede cessor, Sidney Leviss, a special assistant until the end of the year at a salary of $1,000 a month.

title: City Council Delays Step On Theater
description: Because of questions raised over possible conflict of in terest involving members of the Rockefeller family, the City Council yesterday post poned final action on appro priating $5.2million for the acquisition and renovation of the Vivian Beaumont theater in Lincoln Center.

title: SCRIBNER WARNS SCHOOL BOARD 5
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner warned a Manhattan community school board yes terday that he would take ap propriate action if it did not rescind a local directive defy ing the central Board of Edu cation's mandated budget cuts.

title: Board of Directors Is Replaced At Deltec's Swift de la Plata
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 (AP)The board of directors of the financially troubled Swift de la Plata meatpacking company was replaced last night by a court order. The concern is owned by Deltec In ternational, an AmericanWest ternational, an American con cern based in the Bahamas.

title: 10 at Westbeth Get Eviction Notices
description: Eviction notices for non payment of rent were served this week on 10 tenants of Westbeth, the middleincome housing facility for artists at West and Bethune Streets. The 10, who include painters, actors, filmmakers and writ ers, were said to be from four months to one year be hind in their payments. The notices are the first for non payment of rent at the proj ect.

title: Billy Gilbert, Actor, 77 Dead; Noted as Man With the Sneeze
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 23 (UPI) Billy Gilbert, the stage and screen comedian, died today in a convalescent home. His age was 77. He leaves his wife, the former Lolly McKenzie, a for mer film actress.

title: Miranda, Defendant In Landmark Case, Is Convicted Again
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 23 (AP) Ernest Miranda, whose name is attached to a famous United States Supreme Court decision, was convicted for the second time today for a 1962 robbery of $8.

title: Ninth Jail Suicide In City This Year Reported at Tombs
description: A convicted robber with mental problems hanged him self in his cell in the Tombs late yesterday, according to the Department of Correction. It was the ninth suicide in a city prison this year and the second at the Tombs, the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.

title: Alabamian Asserts $60,000 Was Paid Only to Legislator
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 23Alfred Rose, a Birmingham lawyer who handles legal work on bond issues in Alabama, acknowledged today that his law firm had paid a $60,000 fee to the Speaker of the Ala bama House in connection with bond issues in 1965 and '67

title: ABM Accord Called Near As Helsinki Meeting Ends
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 23  Reliable sources reported that the United States and the Soviet Union were near an un derstanding on the limitation of antiballistic missiles as they ended the fifth round of their nuclear arms talks here today.

title: System of Points Will Measure How Hard Firefighters Work
description: After nearly two years of hearings, studies and rides in fire engines, Eric J. Schmertz, impartial chairman in a dispute between firefighters and the city, has devised a point sys tem to measure how hard fire fighters work.

title: Rand Seeks to Dissociate Itself From Book on China by ExAide
description: Late last spring the Rand Corporation, a defense consult ing organization, asked D. C. Heath, a major textbook pub lisher, to rush into print a study of China's foreign rela tions by one of Rand's staff members, Melvin Gurtov.

title: U.S. COURT HOLDS UP POSTAL PROCEDURES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The United States Postal Ser vice and seven unions that had negotiated a labor agreement with it were temporarily re strained, today from carrying out employe grievance and dis cipline procedures in accord ance with their contract.

title: Giants Win, 21, Raise Lead to 3 Games
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23By the length of Willie McCovey's size13 left shoe, the San Fran cisco Giants defeated the Hous ton Astros, 21, tonight and extended their lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers to three games with only six to go.

title: Albania Seeks to Bar U.S. Plan on China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23Albania today told the supporters of her resolu tion to oust Nationalist China from the United Nations that she would ask the General As sembly tomorrow to block from its agenda the item on China sponsored by the United States.

title: Clinton Prison Bans Inspection by Dunne
description: DANNEMORA, N. Y., Sept. 23State Senator John R. Dunne, chairman of the Senate Committee on Crime and Cor rection, who is on a factfinding tour of prisons, was barred today from the Clinton Correc tional Facility here.

title: Film: Mailer's 'Maidstone' Opens Whitney Series
description: In a foreword to the Signet paperback version of "Maidstone," which is actually a transcription of the screenplay as improvised by the actors, Norman Mailer sounds very much as if he's become a prisoner of the sort of fantasies that keep alive the hopes of all conventional, money-grubbing movie producers.He reports that audiences for the film, which is his third, said either "Sensational" or "It stinks." Every showman, no matter what the height of his brow, fears general apathy more than critical assassination.The truth of the matter is that "Maidstone" is a very mixed bag, and were it not the work of one of our most brilliant writers, and had it not prompted Mailer to write an intense essay ("A Course in Film-making"), it would be very easy to be apathetic about it.Judged simply as a movie, "Maidstone" marks an abrupt decline from "Beyond the Law," Mailer's highly entertaining second film, as well as from "Ocean's II," "Sergeants Three" and all those that Frank Sinatra made with his rat pack in the early 1960's.However, seen as part of the Mailer continuum, "Maidstone" is a sometimes hilarious, often boring but always adventurous ego trip, a very expensive, 110-minute home movie that has been edited, rather fancily, out of something like 45 hours of original footage. That, in turn, prompts the thought that almost anybody should be able to get 110 minutes of something out of 45 hours of anything, even if it's simply the filmed record of a chic, chaotic, seven-day brawl in East Hampton, which is the raw, not-so-base material of "Maidstone."Mailer conceived the film as a giant, multileveled improvisation, involving 100 or so friends and professionals, which would try to capture a new kind of cinematic truth and purity by letting his actors go where they would once the original premise had been presented to them. The premise, in fact, is just nutty enough to be brilliant:Norman T. Kingsley (Mailer), a notorious film director (modestly compared to Bufiuel, Fellini, Dreyer and Antonioni) who is making a spoof of "Belle de Jour" on eastern Long Island, is being considered as a Presidential candidate. In the course of his production, he is visited by various delegations, interviewed by television, profiled by associates and the object of an assassination attempt that may or may not be the work of his brother, played by Rip Torn, who has been given the name of Raoul, apparently to add still another association between Norman T. Kingsley and various authority figures.That's the way the movie began, but, sadly, Mailer's huge cast didn't seem to improvise as well on-camera as they reportedly did off. The whole thing was becoming a disaster of the order of a rained-out Boy Scout picnic until, on the last day of shooting, Rip Torn improvised an attack on Mailer-Kingsley with a toy hammer that turned into a real fight. As the two men fought (Mailer's choppers neatly clamped on Torn's ear, drawing blood), Beverly Bentley (Mrs. Mailer) and the Mailer children screamed hysterically, and the cameras continued to roll.The result is a very mysterious scene that is more than just a close-up of the author-at-play. At one moment Mailer is shouting about trust betrayed, which is one of his most seductive themes, and in the next he is saying that he'll never forgive Torn for having, in effect, made a fool of him in front of his children. It's complex and dense and very much in keeping with what a major author is required to give his public in this era of Total Revelation.Nothing else in "Maidstone" is as interesting, not the satire of the news media, not the soft-core sex scenes, not Mailer's put-downs of actresses auditioning for Norman T. Kingsley ("You may be extraordinarily talented, for all I know, but I think you're a dumbo"), not even Mailer's flights of fancy about politics, Presidents, blacks and whatnots.The movie, which is pretty to look at, doesn't make a great deal of sense, just because Mailer, during production, refused to exercise the discipline that he more or less ridicules in his search for higher truth. "Beyond the Law," made on the same principle, worked quite happily, but the scope was smaller and its confrontations (between cops and crooks) were clearly defined from the beginning.The screenplay for "Maidstone" is worth reading, however, not only because Mailer can be an incomparable word man, but also because his stage directions amount to criticisms of everything the film doesn't succeed in doing, as when Mailer tells us or, rather, he orders us: "The mind of the audience must now work to establish some separate levels of reality. But the levels seem to insist on coalescing with one another . . ." Truer words were never written after a fact.Only because "Maidstone" is Mailer, I wouldn't have missed it. The film opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum to start the new fall series devoted to American moviemakers. It will be shown for the next two weeks, every day except Thursday, at 12, 2 and 4 P.M., and Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at 6 and 8.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 On the day John Marshall Harlan was nominated to the Supreme Court 16 years ago, he invited newsmen into his judicial chambers at Foley Square. Then, amid much clamor and bustle, he limited his comment on his nomina tion to one sentence:  I am very deeply hon ored. Was that all he wanted to say? he was asked. I wouldn't, want to make another statement right now, he, re plied.

title: Findings on Justice Schweitzer Turned Over to SixMan Court
description: ALBANY, Sept. 23The law yer in charge of investigating State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer for the Court on the Judiciary inter rupted his inquiry today to re port his findings to the court because, he said, we just got to the point where we thought we had enough to recommend action to the court.

title: Merchants Award Is Set
description: Jack I. Straus, chairman of the executive committee of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., has been selected to receive the 1972 gold medal award of the National Retail Merchants As sociation. The presentation, which is for distinguished service to the retail craft, will be made on Jan. 12, 1972 dur ing the N.R.M.A.'s annual con vention at the New York Hil ton Hotel.

title: Film: Three Friends and a Girl in Rio:'The Big City' Opens at 5th Avenue Cinema Plot, a Simple One, Is More Like a Fable
description: Carlos Diegues's "The Big City" ("A Grande Cidade") opens with a travel-poster view of the harbor of Rio de Janeiro. A vibrant young black man named Calunga (Antonio Pilanga) bounds into the picture. He addresses the camera and extols his city, calling it among other encomiums an "earthly paradise." Since Calunga is bubbling with the enthusiasm of a clever confidence man, one senses immediately that in this example of Brazil's Cinema Novo we are in for an ironic tour of Rio.Calunga is a rogue who works if he has to, borrows when he wants to, and never pays back. He is soon bearding passersby and badgering them with questions, mostly about their waste of time. He smiles broadly, sings, dances and is thoroughly winning. He is all charm  and no villany.Calunga holds the movie together. He is the framework and "The Big City" is the tale he is telling. I wish he were the tale. The movie, according to a subtitle, is about "the adventure and misadventures of Luzia and three friends"with Calunga only one of the three friends.Luzia (Anecy Rocha) is a country girl with a cardboard suitcase. She is freshly arrived in the city and looking for her lover, Jaso, who has left their hometown to make his living in Rio. Calunga flirts with her, teases her, takes her into protective custody. Where will she sleep? He welcomes her to a public park and with a grin declares, "It's all yours."As we soon discover, Jaso, a "cowman" (which I assume is the equivalent of cowboy), is a thief and a murderer, protecting himself  Hollywood-western stylewith two pistols. In spite of his villainy and her religiosity, Luzia is still drawn to him.When Jaso goes into hiding, Calunga is called upon to act as go-between, which he does with outward heartiness but an inward embarrassment. He is also attracted to the girl, as is his friend, Ignacio, a quiet construction worker (the third "friend").The plot is simple, like a fable. But underneath, the movie is complex, a philosophical morality play. Calunga is the poet and philosopher. "The more you wait, the more you lose," he says  and live life to the fullest. To him, Rio is hell on earth  but who cares? He is scornful of heaven: too many people are waiting to get in.His great expansiveness and appetite for experience is reflected even in his walk. He strides through the pictureuntil the end when the walk suddenly becomes mechanical. He has been touched by the inevitable tragedy of the lovers.Jaso, on the other hand, by his own judgment has absolutely no control over his fate. He is destined to be a bad guy, and does nothing to gain himself a reprieve. Ignacio, the least developed of the characters, is merely wistful. He might have a life if only he could get out of the city and return to his roots.The contrast in characters and attitudes is interesting, but the basic storyline is banal and with its sometimes inflated dialogue the screenplay by Mr. Diegues and Leopoldo Serran does not measure up to the direction or the performances (the four leads are excellent). Even so, the movie is appealing and when Calunga dominates the screen, which he does whenever he is on screenit is quite pleasurable.The film began a two-day run yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. Now the offislanders have returned to what is euphemistically called civilization and from Gay Head to Gape Poge, from the pounding surf on the oceanside to the gentle shores of the sound, the Vineyard is glowing under the special light before Indian summer. Wild grasses are turning russet, cranberries are scarlet, golden rod and asters dot the hillsides. Mar tha's Vineyard is going native again but for how many Septembers in the future?

title: Komeito Will Join Other Parties In Japan in Efforts to Oust Sato
description: TOKYO, Sept. 23The op position Komeito, or Clean Government party, ended its annual convention today with a new program of political action intended to further its efforts to become a national rather than religious party.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers Angered by Freeze on Wages
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 23 The attitude of union members toward President Nixon's wage price freeze, Which was origi nally reported to be favorable, now appears to be generally antagonistic and often bitter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hall Jazz Trio Pleases
description: For a year or more, Jim Hall and Ron Carter have been working as an unusual ly effective duo on guitar and bass. Most of their ap pearances have been at The Guitar, 10th Avenue at 51st Street, where they are sched uled to return on Oct. 13. But meanwhile, Mr. Hall has expanded the group to a trio with the addition of Ben Aranov on piano.

title: China Believed in Grip of Political Crisis
description: Western diplomatic reports said yesterday that there ap pears to be a continuing politi cal crisis in China.

title: BELGRADE ACCORD REPORTED ELUSIVE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23President Tito and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Commu nist party leader, conferred to day for a second day, and the Russian, who arrived yester day, expressed the belief that the two had succeeded in find ing a common language.

title: MAX S. SOKOBIN
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 23Max S. Sokobin, president of the Sokobin Glass Company of Newark, died today in St. Barnabas Hospital in Living ston. He was 74 years old and lived at 40 Meadowbrook Place.

title: WHITE DRIVER FREED IN DEATH OF BLACK
description: BUTLER, Ala., Sept 23  A white man accused of killing a black civil rights demonstrator in this southwest Alabama com munity Sept. 11 was cleared of all charges in a grand jury re port released today.

title: Letellier, on 68 for 139, Gains Edge by 3 Shots
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 23 Ron Letellier, the Long Is land Professional Golfers' Asso ciation titleholder, played four underpar golf over the last 14 holes today and took the 36hole lead in the Metropoli tan open championship by three strokes.

title: Nansemond Wins 4Heat Pace
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 23 Who else but Herve Filion, heading for his fourth straight. North American driving title, would help to spring the most astounding upset of the 1971 harness racing season?

title: PETER R. KNAUR, 44, DEFENSE ASSISTANT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Peter R. Knaur, special assist ant for Congressional relations in international security af fairs, died at his home yester day. He was 44 years old.

title: House Panel Approves Bill for a Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Legislation to set up an inde pendent Federal agency with authority to champion and pro tect consumer interests moved a big step toward House pas sage today.

title: Faust Returns to Met With Mostly New Cast
description: Would that the Metropoli tan Opera had the power of Mephistopheles to rejuvenate the old. The company brought back Gounod's Faust, after a twoseason absence, on Wednesday night, and it couldn't breathe much vitality into the work.

title: PARIS BANKER WARY OF 2TIER MARKET
description: The chairman of one of France's largest banks  the Governmentowned Credit Ly Onnais  questioned yesterday the wisdom of his nation's two tier market for foreign ex change, in which francs to be used for trade command one price and those for tourism and investment another.

title: CORPORATE CAPITAL CLIMBS $5.9BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Net working capital of United States corporations rose $5.9billion in the second quarter of 1971, totaling $226.3 billion at the end of June, the Securities and Exchange Com mission reported today.

title: HOUSE UNIT RAISES CAMPAIGN OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The House Commerce Commit tee voted today to double the amount of money that Presi dential and Congressional can didates could spend for radio and television during the 1972 campaign.

title: Senate for End to Ban on Rhodesian Ore
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The Senate put aside defense matters temporarily today to decide, in defiance of a United Nations embargo, that the United States should permit the importing of chrome ore from Rhodesia.

title: More Ugliness to Japan
description: The reported White House ultimatum to Japan, threat ening imposition of textile quotas Oct. 15 unless Tokyo restricts shipments to Washington's satisfaction, unwise ly accelerates the downward spiral in America's relations with its chief Asian ally. The timing is particularly in comprehensible, since President Nixon will be making an effort this weekend to improve the atmosphere by flying to Anchorage for a ceremonial meeting with Em peror Hirohito.

title: MRS. RAYMOND MALON
description: Mrs. Grace Holmes Malone, widow of Raymond Malone, a lawyer and former member of the Village Council of Free port, L. I., and mother of Ray mond H. Malone, Nassau Coun ty Housing Coordinator, died yesterday in Whitefield, N. H. She was 82 years old and lived in Freeport.

title: Human Rights for Prisoners
description: HARTFORD, Conn.  In the begin ning, prisons housed the untried who, if found guilty, were beheaded or hung or, if more fortunate, whipped or maimed and then set free. One hun dred and fifty years ago, the reform ers, principally Quakers, urged prison as an alternative to death to enable the wicked in solitude to see the error of their ways and to reform.

title: Pennsylvania Company Registers Loss
description: The Pennsylvania Company, all of whose common stock is pledged as security for a $300 million bank loan of its parent, the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company, yes terday issued its own income account for 1970. It showed a $246,150,000 net loss, in con trast to an $87,570,000 profit for 1969.

title: Advertising:
description: Time Inc., the country's most successful publisher of mass magazines, will take another step today toward getting into the specialty magazine field.

title: Britain to Strengthen Patrols and Air Observation at Ulster Border
description: LONDON, Sept. 23, (Reu ters)  British military au thorities in Northern Ireland are tightening border security to prevent guerrillas from slipping into the province from the Irish Republic.

title: Monopoly Position of I.B.M. Scored by Memorex Corp.
description: The Memorex Corporation charged yesterday that the monopolistic position of the International Business Ma chines Corporation had driven both the RCA Corporation and the General Electric Company out of the industry.

title: J. W, ALEXANDER 2D, MATHEMATICIAN, 83
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 23 Dr. James W. Alexander 2d, a mathematician and a creator of modern topology, a branch of higher mathematics, died today of pneumonia in Prince ton Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 29 Cleveland Lane.

title: ASPROMONTE'S HIT DEFEATS CUBS, 54
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23  Nolan Ryan and Bob Aspromonte, whose contributions lately have been virtually, nil, provided the pitching and the hitting today that enabled the Mets to defeat the Cubs, 54, and move to within one game of third place.

title: Weekend Fishing Prospects in Surrounding Areas
description: AREA AGood catches of blues are reported the length of Long Beach Island by surf fishermen. The blues, rang ing from two to six pounds, are being taken on metal lures and mullet. There are some weakfish in the surf, also biting on metal and bait. Bass are running fair to good along the jetties of Surf City and Barnegat Light, taking plugs. At the extremes of Barnegat Bay, near the in lets, there are good hauls of snappers (using spearing), weakfish and fluke (using squid).

title: The Civil Service System Is Criticized by Murphy
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy criticized the Civil Service system, yesterday as having serious weaknesses and suggested it might be im peding his anticorruption cam paign.

title: Energy Shortage Is Laid to Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Leaders of nuclear, electric, gas, coal and oil trade associa tions said here today that tight governmental controls and ar chaic antitrust laws were caus ing much of the energy short age facing the nation.

title: Army Investigator Says Missing Report on Mylai May Have Been Fabrication to Cover Up Slayings
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 23  An Army criminal investiga tor said today he believed that a report of the infantry at tack on Mylai 4 a docu ment that Is missing from mili tary files  was a falsifica tion of what took place in the South Vietnamese hamlet.

title: Winigo Wins Hurdle by 8 Lengths
description: A hurdle race that started as a cavalry charge found rid ers falling almost like tenpins yesterday as the 14th running of the Elkridge Handicap was won by Montpelier's consistent Winigo on Belmont Park's soft turf.

title: Art Protection Debated in Italy
description: ROMEThe dizzying spate of art thefts and the resulting public shock have produced calls for stricter surveillance over the Italian artistic patri mony. Premier Emilio Colom bo has declared that the Gov ernment is already taking measures to play a larger and more efficient role in the protection of works of art.

title: Detroit's Orchestra Hall Gets Gift to Bar Razing
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) Orchestra Hall will escape the wreckers' ball thanks to a gift of $30,000 from David Elgin Dodge.

title: MILK FIRMS FINED IN PRICEFIXING
description: Twenty milk companies and two individuals were fined a total of $220,000 yesterday in State Supreme Court after pleading guilty to conspiring to raise the price of milk in the city.

title: TV: Valuable Documentary Studies the New China
description: And now it's China. A pingpong tournament, a star tling announcement by the President of the United States and the threatening colos sus has become an object of intense, startlingly friendly curiosity. With primary sources on China itself lim ited, some media have gone so far as to breathlessly re discover Chinese communi ties in America. For the mo ment, evidently, any Chinese will do.

title: HARLAN RETIRES; NIXON HINTS POFF IS A COURT CHOICE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Associate Justice John M. Harlan retired from the Su preme Court today after 16 years of service. His physician raid that Mr. Harlan was af flicted with bone cancer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SICK ENGINEERS CUT RAIL SERVICE
description: Railroad commuting from Connecticut suburbs was dis rupted yesterday morning when engineers with a grievance called in sick, curtailing serv ice on the New Haven division of the Penn Central from 27 rushhour trains to 10 that were operated by supervisory personnel.

title: Talks in Rhodesia End
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 23 (Reuters)British and Rho desian negotiators held a final twohour meeting today, end ing the latest round of talks the sixyearold independ ence dispute.

title: Skouras Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Spy ros P. Skouras will be held to morrow at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street. There will be a liturgy at 9 A.M., fol lowed by a service at 11 A.M. Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, will officiate. Mr. Skouras died on Aug. 16 at the age of 78. He was board chairman of Pruden tialGrace Lines, Inc., and had been president and board chair man of 20th CenturyFox Film Corporation.

title: 2 SENATORS SEEK TO EXPAND STUDY, TAKE IN BASEBALL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Two United States Senators re quested today that baseball's antitrust exemption be investi gated along with the request of the two major basketball leagues to merge.

title: FRANK X. KISSANE, BANKER, 58, DEAD
description: Frank X. Kissane, a vice president of the Chase Manhat tan Bank, died at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn on Wednesday after a short illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 92.40 242d Street, Bellerose, Queens.

title: ROSSETTI SECURE IN HIS PARTY POST
description: With Mayor Lindsay remain ing aloof from the continuing struggle for control of the Man hattan Democratic organization, Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti appeared assured yesterday of reelection as Manhattan Demo cratic leader.

title: Mississippi Whites Join Blacks to Listen to Evers at Labor Rally
description: LAUREL, Miss., Sept. 23 A remarkable meeting was held in the Jones County court house here last night.

title: No Tension in Peking  The Globe and Mall, Toronto
description: PEKING, Sept. 23 There was none of the tension in Pe king today that has been hinted at in Western broadcasts reach ing here.

title: Mexican Leftist Group Formed To Challenge the Ruling Party
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 A group of leftwing intellec tuals and labor leaders, includ ing the writers Carlos Fuentes and Octavio Paz, has an nounced the formation of a new organization to challenge the political monopoly of Mex ico's ruling Institutional Rev olutionary party.

title: Jets Take Dim View of Next 3 Games on Artificial Turf
description: Bill Hampton, the Jets' equip ment manager, displayed a spe cial elbow pad at Shea Stadium yesterday designed to cut down skin burns on artificial turf. Another member of the Jets' staff obtained permission to shift today's workout from Rikers Island to Hofstra to al low the team to work out on artificial turf before its game Monday night against the Car dinals in St. Louis.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Not many people are aware of the fact that the course of baseball history was among the many changes that resulted from a certain Japanese impetuosity 30 years ago. The American League had scheduled a meeting in Chicago for Dec. 8, 1941. Note the date, please. The purpose of the gathering was to give approval to the request of Don Barnes of the St. Louis Browns to move his franchise to Los Angeles.

title: East German Paper Sees No Crisis in Treaty Talks
description: BERLIN, Sept. 23 (Reuters) East Germany's main Com munist party newspaper said today that there was no crisis in the deadlocked East German West German talks on the com pletion of the fourpower agreement on Berlin.

title: Books of The Times
description: ELLIS ISLAND. Text by Thomas Dunne. Pho tography by Wilton Tifft. Unpaginated. W. W. Norton. $10.??

title: RATEPLEDGEMADE FOR HOME LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The nation's savings and loan associations pledged today that they would refrain from raising mortgage interest rates during the 90day wage and price freeze and throughout all of the Phase Two economic pro gram that is to follow the freeze.

title: PAUL H. NISLEY, 74; LED CHEMICAL FIRM
description: Paul H. Nisley, president and general manager of A. D. Mackay Inc., 198 Broadway, dealers in rare chemicals and metals, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 2 Tudor City Place.

title: Justice Harlan's Departure
description: With President Nixon still engaged in a search for a successor to Associate Justice Hugo L. Black, another aging and ailing member of the Supreme Court has decided to step down. The retirement of Justice John M. Harlan, an erudite conservative, doubles the Presi dent's task and his responsibility to history.

title: For Spirit in Flesh, Voices of Commune, The Trip Is Visual
description: In case you've been wonder ing about the Spirit in Flesh signs that have been as numer ous around town lately as Kil roy graffiti, the mystery has been solved. Spirit in Flesh is a rock group, the musical voice of a 200member Massachusetts commune called the Brother hood of the Spirit.

title: Standards at Pearl's Have Slipped a Bit
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmo sphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Report Confirmed in Bonn
description: BONN, Germany, Sept. 23 (AP)A Tokyo report that the International Monetary Fund has proposed a 3to5percent dollar devaluation and revalu ations of other currencies is substantially correct, informed sources said here today.

title: City Policeman Wearing Shield of Slain Partner
description: The policeman who rode for 10 years alongside Patrolman Kenneth A. Nugentthe ninth policeman to be killed here in the line of duty this yearhas received special permission to wear his partner's shield.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Scranton, Pa.  Tommy Hicks, 170 pounds, Ithaca, N. Y., knocked out Walter Opshinsky, 170, Scran ton, 7 rounds.

title: Small, Roomy Cab Designed for City
description: A model of a new taxicab, only two inches longer than a Volkswagen but with more head and leg room than a a Cadillac limousine, was un veiled here yesterday by Pratt Institute. Its designers said prototypes could be running on New York streets in two years.

title: Hugo Black Weakening; Condition Is Very Serious

title: Walter C. Kurz, 63, Is Dead; A Chicago Tribune Official
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) Walter C. Kurz, former general manager of The Chicago Trib une, died today in Passavant Memorial Hospital after, a long illness. He was 63 years old.

description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yes terday in slower trading.

title: Israelis Appoint Arab As the Mayor of Gaza
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 23Ra shad Shawa, an elder of a prominent Arab family of landowners, was named May or of Gaza tonight by the Is raeli military, government.

title: Seoul Arrests 17 as Spies
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 23The South Korean Army counterintelligence corps an nounced today that 17 spies for North Korea in seven sep arate rings were arrested in Seoul and the southern port city of Pusan last week.

description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America announced a new pen sion plan today to give its members the opportunity to move from one area to another and from construction to in dustrial work while still re taining their full pension rights.

title: No Vote on Lottery Veto
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate ad journed today without acting on Gov. Francis W. Sargent's veto of the state lottery bill. This meant that the veto could not be acted on before Monday. The House voted yes terday to override the veto.

title: Washington: For the Record

description: The election of Ed mund T. Pratt Jr. as president of Pfizer, Inc., was announced yester day by the diversified pharmaceutical and chem ical company. Mr. Pratt, formerly executive vice president, is the seventh president of Pfizer. The company, with sales over $870million, was incor porated In 1900. Pfizer also elected Gerald D. Laubach as executive vice president. Mr. Lau bach, formerly president of Pfizer Pharmaceuti cals operations, in his new position will direct a new corporate group comprising domestic

title: All Nippon Airways Buys 11 Jet Liners From Boeing

title: David R. Pokross Jr., Lawyer, Weds Nancy Lynne Cahners
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 23The marriage of Miss Nancy Lynne Cahners to David R. Pokross Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pokross of Bel mont, took place here this evening. Rabbi Manuel Saltz man performed the ceremony at the, home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nor man L. Cahners.

title: HYMAN REACHES GOLF SEMIFINALS
description: PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Sept. 23Tom Draper of Troy, Mich.; William Colm and Ernest Pieper Jr. of California, and William Hyndman of Abington, Pa., gained the semifinals of United States senior amateur golf championship after two rounds today at the Sunny brook Golf Club. They will meet tomorrow in the order mentioned.

title: DETECTIVES INDICTED IN EXTORTION HERE
description: Two Manhattanbased detec tives were charged yesterday with extorting $500 from a Brooklyn storekeeper, and, in another case, a probationary patrolman was arrested with two other men on narcotics charges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HUMPHREY CLOSER TO PRESIDENCY BID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has moved to the brink of an other bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The air strike carried out against North Vietnam Tues day was the fifth such massive raid ordered by President Nixon under his muchexplained, muchmisunderstood policy of protective reaction. In the three days since the first bombs were dropped, Administration spokes men here and in Saigon have la bored to persuade reporters that the huge raid was consistent with the standing definition of protective re action. Privately, however, officials here have begun to acknowledge what they so far have declined to say in public: that protective reaction has a political definition as well as a literal one, and that the Ad ministration is using these oc casional heavy air strikes to keep North Vietnam off balance and prevent a buildup for an offensive.

title: Economist Says Policy Will Check Inflation and Spur Business
description: Walter W. Heller, a key eco nomic adviser to the last two Democratic Presidents, gave ef fusive praise yesterday to Phase One of President Nix on's new economic policy and predicted the successful opera tion of the forthcoming Phase Two.

title: Checkless Relief
description: In a report disclosing the fraudulent cashing last year of about $4 million in duplicate relief checks, State Con troller Arthur Levitt recently pronounced inadequate the steps taken by New York City welfare officials to prevent more such abuse through tightened administra tive procedures. The problem remains serious, said the Controller's report.

title: Money Growth Rate Cut
description: A leading monetary scholar charged yesterday that the country's inflation problem conforms to a classic example of overexpansion of the money supply without which infla tion would have withered.

title: BULLET TRIUMPHS IN ONE TON SAIL
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 23 Bullet, the PJ 37 sailed by Andy MacGowan, captured the sec ond race of the Ida Lewis Yacht Club One Ton Cup series today for her second victory in a row.

title: News Analysis;
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The retirement of Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan gives President Nixon a rare opportunity to nominate two Justices at once and presents a real possibility that the time may have come for a woman Justice to sit on the Supreme Court. Presumably, the Presi dent will have up permost in his mind to mold a Nixon Court that will impress his strictconstruc tionist philosophy upon the law for decades to come. These will be his third and fourth vacan cies to fill, and if he wins a sec ond term, he will probably ap point at least a fivemember majority of the court.

title: CARROLL WIDDOES, EXFOOTBALL COACH
description: LAKE WORTH, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP)  Carroll Widdoes, who succeeded Paul Brown as Ohio State football coach, died last night of a heart attack at the age of 67.

title: Advertising:
description: The Ally cats are purring today without a sneeze, a sniffle or a foot itch and with the sight of $4million in new billings coming down the chute.

title: Suspects in Police Deaths Seen Likely to Be Indicted
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 Five witnesses flown here from New York City viewed two suspects in the slaying of two patrolmen in Harlem last May in a tense, twohour line up here today and an assistant district attorney said afterward there was a strong possibility that grand jury indictments would be sought.

title: U.S. War Deaths at 12, Below 20 for 10thWeek
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23 (AP) The United States command announced today that 12 American serv icemen were killed in action in Indochina last week, mark ing the 10th consecutive week that combat deaths were be low 20.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Rights Offerings Proposed By B.P. and Illinois Bell Phone
description: The British Petroleum Com pany, Ltd., and the Illinois Bell Telephone Company yesterday proposed large rights offerings of common stock.

title: New Complex Proposed to Replace Garden City Hotel
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 23A proposal to replace the Garden City Hotel with a new hotelapartmentoffice complex that will cost $70 million to $75million was made to the Village Board here tonight.

title: The Screen
description: Felix Greene, the British cameraman-journalist-author, who gave us feature-length color close-ups of "China!" in 1965 and "North Vietnam" two years later, continues his role as a movie Marco Polo for the embattled Left in "Cuba Va!", his latest color documentary on a nation largely concealed by a "curtain." As in the previous cases, he illustrates a contented people, who admittedly haven't yet achieved their revolutionary goals but are, as the title translates, moving forward.Using some old black-and-white footage to stress the enrichment of the few wealthy, both local and foreign, and the deprivation of the masses of the poor and ignorant Latin Americans, Greene, who shot his color film over the last year or so, makes visual comparisons in generally calm and effective style.With Premier Fidel Castro appearing on a few occasions to explain that Cuban freedom could be achieved only by revolution after 400 years of foreign domination, the film's natural bias is apparent but not overpowering. It opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema.The "85 per cent" illiteracy that existed 12 years ago when Castro ousted the former dictator, Fulgencio Batista, is given cheerful counterpoint by happy youngsters and adults receiving free education and instruction in trades in various immaculate up-to-date urban and rural schools. The admitted fact that did not meet its 10-million-ton sugar cane goal last year is offset by various scenes showing the harvesting of eight and a half million tons, a record crop.A viewer is fascinated by workers from other areas chipping in voluntarily to help with the cane, tobacco and other harvests; by a fine teachers college, medical school with many distaff students, and an especially modern psychiatric hospital near Havana; by an orchestra devoted to Western classics that is viewed, somewhat less favorably, than an excellent modern dance team working with native rhythms as another sign of Cuba's socialistic approach to the arts.One is impressed by younger composer-guitarists such as Silvio Rodriguez, Noel Nicola and Pablo Milanes, whose fine voices extol their brave new world. And one assumes that Mr. Greene knows what he is talking about in noting that "the cinemas are filled and a nightclub has to be booked weeks in advance."One also get glimpses of modern highways being built and slums being razed and a climactic scene showing Cubans reacting forcefully in Havana demonstrations when their captive fishermen were freed by Americans last year. The over-all impression sought by Mr. Greene is a bright present and a brighter future. But despite his largely happy vistas, his "Cuba Va!" leaves a nagging feeling that it is only a partial view of current history that still desperately needs fuller explanations.Also on the bill is "Reggae," a 60-minute documentary on Jamaican music filmed at a concert in London last year and intercut with observations on its origins and purposes. As an outgrowth of traditional African, calypso, rock, soul and blues, its beat is infectious.And, even though Mike Raven, a British disk jockey, explains that "Reggae" was the name of the first record label to feature that genre and that it is also a form of protest, it is basically an item for the buffs, who should appreciate it most.

title: SPEAKER OF TEXAS INDICTED FOR DEAL
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 23 (UPI) Four persons, including House Speaker Gus F. Mutscher Jr., were indicted today for their roles in a stock scandal.

title: L.I. SCHOOL STRIKE ENTERS SECOND DAY
description: CENTEREACH, L.I., Sept. 23  More than 15,000 students were without formal classes to day as a strike by the 850 member Middle Country Teach ers Association went into its second day, in a dispute in cluding wages and class size.

title: RAIL FREIGHT OFF; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Sept. 18 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck ton nage in the same period in creased.

title: Video Project Deferred
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI)  The Ampex, Corporation said today it is deferring production of its cartridge video recording sys tem for several months because of engineering delays. The car tridge video recording project is a joint venture with the To kyo Shibaura Electric Company.

title: Guggenheim Shows 10 Young Artists
description: The exhibition called Ten Young Artists, which opened yesterday at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, is the second in the series of Theo doron Awards  named in honor of an anonymous foundation whose principal interest is said to be in aid ing young artists. Apparently this foundation provides funds to enable the Guggen heim to purchase works it would not otherwise be in a position to acquire for its permanent collection. The works themselves, however, have been selected by the museum's associate cura tor, Diane Waldman, who was assisted in this task by Linda Shearer, a curatorial assist ant.

title: LTV SETS A PLAN FOR DEBENTURES
description: LingTemcoVought, Inc., pro posed yesterday a plan under which it would offer holders of its $98million of outstand ing 6 per cent debentures due June 1, 1973, an equivalent amount of new 7 per cent convertible debentures, due 1981.

title: Dodgers Win, 20, for Downing's 20th
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 24  Min utes after Al Downing and Willie Davis sparked the de termined Dodgers to a 20 vic tory over Atlanta tonight, a dozen Dodgers sat around the table in the middle of their clubhouse, eating fried chicken, drinking beer and listening to the game between San Fran cisco and Cincinnati.

title: ORIOLES CLINCH 3D TITLE IN ROW
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles clinched the American League's East Di vision title for the third con secutive year by beating Cleve land, 92, tonight in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: U.S. PLAN ON CHINA PUT ON U.N. AGENDA BY A NARROW VOTE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24The General Assem bly, in its first test vote on China, today gave the United States and the cosponsors of its China item the right to put it on the agenda.

title: Haines Shoots 72 to Take Medal in Crump Cup Golf
description: CLEMENTON, N. J., Sept. 24 George Haines Jr., a former New Jersey State amateur champion, took the medal with a twooverpar 37, 3572 in the qualifying round of the 47th annual George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup golf tournament today at the Pine Valley Golf Club.

title: PMC Tops Fordham, 2114, As Johnson, Weaver Star
description: CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 24 Pennsylvania Military Colleges defeated Fordham, 2114, to night before 3,500 at PMC Sta dium behind the brilliant running of Bill Johnson and Rich Weaver.

title: SnakeHandling Sect Survives in Appalachians
description: NEWPORT, Tenn., Sept. 20All through the hymn singing there was this loud rattling from some boxes near the pulpit.

title: Trading Halted by S.E.C. Of Telstar Common Shares
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended overthecounter trading in Telstar common shares until Oct. 3.

title: 10% of Police Sergeants To Be Shifted in ShakeUp
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yes terday a transfer of sergeants to take effect Monday in virtually every precinct in the city in what is believed to be one of the biggest shifts of supervisory manpower in the department's history.

title: Lenore G. Marshall, 72, Dies; Was Poet, Novelist and Editor
description: Lenore G. Marshall, poet, novelist and a founder of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, died of an em bolism Thursday in Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at the Dorset Hotel and in New Hope, Pa.

title: PIEPER AND DRAPER ATTAIN SENIOR FINAL
description: PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Sept. 24Ernest Pieper Jr., of San Juan Bautista, Calif., and Tom Draper of Troy, Mich., reached the final of the United States senior amateur golf championship today at the Sun nybrook Club. They play for the title tomorrow.

title: GOLF LEAD SHARED BY COLBERT, NEVIL
description: ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 24 (AP) Jim Colbert, a onetime Kan sas State halfback, carded a fiveunderpar 66 today and tied Dwight Nevil, a tour rookie, for the secondround lead in the $100,000 Robinson open golf tournament.

title: Justice Black Dies at 85; Served on Court 34 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Sept. 25Retired Associate Justice Hugo L. Black, whose liberal philosophy influenced the Supreme Court through 34 years of social change, died early today. He was 85 years old.

title: U.S.Tax Incentive Urged To Lift Broker Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Leon T. Kendall, president of the Association of Stock Ex change Firms, suggested today that Congress consider enact ment of a tax incentive for brokerage firms to set aside cash reserves against bad times.

title: Maureen Kennedy Is Wed in Jersey
description: PRINCETON, N.J. Sept. 24 In the Princeton University Chapel today Miss Maureen Rose Kennedy was married to Thomas Henry Vander spurt, a doctoral candidate in chemistry at the univer sity: The Rev. William D. Moriarty performed the cere mony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. Andrew F. Quinn.

title: New HotLine Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The two agreements with the Soviet Union aimed at modern izing the WashingtonMoscow hot line and reducing the risk of accidental nuclear war break down, according to statements made public by President Nixon and the State Department, into these main areas:

title: BIG BOARD BARS DEVONSHIRE AIDE
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that it had disciplined a former of ficer of the First Devonshire Corporation for allegedly ac cepting payoffs to expedite the delivery of certain customer ac counts after the firm was sus pended last year.

title: Canceling of Test Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  A former White House science adviser joined with others today in urging President Nixon to cancel the under ground nuclear test scheduled to take place early next month on Amchitka Island.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given at the end of the WQXR 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times or WQXR for scores: the calls tie up lines and Interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

title: RCA COMPUTER UNIT LAYS OFF IN JERSEY
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 24 (AP)A total of 487 employes in RCA's computer systems di vision in South Jersey were Iaid off today as a result of the company's withdrawal from computer manufacturing.

title: Martin's Contract Extended
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (UPI) Manager Billy Martin of the Detroit Tigers had his contract extended through 1973 today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW STOCK RATES CLEARED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Securities and Exchange commission approved today with only one small change, the new schedule of sales commis sions on stock transactions that the New York Stock Exchange proposed in June.

title: Iona Wins Opener, 2721
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 24Iona College opened its seventh clubfootball season with a 2721 victory over Seton Hall University tonight. The decisive touchdown was scored with 5 seconds left in the game by Brian Colleary, who plunged 2 yards.

title: The Release of Mujib Soon Rumored as Part of a Deal
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 24 Rumors circulated here to day that Sheik Mujibur Rah man, the Bengali leader now on trial for treason, might soon be released as part of a politi cal accommodation in East Pakistan.

title: Modern Jazz Quartet Playing Blues With Warmth and Vitality
description: In the early stages of the Modern Jazz Quartet's exist ence  it has, incredibly, been around for 19 years and has outlived any relevance to the term modern jazz, which has gone the way of bebop, cool jazz and other catch phrases  the group was sub jected to a running barrage of complaints that it did not swing and that John Lewis, the group's pianqist and musical di rector, was imposing stifling, nonjazz ideas on Milt Jackson, the vibraharpist. These objec tions have long since been dis posed of to the satisfaction of most jazz followers. But the basic swinging guts of this group have rarely been exposed as openly as they were in its second set Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, where it began an engagement that will run through tomorrow.

title: State Policeman Shifted
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP) Capt. Henry F. Williams, who was tactical commander of the state police when it crushed the Attica prison rebellion, was ap poined today head of the State Police Special Investigatory Unit here. Captain Williams, who is 40 years old, has been commander of the department's Bureau of Criminal Investiga tion at Troop A in Batavia. Capt. Fred J. Penfold succeeds him.

title: LINCOLN TROUNCES JOHN JAY, 29 TO 0
description: With its firststring quarter back sidelined by an injury. Abraham Lincoln employed strong running attack yesterday and defeated John Jay, 290, in a Brooklyn Public Schools Ath letic League game at Lincoln Field.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS INCREASED IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) Auto production lines hummed this week as the industry con tinued on its way to what ap parently will be its secondbest September.

title: Vermont Aide in House Race
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 24 (AP)Secretary of State Rich ard C. Thomas, 34 years old, said today he was entering the Republican Congressional pri mary election Nov. 16. He is the fourth candidate for the House of Representatives seat. The seat became vacant when Representative Robert T. Staf ford was named to succeed Senator Winston L. Prouty, who died.

title: Recall by MercedesBenz
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., Sept. 24 (UPI)MercedesBenz announced today it was recall ing 2,281 of its 1971 cars to modify their fuel injection sys tems because of a fire hazard. A spokesman for the com pany's North American head quarters here said the recall affected only the 280SE 3.5 convertible, the 280SE 3.5 coupe and the 300SL 3.5 sedan.

title: Rogers Reassures Gromyko at Meeting Here and Talks With Other Ministers
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko reviewed the state of AmericanSoviet relations and other world prob lems last night in the first high level contact between the two Goverments since the United States launched its new China policy last July.

title: Cosmos 440
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (UPI) The Soviet Union today fired an unmanned satellite desig nated Cosmos 440 into an elongated earth orbit, the news agency Tass said. Tass said the orbit had a maximum dis tance from the earth of 289 miles and a minimum distance of 169 miles. The orbit is inclined 71 degrees to the Equator.

title: Vermeer Painting Is Stolen in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 24 (AP) A $2million painting by the Dutch 17thcentury master Johannes Vermeer was stolen last night from the Brussels Fine Art Museum, museum au thorities announced today.

title: Savings Deposits Exceeded Withdrawals During August
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24, Reuters Savings deposits exceeded withdrawals by $1.14billion last month at savings and loan associations, the smallest mar gin for any month this year, the United States Savings and Loan League reported today.

title: MALCOLM E. SMITH
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Sept. 24Malcolm E. Smith, who had been a prominent realestate broker in New York 40 years until his retirement in 1965, died at his home here yesterday. He was 89 years old.

title: METS LOSE, 3 TO 2, ON CLEMENTE HIT
description: Roberto Clemente, who obvi ously has a fine sense of occa sion, showed his appreciation of pregame ceremonies honor ing him last night at Shea Sta dium by driving in two runs, including the one that gave his Pittsburgh Pirates a 32 triumph over the Mets.

title: Nixon Security Aide Holds Talks With Thieu and Ky
description: SAIGON, South Vietnen, Sat urday, Sept. 25  President Nixon's deputy assistant for na tional security affairs, Brig. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., has met with President Nguyen Van Thieu and his most outspoken opponent, Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky.

title: BUILDINGS CHIEF SWORN BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay swore in Joseph Stein as the city's Buildings Commissioner yester day and asked him to root out corruption wherever it might exist in the department.

title: New Uses for TrashA Show on Ecological Decorating
description: The things people throw away every day can, with ingenuity, become decora tive and functional furnish ings. Bits of string are knit ted into a rug. Beer cans are welded to form a chair. Beer bottles become the shades for a lighting fixture. Baby food jars are transformed into spice containers. Mail ing tubes and toilet paper rolls are used to hold uten sils. Wine crates become drawer fronts. Recycled card board frames chairs, tables and chests. The ways peo ple are turning trash into treasures are all there to see through Nov. 10 at the Hall mark Gallery, Fifth Avenue at 56th Street. The show, called Garbage: The Need to Recycle It, is open Monday through Saturday, 9:30 A.M. to 7 P.M.
