title: Memories of Riot Are Evident As Attica Village Board Meets
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 24 The death and bloodshed of the uprising at Attica prison shared time last night with the normal problems of storm sewers, street paving, garbage disposal and abandoned automobiles as the fiveman Attica Village Board of Trustees here met for the first time since the prison rebellion was quelled on Sept. 13.

title: Police Seize Painting
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Sept. 24 (UPI)The police went to the International Antique Show yes terday and seized a late Ren aissance painting stolen two decades ago from a Florence museum.

title: DR. LUCY HAYNER, PHYSICIST, WAS 73
description: Dr. Lucy Julia Hayner, pro fessor emeritus of physics at Columbia University, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived as 535 East 86th Street.

title: Duquesne Light Co. to Build A Nuclear Power Plant
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 24 (Reu ters)  The Duquesne Light Company said today it will build a $200million, 847000 kilowatt nuclear power plant at Shippingport, Pa.

title: BEST WOMEN HELD TOO OLD FOR COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, who said she had been talking up the idea of a woman for the Supreme Court, cast a few doubts today on the chances for such an appointment.

title: Price War in the Air
description: A price war has broken out among the airlines flying the Atlantic. A week ago Lufthansa disavowed a trans Atlantic fare agreement and offered a $210 roundtrip fare between New York and any German city, effective Feb. 1. Now Air France has offered a $170 New York Paris roundtrip group fare, and Atlantis, a West German charter airline, has slashed the price of a roundtrip group flight from New York to Frankfurt to $135. Offi cials of other nonscheduled airlines say the price war could drive roundtrip charter rates to Europe down to $120 or less.

title: Rulings by Freeze Panel
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 24 Following is Policy Statement No. 24 issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: New Ph. D. Programs in State Barred by Nyquist for a Year
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24A one year moratorium on the ap proval of new Ph.D. programs at all universities in the state was announced today by Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Educa tion Commissioner.

title: Two Economists Propose Tough Phase Two Curbs
description: Two economists warned yes terday that any compromise in the campaign against inflation would produce disastrous re sults for the financial markets and the economy that, in turn, would lead to the imposition of all out controls.

title: CHINA ASSAILS U.S. FOR VIETNAM RAID
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Sept. 25The Chinese Foreign Min istry has expressed indignation over the bombing of North Vietnam Tuesday by United States planes.

title: U.S. Finds CleanEngine Advance
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24  The Government's Environment Pro tection Agency announced to day an experiniental automobile engine that represents a breakthrough in emissions con trol technology and means that the truly clean car is not as far away as many, people thought.

title: Brandt's Face Slapped by Rightist Youth
description: BONN, Sept. 24A right wing radical student slapped Chancellor Willy Brandt on the cheek today on a street in Munich, shouting, That is for your policy in the East.

title: LOUIS A. BREAULT JR., AN ARMY PRESS AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP). Louis A. Breault Jr., a former press aide and publicaffairs adviser to Gen. William C. Westmorland, the Army's Chief of Staff, died Wednesday in a tractor accident at his farm in McConnellsburg, Pa., the Army reported today.

title: Money Crisis Hits Poor Lands Hard
description: PARIS, Sept.'24  As the rich men's club of nations struggles to create some order out of the monetary crisis, little attention is focused on the in terests of the third world.

title: ISRAEL TELLS LANSKY HIS VISA ENDS SOON
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 24Meyer Lansky, a reputed financial leader of the American under World, received official notice today that his haven in Israel would end Monday when his visitor's visa expires.

title: PACE MAINTAINED FOR NEW ISSUES
description: The new issue market, which recently has shown a surge in trading activity and in the num ber of companies making ini tial public offerings, maintained the pace this week although overall prices were mixed.

title: Gas Concerns Cut Payouts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reu ters)The Cost of Living Coun cil announced today that two natural gas companies have agreed to comply with council requests that they cut their an nounced dividend increases.

title: 2 Gas Companies Agree To Rollback on Dividends
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Two natural gas companies, one in Texas and the other in Tennessee, have agreed to roll back dividend increases, the Cost of Living Council said to day.

title: Elisir d'Amore, Full of Charm, Brightens the Stage at the Met
description: Nothing brightens the stage of the Metropolitan Opera as much as the company's occa sional revival of Donizetti's L'Elisir d'Amore. It was given Thursday night for the first time in four seasons, remind ing us how good it is. Light weight, yes; one wouldn't want to hear it too often. Yet what a brilliant piece of craftsman ship, with one bouncing tune following another and a funny libretto, whose characters are more human than those of most early 19thcentury operatic comedies.

title: Moscow Stresses DiplomatSpy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The use of embassies as legal cover for espionage operations is standard practice around the world, and, according to Ameri can experts, has been for cen turies.

title: AFRICAN LINKS NATO WITH COLONIAL RULE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 President Moktar Ould Daddah of Mauritania blamed the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today for the remaining colonialism in Africa.

title: 12 County Chiefs Prepare Road Show
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 24 The Big Twelve Counties of New York, conceived as an or ganization counterweight to Mayor Lindsay's Big Six Cities, was formed here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rep. John C. Watts Dies at 69; Served. Kentucky for 20 Years
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 24 (AP)Representative John C. Watts, Democrat of Kentucky, second ranking member of the House Ways and Means Com mittee, died today at St. Joseph Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW SLIM RISE
description: The American Stock Ex change managed to make a small advance yesterday in slow trading.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS NEW JUSTICE CODE
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24Gover nor Rockefeller said today that radical reforms in the state's system of criminal justice could no longer be delayed, and he estimated it would cost $200million to replace the state's prisons with new facili ties.

title: British Bill Rates Fall
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of treasury bills fell to 4.7531 per cent from 4.8049 per cent last week. This week's 180 minion sterling offer of 91day bills met applications of 523, 735,000 sterling. Applicants for bills dated Monday to Friday at 98.81 per cent received about 34 per cent. Next week 120 million sterling bills will be offered, replacing 100 million sterling of maturities. Applica tions for 92day bills dated Monday at 98.80 sterling and above were allotted in full.

title: BUTTERFIELD GIVES CONCERT FOR TUBAS
description: Don Butterfield, a man who is an expert on the tuba and is clearly devoted to the in strument, presented a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. on Thursday night given over largely to music for the instru ment.

title: MARKET DECLINES 5TH TIME IN WEEK
description: The stock market's latest Nixon rally lasted only a few hours yesterday. By the final bell, prices were lower to round out a week of five declining sessions.

title: 2 Seized in Lower East Side Robberies
description: Housing Authority policemen arrested two youths yesterday as suspects in a wave of rob beries in three Lower East Side housing projects.

title: One Step Ahead of a Chinese Fashion Invasion
description: While everybody is holding his breath waiting for the fashion invasion from the China mainland to happen, Veronika Yhap, a pert Chi nese girl whose field is archi tectural planning, is doing something about it. She's im porting work clothes from China and finding a warm welcome from American re tailers.

title: U. S. Indicates Willingness To Negotiate on Textiles
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)  A State Department spokesman said today that there is room for negotiation in United States efforts to ob tain Governmentlevel agree ments to restrain the flow of textiles from Japan, Hong Kong, Korea and Taiwan.

title: JORDANIANS HOME FROM JIDDA TALKS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept 24 The Jordanian Government's delegation to the reconciliation conference with Palestinian guerrillas in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, returned to Amman today but did not disclose what had gone on at the talks.

title: CLARENCE W. GALLUP
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept: 24Clarence W. Gallup, a for mer director and purchasing agent of the New York and Pennsylvania Paper Company, died today in Englewood Hos pital. He was 79 years old and lived at 52 Brayton Street.

title: SCHWEITZER FACES MISCONDUCT COUNT AND IS SUSPENDED
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24  State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer was charged to day with extensive misconduct ranging from the crimes of con spiracy and obstruction of jus tice to having private business activities inconsistent with his duties as a judge.

title: Merger News
description: Two Federal courts terminat ed yesterday the Government's three antitrust suits challeng ing three major acquisitions of the International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation.

title: U.S. JETS RAID NORTH FOR 4TH DAY IN A ROW
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 25 (AP) American bombers struck po sitions inside North Vietnam yesterday for the fourth con secutive day, the United States command disclosed today.

title: GOVERNOR SCORED BY BLACK LEADERS
description: Some of the country's most prominent black men and women condemned Governor Rockefeller yesterday for his behavior during the revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: N.A.A.C.P. Leader Opposes Poff as Nominee to Court
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N.J., (AP)The chairman of the na tional board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said tonight that the group would oppose the nomination of Representative Richard H. Poff, Republican of Virginia, who is considered a prospect for the Supreme Court. Bishop Stephen G. Spotswood, he N.A.A.C.P. Official, said President Nixon could expect a fight should he choose Mr. Poff for one of two seats on the Court.

title: Petrie Undergoes Surgery
description: PORLAND, Ore., Sept. 24 (UP)Geoff Petrie of the Port land Trail Blazers underwent surgery today for removal of torn knee cartilage. Dr. Frank B. Smith, the basketball team's physician, said Petrie would be sidelined eight to 10 weeks.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: Writer Is Accused
description: PARIS, Sept. 24 (UPI) Simone de Beauvoir, the novel ist and essayist, was charged today with libeling the French police, the police said. The novelist, who is 63 years old, was formally accused of print ing libelous statements in last April's edition of a leftwing monthly, L'Idiot Internation ale, of which she was director, the police said.

title: CIGARETTES ARE UP IN TAR AND NICOTINE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 24 (UPI)More cigarette brands increased tar and nicotine lev els in the last 10 months than decreased them, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cometogether':Serene Tale of Actor and Tourists Bows
description: "Cometogether," which opened yesterday at a theater near you if you live in a culturally depressed neighborhood, is an empty-headed, romantic movie about a young American actor in Rome who finds himself in a not unpleasant (quite serene, in fact) mnage  trois with two extremely pretty American tourists.Saul Swimmer, the director and co-author of the screenplay, seems to acknowledge that all of the possibilities of the situation (poetic, comic, psychological and pornographic) are simply beyond him, and so he spends most of his time photographing his three principals against travelogue scenery that has been wired with something like rock Muzak.He also, periodically, invokes images of death (a slow-motion automobile accident, a body being fished out of a Venetian canal, a Vietcong massacre of American P. O. W. 's), but they are as wan as the efforts of a small child who makes rude noises to give himself importance.Luciana Paluzzi, who is Italian, and Rosemary Dexter, who is British, play the two American tourists, speaking their lines with tiny, disembodied American voices that may not be entirely their own. They look so much alike, that I never did figure out which actress was playing which role. Such interchangeability in, say, a Truffaut film, would have to be interpreted as a psychic mystery. Here it's a casting goof.Tony Anthony, an American actor who has made a number of Westerns in Italy, plays the American actor, and he must be the least magnetic movie personality to come along since Frankie Vaughn, whom all of you lucky ones won't remember as Marilyn Monroe's secondary love interest in "Let's Make Love."

title: ELECTIONS BOARD ORDERED REMADE
description: A change in the traditional composition of the city's Board of Elections was ordered yes terday by Judge Marvin E. Frankel in Federal District Court here.

title: U. S. Sees Its Role In Energy Growing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Administration spokesmen said here today that the Govern ment intended to expand its role in the energy business in order to solve problems of sup ply and to protect the environ ment. They called on industry leaders to support creation of a Department of Natural Re sources as originally outlined by President Nixon in his en ergy message to the Congress last June 4.

title: Carolyn S.Pfunder Is Bride of Private
description: SUFFIELD, Conn., Sept. 24  Miss Carolyn Susan Pfunder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elbert F. Pfunder, and Pfc. Charles Stephen Schnelle Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schnelle of Westport, were married here this afternoon in the First Church of Christ, Congrega tional, by the Rev. J. Gor man Smith. He was assisted by the Rev. Daniel J. Sulli van, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Antiques: Shops in Lisbon
description: What to look for when pursuing antiques in Lisbon? One item in particular. Sim ple blown glass.

title: 6 ARE KILLED AS BUS HITS TRUCK UPSTATE
description: NORTH BRANCH, N. Y., Sept. 24Six persons were killed and seven injured today when a bus converted into a camper struck a pickup truck from behind on a downgrade three miles north of this Sullivan County com munity.

title: BRITISH EXPEL 90 RUSSIANS FOR ESPIONAGE ACTIVITIES; DENY REENTRY TO 15 MORE
description: LONDON, Sept 24Britain today ordered 90 Soviet repre sentatives to leave because of espionage activities and barred the return of 15 more who are temporarily away.

title: A Pied Piper Gets Memorial
description: If one believed in those things, one Might see a momentary shadow slipping from behind a tree in Washington Square Park this morning, smiling at the children. He would be a tiny man, a little over 5 feet, with a serene face and an erect carriage. Tucked under his arm would be a briefcase, filled with all the things that children need candies and cakes, and tops, and cray ons, and picture books. As he disappears down a path in the park, one might see in a sudden cloud, a host of children joyously following after.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Numbered Account Heads Phipps Family 4Horse 110 Matron Entry Today
description: The rotund clocker, a thor oughbred racing observer for more than 40 years, was in the horsemen's room at Belmont Park yesterday scrutinizing the mimeographed sheet that lists the next day's entries.

title: DOCTORS TESTIFY ON HOSPITAL TIES
description: Doctors testifying before a legislative committee divided sharply yesterday on whether hospitals should be required to grant staff privileges to any physician who wants them.

title: HENRY A. M'CASHIN, MACY'S EXECUTIVE
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 24 Henry A. McCashin, who had been an executive of Macy's Herald Square for 42 years until his retirement last July, died yesterday of a heart at tack at his summer home in Brant Beach. He was 68 years old and also lived at 256 Kim ball Avenue in this community.

title: OPERATINGREVENUES SHOW RISE AT T.V.A.
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 24 Tennessee Valley Authority operating revenues for the fis cal year ended June 30 were $598million, up almost 25 per cent over the preceding fiscal year, according to the 1971 Power Annual Report released today.

title: Two Airlines Appeal to U.S. on Fares
description: Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, con tending that they face a ruinous price war over trans Atlantic fares, have appealed to Washington for help, but Government officials have de clined to take any immediate action.

title: Schweitzer Tied to Loan Transactions
description: The charges against Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer presented to the Court on the Judiciary by its counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh, shed new light on some of Jus tice Schweitzer's business deal ings.

title: Bridge:Declarer's Small Slam Wins No Plaudits Across the Table
description: In a duplicate game a play er sometimes works hard to overcome a bad distribution, only to find that his magnifi cent play has earned him hardly any match points. A sad story on these lines was related recently by Norman Jacobowitz in the Southern California Bridge News.

title: AWARDS TO SPUR WRITING OF MUSIC
description: Sixteen young American soloists have been chosen by the Ford Foundation under its Concert Artists Program to act as catalysts for the writing of new music. Each musician will receive $5,000 to help pay re hearsal, travel and similar ex penses, or to free himself from nonperforming tasks so he may concentrate on his profession al development.

title: Hot Line in Space
description: Agreements by the White House and the Kremlin to switch their groundbased hot line to a more reliable satellite communications system and to give each other advance warning of missile launches that might occasion panicky reaction are the first tangible fruits of the twoyearold SALT talks. They represent prudent steps to reduce the danger of accidental nuclear war; they are also welcome signs of cooperation between the world's two leading nuclear powers.

title: Value Held Arbitrary
description: The figure of $2million given as the value of the painting stolen in Brussels is arbitrary and probably only a fraction of what it would bring in the in conceivable event of its sale by the owner.

title: PETTERSON VICTOR IN 4TH SOLING RACE
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I. (AP)  Pelle Petterson of Askim, Swe den, beat David Forbes of Aus tralia in the fourth race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club centennial sailing series in the Soling Class on Long Is land Sound today.

title: WALLACE SUPPORTER HITS TAX INDICTMENT
description: MONTGOMERY, Aia., Sept. 24 (UPI)  Earl Goodwin, a Selma businessman who is one of several supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace under Fed eral indictment for income tax evasion, accused the Nixon Ad ministration today of political persecution to hurt Mr. Wal lace nationally.

title: Brazilian General Ousted Alter Prelate's Talk
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 24 (AP)The director of Brazil's Superior War College was dis missed today, following a con troversial speech at the insti tution yesterday by a Roman Catholic archbishop.

title: Armed Woman Held on Hijacking Tip
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24A woman who allegedly planned to seize la New Yorkbound jetliner to force the release of two im prisoned Black panthers and fly them out of the country was seized at Metropolitan Airport here today with a pistol and a satchel containing sev eral sticks of dynamite.

title: Man In the News
description: More than 30 years ago, a tall, lean grayeyed young lawyer from Columbia Uni versity was working in the New York County District Attorney's office in the ap peals bureau, which was headed by a man named Stanley H, Fuld. Today Mr. Fuld is Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals. His former side, Lawrence Edward Walsh, no less lean than he was then, is a mem ber of the New York law firm Of Davis, Polk & Ward well a firm with a tradition Of encouraging its members to lend themselves to public service.

title: Anderson in New Hampshire
description: INTERVALE, N. H., Sept. 24 (AP)Representative William R. Anderson, Democrat of Tennessee, a potential Presi dential candidate, told a gath ering of New Hampshire muni cipal officials today that any Federal Revenuesharing plan should funnel funds directly to local communities. Mr. Ander son made, the comment in a talk to the New Hampshire Municipal Association on a tour of the state to sample his chances in its primary.

title: Soviet Demands Early Halt in Lake Baikal Pollution
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24The So viet leadership, displaying a renewed sense of urgency over the pollution issue, called to day for prompt measures to protect the environment of Lake Baikal, the world's largest fresh water lake.

title: Giants Bow, 65 Lead Cut to 2
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 24If the season lasted another month, the Reds would have a magnificent shot at the pen nant. As it is now, they must content themselves with knock ing off every poor, fumbling team that does have a chance.

title: Fischer Cautions Officials About Attica Statements
description: State officials who played leading roles during the upris ing and police assault at the Attica Correctional Facility were requested by Deputy State Attorney General Robert E. Fischer yesterday to re frain from making prejudicial statements.

title: Dr. De Marco Named Head Of AmericanKorean Unit
description: Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chair man of the, AmericanKorean Foundation, announced yester day the appointment of Dr. Roland R. De Marco as presi dent of the organization, which is dedicated to helping Koreans help themselves.

title: CUTS IN LUNCH AID ARE CALLED NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 An official of the Department of Agriculture said today that formal approval would soon be given to several controversial amendments to guidelines gov erning disbursement of funds for the school lunch program.

title: TV Review
description: Tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock, on the Columbia Broadcasting System, a pro gram will begin with the sounds of music and a heav ily accented Voice describing much dancing, the singing of children and the young man who plays his new sonata to his new young lady. As the voice tells us, the sounds and images could have been plucked out of Vienna or the Berlin Conservatory. It hap pens, though, that they are the survivors of Czechoslo vakia's World War  concen tration in Terezin.

title: Monetary Reserve Assets Off $1.15Billion in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  United States monetary reserve assets declined by $1,155,000, 000 in August, the Treasury re ported today.

title: G. MAXWELL ULE, 64, AN ADVERTISING AIDE
description: G. Maxwell Ule, a former vice president in charge of market ing service of Kenyon & Eck hardt, Inc., an advertising agency, and more recently a consultant to the Milwaukee Advertising Laboratory, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, He was 64 years old and lived at 5 Loch Lane, Port Chester, N. Y.

title: The Last Rebel' Stars Sheepish Namath
description: "The Last Rebel" is an Italian Western that looks as if it had been made by someone who took a correspondence course from the Famous Film Directors School in Westport ("Earn money in your spare time. Be a famous film director . . ."). It is dumb and technically dreadful but harmless.Joe Namath, in a style that might be identified as sheepish, plays a Confederate soldier who refuses to surrender when Lee does. Either Namath seems embarrassed (when he has to say something like "All right, men, guns on the table!") or else he simply grins, as if in acknowledgment of his great good luck to be making any movie at all. The film was directed by Denys McCoy, who is identified in my publicity material as a nephew of Andrew Wyeth.

title: ANDIAMO SCORES IN HALF TON SAIL
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 24 For the third straight day in the One Ton Cup yachting series, Andy MacGowan's Bul let took the measure of the small but exclusive fleet. This time the margin was just 17 seconds over Kangaroo.

title: GROVER HALL JR., EDITOR IN SOUTH
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 24Grover C. Hall Jr., a for mer nationally syndicated col umnist and a former editor of The Montgomery Adiertiser, died today of cancer. He was 56 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
Football Makes Big Pitch Today
description: Ed Marinaro opens his Heisman Trophy campaign, Tennessee tests Pat Sullivan's credentials and Notre Dame returns to Lafayette, Ind.

title: Saigon and Hanoi Can Do It
description: PARISThe South Vietnamese un derstand that what the American peo ple want to know is, When will American forces be out of Vietnam? and, Was it all worth while? Our people are working and fighting to make these two questions soon and yes. But we realize too that unless the Communists show some interest in negotiationand they have shown none yetfor us the war goes on.

title: Market Place: Capital's Funds Are Not Bearish
description: There is a lot of bearish ness aroundT. J. Holt and Eliot Janeway are among the most outspoken gloom and doomers at presentand we wondered how the men at the Capital Research and Management Company felt.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Sept. 25, 1971 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 5 P.M. to discuss Jerusalem.

title: Music: Rarities (and a New Look) at Philharmonic
description: The subscription season of the New York Philharmonic started Thursday evening with an unusual program and something of a new look in clothes. Both the conductor, Pierre Boulez, and the or chestra have discarded tails for tuxedos. Sign of the times?

title: GEORGE R. WOOD
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Sept. 24George It Wood, a motel owner and member of the board of the Hamptons Association, died of a heart attack yester day in New York Hospital. He was in his fifties.

title: BEN GLICK
description: Ben Glick, president since 1933 of Ben Glick, Inc., an in terior designing and decorating concern, died of a heart attack on Thursday at New York Hos pital, He was 68 years old and lived at 35 Sutton Place.

title: Seoul Sees Pact Inevitable
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 24 (AP)  South Korean Gov ernment sources said today that it appears inevitable that Korea will reach a bilateral agreement on textile exports to the United States in view of the firm United States stand on the issue.

title: Notes on People
description: While they were picking up their marriage license at the Municipal Building, looking happier than many of the younger couples waiting on line, the prospective bride groom, 79yearold W. Averell Harriman,and his fiance 51yearold Mrs. Pamela Dig by Churchill Hayward, seemed briefly to be stepping on each other's lines.

title: Tax on Plastic Containers By City Is Stayed by court
description: New York City was barred in state supreme court yester day from starting to collect a special 2cent tax on plastic containers sold here pending the outcome of a trial sched uled for next Friday.

title: Black God, White Devil,' From Brazil
description: "Black God, White Devil," which opens a two-day stand today at the Fifth Avenue Cinema as the final offering in the retrospective of Brazil's revolutionary Cinema Novo, is, at once, one of the most visually effective and artistic examples of the work of Glauber Rocha, a leading light among Cinema Novo's young directors. But as a contemporary allegory fulminating darkly against miseries inflicted on the poor by landowners and the Government, it is more mystically stylized than moving.Rocha's dedication to a barbaric theme is obvious but his religious symbolism and floklore make for stark, strictly native drama to which it is hard to re-relate despite literal English subtitles for the Portuguese dialogue.The essentials of his plot are simple. Basically, he is relating, with the aid of off-screen troubadours (cantadores) the dual struggle of Manoel, an oppressed cowhand who seeks salvation as a devoted follower of Sebastian, a black, religious mystic, and then with Corisco, one of the last, fierce outlaws battling the landowners.His tragedy is, of course, unavoidable after he murders a rancher who has tried to rob him. Sebastian (personifying spiritual help) is killed by Manoel's patiently suffering wife, Rosa, and Corisco (the temporal savior) is ultimately dispatched by Antonio Das Mortes, the killer hired by the church and landowners.Rocha, it should be noted, made this, his second feature, in 1963 when he was 25 and his black-cloaked, dour executioner became the hero of the sequel, "Antonio Das Mortes" shown here last year.As Manoel, Gerardo Del Ray, is an authentically driven, illiterate and confused peasant for whom there is no salvation. Lydio Sylva and Othon Bastos, to whom he turns, emerge as strange, larger-than-life figures on a strange landscape, as does Mauririo Do Valle as Das Mortes.Rocha, it is apparent, is more concerned with his symbolism, injustices and the arid, sombre "sertao" of provincial Bahia in which he filmed, than in compelling characterization. His symbols are broodingly obvious parallels to Biblical events and his outlaws are theatrically savage."The Earth belongs to man, not God or the Devil," Rocha proclaims climactically. And his film, like his credo, is simple, black-and-white, more arresting as a shocking polemic than as memorable drama.

title: LETELLIER'S 279 TAKES OPEN TITLE
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 24  Ron Letellier, 36yearold professional from the North Hills Country Club, Manhasset, L.I., sank a decisive 18foot birdie putt at the last hole to win the Metropolitan open golf championship by one stroke to day.

title: Art: Apathy Absent as Season Begins
description: According to general ex pectations, originating who knows how, the new art sea son is supposed to be greeted with public apathy. It is too early to tell about the gal leries, but there was no sign of apathy at either the Whit ney or the Metropolitan this week. On Wednesday after noon, an ordinary day, both were well filled if not exactly jammed. The Metro politan's new Der show, which has not had much publicity, had a good crowd, and Whitney was really alive, which it isn't always.

title: Harris in Race for Presidency, The Second Democrat to Declare
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Senator Fred R. Harris of Okla homa became today the second declared candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Books of The Times
description: NIGHTSPAWN. By John Banville. 224 pages. Norton. $5.95.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope for ARM Accord
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 24 The chief United States nego tiator at the nuclear arms talks indicated today that he saw at least an even chance that the 11week session now ended here would lead to a limitation on defensive missiles by the end of the year.

title: International Executives Group Elects First Woman President
description: The International Executives Association, a 55yearold world trade group that has been dominated by men, an nounced yesterday the election of a woman as its new presi dent.

title: TV of the People Operating on Cable
description: Television of the people, not just for the people, has begun in the United States.

title: Nixon Gets Support On Mortgage Rates
description: The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks formally asked its 491 member banks yesterday to continue to charge no more for new mort gages and other kinds of loans than they charged just prior to the announcement of the wage price freeze on Aug. 15. Alto gether, savings banks have as sets of about $87billion and are a major factor in the home mortgage market.

title: Engineer Named Head Of Mine Safety Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Donald P. Schlick, a mining engineer who has headed the coal mine health and safety activities of the United States Bureau of Mines for the last six months, was pro moted today to the post of acting deputy director of the bureau, in charge of all health and safety matters, in cluding those in metal mines.

title: The Right to Die With Dignity
description: Few people ever think about their own death. Some occasionally may joke about going this way or that but it is a rare person who can truly contemplate a world without him in it. However, there are some who can envision such a world. People who are desperately sick often are forced by circumstances to such contemplation. Over the last year, we have lived with someone forced to that kind of self awareness. My husband's brother, Flip, died of cancer on June 23, 1971, at the age of 23.

title: North American Output Of Newsprint Down 2.7%
description: North American production of newsprint last month amounted to 957,341 tons down 2.7 per cent from a year ago, the Newsprint Division of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

title: 7MAN HIGH COURT DELAYS KEY CASES ON A NEW DOCKET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Supreme Court, faced with the likelihood that only seven Justices will be behind the bench when the new Court term begins Oct. 4, today post poned scheduled hearings on capital punishment and several other major issues.

title: A Dam for Sicily's Peasants
description: PARTINICO, SicilyPerhaps this is the first Year, in our part of the world, that everyone is happy when it Every Week a lot of people (some of them every day) Come to see how high the waters of the new lake have risen, and they are constantly astounded. There are many dikes in the world of course, and quite a few of them bigger than this one, but none can hold more meaning for the local popu lation.

title: MINISTERS GATHER FOR I.M.F PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Finance ministers and central bank governors from more than 100 countries began arriving here today for the annual meet ing of the International Mone tary Fund, which will focus on, but not resolve, the world's current monetary uncertainty.

title: Queen's Painting Stolen From Gallery in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (UPI) A 300yearold painting owned by Queen Elizabeth H wag stolen from the Queen's Gal lery next to Buckingham Pal ace today. The gallery was filled with visitors at the time.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Budd Company, Philadelphia, yesterday named Gilbert F. Rich ards as president and chief executive officer and a director of the company. He succeeds Philip W. Scott, who was named chairman of the board. Mr. Richards has been president of Budd's Automotive Division since 1968, and was ap pointed to the addition al position of executive vice presidentatitotnotIve products of the Budd Company in February, 1971. Mr. Scott, who joined Budd in 1958, has been president since 1965 and a director since 1960.

title: September Means BacktoSchool for Adults as Well as Children
description: One stormy afternoon a few days ago, a hard rain ham mered at the oak tree and abstract sculptures in the courtyard of the New School for Social Research at 66 West 12th Street, a school that describes itself as America's first university for adults.

title: Writ Is Obtained
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 24 (AP)  A United States District Court judge today directed New York state officials, from Governor Rockefeller to Attica prison guards, to show cause Monday why they should not be barred from questioning inmates about the Attrica riot Sept. 9.

title: Tito and Brezhnev Said to End Talks on Document on Relations
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24  The Soviet Communist party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and Yugoslavia's president, Marshal Tito, were reported to night to have concluded nego tiations on a document outlin ing their party and state rela tions.

title: Mara Lashes at Critics of Giants' Shift
description: Fran Tarkenton missed the New York Giants' twohour drill at Yankee Stadium yes terday morning. The quarter back was home in bed with a 102degree temperature, but was expected to recover in time to call signals when the Giants open their home sched ule tomorrow against the Washington Redskins.

title: Students in Vietnam
description: ASHLAND, N. H.There are more than 42,000 university students in Saigon, and for most of them there is no meaning in their lives or in their ed ucation. Not only are they disconnected from the war (students are deferred), but they find it wise not to discuss it, It does not appear in any part of their curriculum, they are jailed for wanting peace, branded as traitors if they protest against Government policy.

title: An Appraisal
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24If you turn your back on the $1 billion worth of high camp rising ominously on the Albany Mall, you will face one of the neatest architec tural achievements in the country. Just beyond the State Capitol, fronting Acad emy Park on Elk Street, is the new head quarters of the New York State Bar Association, dedicated today. This $1,626,616 center for the 22,000 mem bers of the State Bar is an object lesson in how to build intelligently, sensitively and well. It is nice to know that someone is doing something right.

title: Universality of Restraint
description: Making any longterm program for wageprice restraint work effectively in peacetime is difficult at best; it is impossible if controls are confined to certain highly visible sectors of the economy in the hope that every thing else will automatically fall into place.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: First Comment by Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24The So viet people were told tonight that China was troubled by a number of grave internal politi cal developments, which Pe king's leaders were trying to keep from the world.

title: OTB Looks Out of State For Its Action in Winter
description: Howard Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Corpor ation, asked yesterday for a change in Federal law to allow OTB to compensate outofstate tracks when New Yorkers wag er on them.

title: Queens G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The names of three American servicemen killed in the Indo china war, were announced to day by the Defense Depart ment. Among them was Pfc. Miguel A. Bynoe of Jamaica, Queens, of the Army.

title: The Talk of Kofu
description: KOFU, Japan, Sept. 18 The rolling hills and slopes that ripple gently below Fuji yama are misty on these chilly autumn days, but the sun usually peeks through billowy clouds by midmorn ing, warming the fingers of the squat women who roam the slopes wearing white aprons and scarves and car rying baskets. This is the time of year when To monosuke Imai is most happy. The women are picking grapes and he is busy practicing an art he learned from his father and sent his son to Europe for four years to study further  making wines like those of France.

title: Combination Candidate
description: When a man of less than established and nationwide political appeal runs for President, conventional wisdom has it that he isn't; he is running for Vice President but can't say so.

title: French Jail Guards Protest
description: PARIS, Sept. 24 (Reuters) Convicts in France were per mitted no visits from relatives, lawyers or priests today as guards staged a day of action to express their shock at the Clairvaux jail escape attempt in which two hostages died.

title: Spring Is Seen as Start Of Trans Alaskan Pipeline
description: Senator Mike Gravel, Demo crat of Alaska, predicted yes terday that construction of the Trans Alaskan Pipeline would begin in early spring and that the Department of Interior would grant a permit for con struction before the end of this year.

title: ADDICT TREATMENT BY U.S. UP SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The director of the National In stitute of Mental Health said today that there had been a threefold increase over the last year in the number of narcotics addicts receiving treatment at community centers supported by Federal grants.

title: Crown Zellerbach to Raise Capacity for Funded Debt
description: The Crown Zellerbach Cor poration, San Francisco, an nounced yesterday that agree ments had been reached with holders of its outstanding pri vately placed promissory notes to increase the company's fund ed debt capacity from 35 to 50 per cent of total capitalization.

title: Big Stock Offering Filed With S. E. C. By Southland Corp.
description: The Southland Corporation, Dallas, announced filing yester day with the Securities and Ex change Commission of plans for an offering of 744,419 shares of common stock. The underwrit ers will be managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., and Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: Suit Filed to Unfreeze Teacher Raises.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The National Education Asso ciation filed a suit in the United States District Court here today asking that the President's Cost of Living Council or any other Govern ment agency be prevented from blocking salary increases for teachers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: At the same moment President Nixon was delivering his Labor Day message and was exhorting the nation to attain new prosperity without war or inflation, under his orders, one Million tons of bombs were being dropped, largely on innocent people in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: PANTHERS ADMIT GUILT IN ROBBERY
description: Three Black Panthers under indictment in Queens on mur der and arson charges in the slaying of an official of their party pleaded guilty yesterday to holding up an allblack so cial club in the Bronx last June 5.

title: Texts of British Note to Soviet on Spying and of Home Letters
description: Following are the texts of a British note to the Soviet Union on espionage activities, as made public in London and transmitted by Reuters, and of two letters from Sir Alec DouglasHome, the British Foreign Secretary, to Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet For eign Minister, as transmitted by the London bureau of The New York Times:

title: New President Is Named For Volkswagen Concern
description: BONN, Sept. 24The super visory board of Volkswagen de cided unanimously today to ap point Rudolf Leiding, a long time VW executive, as new president of Europe's largest automobile company.

title: Tabarly Wins Yacht Race
description: GIBRALTAR, Sept. 24 (UPI) Eric Tabarly of France won the Falmouth, England, to Gi braltar yach race today in his Pen Duick III. Tabarly, famed for his roundtheworld solo yacht voyage, completed the 1,020 miles in a record time of 6 days 44 minutes.

title: World Gets Rights to Memoirs By Gehlen and Loses an Editor
description: The World Publishing Com pany signed this week a con tract for the controversial mem oirs of Gen. Reinhard Gehlen, West Germany's former intelli gence chiefand lost a top edi tor who had played a key role in obtaining them.

title: Police Lose a 2d Judge in Crater Case
description: Still actively pursuing the mysterious disappearance of Judge Joseph Force Crater after 41 years, the Police De partment's missing persons unit is trying to locate the man who reported him miss ing in 1930Simon H. Rif kind.

title: Humphrey Suffers Setback as Senate, 3912, Rejects Plan to Curb Warheads
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 In his most embarrassing set back since returning to Capitol Hill Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey found an apparently un interested Senate rejecting to day the major disarmament amendment of the year, which he had proposed.

title: Swedish Cabinet Bars Spy's Plea for Parole
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 24 The Cabinet refused today to grant parole for Stig Wenner strom, who was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1964 for selling Swedish defense se crets to the Soviet Union. Wennerstrom, a former air force colonel, had asked the Government to fix a date for his parole because of ill health. He is 65 years old.

title: Tigers' 7Run 7th Beats Yankees, 85, For Coleman's 19th
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (AP) The Detroit Tigers scored seven runs off Mel Stottlemyre in the seventh inning and beat the New York Yankees, 85, to night as Joe Coleman won his 19th game.

title: DINGHY SERIES WON BY ANNAPOLIS CREW
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 24 St. John Martin and Fred Patch became the second Annapolis crew ever to win the Interna tional 14foot dinghy class na tional championship regatta to day.

title: Britain Tells How Soviet Spread Its Spy Network
description: LONDON, Sept. 24A year ago, at the Farnborough Air Show on the outskirts of London, a man who called himself Jim offered a British defense official a ride to a train station. The ride turned into a trip to London, during which the driver identified himself more accurately as Dmitri Ivano vich Sorokin, second secretary of the Soviet Consulate in London.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Sept. 24What is at stake is not just money but the West's whole postwar achievement  the system of international security, trade and economic growth. That is one unexcitable Englishman's view of the monetary crisis as the bankers and treasury men of the world meet in Washington to seek a way out.

title: Hunt Leads by 7 Shots
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 24 (UPI)Bernard Hunt's eight underpar 64 in the third round of the Wills open golf tour nament today gave him a 54 hole total of 203 and a seven shot lead.

title: Slap at the U.N.
description: With scarcely a hint of protest from the White House the Senate has incorporated into the military procure ment bill an amendment that would seriously undercut the authority of the United Nations and the credibility of American support for the world organization.

title: French Banking Change
description: PARIS, Sept. 24 (Reuters) The Bank of France issued to day a circular to French com mercial banks allowing them to increase their positions in foreign currencies, on the con dition that these purchases take place on the financial franc market.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Maj. Walter Clopton Wingfield, the British aristocrat, devised the first court for a new outdoor game he was attempting to patent in England, he settled on the shape of the hourglass. All existing court surfaces at the time were rectangular. His court, he reasoned, would be new and distinctive, narrower at the net than at the ends, a symbol.

title: M'GOVERN MEETS STUDENT SKEPTICS
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 24The campaign poster for Senator George McGovern on the wall of the Long Beach State Student Union read, We've been misled too long. Demand truth.

title: A Pump Failure Could Delay Atom Test in Alaska
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 Whether the hydrogen bomb test called Cannikin is held on Amchitka island in the west ern Aleutians next month de pends on whether a set of pumps continues to operate, as well as on whether President Nixon decides that he wants the test made.

title: Japan Reports Formal Bid
description: TOKYO, Sept 24 (AP)  The United States Government has formally asked Japan to state by the end of September wheth er it will accept a Government level agreement restraining its textile exports to American markets, the national daily Yo miuri Shimbun reported today.

title: Two Coast Groups Give Rock Concert At Carnegie Hall
description: The strengths and weak nesses of rock n roll were on display at Carnegie Hall Thurs day night. Fanny, a fairly new West Coast group, opened the program, and immediately dem onstrated the joyous vitality that still courses through what has been described lately as a moribund musical form.

title: Dr. Robert A. Moore, 70, Dead; Led Downstate Medical Center
description: Dr. Robert A. Moore, retired president of the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York and former dean of its School of Medicine, died yesterday at Kings County Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 3500 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: MACY'S PROFIT UP 23% IN QUARTER
description: R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., which expects to be operating at the $1billion annual sales level for the first time next month, re ported yesterday earnings gains of 14 per cent and 23 per cent in its fiscal year and fourth quarter ended July 31, respec tively, compared with the year earlier periods.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Trading of soybean futures opened yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade with spec ulative buying and commercial buying, prompting local pro fessional short covering.

title: Dollar Plunges Again
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (UPI) Uncertainty over the outcome of this weekend's meeting of major financial nations in Washington sent the United states dollar plunging to new lows in Britain and West Ger many today. The American currency also lost ground on other money markets.

title: Colonel Is Unable To Recall Seeing Report on Mylai
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 24 An Army officer formerly on the staff of the Americal Divi sion in Vietnam said today he did not recall having seen a formal report on the infantry attack by Mylai 4 despite testi mony that he had once had the document in his possession.

title: NEW HOCKEY LOOP PICKS CLUB SITES
description: The World Hockey Associa tion, a fledgling group that is going to attempt to compete with the National Hockey League, awarded 11 franchises to major North American cities last night and declared its in tention to begin play Oct. 1, 1972.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 24 Eddie Rossi, the Poly Prep cocaptain, scored the winning touchdown in the third period today as Poly Prep defeated Pingry, 1814, With his team trailing, 1412, Rossi scored on a 1yard run to cap a 75yard drive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mead Sets Expansion
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 24 (UP1)The Mead Corporation is, joining the Inland Container Corporation and three Japan ese concerns in building a $4 million oilfractioning plant at Kakogava, Japan, with a ca pacity of 70,000 tons a year.

title: SMITH AND MRS. KING MOVE TO SEMIFINALS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI) Topseeded Stan Smith and Mrs. Billie Jean King, the Unit ed States Open champions, ad vanced to the semifinals of the $73,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis championship today.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The rate at which fluid is being dripped into a patient's veins can be accurately measured with an electronic flowmeter invented by a Columbia Uni versity professor. The device will relieve the nurse of the timecon suming task of counting the drops by using a wristwatch.

title: Delay in Protecting Wilderness Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Conservation leaders charged today that a program to pre serve a small portion of the nation's wilderness for posteri ty was being thwarted by both the White House and Congress, which enacted the program.

title: The Magnificent Fiction
description: LONDONAncient sailors found rough passage in the straits between Sicily and Italy. On one hand was the Rock of Scylla. On the other was the Whirlpool of Charybdis, and monsters of mythology infested each. Scylla and Charybdis were equally dangerous alterna tives. The avoidance of one risked encounter with the other.

title: Isabel Lucom, Robert Clark Plan Wedding
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wilson C. Lucom of Washington and Palm Beach, Fla., of the en gagement of Mrs. Lucom's daughter, Miss Isabel Maria Lucom, to Robert Marvin Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Raymond Clark of San Diego, Calif.

title: MILWAUKEE GROUP SPOOFS JOB PLANS
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25On the surface, it looked like a typical Model Cities project.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Hunt of Britain Captures Wills Event by 4 Strokes
description: DALMAHOY, Scotland, Sept. 25 (AP)Bernard Hunt, despite a final 73, won the $24,000 Willis open golf tournament to day with a fourround total of 276, 12 under par.

title: Humphrey Calls for Study Of Congress by Citizens
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humph rey, Democrat of Minnesota, proposed today the creation of a 15member citizen's commit tee to study Congress and rec ommend ways to make it more effective.

title: Montclair State Bows
description: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Sept. 25Driving 47 yards on seven plays midway through the third period, East Strouds burg State College gained its second straight football victory today, downing Montclair State, 147.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (UPI) Tom Shopay singled home Chico Salmon with the go ahead run in the 11th inning today as the Baltimore Orioles ran their winning streak to sev en games by defeating the Cleveland Indians, 64.

title: View of Sea From L.I.: Big Boats, Little Boats
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I. When a fellow spends his work year in midtown Man hattan breathing in the heavy fumes of automobiles it's nice to have a place like this to escape to for vacation.

title: MICH. STATE ROUTS OREGON STATE, 3114
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 25 (UPI)Frank Kolch, a third string quarterback, threw for two touchdowns and Brad Van Pelt scored twice on intercep tions today as Michigan State posted a 3114 triumph over Oregon State.

title: Oldest Fair On L.I. Sheds Modernity For the Past
description: MINEOLA, L. I.Nostalgia has gained favor this year, and that would seem to bode well for the Long Island Fair, which opens next Friday for three days at the Old Beth page Village Restoration.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Win one, lose one.

title: RISE IN CHEMICALS IS CAUSING ALARM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The vast array of manmade chemicals such as PCH, DDT, DDE and 2, 4, 5T that are turning up increasingly in every nook and corner of the globe is producing outcries of alarm from scientists, ecologists and Congressmen.

title: Photography
description: PICASSO has not often been noted for being incorrect in his eval uations of other ar tists, but he surely erred when, during the second World War, he said to Bras sai, Why did you give up drawing for the camera? You have a gold mine and instead you exploit a silver mine. For, interesting and effective though much of Brassai's work in other me dia may behe has created films, drawings, sculptures and poemshis major crea tive contribution is unques tionably his photography. His photographs, unlike any of his other creations, are entirely and unmistakably his own; taken all together, his silver images form one of the most rewarding bodies of work in 20thcentury photog raphy.

title: The Sources of Insurgency
description: The rebellion in South Vietnam began hi 1958 as a reaction against Ngo Dinh Diem's repressive pol icies, particularly the re turn to landlords of fields that had been given to ten ant farmers and day labor ers by the Vietminh during the first Indochina war, the persecution of former Viet minh cadres and soldiers, and the suppression of all political parties except the secret Canlao organization founded by Diem's brother and chief adviser, Ngo Dinh Nhu. There is no evi dence that this insurgency was directed from North Vietnam or that, in the be ginning, it was directed at all.

title: MEDICAID FRAUD LAID TO CARRIERS
description: Commissioner of Investiga tion Robert K. Ruskin said yes terday that the city may have been defrauded out of millions of dollars by some transporta tion companies in the Medicaid program for the sick poor.

title: Don Juan's 21Year Affair With the Met
description: TWENTY  ONE years ago, a young basso from Italy crossed the Atlantic to make his debut on the night that ush ered in a new operatic dy nasty. Last Monday, history was repeated. For the open ing night of his final season as general manager, Rudolf Bing called upon Cesare Siepi to sing the role he sang on that eventful evening in 1950 King Philip in Verdi's Don Carlo.

title: M'RAE HITS PAIR
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 25?? Giants couldn't do it in the day, light, either. For the second time within 24 hours, they lost by a 65 score to the Reds, to further complicate the Western Division race in the National League.

title: Preps
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Sept. 25 An 80yard passrun play with Paul Buika tossing to Ted Berry provided the highlight of a 196 victory by Loomis over Hopkins Grammar today. It was the opening game for both teams.

title: Floyd and Kermit at the crossroads
description: Despite its brevity, Fire Sermon is simonpure, dyed in  the  wool, honest  to God Wright Morris of the very highest grade. I am not saying that it is his best bookbut it is a radiant expression of the art he has developed through 30 years and 14 earlier novels. Although it is anything but preachy, it will stick in the minds of some members of the congregation for a long time.

title: GODDARD LEADER IN STAR REGATTA
description: MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 25 Jack Goddard of the Sandy Bay Yacht Club, Rockport, Mass., and the Cape Ann, Mass., fleet took a 1point lead for the Nut meg Trophy today after the first two races of the Star Class regatta were sailed off Milford Y. C. One race remains to be sailed tomorrow in the regatta, the final of the sea son series for the Nash Trophy.

title: Whiteonwhite IN SAN FRANCISCO
Sailing Nepenthe, Purcell Captures Hiscoe Cup Honors
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 25 Martin A. (Skip) Purcell, sailing T. Vincent Learson's tallrigged 50foot sloop, Nep enthe, out of American Y. C., Rye, N. Y., won the Belle Haven Club's annual cruising race for the Hiscoe Trophy today.

title: Oklahoma State Triumphs Over Virginia Tech, 2416
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Sept. 25 (UPI)Brent Blackman, a quar terback, scored two touch downs today, one of them on a 79yard scamper, and led Okla homa State to a 2416 victory over Virginia Tech.

title: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title
IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONEverybody is com menting on the musual opportunity given to President Nixon by the need to appoint two Supreme Court jus tices. He can shape the direction of the Court for a generation, they say, but that's not the half of it.

title: Cuite Plans FoodLabel Bill
description: All additives, preservatives and other ingredients would have to be listed on the labels of canned or prepared food sold in New York City under a bil lthat Thomas J. Cuite, ma jority leader of the City Council, said yesterday that he would introduce to help people avoid substances, that might triger allergic reactions or cause intestinal disturbances. He said he anticipated spirit ed oposition from food pack agers.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Preps
description: Hubie Morgan, a 200pound allcity fullback last season, re turned a kickoff 90 yards yes terday and Kevin Sylvan scored two touchdowns as Horace Mann defeated Hackley, 2414, at Horace Mann's field. Sylvan, a junior, scored on a 10yard run and was on the receiving end of a 13yard pass from Rich Hagan. Hagan also scored on a 53yardrun.

title: Prelate in Brazilian Dispute Flies to Rome for Synod
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 25 The Roman Catholic Archbish op of Salvador, Bahia, the Most Rev. Avelar Brando, flew to Rome today for the Bishops' Synod after setting off a con troversy by warning the Bra zilian Government against strict application of the na tion's laws against subversion.

title: Beach Boys Fans Here Demand The Old Hits, Not the New Ones
description: One of the mixed blessings of rock stardom is the recurring demand by listeners that per formers play the roles of living juke boxes. Like audiences everywhere, most people who go to rock concerts are more interested in hearing what they know than what they don't know, and there's the rub that grates the nerve ends of so many rock players.

title: Hugo Black An Elemental Force
description: It was his qualities as a human being as much as his particular legal views that made Hugo La Fayette Black, who died yesterday at the age of 85, so remarkable a figure in Amer ican life. There was a serene simplicity in him that baffied sophistication, a power that seemed to be drawn from the earth. He was an elemental force.

title: Publishers Report Upswing In Pupil Use of Newspapers
description: The use of newspapers in the United States and Canada as a classroom teaching aid is on the upswing, affecting nearly five million students in 33,575 schools, the American News paper Publishers Association re ported yesterday.

title: Bowling Green on Top
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Sept. 25 (UPI)Tony Bell, Paul Miles and Jerry Fields scored two touchdowns each to lead Bowling Green State to a 4127 victory over East Carolina to day.

title: Creator of Show ExNavy Man Whose Dream Became Reality
description: Six months after having commanded a dozen Navy patrol craft in Vietnam, Paul Dodson Jr. resumed civilian life in Newport, R. I., in the spring of 1970.

title: Et A1.
description: Mr. Drucker describes these essays as concerned with political (or social) ecology. By way of curious proof, the first praises Kierkegaard's sense of tragedy; it is followed by a dated and ordinary ac count of The New Politics, first published in 1966. There is also a weird essay titled The American Genius Is Political,'an arguable notion. Easily superior are the two long economic essays that end the collectionthe first a sharp discussion of the latesixties merger boom, the second on Japanese management prac tices. The overall moral of the book seems to be that Mr. Drucker the management econ omist has something Mr. Drucker the political (or social) ecologist lacks.

title: W. Michigan Triumphs
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept 25 (AP)  An 80yard touch down dash by Larry Cates in the fourth quarter sparked Western Michigan to an uphill 2717 victory over Northern Il linois today.

title: Is this written in the stars?; See It Through With Nguyen Van Thieu
description: SAIGON.

title: Bergen
description: Hackensack ran into unex pected difficulty, but Passaic Valley performed up to expec tations as both opened their seasons with victories yester day.

title: Civilized classics
Airline Space Race Turns to EconomyClass Lounges
description: It began two years ago, when Northeast Airlines equipped the middle seats in threeabreast seating with dropdown tables to be used if light passenger loads meant that the seats would not be needed. A seat and a half, the airline advertised.

title: Miss Nicholas Is Wed
description: Miss Colombe Margaret Nicholas, daughter of Dimi tri Nicholas of New York, Piqua, Ohio, and Chub Tor, England, and Mrs. Laberge Nicholas of Cincinnati, was married here yesterday after noon to Frank Anthony Bu calo, son of Joseph Bucalo of Queens Village, Queens, and Mrs. Helen Bucalo of Glendale, Queens. The Rev. Edmond Totten performed the ceremony in the Roman Cath olic Church of Our Saviour.

title: Council Considering More Court Actions In Freeze Violations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) The Cost of Living Council announced today that three more court actions were under consideration, including one against a professional football team, for violations of the wageprice freeze.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: H. B. Schaffer to Wed Tezi Currie
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Cur rie, have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Teresita Currie, to Howard Bruner Schaffer of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. M. Schaffer of Kew Gardens, Queens. The wedding is planned for late October.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
THOMAS JEFFERSON TAKES OPENER, 2221
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 25 Thomas Jefferson of Brooklyn scored a touchdown with less than three minutes to play to edge Liberty High, 2221, at the loser's field tonight. The home team had won two games pre viously this year while Jeffer son was opening its season.

title: The multiracial family
description: NOT long ago, a black youth confronted a Minnesota editor who had just given a talk on how interracial adoption was working out in his family.

title: Manor of St. George and Documents Preserved by Its Owners Reflect Early L.I. History
description: MASTIC, L. I.With the opening of schools, teachers are again leading their classes here for a valuable glimpse into the early history and culture of Long Island and their country.

title: Actors, Write Your Own Plays
description: ANYONE who's been reading the sea sonal announcements knows that fewer scripts are scheduled for this year than for last, and everyone who was around last year knows that last year was a new low. Even where money is available, plays aren't. And though we have a small handful of ex citing young playwrights now on the way up, a handful isn't going to be enough to keep Broadway solvent or Off Broadway busy. We're going to need more, and we're going to have to cook up some way of getting them. In the circumstances, I guess, there's nothing else for it. Actors are going to have to start writing their own plays again.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25There has been a lot said and written these past few years about the lack of heroes, the usual paint of the argument being that there is some sort of relationship between the hero shortage in America and the American youngster's tend ency to behave in ways that make parents want to slam their fists through plateglass windows.

title: Reader's Report
description: Early Spring finds us in the company of a familiar archetype, the university lib eral hemmed in by Philistines. Life among the Kentucky red necks is bearable for Prof. Richard Lawrence while he shares his bed and board with Heidi Johnson, one of the more attractive students in his writ ing class  at least, until Heidi's insufficiency and her heavy father (a local fat cat) begin to spell big trouble. Mr. Hazel also looks back in anger at his hero's American Gothic upbringing in a Hoosier vil lage. And he takes note of academic turmoil at various levels, particularly as it affects an interracial love affair.

title: Drugs an Issue
description: It seems that any discusion of public schools these days eventually turns to drugs. Are Long Island schools any worse off or any better off than schools elsewhere when it comes to drugs? What is the situation in Long Island as com pared to other places?

title: Table talk
ARKANSAS UPSET BY TULSA, 21 TO 20
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Sept. I25 (UPI)Lightregarded Tulsa struck for three fourthquarter touchdowns today on the pass ing of Todd Starks to stagger ninthranked Arkansas, 2120.

title: Letters
description: Having read Mr. Gasnick's fish story, I want to re assure him as a neighbor of long standing that his under ground stream is still active. Our basement has a con stantly rising water table. Whenever there is excessive rainfall our basement pump is heavily taxed to keep pumping out a rising tide of water.

title: Medicine/Environment
Football Doctor: He Has the Biggest Medical Practice in Town on Weekends
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 25It was two hours before the Purdue Boilermakers kicked off to the Washington Huskies. In the Stadium training room, Dr. James G. Garrick, the Husky team surgeon, began the busiest medical practice in Seattle last weekendtreating the anxieties, bruises, bumps, sprains, muscle tears, cuts and concussions that the players suffered during and after the nationally televised game.

title: Bayh to Declare His Candidacy For President Despite the Odds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Among the party professionals, the word has been circulating for weeks: Bayh's had it  You don't hear much Bayh talk any more  I bet Bayh pulls out by Christmas.

title: Smithsonian to Be Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) President Nixon has designat ed tomorrow as a special day to honor the scientific and cul tural achievements of the Smith sonian Institution.

title: Medicine/Environment
description: WASHINGTONPCB, one of the alphabet soup of man  made chemicals, has been around for more than a generation. A colorless, odor less liquid, thicker and more syrupy than molasses, this polychlorinated biphenyl has traveled the world as a thickener in plastics, pesti cides, paints and chemicals for office copying equipment. And its strange ability to withstand, temperatures of up to 1,600 degrees Fahrenheit has led to its use as a heat exhange material. (Coils and tubes filled with PCB con duct heat from furnaces to ovens and radiators.) Tens of thousands of tons are used every year.

title: W. Virginia Wins, 163
description: RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI)  Pete Wood scored a touchdown and helped set up another tonight to pace West Virginia to a 163 victory over the University of Richmond. Wood plunged 2 yards for his touchdown and ran 13 yards with a screen pass on a key play of another scoring drive.

title: WASH. STATE BEATS MINNESOTA, 31 TO 20
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 25(UPI) Ty Paine threw 30 yards for a touchdown and ran 2 yards for another today in helping to break Washington State's 11 game losing streak and leading the Cougars to a 3120 victory over Minnesota.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: MARINARO PACES CORNELL VICTORY
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 25Ed Marinaro led Cornell to a 3820 victory over Colgate before 16,500 fans today. It was the first game on synthetic turf at Schoelkopf Field.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There are mystery novels in which there is no mystery.IN SPECTOR GUOTE BREAKS AN EGG by H. R. F. Keating (Doubleday, $4.95) is one. From the beginning, there is no doubt about the nature of the crime and its perpetrator. The point is how the detective goes about gathering evidence evidence, in this case, about a 15yearOld murder.

title: Children Killed in Blaze
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 25 (UPI)Five children were killed early today when fire damaged their frame home on the north side of Birmingham. The vic tims, the children of Mrs. Na mone Diggle, were alone when the fire started. They were identified as Carry Diggle, 2 years old; Willie Lee, 3; Na mone, 4; Marie, 7 and Jeanette, 8.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: AT Bergdorf Goodman, nothing is done that is not done with elegant flourishes. When An drew Goodman, the 64yearold presi dent and owner of the store which confers New York's most prestigious fashion label, brought in a urine sample one recent December to be sent over to his doctor, his secretary, in the Christmas confusion, had it giftwrapped and sent to the doctor's house. It was under the tree on Christmas morning. In the Bridal Salon not long ago a bridetobe was hesitant about buying a white wed ding Own because, as she put it, she was still in mourning for her first husband. A hasty conference was called among Bergdorf's brass, and the bride wore gray. At the same time, during the recent craze for women's wearing cartridge belts slung around their hips, Bergdorf's would not stock the belts because Andrew Goodman found the fashion personally distasteful.

title: Social Welfare Group Names Head
description: The appointment of Mar garet E. Berry as executive director of the National Con ference on Social Wefare, ef fective next Jan. 1, was an nounced yesterday by James R. Dumpson, national confer ence president and dean of the Fordham University School of Social Service.

title: The Last Word: Policy I, for Freshmen
description: Pedagogy, said Lionel Trilling, is a depressing subject to all persons of sensibility. Mr. Trilling said so some years ago, long before the appearance of hundreds of education books exhorting the pedagogue to save our souls and solve our social problems How Mama Sincere Reached the Recalcitrants, Happiness Is a Warm Professor, Absolute Truth for Break fast  the polonaise, the clair de lune and the ritual fire dance of the radical reformers. Even Mr. Trilling didn't know how depressing the subject could become.

title: EssexUnion
description: Two Essex County traditional powers, Montclair and Colum bia, travelled to Morris County yesterday, and suffered surpris ing setbacks.

title: Coins
description: FEW discoveries of the last decade have proved as fascinating to numismatists and historians as the sunken treasures of the New World that have been salvaged by divers. The hulks of old sail ing shipsvictims of storms, wars and piracycarry a romantic story of new lands.

title: Pop
description: LADIES and gentlemen, meet the new Jeffer son Airplane. Slightly new, that is, since the principal personnel change is the replacement of singer Marty Balin by fiddler Papa John Creach. On the face of it, that doesn't seem to be such a big dealother rock groups have had personnel changes without noticeably altering the style or sub stance of their music. In the case of the Airplane, how ever, Marty Balin was one of the group's organizers and a major element in its quite unique sound. Substituting a country blues fiddle for the soaring harmonies that were produced by Balin and Grace Slick may not necessarily make for a lessening in qual ity, but it sure makes the Air plane sound like a different band.

title: Manes: New Top Man for Queens
description: Donald R. Manes, a Demo cratic City Councilman for six years, was sworn in Wednesday as Queens Bor ough President, replacing Sidney Leviss, who resigned to run for a seat on the State Supreme Court. The following were some of his sunrisetosunset activities on Thursday, his first working day in office.

title: AIR FORCE VICTOR IN FINAL SECONDS
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Sept. 25 (AP)  Two sophomores, the quarterback, Rich Haynie, and a flanker, Greg Smith, combined for a 15 yard touchdown pass play with two seconds left that gave the Air Force Academy a 2319 vic tory over Wyoming today.

title: Town Moves Against L.I. Hall
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I.Town officials are trying to close down the People's Town Hall, home to such countercultural activities as a men's libera tion study course and the birth control lecture in which the speaker was arrested be cause a baby was do the audience.

title: Chilean Party Breaks Off From Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 25 The Christian Democratic oppo sition, which helped elect Pres ident Salvador Allende Gossens and has supported parts of his program to bring socialism to Chile, broke off its working compact with the Government last night.

title: BULLET IS VICTOR IN ONE TON SAIL
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 25 Bullett and Incredible scored convincing victories today in the overnight race to capture the overall titles in the Ida Lewis Yacht Club One Ton and Half ton Cup Series.

title: Miami Routs Wake Forest
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Sept. 25 (AP)Miami held Wake Forest's vaunted veer offense to a total of 137 yards tonight and posted a 2910 victory.

title: Larchmont Sail Called Off
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 25 The regatta scheduled today by the Larchmont Yacht Club for Yacht Racing Association classes was canceled because of lack of wind.

title: MICIIENER'S PROGRESS REPORT
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: YOUTH UNITS FEEL SCHOOLFEE RISE
description: A recent policy change by the Board of Education author izing community school boards to charge a substantial fee for the use of public school facili ties by outside organizations is causing serious problems for many youth groups throughout the city.

title: Hot Meals for Shutins
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I. A pilot nutritional program in which volunteer workers will deliver hot meals to the homes of older persons who are unable to shop and cook for themselves will be started on Long Island next month by Catholic Charities of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre.

title: A 37Foot Motorsailer Brings North Sea Tang
description: Ploughing her way to Newport is the Banjer, con structed by Eistra Werf in the Netherlands. The Dutch 37foot motorsailer will be seen for the first time at a show.

title: A State Urban Center Gets Under Way in the Suburbs
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I.The Urban Center at the State University's Agriculture and Technical College here has begun its second year of operation with an increased budget and a larger enroll ment of youths and adults who are unemployed or un deremployed.

title: Brownstone with a
The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt was a good political year for black people, 1970: Black Congress men were elected in districts previously represented by whites in Baltimore, Chicago and Oakland, Calif.; 114 of about 300 black candidates won in the South, and Ken neth Gibson was elected Mayor of Newark in a turbu lent campaign.

title: Front Page 5  No Title
description: SAVE A LIFE! Help purchase vital equipment for Israel's Blood Bank. American Red Magen David for Israel, 50 W. 57th St. NYC 10019 (Advt)

title: Sagamore Toccoa, Cocker Spaniel, Takes Top Award at Ox Ridge K.C. Event
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 25A 2 silverbuff cocker spaniel, Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, owned by Mrs. Peggy Westphal of Bedford, N. Y., took her eighth bestinshow award in a field of 1,791 dogs today at the 35th Ox Ridge Kennel Club event.

title: Store Becomes ChildCare Center
description: A former supermarket with a rubberpadded roof is the setting for one of the Nation al Association for the Ad vancement of Colored Peo ple's most ambitious projects herea childcare facility for the residents of south western Queens.

title: Washington Plans an Aggressive War
description: In the court of public opinion, the verdict is already in. The war in Vietnani has been judged a mistake of such magnitude as to constitute a political crime. And the guilty are being punished: Save for the few who recanted in time, the high officials who planned and conducted the war are probably barred from officeholding, the academics are exiled to havens in the South and Southwest, and all are destinedso long as the public mood holdsto suffer obloquy and opprobrium.

title: Bills' Braxton Returns
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 25 (AP) The Buffalo Bills today activat ed a rookie running back, Jim Braxton, who had been side lined with an ankle fracture since Aug. 6.

title: Fresh Yankee Trot Victor In Stakes at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (AP)Fresh Yankee captured the Pennsylvania Sires Stakes at Liberty Bell Race Track last night.

title: NIXON BEGINS TRIP TO MEET HIROHITO
