description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 25 President Nixon embarked today on an elaborate 4,260 mile trip to Alaska to confer for 50 minutes tomorrow night with Emperor Hirohito of Ja pan, an essentially symbolic gesture that Mr. Nixon clearly hopes will ease some tensions in JapaneseAmerican relations.

title: Amanda Bethsabe Pedersen Wed to Gerald Norton
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The marriage of Miss Amanda Bethsabe Pedersen to Gerald Patrick Norton took place in All Souls' Church here today. The cere mony, written by the cou ple, was perfomed by the Rev. William Gardiner, a Unitarian.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A TAX LEVY URGED ON GOAL DEPOSITS
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 25  Citi zens of five of Tennessee's most impoverished counties in Appalachia are seeking to en force collection of about $350,000 a year in property taxes from large coal mining companies that do not have headquarters here.

title: David Morley Rathbun Fiance Of Miss Anne Bridget Burke
description: John S. Burke Jr., chair man of the board of B. Alt man & Co., and Mrs. Burke of New York and Watch Hill, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Bridget Burke, to David Morley Rathbun of Stonington, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Rathbun Jr. of Avondale, R. I.

title: Jews Invite Religious Leaders To Discuss Jerusalem's Status
description: The Synagogue Council of America disclosed yesterday that it had invited spiritual leaders of all faiths in this country, including Moslems, to hold a special meeting to dis cuss a growing rift in inter religious relations over the status of Jerusalem.

title: Miss Rudd Is Bride Of Lionel E. Bolin
description: Miss Marjorie Jean Rudd and Lionel Emery Bolin were married here yesterday at the St. RegisSheraton by Judge Jane Bolin of the New York State Family Court, aunt of the bridegroom.

title: Capital Ends an Experiment in Busing Black Pupils to Suburb
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25A threeyearold experiment in busing black innercity chil dren from the District of Co lumbia to a virtually allwhite suburban school has been ended by the District's Board of Education.

title: Nassau Radio Station is Putting the Country Back in Music With the Nashville Sound
description: MINEOLA, L. I.From sun rise to sunset every day, radio listeners who hanker for the Nashville Sound can find it at 1520 on the AM dial, emanating from a trans mission tower here that, Richard M. Winslow, general manager of station WTHE, proudly points, out, is the highest point in Nassau Coun ty.

title: Surprise for Gov. Licht
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 25 (UPI)Gov. Frank Licht has learned that state workers who took time off for the Jewish holy days will not be paid under a new state policy. Mr. Licht, who is Jewish and took the two days off, said Thursday he would look into the new pol icy instituted by the Depart ment of Administration.

title: Rutgers Upsets Princeton, 33 to 18, in College Football's Oldest Rivalry
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 25 Jake McCandless, the Prince ton coach, always worries when Rutgers comes to play his team with a game under its belt. His worries proved wellfounded today as the Scarlet Knight up set the Tiger, 3318, before, in Palmer Stadium.

title: CALLOUS
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: CLEANUP QUERIED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 (AP)  Pennsylvania's multi milliondollar campaign to put out mine fires and burning ref use banks  smoldering piles of rock and lowgrade coal that pollute the airis being in vestigated because of allega tions of waste, inefficiency and mismanagement.

title: Most Pittsburgh Air Bad
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (UPI) The Allegheny County Air Pollution Control Bureau re ported Wednesday that rsidents breathed unsatisfactory air 90 pr cent of the time. The report was disclosed when the bureau unveiled its air pollution index service, an adjusted scale show ing the average amount of sul phur dioxide and fine particu late matter in the atmosphere in the previous 24hour period.

title: Et A1.
description: A counterblast to Women's Lib by two founders of the Pussycat League. Mrs. Gold berg, a newspaperwoman, and Miss Sakol, a freelance writer, are serious but superficial. Still, they have done their home work on such matters as vag inal orgasm (not a myth) and the physiological differences between boys and girls (more than skin deep). Some women really want to be feminine, they say; and the Lib types often put their personal prob lems on society. Hardly the definitive rebuttal, but there's enough matter here to raise an argument; and some women who feel threatened by the Lib's more outr manifestations may take comfort from the book if they can stomach its breezy prose.

title: CHALLENGE FILED ON POLLUTION ACT
description: The United States Steel Cor poration has directly challenged the validity of the Federal Gov ernment's major weapon against industrial water polluters.

title: Court Orders U. of Washington To Admit White Law Student
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 25A white student has won a suit for ad mission to the law school of the University of Washington after contending that he was passed over while 30 minority students with lower qualifications were admitted.

title: Christopher Keene Makes Debut At Met, Leading Cav and Pag
description: Christopher Keene does not waste time. Two years ago he came East from California as winner of the Julius Rudel Award at the New York City Opera. A year ago he made his local conducting debut with that company. On Friday night he made his Metropolitan Opera debut, conducting Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana and Leoncavallo's Pagliacci.

title: PENN TURNS BACK LEHIGH BY 2814
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 (UPI)Ron Dawson, a junior halfback who left the team on his own volition after three games last season, staged a personal comeback today and scored two touchdowns as Penn opened its 95th football season with a 2814 victory over previously undefeated Lehigh.

title: Temple B'nai Jeshrun Honors Its RabbiEmeritus
description: Rabbi Israel Goldstein, a leader in American Zionism and Conservative Judaism, was honored yesterday on his 75th birthday, in special services at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West 88th Street, where he is Rabbiemeritus.

title: On the cover
Preps
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Sept. 25 Brian O'Connor led his team in rushing, but McBurney team mates Gene Healey and Ken Franklin grabbed the glory in today's 386 victory over Wood mere with two touchdowns each. Healey scored on runs of 27 and 9 yards. Franklin scored on an 18yard carry and re turned an intercepted pass 37 yards for a second touchdown.

title: Self sufficient
10 TEXAS CHICANOS TO GET A.C.L.U. AID
description: PHARR, Tex., Sept. 25 The American Civil Liberties Union has announced that it would help pay the legal fees in de fending 10 MexicanAmericans arrested here in a disturbance in February in which a 20year old Chicano was shot to death.

title: Gardens
description: AUTUMN'S traditional colors are the golds, russets and reds of falling leaves and ripening fruit, evidence of nature's winding down the sea son before the last harvest and the long winter. The fields have given a final burst of goldenrod, woodbine has turned scarlet where it climbs over fence and bush, ferns are yellowing, and summer asters are already looking weedy.

title: Art
description: WHETHER an artist fails or succeeds in fulfilling his po tential depends a great deal on his ability to recognize the nature of his aptitude and his willingness to work within it. The big John Sloan retrospective at the National Gallery in Wash ington, celebrating the cen tenary of this American ar tist's birth, is an excellent survey of Sloan's develop ment, which means that it is full of ups and downs end ing, alas, in a steep decline that wasn't necessary.

title: Sheffield United Tops Chelsea, 1 to 0
description: LONDON, Sept. 25, Reuters Sheffield United maintained its unbeaten record and stretched its lead to 3 points today in the English Soccer League First Division with a 10 victory over Chelsea.

title: Preps
description: WILBRAHAM, Mass., Sept. 25 Steve Desmarais paced Wil brahamMunson to a 2814 vic tory over Cheshire Academy today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk
description: Bayport, an underdog, rallied in the final period to defeat Amityville, 1814, yesterday as the two teams opened their 1971 football campaigns. The upset was realized through ball control exercised by Bayport during the entire second half.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Miss Judith Rosenberg Fiancee of Lieutenant
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 25The engagement of Miss Judith Susan Rosenberg to Second Lieut. Thomas John Kent, Adjutant General Corps, U.S.A., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rosenberg. Her fi anc is a son of Gerald P. Kent of Fort Lee, N.J., and Mrs. Roy Gast of Annapolis, Md.

title: Study Finds Federal Employment Test Fails Too Large a Share of Black College Graduates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25A study of the entrance examina tion used for college graduates seeking Federal employment has concluded that the test re jects a disproportionate num ber of blacks and that its use should be suspended.

title: For the bath
Youths Signing Up for'72
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 A 20yearold nurse wearing a Woody Woodpecker Tshirt had just registered to vote at portable tables set up on the edge of Pittsburgh's Point State Park. In the back ground, a crowd of 30,000 young people listened to an outpouring of speeches urg ing them to work for peace and new priorities.

title: Chess
description: ACHESS fest at the Manhattan Chess Club a few Sundays ago con sisted of a doubleround, 12man round robin of fiveminute chess games. The players in this battle royal were all high echelon competitors, rep resenting metropolitan's best in chess. The event, to celebrate Fischer's ascent to the world title in the qualifying matches, added another victory to his already invincible score.

title: Television
description: IT'S a curious, almost toucning, spectacle. The commercial networks, under increasing pres sure from various groups and panels around the country, are desperately trying to im prove their programing for children. They are not gen erally succeeding, mind you, but they are trying.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: A Philadelphia ad agency working for a great New York hotel has proved that direct mail not only can bring happiness to agency and client but also that a lot of American businessmen have a sense of humor.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: Sao Paulo, BrazilJoao Hen rique, Brazil, knocked out Garibaldi Pereira, Brazil, 4 rounds.

title: Front Page 4  No Title
description: POINT OF THE MOUNTAIN, Utah, Sept. 25  L. E. Birchell is 56 years old, and he has spent most of his adult life locked up with convicted crim inals. In my 21 years here, he says, you might say that I've done a sevenyear stretch on eighthour shifts.

title: About Motor Sports
description: President Nixon, who has often called attention to his enthusiasm for sports, has added another one to his list. He gave a reception last Tuesday afternoon at the White House to officially recognize motor racing. The historical impact of the party can be gauged by the fact that Jackie Stewart wore a conven tional business suit; Parnelli Jones wore a necktie, and Aggie Agajan ian, who is reputed to wear his Western Stetson to bed, checked the hat downstairs.

title: NIXON INTERVENES IN DOCK DISPUTE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 25 President Nixon intervened per sonally today in the crippling West Coast longshoremen's strike. He conferred here with leaders of labor and manage ment and reported afterward that both sides had agreed to try to reach a settlement by the end of next week.

title: Yul Brynner Remarries
description: PARIS, Sept. 25 (AP) Yul Brynner, the film actor, married Jacqueline De Croisset, a French widow, two days ago in Nor mandy, a friend of Mr. Brynner said today. It was the third wedding for the 51 year  old screen star and the second for his bride, whose first husband, Philippe De Croisset, a news man, died a few years ago. The actor's marriages to Virginia Gilmore and Doris Kleiner end ed in divorce.

title: Eliza Wolcott Has Nuptials
description: NEW CASTLE, Del., Sept. 25 Miss Eliza Wolcott, daugh ter of Chief Justice Daniel Fooks Wolcott of the Delaware Supreme Court and Mrs. Wol cott of New Castle, was mar ried here this afternoon to Eric Scott McCready, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. W. McCready of Eugene, Ore., where Mr. McCready is vice president and general manager of Ore gon Triangle Television.

title: Kristin Crawford Bride of Navy Man
description: ROWAYTON, Conn., Sept. 25Miss Kristin Turnbull Crawford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Turnbull Crawford, was married in the United church of Rowayton today to Electricians Mate Third Class David Emory Fultz, who is serving with the Navy in New London. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emory Fults Jr. of Evans Willis, N. Y. The Rev. Donald Emig performed the cere mony.

title: What's At the Movies?
description: GLEN AND RANDA, directed by Jim McBride and star ring Steven Curry and Shelley Plimpton as a boy and girl born after The Bomb has destroyed the world, is as solemn and sincere and, I'm afraid, as unprovocative as most newspaper editorials call ing for an end to the arms race, remarks Vincent Canby. It is neither a suc cessful nor an entertaining movie, but it is sober, and what mind it has is high. Thus I'm completely mysti fied by the X rating that has been attached to it, ap parently because of its nudity and lovemaking. They might be thought ob scene only by stretching a censor's imagination. At Cinema Rendezvous.

title: FANS IN THE DARK ON REFUNDS HERE
description: For once, the Giants, the Jets, the Knicks, the Rangers and the Nets have a common enemythe pricefreeze.

title: The traveler's world The Great Air Bag Controversy
description: THE Battle of the Air Bag may someday be recounted in detail by social historians as a crucial point in American life of the nineteen seventies and in the development of our automobile civilization. The battle has been raging between Washington, D.C., and Detroit for several months and it is now reaching the level of a fearful power struggle between most automo bile manufacturers, both foreign and do mestic, and the National Highway Safe ty Administration of the Federal Depart ment of Transportation.

title: Senate Honors Ellender
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The Senate paid tribute yes terday to Senator Allen Ellen der, Democrat of Louisiana, its oldest member and president pro tempore, on his 81st birth day.

title: The Beaumont: Who's the Villain of the Piece?
description: Chairman, New York City Center

title: Louisiana Attorney General Convicted
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25; (AP)Atorney General Jack Gremillion of Louisiana was convicted today by a Federal jury on five counts of perjury.

title: AHIRA TRIUMPHS AT ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 Ahira, a lightly regarded colt who had not raced at more than a mile since last December, upset the Canadian horse Speedy Zephyr today and cap tured the $30,000 added Board walk Handicap on the turf course.

title: DRAPER CAPTURES U.S. SENIOR FINAL
description: PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Sept. 25Tom Draper of Troy, Mich., recovered from one down at the end of 10 holes today to win the United States senior amateur golf champion ship, scoring a 3and1 victory over Ernest Pieper Jr. of San Juan Bautista, Calif., in the final of the 17th annual tour nament at Sunnybrook Golf Club.

title: Tannen Irked at Nonbelievers
description: As the New York Jets await tomorrow night's game in St. Louis, an internal con troversy has flared involving Steve Tan nen, the left cornerback.

title: TEXAS TROUNCES TEXAS TECH, 280
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI) A substitute quarterback, Donnie Wigginton, ran for two touchdowns and an alert Texas defense set up two others with interceptions today as the Long horns drubbed Texas Tech, 280, in the opening Southwest Con ference football game.

title: Miss Murphy, W. R. Freund Married Here
description: Miss Andrea Maryellen Murphy, daughter of Andrew Laurence Murphy of New York and Ocean Beach, L. I., and the late Mrs. Elizabeth McGuill Murphy, was married here yesterday morning to William Robert Freund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford C. Freund of Pewamo, Mich.

title: Letters
description: I so enjoyed Tack Gas nick's letter [Aug. 22] remi niscing about his basement fishing experience on Second Avenue and 53d Street. As a gal who was born and raised in that very vicinity, and a resident until 10 years ago, I can vouch for its unique Main Street U.S.A. image, probably unmatched any where.

title: N. CAROLINA TOPS MARYLAND, 3614
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 25 (UPI)Lewis Jolly caught a 62yard pass from Paul Miller for one touchdown and ran for another today as North Caro lina crushed Maryland, 3514.

title: Soviet Union Accuses Britain of Stirring Up Hysteria in Ordering Expulsion of 105 Russians as Spies
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25The So viet Union charged Britain to night with whipping up anti Soviet hysteria to try to block efforts toward relaxation of tensions in Europe by her ac tion yesterday in ordering the expulsion of Soviet representa tives as spies.

title: SPANISH DRIVERS FUME OVER FINES
description: MADRID, Sept. 25Com plaints that the Government is threatening Spaniards' rights have occupied an uncommon amount of space in the Madrid press in recent weeks.

title: For serious cooks
New York Tech Victor
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25New York Tech made a successful debut in the Metro politan Intercollegiate Soccer Conference today by defeating C. W. Post, 20.

title: Miss Snyder Has Wedding
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 25In the First Pres byterian Church of South ampton this afternoon Miss Johanna Camilla Snyder, daughter of David Mattis Snyder of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Mrs. Josephine Bucking ham Snyder of Chicago, was married to Donald Stewart Leas Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., son of Mr. and Mrs. Leas of Haverford, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John L. Felmeth.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THREADING their way with obvious caution, the financial markets extended their price, declines last week as worry over the general economic situation broadened in investment circles.

title: Donald Miller, Banker, Marries Barbara D. Duff
description: Miss Barbara Dewees Duff and Donald Keith Miller were married here yesterday afternoon at St. James' Epis copal Church by the Rev. Alums M. Thorp Jr.

title: MEN AND MACHINES IN SPACE
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: F. and M. Conquers Ursinus As Wilgucki Stars, 2414
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 25 Two touchdowns by, Ed Wil gucki, a 150pound freshman, led Franklin and Marshall to a 2414 victory over Ursinus to day in the season's opener. It was the Diplomats sixth straight over the Bears.

title: Newport Raising Curtain On Extravaganza of Snapping Sails
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 25 Suddenly there are sail boat shows, not boat shows combining motor yachts and cruisers, engines and speed boats, but pure, unadulter ated sail extravaganzas where a stinkpot sticks out like a zebra in a horse show.

title: Hearst Journalism Awards Offer $63,550 in Prizes
description: Journalism students in 57 colleges around the country are expected to submit writing and photography this year in the 12th annual William Randolph Hearst Foundation Journalism Awards program.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: Prisoners in the cells and yards of New York's state prisons say overt repression has been the overriding conse quence of the inmate rebellion at Attica two weeks ago. Guards on the other side of cell bars say they now work in an atmosphere of nearterror that abates only when they lock inmates in their cells.

title: Bally Cor Captures Honors In East Stakes Dressage
description: BEDMINSTER, N. J. Sept. 25 Bally Cor, owned and ridden by Hardin Crawford 3d of Far Hills, N. J., captured both the second level tests today at the opening session of the twoday Eastern Stakes Dressage Asso ciation's fall horse show at Hoopstick Farm.

title: Home Nuptials ForNoraLeake
description: GARRISON, Md., Sept. 25 Miss Nora Leake was mar ried here today to Juan Ran dolph Mayer Cameron at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Leake, parents of the bride. The Rev. Howard Waterhouse, a Unitarian min ister, performed the cere mony.

title: Lafayette Booters Down Columbia in 2 Overtimes
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 25La fayette gave its new soccer coach, Gary Williams, a present in his debut today by defeating Columbia, 21, in a double overtime. It was the season opener for both teams.

title: Hubba, Hubba HubbyIt's Hedy!
description: eavesdropped by BOB EDISON

title: GROUP TO MONITOR CIVIL RIGHTS LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25A private organization funded by foundations has been estab lished, in Washington to moni tor on a daytoday basis the enforcement of civil rights laws by the Federal Government.

title: Preps
description: CORNWALL  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 25Steve Joffe, a fullback, led Riverdale to a 28 16 triumph today over New York Military Academy today. Joffe gained 160 yards rushing and scored on a 3yard run and a twopoint conversion.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: TO OUR READERS

title: Buffalo Transit Line Runs Afoul of Hospital's Expansion Plans
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 25Rapid transit construction plans have collided with hospital expan sion plans here.

title: EXAIDE IN NEBRASKA CONVICTED IN FRAUD
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 25 A former State Welfare Direc tor, Harold J. Stode, has been convicted in Federal District Court on all 13 counts for his part in setting up a fictitious Federal program and splitting the proceeds, $88,500, with an other man.

title: If an Artist Wants to Be Serious  Popular, He Is Suffering
description: IT seems likely that if the cultural history of this era ever comes to be written, then the postwar period, and particularly the last dec ade, will be seen as the time of America's greatest moral collapse and intellectual confusion. So pro foundly unsettling are these con ditions, in fact, that even the publi cation of such a record becomes somewhat problematical. Now that the traditional function of history, as an effort to evaluate human events objectively, is under assault, and now that the culture itself has become a grab bag of careerist advancement and media opportunism, cultural history may soon become another disposable item  like philosophy, classic languages, pre20thcentury literature and drama, pure science and all those other artifacts of the curious period preceding our present Great Age of Relevance. On the other hand, since it is customary for disin tegrating societies to chronicle their own degeneration, it is not unlikely that some modern Tacitus may even now be observing our inexorable march toward ethical, spiritual and artistic bankruptcy.

title: Another Attica Prisoner Dies, Bringing Toll to 42
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 25 The death toll in the Attica pris on rebellion rose to 42 late yes terday with the death of a pris oner, Edward Menefi, who re portedly had been wounded when the authorities regained control by force of arms.

title: Hanoi Gets Peking Pledge
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Li Hsiennien, a Chinese Deputy Premier, today stressed the determination of the Chinese to support the North Vietnamese in their fight against imperial istic American aggression. He made his statement at a ban quet given by a North Vietnam ese deputy premier, Le Thanh Nghi, in honor of a visiting Chinese economic delegation.

title: UsedCar Lot on Red Square? Not Exactly, but Soviet Government Is Going Into SecondHand Business
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25 Em broiled in the complexities of the new automobile age, the mighty Soviet Government has now established itself firmly in the usedcar business.

title: Art Notes
description: AS strikes go, the one last month by the Profes sional and Staff Asso ciation of the Museum of Modern Art (hereinafter referred to as PASTA) was a remarkably lowkey affair. To begin with, the August 20th date, precipitated by MOMA's dismissal notices sent during contract negotia tions to eight employes, was hardly prime time for action at a major museum, since most of New York's art com munity was estivating else where. (If MOMA were in Ptown or East Hampton, we'd have had real support, lamented one striker.)

title: Claire Whitman Bride Of Harry Marshall Jr.
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Sept. 25 St. Matthew's Episcopal Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Claire Sanford Whit man, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Morton Whitman of Bedford Hills and Nan tucket, Mass., to Harry Rein hard Marshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Mount Kisco. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. Morton Whitman, cousin of the bride.

title: Going Thru First in Pace At Freehold and Pays $4
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 25 (AP)  Going Thru won the $10,000 Pleasant Valley Pace at Freehold Raceway today, re turning $4, $3.40 and $3 for $2 across the board.

title: Movies
Delaware Triumphs, 407; Neff Tosses for 3 Scores
description: DURHAM, N. H., Sept. 25 (UPI)Delaware defeated New Hampshire, 407, today on three touchdown passes from Sam Neff to Pete Johnson.

title: Nassau South
description: If history really does repeat itself, Wantagh High is in great shape to retain its title as Nassau County champions of Divisions  and . Wantagh got off yesterday to the same start it did last season by losing to Levittown Memorial, 62, in a South Shore Division  game.

title: Peter Sourian Weds Miss Eve Pocquet
description: Miss Eve Pocquet, as sistant professor of French at City College, was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter Soaurian, a novelist and associate professor of Eng lish at Bard College.

title: S. CAROLINA SINKS N.C. STATE, 24 TO 6
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 25 (AP) Chuck Mimms carried the ball on all but one play in an 80yard opening scoring drive tonight to lead South Carolina to a 246 victory over North Carolina State.

title: Reader's Report
description: Problems of caste and iden tity among black Africans are explored with sensitivity in this novel by the author of When Rain Clouds Gather. The pro tagonist is Margaret Cadmore, an orphaned girl of the Bush man people who is raised by a missionary teacher as an experiment in education. Aft er a record of straight A's, Margaret herself becomes a pri maryschool teacher, totally un prepared by book learning for life.

title: Preps
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 25Twentyseven seconds were remaining in the game yester day when Mike Enoch passed to Pat Green for a Penn Char ter touchdown in its opening game against Lawrenceville. Then Green swept around end for the twopoint conversion that gave the visitors a 87 victory.

title: Bridgeport's Late Aerial Downs Northeastern, 103
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP)  Bridgeport scored with five minutes remaining today for a 103 victory over Northeastern.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE ROUTS NAVY, 496
description: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)Ed Rideout sprinted for two firstperiod touchdowns, one on a 59yard punt return, and Boston College went on to rout Navy today, 496. Rideout, a senior flanker, went on his lorig scoring jaunt with the game only 63 seconds old. Later in the period, running from a setback slot, he capped a 37yard march by slamming into the end zone from 4 yards out.

title: State's Only School of Optometry Starts Classes Here Tomorrow
description: Classes will begin tomorrow at the only professional school in the state for training spe cialists in the scientific exami nation of the eyes to detect diseases and prescribe lenses or exercises.

title: Three Signs
description: By three signs you can tell when autumn has come. He who would know listens for a wild goose, watches maple tree and tastes a white oak acorn.

title: Et A1.
description: The career of a dedicated Kopfjger (headhunter) who served the SS in World War II, slipped through the War Crimes Trial net and found a new home in the French Foreign Legion as a moving spirit in the Nazi cadre, sent to Indochina to fight the Vietminh. Mr. Elford, a zoologist searching for speci mens in the area, discovered this exstorm trooper and lets him tell his bloody story with out authorial comment. A long way from Beau Geste, and not Up.

title: The World
description: SAIGONAs if it would make any difference in the eventual outcome of the Presi dential voting next Sunday, President Nguyen Van Thieu. fi nally went on radio last week to tell the South Vietnamese how they could vote against him in his uncontested bid for reelection.

title: 2 Councilmen Urge School Board to Use Wage Freeze Savings to Cut Transit Fares for Children
description: The national wageprice freeze will provide a multimil liondollar windfall for New York schools and the money should be used in part to re store reducedfare transit rides for schoolchildren, two in fluential City Councilmen said yesterday.

title: Pamela Trimingham Is Bride Of Stephen Amer Van Dyck
description: Miss Pamela Dunbar Trim ingham, daughter of Mrs. Trowbridge Trimingham of Darien, Conn., and deForest Trimingham of Paget. Ber muda, was married yesterday in St. Paul's Anglican Church in Bermuda to Stephen Amer Van Dyck. Archdeacon John Cattell performed the Cere mony.

title: Jamaica Water Told To Fluoridate Supply
description: The company that supplies water to 500,000 residents of southeastern Queens and 100,000 others in nearby parts of Hempstead and North Hempstead towns in Nassau County had been giv en a state order to submit a feasible plan for fluoridat ing its water and metering all its customers' usage.

title: In the great tradition of imperious headmasters
description: In education, maybe even more than in other realms of our cultural life, the old controversies keep re curring, the combatants frozen into ritual postures like mastodons em balmed in icebergs. Recently the stage has been held by progressives and radicals. Now, on cue, comes Donald Barr, a selfproclaimed reac tionary who occupies an interesting pulpit, the headmastership of Dalton, a New York City private school once noted for its progressivism. Barr rules in the great tradition of undemocratic, imperious headmas ters, and you may be sure that he has occasioned gnashing of teeth and rending of garments among the pro gressive faithful. Others like his es pousal of intellect and discipline, and some may feel uplifted by the spec tacle of a man willing to take on the poisonous and deformed mush room philosophies that are springing up everywhere to challenge old cer titudes.

title: ARMY WINS,1613, FROM GA. TECH
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 25Don't blow taps for Army football yet, not after the cadets' satis fying 1613 victory over favored Georgia Tech today.

title: The World
Cholera Now Spreading to Remote Regions
description: GENEVA, Sept. 25In a man mer unique to the jet age the current cholera pandemic has continued to spread with re markable rapidity, reaching re cently into as remote a region as Lapland.

title: 2 Witnesses Slain in Ohio
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 25 (UPI)An unidentified man shot and killed two persons to day who were witnesses to a fatal shooting in a bar a week ago, according to the police. A third person, who also wit nessed last Saturday's shooting, wa hot and wounded critically. The hootings took place in the home of one of the witnesses.

title: Hosley's 2 Homers Drive In 5 Runs for Tigers, in 107 Victory Over Yanks
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25 (UPI) A rookie catcher making his second start of the season, Tim Hosley, slammed two home runs today to account for five runs and give the Detroit Tigers a 107 victory over the New York Yankees.

title: L.S.U. TURNS BACK WISCONSIN BY 3828
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 25 (UPI) Paul Lyons ran for three touchdowns, passed for another score and set a Louisi ana State totaloffense record of 304 yards in leading the Tigers to a 3828 victory over Wisconsin today.

title: Et A1.
description: Pedestrian but caustic and thorough history of the U. S. intervention in Haiti. Prevail ing imperialistic and racist at titudes in America, coupled with a fatuous faith in tech nological progress, accounted for the involvement. The Na tional City Bank had invest ments in Haiti, but American policy, according to Mr. Schmidt, was more the result of fears that European coun tries, specifically France and Germany, had their eyes on the Caribbean. This is a good his tory of a sordid intervention that submitted a people to au tocratic military rule and did little for economic development. Parallels with our recent Viet nam venture are not out of place.

title: PATROLMAN SLAIN IN BROWNSVILLE
description: One Housing Authority pa trolman was killed yesterday and another patrolman and a civilian passerby were wound ed in a shootout between the police and a robbery suspect whom they tried to question near a Brooklyn housing project.

description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 25 (UPI)Kenny Lyons, a sopho more quarterback, passed for three touchdowns and ran for one score today in leading Mississippi to a 3420 victory over Kentucky.

title: The Nation
description: It took the five officers on the military jury only 57 min utes to reach a verdict: not guilty on all counts. In the course of the monthlong court martial, the credibility of sever al Government witnesses had been damaged; others had changed their stories. Most of the charges, which had original ly been for capital crimes, were successively reduced by the military judge to noncapital crimes and then, at the end, to mere misdemeanors. But even they didn't stick. Last Wednes day afternoon, Capt. Ernest L. Medina walked out of the court room at Fort McPherson, Ga., a free man.

title: Et Al.
description: The Times gets the Jim Bishop treatment. Feb. 28, 1969, was arbitrarily selected in advance; reporters, foreign correspondents, ad men con tributed their logs of what they did. Miss Adler has skillfully formed all this into a mosaic of a typical newspaper day. She shuttles back and forth be tween the Washington bureau, foreign bureaus, national and metropolitan men on their beats; Frankel and Wicker are covering Nixon in France, Gen eral Eisenhower is sinking, trouble in West Berlin, riots in the city schools. Hundreds of other news stories are covered, written, transmitted and edited; tensions build as deadlines ap proach. An accurate look at how a newspaper is put out.

title: California Wins, 3410
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)After a lethargic first period in which they netted only 36 yards, the California Bears erupted for three touch downs in the second period to day en route to a 3410 victory over San Jose State.

title: SCHW ARTZMAN SINGS A LIKABLE MARCELLO
description: Seymour Schwartzman was a newcomer to the New York City Opera's production of Pu ccini's La Bohme when it was repeated on Friday night at the State Theater. The bari tone is a big man with a big voice, and in the role of Mar cello this helped to make the painter hearty and likable. Mr. Schwartzman could develop moments of sympathy, too, con tributing to a wellrounded, wellsung characterization.

title: CLIFFORD S. HOLLANDER
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 25Clifford S. Hollander, a stockbroker for 54 years, died today at his summer home here. He was 75 years old and lived at 23 East 74th Street, New York.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Villa Hopping in the Puerto Rican Alps
description: PLATTEKILL, N. Y.  Dusk was setting in when I stopped for drink at a roadside resort on State Route 32, a few miles south of New Peitz, N. Y. A Iarge group of Puerto Ricans in gay holiday dress milled about the gloomy dance hall as loudspeakers wafted Latinrock rhythms into the neighboring apple orchards. An argument broke out among two athleticlooking men in starspangled Tshirts, a dark, pinstripesuited man with a straw hat, and a large, boisterous woman in a lowcut red dress. The two starspangled athletes began tugging at the woman's fleshy left arm, bickering in colorful Spanish, as the strawhatted man pulled energetically at her right arm. The woman, the hefty bone of their Solomonic contention, laughed up roariously, even as the top of her dress ripped at both ends. Suddenly four pa trol cars swooped down with lights flashing and sirens wailing. A tall, husky Puerto Rican policeman was the first to get out and step between the hostile parties. There was some fast Spanish banter back and forth, an ex change of backslaps, a few earthy cracks from the officer, more loud, gravelly laughter from the woman, and the three men settled their differences with a handshake and a Latin embrace. The officer led the woman away, his hand on her shoulder, as she laughed huskily and pinched his cheeks.
