title: Convicts Seek to Form a National Union
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 25  An organization of con victs and former convicts whose rallying slogan is power to the convicted class set out this week to form a national union for the country's 200,000 prison inmates.

title: BICYCLISTS DENIED A PUSH BY MAYOR
description: The Lindsay administration, which in the past has enthusi astically endorsed the bicycle as an alternative to the pollut ing automobile, has now cooled to that idea.

title: Bucks Checked 3 Times Near Goal in 2014 Loss
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 Ken Johnson, the quarterback who wasn't supposed to play ran for two touchdowns and Cliff Branch returned a punt 68 yards for a score as Colo rado upset Ohio State today, 2014.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Originala, Inc., after 10 years of public ownership, has not lost its image as a highfashion house. But go ing public provided an incen tive for the company to grow not only in women's coats, but also in suits, dresses, rainwear and sportswear. Volume increased from $2.3 million in 1962, its first year of public ownership, to $12.3million in the year end ed last June 30.

title: Harvard Consultants Named
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 25 (AP)Hale Champion, Harvard University's new financial vice president, on Tuesday appoint ed two consultants. They are David W. Davis, director of the Economic Development and In dustrial Commission in Boston, and Thomas O'Brien, formerly a fellow in the Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Financing Pollution Control
description: Taxexempt bond financing to build facilities for priv ately owned corporation  a controversial way to raise cash that was almost com pletely halted by Congress more than two years ago has revived. This time the money is being spent to con trol pollution and there is little controversy.

title: POLLUTION GROWS IN PACIFIC ISLES
description: NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Sept. 24Officials of 16 tropi cal Pacific territories, meeting here this week with representa tives of Western powers in the area, expressed deep alarm over pollution on numerous islands that have been renowned for unspoiled natural charm.

title: The Nation
description: PORTLANDThere are weeks in the Nixon Presidencyand last week was one of them when the Chief Executive seems to be doing so many things in so many different places that one gets the impression that something fundamentally im portant is happening, when in fact nothing has changed at all.

title: Williams Defeats Trinity On SecondHalf Rally, 3510
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass, Sept. 25Williams scored four touch downs in the second half today to defeat Trinity, 3510.

title: LAFAYETTE BEATS COLUMBIA, 3 TO 0
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 25Co lumbia University opened its football season on a sad note this bright, sunny afternoon, losing to a rockribbed Lafay ette team, 3.0, before 9,000 fans.

title: Division Marks Anniversary
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI)The First Cavalry Divi sion celebrated its 50th anni versary yesterday, the first time in 28 years that the division marked its birthday on Ameri can soil. The division, now an airmobile unit, was formed in El Paso, Tex., in 1921.

title: Huntington Will Train Students For Theater
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.The performing Arts Foundation of Huntington, which this summer opened the first yearround professional rep ertory company on Long Is and, plans this fall to in stitute a new theatrical ed ucational experiment for Long Island High School students.

title: A bastard from Nottingham tells his story
description: Alan Sillitoe's first two books were widely admired for the authority with which they presented English working class life. Without minimizing the acrid, deadening struggle, they conveyed the joys open to boisterous, cunning men in private rebellion against society. Despite narrowness of range, Saturday Night and Sun day Morning and The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner had a savage energy and got their propor tions right.

title: VANDERBILT UPSETS MISS. STATE BY 4919
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Sept. 25 (UPI)  Vanderbilt, sparked by Steve Burger and a fleet of strong running backs, scored in every period today and routed favored Mississippi State, 4919, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Designs of the Decade
description: What is one of the most inventive design trends of the decade? Furni ture derived from organic forms: we can sit in a tooth, snuggle in a hand, listen to music from a futuristic capsule, read by a snake light. These designs record the range of inventiveness of designers alive and practicing today. They extend the American dream of dials, gadgets and push buttons. In this century, we have placed men on the moon, sat by while they walked its awesome surface, retrieved themand watched it all on color TV. Can we really return to the pilgrim era, that of Louis XV, or the Georges of England? Certainly, if that's what we wishand can afford. But we can also salute the inventiveness of our new pioneers. To their audacity, imagination and humor, we say: Hooray! And, we'll be seeing more of you in the future.

title: PRAYER BAN FOES APPLAUD MOTHER
description: CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio, Sept. 25If Congress passes a constitutional amendment this session permitting nondenomi national prayers in schools and sends it to the states for their ratification, a lot of the credit will be given to a questioning young man and the determina tion of his mother.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Mary G. Patterson Betrothed To Richard Howard Webber
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 25  Mr. and Mrs. A. Gordon Pat terson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Gordon Patterson, to Richard Howard Webber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Webber of Garden City, L. I.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  As the annual meetings of the Inter national Monetary Fund and the World Bank take place here this week, only one thing is reasonably clear: Just about everybody is very angry at the United States, or at least, has grave new doubts about it.

title: Today's Problems Echo Pentagon Vietnam Study
description: A section of the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war that focuses on United StatesSouth Vietnamese political relations in the 196367 period con cludes that, in seeking to apply political leverage to bring about a stable government in Saigon, everything we did went wrong.

title: Arms Raid in Maryland Leaves Collector Paralyzed
description: MONTGOMERY COUNTY, Md., Sept. 25Kenyon Frank lin Ballew went home from the hospital this week with half his body paralyzed from a bul let embedded in his brain June 7, when the police and Treasury agents raided his apartment seeking illegal firearms.

title: Sinking Shuts Texas Tunnel
description: PASADENA, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI)A barge rammed by a Greek freighter in the Houston Ship Channel yesterday sank on the roof of the Washburn traffic tunnel, temporarily forc ing its closing for 15 hours and causing detours for thousands of motorists before the tunnel was reopened late last night.

title: Prices and Companies
description: WASHINGTONWe know that we are reducing the ability of many firms to be come more efficient by not allowing them to raise prices, Earl D. Rhode, exec utive assistant to the direc tor of the President's Cost of Living Council, said re cently.

title: The Discovery Of the Asylum Social Order and Disorder in the New Republic. By David J. Rothman. Illustrated. 376 pp. Boston: Little, Brown &
description: Few people nowadays care to say much in favor of tra ditional methods of handling the erring and unfortunate members of our societythe criminal, the insane, the or phaned, the indigent. Critics of many kinds have questioned the heavy reliance on institu tions, on the principle of incar ceration; and public officials have begun to explore alterna tive strategies. Yet, for all that, we are stuck with our prisons, our mental hospitals, our orphanagesa whole pan oply of asylums for isolat ing various deviant and de pendent elements of the pop ulation.

title: Rice Upsets Tulane, 1411
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) Bruce Gadd's 48yard touch down pass to Gary Butler and the steady running of Stahle Vincent sparked Rice to a 1411 upset over Tulane tonight.

title: Funds Asked for BrooklynQueens Schools
description: Last year Brooklyn had more public school pupils than seats in school build ings.

title: Rift Inside Taiwan as Wide as the One Between the Two Chinas
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 21 Withdraw your Seventh Fleet, and let Taiwanese decide the fate of Taiwan themselves, Mr. Lee shouted. He was sitting in the privacy of his modest home, talking to an American visitor, and he was angry.

title: Johnson and Hooker Create Blues Mood At Hunter College
description: It was all blues at Hunter College Friday night, most of it old, and much of it disappoint ing.

title: POLL FINDS MOST CONTENT IN LIFE
description: Although as many as one American in eight would like to emigrate to some other nation if given the chance, Americans as a whole continue to express a high degree of satisfaction with the basic circumstances of their lives, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LURE TAKES LAURELS IN RESOLUTE SAILING
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept 25Only 39 of the 68 starters were able to complete their courses in dying and variable winds on Manhasset Bay today.

title: Artist Divided Against Himself
description: THERE are artists whose careersby default, almostgive one a clear understanding of the personal risks involved in the artistic vocation. The late Jean Xceron was an ar tist of this type. In the course of a long and distin guished, if not wellpubli cized, career, Xceron man aged to be in the right place at the right moment. He knew the right peoplemany of thein the most important artists of his time who re spected and praised his work. Yet Xceron's career never managed to catch fire, so to speak.

title: Reader's Report
description: Dick and I were brought up on Spock and Gesell and a wonderful balance of per missivenessdiscipline, tremen dous understanding, interest, vitamins, museums, walks, books, goldfish, love. With such a background, you suspect that Dick and Jane, his teen age sister, and the narrator of this engaging novel, will have problems. They do.

title: Brooklyn a Rival of San Francisco as Home of Writers
description: When Marianne Moore left Brooklyn in 1965, driven away by the catastrophic de cay of the neighborhood where she had lived for so long, many felt as though the borough had lost its last ornament and that, with the exception of the Manhattan oriented enclave on the Heights, the sun had set for ever on its literary life. Hap pily the opposite has proved true. Miss Moore's departure, though sad in itself, marked the end of a long, slow de cline and came at the begin ning of a remarkable renais sance of Brooklyn letters that has, by now, put the borough on the same level with San Francisco as the home of serious, practicing writers.

title: 3 Seeking D.A. Post In Nassau Election
description: MINEOLA, L. I.A Demo crat and a Conservative who have had limited experience in the practice of criminal law are seeking to unseat Nassau County District At torney William Cahn, a Re publican who has been a prosecutor for 21 years.

title: Encyclopedia Sale Abuses Go On Despite New Laws
description: The highpressure encyclope dia salesman who uses mis leading and deceptive techni ques to sell his expensive wares in the home is still very much on the scene, despite new laws designed to curb doortodoor selling abuses in several states.

title: Alice R. Tepper Wed to Professor
description: ELBERON, N. J., Sept. 25 Miss Alice R. Tepper, ex ecutive director of the Coun cil on Economic Priorities, was married here this noon to Dr. John Anthony Tepper Marlin, who legally added his wife's maiden name as a middle name.

title: Catholic Group Lists Grants
description: The Campaign for Human De velopment, an antipoverty ef fort by the United States Cath olic Conference, has announced 30 new grants, totaling $513 000, for selfhelp projects in 14 states. The awards were an nounced here Friday by the Most Rev. Michael R. Demp sey, Auxiliary Bishop of Chi cago, who is director of the national campaign.

title: Boatmen of 13 Nations To Begin Conference
description: More than 90 members of the international boating community, representing 13 countries, begin a weeklong exchange of ideas today in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Films, Talks By Experts Add Flavor
description: On the public days of the Newport show, Oct. 1 to 3, Sail magazine will sponsor a series of films and lectures given by sailors who are ex perts in their fields.

title: Walter C. Baker, Banker, Dies; Guaranty Trust Vice President
description: Walter C. Baker, a former vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, died yesterday at his home, 555 Park Avenue, after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Letters
description: As people in the blue printing business, we are in contact with architects ev ery day [Architects Find Computer A Friend, Aug. 29. It is unfortunate that when it comes to updating his own office techniques, the archi tect must be placed in the semiliterate class. He seems interested in new ideas for his clients, but when it is time for him to change, he has second thoughts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvation Army Swears in New York Commander
description: A 52yearold softsell evan gelist faced his corps of cadets and officers, garbed in tradi tional blue, and reaffirmed yes terday the Salvation Army creed to care for the poor, feed the hungry, clothe the naked, love the unlovable and befriend those who have no friends.

title: Dance
description: THE end of the New York summer and the begin ing of the New York dance season has for some years been the New York Dance Festival. This is an offshoot, or at least an epilogue, to the New York Shakespeare Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. I have an idea that the first person to subsidize it was Rebekah Harkness, but all that was some years ago. Now it picks up cash where it canthis year its sponsors have been varied but gener ousand it has become a genuine people's festival of the dance.

title: Stanford Routs Oregon, 3817, as Bunce Throws 3 Passes for Touchdowns
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)Don Bunce, proving to be a worthy successor to Jim Plunkett in Stanford's first Pa cific8 Conference game, threw three touchdown passes today and ran for a fourth as Stan ford routed Oregon, 3817.

title: Preps
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 25 Blair Academy and Borden town Military Institute, battled to a 77 tie in the season opener for both teams.

title: Medicine/Environment
description: WASHINGTONThe non prescription pills sold to help people stay alert or keep calm or go to sleep are often advertised as amazing, or remarkable, and almost al ways as new.

title: Coast Guard Routs Colby On 333Yard Offense, 2413
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 25 (AP)The Coast Guard Acad emy gained 333 yards on total offense today and trounced Colby, 2413.

title: Mrs. Raikes Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fitz Gerald Raikes of New York on Sept. 17 at the New York Hospital. The child will be named Jennifer Cather ine MacKinnon. Mr. Raikes is associate general counsel of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. Mrs. Raikes is the former Miss Antonia Raikes, daugh ter of Sir Victor and Lady Raikes of London. The cou ple are distant cousins.

title: Latin Parley Is Called By Four From Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)Four Spanishsurnamed members of Congress have an nounced their sponsorship of a national conference of MexicanAmerican and Puerto Rican groups.

title: Subways to S.S.T.: Does bigger and faster mean better?;
description: The climactic battle over the supersonic transport last win ter was remarkable in the general field of transportation politics not only because of the outcome (the machine lost) but because the fight finally went public.

title: Penn State Crushes lowa, 4414, As Harris, Mitchell Run Wild
description: IOWA CITY, Sept. 25Fran co Harris and Lydell Mitchell put on a rushing performance reminiscent of Army's Glenn Davis and Doc Blanchard to cut up Iowa's defenses and carry Penn State to a 4414 victory today.

title: Westchester
description: Westchester County's long est winning streak came to an end yesterday when Roosevelt of Yonkers capitalized on a fumble to defeat Horace Gree ley of Chappaqua, 86, in a bat tle at Roosevelt Field between two of last year's undefeated, Untied teams.

title: Most City Suicides Called Preventable
description: A major portion of the 1,200 suicides recorded in New York City each year for the last de cade could have been prevented if adaquate treatment facilities had been available, according to a number of physicians and psychiatrists.

title: Mystery Man in U. S. Yachting Lifts Veil From Self and Vessel
description: NAHANT, Mass., Sept. 25 Richard E. Carter, known in Europe as a designer of racing sailboats but a mystery man in American yachting, is introducing a OneTon Cup craft to the United States at the Newport show.

title: Helaine F. Geismar Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Geis mar have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Helaine Felice Geis mar, to Arthur Alan Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Klein, also of New York.

title: Adelphi Is Routed, 510. By Central Connecticut
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Sept. 25 (AP)  Unbeaten Central Connecticut rolled to its third victory today, routing Adelphi, 510.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: LINDA BENNETT AT RAINBOW GRILL
description: Show business being what it is and always has been, when a girl makes a visit and as immediate a visual impression as Linda Bennett, a blonde who is the epitome of the idea lized fresh, blowing, allAmeri can girl, it comes as something of a surprise to find that there is considerately more of her than meets the eye.

title: Preps
description: EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., Sept. 25East Rockaway, on the passing of Rick Mayell, de feated Long Island Lutheran, 190, in the Metropolitan Foot ball League debut for both teams. Mayall completed 11 of 23 passes for 176 yards.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  They've really started throwing their high cards in Washington, the United States Air Force officer said as he scanned the fact sheet on last Tuesday's massive American air raids against Communist antiair craft sites and supply storage dumps inside North Vietnam.

title: Mini environment
Miss Krisch Plans Bridal
description: ROANOKE, Va., Sept. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Joel Krisch have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Jane Krisch, to Jack Loeb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Loeb of Montgomery, Ala.

title: Et A1.
description: An attempt at withit Shake speare criticism. Opening para graph about how the book was conceived in a Paris flat on the Left Bank, which was soon to reverberate with echoes of police batons hammering on student skulls.  born in Berkeley clouded with tear gas. , etc., etc. Comparisons are thrown around: Much Ado with Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf discussion of Shakespeare's relevance, of LSD. Outa sight.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Thank God: Malta is staying with Britain! That was the re action of one Maltese last week to the news that, after months of bickering, agreement had been reached between the Govern ment of Premier Dom Mintoff and the British over continued use of the naval base on the Mediterranean island. For 200 year's, Malta has been tied to Britain, and many islanders were fearful that Mr. Mintoff was seeking to end what has been a mutually beneficial relation ship in favor of closer ties to Arab North Africa or the Soviet Union.

title: William and Mary Wins From Davidson, 40 to 14
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI)  William and Mary, paced by the running of Phil Mosser and the kicking of Mike Dodds, crushed Davidson, 4014, today for its third straight Southern Conference victory.

title: Protest Vote Fails To Bar the Sailing Of Carrier to Asia
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 25The Navy rejected today as utterly meaningless a protest vote of nearly 5 to 1 cast by San Diego civilians and military personnel against the return to Vietnam of the aircraft carrier Constel lation.

title: Manhattanville Adapting To Coeducational Status
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 25 Coeducation is not as ex traordinary a step for us as one would think, said Elizabeth J. McCormack, the president of Manhattanville College. It's really a natural flowering of what has been happening here.

title: Nassau North
description: Syosset's Massive line was as good as it was supposed to be yesterdayit held Farmingdale to one touchdownbut that was one more than Farming dale's line allowed in a 60 up set over the Nassau County Division III playoff champions of 1970.

title: The Busing Dilemma
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 25In many communities across the nation there are disputes over the busing of chil dren to achieve racial integration in the schools. The controversies evoke so much anger and generate so much confusion because two valid aspira tions are in conflict.

title: Et A1.
description: Essays by the Warden of Wadham College, Oxford, and formerly chairman of the phi losophy department at Prince ton. On Ryle's The Concept of Mind  Ethics: a Defense of Aristotle, Spinoza and the Idea of Freedom. Previously published in such professional journals as Mind, Analysis, the Philosophical Review. Quite technical.

title: Barbara Billows Bride of Roy Tilles Jr.
description: HYDE PARK, N. Y., Sept. 25Miss Barbara Billows, a secretary with Reader's Di gest in New York, was mar ried here this afternoon to Roy E. Tilles Jr., an assistant national brand manager with Liggett & Myers in New York. The Rev. Franklin A. Mahlau performed the cere mony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Police in Italy Recover 47 Stolen Works of Art
description: GENOA, Italy, Sept. 25 (Reuters) Italian authorities today recovered 47 stolen works of art in Naples and Genoa.

title: When sleeping deep
description: In September, 1939, there was a war; and on the first day of British involvement, a young Englishwoman in her early thirties, writing under the sincedurable penname of Mol lie PanterDownes, sent her first Letter from London to The New Yorker. Like Edward R. Murrow's This Is London broadcasts, her columns, Con fident even in the face of the facts she relayed, provided Americans with a sense of what it was like to live on an island even more embattled and iso lated than it had been a gen eration earlier. World War I, except for raids by tinderbox Zeppelins and ungainly Gothas, had been fought on the other side of the security ribbon of the Channel, across which hun dreds of thousands of casualties were quietly unloaded in Lon don railroad stations under cover of censorship and dark ness. By 1940 the war Mollie PanterDownes described in cluded nightly incendiary raids, and reporting the home front was reporting the battlefront.

title: White Hause Pit Stop Costs Donohue a Lead
description: At a White House recep tion last Tuesday in honor of auto racing, Mark Donohue was standing in the receiving line of guests waiting to shake hands with President Nixon. In the shuffling, he sneaked ahead of Bobby Isaac, a leading driver in the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

title: Reader's Report
description: Now hear this! Nuclearpow ered submarine Lancerfish dis abled in 1,250 feet of water, 160 miles off Cape May, N. J.  Topside, rescue operations snafu. Below, fire and flood decimate survivors. Meanwhile, back at Naval Headquarters, there is politics involved in revving up a new deepsea sal vage device. As the days lengthen into weeks and con ditions worsen, a Soviet ocean ographic vessel heaves into view

title: L'Affaire Pingeon: Cycling's Flood Case
description: PARIS, Sept. 25A bicy cle race does or does not take a drug. Traces show up anyway in a urine sample and he is suspended four months by the sport's gov ernors. The cyclist shouts foul and goes to civilian courts. That's not allowed. He is, it seems, suspended for life.

title: DUKE WINS, 280, FOR THIRD IN ROW
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI)Duke's full back, Steve Jones, ripped through Virginia for two touch downs today as the unbeaten Blue Devils posted a 280 tri umph.

title: Dog Pulls Veteran to Class
description: MARSHALL, Minn., Sept. 25 (AP)A former Army sergeant disabled by a booby trap in Vietnam attends classes at Southwest State College here in a wheelchair pulled by his 120pound Alaskan Malamute, Sarge. Darwin Madtson, 24 years old, a sophomore from Jasper, has a chain attached to the collar of his dog. Mr. Madt ?? holds the chain in his hand ?? Sarge pulls him around.

title: VILLANOVA VICTOR OVER V.M.I., 133
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 25 (UPI)Daryl Woodring passed 21 yards for a touchdown to Mike Siani on his first aerial and Villanova survived a battle of turnovers to defeat Virginia Military Institute, 133, today.

title: The Nation
description: Just because Edward Cox, who worked one summer for Ralph Nader, got by with inviting him to the White House wedding doesn't mean that Mr. Cox's fatherinlaw is going to invite him back.

title: Hartman Takes Pennsylvania 500 and Gains USAC Stock Car Driving Title
description: LONG POND, Pa., Sept. 25Butch Hartman of South Zanes ville, Ohio, won the Pennsyl vania 500 today in the season finale of the stockcar division of the United States Auto Club. The victory gave Hartman the division championship.

title: W. R. Grace's New Thrust
description: The world's largest manu facturer of pasta. A major producer of ice cream in Ireland and Italy. A leader in the soft drink industry of thp Netherlands. A distribu tor or salad oil and house hold soaps in France.

title: Appalachian Agency Is Told Region's Indicators Are Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) The Appalachian Regional Commission, created in 1965 to alleviate the depressed economy of a 13state area, has been told that most indicators are up but that the region is lagging ecomonically behind a year ago.

title: Super stuffed
New HeroinLaden Car Found on Ship
description: Three men were arrested in Queens yesterday on a charge of having smuggled 200 pounds of heroin valued at $40million int othis country hidden in an automobilethe sixth such at tempt discovered in the last, five months.

title: They're still the way to start the day
description: Oranges and lemons are still effective alarm bells in the form of freshly squeezed orange juice and lemon bread. Squares of crisp, bacontopped corn bread are another good way to get the family started on workdays and school days  and especially on lazy Sundays. A special Sunday breakfast might feature a stack of sour cream pancakes to be eaten with generous amounts of maple syrup  the real thing not the adulterated stuff.

title: OKLAHOMA ROUTS PITT TEAM, 5529
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (UPI) Jack Mildren and Joe Wylie scored three touchdowns each and Greg Pruitt rushed for 118 yards today as 11thranked Oklahoma, behind a swift of fense, walloped Pitt, 5529.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A OneShot Antelope Hunt
description: LANDER, WyoThe year's first snow fell on the foot hills and the mountains of the Wind River range west of this small midWyoming commu nity the day before the Lan der OneShot antelope hunt was to begin, but it is unlikely that even a blizzard could have chilled the exuberance of the arriving hunters.

title: The Public Sentinel
description: In recent years, press and Government have appeared to be increasingly on a collision course. The Justice De partment's attempt to restrain publication of the Penta gon papers and the House Commerce Committee's effort to examine the unused film prepared for a Columbia Broadcasting System documentary both ended in failure, but both were significant efforts by Government to con strict the traditional freedom of the press. Grand juries investigating criminal cases have increasingly resorted to the practice of subpoenaing reporters and their notes in an effort to use the press as an arm of the law.

title: Study Finds Auto Head Restraints Curb Whiplash Injuries but Are Often Misused
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Head restraints, required on the front seats of all cars built since January, 1969, have significantly reduced re ported neck injuries in rearend collisions, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: N.Y. Tech Wins, 4113
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25Bob Levine threw touch down passes of 65 and 7 yards today to lead New York Tech's club football game to a 4113 victory over LivingstonRutgers. Levine's first scoring pass covered 65 yards to Steve Szewczuk and the second was a 7yarder to Bob Dante.

title: Preps
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 25 Rick Doolittle, whose older brother Jeff plays quarterback for Hofstra University, made his debut for St. Paul's, and re turned a kickoff 67 yards for his team's lone touchdown in a 128 loss to Dalton School. Orlando Wright scored twice and gained 87 yards in 14 car ries for Dalton.

title: 2 BLACKS TO VIE IN HOUSTON RACE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 25  The first black member of Con gress from the Deep South since Reconstruction could come out of the newly created 18th Congressional District in Texas, but probably not with out a pitched battle between two black state legislators.

title: PassaicHudson
description: Clifton lived up to its pre season billing as the best high school football team in Passaic County yesterday by powering to a 410 victory over Paterson Kennedy in Paterson.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: CHICAGOI doubt that the directors of this com pany ever thought a rail road would end up getting into panty hose, said Wil ham B. Johnson with an imp ish grin.

title: MISSOURI PASSES SINK S.M.U., 2412
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 25 (UPI)Chuck Roper stunned Southern Methodist with three decisive passes, two for touch downs, today as Missouri notched its first victory of the season, 2412.

title: Berkeley Councilmen Scored
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)Since the radicalliberal April Coalition won in the Berkeley municipal election last spring, 31 policemen have either quit or retired. Capt. Jo seph F. Hill, who resigned last month, said the new council men were making a political football out of the police de partment.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONSEvery fall for more than 20 years, the Turtle Bay diplomats have been going through the motions of a fierce battle on China. Each time they knew that they were shadowboxing. Nothing would be changed as a result of their efforts.

title: Baylor Tops Indiana, 100
description: WACO, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI) Godfrey White returned the secondhalf kickoff 94 yards for a touchdown tonight and Bay lor's defense contained Indi ana's power runner, Ken St. Pierre, in a 100 Baylor victory.

title: Army to Tear Down Part of Florida Canal
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 25 (AP)Judge Harvey M. 25 (AP)Judge Harvey M. Johnson of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has signaled a goahead for the Army Corps of Engineers to tear down part of the CrossFlor ida Barge Canal, which has been halted by President Nixon.

title: A New World Monetary System
description: The International Monetary Fund is opening its 1971' meetings in Washington under the shadow of the worst threat to the economic and political unity and stability of the nonCommunist world since World War II.

title: Knicks Rout Celtics, 12185, For 2d Exhibition Triumph
description: UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP) The New York Knicks easily defeated the Boston Celtics, 12185, tonight in a National Basketball Association exhibi tion.

title: MERGER PROPOSED FOR TECH SCHOOLS
description: The establishment of a Met ropolitan Institute of Tech nology here by amalgamating four or possibly five of the graduate engineering schools in the city has been proposed by Dr. Seymour C. Hyman, act ing chancellor of the City Uni versity.

title: Pathology of the pill and the needle
description: Drug abuse is probably the most frightening problem facing many Americans today. The Vietnam war can be turned off like a television set, unless you have a draftage son. Pov erty is something most people see out the window of a com muter train. Polluted air and water are an annoyance, not an immediate threat. But any parent with a child in high school, or even junior high, must confront the drug issue.

title: GOAL IN SOCCER MAY BE EXPANDED
description: VIENNA, Sept. 25 (UPI) Soccer players don't score enough because the goal just is not big enough.

title: Row, Row, Row
description: MARLOW, England, Sept. 25 (UPI)Members of the Marlow Rowing Club claimed a world nonstop record yesterday after having done 2,124 miles up and down the Thames, 24 hours a day, for two weeks.

title: CARDS TOP EXPOS ON 2RUN 6TH, 86
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (UPI)Joe Hague drove home two runs with a triple in the sixth inning today to give the St. Louis Cardinals an 86 triumph over the Montreal Expos.

title: Miss Haddican Engaged
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Sept. 25  The engagement of Miss Maureen Haddican to Lieut. John J. Pingel, U.S.A., has been announced by her par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Haddican. Lieutenant Pingel, a graduate of the United Stages Military Academy, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Pingel of Uniondale. The fu ture bride is a graduate of Ladycliff College. A Decem ber wedding is planned.

title: Numbered Account Takes $105,010 Matron Stakes
Prophet of a coherent heterogeneity
description: No doubt about it! That old time social evolution is around once again. Revivalism is in the air. There is much testimony from some of the light and leading of American sociology, who want to tell us how the spirit  the evolutionary spirit, that is  has transformed their sociologies if not their moral lives.

title: Panel Topics: Growth, Funds, Drugs, Race
description: Excerpts from the educational sym posium at The New York Times fol low. Much discussion centered on this question: Is there anything dis tinctive about the educational scene on Long Island or is it essentially the same as that in any other metropoli tan area?

title: Taiwan Stresses Positive
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 25 Taiwan's newspapers reported briefly and matteroffactly that the General Committee of the General Assembly voted on Wedneday against debating the American and Albanian resolu tions on China representation at the same time. There was no mention that the vote was interpreted by many at the United Nations as a setback, if only a slight one, for American efforts to preserve a seat for Nationalist China.

title: Living in a sculpture IN GEORGETOWN
Marshall Comes Back; Triumphs in Final Play
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Sept. 25 (UPI)Reggie Oliver tossed a 13yard touchdown pass to Terry Gardner on the final play of tthe game today to give Marshall a 15.13 vic tory over Xavierthe first for the Thundering Herd since most of its team was killed in an airplane crash last Novem ber.

title: Bowdoin 3514 Victor
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Sept. 25 (AP)Dick Bates scored three touchdowns and Al Sessions two as Bowdoin rolled to a 3514 victory over Worcester Tech today.

title: Burned Prairie Town Fighting Back After Worst Fire Season in Decade
description: OSWEGO, Mont., Sept. 22 The dry wind, gusting close to 90 miles an hour when it chooses, sweeps down the open plains from the north and northwest and still today blows wisps of smoke from this town that stands in ashes.

title: Moretti's 4 Scoring Aerials Help Alfred Win, 3412
description: ALFRED, N. Y., Sept. 25 Jimmy Moretti, Alfred quarter back, completed four touch down passes and scored once in leading the Saxons to a 3412 victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute before a crowd of 5,225 today.

title: BARCLAY ROBINSON
description: HARTFORD, Con., Sept. 25 Barclay Robinson, a lawyers and former city official, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital after heart surgery. He was 74 years old and lived in nearby Avon.

title: Army Football Tickets Available for 4 Games
description: Tickets for Army's last three home football games, plus the annual ArmyNavy game in Philadelphia, are still available from the Army Ath letic Association ticket office at West Point, N. Y.

title: Reader's Report
description: Here is a book that asks a simple question: Can a boy of 20 fine happiness with a woman of 80? If the boy is a nut, and the old lady has the romantic appeal of the late Ben Turpin? Harold and Maude are a pair of sitcom kooks who go from oneliner to oneliner  until a final blackout that will cause your gorge to rise, if your gorge resembles mine.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: President Nixon's 90day wage and price freeze order of midAugust was accom panied by requests that work ers then on strike return to their jobs and continue nego tiations. The requests have continued, with varying im pacts on several strikes.

title: Maple Leaf Power Time
description: As university students in Montreal, during the forties, we used to divert ourselves playing the Canadian Iden tity Game, trying to trap that elusive nuance that made us different from other Americans. A friend came clos est. If, he ventured, it had been a Canadian marine who had broadcast the last ringingly defiant message from Wake Island in the darkest days of World War II, he would not have dared, Send us more Japs, but instead, No offense intended to any ethnic group, but could you, um, allow us more Japanese, please.

title: Federal Environment Chief Named for FiveState Area
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)Edward Furia, a 30 yearold Philadelphia lawyer, city planner and environmental consultant, has been placed in charge of Federal environment al programs covering a five state area.

title: America Is All Upside Down
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.It happens sometimes that the natural order of the atmosphere becomes reversed and the heavier cold air, which should be on bottom, is on top, while the lighter warm air, which should be on top, is on bottom. This is atmospheric inver sion which makes smog and pollution unbearable.

title: Director of I.M.F. Asks U.S.for Small Devaluation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today that the goal of res toration of a stable world monetary system could be achieved more easily if the United States made a contribu tion in the form of a small de valuation of the dollar by an increase in the price of gold.

title: Summer house
The Nation
description: ATTICA, N. Y.The reek of tear gas lingered in Attica Prison hallways last week, and Courtyard Da jumble of torn sheets and smashed furniture still looked like what it briefly had been: a battlefield.

title: Boats Fail to Finish in Time In Multihull Sailing Series
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 25 The East Coast multihull sail ing championships, sponsored by the Long Island Multihull Association, got off on the wrong foot today when both races had to be abandoned after no yacht had finished within the twohour time limit.

title: PEACE GROUP LISTS CANDIDATE CRITERIA
description: The national board of SANE, the nonpartisan peace group, declared yesterday that candi dates for the Presidency and Congress who wished its sup port mut be committed to re ducing the power of the mili taryindustrial complex and curtailing the warmaking pow ers of the President.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Ministers of finance and governors of central banks are not to be envied. They rarely reap credit, much less publicity, when the eco nomic news is good. They always harvest blame and are too much publicized when the news is bad.

title: TRAVELER WINS IN EASTERN SHOW
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25Mrs. Diane Ward's Traveler triumphed in the ama teurowner jumper competition at the Eastern States horse show today.

title: Hong Kong Observers Sift China Clues
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 25Ob servers here are Inclining in creasingly to the view that political problems in the Peking leadership are behind such re cent events as the cancellation of the customary Oct. 1 parade and the threeday closing of all mainland airfields.

title: Research Center in Jersey Dedicated by Drug Concern
description: NUTLEY, N. J., Sept. 25 HoffmanLa Roche Inc., a large pharmaceutical manufacturing concern, yesterday dedicated a $14million building here that was designed to house what the company says is the indus try's first research institute with a program not aimed at developing new drugs.

title: MORE BLACKS HIRED BY 5 TEXTILE MILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) The Pentagon reported this week substantial gains in Negro employment by five of the na tion's largest textile companies, including three once threatened with the loss of defense con tracts because of alleged dis crimination.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: BOSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) Rookie lefthander John Curtis spaced eight hits and was backed by a 12hit Boston at tack today as the Red Sox beat Washington, 63, and handed Denny McLain his 22d defeat of the season.

title: The Nation
U.S. Tied in Water Polo
description: HVAR, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 (AP)The United States and Rumania tied, 44, in the first round of an international water polo tournament yesterday.

title: Utah State Wins, 277
description: LOGAN, Utah, Sept. 25 (AP) Utah State defeated Nevada Las Vegas, 277, today in a game marked by interceptions.

title: President and Labor May Face Confrontations Over Pay Curbs
description: Organized labor's determina tion not to be shortchanged under existing contracts or dis criminated against in the post freeze period has raised the possibility of critical confronta tions with the Nixon Adminis tration in the months ahead.

title: Hofstra Wins, 2822
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 25 Jeff Doolittle ran and passed Hofstra University to its first victory of the season today, a 2822 triumph over the Univer sity of Maine.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collectors around the country will observe National Stamp Collect ing Week, Nov. 15 to 21, and this week will be cli maxed in New York by the National Postage Stamp Show, Nov. 1921, in the Exposition Rotunda of Madi son Square Garden Center, Seventh Avenue and 32d Street.

title: Coast Student, 21, Is Held In Inquiry on Triple Killing
description: SIERRA CITY, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI)A 21yearold student was held today for investiga tion of murder in the triple slaying of three fellow deer hunters in a campground.

title: Miss May Married To Spencer Tandy
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 25Miss Nancy Ann May, daughter of Mrs. Norman E. King and the late James S. May, was mar ried here this afternoon to Spencer Adams Tandy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Tandy Jr. of Westfield, N. J.

title: Preps
description: FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 25Dart Roberts 2point conversion gave Germantown Academy 1514 victory over the Hill School today. Roberts, a fullback, ran for his conversion following his 2yard touchdown run. Jim Gossett, the Hill 180 pound halfback, scored all of his team's points, but fumbled on a conversion try that would have put Hill ahead in the fourth period.

title: Preps
description: MADISON, N. J., Sept. 25Ted Monica Jr., son of the Madison coach, kicked a 30 yard field goal in the fourth pe riod to give his father's team a 30 victory over Delbarton School today.

title: McCarthy and McCloskey Tell Antiwar Youths to Vote
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (AP) Young people who oppose the Indochina war were promised by two possible Presidential candidates last night that they would havea choice of how the country was to be run by exer cising their right to vote.

title: WORTH THE PRICE
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sports of The Times
description: If it works, the George Allen motto will undoubtedly be carved on the Washington Monument. It undoubtedly could be chis eled into Mount Rushmore, too, but the towering spire in the nation's caiptal has the advantage of being closer to the scene. The imperishable words that Allen authors are: The future is now.

title: For Elliott Baker, roses and one brick
description: In a restaurant in Penn Station, I was thought to be epileptic. Or drunk. Or both. Later, I fell out of an overstuffed chair (it is very dif ficult to fall out of an overstuffed chair) and bruised the third and fourth ribs on my right side. Elliott Baker's Pocock & Pitt was the cause of it all. There are parts of this book that can cripple you with laughter. One of the things I've al ways regretted is that I do not laugh often or well. But in Penn Station, I was howling and sputtering, knock ing dishes about on the table, alter nately stamping my feet and chew ing my tongue. So know the book is dangerously funny, whatever else it may not be.

title: Locomotive Cab Design Blamed in '70 Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)The National Trans portation Safety Board has called for improvements in the design of locomotive cabs and for improved warnings at railroad grade crossings.

title: U.S. Gives 15 More Boats To South Vietnam's Navy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP)  The United States Navy took another step today toward completion of its pro gram to train and modernize the South Vietnamese navy with the turnover of 15 boats, including the 1,590ton de stroyer escort Forster.

title: MISS BARNETT KEEPS STROKE LEAD IN GOLF
description: ALAMO, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI) Pam Barnett, resisting pres sure from Pam Higgins and Kathy Whitworth, carded a one underpar 72 today to retain a onestroke lead in the $25,000 LincolnMercury tournament.

title: SOVIET SPACEMEN CARRY A RAY DRUG
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 25  Ac cording to Soviet specialists in space medicine, Soviet astro nauts carry a special antiradia tion drug on all space flights but have never used it so far, either in space or in prepara tion for a flight.

title: So. Connecticut Beaten

title: Death
description: Death is discovered early. Chil dren find a dead animal; a relative, family friend or pet dies. Then there are grief and questions  questions most grownups have pushed out of their minds because the answers are hard to accept, even for them. Why did it die? Will it come back? Is it afraid? What will happen to it now? And then the really difficult ones: Will you die? Will I die too?

title: Mixing classics
description: Anyone with lingering doubts that modem and traditional styles do not mix had better catch up with current decorating. The trend is wellestablished and all that matters is the way the mix is done. In this city apartment, the designing team of Schule McCarville added modern art, lighting and fabrics to the owner's antiques. (The owner, a young bachelor is, coincidentally, an an tiques dealer.) Retaining his Georgian side chairs, Chippendale chest (on the far wall) and oriental rugs, the designers intro duced such modern classics as an arc lamp, steelandglass table, an hexagonal plastic table, and a corner screen covered in a boldly graphic pattern.

Since Webster owed Parkman money and had been constantly harassed by Park man, he was an immediate sus pect. At the trial, amid much public outcry, Chief Justice Lemuel. Shaw delivered a biased charge. Since Webster's de fense had been poorly handled and Webster under Massachu

title: In Asia Minor, an allbutforgotten tragedy
description: Under cover of World War I, more than a million Armen ians and approximately 50,000 Greeks were liquidated in a uniquely Turkish prefiguration of the Final Solution. For the Christian survivors of this Ot toman horror, Allied victory in November, 1918, represented a messianic deliverance. Even the Turks themselves awaited their coup de grce with a certain fatalistic immobilism; dismem berment at the hands of the Great Powers was neither unex pected nor shameful, after all. As it happened, Lloyd George, Clemenceau and Wilson con ceived the notion of blocking an unwarranted Italian intru sion into southwestern Turkey by landing a division of Greeks at Smyrna as a preemptive force. The official rationale for this decision was the need to protect Smyrna's consider able Hellenic population. On a sunny May afternoon in 1919, therefore, the Greeks disem barked and immediately set about advancing beyond the city limits in search of a re surrected Kingdom of Ionia.

title: Music

Now comes the news that complete cessation of public service is threatened, come Jan. 1. Fun City is getting funnier and funnier. Ridi, Pugliaccio, ridi.

title: The home american lifestyles
description: America is undergoing its own brand of cultural revolution. A look at the American way of life points up a diversity of lifestyles that will become more and more pronounced, cautions Alvin Toffler in his current bestseller, Future Shock. And the home has displaced fashion and auto mobiles as the nation's status symbol. Some people search for excitement in architecture and furnishings, intent on making a 20thcentury statement for living. Others resist the frantic march of time, finding ideal surroundings in a nostalgic throwback to lessdisquieting times, as in the graciousness that still pervades the South (top right). But everywhere there is a greater appreciation of nature. Solariums and outdoor living areas like the one on the cover are a vital part of life in warm climates. Even indoors, an airy dining space like the one at right (second from top) indicates that the outdoors is not far away. Although the urban experience takes us headlong into futuristic interiors (second from bottom) that are well established in Europe and attempted with a degree of caution on our shores, the concept of delight in nature is equally strong in the cities. Urban folk find nature by fleeing the noise and pollution for a threeday respite in the country; thus vacation housing has given rise to new and exciting forms of architecture (bottom right). Houses forgo walls for screens of glass, catching the precious sun through adven turously placed skylights. Weekenders enjoy inhabiting a sculpture that not only shelters and protects, but also allows a communion with nature not permitted by other kinds of architectural design. Despite the tremors of future shock, the home is already displaying its adaptability to all of the diverse styles of the American of life.

title: World
description: Considering the low turnover and stagnant state of British Soviet trade, the vigorous growth of Moscow's commercial enter prises in Britain in the past two or so years may have seemed, to some, a case of poor economic planning. But not to the British Government. The disparity be tween the 550 Russians lately stationed in Britain and the 110 British nationals in Moscow has long been recognized by the British authorities as a measure of the Kremlin's espionage oper ations in the British Isles.

title: STOCK GAINS TIED TO ILLINOIS AIDES
description: CHICAGO, Sept 25A Fed eral grand jury taking testi mony here has been told that prominent Illinois politicians made thousands of dollars by selling race track stocks they had been secretly offered at bargain prices.

title: Of Supreme Stature
description: The death of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black only one week after his retirement deprives the nation of the wisdom as well as the active service of one of the more influential jurists of our time. The concurrent retirement of Associate Justice John M. Harlan, a preeminent crafts man of the law, confronts President Nixon and the Senate with a heavy responsibility to insure no letdown in the high standards these two distinguished jurists have established during fifty years of combined service on the Supreme Court. Only through the selection of menor womenabove politics or regions or creeds can respect for the Constitution and the liberty and justice it embodies be safeguarded in the courts and grow among the people.

title: Norman Mailer An Ego to Cherish
description: MAIDSTONE, Norman Mailer's third feature film (after Wild 90 and Beyond the Law), is something less than the revolutionary movie that the pub lishers of its screenplay claim it to be. It's almost two hours of comparatively expensive fooling around  of making do, putons, putdowns, desperation, junk, genius, satire, pretension, jokes, softcore sex (of an ancient, 1968 vint age), brilliant wordplay, silly byplay, climaxed by a spooky and hilarious and sad confrontation of two exhausted friends, all photographed in a set of lo cations that, in my list of priorities of places to see, come somewhere below Monument Valley but a little above As bury Park. I mean, how many of you are going to feel culturally deprived for not having visited Barney Rosset's place at East Hampton?

title: Moviegoing as a way of life in Argentina
description: Leaving out Borges, Argentine literature of the 20th century is not exactly required reading for the global village. For reasons, that I do not quite understand, it seems on the whole to be choked with metaphysics and cosmic skyscrapingthe tragedy of modern man without a God, bleak encounters with the void, the Pascal ian silence of the spheresthe whole bit. Nada. Wheezy angst this, and even in Borges, who has made a comic and burlesque cosmos out of just these fatal symptoms. Imagine what it must be like to write in Argentina with Borges still around. It's true that there are now two recognizable generations of writers after Borges (some nobly engage and even openly revolutionary); but he seems to lurk everywhere, if only the victim of a parricide by younger valiants who want something more real.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE table shown above is made entirely of Plexiglas. The base consists of three  inch thick sheets, 18  22 inches, with what will be the top edge (when assembled) notched as shown so that there is a inchhigh projec tion sticking up at each end. These projections will then fit into slots in the circular top when the table is put together. After cutting and notching, each sheet is then bent down the middle to a 120degree angle as indicated, using the special strip heater to soften the plastic along the fold mark. The edges are polished with very fine sandpaper, then the three pieces assem bled, after drilling 5/16inch holes, by bolting together with six short lengths of  inch threaded rod (sold in hardware stores) with a cap nut at each end as shown in the enlarged detail. The table top is cut out of inchthick material, and is an 18inch diameter circle. It is placed on top of the base and marks made for cutting out the notches that will accept the projections at the top corner of the base. These notches should be cut for a snug fit, and cement can be used to hold the top permanently down. Its edges should then also be polished with very fine sandpaper.

title: Now I'll Show You How a Star Talks
description: HALF the fun of being an actor is getting away from your own disgusting self, said Richard Burton. Richard Burton didn't say that to me, he said it to a reporter. He's never spoken to me. He's never even knocked me down and broken my camera. But I collect sayings of the great, against the time when I achieve greatness. I want to know how to be have on the day a columnist accosts me, hoping for a printable witticism.

title: A week in the life of Bill Buckley
description: At times, Bill Buckley seems to be the Muhammad Ali of the ToryYale ConnecticutEastcoast. The pre Frazier Muhammad Ali anyway. A lot of prancing around Strutting. Quick flicks of the wrist at the end of a long arm  an arm trained and lengthened by the best arm people in Greenwich, New York and Switzerland. Float like a butterfly, sting like a bee. A whole lot of per sona stuff. Very beautiful. The news magazines chastise him  the Head masters of our time  by printing his picture often, then covering for that by calling him impudent, then brilliant. I haven't been counting lately, but it seems to me that few people  certainly since Mary Mc Carthy's last 30game season  have been so relentlessly described as brilliant by Time magazine.

One was the vividly in tellectual George Bernard Shaw. The other (no less sug gestive of great wisdom) was an anonymous peasant, pho tographed by Margaret Bourke White in some remote Russian village.

title: The Seven Wonders of the Polluted World
description: RATHER than always spend your vacation seeking out virgin for ests, umblemished beaches and unspoiled natural wonders, how would you like to try something down right polluted? Before you say no, stop and think for a moment. Wouldn't you appreciate the beauties of the earth more keenly after having exposed yourself to a ravaged wilderness, a fetid water way or a decayed town?

title: A 10Day, 400Mile Auto Tour Through Iran: A Trip Of Tempting Diversions

During the next few days, the Government of Iran will host scores of foreign dignitaries and offer them, on Oct. 15 in Persepolis, an inter nationallytelecast parade that will rival a DeMille extravaganza. In essence, it's a private party, except for the in vited dignitaries and thousands of na tives and the tourists who have already booked up all the available hotel space.

What if the bombing had intimidated the leaders in Hanoi, and the Viet congoverwhelmed by napalm, de foliants, and B52shad decided to lie low until another day? What if the war had been wonas the Joint Chiefs and the President's cold war liberals had predictedin 1966, or even 1967?

description: MINEOLA, L. I.  Col ores Magicos, a sound andlight composition, will be the featured piece when the Orchestra Da Camera, Long Island's youthoriented cham ber ensemble, opens its 14th season in the Brentwood public schools on Oct. 4.

title: Lincoln's GreatGrandson Left $1.5Million Bequests
description: DORSET, Vt., Sept. 25 (AP) Lincoln Isham, a greatgrand son of President Lincoln, has left bequests in his will total ing more than $1.5million. He died Sept. 1 at the age of 79 years.

title: Et A1.
description: Translation of a silly piece of French journalistic history, taken from potted French Revolution books. It purports (at least in the Herder & Herder edition) to be a psychobiog raphy' but the author is neither biographer nor psy chologist, just a hack. Poor Robespierre, lonely man, always hoped the People would be Daddy. Off with his head! Gallo's too!

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWith almost unseemly speedonly 15 days after it first began hearings on the mattcr and less than six weeks after President Nixon first proposed itthe House Waysand Means Committee has ap proved a taxreduction bill. Cutting taxes has always been an easy, happy task.

description: Jensen Marine of Costa Mesa, Calif., has begun pro duction of its latest ocean racing contender, the Cal 33.

description: There will be a strong rep resentation of foreign sail boat builders and equipment manufacturers at the New port show despite recent un certainties over the dollar and the import tariffs.

title: More, but Smaller Schools Urged in City
description: Construction of more, but smaller schools, accompanied by the lease and purchase of school space in commercial and residential buildings, is recom mended in a report that urges major changes in the traditional methods of planning, building and utilizing the city's school facilities.

title: Strip Mining Curbs Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) The United Mine Workers of America endorsed with enthu siasm today the proposed Strip Mine Control Act of 1971 introduced by the chairman of the House Interior Committee, Representative Wayne N. Aspi nall, Democrat of Colorado. W. A. Boyle, chairman of the union, said the legislation would create new jobs by cleaning up strippedout lands and would protect the jobs of thousands of miners.

description: The chairman of the city commission on citystate rela tionships accused Dr. William J. Ronan yesterday of rebuff ing invitations to testify and even refusing to answer the chairman's personal telephone calls.

Muskie's undeclared Presiden tial candidacy today, saying that polls showed that the Maine Senator could be the first Democratic candidate to carry Arizona since 1948.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Rights Leader Urges Economic Development as Priority for Black Community
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson is urging the nation's black com munities to give top priority to economic development.

title: Diplomatic Break Feared
description: LONDON, Sept. 25British officials were anxious today about a possible breach of dip lomatic relations with the So viet Union in the wake of the British Government's dramatic order ousting 105 Soviet rep resentatives on espionage charges.

title: Patriarchal Role Denied To Ukrainian Rite Church
description: The Vatican has declined to grant patriarchal status to the Ukrainian Rite Catholic Church, ending nearly a year of inten sive protest by leaders of that rite against what they called second class treatment by the Vatican.

title: Recordings
description: THE world moves fast. If you don't hurry you may miss it. China, so long taboo to Ameri cans, is now opening up. First the PingPong invasion last Spring, then President Nixon's July announcement that he will visit China to talk with Mao Tsetung. Si nology will now emerge from its eclipse and become the rage. Being as alert as the next man, I realized there was not a moment to lose and set about getting some re cordings of Communist Chi nese music. Easier said than done.

title: While the King Slept His Soul Went to Heaven; When He Awoke He Built Lalibela
description: PILGRIMAGE roads, wherever they lead, draw us into their spell. At the end we may find a church, a river or simply a rock. But some times in the pilgrimage itself a deeper meaning lies. Lalibela, a village high in the mountains of northeastern Ethiopia, is heralded today as possessing one of the artistic Wonders of the World10 or 12, depending on how you count them, churches cut out of the living rock in a tangle of pits, chambers, tun nels and facades. They were built in the 13th century as a deliberate lure to draw pilgrims away from Jerusalem, which was then held by the Moslems. Probably bands of Christian refugees from Syria and Egypt, hearing word of King Lalibela's mountain hideout and sanctuary, worked their way south into his fold. Some among them would have been experienced stonecutters, willing to help with his grandiose building proj ect, working with crude iron picks, not with the assistance of angels as the legends say. King Lalibela was a great dreamer in other ways too: he supposed ly had the idea of diverting the Blue Nile to empty into the Indian Ocean and thus starve out the infidel in Egypt. But time, weather and human destruc tiveness have reduced his soaring ambi tions. His birthplace today is sunk in poverty and his works seem on the point of decaying back into the red stone from which they were cut.

title: Subway Murals Depict History of Bryant Park Area
description: It may not compare with the Metropolitan Museum of Art or the Frick Museum, but subway riders transfer ring between the IND and the IRT under Bryant Park are being given something to look at besides advertis ing posters.

title: About Pro Football
description: Even the greatest athletes, old and young, have their bad days. George Blanda's bad day came last Sunday after an incredible series of good ones a year ago when the 44yearold quarterback of the Oakland Raiders very nearly walked on water. Blanda may have had a premonition at Foxboro, Mass., against the New England Patriots that it was not going to be one of those mostvaluableplayer afternoons.

title: L.I. to Get Federal Aid To Provide 1,000 Jobs
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  Nearly $12million in Fed eral Emergency Employment Act funds will be pumped into the economies of Nassau and Suffolk counties, provid ing more than 900 jobs be tween now and June, 1972.

title: GEORGIA RALLIES TO ROUT CLEMSON
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Sept. 25 (AP)Powerful Georgia, its of fense sputtering early in the game, rallied in the second half today and routed Clemson, 280.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 25 (AP)A Federal judge ordered a city school system yesterday to turn over its authority to the turn over its authority to the county school board Monday because it refused to bus stu dents in accordance with a courtordered desegregation plan.

title: Upswing Is Seen in NassauSuffolk Economy; Unemployment Tapering Off
description: A halt to a twoyear down turn and at least stabilizing of Long Island's economy are foreseen this fall for Nassau and Suffolk Counties by State Labor Department experts and others. Unem ployment has began to taper off after reaching a record last July above 70,000.

title: Mortimer H. Hess 3d To Wed Mary Spinner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Spin ner Jr. of Brooklyn have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Katherine Spinner, to Mor timer Henry Hess 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hess Jr. of New York and North Stam ford, Conn. A January wed ding is planned.

title: Rockland
description: North Rockland started de fense of its Rockland County Public Schools Athletic League title yesterday with, a laugher. The defending champions, led by Jimmy Brechbiel's 25 points trounced Tappan Zee 440.

title: AROUND THE
description: The planting schedule is still on: evergreens, shrubs, hedges, perennials, bulbs, etc. It's getting late to sow lawn seed; better switch plans to sodding.  Prune suckers from lilacs, crabapples and haw. thorns.Divide old established clumps of perennials.

title: Explosion in East Pakistan Injures a Cabinet Minister
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 25 The Minister for Local Gov ernment in East Pakistan's weekold Government, Maulana Moammed Ishaque, was slightly injured today by an explosion in his car in Dacca, thought to have been a bomb. He was in jured in the right leg and arm.

title: Abundant in Visual Incident
description: THE career of Edouard Vuillard (18681940) evokes for us today a world almost as remote from the tensions and pressures of con temporary life as the world of Frago nerd. It is a world in which the culti vated bourgeoisie is still secure in its privileges and in its tastea world in which art, money, comfort, talent, and new ideas exist in an untroubled har mony, a world insulated from catas trophe.

title: Headliners
description: Sentimental Interest

title: 7 LOAN INSPECTORS DISMISSED BY CITY

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 25 (UPI)Senator Henry M. Jack son of Washington, a Demo cratic Presidential hopeful, met with Gov. Milton J. Shapp to day to discuss the political situ ation in Pennsylvania.

title: CLOSE RACES SEEN FOR CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 25 Incumbent mayors in three of Connecticut's largest cities, renominated after bitter pri mary elections, are seen as fac ing trouble in the general elec tion in November because of defections in their parties' ranks that became evident in the primaries.

title: News of Dogs

Suf folk stages its 33d annual fix ture on Saturday at Lake Grove, with 1,205 dogs, and Westbury holds its 49th show next Sunday, at C. W. Post Col lege, Brookville, L. I., with an entry of 1,832. This week will be the busiest of the year in the Long Island area. In addition to the allbreed events, three specialties are listed.

description: The Manhattan College foot ball team defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 190, yesterday in a defensive battle that saw the Peacocks fumble 10 times.

Phillips of the Air Force Systems Command's Space and Missile Organiza tion, will be honored for work as director of the National Aeronautics and Space Admin istration' Apollo manned space program from 1964 to 1969.

description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25The So viet Government has been publicly urged to provide mod em, Westernstyle carnival amusements in all cities as a means of curbing crime among youth and of reducing tradi tionally heavy drinking among all age groups.

title: Knit and purl
description: When you've been living in sweaters and skirts or sweaters and pants for a couple of years and decide to try a dress, what's your obvious choice? A sweaterdress, of course. It may button down the front like a cardigan or slip over the head like a pullover, but the feeling is that same old sweater feeling casual and comfortable. It's a dress to live in.

description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 25 (UPI)  Thwarted by a tough Tennessee defense for three periods, Auburn finally staged an 89yard march to gain 109 victory today in a hard hitting battle of Southern pow ers.

description: Are Long Islanders hypocritical as they point their fingers at the South and criticize it for not accepting racial integration? description: TORONTO, Sept. 25Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said of the United States this week, I don't think they know much or care much really about Canada.

description: ROME, Sept. 24Warring moderate and leftwing fac tions of the Christian Demo cratic party, Italy's dominant political forces, were headed for a showdown today.

description: MILAN, Italy, Sept. 19The recent opening of Italy's first hypermarket  a suburban shopping center  highlights the emergence of a megalopolis of perhaps five million people in the MilanTurin area.

title: Without Marx or Jesus
description: Only Europeans have appreciated just how much of a revolution in human affairs America represents. Americans have been too busy being this revolution, trying in their dif ferent ways to live with it, to be able to give to so much change the awareness necessarily based on the past, on European society and tra dition, that a succession of brilliant and usually disapproving Europeans have made about America as an overthrow of their traditions, about America as a revolution in human relationships, even about America as the natural home of revolution.

title: Vietnam as the medics saw it
description: About two years ago I helped perform an autopsy on a sevenyearold girl who had died, needlessly, of pyelone phritis. A chronic urinary tract infection had gone undetected for five years and had left her kidneys knotted by scar tissue. Several hospital physicians had worked hard and long to save her, but failed. She looked ter ribly small, I remember framed by gleaming stainless steel, on a P.M. table meant for bigger people.

title: VIETNAM VOTERS FEAR TO ABSTAIN
description: CUCHI, South Vietnam, Sept. 23The old man in his under shorts, sitting in a village re pair shop for Honda motor cycles, does not want to vote for President Nguyen Van Thieu, who runs unopposed, on Oct. 3, but he will.

description: CHICAGO, Sept., 5Albert C. Buehler, board chairman of the Victor Comptometer Corpora tion, died Thursday at Chicago Wasley Memorial Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: A Bitchy Society Will Be An Inflationary Society And other responses to a questionnaire
description: ON Aug. 15 President Nixon announced a dramatic reversal of his former eco nomic policy. The nation woke up to find wages and prices frozen for 90 days, Congress was presented with an important tax package to stimulate the economy and reduce unemployment, and the rest of the world discovered that in a single blow the President had shattered the 25yearold international monetary system.

title: YOUTH VOTE ROLE IN STATE WEIGHED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The potential youth vote may create considerable uncertainty for eight of New York's incum bent Representatives in the 1972 elections, but its overall effect on the state will probably be less pronounced than else where in the nation.

description: The private club, that ail ing backbone of corporate America's business and social life, has been dealt another painful blow. Bludgeoned by recession, uncontrollable costs and civilrights activ ism, the club is now threat ened by strangulation through taxation and record keeping.

Presi dent Pompidou of France urged a hard European line against the United States in monetary negotiations and Guido Carli, head of the Bank of Italy, called for a Euro pean monetary bloc whose currencies would float in unison against the dollar.  The dollar plunged to 22year lows on the foreignexchange markets.

description: BANGOR, Maine, Sept, 25 (AP)Thomas P. Di Paola, who graduated from the University of Rhode Island last June, has become soccer coach at Hasson College.

description: WASHINGTON  Brooklyn's delega tion to Congress, long accustomed to having its share of the more influential members of the House of Representa tives, is facing a major shakeup.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: A colossus whose luck ran out
description: Sir Walter Ralegh (never Ra leigh in his lifetime), the fox in question, was a West De von man who rose skyhigh during the English Renaissance, becoming a favorite and trust ed counselor of Elizabeth I aft er his exploits as a soldier on the Continent and in Ire land. As a voyager to the New World, and as a privateer con ducting forays against the gal leons and overseas bases of the Spanish Empire, he won pre ferment at the English court. He was a distinguished poet and historian. He introduced tobacco and other American agricultural products to Eng land. He was a cunning and resourceful intriguer in an age of factions  and was instru mental in the defeat of Essex and his rebellious cohorts. His acquisitive instincts and talents brought him vast estates in England and Ireland.

title: Fla. State is Victor, 307
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 25 (UPI)Gary Huff, playing less than three quarters, passed for 300 yards and three touch downs tonight as Florida State routed Kansas, 307.

title: Riverboat Will Serve As a Carrier of Mail
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Delta Queens, one of the last operative paddle wheel steamboats, will churn the waters of the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers as a mail carrier.

title: ROGERS TIES ISSUE OF SOVIET SPYING TO EUROPE TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25  Secretary of State William P. Rogers warned to day that the scope of Soviet espionage in the West is go ing to be a factor in the Atlan tic alliance's decision on wheth er to agree to a European secu rity conference proposed by the Warsaw Pact.

title: Egypt Reaps Disappointment and Deficit in Reclaimed Desert
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25A dream of wresting land from the des ert and making it bloom with cotton, corn and other crops has cost Egypt about $1billion since reformminded young of ficers overthrew King Farouk in 1952, but the main harvest has been disappointment and defi cits.

title: Miss Ann O'Donnell Is Affianced

Prichard of West port, Conn., son of Jarvis B. Prichard of Thief River Falls, Minn., and the late Mrs. Floris Smith Prichard. The wedding is planned for No vember.
