description: WAHSINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, reopened the Vietnam debate in Congress to day by introducing a new amendment calling for with drawal of all American forces from Indochina in six months.

title: Students Clash With Police
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Sept. 28 (AP)  Students hurling fire bombs clashed with the police in a new flareup of antiGov ernment demonstrations today and witnesses said one student was shot and wounded.

title: GROMYKO PROTEST SPURNED BY HOE
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union expressed a vigorous protest here yesterday over Britain's decision to expel alleged Soviet spies and indicated to Sir Alec DouglasHome, the British For eign Secretary, that Moscow felt obliged to retaliate in some fashion.

title: Sports of The Times
description: There was some notable pitching in town on Sunday afternoon. Bill Kilmer of the Washington Redskins out pitched Fran Tarkenton of the Giants at Yankee Sta dium, while Tom Seaver of the Mets outpitched Steve Blass of the Pirates at Shea. So slick did Kilmer perform as a fillin for the injured Sonny Jurgensen that Giants fans were instantly jolted into the realization that they are in for a long and unhappy autumn. Such was the virtuosity of the Seaver feat that it gave rise to the hope that he may yet finish his personal season amid the blast of triumphant trumpets.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: Rangers Defeat Wings Here, 40
description: The two new Ranger for wards, Bobby Rousseau, who was wise and cool, and Pierre Jarry, nervous and inexperi enced, made successful Madi son Square Garden debuts last night as the New Yorkers cap tured a freewheeling exhibi tion from the Detroit Red Wings, 40.

title: $4Million in Emergency Funds Allotted to Repair Attica Prison
description: Governor Rockefeller and the Republican and Democrat ic leaders of the Legislature an nounced yesterday that $4mil lion would be allocated imme diately from the state's emer gency fund to repair damages at Attica prison and to pur chase additional security equipment throughout the state correctional system.

Y., Sept. 27India's Foreign Min ister, Swaran Singh, over the shouted objections of the Paki stani delegate, told the United Nations General Assembly to day that the Pakistani Govern ment had unleashed a reign of terror and was conducting deadly activities in East Paki stan.

title: Youth Denies Coast Slayings
description: DOWNIEVILLE, Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI)Carter P. Yuen, a 21 yearold resident of San Fran cisco's Chinatown, pleaded not guilty today in Justice Court here to three counts of murder in the gunshot slayings of three deerhunting companions. Mr. Yuen was accused of killing Russell K. Wong, 22; Wendell Lee, 21, and Daniel Yen Woo, 21, whose bodies were found Friday in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada along the north fork of the Yuba River. The three victims also were from San Francisco.

title: Trojan Women':Cacoyannis Presents a Star-Filled Drama
description: "The Trojan Women," Michael Cacoyannis's not quite all-star film version of the Euripides lamentation on war specifically the Achaean's destruction of Troy after Helen took off with Paris, is the kind of movie that a lot of good people will feel called upon to praise for the fact of its having been made at all. The argument is that there simply aren't that many people around who won't rest until they put Euripides on film, and, after all, any Euripides-on-film is better than none.I'm not too sure, at least, as long as there are printed texts available and those occasional theatrical productions, such as the one Cacoyannis himself staged successfully at the Circle in the Square in 1963, that, without being terribly adventurous, still capture the power of what is essentially more of a ritual than a narrative drama.The film that Cacoyannis has made is not bad, but something that is somehow more offensive to anyone interested in the possibilities of movies to enrich and excite the mind. This "Trojan Women" is high-class mediocre. Cacoyannis has slightly trimmed the Edith Hamilton translation (the gods have been excised from the text), and added at least one hilarious exchange of dialogue for continuity's purposes (Herald: "Tell Menelaus to come at once to the women's camp." Soldier: "What's up?" Herald: "They're after Helen's blood.")What's most disheartening, however, is that he has chosen a banal style that falls midway between the literal realism of the film's exterior landscapes and the poetic realism of the play's language. This is a confusion, I might add, that is further compounded by a series of casting coups that look like the remains of 30 years of Miss Universe contests.All of these women are good actresses, but their manners and methods are so different from one another that the effect of the drama, which should be that of one long, carefully orchestrated moan, is squeaky and Babel-like, as fragmented as the close-ups (mid-forehead to bridge-of-nose) with which Cacoyannis periodically studies the faces of his Spanish-looking chorus. (The movie was shot in Spain.)Katharine Hepburn, flinty New Englander that she is, plays old, gray-headed Hecuba, not so much like the defeated Queen of Troy she is supposed to be, but more like an apple grower's widow who weeps a lot.Hecuba is the center and the power of "The Trojan Woman." She is the mistress of the awful ceremonies that make up the drama, presiding helplessly but with almost pre-moral strength, over the horrors the Greeks have committed on her family, Troy and the human race.Miss Hepburn speaks most of her lines with small, elegant accents that have very little to do with epic grief, and only in her final confrontation with Helen, the one who has brought the ruin down upon them all, does her Hecuba suggest real depth and passion. Genevieve Bujold, the French-Canadian actress, is a more or less elfin Cassandra, which is not, however, the way I imagine her.In their own, very different ways, Vanessa Redgrave, as Andromache, and Irene Papas, as Helen, are quite interesting. Miss Redgrave is very English, but she is also an actress of such classic beauty, and classical authority, that she commands attention. So does Miss Papas, an actress I haven't always admired, but here her dark, ageless, almost masculine beauty gives real dimension to the role of the woman who was once the most beautiful in the world, and may still be.I suspect that Cacoyannis needs the limitations of the stage to give his work automatic discipline, to fix the focal point, which the movie never finds.On the stage, "The Trojan Women" takes place outside the Greek camp, with Troy in the background, but it is probably played most effectively against a minimum of scenery and props. In Cacoyannis's film, I never was sure where we were supposed to be, and since the film opens in such dense clouds of smoke, I was genuinely surprised when, at the end, Troy is finally set afire. I'd assumed it'd already burnt down.In spite of the fact that "The Trojan Women" is a kind of moving fresco, or frieze, which should be kept at a certain distance, Cacoyannis often uses his camera subjectively (most atrociously when it spirals to earth, as if it were in the body of the boy, Astyanax, being hurled to his death from a cliff.) The director, however, doesn't pursue any style long enough for it to become dominant. The result, like the accents of its leading ladies, is a confusion of compromises that tell you the plot, which is not important, but communicate hardly any of the exaltation, which is."The Trojan Women" opened last night at the Fine Arts Theater.

title: Unit to Report. On Forum Step
description: A progress report on the campaign to prevent the re location of the 299seat Forum Theater from the basement of the Vivian Beau mont in Lincoln Center to a backstage area will be pre sented at a meeting of the Drama Desk, the organiza tion of theater writers and editors, at Sardi's Belasco Room on Monday.

description: Announcing yesterday his resignation as chancellor of the Jewish Theological Sem inary of America, Dr. Louis Finkelstein, 76 years old, ex plained:

title: BELLE ACTON PACE TO HOPE DIAMOND
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 27 Only the fact that the 12th edi tion of the Belle Acton pace for 2yearold fillies was a non betting feature saved the chalk players at Roosevelt Raceway tonight the proverbial bundle. If wagering had been permit ted, Romalie Hanover surely would have been sent away the heavy favorite on the strength of her season's record, which showed 15 firsts in 18 outings, a mile mark of 1:59 1/5 and a winning streak of eight.

title: Sir Douglas Copland Dies at 77; An Australian Economic Adviser
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept 27  Sir Douglas Copland, Aus tralian economist and diplomat, died of peneumonia today in a Melbourne hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Amoco Chemicals Reduces Polypropylene Film Prices
description: The Amoco Chemicals Corp oration, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (In diana), said yesterday that it would reduce prices on poly propylene films, effective today, to make them more competitive with imported films.

title: DEPOSITORY IS SET FOR STOCK SHARES
description: Agreement to create a cen tral depository that could hold more than 5 billion shares of stock and handle up to 100,000 transactions a day was reached yesterday by representaives of the securities industry and 11 New York banks.

title: Seat Sale Price Declines
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday a seat had been sold at $215,000, off $10,000 from the previous sale Sept. 10. The current mar ket rig $175,000 bid, $235,000 asked.

title: NASSAU VOTES BILL ON DISPOSAL OF OIL
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 27  A bill providing penalties of a fine or jail term for in dividuals or companies that permit the intrusion of waste oil into Nassau County's water ways or underground drinking water supply was passed to day by the Board of Super visors. County Executive Ralph G. Caso signed the Measure.

title: General Foods Ends Role In Bids to Save Lines Group
description: LONDON, Sept. 27 (UPI) General Foods of the United States pulled out today from involvement in bids to save the Lines Brothers Group, one of Britain's largest toy con cerns, and said it would defer further action until liquidation proceedings were complete.

title: Danish Coalition Resigns, 4th Party Refuses to Join
description: COPENHAG EN, Denmark. Sept. 27 (UPI)  Premier Hilmar Buansgaard's centerright coa lition Government resigned today after more than three years in power. It was suc ceeded by a Social Democratic minority government.

description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27With a rookie, Rich Sowells, at left cornerback for the New York Jets, the St. Louis Cardinals ex ploited the 12thround draft, choice's inexperience tonight for a 1710 victory in the na tionally televised game at Busch, Memorial Stadium.

title: A New Agreement on Aid Signed by Peking and Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Sept. 28A new agreement covering Chinese Communist aid to North Vietnam in 1972 was signed in Hanoi yesterday, cli maxing the visit there of high  level Peking delegation under Deputy Premier Li Hsien nien.

title: 3 British yachts Selected
description: LONDON, Sept. 27 (UPI) The team of three British yachts that won the Admirals Cup series this summer under the leadership of Prime Minis ter Edward Heath was named today by the. Royal Ocean Rac ing Club to compete in Aus tralia's Southern Cross series in December. The British Pre mier will not, however, com pete in the series, which, gave him his first major yachting triumph two years ago.

title: House Panel Favors a Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The House Government Opera tions Committee approved to day a bill to establish an inde pendent Federal agency with authority to advocate and pro tect consumer interests.

title: ...Such as One in an East Side Church
description: Samuel's Temple Day Care Center, one of the city's two licensed 24hour care facilities, has been a community effort right from the start.

title: Municipal Bonds Edge Up In Price in Light Trading
description: Taxexempt bond dealers, faced with today's huge $500 million newissue volume, ap pear convinced that they can push interest rates downward and still sell bonds to invest ors. Although trading activity was light in the municipal bond market yesterday, prices tended to rise slightly as underwriters prepared to bid today.

title: Festival in Capital Ends With Nine Hours of Music
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The House of Sounds Festi val, the first jazz presenta tion at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, wound up its threeday stand in the center's Con cert Hall yesterday with nine hours of musicfour in the afternoon, five at night.

title: Two Tennis Stars Fine Themselves
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rose mary Casals, who angrily quit their finalround singles match in the Pacific Southwest open tennis championships yesterday, have fined themselves $1,000 each to show they have the guts to admit they were wrong, the director of the World, Ten nis women's pro tour said today.

title: Roy L. Curthoys, Reporter For Times in Australia, 78
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 27Roy Lancaster Curthoys, former correspondent of The New York Times in Australia, died in Melbourne on Friday after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

title: DR. TANNENBAUM, 44, PHYCHIATRIST HERE
description: Dr. Gerald Tannenbaum, as sociate professor of psychiatry at New York Medical College and director of inpatient psy chiatric service at Metropoli tan. Hospital, died Saturday in a motorcycle accident at Park Avenue and 85th Street. He was 44 years old and lived at 115 East 85th Street. His office was at 185 East 85th Street.

title: Portrait of an OTB Bettor: Male, Affluent and Single
description: Offtrack betting's typical customer emerged from a market survey here yester day as a white, middleclass, middleaged unmarried male who plays the horses regu larly, yet supposedly has more brains and money than his neighbor. These conclu sibns were reached through interesting, if convoluted, rea soning.

title: BP Oil Fined for Pollution
description: ALBANY, Sept. 27 (UPI)  The BP Oil Corporation of Atlanta has been fined $1,500 for a diesel oil discharge into the Hudson River, it was an nounced today by the Environ mental Conservation Commis sioner, Henry. L. Diamond. Mr. Diamond said the penalty was for a discharge of 20,000 to 25,000 gallons of diesel fuel into the river when a tank rup tured last Nov. 4 at Verplanck, Westchester County.

title: STOCKS REGISTER 6TH LOSS IN ROW
description: The stock market, beset by uncertainty over the economy and by investor caution, de clined yesterday to register its sixth loss in a row.

title: Manes Nominated in Queens
description: Donald R. Markes, a Democrat, received the Republican nom ination yesterday for Queens Borough President. Mr. Manes, a former City Councilman, was appointed Borough President Sept. 22 after Sidney Leviss, a Democrat, resigned. Mr. Manes now has the Republican, Demo cratic and Liberal nominations and appears assured of being elected to a full term on Nov. 2. His only opponent will be Rob ert J. Hanophy, a Conservative.

title: ZINC MINE IS OPENED BY ST. JOE MINERALS
description: BALMAT, N. Y., Sept. 27 The St. Joe Minerals Corpora tion opened here today what was described as the largest single zinc mining operation in the United States.

title: Some Progress for McGovern
description: News Analysis

title: Market Place: Paniflex Looks To Next Steps
description: The folks at the Paniflex Corporation, makers of spe cially designed bifold closet doors, appear to have found a way to raise substantial capital without immediately undergoing the rigors of a fullscale registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Los Angeles Cool to Dodgers' Struggle
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 The Los Angeles Dodgers, struggling to catch the San Francisco Giants, were play ing a big game in Atlanta yesterday. On the beach in Santa Monica dozens of port able radios blared forth the unmistakable sound of a cheering crowd.

title: More BrokerageFirm Data Asked by S.E.C. Accountant
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)The chief accountant:of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a House Com merce subcommittee today that brokerage firms should publish more detailed informa tion about their own activities.

title: Marine Killed in Accident
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Sept. 27 (AP)One Marine was killed and another injured yes terday in a grenade accident on a Camp Pendleton firing range. A spokesman said that Pfc. Harold M. Stover, 18 years old, of Elyria, Ohio, was killed and Pfc. Danny L. Crotter, 20, of Walnut Springs, Tex., wounded.

title: DISSIDENT SEEKS HELP OF LINDSAY
description: A Manhattan Democratic dis trict leader challenging the re election of Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti as Democratic county leader said yesterday that he would seek the help of Mayor Lindsay in his effort.

title: RCA HAS CUT 2,000 IN COMPUTER GROUP
description: The RCA Corporation has dismissed 2,000 workers in its computer  systems group, or about 20 per cent of the group's work force, as part of the com pany's plan to withdraw from the generalpurpose computer business.

title: U.S. Showed a Trade Deficit in August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  The United States bal ance of trade ran in the red for the fifth month in a row in August as Americans im ported $259.7million more in goods than they exported.

title: Suspect in Stabbing Was Seized On Gun Charge the Day Before
description: The panhandler and former mental patient who the police said stabbed three passersby outside Madison Square Gar den Sunday night had been ar rested last Saturday on gun charges and was released with a summons.

title: Illinois Lieutenant Governor To Enter Governor Race
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) Lieut. Gov. Paul Simon declared today his candidacy for the 1972 Democratic gubernatorial nomination, ruling out any sug gestion that he might seek the Senate seat of Charles H. Percy, Republican.

title: COLLEGE TRAINING IS COAL OP POLICE
description: Within a year or two no one will be able to enter the New York City Police Department unless he has had at least one year of college education, under plans being drawn by Commis sioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: L.I. School Board Ratifies Contract
description: CENTEREACH, L. I., Sept. 27The school board of the Middle Country School Dis trict tonight ratified a contract with the striking teachers as sociation, ending a fourday walkout of the 850member union in the district.

title: List Still Awaited
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The Justice Department has not yet forwarded to the Amer ican Bar Association for screen ing a list of potential nominees for the Supreme Court, a spokes man for the department said today.

title: RACIAL DISORDERS CLOSE 2 SCHOOLS
description: Racial disturbances erupted yesterday at high schools in Piscataway and Irvington, N. J.

title: Notes on People
description: My doctor tells me I have the heart of a 40yearold man, said Wayne Morse, the former Senator from Oregon. Therefore, Mr. Morse has de cided to run against Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican, next year.

title: SENATE PANEL BID REJECTED BY KLEIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Nixon Administration's chief of information has de clined an invitation to appear before a Senate subcommittee that is scheduled to begin hear ing tomorrow on freedom of the press.

title: Cards Turn Back Mets With 5 Runs in 10th, 61
description: Gil Hodges gambled and lost last night at Shea Stadium. With the gamble, the Mets may have lost third place.

title: CITY U. BOARD HEAD OFFERS RESIGNATION
description: Dr. Frederick H. Burkhardt submitted his resignation last night as chairman of the Board of Higher Education, which governs the City University.

title: U.S. Atlas Giants Update the World
description: For the nation's biggest makers of atlases, this is the time of the major model change each decade, the publication of new census editions. They have tackled the awesome updating task. hundreds of new maps, spectacular earth photo graphs from space, and more than 100,000 entriesfrom A to Zip.

title: Taxi Dispatching Begins in the Theater District
description: TakACheck Taxi, what might be called Broadway's lat est spectacle, opened on both 45th and 46th Streets last night to mixed reviews.

title: ANDREW DE SARLE
description: Andrew De Sarle, sales manager of entertainment for Cue magazine and former as sistant amusements advertising manager of The New York Journal American, died Sunday in Downnstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, after Surgery He was 51 years old and lived at 1873 East 26th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Attica Prisoners Notified by State of Right to Consult Lawyers
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 27State authorities disclosed today that they had given Attica inmates written advice of their right to speak to a lawyer before being interrogated about their actions during this month's prison re bellion.

title: Lottery Veto Overriden
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate voted 26 to 13 today to override Gov. Francis W. Sargent's veto of the state lottery bill. However, the Senate minority leader, John F. Parker, moved immedi ately for reconsideration in an effort to swing the one vote that would keep the veto from being overridden.

title: Theater: Czech Black Light Troupe
description: Clever is as clever does, and the Black Light Theater of Prague, which returned to the City Center last night, takes ingenuity to the point of ingenuousness.

title: MEXICAN GUERRILLAS SEIZE INDUSTRIALIST
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 Three armed men and a wom an today kidnapped the direc tor of Mexico's airports sys tem, Julio Hirschfeld Almada, the police reported.

title: Billy Graham, Yankees and Giants Support WPIX
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The Rev. Billy Graham, the New York Yankees and the New York Giants were among 60 people or groups backing assertions by WPIXTV today that its programing serves the community interest.

title: Censored Pentagon Data Placed on Sale by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A censored version of the Pentagon study of the Unit ed States involvement in Vietnam went on sale today in Government Printing Of fice bookstores here.

title: PAROLE IS FORECAST FOR BENGALI LEADER
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 27 Pakistani newspapers predict ed today that Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the imprisoned Ben gali leader, would be released on parole soon to visit his ail ing parents in East Pakistan.

title: U.S. Sues to Cut Prices Of Atlanta Falcon Tickets
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Department of Justice charged the Atlanta Falcons to day with increasing their ticket prices in violation of the Presi dent's wage and price freeze.

title: A Resilient Aristocrat
description: Man in the News

title: Ody H. Lamborn, Sugar Broker Who Led Exchange, Dead at 74
description: Ody H. Lamborn, president of Lamborn & Co., Inc., sugar brokers, from 1935 to 1964 and a longtime leader in the sugar industry, died Sunday in Uni versity Hospital. He was .74 years old and lived at 4 East 70th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wennerstrom Takes First In 2d Soling Class Race
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 27 Stig Wennerstrorn of Sweden, won the second race today in the world Soling Class sailing championships on Long Island Sound.

title: Kahane Declares If Prisoner Dies, Russians Will, Too
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27  Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, asserted here today that Jewish militants would kill two Soviet diplomats some where if Miss Silva Zalmanson died in a Soviet labor camp.

title: Freeze Delays the 4Day Week At a Texas Insurance Company
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 27A ruling from the Federal Office of Emergency Preparedness has forced the United Services Automobile Association of San Antonio to delay an experi mental fourday work week for its 3,000 employes.

title: Bank Assets Up 12.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) Total assets of 4,599 national banks stood at $353billion on June 30up 12.9 per cent over the figure for a year earlier, according to a report today by the Controller of the Currency, William B. Camp.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that four executives were appointed to new posi tions. Edgar R. Molina was appointed vice presi dentAsiaPacific and Latin American automotive operations. He previously was vice presidentLatin American group. Robert B. Alexander was named vice presidentLatin American group, reporting to Mr. Molina. He was vice presidentcar engineering, Ford North American automotive operations. Har old K. Sperlich was made vice presidentassistant to the president, European automotive operations, reporting to Lee A. Iacocca, president. Danald E. Petersen will succeed Mr. Sperlich as vice president and general managertruck operations. He has been vice presidentcar planning and research.

title: New Pro Six Seeks An Arena; Brooklyn Is Showing Interest
description: The New York franchise of the World Hockey Association, formed over the weekend, moved quickly yesterday when it officially requested 39 play ing dates in the Nassau Coli seum for the 197273 season.

title: Quebec Police Still Out
description: DRUMMONDVILLE, Quebec, Sept. 27 (AP)Provincial po licemen extended a 24hour work stoppage indefinitely to night, leaving most posts closed down or manned by super visory personnel.

title: BJORN ANDERSEN, AN ENGINEER, 74
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 27 Bjorn Andersen, a chemical engineer and inventor, who served as a vice president of the Celanese Corporation of America from 1951 to 1962, died today in Community Hos pital, Montclair. He was 74 years old and lived at 38 Park Road,

title: Chairman of House Unit Charges Impropriety in Selection of 2 Underwriters for Postal Service Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The chairman or the House Postal Services Subcommittee charged today that the selec tion of two of five investment companies to underwrite the United States Postal Service's first Issue of $250million in bonds had a strong ap pearance of impropriety.

title: White Youths Attracted by Gospel Music
description: The gospel music industry, the only music field where Negroes are said to hold a controlling edge, has profited in recent months from an un expected source  white youths who are listening to and buying gospel recordings.

title: Some G.I's Are Happy to Be Sent to Vietnam
description: BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Sept. 26They tell you they're winding down the warthen you turn around and bang, you're here, the young draftee said after he stepped off the chartered troop carrier at this air base.

title: Nixon and Hirohito Pledge Amity in Anchorage Talks
description: ANCHORAGE, Sept. 27A President of the United States and an Emperor of Japan met last night for the first time in history. The meeting was held here in a colorfully decorated hangar at a chilly air base midway between Washington and Tokyo.

title: Available for Court
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 27 (AP)Dr. Pauli Murray, Stul berg Professor of Law and Poli tics at Brandeis University and a lecturer in law at Boston University Law School, said to day that she wrote to President Nixon, saying she was available if he decided to nominate a woman to the Supreme Court.

title: Birth in the Wilds: II
description: ROMEWhen you pretend that natural law applies to others but not yourself, then normal expectation points to trouble. Man in his hubris has seen himself the master of all things, and has lived to witness na ture's answer in polluted waters, poisoned air. And nowa bit late as alwayshe begins to glimpse that farther choking shore, pollution of his social environment through unrestrict ed reproduction. And however church men or demagogues or mildewed phi losophers may inform him, he stands in violation of that natural law dictat ing the selfregulation of animal num bers.

title: EDWARD S. MORSE
description: Edward Samuel Morse, presi dent of Clark, Boardman Com pany, Ltd., 435 Hudson Street, law book publishers, from 1946 to 1963, died Sunday at his home, 119 Willow Street, Fair Haven, N.J. His age was 87.

title: PLOT IS ADMITTED BY LADY FLEMING
description: ATHENS, Sept. 27  Lady Fleming, the Greekborn widow of Sir Alexander Fleming, the Briton who discovered penicil lin, told a military court here today that she had tried, as charged, to help free a Greek prisoner.

title: Ending Manhattan Boss Rule
description: It has long been a political anomaly that Manhattan Democrats, who form one of the nation's most progres sive constituencies, have been led by a backward looking politician out of yesterday's era of smokefilled rborns. Asserriblyman Frank G. Rossetti, recently re elected to his post as district leader, intends to move Thursday to secure reelection as Manhattan's Demo cratic county leader, thus keeping intact a type of con trol little changed from the heyday of Tammany Hall.

title: A Contaminant Is Found in Cardboard
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Food and Drug Administra tion announced today that it had found high levels of the chemical contaminant PCB in shredded wheat packed in re cycled cardboard.

title: Quitman to Give $1Million To Yale Over Two Years
description: Yale University announced yesterday that one alumnus, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, the chair man of the board of Phillip Morris, Inc., had pledged $1 million to the Yale Alumni Fund over the next two years as a challenge to other alumni.

title: Mitchell and the Wiretap
description: Attorney General John Mitchell is again asking the courts to give the executive branch the final say on when the Bill of Rights must bend to national security.

title: 10 Soldiers Are Wounded
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 27 (UPI)Ten British sol diers were wounded today in an ambush near Newly, a machine gun attack in Londonderry and a clash with a mob in Belfast, the British Army said. The inci dents caused the highest single day's casualty toll the army has suffered in two years in North ern Ireland.

title: Playoff Tickets on Sale
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (UPI)The Los Angeles Dodg ers placed on public sale today tickets for the Naticinal League playoffs against Pitts burgh, in the event the Dodg ers win the Western Division title in their battle with the Giants.

title: Ecological Science Suing Union Bank
description: MIAMI, Sept. 27The Eco logical Science Corporation filed suit today in Federal Dis trict Court here against the Union Bank of Los Angeles seeking damages of $309mil lion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gaming Inquiry Initiated
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Sept. 27 (UPI)A special Federal grand jury convened today to inves tigate possible bidden casino interests and skimming by gambling resort owners. Skim ming is a term used for raking money off the top in the casino counting rooms before report ing profits for Ames. Govern ment officials declined to say which gambling interests would be investigated.

title: Assembly of Trucks In Chile to Be Ended By General Motors
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 27 General Motors announced here tonight that its Chilean truck assembly plant would stop operations by the end of this year.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
No Ouster Plans Here
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) The United States has no plans to oust a large number of Soviet officials as Britain has, the State Department indi cated today in response to questions.

title: Washington: For the Record
Muskie at Milwaukee Rally
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 (AP) Senator. Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, a potential candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, told a rally here tonight that Americans are living in doubt about our po litical leaders. He spoke to about 600 persons in a pre dominantly PolishAmerican neighborhood.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 of 10 Charges Dropped As Roy Cohn Case Starts
description: Six of 10 charges against Roy M. Cohn were dropped yesterday at the start of his trial in Federal Court here on charges of filing false state ments regarding Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

title: Discussion of Sclerosis Set
description: A seminar discussion of Re cent Advances in MS Research and Their Significance Toward Finding a Cure will be held Oct. 6 at the Red Cross Audi torium, 150 Amsterdam Ave nue. Dr. Murray B. Bornstein, professor of neurology at the Albert Einstein College of Medi cine, will be the principal speaker. The seminar is spon sored by the New York County Chaptet of the National Multi ple Sclerosis Society.

title: Police Testimony Links 2 at Trial To Bombing Plots
description: Three policemen testified yesterday that they had found explosive substances, detona tors and timers on the floor of a car driven by two young men allegedly linked to a series of more than 100 actual or at tempted bombings in the city over the last two years.

title: 3 LEADERS URGE ACCORD IN ULSTER
description: LONDON, Sept. 28The Brit ish, Irish and Northern Ireland Prime Ministers joined today in urging a process of political reconciliation in troubled Ul ster. But they left the specific problems unresolved.

title: A Learning Experience, With Credit, for 18YearOld: Working for Farm Union
description: If somebody held a sweepstakes for the most interest ing What I Did On My Summer Vacation story, Laurel Reiner of Ossining, N. Y., might rank right up there near the top.

title: Advertising:
description: Lee Slurzberg Research did a survey of 500 Negroes in 20 urban areas to see how well advertising slogans are being remembered. The high est recall was for Flo through tea bags by Lipton with a 79 per cent. The next in order of their memorabil ity (respondents were mostly asked to fill in the blanks in the slogans) were Dial, Grey hound, CocaCola, Pepsi Cola, Wonder bread and Charmin.

title: Excerpts From Gromyko's Policy Statement in General Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28Following, as sup plied in English translation by the Soviet mission, are excerpts from a policy state ment made in the General Assembly today by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister:

title: East Europe Says U.S. Tries to Wreck Detente
description: WARSAW, Sept. 28Bri tain's decision to expel Soviet diplomats accused of spying is being treated in Eastern Europe as a deliberate attempt to sabo tage the relaxation of tensions in Europe. Washington was said to be behind the move.

title: CITIZENSHIP LOST BY QUEENS WOMAN
description: A Queens housewife who was a guardsupervisor in Nazi con centration and death camps during World War II lost her American citizenship yesterday.

title: C.I.A IS ACCUSED BY REP. M'CLOSKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Representative Paul N. McClos key Jr. of California said today that the Central Intelligence Agency was recruiting Ameri cans to become combat mer cenaries in Laos.

title: JACOB FRUMKIN, ORT AIDE, WAS 91
description: Jacob Frunikin, a lawyer for more than six decades, in Jewish organizations in Russia, Germany, France and the United States, died Monday after a heart attack in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 50 West 77th Street.

title: Council Asks Mayor to Restore Half Fare for 60,000 Students
description: The City Council yesterday urged Mayor Lindsay to ap propriate sufficient funds to the Board of Education to pro vide halffare bus and train passes to 60,000 students whose reducedfare passes had been terminated in an econ omy move.

title: TV: New Shows EscapistAnd Dull
description: As the new commercial television season stumbles through its third full week of heavily revised schedules, one conclusion is inescap able: It may not be the worst new season on record but it is very probably the dullest.

title: McGovern to Press Drive
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 28 (AP)Senator George Mc Govern, Democrat of South Dakota, will make another swing through New Hampshire next month in his campaign for votes in the state's March Pres idential primary, his headquar ters said today. Mr. McGovern will make a threeday tour be ginning Oct. 9 with addresses in Waterville Valley and Leb anon.

title: AMTRAK PLANNING SERVICE CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, said to day that it planned a major improvement in rail service this fall.

title: Bank Merger Is Approved
description: The New York State Banking Department annonuced yester day its approval of the merger of the $3million Bank of Elba into the Citizens Central Bank in Arcade, a unit of the Charter New York Corporation.

title: Cohn Defended on $350,000 Payment by Bus Lines
description: Roy M. Cohn was described by his defense lawyer in Fed oral Court here yesterday as the mastermind of lengthy condemnation proceedings that won $55million for Fifth Ave nue Coach Lines, Inc.

title: M.O. CHANGES POLICY ON QUOTES
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has informed its members of a policy change aimed at curbing the insertion of phony stock quotations in its automated new marketquota tion system.

title: Blown Glass Trees That Create a Forest of Light
description: The trees in that fragile glass forest are eight feet tall. All are white. Some are twisted, pretzellike, and seme pulse with neon light.

title: A STRONGER PACT SET ON GERM WAR
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28A revised draft convention aimed at out lawing biological warfare was submitted to the Geneva dis armament conference today by the United States and the Soviet Union, with their respective Atlantic and Warsaw Pact allies joining as cosponsors.

title: Mine Union Talks Go On
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Negotiations between the United Mine Workers of Amer ica and the soft coal industry continued today with no indi cation that a strike at midnight Thursday could be avoided.

title: U.S. COURT BARS STATE VOTE LAW
description: A special threejudge Federal panel yesterday declared un constitutional a new state elec tion law that bars major party candidates from accepting the nomination of small political groups in local elections.

title: STATE OPENS CASE AGAINST MULLIGAN
description: The identity of a current member of the police force for whom Hugh Mulligan allegedly sought a promotion two years ago was disclosed in court yes terday.

title: THAIS TO JOIN U.S. IN NARCOTICS DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The United States and Thailand formally agreed today to co operate in an effort to combat the growing narcotics traffic in Southeast Asia.

title: Bridge: Prevention of Slow Play A Problem in Tournaments
description: How to prevent excessively slow play in matches of great importance is a problem that has never been satisfactorily solved. In international cham pionships, it is usual to im pose penalties on teams that repeatedly exceed the allot ted time for a session. These rarely have any impact, al though a slowplay penalty hassle in a European women's championship once resulted in an official verdict that no team had won.

title: YANKEES DOWNED BY SENATORS, 42
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Although the lame duck Sena tors topped the Yankees, 42, tonight at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, the high point of the evening for the 3,242 fans who turned out for an almost final look at the Senators came in the fifth inning.

title: Atlantic Richfield Removes Price Supports on Gasoline
description: The Atlantic Richfield Com pany withdrew yesterday wholesale gasoline price sup ports from its dealers. The At lantic Richfield move followed similar steps taken by many other large oil companies to halt competitive price cutting.

title: Washington: For the Record
In French Prison Town, Rage at Those Across the Road
description: CLAIRVAUX, France, Sept. 27Only the barking of dogs broke the silence of the wooded valley, tinted with the first gold of autumn. In the bar across the road from the prison, men moodily drank their beer or red wine, and glared suspiciously at a stranger. They spoke reluc tantly, holding back their se crets, reflecting the hatred and fear that exploded in violence there last week.

title: Defective Boiler Sluts Down Big Allis
description: An apparent fuel malfunction in one of the two boilers of Big Allis, the giant Consolidated Edison generator at Ravens wood, Queens, shut down the millionkilowatt plant last night. The resulting massive roar from safety valves was heard throughout upper Manhattan and Long Island City.

title: Neighborhoods: Derelicts Plaguing Penn Station Area
description: To the anger and dismay of sports fans, commuters and security men, a new breed of aggressive derelicts is operating around Madison Square Garden and Pennsyl vania Station.

title: Garden Names Cooperman To New Development Post
description: Alvin Cooperman, executive vice president of Madison Square Garden Center, has been placed in charge of creative development and production for the center and its affiliates in all media and live presenta tion, it was announced yester day by Irving M. Felt, the center's president and board chairman.

title: French Urge Free Trade And Stable Money Rates
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28Maurice Schumann, the Foreign Minister of France, told the General Assembly to day that free trade and stable exchange rates were essential to the continued development of the world's economy.

title: N.&W. Head Cites Decline in Business
description: John P. Fishwick, president of the Norfolk & Western Rail way, yesterday gave a terse description of his road's cur rent business: It's lousy.

title: BAGHDAD REPORTS 2 AIDES DEMOTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 The Vice President and For eign Minister of Iraq have been dismissed from their offices and been given new ones in a purge by the leftist regime.

title: REGIONAL MARKETS SET CLEARING UNION
description: Representatives of the clear ing corporations of the regional stock exchanges in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and Phila delphia announced an agree ment yesterday to provide re ciprocal services to their mem bers.

title: Carol Beinbrink Scores In Woodcrest Golf With 82
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Sept. 28 Carol Beinbrink of Piping Rock scored 43, 3982 to win low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Class A tournament at the Woodcrest Club today. Par for the 5,681yard course is 36, 36 72.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH OVER STARS, 9689
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 28 The New York Knicks took a liking to the American Basket ball Association's red, white and blue ball and the 3point goal and held off the A.B.A. champion Utah Stars, 9689, tonight for their fourth pre season victory without a loss.

title: EGYPTIANS MARCH TO NASSER TOMB
description: CAIRO, Sept. 28The people and leaders of Egypt paid tribute today to Gamal Abdel Nasser, who helped seize power from King Farouk in 1952 and led the Egyptians into one of the most turbulent periods of their long history.

title: Prospects for a Partial Middle East Settlement Termed Bleak
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28Prospects for a par tial settlement, between Egypt and Israel were described as extremely dim here today after recent consultations among the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four and other diplomatic exchanges.

title: Columbia Wins in Soccer
description: A goal by Peter Vasudhara with 3:32 remaining in over time lifted Columbia's soccer team to a 32 victory over City College yesterday. Each team now has a 11 wonlost mark.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rates Decline on TaxExempt Bonds
description: The taxexempt bond market took a big step toward lower interest rates yesterday as it shouldered half a billion dollars worth of new issuesincluding New York City's $334.86mil lionwith ease.

title: W. WARD KIEVIT
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Sept. 28 W. Ward Kievit, who retired in 1958 as treasurer and con troller of the RaybestosMan hattan Company of New York and Passaic, died today in Montclair Community Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 24 Richmond Terrace.

title: 2 Engine Fires Delay Penn Central Runs
description: Three hundred and thirty persons were evacuated from a train in the Park Avenue tunnel yesterday morning be cause of an electrical fire in the engine of a Harlem line Penn Central railroad train as it was about to pull into Grand central Terminal. No on was injured.

title: Candido de Leon, Now Hostos Dean, Will Head College
description: Dean Candido de Leon was named yesterday president of the City University of New York's Eugenio Maria de Hos tos Community College in the South Bronx.

title: Bonn to Protect Farmers In a Revaluation of Mark
description: PARIS, Sept. 28  Germany warned its Common Market partners today that it wilt not permit its farmers to suffer a loss of income as a result of a revaluation of the mark.

title: Nixon Drug Aide Seeking Data On Veterans to Aid Wide Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Three months after he assumed the task of leading President Nixon's drive against drug ad diction, Dr. Jerome K. Jaffe is moving to fill an information void that he and other experts on drugs have said is a major obstacle to development of a national program to combat the problem.

title: Cardinal Mindszenty Departs
description: Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty has bowed to the pleas of Pope Paul and ended his long selfimposed confinement in the American Embassy in Budapest. Almost fifteen years ago, when he fled to the safety of the embassy as Soviet tanks and troops bloodily suppressed the 1456 Hungarian revolution, he was acclaimed as, a hero in much of the world. During the few brief days of his freedom from a Communist jail at the height of the revolution, he had become the symbol of outraged Hun garian nationalism lashing out at Moscow's imposition of satellite status upon Hungary.

title: Notes From the Wilderness
description: HARBORSIDE, MaineScott and I first went to the wilderness in 1932, in the midst of the Great Depression, to live a simple satisfying homestead ing life in the Green Mountains of Vermont. We thought we would rather be poor in the country than in the city; we had had enough of city living, both in this country and abroad, and we wanted to try our hand at meager selfsubsistence in an economy glutted with unnecessary articles bought by people who neither needed nor could afford the goods. We intended to grow our own food, put up our own build ings, find some cash crop we could produce in minimal time, and still be able to go on with our avocations: reading, writing, and making music.

title: Economic Indicators Show Decline of 0.9% in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reu ters)The Government's com posite index of leading economic indicators fell 0.9 per cent in August to 125.9 after a 1.7 per cent increase in July, the Commerce Department reported today. The base period is 1967 equals 100.

title: Antiwar Leaders Plan Demonstrations at Prisons
description: Antiwar activists will lead demonstrations Saturday at prison facilities across the nation to urge reform in prison policies in the United States and South Vietnam.

title: Democrat Supported by Stokes Nominated as Cleveland Mayor
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28Last minute support by Mayor Carl B. Stokes gave the Democratic nomination for mayor to a wealthy realestate developer, James M. Carney, in primary elections here today.

title: Baseball Highlights
description: Andy Messersmith became the third pitcher in California Angels' history to win 20 games in one season as he beat the Minnesota Twins, 62.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Backs Consumer Agency In a Policy Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The White House, in a policy shift, announced its support today of legislation to create an independent Federal agency with authority to advocate and defend con sumer interests.

title: Attica Inquiry Delayed
description: Selection of a citizens' com mittee to conduct a full and impartial investigation of all the facts in the Attica prison uprising is proving elusive.

title: Navy Aide Says 4 in Congress Applied Unreasonable Pressure in Cost Claim Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The director of the Navy's claims review office charged today that four members of Congress had applied un reasonable pressure in a multi milliondollar cost overrun case.

title: Palisades Park Trails Are Dedicated as National Urban Retreats
description: Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said yes terday that conservationists were going to have to live with more offshore oil wells, more bridges and more power plants.

title: Spartan Missile Fails Test
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)A Spartan missile pre maturely blew up in flight during the 17th test of the Safeguard antiballistic  missile system, the Pentagon said to day. The early detonation, which occurred last Thursday, was the fourth failure in the Safeguard test program.

title: NIXON URGED TO PICK ALABAMIAN AS JUDGE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 28Twentyseven participants in a secret caucus of black officials in Chicago last week end have mailed a letter to President Nixon recommending the appointment of an Alabama Federal District Judge to the United States Supreme Court.

title: 6 NATIONS ASK END OP DOLLAR'S ROLE AS KEY CURRENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 A number of leading industrial countries proposed today, with varying degrees of detail, a new world monetary system not de pendent, as in the past, on the United States dollar.

title: Shipyard Is Reopened
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., Sept. 28 (AP)Company and union officials announced today the reopening of Litton Ship Sys tems here after negotiations apparently solved the question of work assignments at the shipyard. Most of the facility's 6,000 employes have been off their jobs since Aug. 31.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: And Now, Beyond Attica
description: Imagine Attica rebuiltblack and Spanishspeaking guards, better food, censorship eased, the screens between visitors and inmates removed, full freedom of religion, daily showers available. There are classrooms, coun seling sessions and access to a good library. Officials are making an effort to remember that inmates are human beings.

title: Met Opera Presents Case for Subsidy
description: The Metropolitan Opera, in what it called a White Paper covering its operations for the last 10 years, yester day presented its case as an organization deserving and desperately needing subsidy from major foundations and government at all levels.

title: Inching Forward Reported in Talks In Filming Dispute
description: Negotiations resumed Mon day night between represen tatives of five major movie companies in New York and Local 52, International Al liance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators. After the 5hour meeting, held in the union's office, both sides were optimistic about a pos sible settlement. We inched forward, said Harold S. Klein, negotiator for the movie companies.

title: Attends Funeral in the Capital for Justice Back Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  President Nixon put in an un expected appearance this after noon at the funeral of former Associate Justice Hugo L Black, and heard a sermon on the un suitability of strict construc tionists for the Supreme Court.

title: Gold Imports Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters)United States gold imports totaled $47,813,845 in August, their highest level since last November's $69,984,536, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Cuts Rate
description: Directors of the Kaiser Alu minum and Chemical Corpora tion voted yesterday to halve the quarterly dividend. The new rate, 12 cents a share, will be paid Nov. 30 to stockholders of record Nov. 5. The company said that, in view of the indus try's over capacity and de pressed prices coupled with Kai ser's lower earnings, a reduc tion was in the best interests of the corporation.

title: Nonaligned Group Seeks Increased Impact in U. N,
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28The socalled non aligned countries, mainly Af rican and Asian, have agreed on an approach designed to increase their influence on the big powers.

title: Johnson of Angels Will Get Back Pay
description: An emotional disturbance should be treated no different ly from a physical ailment in baseball, an arbitration board ruled yesterday in ordering the California Angels to restore full pay to their recalcitrant out fielder, Alex Johnson.

title: COLONEL TESTIFIED HE KNEW OF MYLAI
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 28 Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers said today that Col. Oran K. Henderson had testified before a Pentagon board of inquiry that he had been aware on the day of the attack on Mylai 4 that a number of old men, women and children had been killed.

title: Four Seasons Submits Plan To Court for Reorganization
description: James R. Tolbert 3d, trustee for Four Seasons Nursing Cen ters of America, Inc., said yes terday that he lead submitted a plan for the reorganization of the company and the Four Sea sons Equity Corporation and related companies to a court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Special News Program Postponed by Chinese
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 28 (AP)Canton television post poned for 24 hours today a Peking  originated broadcast that may give some answer to what is happening in China.The Canton broadcast, mon itored in Hong Kong, said the special and important news program concerning circumstances of the Oct. 1 National Day celebration would begin at 9 P.M. tomor row night.Specialists in Chinese af fairs here believe the special broadcast will try to explain why China canceled the tra ditional Oct. 1 parade in Peking after preparations had been going ahead for almost two weeks.The parade had been held yearly since the Chinese Communists conquered the mainland in 1949 and it was always attended by Mao Tse tung and other Chinese lead ers.The cancellation touched off worldwide speculation that Mr. Mao was dead or seri ously ill. This has been de nied by the Foreign Ministry in Peking and Chinese em bassies abroad.

title: Quarterly Dividend Up; Violation Is Doubted
description: Morrison, Inc., a food serv ice concern, raised its divi dend yesterday but said it did not believe it was defy ing the President's wage price freeze.

title: SENATORS WARNED OF CURB ON PRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Congressional hearings on free dom of the press opened today with suggestions that the con cept was threatened by the Nixon Administration. The White House denied that the suggestion was valid and said the press was too sensitive on the subject.

title: 13 PLAYERS DROPPED AFTER DRUG TESTS
description: DOVER, Del., Sept. 28 (UPI) Delaware State College, loser of its first two football games, suspended 13 unidentified play ers today as the result of a drug abuse investigation.

title: Ewbank Disturbed as Jets Laugh It Off
description: As the New York Jets' char tered airliner taxied to its gate at LaGuardia Airport early yes terday, a burst of laughter re sounded from where the players were sitting in the rear. Up front, Coach Weeb Ewbank spun in anger.

title: DOCK WORKERS WARN OF POSSIBLE STRIKE
description: Officials of the International Longshoremen's Association voted here yesterday to au thorize a strike at all East and Gulf Coast ports if the New York Shipping Association re fuses to continue the current contract's provision for a guaranteed income. The con tract expires tomorrow at mid night.

title: To Schiaparelli, Fashion Today Is an EightLetter Worth
description: PARIS, Sept. 28 (UPI)Elsa Schiapa reln, who was a dominant influence in international fashions in the nineteen thirties and forties, sums up in one word how women look these days.

title: Rainout at Trenton Costs Grand Prix Two Top Drivers
description: About Motor Sports

title: Chile Nullifies Payments For Seized Copper Mines,
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 President Salvador Allende Gos sens today deducted $7.74mil lion in alleged excess profits from the compensation to be paid to United States com panies for three copper mines nationalized this year. This legal order effectively elimi nated the possibility of pay ments for the three properties.

title: CORE CONVENTION SET FOR HARLEM
description: Roy Innis, the national direc tor of the Congress of Racial Equality, announced yesterday that the organization's 30th an nual convention would be held in Harlem.

title: A Program by Jan Hoff Blends Dance and Film
description: There is clearly a virgin continent (well, as the old joke has it, an almostvirgin continent) to be discovered and explored in the relation ship between dance and film.

title: MERRELL R. FENSKE OF PENN STATE, 67
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 Dr. Merrell R. Femske, who re tired last, year as professor emeritus of chemical engineer ing at Pennsylvania State Uni versity, died today in the Uni versity of Pennsylvania Hospi tal. He was 67 years old.

title: MUSIC IS MODERN AT WARSAW FETE
description: WARSAW  Several hun dred musicians from about 20 countries gathered here last week to take part in the 15th Warsaw Autumn, the largest annual festival of con temporary music in Eastern Europe.

title: Market Place: Hardwicke Tells Comeback Story
description: You may remember Lord Hardwicke, Ltd.a franchise promotion like lots of others back in the bull market of 1969.

title: New Hampshire House Kills Measure for Student Voting
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 28 (AP)  The New Hampshire House killed today a measure that would have allowed stu dents to vote in the state's Presidential primary and elec tion in their college communi ties.

title: Lindsay, in California, Tests Political Climate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (UPI)Mayor Lindsay, test ing the climate in California for his potential candidacy for the Democratic Presiden tial nomination, indicated to day in San Francisco that he was not interested in being Vice President.

title: Kenny Organization to Forgo Mayoral Election
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28 Battered by charges of corrup tion and with many of its top leaders either convicted or under criminal indictments, the oldline Democratic organiza tion announced here today that, for the first time in half a century, it would not have a candidate for mayor.

title: South Vietnamese Border Posts Reported Under Stiff Pressure
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 29 (AP) B52 bombers, struck in three waves near the Cambodian bor der today in an attempt to break up North Vietnamese forces that are reported on the offensive along the Cambodian South Vietnamese border.

title: A NEW MOONCRAFT LAUNCHED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28The So viet Union announced today that it had launched an un manned spacecraft, Luna 19, toward the moon.

title: JUDGMENT WITHHELD ON DREYFUS ACCORD
description: Judge Edward C. McLean withheld a decision yesterday after hearing arguments on a proposed $5million settlement agreed upon by 10 original shareholders in the Dreyfus Corporation and Abraham L. Pomerantz, who represented a client who had charged that the 10 profited illegally by selling Dreyfus shares to the public in 1965.

title: Pupils Improve in School Run by Private Company
description: GARY, Ind., Sept. 28The reading and Mathematics skills of pupils in a school here have been significantly im proved since supervision of the learning process was taken over by a private company that guaranteed to improve the skills or give back the fees it is charging.

title: Phits' Banning Retires Alter 16 Years in Game
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Jim Bunning, of the Philadelphia Phillies, who pitched two nohitters, one a perfect game, and ranked sec ond in career strikeouts, re tired today after 16 years in the major leagues.

title: Chief of Labor Statistics Says His Bureau Is Being Reshaped
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28A reorganization of the Bureau of Labor Statistics is now in process, it was confirmed to night by Geoffrey Moore, Com missioner of Labor Statistics.

title: WEBSTER'S PLAN: A SWITCH IN TIME
description: Secondguessers of Alex Webster, head coach of the New York Giants, will have to get in linebehind Alex Web ster.

title: Hughes Petition Refused On Award of $145Million
description: The United States Court of Appeals here declined yester day to reconsider its Sept. 1 approval of a default judgment of more than $145million against Howard R. Hughes and his tool company to be paid to Trans World Airlines.

title: PARADERS SOLICIT VOTES FOR THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 29President Nguyen Van Thieu's administra tion has opened a series of low key, proGovernment meetings and parades in several cities in support of the presidential refer endum Sunday, and two small antiThieu student demonstra tions flared briefly here yester day.

title: Survey by Tass Gives Fischer Favorite's Role
description: MOSCOW, Sept 28Chess experts surveyed by Tass the official Soviet press agency, give Bobby Fischer, the American champion, a slight edge over his Soviet oppon ent in the forthcoming inter national chess matches.

title: Joan Baez Salutes A Labor Organizer With a Solo Concert
description: Good vibes filled the air in Carnegie Hall Monday night, when Joan Baez sang a solo concert in honor of Danilo Dol ci, who is a labor organizer in Sicily. It would be overstat ing the case, perhaps, to sug gest that the power of radical chic is rapidly spreading through the ranks of the under 30's, but the manner, dress and attitude of the audience, as well as the benignly radical senti ments expressed by Miss Baez and Mr. Dolci (through a trans lator), were not all that re moved from the ambiance of garden party for the Panthers.

title: JAMES H. MUMMA
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 28James H. Mumma, a personnel consult tant, died today in United Hos pital, Port Chester, after a brief illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 10 Heritage Lane.

title: H. A. STERZELBACH JR.
description: Herbert A. Sterzelbach Jr., a retired distributor of woolen textiles, died yesterday of heart ailment at his home. He was 88 years old and lived at 1 University Place.

title: STATE PENALIZES 177 FOOD STORES
description: A Jamaica, Queens, market that processed meat without having it inspected was fined $1,000 last month, the New York State Department of Agri culture and Markets announced yesterday.

title: Head of F111 Parts Concern Found Guilty of Conspiracy
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. Sept. 28 (UPI)The president of a com pany that made parts for the F111 jet fighterbomber was convicted tonight of conspiring to conceal defeective parts used in the plane.

title: Edward F. Weston, 92, Maker Of Scientific Instruments, Dies
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 28 Edward F. Weston, a former chairman of the board of the Weston Instrument Corporation, maker of scientific instruments, Newark, died at his home yes terday. He was 92 years old and lived at 40 Wayside Place.

title: Activity Stops in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 28The setting sun marked a brief truce of the divisions and argu ments within Israel tonight, as Jews in Jerusalem and the world over observed the most solemn day or the Hebrew year  Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

title: Strike Mediation Offered
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (UPI)The chairman of the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors, James V. Fitzger ald, offered today to mediate a strike of cemetery workers that had left 1,400 bodies un buried, smile of them since last June. He asked the county health director to determine whether the unburied bodies created a health hazard.

title: France to Back First Exhibition By Her Artists
description: PARIS, Sept. 28The first exhibition of any painter or sculptor working in this country is eligible for a Gov ernment subsidy equivalent to half the show's cost, under a new project of the French Ministry of Culture.

title: Modest Advance on Ulster
description: The summit meeting on Northern Ireland achieved everything that could have been hoped for it at this critical stage. There was no breakup, no walkout and, so far, no recrimination or public posturing for narrow political purposes. The three Prime Ministers joined in condemning violence and in promising to try to end both violence and internment without delay. They agreed that their discussions had served a useful purpose and that additional meetings might be helpful.

title: Title Bout Set for Oct. 25
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (FP)  The world bantamweight champion ship fight between Ruben Olivares of Mexico and the challenger, Kazuyoshi Kana zawa of Japan, to be held in Nagoya, was rescheduled today for Oct. 25.

title: 6 Arrested as Disturbances Go On in Springfield, Mass.
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 28 (UPI)Roving bands of youths created disturbances to day in the downtown section in the city's sixth day of racial unrest.

title: STANS DENOUNCES ECONOMIC CRITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Secretary of Commerce Mau rice H. Stans assailed critics of President Nixon's economic policies today, accusing them of making inaccurate state ments about the program and of bringing it into the political arena.

title: ENRIQUE SANTOS, 85, BOGOTA JOURNALIST
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 28 (UPI)Enrique Santos Monte jo, a political columnist for the newspaper El Tiempo here for almost half a century, died to day after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Guards to Get Riot Gear
description: ALBANY, Sept. 28  The state has agreed to equip all guards in state prisons with riot helmets that have face shields, and with gas masks, an official of the uniformed) guards' union said today. At present, the union maintains, only 5 per cent of the guards have such riotcontrol equip ment, and some of the gas masks are said to date back to World War I.

title: Bank Women Name Officers
description: The Metropolitan New York Group of the National Associa tion of Bank Women has elected these 197172 officers: chair man, Miss C. Helen Lovell, as sistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany; vice chairman, Miss Irene de Rienzo, assistant secretary of the Manufacturers Trust Company; secretary, Mrs. Helen M. Korsen, second vice presi dent of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and treasurer, Miss Mary E. Grace, assistant cashier of the Royal National Bank of New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Adamant Churchman Jozsef Mindszenty
description: Man In the News

title: Price of Gold Rises On London Market
description: LONDON, Sept. 28 (Reuters) The London free market price of gold suddenly shot up today to its highest point since the days immediately after Presi dent Nixon's Aug. 15 move sus pending the convertibility of the dollar into gold.

title: CONNOR OPPOSES S.I. CITY IN CITY
description: Borough President Robert T. Connor of Staten Island, in surprise and unexpected move at a sixhour public hearing that ended after 1 A.M. yester day, criticized as a monstros ity a proposed plan for a $6.5 billion South Richmond Devel opment Senator John J. Marchi, Corporation.

title: Rabbis Ask Moral Inventory
description: As Jews observed Yom Kip pur, the Day of Atonement, vith allday fasting and prayers, rabbis pleaded in sermons for a daily taking of spiritual and moral inventory to improve the lives of others.

title: TENNESSEE MOVES ON BOND SALESMEN
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 28 (AP) State officials moved today to crack down on unethical sales of municipal bonds by what they described as a few bond dealers in the city of Memphis and conceivably elsewhere in the state of Tennessee.

title: City Loan Borrowers Accused Over Wage Scale
description: Borrowers from the Munici pal Loan Program, already ac cused of pocketing profits from inflated mortgages and pay ments for rehabilitation work that was not done, were charged yesterday with pock eting money that should have been paid to black and Puerto Rican workers.

title: MOSBACHER GAINS SOLING SAIL LEAD
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 28 Bob Mosbacher of Houston, the North American champion, (moved into the series lead of the world Soling Class cham pionship today after finishing second in the third race on Long Island Sound.

title: Avco Corporation Shows Rise In Quarter and 9Month Profit
description: Improved earnings were re ported yesterday by the Avco Corporation for the quarter and ninemonth period ended Aug. 31.

title: Con Ed to Offer Stock
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany said yesterday that it planned to make a public offer ing of 4 million additional shares of common stock in mid November.

title: Dollar Devaluation
description: Economic Analysis

title: City College Harriers Top Columbia for First Victory
description: Ming Louie sprinted past Dwayne Dahl in the final 100 yards to take third place and give City College a one, two, three sweep and a 2930 cross country victory over Columbia yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: Soviet Jews Take Petition To Party's Headquarters
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP) Nearly 100 Soviet Jews carried a petition to Communist party headquarters today requesting a meeting with a member of the Politburo to discuss their attempts to emigrate to Israel, Jewish sources reported.

title: Foes of Family Assistance Plan Study Move to Isolate Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Opponents of President Nixon's Family Assistance Plan are threatening to undercut its al ready limited prospects by stripping most of the politically attractive elements out of the omnibus welfare bill that the House passed last June.

title: Potter Instrument Settles Patent Dispute With I.B.M.
description: MELVILLE, L. I., Sept. 28 (AP)The Potter Instrument Company said today it had re solved a patent dispute with the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Shadow Brook Is Victor In $3,480 Steeplechase
description: A claim of foul, a brief ex hibition of unscheduled Wild West riding and a 2length victory by Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s 7to10 Shadow Brook pro vided the highlights of yester day's 63d running of the $33, 480 Brook Steeplechase Handi cap at Belmont Park.

title: Hope for Passenger Rails
description: The Department of Transportation, after five years study, has come to a conclusion that seemed inescapable from the start: highspeed trains are the only sensible answer to the traffic problem in such highly traveled areas as the Northeast Corridor linking Boston, New York and Washington.

title: SATO'S BROTHER WILL VISIT NIXON
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28Japanese officials said today that for mer Premier Nobusuke Kishi would confer with President Nixon in Washington early next month in an effort to re solve some of the current po litical and economic issues be tween Japan and the United States.

title: L. W. FROHLICH; LED AD AGENCY
description: L. W. Frohlich, founder and chairman of the advertising agency bearing his name, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived in the East Six ties.

title: STOCKS REGISTER TOKEN ADVANCE
description: The stock market won token victory yesterday as prices advanced for the first time in seven sessions.

title: Copeland Refrigeration Asks Approval for Stock Split
description: SIDNEY, Ohio, Sept. 28 (Reu ters)The Copeland Refrigera tion Corporation said today its directors had proposed a two forone stock split.

title: Kheel Unalterably Opposed to TransitBond Plan
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the at torney and labor mediator, an nounced Ms unalterable oppo sition to Governor Rockefel ler's transportation bond issue yesterday amid signs that lines were beginning to sharpen for the expected battle over the $2.5billion proposal.

title: Notes on People
description: A fortnight before he was scheduled to go on trial in California in connection with the killing of a policeman, Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, showed up at the border in Hong Kong and entered Communist China.

title: AMEX STOCKS GAIN AS VOLUME RISES
description: The American Stock Ex change managed to post its frst advance in seven sessions yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Lady Fleming Gets 16Month Sentence
description: ATHENS, Sept. 25A mili tary court today sentenced Lady Fleming, the Greekborn widow of the discoverer of penicillin, to 16 months in prison for her part in an un successful plot to help a would be assassin escape from prison.

title: Hirohito Sees the Sights On First Day in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 28  Emperor Hirohito, of Japan took the tourist route around Denmark today on the first full day of his sevennation European tour.

title: Buckley Is Called Too Soft on Red China
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 28 Senator James L. Buckley, Con servativeRepublican of New York, sought today to lead a solidarity move among Congres sional conservatives in support of the Administration's China policy in the United Nations, only to have two of his con servative colleagues criticize him for being too soft on Communist China.

title: Massachusetts Prisoners Press 2 Work Strikes
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Sept. 28 The twodayold work strikes by prisoners at two state insti tutions near here showed no signs of ending today. Correc tion officials and prisoners' committees, continued to nego tiate over the prisoners' de mands.

title: Sick Crank Calls Harass Widows of Attica Guards
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 28 Attica townspeople reported today that widows and other relatives of guards held hos tage during the prison revolt here were being harassed by anonymous phone callers and unidentified youths who had thrown stones at their houses.

title: Padres Are Beaten
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 28 To the accompaniment of Count Basie and his 22piece orchestra, the San Francisco Giants won their half of the Western Sweep stakes tonight with a ringing 71 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Unfinished Nassau Coliseum Looks Good to Frazier
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 28  Joe Frazier, the world heavyweight champion, stepped deftly lest the debris of the Nassau Coliseum, now under construction, soil his black doublebreasted Italian wool knit suit and red and pink embossed floral shirt with paisley tie, and gave his decision.

title: Student, 19, in Council Race
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 28 (AP)David Aron, a 19year old philosophy student at the University of Maine here, an nounced his candidacy today for an atlarge seat on Port land's city council.

title: Pennsylvania Will Hire Women State Troopers
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 28 (UPI)State Police Com missioner Rocco P. Urella an nounced today that women were now eligible to become troopers.

title: Dunne Denied Permission To Talk to Attica Inmates
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 28 State Senator John R. Dunne, chairman of the Senate Com mittee on Crime and Correc tion, walked through the cell blocks of the Attica Correc tional Facility today, but State Correction Commissioner Rus sell G. Oswald barred him from talking with inmates.

title: 5,000 to 6,000 Substitute City Teachers To Miss First Payday in Unusual Action
description: All 5,000 to 6,000 substitute teachers in the city will not get their salary checks Friday, the first payday of the new school year, because of payroll processing problems and steps taken to prevent excessive hir ing and overspending by local school districts.

title: DR. E. R. STABLER, 65, TAUGHT AT HOFSTRA
description: BARRINGTON, N.H., Sept. 28 Dr. E. Russell Stabler, who taught mathematics at Hofstra University from 1942 until his retirement here in 1968, died Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: William H. Jackson Dead at 70; Former C.I.A. Deputy Director
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 28 William H. Jackson, former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died today after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: The Missing Model
description: Before introducing a new product, businesses test its acceptance by the public in several cities and towns. Repeated efforts have been made to apply this ele mentary, concept of market research to new Federal programs, but political courage and administrative firmness usually fail before the test can be carried out properly.

title: Census Study Shows Cities' Expenditures Rising Faster Than Revenues
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 28 Census figures released today substantiate the complaint of Mayors across the country that city expenses have been rising faster than revenues.

title: Carlton Notches No. 20 As Cards Beat Mets, 52
description: Everybody seemed to be try ing to help. Steve Carlton of the Cardinals gain his 20th vic tory of the season yesterday, even the New York Mets, who eventually lost, 52, to the St. Louis lefthander before 3,338 fans, the smallest crowd in Shea Stadium this season.

title: Nixon Presses Interior Agency To Reform Policies on Indians
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Pressed by President Nixon, Department of the Interior offi cials are moving to make ma jor policy changes in the Bu reau of Indian Affairs.

title: Suffolk to Study Ability To Sustain Population
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept 28 The County Legislature to day commissioned a study of the ability of Suffolk Coun ty's resources to sustain its population  a study that could lead to limitations on the future population of the county.

title: Bronfmans Cancel Offer to Sell Stock Of Rheingold Corp.
description: The Bronfman family, whose members head the Seagram whisky interests, has changed its mind about selling most of its stock in the Rheingold Cor poration, the large brewing Icompany.

title: Unless a President is certifiably a traitor or an idiot, we have to assume he knows what he is doing
description: WASHINGTONAfter being around the White House for a while in connection with a hook, I have news for the pouting panjandrums of the Righteous Right: their erstwhile hero. Richard Nixon, whom they have now abandoned with some fanfare, is still a perfectly decent and wellmeaning man who deserves the same tolerance and the same chance as anybody else in trying, to solve the problems of this complex and uneasy land.

title: MONROE POLO TEAM ROUTS OX RIDGE, 3217
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 28 The Monroe Pitchforks, ahead by four goals after four chuk kers, defeated the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, 3217, today in freewheeling firstround game of the Northeast Circuit Gov ernor's Cup five  goal polo championship.

title: Ban on Violence and Ads In TV for Children Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Senator Vance Hartke, Demo crat of Indiana, said today that commercial advertising and vio lence should be eliminated from children's television programing.

title: RALPH V. WHITENER
