description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)  Ralph V. Whitener, former executive director of the Na tional Aeronautic Association, died Saturday at his home in Annandale, Va. He was 52 years old.

title: Some Cloud Dispersal Indicated In Second Seeding of Hurricane
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Sept. 28Satellite photographs of Hurricane Ginger, which may set a record as the longest lasting Atlantic storm, indicat ed today some dispersal of the storm's highenergy clouds aft er the second silveriodide seed ing operations by scientists.

title: Study Finds Rackets Bleed BedfordStuyvesant
description: At least 10 per cent of the Income of residents of the Bed fordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn$58 million annually goes to organized crime, ac cording to a study disclosed at a hearing yesterday before the State Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MAGICIAN. By Sol Stein. 258 pages. Dela corte. $6.95.

title: Dodgers Win, 21
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28  Held hitless for five innings, the Los Angeles Dodgers ral lied to defeat the Houston As tros, 21, tonight and stay on the heels of San Francisco in the National League's wild Western Division race.

title: Castro Warns the U.S. Not to Promote Escapes
description: MIAMI, Sept. 28Premier Fidel Castro, speaking about the end of the Cuban refugee airlift, tonight warned the United States not to encour age escapes by boats from Cuba.

title: U.S. Steel Officer Retires
description: The United States Steel Cor poration announced yesterday that Ralph C. Moffitt, president of the Universal Atlas Cement Division, would retire effective Jan. 31, 1972. Mr. Moffitt, who is retiring for reasons of health, will become special assistant to the executive vice president of production in October of this year to effect an orderly tran sition in the Universal Atlas operations.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES POST A SLIGHT GAIN
description: Soybean futures closed frac tionally higher and wheat fu tures declined on the Chicago Board of Trade yestetday.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Cities Service Company announced yes terday the election of Charles 3. Waidelich as president, succeeding J. Edgar Heston, who has requested early retire ment as president and a director for reasons of health, effective Oct. 1. The diversified oil, netu ral gas and chemicals company also elected Robert V. Sellers to the new position of vice chairman. Mr. Waidelich, 42 years old, has been executive vice president operations, a director and member of the executive committee since 1970. Mr. Sellers, 44 old, has been vice presidentfinance, a director and member of the executive committee since 1969. Charles S. Mitchell, chairman and chief executive officer, who made the announcement, said Mr. Heston is suffering from a circulatory ailment and his request for early retirement effective Oct. was accepted by the board of directors with sin cere regret. He has made significant contributions to the growth of Cities Service. He joined the corn pany in 1930, was president for the last four years, and served as a director since 1961.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: In Memoriam

title: Longchamps to Sell Luchow's And 4 Others for $8Million
description: Merger News

title: OSWALD SEEKING FACILITY TO HOUSE HOSTILE CONVICTS
description: ALBANY, Sept. 28Russell G. Oswald, State Commissioned, of Correction, said today that his department was seeking a facility to house as many as 500 of the system's most ag gressive inmates, so they could be isolated from the rest of the state's 16,000 prisoners.

title: Airline Crash Kills 32 In the Amazon Jangle
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 28 (AP)  A Brazilian airliner crashed in the Amazon jungle today killing all 28 passengers and 4 crewmen aboard, of ficials reported.

title: Film: Satiric Documentary on Nixon:De Antonio's 'Millhouse' Is at the New Yorker
description: The easiest way to describe Emile de Antonio's "Millhouse" is as a satiric documentary, but that's a bland, weasel-like definition for the exuberantly opinionated film form that de Antonio first used in "Point of Order" and then pursued, with somewhat less dramatic results, in "Rush to Judgment" and "In the Year of the Pig."De Antonio has no special interest in balanced reportage, which is as antithetical to his concerns as it is to those of superior fiction, and "Millhouse," a study of the political career of Richard Milhous Nixon (as well as of his career's various lives and times), is superior fiction, as implacable as "An American Tragedy," as mysterious as "You Can't Go Home Again," as funny as "Why Are We in Viet Nam?" and as banal as "Main Street."By this I don't mean to say that it's not true, but rather that it shares with fiction the kind of truth that is greater than the sum of its factual parts. In this case, those parts are mostly newsreel footage, television kinescopes and some out-takes from political spots that Mr. Nixon made as a Presidential candidate in 1968.There also are interviews with such professional Nixon watchers as James A. Wechsler, Joe McGuinniss ("The Selling of the President") and Jules Witcover ("The Resurrection of Richard Nixon"), and with old opponents and former friends. When Mrs. Marjorie Hildreth Knighton, who dated Mr. Nixon at Whittier College, reports cheerfully that she can't think of any Nixon anecdotes, the effect is Transylvanian, as if the man had passed in front of the mirror and not created a reflection.The only ambiguity in de Antonio's new work is the second "l" and the "e" he has injected into the title, which, if it is supposed to be a pun, leaves me mystified."Millhouse" is otherwise a Dos Passos-like collage of the American scene as represented by the man who, in de Antonio's portrait, seems always to win when he loses and lose when he wins, whose speeches are as barren as the California desert, whose rhetoric consists mainly in answering questions no one has asked (and avoiding those that someone might ask), and who can't even tell a funny story, or a reminiscence, without somehow sandbagging himself into exposing a lot more of his fantasy life than any man need decently do.The film concludes with the jolly gaffe, made at the Inauguration Ball, when the new President recalled having saved his money so that he and his wife could celebrate V-J Day with Guy Lombardo at the Roosevelt Hotel and hoped that the orchestra leader would be around to play at the end of the next war."Millhouse" is anything but subtle, which is not De Antonio's style, and some of the ironic juxtapositions of sounds to images are less than inspired (such as the "Chiquita Banana" jingle that is lapped over shots of Mr. Nixon's South American tour).Others, however, are brilliant and, in Norman Mailer's phrase, very spooky. I think especially of Mr. Nixon's campaign oration that actually parodies the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, with which it is intercut on the soundtrack, as well as the magical moment when Mr. Nixon accepts the 1968 nomination saying, "Let's win this one for Ike." The movie cuts to the Gipper scene from "Knute Rockne" (Win this one for the Gipper"), and then to the Gipper himself, who turns out to be the present Governor of California at what looks to be the age of 13.De Antonio is obviously both astonished and outraged by what he sees in the Nixon career, but no more by what he sees as the conscious deception of others during the campaigns than by the self-deception that allows Mr. Nixon to call himself an egghead and to express the wish to teach at some place like Oxford and write two or three books a year.In one key area, in expressing horror at Mr. Nixon's tremendous ambition, de Antonio is being a little naive. Ambition in itself is no more immoral or moral than the drive to eat, and can be judged only by the channels through which it is directed. I would agree, however, with what I feel to be one of the filmmaker's most important points: that we have notsadlyreached that point of social perfection when we can enjoy, as an especially fascinating display, the exercise of power for its own sake."Millhouse," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, is a fascinating 'work, but not quite "the white comedy" in the Marx Brothers tradition that its producer claims. Also on the bill, however, is something that really is funny, "Thank You, Mask Man," the hilarious cartoon version of the late Lenny Bruce just-so story on how and why the Lone Ranger formed his attachment to Tonto. Bruce does the various voices, and they are all great.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Long before he became a baseball broadcaster, Ralph Kiner learned the value of conversation. He learned it on the receiving end, however, and that is a gross violation all space cadet principles. The primary rule of the trade, would seem, is that the airwaves must be kept filled with words.

title: Reforming The Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Without anyone noticing, this country has moved remarkably close to choosing one of its Presidential candidates by a national primary.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Latest Ruling on Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Following is Policy Statement Number 26 issued by the Pres ident's Cost of Living Council on the latest ruling relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Jury on Coast Votes to Indict 2 Suspected of Slaying Here
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 The San Francisco County grand jury has decided to in dict on a local charge two men who are upder suspicion for possible involvement in the slaying of two New York policemen.

title: FARRAR, STRAUS GETS HILL & WANG
description: Hill & Wang, for more than a decade a specialized publisher in American history and drama books, has been acquired by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, a lead ing literary house.

title: SOVIETINDIA PLEA MADE TO PAKISTAN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India today urged that President Agha Mohammoud Yahya Khan of Pakistan permit the return to East Pakistan of several mil lion refugees who have fled to India.

title: Retiring Bond Analyst Is Still an Optimist
description: Sidney Homer, in his vale dictory talk as a general partner at Salomon Brothers, told an overflow audience at the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday afternoon that shortterm in terest rates would rise and longterm rates would fall if President Nixon's new eco nomic policies succeed. Mr. Homer, who began studying the bond market 48 years ago, will retire Friday.

title: Texas Sheriff Slain
description: BOERNE, Tex., Sept. 28 (UPI)  Kendall County's sheriff. Douglas Kuebel. 61 years old. was shot four times and killed today while answering a dis turbance call. A suspect was arrested 17 miles away.

title: Lions' 20Year Famine Concerns Tigers' Coach
description: Ivy League Roundup

title: Washington Group Talks To Padres About Moving
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 28 (AP) C. Arnholt Smith, the prin cipal owner of the Padres, says he wants to keep the National League club in San Diego, even if he is discouraged by the amount of money the team is losing.

title: RCA Weighs Company Bids
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that preliminary dis cussions were under way with several companies that have approached RCA concerning the disposition of its generalpur pose computer business. A spokesman for RCA confirmed that the Control Data Corpora tion was one of the companies with which preliminary discus sions had been held.

title: Member of the Wedding to Bow as Musical
description: Circle in the Square, whose past revivals have breathed new life into allbut forgotten works, will present this sea son a new musical version of Carson McCullers's 1950 prizewinning comedydrama, The Member of the Wed ding.

title: Two Are Sentenced Here In Killing of a Patrolman
description: Two men were sentenced in State Supreme Court in Brook lyn yesterday on charges stem ming from the slaying of an offduty patrolman. During their trial here last summer, they changed their pleas to guilty.

title: A Senate Study Estimates Aid For Next 5 Years at $51Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff estimated to day that the United States would provide about $51billion in foreign assistance over the next five years, with the possi bility that the total would go higher.

title: Endangered Green
description: The owner of 3,200 acres of mountain wilderness northern New Jersey wants to give it to the state for a nature center and wildlife preserve, asking only the $1.5 million he owes in mortgage payments and back taxes. The state very much wants the landand not merely because it has been appraised at four times that amount. It happens to occupy a pivotal spot in that magnificent greenbelt running from New York State south to the Blue Ridge Mountains, which planners and conserva tionists hope to preserve for the relief of the megalopolis.

title: Touch of Paris Comes to New York
description: Shop Talk

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Louisiana Negroes Seek Power
description: TALLULAH, La., Sept. 27 Talking around an ever present cigar, Police Chief Zelma Wyche thumbed through the posted notices at the Madison Parish Court house that showed black candidates competing for 22 of 27 elective parish offices this fall.

title: Bus Safety Rules Drawn
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) Douglas W. Toms, the Federal Highway Administrator, an nounced today that new rules were being completed under the Vehicle Safety Act to improve bus safety by requiring strong er seats and more padding in areas near passengers. Mr. Toms spoke before the House Commerce Subcommittee on Roads.

title: GROWN ASSERTS U.S.CHINESE THAW IS NATURAL STEP
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28Foreign Minister An drei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that his Gov ernment in principle regard ed the improvement of rela tions between Washington and Peking as a natural develop ment.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: Disturbance in Kansas
description: LANSING, Kan., Sept. 28 (AP) Cooks returned to the kitch en at the Kansas State Peni tentiary here today but some inmates refused to eat.

title: Mindszenty Leaves Hungary, Goes to Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 28Jozsef Car dinal Mindszenty, accepting at last the exile from Hungary that he said was perhaps the heaviest cross of my life, ar rived here today from Budapest, never to return.

title: President, at Capital Meeting Reassures Families of P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 28 (UPI) President Nixon told families of American prisoners of war today that the United States would eventually succeed in winning their release.

title: A Right Smart Race in Stupidville
description: STUPIDVILLE,. Tenn., Sept. 28 (AP)Sam Briggs's son, Larry, says his father is not qualified to be Mayor of Stupidville. On technical grounds, that is.

title: DRAFT ACT SIGNED, PAY RISE FROZEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Nixon signed into law today a bill extending the draft for two years but froze until after Nov. 13 a $2.4 billion military pay increase in cluded in the measure.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WESPORT, Conn., Sept. 28 Sill Whitehead scored from 10 feet in front of the goal as darkness was settling on the field today to give the Fairfield County Hunt Club a 65 sud dendeath overtime victory over Yale in a firstround game of the Governor's Cup cham pionship.

title: M'CRACKEN SEES DOLLAR AS VICTIM
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28  Paul W. McCracken, the chair man of President Nixon's Coun cil of Economic Advisers, said here today that basic problems in the structure of international finance had played a major role in creating the world mone tary crisis.

title: Yahya Khan Speaks
description: These are excerpts from an interview in Le Figaro with General Yahya Khan, President of Pakistan. Pierre Bois is the correspondent.

title: PAKISTAN CAUTIONS PRESS ON MUJIB FATE
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 28The Government of Pakis tan said today that the secret military trial of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Bengali leader, was continuing, and warned against public speculation about its outcome.

title: 2 of 3 Plead Not Guilty In Slaying of Yablonskis
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP)Two persons charged with the murders of Joseph A. Yablonski, United Mine Work ers insurgent leader, and his wife and daughter in Decem ber, 1969, pleaded not guilty today. But the judge refused to accept a plea from a third; a woman.

title: Advertising:
description: Frustrated consumers of America, at last you have a place to turn if you feel you've been duped by an un truthful (lying) or misleading (lying) ad.

title: Alabama Ending Fiscal Year With No Funds Appropriated
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 29  An impasse between Gov. George C. Wallace and the State Legislature has created a financial crisis that could halt government operations.

title: Habib Confirmed as Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Senate today confirmed President Nixon's nomination of Philip C. Habib, a career diplo mat and former deputy repre sentative at the Paris peace talks, as ambassador to South Korea. He succeeds William C. Porter, now chief representative at the talks. Others who were confirmed were Nathaniel Da viss, Ambassador to Chile; Henry E. Catto Jr., Ambassador to El Salvator; William G. Row dier, Ambassador to Guatemala, and John E. Reinhardt, Ambas sador to Nigeria.

title: Personal Finance: NoFault Policy
description: Two cars collide at a busy intersection. A man in one automobile loses an eye. A child in the other is para lyzed for life.

title: 2 Candidates on West Side Sue to Force New Election
description: Two Democratic candidates for district leadership who were narrowly defeated in the Sept. 14 primaries sued in State Supreme Court yester day to force a new district election.

title: U.N. Missions to Guinea And Senegal Deliver Reports
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29The Security Coun cil today received reports from missions appointed to investi gate charges by Guinea and Senegal of hostile activities by Portugal in West Africa.

title: KIDNAPPERS RELEASE OFFICIAL IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) Julio Hirschfield Almada, Mexico's Director of Aviation, was released apparently un harmed by his kidnappers to night after payment of $240, 000 ransom.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report of changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Arthur Peck, Lawyer Here Who Aided Youth Training
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 29 Arthur J. Peck, who had practiced law in New York City since 1908, died Tuesday in Mountainside Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 180 Walnut Street.

title: Oswald Meets With Guards To Discuss Penal Reform
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29State Correction Commissioner Rus sell G. Oswald met for two and onehalf hours today with lead ers of the state's prison guard union, which is seeking a sevenpoint penal reform pro gram.

title: Bronx Pastor Seized in Prostitution Case
description: Two juvenile counselors at a city Probation Office facility in the Bronxone identified also as a Baptist minister and the other as his church secretary were arrested yesterday and accused of trying to solicit women to engage in prostitu tion.

title: Xerox Plans Training Unit
description: The Xerox Corporation an pounced yesterday the filing at Leesburg, Va., of an application for a landuse permit that would allow the company to build a training facility for em ployes on the south bank of the Potomac River. The cost of the project, which is expect ed to be completed over a sevenyear period, could be as much as $30million, the com pany said. Groundbreaking is scheduled for early November and the initial phase is expect ed to be completed by January, 1973.

title: Port Agency Gets Ad Award
description: PORTLAND, Maine, Sept. 29 (AP)The Delaware River Port Authority received today the top award in the annual adver tising competition of the Ameri can Association of Port Author ities, which is meeting here. The award is a brass speaking tube from the Antarctic explo ration ship Bear of Oakland.

title: Barra Guard Top Lineman
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Sept. 29 (AP)  John Hannah of Ala bama, a 6foot3inch, 274 pound offensive guard who knocked his man out of the action six times in last Satur day's 380 rout of Florida by Alabama, was named today as college lineman of the week.

title: City's Civil Court Cuts Its Backlog of Cases 66%
description: The backlog of cases in the Civil Court of the City of New York was cut by twothirds during the fiscal year ended June 30, the Judicial Confer ence of the State announced yesterday.

title: Mugging Victim Dies
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 29 Patsy Colicchio, 72 years old, 554 Riverside Drive, died last night in the Alexian Brothers Hospital of injuries suffered Saturday when he was mugged and robbed on Lafayette Street here. He operated the Cascade Music Corporation here for many years before retiring seven years ago.

title: UsedTool Sales Decline
description: The Machinery Dealers Na tional Association reported yesterday that August sales of used machine tools fell 10.3 per cent from the July level and 19.4 per cent from a year earlier. John Curd, chairman of the Triangle Machine Tool Cor poration, said the business dropped sharply after Presi dent Nixon's Aug. 15 economic message, because buyers are uncertain whether the proposed investment tax credit will apply to used machines.

title: Program Like Foreign Aid Urged for Black Business
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29  The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, director of Operation Breadbasket, to day urged government and in dustry to assure the economic gronth and development of black American communities by instituting the same kind of massive assistance programs that helped to strengthen the economies of Japan, Germany and Israel.

title: Burden Supports Plan for Beaumont
description: Carter Burden, a member of the City Council, which has the power to approve or reject the plan for the take over and reconstruction of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center by the City Center, yesterday announced that he was very much in favor of the plan. He said that the opponents are tilt ing at windmills.

title: Massachusetts Prisoner Strikes Go On Despite Concession on Mail Censorship
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Sept. 29 A surprise decision by state officials to end all censorship of prison mail failed to bring the immediate end of prison strikes here, and a third night of uneasiness settled over two prisons in rebellion.

title: Slight Rise in Steel Use Seen
description: GENEVA, Sept. 29 (UPI) The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe pre dieted today only a slight in crease in steel consumption this year.

title: FourRun First Starts Rout for Astros
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29I Somebody up there must 1ovei the Dodgers. Los Angeles was pummeled, 110, by Houston to night but still stayed in the Na tional League West race  thanks to San Diego.

title: Bhutto Assails Rule By Pakistani Army, Asks End to Terror
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 29 Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, leader of West Pakistan's majority party, today denounced military rule in the harshest terms he has used to date.

title: U.S. Prosecutors Hiring Own Investigators to Ferret Out Crime
description: Federal prosecutors across the country, moving into new kinds of law enforcement, are relying increasingly on their own investigators and research em and reducing their depend ence on such agencies as the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion.

title: MRS. WALTER ELICKER
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Sept. 29 Mrs. Edna Smith Elicker, wife of Walter G. Elicker, retired secretary of the Texas Com pany, died today in Overlook Hospital, Summit. She was 80 years old and lived at 235 Munsee Way.

title: Roy W. Moore Sr. Dead at 80; Former Canada Dry Chairman
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Sept. 29 Roy W. Moore Sr., who re tired in 1967 as chairman of the Canada Dry Corporation, died today in Bridgeport Hos pital. He was 80 years old and lived at 24 Old South Road.

title: Exemptions on Freeze Allowed for Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)The Cost of Living Council allowed today what it said were the first exemp tions to the wageprice freeze by permitting new Govern mentfunded group insurance benefit programs to go into effect in Florida, Texas and Missouri.

title: Argentine Exploration Set
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 (UPI)  The military govern ment of Argentina announced the signing of a contract today with a Canadian company for the exploration for copper and other mineral resources in one of the country's southern provinces.

title: First Aid to the Voter
description: Starting today, New Yorkers who have not yet regis tered have three days left in which to assure themselves the privilege not only of voting in November of this off year but of having a say in next year's Presidential primaries.

title: Luna 19 Continues Flight
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (UPI) The Soviet Union's unmanned Luna 19 headed toward the moon today but the Soviet Union indicated that the craft would not attempt a landing.

title: Braves Rehire Harris After Clinching Third
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP) Luman Harris, who piloted the Atlanta Braves to a third place divisional finish despite the loss of two star hitters  Rico Carty and Orlando Cepedaand a controversial third basemanClete Boyer signed a oneyear contract today to manage the team again in 1972.

title: Thieves Could Feel No Pain
description: Three hijackers commandeered a truck in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday and made off with the cargo of 462 cases of Anacin worth more than $65,000, the police said. The police said Wilbur Rudolph, 53 years old, of Franklin Park, N. J., the driver, had made a delivery at 4701 Van Dam Street shortly after 10 A.M. When he returned to the truck, a gunman was waiting in the cab, the police said. Mr. Rudolph, forced to enter a pri vate car, was driven around for about an hour and a half and then released unharmed at Flatbush Avenue and Avenue N in Brooklyn.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: JERSEYAN IS SLAIN IN MIDTOWN AREA
description: The former commandant of a boys military academy in Mount Freedom, N.J., was found shot to death last night in the fourthfloor hallway of a build ing at 918 Eighth Avenue be tween 54th and 55th Streets, the police reported.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Mercer, and Bphron Team Up To Produce Broadway Plays
description: Johnny Mercer, the songs writer who has won four Acad emy Awards, and Henry Ephron, the stageandfilm writer, are turning Broadway producers.

title: DART. H. HUNT
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 29 Darl H. Hunt, a past presi dent of the New York Associa tion of Consulting Engineers, died yesterday of a massive heart attack while playing golf at the Scarsdale Golf Club, of which he was also a past presi dent. He was 78 years old and lived in the Stoneleigh Apart ments here.

title: Soviet Pressure on Britons Reported
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29The So viet authorities were reported by British officials today to have stepped up pressures on British diplomats here through more ostentatious surveillance of their movements as well as an expanded press campaign against their Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People
description: Calling him one of the truly great diplomats of the world, President Nixon presented the Medal of Free dom to Manilo Brosio, out going Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Electric Cord is Recalled By I.T.T.'s Royal Division
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Royal Electric division an nounced yesterday at Paw tucket, R. I., that it was recall ing some rubberjacketed, black electric cord that was manufac tured between April 1, 1970, and Sept. 1, 1971.

title: Mrs. Lennon Loses Case
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters) A civil court judge today awarded the British film direc tor Anthony Cox temporary custody of Kyoko, his eight yearold daughter. His former wife, Yoko Ono, is married to John Lennon, formerly of the Beatles Mrs. Lennon was awarded visiting rights.

title: PROXMIRE DOUBTS PRESSURE ON NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  Senator William Prox mire, Democrat of Wisconsin, today rejected a Navy offi cial's allegation that four pow erful Louisiana Democrats in Congress used undue political influence in an attempt to force a favorable claim settle ment for a company in their state.

title: Panarctic Oils Tests Well
description: Panarctic Oils announced yesterday in Calgary, Alberta, Canada, that a stepout well on King Christian Island tested gas at a rate of 165 million feet a day. The well was tested at an open flow rate but not an absolute open flow rate, the company said.

title: Dawn of a New Monetary System
description: The current meeting of the International Monetary. Fund in Washington is likely to go down in history as the turning point toward creation of a new world mone tary system. Scime of the industrial nationsbut not yet the United Stateshave called for a system that would be based neither on the dollar nor on gold but on a new international money, similar to the already existing Special Drawing Rights.

title: Mindszenty Said to Pledge Silence About His Case
description: ROME, Sept. 29The agree ment between the Vatican and the Communist Government of Hungary under which Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty left asy lum and journeyed to Rome yes terday included a pledge that the Cardinal would not speak in public about his case or about Hungarian political af fairs, sources here said today.

title: Met Revives Freischutz, 1821 Masterpiece
description: Carl Maria von Weber fin ished Der Freischtz in 1821, and four years later it was presented in New York. That gives an idea of the popularity of the opera, which was one of the corner stones of the 19thcentury repertory.

title: Langdon Cites Penn Central Service Gains
description: From an operating stand point things are looking pretty good these days on the Penn Central, according to Jervis Langdon Jr., one of the bank rupt carrier's four trustees.

title: 1,200 Colleagues at Rites for Housing Patrolman
description: Mayor Lindsay, Simeon Golar, chairman of the Hous ing Authority, and other housing officials as well as about 1,200 patrolmen from the Housing Authority police, the city police and depart ments outside the city at tended funeral services yes terday for Housing Patrol man Arthur Pelo.

title: Amex Stocks Divided at Finish in Slow Trading
description: Advances and declines were evenly divided on the Ameri can Stock Exchange yesterday as the trading pace dropped sharply on the Jewish religious holiday of Yom Kippur.

title: PROS SEEK TO STOP ARTIFICIAL TURF
description: In a dual request, the Na tional Football League Players Association demanded yester day that the owners halt plans for future installation of, arti ficial turf in their stadiums pending a study of incidence of injuries and that the Denver and Washington clubs cancel plans to televise home grimes by closed circuit into nearby auditoriums.

title: Reagan Says Productivity Is Key in Inflation Fight
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 (AP)  Gov. Ronald Reagan of California challenged organ ized labor today to work harder and increase its productivity to help the United States turn back inflation and its problems in foreign trade.

title: Adderley Cited for Defense
description: DALLAS, Sept. 29 (AP)  Herb Adderley, the 32yearold Dallas Cowboy cornerback who intercepted three passes last Sunday in a 427 rout of Phila delphia, was named The As sociated Press National Foot ball League defensive player of the week today.

title: JOHN R. PRESTON
description: ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 29 (UPI) John R. Preston, police chief of South Orange from 1944 to 1950, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital at the age of 86.

title: AGNEW DOUBTFUL ON HOUSING TACTIC
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP) Vice President Agnew said to day that he questions whether putting lowincome housing in middleclass neighborhoods is an effective tool infurthering racial integration.

title: SOUTH KOREAN PLAN ON TALKS REJECTED
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sept. 29The South Korean Red Cross proposed today that fu ture fulldress talks with its North Korean counterpart to settle the problem of divided Korean families be held alter nately in Seoul and Pyongyang, the capitals.

title: William S. Hall, 81, CoFounder Of Baker Street Irregulars, Dies
description: William S. Hall, a cofounder of the Baker Street Irregulars, a club of Sherlock Holmes en thusiasts, died yesterday at Le Roy Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 81 years old and lived at 165 East 35th Street.

title: NERVOUS MARKET ON AIMLESS PAM
description: Stock prices remained on the fence yesterday as abnormally slow trading emphasized the current caution in Wall Street. A number of indi vidual issues, however, reacted to specific corporate develop ments.

title: Spaniards Have Election But Show Little Interest
description: MADRID, Sept. 29Voting was reported light today in the closest thing Spain has to free elections: the designation by direct ballot, every four years, of one fifth of the Cortes, or Parliament.

title: Spirituals, Reflecting New Attitude, Regain Popularity
description: This reawakening of the Negro to the value and beauty of the spirituals was the be ginning of an entirely new phase of race, consciousness. It marked a, change in the attitude of the Negro himself toward his own art material; the turning of his gaze in ward upon his own cul tural resources. Neglect and ashamedness gave place to study and pride. All the other artistic activities of the Ne gro have been influenced. James Weldon Johnson, Book on American Negro Spiritu als, 1925.

title: Pnompenh Restaurant Bombed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, Sept. 30 (Reuters) A bomb exploded in a popu lar Chinese hotelrestaurant in the heart of Pnompenh this morning killing at least one person and wounding 10 others. Several more people were feared trapped and possibly, dead in a room in the three story Thai San Hotel and Restaurant.

title: Fairchild Plans Purchases
description: Fairchild Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday it is begin ning a program of limited pur chases of its 4 per cent con vertible debentures from time to time as markete con ditions permit. The company said the reacquired debentures will be used to meet sinking fund obligations.

title: Virginia Prisoners Locked Up
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 27Most of the 1,123 prisoners at the Virginia State Pentitentiary were locked in their cells to day in what prison officials said was a precaution against the rumored possibility of a demonstration Saturday.

title: House Panel Completes Action on Tax Reduction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House Ways and Means Committee approved in final form today its version of a tax reduction bill aimed at stimu lating a business upturn.

title: Subsidiary of Flying Tiger Forms Rail Leasing Unit
description: The Flying Tiger Corporation has announced that a subsid iary, the North American Car Corporation of Chicago, has formed the NAC Leasing Cor poration, to lease new and re built rolling stock to the rail road industry on a net lease basis.

title: SUPERSCOPE NAMED IN ACTION BY SONY
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan has filed suit in Federal District Court in Los Angeles asking clarification of its rights if Superscope, Inc., the exclu sive distributor of Sony tape recorders in the United States, decides to distribute machines made by other companies.

title: Governor Says Kheel Plays Politics on Bond Issue
description: PAINTED POST, N. Y., Sept. 30Governor Rockefeller to day accused Theodore W. Kheel of playing politics in unequivocally opposing his $2.5billion transportation bond issue and said that other poli ticians were indulging in poli tical posturing in threatening to work for defeat of the issue unless the 30cent New York City transit fare was retained.

title: Canada and Iceland to Vote Against U.S. Plan on China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29The advocates of Peking's admission to the United Nations at the cost of ex pelling Nationalist China picked up additional support today as two more membersCan ada and Iceland  made it clear that they would vote for the Communist Government as China's sole representative.

title: TV REARING ASKED ON TRADE CENTER
description: The Port of New York Au thority has asked the Federal Communication Commission to hold a hearing on whether it will be necesary to move most of the city's television trans mitters from the Empire State Building to the World Trade Center.

title: A Decline in Discipline Cited at Attica
description: ATTICA, N. Y.,  The hard discipline that once ruled the lives of prisoners inside the walls of the Attica Correc tional Facility has been eased markedly in recent years by correction officials, accord ing to Richard W. Miller, a prison guard who is Mayor of the Village of Attica.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS TO CONVENE TODAY
description: ROME, Sept, 29Pope Paul Vi will convene the third Syn od of Bishops here tomorrow for discussions of two of the most difficult issues facing the Roman Catholic Church: the crisis in the priesthood and the role of the church in social change.

title: U.S. HOSPITAL CHIEF OUSTED OVER LETTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The director of the Public Health Service Hospital in Seattle has been relieved of duties there because of his ef forts to prevent the hospital from being transferred out of the service.

title: Penn Central Rescinds Rise For Boston Commuters
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP)The Penn Central Railroad has re sponded to an order by the Office of Emergency Prepared ness and rescinded a 10 per cent fare increase on area com muter trips.

title: WORLD MARK SET BY ENTREPRENEUR
description: LEXINGTON. Ky., Sept. 29 (AP)Entrepreneur broke a 12 yearold world record tonight by pacing a mile in 1:56 to win the Meadow Lands Pace at the Lexington Trots.

title: MORE U S. WARSHIPS DUE IN INDIAN OCEAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Vice Adm. Maurice F. Weis ner, Deputy Chief of Naval Op erations, said today that the United States Seventh Fleet would begin sending more ships into the Indian Ocean in re sponse to a Soviet buildup there.

title: Johnson, Tucker Expect To Be Ready on Sunday
description: After practice in Yankee Sta dium yesterday, Ron Johnson lost his third game of the eight of15game chess series with Bob Tucker, the tight end, but the Giants' top running back still leads, four games to three.

title: Visiting Day at Attica Stirs New Charges of Brutality
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 29 More than 200 visitors streamed through Attica prison's iron gate to spend an hour with in mate relatives today, and many emerged weeping, relaying prisoners' accounts of brutality since the fiveday revolt here was put down.

title: Luci Johnson Nugent: Even Out of Spotlight, She Leads Busy Life
description: AUSTIN, Tex. (AP)I'm a chargehellwithabucket ofwater kind of person, said Luci Johnson Nugent.

title: GROMYKO MEETS WITH PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 President Nixon conferred for two hours today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and said that while some steady progress had been made in the talks on limiting strategic arms he hoped for more forward movement when the discussion resume in Vienna Nov. 15.

title: A Nickel for Rehabilitation
description: WASHINGTONAttica reminds us how quickly America resorts to vio lence and how little we revere life. We created the Big House, knew of the inhumanity there and waited for the recurrence of death and destruc tion that was bound to come. When the crisis arose we accepted, perhaps wanted, official violence to smash the prisoners we hated and feareil.

title: CAPITAL FORMATION GAINS NEW PLEDGES
description: Capital Formation, Inc., a nonprofit organization started to promote minority enterprise, announced yesterday that it had received pledges from a number of major corporations to deposit an additional $30 million in minorityowned banks.

title: Chess: Masters Usually Get Gifts In Simultaneous Exhibitions
description: When a chessmaster gives an exhibition of simultaneous play, the score he makes is, of course, his own doing, but his opponents must share some of the responsibility for the quality of the games. The single player goes from board to board and does whatever is necessary to win each of the games. If a brilliant com bination is necessary, he will, more often than not, make one, but if all he needs to do is take off his opponent's pieces, he will do that, too, and gladly. He would, after all, just as soon save his cre ative energies for important tournament games.

title: Magnesium Glut Worries SovietIndustry Planners
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29  The Soviet Union, in an unusual disclosure, said today that it was developing a glut in mag nesium metal as reduced con sumption by the aircraft in dustry was not being taken up by other users.

title: Soccer Goal Mark Broken
description: NORTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 29 (AP)Pete Chart schlaa broke the National As sociation of Intercollegiate Ath letics record for the most career soccer goals today as Bar rington College defeated South eastern Massachusetts Univer sity, 20. Chartschlaa, a 22 yearold senior from Argentina, scored once to give him a ca reer total of 116.

title: Aides Say Chile's Move Will Spur U.S. to Get Tough
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 United States officials said to day that yesterday's decision by Chile's President in effect to pay nothing to United States copper interests for national ized properties would undoubt edly spur get tough moves in the Nixon Administration.

title: Lockheed Is Accused of Waste and Deceit on C5A
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Clutching a rusted drill bit, a former LockheedGeorgia production control officer told a Joint Congressional Economic Subcommittee to day that the company was guilty of misman agement, waste and deceit in its dealings with the Air Force. Seated next to him at the witness table was the company's executive vice president, who denied the allegation of deceit and mini mized the other charges. At the same hearing Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said he would ask the General Accounting Office to determine who was telling him the truth this morning about the company. The concern is contractor for the Air Force's C5A cargo plane, which Senator Prox mire said had been plagued with more than $2billion in cost overruns. LockheedGeor gia is a division of the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Market Place: Pitfalls Abound For Computers
description: Carl H. Freyer, president of the Computer Investors Group, a marketing and leas ing company, was not sur prised when RCA cashed in its computer chips. And he says: There is more of this kind of thing on the way. They'll be smaller companies, of course, but the die is cast.

title: 26% Advance Is Reported For August Construction
description: Contracts awarded for all kinds of construction work throughout the country in August had a total value of $7,711,530,000, up 26 per cent from $6,141,557,000 a year before, the F. W. Dodge divi sion of the McGrawHill In formation Systems Company re ported yesterday.

title: NEWSMEN GET WRIT ON SEEING PRISONERS
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 29 (AP)A Federal judge ordered state cor rectional officials today to answer charges that they had refused to allow newsmen to interview inmates of the state's prisons.

title: Running Mate Considered
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Governor Wallace sent out questionnaires today that ask the public to name persons they would prefer as his running mate if he runs for President in 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Sentence on Coast
description: POMONA, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI)Mrs. Linda Lee Haines, a young divorced woman con victed of the beating and auto accident death of her lover's wife, was sentenced yesterday to death in the gas chamber. Mrs. Haines, 24 years old, be comes the fifth woman on Cali fornia's Death Row.

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC EXPANDS ARMY JOB
description: Western Electric received yesterday a $486.7million addi tion to an Army contract for hardware and supporting serv ices for production and devel opment of the Safeguard mis sile system. Much of the work will be subcontracted.

title: Dance: A Home Is Found
description: WASHINGTONTo some people, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is an architectural disaster and a monumental bore. To Lucia Chase, a codirector of Amer ican Ballet Theater, it is home.

title: FISCHER FAVORED IN CHESS CONTEST
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 Among the chess aficionados who have gathered here for the tournament beginning to morrow between Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles and Tigran Petrosian of Moscow, the feel ing was that the odds favored the temperamental, 28yearold American.

title: Eastern College Football
description: A bunch of Yellowjackets from upstate New York have a mild winning streak of 10 games going, using simple methods of attack and sting. They are the University of Rochester players, who were thumped by Mount Union, 6130, in the 1970 opening game, then reeled off eight victories last sea son and two this year. Pat Stark, the coach, has turned the team completely around since the Mount Union defeat. In his third year, at Rochester, the former Syra cuse player is doing a good job in basics.

title: ROGERS STEPS UP MIDEAST EFFORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 of State. William P. Rogers put forward some com promise proposals on a possible interim Middle Eastern settle ment today during a twohour working lunch with the Egyp tian Foreign Minister, Mah moud Riad.

title: Maiden Name Barred For a Driver's License
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 29  A threejudge Federal Court ruled here today that a married woman does not have a constitutional right to have her driver's license is sued in her maiden name.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Twins Retire Crosetti
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 29 (UPI)Frank Crosetti, in the major leagues since 1932 as a player or coach, will not re turn as the thirdbase coach of the Minnesota Twins in 1972, the Twins announced today.

title: Dollar Still Fluctuating
description: LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP)The dollar maintained its marginal ly fluctuating pattern on major foreign exchanges today.

title: Merger News
description: The Alaska Interstate Com pany announced yesterday that it had joined with the Apco Oil Corporation, the Gulf Interstate Company and the Tipperary Land and Exploration Corpora tion as an applicant to acquire the assets to be divested by the El Paso Natural Gas Company. The assets are still in proceedings now pending in the United States District Court for the District of Col orado in the anti trust case of the United States versus El Paso Natural Gas and the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation.

title: VISITING FRENCH SEE EAST GERMAN TIES
description: BERLIN, Sept. 29  A high ranking French parliamentary delegation visiting East Berlin has established informal con tacts between France and East Germany with a view to bring ing about normalization of re lations.

title: GOLF LEAGUE SET FOR FIRST SEASON
description: The International Profession al Golf League plans to open its first season in Montreal on Saturday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CREDITORS SET PLAN AT EXECUTIVE HOUSE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) Creditors of the Executive House, Inc., have approved an arrangement filed last month by the company with the Fed eral District Court here.

title: Woman Dies in Queens Fire
description: A 60 yearold widow died in a fire yesterday at 55.06 97th Place, Elmhurst, Queens, and a fireman was burned on the face and hands. Five other residents and two policemen were treated for smoke inha lation. The dead woman was identified as Mrs. Betty Silber man.

title: 3 Whaling Nations to Permit Observers in the Antarctic
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29The three major whaling nations, Japan, the Soviet Union and Norway, have tentatively agreed to permit international observers abroad their whaling fleets operating in the Antarctic this season, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Kissinger Is Promoted By a Slip of the Tongue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)In a slip of the tongue, the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, referred today to the President's adviser on na tional security, Henry A. Kis singer, as Secretary of State Kissinger. He quickly cor rected himself.

title: PHASE TWO OPTIONS GO TO NIXON TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Aides to the Cost of Living Council, under the pressures of a Presidentially imposed dead line, worked tonight on options for continued restraints on the economy after the expiration of the wageprice freeze.

title: ROBERT F. BROWN, BANKING PARTNER
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 29 Robert F. Brown, a limited partner in the investment bank ing firm of Kuhn, Loeb & Co. in New York, died here today in Valley Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived here at 360 Bedford Road. He also had a winter home in Stuart, Fla.

title: New Job Program For Puerto Ricans Is Formed in City
description: Seeking to place more Puerto Ricans in middlelevel and up perlevel management jobs in the United States, the Migra tion Division of Puerto Rico's labor Department announced yesterday the formation of a rsum bank to match by computer qualified Puerto Ri cans and available jobs.

title: Colonel's CourtMartial Told Witness Was Not Prompted
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 29 (AP)A key prosecution wit ness was not prompted before he identified Col. Oran K. Hen derson as the officer to whom he had given an eyewitness ac count of atrocities at Mylai, a former Army lawyer testified today.

title: Family of 6 Depletes A $200,000 Bequest In Spending Spree
description: SAN PEDRO, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI)Instant riches came to the Leonard Gearin family two years ago in the form of a $200,000 inheritance. Today they were back where they started  We blew it, said Mrs. Gearin.

title: Eurodollar Borrowings Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  Eurodollar borrow ings by United States banks from their overseas branches rose $446million in the week ended Sept. 22, the Federal Re serve reported. The increase, which brings gross liabilities of the banks to their overseas branches to $2.14billion, fol lowed a $431million gain in the previous week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Gets Money to Reduce Rents In New Public Housing Projects
description: The allocation of more than $9million in Federal funds to reduce rents in publicly aided housing projects under con struction or planned in this re gion was announced yesterday by S. William Green, regional administrator of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Environmental Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.29 (AP) The Environmental Protection Administrator, William D. Ruck elshaus, announced today the appointment of Samuel Hale Jr., 29 years old, to head the agency's solidwaste manage ment programs. Mr. Hale has been the agency's director of special projects.

title: YANKS TURN BACK SENATORS, 6 TO 3
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 After 10,851 games, the magic number for the Washington Senators is 1. One more game tomorrow night and they can leave town.

title: DR. GEORGE WASKOVICH
description: Dr. George Waskovich, pro fessor emeritus of history at Hunter College, died yesterday at his home, 469 Ninth Street, Brooklyn. He was 75 years old.

title: Bridge: New YorkNew Jersey Event Starts at Swan Lake Today
description: Many New York enthusi asts will take their first op portunity of the new season to earn red and gold master points at the regional cham pionships of the New York New Jersey Conference. Com petition begins today at the Stevensville Country Club, Swan Lake, N.Y. with the following schedule:

title: Pope Asks Refugee Relief
description: ROME, Sept. 29 (UPI)Pope Paul VI called today for a worldwide effort to relieve the plight of an estimated eight million East Pakistanis who have fled to India in the wake of civil war and natural disas ters. He addressed members of the International Catholic Commission on Migration, who called on him during a confer ence in Rome.

title: COALITION SOUGHT BY PUERTO RICANS
description: The first steps have been taken to organize a national coalition of Spanishspeaking Americans intended to achieve greater recognition of their numbers and their needs. Gov ernment estimates put their numbers at 16 million, 8 per cent of the population.

title: Advertising:
description: Another free magazine for physicians (a favorite up scale target audience) has made the scene and it is differ erent from most others in several respects. For one thing, it has nothing to do with medicine, for another it is going to only 100,000 heavy prescription writers who are both members and nonmembers of the American Medical Asso ciation. For still another thing, the quarterly started out as a public relations program that Edward Gottlieb & Associates undertook for USV Pharmaceutical.

title: French and Russians Will Join In Psychiatric Research Effort
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28A prom inent Paris psychiatrist dis closed here today that an agreement had been reached between French and Soviet in stitutions on what is believed to be the first EastWest pro gram of joint research in men tal health.

title: U.S. Aides Seek to Calm Fears Over Chemical PCB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Leading Federal food, health and environmental officials sought today to calm public concern over the possible haz ards of PCB, the chemical con taminant akin to DDT.

title: U.S Grants 2Year Delay On Safety Air Bag in Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Automobile manufacturers won a twoyear delay today for the installation of air bags or com parable passive restraints in new passenger cars.

title: News Program Not Shown
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 29 (AP) Canton television failed to deliver its promised important news program today, disap pointing Western observers who hoped to get a clue to recent unusual events in China.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PROFIT MARK SET BY GENERAL TIRE
description: The General Tire and Rub ber Company observed its 56th anniversary yesterday by re porting record earnings for the third fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 31, and the second highest earnings for the ninemonth pe riod.

title: Screen: 'The Last Movie':Hopper Cast as a Mythic Film Cowboy in Work He Directed in Peru
description: Dennis Hopper's independently made first film, "Easy Rider," was the definitive road picture of the 1960'sbeautiful, cool and numbingly inarticulate, a myth on a motorcycle looking for an American that was not there. It also was so financially successful that its director won what is often (though loosely) called the artistic freedom with which to make his second, "The Last Movie," with the backing of a major studio.The new film, which opened yesterday at the R.K.O. 59th Street Twin Theater, was judged the best feature at the 1971 Venice Film Festival by the International Committee for the Diffusion of the Arts and Letters of Cinema  and I can only think that someone must be kidding. I know nothing about the committee, or its perhaps awesome mission, but its name is certainly as ornate, and as immediately meaningful as the movie on which it bestowed its prize."The Last Movie" is an extravagant mess, described by its publicity material as "an allegory concerning the destruction of innocence," in which "the naive dreams involved are the agents of death, when sophisticated games become more absurd than the mind can tolerate . . ." I don't know about anyone else, but my mind had a good deal of trouble tolerating the inflated pretensions of Hopper, who, it's now apparent, is gifted with all of the insights of a weekend mystic who drives to and from his retreat in a Jaguar.Specifically, "The Last Movie" has to do with the effect that a Hollywood movie company has on the Indian inhabitants of a small Peruvian village, high in the Andes, during and after the production of a potboiler about Billy the Kid. It's also about a mythic movie cowboy named Kansas (Hopper), who stays on after the filming and, like the Indians, so loses sight of reality that he finds himself believing the situation as the Indians set about pretending to film a sort of Western movie Passion Play, with Hopper as you-know-who.The film jumps forwards and backwards, and in and out of fantasies, as well as the surface movie, the movie-within-the-movie and the pretend movie, with such nervous desperation that it makes Norman Mailer's "Maidstone," which also has a reality hang-up, look as classically structured as Buuel's "Tristana."Unlike Mailer, who does have a way with words (which are, after all, the things out of which ideas are constructed), Hopper has a very small vocabulary as a filmmaker, and his thoughts here have all of the impact of revelations written down during an acid trip.When, occasionally, coherence threatens, "The Last Movie" becomes bearable. There are some funny scenes of the Billy the Kid production, with Sam Fuller, the legendary but real movie director, playing the director within the film. There is also, somewhere around the middle of "The Last Movie," a beautifully satiric and sad sequence involving Kansas with an American businessman, who manufactures brooms in Peru, and the American's nasty wife (very nicely played by Julie Adams, who is, in real life, an artifact of the old Hollywood to which Hopper keeps referring).To make his "Last Movie," Hopper seems to have had the resources necessary to transport to Peru a huge Hollywood company that included, in unrecognizable bit roles, people like Peter Fonda, John Phillip Law, Severn Darden, Jim Mitchum and Dean Stockwell. They must have had a ball, photographing each other and the local color, and I have no doubt that fantasy and reality did become confused, at least to the extent that "The Last Movie" itself comes to look every bit as indulgent, cruel and thoughtless as the dream factory films it makes such ponderous fun of.Hopper's movie troupe also included the talented Laszlo Kovacs, whose camerawork was one of the best things about "Easy Rider." As a result, "The Last Movie" has enough visual style to suggest that it really does have something on its mind. That, however, turns out to be just another fantasy.

title: VIOLENT CRIMES UP 11% IN NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  Violent crime increas ed 11 per cent in this country during the first half of 1971, outpacing a 7 per dent rise in all serious crime, the Federal Bureau of Investigation report ed today.

title: Jersey Acts to Save Huge Tract From Commercial Developing
description: TRENTON, Sept. 29  Com missioner Richard J. Sullivan of New Jersey's Department of Environmental Protection an nounced today a tentative agreement that would prevent a vast tract of mountainous wilderness, owned by an ar dent conservationist in north ern New Jersey from falling into the hands of commercial developers.

title: U.S. Seeks to Repay Concerns for Losses In Cyclamate Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Nixon Administra tion told Congress today that industries should be repaid the $100million to $120million in losses they estimate they suf fered by a Government ban two years ago on use of cyclamates.

title: Western Air Buying 4 Jets From McDonnell Douglas
description: Western Air Lines announced yesterday it had ordered four DC10 trijets from the McDon nell Douglas Corporation for delivery in April, June and July of 1973.

title: $30Million Suit Accuses United Utilities in Kansas
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) An antitrust action seeking some $30million in damages has been filed in the Federal District Court here against Unit ed Utilities, Inc., of suburban Westwood, Kan.

title: Seymour Urges Penalty for All Who Violate Defendants' Rights
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr. sug gested yesterday that criminals should not be set free solely because their constitutional rights had been violated by il legal searches, wiretaps or other abuses.

title: Advertising:
description: Life magazine, as of the Sept. 14 issue, is off 89 pages of advertising for the year from last year's 1,335. Read er's Digest, up to the Novem ber issue, has 1,001 pages, an increase of 103 over that pe riod of 1970.

title: Cholera in India Is Fatal To 5,805 Bengali Refugees
description: GENEVA, Sept. 29. (UPI) Cholera has killed 5,805 East Pakistani refugees in India, the World Health Organization said today. There have been 46,469 cases of the disease among the Bengali refugees, whose number is now estimated by India to be nine million.

title: LOW DRAFT CALL EXPECTED TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Resuming the draft after a threemonth lapse, the Penta gon will announce tomorrow a new induction quota that will leave 1971 callups at the low est annual total in nearly a decade.

title: MRS. HARDWICK NEVIN
description: WILTON, Corm., Sept. 29 Mrs. Edna Hoyt Nevin, widow of Hardwick Nevin, poet and playwright who died in 1965, died today at the age of 69 in Norwalk Hospital.

title: Pepsice Chief, Meeting With Sato, Rules Out Unilateral Action
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29A former mediator in the JapanUnited States textile dispute met with Prime Minister Eisaku Sato to day but said later that the tex tile issue did not come up in their discussions.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES EVE DOWNWARD
description: Short covering helped to trim a decline of two to four cents a bushel in the trading of soy bean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The futures closed  cent to 2 cents lower.

title: Clash in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 29 (AP) Two fights broke out today among black and white pupils at Grover Cleveland High School and officials shut down the school after the second out break.

title: Dublin Parliament Recalled
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 29The Irish Parliament will be recalled from its summer recess to de bate the situation in Northern Ireland.

title: Minisub to Study Dumping Area Off Sandy Hook
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The dumping place of a lot of New York City's sewage sludge and other waste from the met ropolitan area will be studied at close range tomorrow by two scientists in a minisubma rine.

title: Hirohito Hailed at Start of Belgian Visit
description: BRUSSELS. Sept. 29Em poror Hirohito received an elaborate and festive official welcome today as he arrived in Brussels.

title: End of Jersey City Boss Rule
description: The corruption  infested Democratic organization that has maintained an iron rule over Hudson County for a halfcentury has decided to relinquish without a fight its grip on Jersey City, power center of its empire.

title: Fulbright Seeks PurseString Power
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tried a new ap proach today in its struggle with, the executive branch by proposing a legislative restraint on the State Department's budget.

title: MRS. SARA SCHIFFER, BENNINGTON TRUSTEE
description: Mrs. Sara Jane Troy Schif fer, a trustee of Bennington College since 1962, died yester day in Memorial Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived at 333 East 57th Street with her husband, Dr. Morton A. Schif fer, director of obstretrics and gynecology at Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brook lyn and a clinical professor at the State University's Down state Medical Center.

title: Cardinal's Rejection of a Deal Termed Key to Delay in Release
description: WARSAW, Sept. 29A guide was taking a group of Western tourists through a Budapest cathedral a few weeks ago and mentioned that it was Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty's church. She was asked why he was not permitted to leave the United States Embassy 15 years after taking refuge there.

title: Humphrey Bill Would Give Free School Lunch to All
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has introduced legislation that would provide free daily meals to all elementary and high school pupils, regardless of their ability to pay.

title: Padres Win, 41 Colbert Hits Homer in 10th
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 29A 10thinning home run by Nate Colbert gave the San Diego, Padres a 41 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight, but the Giants backed into a tie for the Western champion ship of the National League when the secondplace Dodgers also lost in Los Angeles, 125 miles north.

title: 2 Accused by Union of Price Violations
description: Spotless Stores, Inc., dry cleaners, and Horn and Hardart retail bakeries were accused yesterday by a union monitor ing the price freeze of raising their prices in defiance of President Nixon's executive order.

title: Thieu Bids Police Shoot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29  President Nguyen Van Thieu told the National Police today that they might shoot down anyone who at tempts to burn vehicles in the streets.

title: Stanton Says F.C.C. Pressure Jeopardizes Coverage of News
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, charged today that the Federal Government was intensifying its regulatory pressures and jeopardizing independent radio and television news.

title: Friend's Book Describes T. S. Eliot's 1st Marriage
description: T. S. Eliot's first marriage, to Vivienne Haigh, was broken up in 1932 in part on the advice of his Anglo Catholic spiritual counselors, according to a biographical memoir of the poet to be pub lished next month. The book, T. S. Eliot: A Memoir, was written by Robert Sencourt, a British literary critic who was Eliot's close friend from 1927 until his death in 1965. Mr. Sencourt died two years ago.

title: TOMMY MERCER HERE WITH BAND
description: Tommy Mercer who could qualify as the last of the big time band singers, has finally emerged from the boy singer role and is leading a band of his own at the Riverboat, Fifth Avenue at 34th Street.

title: G.M. STILL UNDECIDED ON FRIGIDAIRE MOVE
description: The General Motors Corpora tion has advised its supervisory employes in the Dayton, Ohio, area that no decision has been made yet to move its Frigidaire division operations.

title: Canadiens Tie Rangers, 33, On a Goal With 0:58 Left
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 29 (AP)Yvan Cournoyer's goal with 58 seconds remaining gave the Montreal Canadiens a 33 tie with the New York Rangers tonight in a National Hockey League preseason game.

title: LOQUACIOUS DON FIRST IN COWDIN
description: A crowd of 28,415 found it difficult to pick a favorite from among five of the nine start ers in yesterday's $68,000 Cow din at Belmont Park. But when the sevenfurlong fixture for 2yearolds had been complet ed, the people's choice was first.

title: Highway Is Objective
description: TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 30A large allied counteroffensive was re portedly begun yesterday, against North Vietnamese forces along the Cambodian border near here in the hope of preventing them from inter fering with South Vietnam's Presidential election on Sunday.

title: FEWER IN U.S. VIEW CHINA AS BIG MENACE
description: Fewer Americans now than four years ago regard Com munist China as the chief threat to world peace, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Prices of Commodities Greatly Depressed by Monetary Crisis
description: PARIS, Sept. 29The world monetary crisis is having a de pressing effect on international commodity prices.

title: Palmer of Jets Breaks 7 Ribs in Auto Accident
description: The New York Jets, already seriously handicapped by inju ries to Joe Namath, Matt Snell and Steve Tannen, suffered still another blow Tuesday night.

title: Delegation From Peking Lands In Paris for Trade Discussions
description: PARIS, Sept. 29A Chinese governmental mission arrived here today for a friendly visit that was expected to place ma jor emphasis on trade rela tions.

title: Out to Debunk the Motherhood Myth
description: The National Commission on Population Growth and the American Future has been told that destruction of the motherhood myth is essential to conquering the population problem.

title: Jackson Believes He Must Win Florida Primary or Forget Presidential Bid
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 29 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, who plans to an nounce his Presidential candi dacy before Christmas, has no doubt about the alternatives facing him: Win the Florida primary or forget the White House.

title: Cash Controller Is Named For a Unit of Chemalloy
description: Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., said in Toronto yesterday that a temporary receiver had been appointed by the Ontario Su preme Court for the purpose of controlling the cash flow of the Tantalum Mining Corporation, a subsidiary of Chemalloy, pend ing the outcome of litigation between the General Host Cor poration and Tantalum Mining.

title: Hurricane Is Heading For Coast of Carolina
description: CAPE LOOKOUT, N. C., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Hurricane Ginger stirred galeforce winds and high seas along North Carolina's Outer Banks today as the main body of the storm headed for an expected landfall with 80mileanhour winds tomorrow.

title: U.S. Won't Deny Missouri Federal Welfare Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare an nounced today that it would not withhold $8.7million a year in Federal welfare administra tion payments from Missouri.

title: OKKER ADVANCES IN COAST TENNIS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP)  Tom Okker of the Netherlands and Marty Riessen of Chicago were pushed to three sets today to gain the third round of the $50,000 Red wood Bank international open tennis tournament.

title: Satellite Is Launched Into Earth Orbit to Monitor the Solar Corona
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 29A sun watch satellite was launched into an orbit of the earth today in an experiment to monitor the outer atmos phere, flares, nuclear furnaces and other phenomena of the sun.

title: Trustees of Pennsy Got Bid for Hotels in Spring
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transporation Com pany as early as last spring had received an offer of $100million for four of the railroad's midtownManhat tan hotels: the Barclay, Bilt more, Commodore and Roose velt.

title: California Democrats Greet Lindsay Politely as Trip Ends, but Some Question His Grasp of State's Issues
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 Welcome to the party said the invitations to a state Dem ocratic party reception for Mayor Lindsay in the glittering penthouse of Melvin Belli, a fantasy setting with red velvet draperies, ankledeep white carpeting and a sweeping view of the city and San Francisco Bay.

title: Medina to Work for Bailey At Michigan Copter Concern
description: Capt. Ernest L. Medina, ac quitted last week of charges stemming from the Mylai slay ings, said last night that he expected to be discharged from the Army very shortly and would go to work at a heli copter manufacturing concern in upstate Michigan owned by F. Lee Bailey, the lawyer.

title: St. Louis U. Wins in Soccer
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (UPI) The No. 1 ranked St. Louis Uni versity soccer team stretched its undefeated streak to 33 games today with a 60 victory over McMurray College of Jacksonville, Ill. The National Collegiate champions have not been defeated in three years.

title: A DEVICE TO BLOCK HIJACKING SHOWN
description: MIAMI, Sept. 29A new, ad vanced device to prevent the hijacking of airplanes was dem onstrated at the Miami Inter national Airport today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: An Antelope Hunter Is Led Astray
description: LANDER, Wyo.High in the snowcovered foothills of Wyoming's Wind River Mountains, a Lander rancher, Jack Brodie, crouched, then waved for me to approach. Peering over a rock, I saw a herd of antelope 150 yards away.

title: STATE D.A.R. URGES STRONGER MILITARY
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 29Five hundred members of the New York State Daughters of the American Revolution met here today for the start of their threeday 75th annual state conference and heard an urgent plea that the United States re tain or rebuild, if necessary strong military posture, cap able of defending us against all enemies.

title: Pan Am to Match Rivals On Fares Over Atlantic
description: Pan American World Air ways announced yesterday that, beginning Feb. 1, it would match the new lower fares to Europe previously announced by other airlines that belong to the International Air Transport Association.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Backs Israeli Loan
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)  The ExportImport Bank of the United States said it was guar anteeing a loan for $5.4million so that Israel can purchase three big gas turbine generator units.

title: Federal Addict Program Is Called a Total Failure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)  An expert in the treat ment and rehabilitation of drug addicts said today that the Fed eral Government's main effort to deal with the problem was a total failure.

title: PEKING WILL HOLD RECEPTION TODAY
description: PEKING, Sept. 29 (Reuters) The Chinese Foreign Ministry said today that a reception would be given tomorrow by the Foreign Ministry in the Great Hall of the People on Tienanmen Square. The recep tion replaces the traditional banquet held on the eve of the anniversary of the Communist Government.

title: Politicizing the B. L. S.?
description: Few agencies in or out of Government have a more distinguished record for objectivity and integrity than the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Instead of rep resenting the bureau's most Prized adornment, that quality of scholary detachment seems to have become a liability in the present Administration.

title: Skelton Leaves Greece
description: ATHENS, Sept. 29 (AP) John Skelton, a 26yearold American who received a sus pended sentence of seven months at a special courtmar tial, flew to Rome today on the first leg of his trip home. He was convicted of participation in a plot to help a man who tried to assassinate the Greek. Premier in escape from prison. Four others, including Lady Fleming, widow of the discov erer of penicillin, were also ??ovicted, receiving jail terms of 13 to 16 months.

title: Penguins Tie Sabres, 44
description: SUDBURY, Ontario, Sept. 29 (AP)Nick Harbaruck scored with 18 seconds remaining to night to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 44 tie with the Buffalo Sabres in a National Hockey League preseason game.

title: Executive Changes
description: Montgomery Ward & Co. announced the ap pointment of Harold F. Dysart as executive vice president of operations, and the promotion of five other officers to corporate vice presidents by action of the company's executive committee. The new corporate vice presidents, who have served as divi sional vice presidents since 1967, and who also will serve on the company's management committee, are: Robert V. Guelich, William J. Harbeck, Dean Lewis, Herman A. Nater and Richard C. Scheidt.

title: George Garrett, 83, ExEnvoy And Investment Banker, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  George Angus Garrett, former United States Ambassador to Ireland and an investment banker, died of a heart attack at his home here this morn ing, after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: CORPORATE BONDS REBOUND SHARPLY
description: The corporate bond market came to life in a flurry of ac tivity late yesterday, and prices rose sharply.

title: Pope Assails Decadent Critics
description: ROME, Sept. 29 (UPI)Pope Paul said today that the church was under attack by deca dent critics, He drew a round of applause at his weekly gen eral audience when he said there was a widespread criti cal, protesting and impatient frame of mind that is basically decadent and barren of admi ration, enthusiasm and love for the church and thus also of a sense of joy and sacrifice.

title: State G.O.P. Undecided on When to Reapportion Senate and Assembly Districts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  New York Republican leaders have tentatively decided to put off drawing the state's new Congressional districts until early next year instead of try ing to redraw both Congres sional and legislative districts at a special session of the Leg islature in December.

title: Susquehanna Change
description: The Susquehanna Corpora tion announced yesterday that Emmett H. Bradley has re signed as executive vice presi dent, a director and member of the executive committee. The diversified company said that Mr. Bradley had resigned for personal reasons and that the parting was amicable.

title: Kansas Inmates Eat
description: LANSING, Kan., Sept. 29 (UPI)Inmates of the Kansas State Penitentiary, some of whom had not eaten since Sun day night, left their cells today and ate breakfast, apparently ending a halfhearted protest over the quality of prison food.

title: General Medical in Deal
description: The General Medical Corpo ration said yesterday it had agreed to buy the assets of the biomedicalsystems department of the Hamilton Standard divi sion of the United Aircraft Cor poration for cash. The amount of the transaction was not dis closed.

title: Vermont Disturbance
description: WINDSOR, Vt., Sept. 29 (AP)Warden Robert G. Smith met with four inmates of Windsor State Prison late today following what he called a minor disturbance in side the 163yearold facility.

title: U.S. Acts to Spread Subsidized Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today proposed policy guide lines intended to disperse sub sidized housing in metro politan areas.

title: Texans, With 115, Set Pace After 2 Rounds in ProAm
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Sept. 29 (AP)  The Inwood Forest Club of Texas carded a 57 to day for a total of 115 after two rounds to lead the team compe tition in the international pro amateur golf tournament.

title: EISSTROM FIRST IN SOLING EVENT
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 29 Paul Elvstrom of Hellerup, Denmark, rated in many circles as the world's greatest racing sailor, found today's 12to15 knot swinging southwesterly winds to his liking as he won the fourth race in the world Soling Class championship on Long Island Sound.

title: The Ultimate in Pennant Suspense?
