description: If the GiantDodger race for the Western Division title goes to the final day, it will be the 10th time in the last 26 years that the National League has enjoyed this ulti mate in pennant suspense. In the same period, the American League has had only three such races. Only twice in baseball historyin 1908 and 1949have both leagues enjoyed such a finish the same year.

title: ContractLoss Provision To Cut '71 Dillingham Net
description: The Dillingham Corporation stated yesterday that it had established an additional loss provision for a major contract in which its subsidiary, Gordon H. Ball, Inc., is a 40 per cent jointventure partner. The Perini Corporation of Farmingham, Mass., is managing partner of the venture.

title: CYRUS M. HIGLEY, 77, A BANKER UPSTATE
description: NORWICH, N. Y., Sept. 29 Cyrus M. Higley, president of the Chenango County National Bank & Trust Co. here from 1939 until this year, died lyion day at the age of 77.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Giants were opening their 16th season of press luncheons at the Stadium Club and because they had for gotten to tell the Yankees' concessionaire far enough in advance, there was no dessert trailing the roast beef Indeed, a spartan year lies ahead for the club around which the point of interest is the 1975 move to New Jersey rather than the weekly games, which can make true Giants fans stiffen and shudder.

title: ExBoxer's Brother Safe, Couple Seized As His Kidnappers
description: A Dutchess County real estate investor and his wife, were ar rested in Beacon, N.Y., last night and charged with kidnap ping the brother of Tony Can zoneri, the late lightweight box ing champion.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Senator Ed Muskie is generally rated the front runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but after this ritual con cession the criticism usually begins. He does not have enough appeal to the left, or to the right (depending on the critic); his campaign is too bland; the Senator himself is too much a cen trist.

title: I.L.A. Strike Tonight Is Likely; All U.S. Ports Would Be Closed
description: The International Longshore men's Association and steve dore interests here appear to be on a collision course that could result in a shutdown of every, deepwater port in the country when the union's con tract with the New York Ship ping Association expires at midnight.

title: BOMB KILLS TWO IN A BELFAST BAR
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 29 (AP)A bomb wrecked a crowded Belfast bar tonight, killing two persons and wound ing 25.

title: French Airlines Protest TwoTier Money Market
description: PARIS, Sept. 29  French airlines have formally protested to their Government over fi nancial penalties they must pay as a result of France's two tier foreign exchange market, an airline chief said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHO PUSHED HUMPTY DUMPTY? Dilemmas in American Education Today. By Donald Barr. 341 pages. Atheneum. $10.

title: Refugee Children in India: Thousands Die
description: CALCUTTA, Sept. 29Large numbers of East Pakistani refugee children are dying every day front malnutrition and the diseases that accom pany it, and tens of thousands are seriously malnourished and facing death.

title: HANOI AND PEKING STRENGTHEN TIES
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 29A Chinese economic and military mission to North Vietnam, just completed, appears to have re inforced a recent improvement in relations.

title: The Oil Can Wait
description: President Nixon's recent statement in Anchorage about the proposed transAlaskan oil pipeline had the ring of a comment designed to mollify some of the local citizens, in haste to get on with that project, rather than to indicate a final commitment on his part to the building of the line. It promised to reconcile the exploitation of natural resources and protection of the environment without quite saying that this could be done with a pipeline carrying oil from Prudhoe Bay in the Arctic to Valdez on Alaska's southern coast.

title: Bethlehem Steel Head Foresees Industry Emerging From Slump
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (UPI) The American steel industry is preparing to move out of its current slump, Lewis W. Foy, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, told the As sociation of Iron and Steel En gineers today.

title: Film: A Real Love Story
description: That formidable chasm between sodden bathos and genuine pathos is adroitly leaped by the writer-director Bryan Forbes and a professional cast in "Long Ago Tomorrow," the British romantic drama that opened at the Beekman Theater yesterday. While they haven't created a landmark film by any means, Mr. Forbes and company have fashioned an understated but passionate portrait of young people under tragic stress that evokes real compassion, an honest tear or two and, believe it or not, a chuckle here and there.While neither the title of Peter Marshall's 1966 novel, "The Raging Moon" (under which the film was released in England), or "Long Ago Tomorrow" makes more than a poetic point, it is clear almost from the start that the film is not involved with the treacly banalities of soap opera as is, say, the movies' classic example of the genre, "Love Story."This is, simply, a love story involving two paraplegics: Bruce, a working-class, brash, womanizing type felled by a football injury, and Jill, an upper-middle-class doctor's daughter. The two, imprisoned in wheelchairs in an institution, face a forbidding future with consummate bravery.As noted, Mr. Forbes and his principals have not come up with stereotypes. As portrayed by Nanette Newman (Mrs. Forbes in private life), Jill, struggling to free her reluctant but dutiful fianc from his obligation to her, is vibrantly touching as a woman experiencing love for the first time.Her courtship with Malcolm McDowell as the brusque, iconoclastic Bruce, who has begun to express himself in poetry and letters, is a touching (and funny) affair, approached with seeming casualness. In the process, the two enliven the drab existence of the other incapacitated residents.Mr. McDowell is both defiantly belligerent and gentle, a believable, once-rugged male suddenly and helplessly involved with love he desperately wants to fulfill but can't. Miss Newman is tender, adult and feminine as the ill-fated Jill, who briefly finds joy in his poignant affection. They are abetted by some solid vignettes from Georgia Brown, the song belter of "Oliver!", as an understanding staff member, and Geoffrey Whitehead as Mr. McDowell's square but loving brother.Touching on one small aspect of the human condition, "Long Ago Tomorrow" is a subdued but authentically moving view of unusual but real people and a real love story.

title: No Turf for Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP) The Atlanta Stadium Authority, after hearing opposition from its two major tenants, decided today against installing artifi cial turf.

title: BABY LENORE APPEAL IS LOST BY MOTHER
description: MIAMI, Sept. 29The third District Court of Appeals today upheld a lower court decision that permitted Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino to retain possession of the infant who has come to be known as Baby Lenore.

title: Politics Denied in Labor Agency Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Nixon Administration dis claimed political motives today in undertaking a major reor ganization of Federal agencies that gather and issue economic and social statistics.

title: Pacific Northwest Bell Lags
description: The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company reported yesterday a decline in net in come for the three months end ed Aug. 31 despite higher op erating revenues. The company, which is 89.2 per cent owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, placed thirdquarter earnings at $11, 332,000, or 30 cents a share, against $12,189,000, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Net op erating revenues rose to $115, 540,000 from $110,734,000 in the like period of 1970.

title: Big Allis Back at Work After 5Hoar Shutdown
description: Can Edison's Big Allis, the utility's millionkilowatt generator, which provides oneeighth of the city's elec trical power, was back in op eration early yesterday after a fivehour shutdown. There had been no service disrup tion.

title: Blast Kills One in British Sub
description: PORTLAND, England, Sept. 29 (AP)  A Royal Navy sea man was killed and 14 others were injured today in an ex plosion aboard the submarine Alliance, tied up alongside a pier at Portland naval base. The navy said the main battery of the 26yearold conventional submarine had blown up while most of the men aboard were asleep. The submarine is sched uled to be withdrawn from service next year.

title: Nixon Reported Unlikely To Pick Woman Justice
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  Officials of the Nixon, Admin istration are passing the word that the President will probably not nominate a woman to the Supreme Court to fill either of the two present vacancies.

title: CUTS IN MEDICAID PUT INTO EFFECT
description: Drastic state cuts in both eligibility and benefits under the statewide, Medicaid pro gram for the sick poor have been ordered implemented ef fective immediately by the State Department of Social Services.

title: Aux Armes, Citoyens!
description: PARIS, Sept. 29 (Reuters) The parking meter has arrived in Paris. City authorities is sued a formal decree today for the installation of the first meters starting next week in the Rue de Rivoli on the Right Bank. Drivers will have to pay a dime for 30 minutes.

title: PAKISTAN AT U.N. ASKS INDIA TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 29Pakistan today asked India from the rostrum of the United Nations General Assem bly to agree to direct negotia tions or talks under impartial auspices on the problem, of East Pakistani refugees on In dian territory.

title: NIXON CRITICIZES A GROWING MOVE TO ISOLATIONISM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 President Nixon strongly criti cized today growing and dis turbing isolationism in our country as he defended the United States economic meas ures that have created at least temporary monetary turmoil in the world.

title: Glassboro Imposes Curfew After Averting 2d High School Clash
description: GLASSBORO, N. J., Sept. 29 Borough authorities today clamped an 8 P. M. curfew on the 900 highschool students here after the police arrested a total of 20 persons, in cluding 13 students, in an ef fort to end disorders in the high school that began yester day.

title: Eight Indicted in Texas in Federal Banking Inquiry
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 29 (AP)A Federal grand jury investigat ing the collapse of a state bank controlled by Frank W. Sharp, a Texas promoter, in dicted eight men today, includ ing four former bank exam iners.

title: SENATE REFUSES TO SLASH FUNDS FOR ABM AND F14
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 29  The Senate refused today to stop deployment of the Safe guard antiballistic missile sys tem and approved continued production of the Navy's F14 interceptor plane.

title: 3Day Registering Starts Today For Voters 18 to 20 Years Old
description: Polling places in New York City and its suburbs will open today for a threeday voter registration that is likely to be the last chance for youths in the 18to20year group to qualify for New York's Presi dential primary next June.

title: News of Dogs
description: DORADO, P.R.It had been predicted that Hurri cane Ginger would cause torrential rains last Sunday when the PuertoRico Kennel Club staged its 16th allbreed show on the grounds of the Dorado Beach Hotel.

title: KnittedFabric Maker Expanding to Higher Ground
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.In 1955, Fairtex Mills, Inc., then a nine yearold manufacturer of knit ted fabrics, was almost wiped out in a flood that caused the Catasauqua Creek to rise and flow through the concern's two plants. Twelve 40foot refrig erated trucks were required to transport the wet yarn to dry ing plants in Virginia before the knitting company could re sume operations. This took a week, but it took the company a year to regain its financial footing.

title: Excello Is Closing a Plant Due to Lag in Aerospace
description: LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 29 (AP) The Excello Corporation is phasing out one of its plants because of a lack of business in the aerospace industry.

title: Shop Talk
description: The ethnic overtones pervading Altman's 14 model rooms, opening today on the store's seventh floor, are al most always exotic and occasionally ersatz. Take, for instance, the interpretation by Elaine Eisen, the store's home furnishings coordinator, of how an East Indian bed andbath suite might look transplanted here. Hung from the bathroom ceiling is a glit tering brass swing ($400) that is enriched with sculpted ele phants and pea cocks. Below it is an 8footsquare, tiled, pool  like tub (the tiles for such a tub are $500), patterned with temple motifs and Indian maidens. At the windows are screens that may look like pierced wood but are, in fact, molded plastic. At the doorway hang yards and yards of sheer muslin. And furnishing the sleeping area are painted pierced wood furnishings that include a headboard ($595), mirror ($199) and Victorian  looking chair ($219).

title: Blackout Hits Bergen
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 30A massive electrical black out throughout northeastern Bergen County this morning cut off power for more than 75,000 residents, the Bergen County police said. Power was out from 1:40 A.M. to 2:05 A.M. in the area, which includes Hacken sack, Englewood, Teaneck, and Fort Lee. The cause of the blackout was not immediately known.

title: 2,500 Soviet Jews Mark The Massacre at Babi Yar
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (UPI) About 2,500 Jews from all over the Soviet Union gathered in Kiev today to observe the 30th anniversary of the Babi Yar massacre, Jewish sources said.

title: Wilkins Gets Award
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, received the first an nual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Humanitarian Award today. It was presented by Operation Breadbasket on the first day of the exposition.

title: Reserve Postpones Start Of Margin Amendments
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board announced today it has postponed until Dec. 1 the ef fective date of proposed regu latory amendments that would set forth conditions under which credit may be obtained without regard to margin re quirements for the purpose of providing capital to broker dealer firms.

title: Petroleum Executive Leaves
description: The Great Basins Petroleum Company, Los Angeles, an nounced yesterday that R. G. Greene, senior chairman of the board, has resigned effective Sept. 30, to pursue personal business. Mr. Greene, 72 years old, was president of Great Ba sins from 1956 until 1967, when he was elected chairman. In May, 1971, he became senior chairman.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  An outbreak of cholera in Kuala Lumpur was confirmed today with the death of one person and another case ad mitted to a hospital in serious condition. A cholera innocula tion campaign has been started.

title: Soviet Mission Neighbors in the Middle
description: To many residents of 67th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, the block has become occupied terri tory in an international war in which they are the inno cent victims.

title: ABomb Tested in Desert
description: MERCURY, Nev., Sept. 29 (AP)A lowyield atomic bomb was detonated under the Ne vada desert today, the Atomic Energy Commission said, add ing that no radiation had leaked into the atmosphere. The test shot had the force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT, approxi mately the force of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima in World War II, the AEC said.

title: Crash Kills Yugoslav Envoy
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  Radivoj Uvalic, Yougoslavia's new Am bassador to India, was killed in an accident yesterday near Gorgan, Iran, while driving to his post, the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported today.

title: Art Theft in Yugoslavia
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Seven paintings, including a Rembrandt and an El Greco and valued at about $325,000, were stolen from an art gallery in this town in northwestern Yugoslavia, the police said today. The theft was described as the biggest of its kind in Yugoslavia since World War II. Police said the robbery occurred last week.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29  This nightmare began developing about two weeks ago with the onset of the fall advertising season when the news paper ads began to fill up with men wearing $200 suits.

title: Huey Newton in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 29 (Agence France  Presse) The American Black Panther leader Huey Newton arrived in Peking today on a visit to China. He was accompanied by Elaine Brown, an information officer of the Black Panther party, and Robert Bay identified in reports from the United States as a bodyguard.

title: Wine Lover Who Scorns All That Fuss
description: More useless words have been written on wine than on any other subject, with the possible exception of sex.

title: And Now, Sports Fans, the F.S.C.
description: Squabbles on the professional sport ing scene involving matters of high (and low) finance and some finer points of contract law lead me to speak brazenly out in a desperate at tempt to bring the sporting element back into sports.
